HEADLINE: Industrial Output Up in June for a 3d Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities climbed seven-tenths of a percent in June, the third straight sizable advance, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Although analysts had expected such an increase, the gain was greeted by economists with some relief, after a Government report on Friday of a surprising decline in retail sales in June. 
 "This certainly confirms even further that the recession's over," said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank North America. He noted that the economy was getting "a lot of thrust" from automobile and truck production, which hit an annual rate of nine million in June. But the rise in the index of industrial production was broadly based and was up six-tenths of a percent even when motor vehicles were excluded.
The Fed's report also showed that industry again stepped up its operating rate last month, to 79.3 percent, three-tenths of a point above the May level.
Bond prices remained largely unaffected by today's figures, which had been foreshadowed by the Labor Department's report 10 days ago of a sharp expansion in the workweek.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said business inventories posted a broad decline of five-tenths of a percent in May, the fourth decline in a row and an indication that production would need to be stepped up to still higher rates if demand climbed. The report also said that business sales rose by 1 percent.
"People are selling out of inventory because demand is so strong," said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at the First Boston Corporation.
In addition to rising seven-tenths of a percent in June, to an index level of 106.9, industrial production was revised upward for the two preceding months. May's gain is now put at seven-tenths of a percent instead of the five-tenths initially estimated, while April's was raised to five-tenths of a percent, from three-tenths.
Although the figures published today cover only one-third of the economy, industrial output is intently watched because its components are generally those that are most susceptible to business cycle ups and downs. Much of the balance is accounted for by services.
For the second quarter, output rose at a 1.7 percent annual pace after falling steeply in the first quarter of 1991 and the fourth quarter of 1990 at rates of 9.7 percent and 7 percent, respectively. Still, production last month was down 2.9 percent from a year earlier.
Among consumer goods, output of such nonautomotive durables as appliances, furniture and carpeting rose markedly for the fourth straight month, but the Fed said output of nondurable consumer goods has risen only slightly in recent months.
Output of nonautomotive business equipment, which fell over the fall and winter, rose slightly in April and was unchanged in May and June, the Fed noted. Production of construction supplies, steel, textiles and paper rose sharply.
 
Gain in Manufacturing
 In manufacturing, the June advance was seven-tenths of a percent compared with five-tenths in May, with durable goods up eight-tenths and nondurables up six-tenths. Mining output rose 1.5 percent, aided in part by a rebound in coal. Utilities registered a drop of five-tenths of a percent, but this was considered minimal since it followed a 3.9 percent jump in May that reflected exceptionally hot weather that raised demand for air-conditioning.
With today's report the Fed began publishing a set of indexes showing, with one-month lags, the percentage of industries with production increases over the latest one-month, three-month and six-month periods. The three-month index of output reached 50 percent in May, up from 41.6 percent in April and from a recession low of 27.7 percent calculated for January.
Before seasonal adjustment, today's report also showed, industrial production rose 4.2 percent in June, to 108.7 percent of its 1987 average.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Industrial Production" shows index of total industrial production from Jan. 1990 to June 1991. (Source: Commerce Department); "Capacity Utilization" shows total output as a percentage of capacity from Jan. 1990 to June 1991. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)(pg. D8)

HEADLINE: NCR Profits Are Off 13.9%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, July 15

 BODY:
Lower international orders and the recession resulted in reduced second-quarter revenue and a 13.9 percent profit decline at the NCR Corporation, the computer company said today. The company attributed the decline in orders to the stronger dollar.
NCR, which agreed in May to merge with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said profit for the three months ended June 30 totaled $99 million, or $1.51 a share, compared with a record $115 million, or $1.66 a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. 
 Per-share earnings in the latest quarter were reduced by 5 cents because of special charges of $6 million related to the pending merger.
Revenue totaled $1.57 billion, down 2.5 percent from a record $1.61 billion a year earlier.
"The decline in worldwide orders was broad-based across most major product lines," said Charles E. Exley Jr., chairman and chief executive. "The continued U.S. recession, together with the weakening business environment in Europe, were major contributors to our disappointing order results in the second quarter. These poor business conditions, coupled with the stronger U.S. dollar, make it unlikely that we will achieve the record levels of revenue and earnings per share attained in 1990."
The merger is pending approval by Government regulators and by NCR's shareholders at a meeting planned for the fall.

HEADLINE: The Bank Merger;
For New York, A Loss of Jobs And Revenues

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
The merger of Chemical Bank with Manufacturers Hanover may make a lot of banking sense, because the two weak banks, by combining, have a chance to emerge as a stronger, more vibrant lending institution.
But for New York City and other communities, this merger and the larger consolidation in the banking industry will bring a lot of pain as institutions slim down, trying to determine the number of branches and employees that will make them more profitable and bring them into the new banking era. 
 In the near term, however, the merger of the Chemical Banking Corporation with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation means the loss to New York City of as many as 5,900 jobs, fewer tax dollars paid to a revenue-starved city and 70 branches and untold office space coming onto an already-glutted property market.
 
Industry Shrinking Faster
 The merger also signals a quickening in the pace of the banking industry's shrinkage -- a process that many analysts said was just beginning to get under way in New York City. While analysts think that Citicorp still has a lot of cost savings it can gain from simply streamlining its own operations, others looked to banking companies like Chase Manhattan, Marine Midland Banks and Bank of New York as potential merger candidates.
New York has long been home to some of the nation's largest and most prominent banking organizations. But a combination of soured loans to third world countries, greater competition for bread-and-butter corporate lending, and newcomers invading their turf from regional cities and abroad have made these titans' futures precarious.
Many banking analysts and economists viewed yesterday's merger announcement as just the beginning of a wave of consolidation. Indeed, Deputy Mayor Sally Hernandez-Pinero said yesterday that at a Gracie Mansion breakfast earlier this year, top bankers were in universal agreement that there would be more than one mega-merger before the year was out.
"I was shocked," said Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, who nonetheless admitted to being impressed that two such stalwarts in an industry known for its conservatism would finally decide to take such a painful step to insure their long-term survival.
 
Another Blow to City's Jobs
 A new round of layoffs in the banking industry will hit the city just as the well-publicized contraction on Wall Street seems finally to be abating. Although the banking and brokerage industries have each lost about 10,000 jobs in the last 12 months, the pace of those losses in the brokerage industry has slowed to a monthly rate of about several hundred in recent months, while those in the banking industry are running at about 1,000 a month.
"The banking industry's job losses will continue into the next year," said Rae D. Rosen, senior economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. She said she expected the local recession to continue into 1992, with the economy showing no sign of growth until 1993 or 1994.
Coming on top of the 6,300 pink slips that were recently handed out to city employees, and the several thousand jobs that are expected to be cut from the Pan Am Corporation, this latest announcement is certainly not good news for the city.
 
Calls to Governor and Mayor
 In recognition of how important this development is to the local economy, John F. McGillicuddy, the chairman of Manufacturers Hanover, called Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York early yesterday, while Chemical's chairman, Walter V. Shipley, called Mayor David N. Dinkins. The response, Mr. McGillicuddy said, was not surprising.
"No politician likes to hear about job cuts," he said at a news conference later in the day.
The merger is expected to result in the loss of about 6,200 jobs, 95 percent of them in New York City. Those figures could be reduced still further, depending on the rate of attrition at the two banks over the coming months.
Although some senior-level jobs are likely to be lost because of the consolidation of overlapping administrative functions, most of the cuts are expected to come from the banks' clerical ranks and back-office workers. And that could have important social consequences.
 
Minorities and Women Affected
 "Over half of the jobs in banks are clerical, and in the past they have provided a significant source of upward mobility for minority employees, and especially women," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Aside from the job losses, New Yorkers will likely notice the closing or sale of 70 bank branches, which will be concentrated in Manhattan, especially downtown. There will be no closings of Chemical's branches in New Jersey or Texas.
Bank executives yesterday gave no specifics on which branches in New York City would be closed, and little detail about what criteria they would use, although they gave assurances that no neighborhood would be left bereft. The New York State Superintendent of Banks, Derrick D. Cephas, who has been on the job for one week, said that his department would have some contribution to the final decision-making process.
He noted that the closing of a branch that was next door to another branch would not matter, but that if there were only one branch in a neighborhood, "we would certainly take a different view," he said.
 
First and Third in Serving City
 According to a list prepared by the Department of Finance that ranks how well banks do in serving city neighborhoods, Chemical Bank was in first place and Manufacturers Hanover third.
Both banks have also been active in philanthropic efforts that benefit the city: Manufacturers Hanover with its sponsorship of the New York City Marathon and corporate challenge races, and Chemical with its sponsorship of the Metropolitan Opera's concerts in Central Park and other outdoor venues. A spokesman for Chemical said those commitments would not change.
The outlook is less bright, however, for the real estate market. The closing or sale of bank branches will put more pressure on the market for sublet retail space, which is already weak. In the 53 square blocks that make up the Grand Central business district, for instance, the vacancy rate for retail space is higher than 11 percent.
 
Effect on the Office Market
 Chemical's announcement that it intended to vacate its executive offices at 277 Park Avenue, at 48th Street, which it has leased until mid-1994, and to move into Manufacturers Hanover's headquarters across the avenue will also hurt the office market.
Chemical currently leases about 750,000 square feet in its Park Avenue offices, and real estate specialists said the sudden arrival on the market of that much premium office space would hurt landlords with space available in less attractive areas or in slightly older buildings.
"The impact on the city now will not be good in the short term," said Jerry L. Cohen, chairman of William A. White/Grubb & Ellis, a real estate firm. Further consolidation is expected in the two banks' back-office operations, situated in New York City, Long Island and New Jersey.
Still, large bank mergers have been anticipated by many in the real estate industry for some time. Salomon Brothers' real estate analyst, David Shulman, said that he had been assuming that a transaction like this would occur for so long that it had become a precondition, in his mind, to future improvement in New York City real estate. He said that he, too, expected another merger involving large New York banks and that as far as he was concerned, the sooner the city got the pain over with, the better.

HEADLINE: The Bank Merger;
From Wonder Boys to Survivors

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
As they emerged, smiles brimming, from the unveiling of the new Chemical Banking Corporation, the tall, youthful-looking chairman of the old Chemical, Walter V. Shipley, turned to the portly, silver-haired chairman of the new Chemical, John F. McGillicuddy, to offer a bankerly version of the athlete's high-five.
"Nice job, John," Mr. Shipley said. 
 "Congratulations, kid," Mr. McGillicuddy answered, before retiring to another floor of the Helmsley Palace Hotel for a big cigar.
The familiarity, say people who know both men, wasn't forced. Their differences of size, manner and shape -- even their new hierarchy -- belie a long personal relationship and common struggles that led them into sudden partnership in the country's second-largest bank.
Neither man has much difficulty recalling the days when they were considered banking's wonder boys. And attending to troubles that were emblematic of their industry's afflictions, both look today more like survivors.
At 60, an age that many senior banking executives might consider their prime, Mr. McGillicuddy, the last chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, might be better described as battle-scarred.
Not five years ago, he could look down from his suite on the eighth floor of 270 Park Avenue at a bank saddled with more Latin American loans as a percentage of assets than any other major American bank, one of the country's heaviest energy-loan portfolios, and a higher percentage of bad loans than any competitor except Bank of America. Rating services downgraded big portions of the bank's debt and analysts gave the bank long odds to bounce back.
When the bank, known as Manny Hanny, was described as "the Wonder Bread of banks" -- nice, airy, not too substantial -- the moniker seemed not to go away. When it was said to be a nice place to work, that was not always meant as a compliment. And the bank's chairman and chief executive took a similar rap. Though one of the nation's more visible money-center bankers, Mr. McGillicuddy often appeared, smoking his cigar, in a seemingly somber mood.
Not long after he became chairman in 1978, the bank gained notoriety for a deal with the New York State Republican Party to pay the party $2.50 for every member it signed up for a Manufacturers Hanover Visa card. Later came the mess with the nation's money supply: accounting errors so huge by Manufacturers Hanover clerks that financial reporting for the entire country was mixed up. And in the days when "financially troubled" and "Chrysler Corporation" went together always, Manufacturers Hanover and Chrysler seemed to go everywhere together.
Mr. McGillicuddy's strategy was presumed to be one of beating competitors at their best game. But as the game played itself out, some analysts and investors believed that where misguided lending executives ventured -- be it in the direction of underdeveloped nations or oil tankers -- Mr. McGillicuddy's men followed. Where the bank played cautious, it missed some of the killings that its rivals made for a time in investment banking, trading and consumer banking.
 
Staying Power
 Throughout the hard times, though, Mr. McGillicuddy never quite lost his noted sense of humor or the confidence of the bank's directors or investors. In 1985, the bank's top management was shaken up and its operations decentralized, but Mr. McGillicuddy stayed on top.
When Mr. McGillicuddy finally brought his bank out of the shadow of its old-style business, he did so boldly, selling control of its CIT Financial Corporation to Japan's largest bank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo, and slashing costs in its overseas operations.
And when Mr. McGillicuddy and Mr. Shipley of Chemical first met to discuss seriously the possibility of a merger two or three years ago, Manufacturers Hanover's pending sale of a 60 percent interest of the CIT group was one of the major stumbling blocks, Mr. McGillicuddy said in an interview yesterday.
Not that Mr. Shipley didn't carry some obstacles -- and some scars -- of his own.
Now 55, the Chemical chairman, who will be president and chief operating officer in the new bank, jokes that he did not take command of his bank as quite the whiz kid that his new boss, who took over Manufacturers' presidency at 40, was. "I waited to the ripe old age of 47," Mr. Shipley said. (Mr. McGillicuddy did not become a chief executive until he was nearly 49.)
 
'Tempering Process'
 Mr. Shipley is quick to add that the crucible of the banking industry has been the period that coincides with his tenure that began in 1983. "I think we've both been through a very important learning and maturing and tempering process over these years," he said, including Mr. McGillicuddy.
Like Manufacturers Hanover, the Chemical bank of the 1980's weathered its share of turmoil from foreign loans. When he took over, Mr. Shipley said, about 40 percent of the bank's loans were international. Worse, its success at making money as a money center institution was waning. In late 1986, Chemical agreed to buy the Houston-based Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. for $969 million as the first out-of-state bank to venture into the oil patch that was then ablaze with losses.
Analysts groaned that Mr. Shipley had paid too much, and, indeed, the bank racked up years of losses. (Other Texas acquisitions included Government assistance.) A New Jersey bank acquisition in 1988, Horizon Bancorp of Morristown, has also been a loser, Mr. Shipley concedes.
Last year, fueled by rumors that the bank's bad loans were mounting and its commercial paper could not find takers, Chemical stock was plummeting. Some analysts described it as the weakest of the major New York banks.
Chemical's rebound, beginning with a first-quarter profit of $152 million last year, was clearly a precondition to yesterday's merger pact. But as they discussed the evolution of their deal in separate interviews yesterday, the two chairman also attributed considerable import to the chemistry between them.
 
'Culturally Similar'
 "Anybody in this town who's had his eyes and ears open has been cognizant of the potential economics of an in-market consolidation," Mr. Shipley observed. But he added, "You've got to have two chairmen who are willing to share responsibility. You've got to have two people who are culturally similar."
Or, as Mr. McGillicuddy put it, "It really started with us."
Although the two men are not close friends, they go back a long way. Early in their careers, both were hard-traveling lenders working in their banks' national divisions. They remembered meeting over dinner in a Kansas City steakhouse in the early 1960's, though they couldn't recall exactly when.
For privacy, the first meeting that led to yesterday's deal took place at the Intercontinental Hotel. Mr. McGillicuddy said that initially both men "were really testing each other.
Their deputies devised a cloak-and-dagger system of code words. Chemical was "Symphony," named for a software program used by the bank to analyze bank mergers, and Manufacturers Hanover was "Vanguard" a name it had used before.
From the beginning, Mr. McGillicuddy added, they agreed about who would be chairman. As for his new boss's head-patting yesterday, Mr. Shipley was philosophical.
"John refers to everybody as 'kiddo,' " he said.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Bank Merger
The largest bank merger in American history was announced by two of New York's biggest banks. The combination of Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover would create the nation's second-largest banking company, after Citicorp. But 6,200 people would lose their jobs, up to 70 branches in the New York area would be closed and Chemical's Park Avenue headquarters with its lobby gardens would be abandoned. [Page A1.] 
 For New York City and other communities, the merger will bring a lot of pain as the institutions slim down and try to become more profitable. [A1.] The "Manny Hanny" name, like those of so many other financial giants over the years, is receding into history. [D6.]
 
The Economy
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Federal Reserve said. [D1.] Business inventories shrank five-tenths of a percent in May. [D5.]
Sales of domestically built vehicles fell a modest 7.7 percent in early July. The seasonally adjusted annual sales rate for the period was 7.3 million, the second-highest 10-day rate this year. [D1.]
The Bush Administration predicted a $348.3 billion budget deficit next year, the largest ever. [A20.]
 
Companies
The Treasury awarded A.T.& T. a contract worth at least $1.4 billion over seven years under which A.T.&T. will supply high-performance computers and work stations to the I.R.S. [D1.]
Directors of Mutual Benefit Life Insurance voted to place the insurer under the custodianship of the State of New Jersey. [D1.]
NCR said its second quarter net totaled $99 million. Paine Webber Group said earnings more than doubled to $33.8 million. [D4.]
 Chemical Banking reported lower second-quarter earnings and Manufacturers Hanover had a gain. Several other banks issued earnings reports reflecting the kinds of problems that are propelling them to unite. [D6.]
 Sears, Roebuck will offer warranties against wear and tear on children's clothing and give discounts to frequent shoppers. [D8.]
 The New York Times Company will take a pretax charge of $20 million against second-quarter earnings. [D17.]
 Spy magazine is losing its co-editor and co-founder to the New York Observer, a publication it once ridiculed. [D20.]
 
International
The leaders of the seven leading democracies began their 17th annual summit conference with talks problems in Yugoslavia, South Africa and the Soviet Union. [A8.]
 
Markets
The Dow rose 9.84 points, to 2,990.61, while the proposed merger of Chemical and Manufacturers pushed the New York Stock Exchange's financial index up 1.6 percent. [D8.]
Treasury securities prices fell after the White House said that the Federal budget deficit will be nearly $350 billion. [D14.]
The dollar was mixed in quiet trading as the market took a breather after last week's volatile sessions. [D15.] Hot, dry weather over much of the Midwest sent corn futures prices higher. [D15.]
 
Today's Columns
The pressure on the Federal Reserve to shape policy the White House way has been roughly the same throughout the years -- and without letup. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene. [D2]
 Two of New York's largest banks hope that together they can forge a strong institution again. Floyd Norris: Market Place [D7.]
 A "green" advertising campaign for household products made by Procter & Gamble focuses not only on packaging, but also on the products in the packages. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D17.]

HEADLINE: Dinkins Considers Shorter Workweek To Save Some Jobs

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
New York City's municipal hospital workers' union has proposed saving the jobs of hundreds of its laid-off members by temporarily shortening their workweek to three or four days at reduced pay, and the Dinkins administration has agreed to discuss the idea.
The decision to discuss the proposal was aimed mostly at averting a one-day work stoppage today by hospital orderlies and janitors to protest the layoffs. Last night the hospital workers' union voted to postpone the walkout. 
 The union is proposing that its members work fewer hours and be paid accordingly. It is not clear how much money such a plan could save, whether it would be attractive to other city unions, whose workers are better paid, or even whether the city will agree to it.
But concessions from municipal unions are how the Dinkins administration hopes to restore the worst of the service cuts and thousands of layoffs in its just-adopted budget. Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday called the talks with the hospital workers "substantial progress."
Negotiations with the main city workers union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees, have swung up and down in the last several weeks, with the city insisting on a comprehensive package of money-saving concessions before it considers early-retirement programs and a guarantee to rehire permanent Civil Service workers first.
Senior city officials said the talks with the hospital workers local showed promise. But if the city reaches a broader agreement on concessions with the 140,000-member District Council 37 -- the hospital union's parent organization -- any agreement with the hospital workers might become part of it. Negotiators for the city and unions are to meet again today.
 
Broad Demands on Table
 Neither side would spell out specifics. But Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37, said his union and Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were awaiting the city's response to a six-point list of demands they presented at their last session on Friday. It includes, he said, such issues as rehiring permanent workers first.
"If we come to an overall understanding, it would include the hospital workers, as well as everybody else, and make this unnecessary," one senior mayoral aide said.
 
'Not a Permanent Thing'
 James Butler, president of Local 420 of the hospital workers union, said any shorter workweek would be a temporary measure to restore the jobs of nearly 900 of his 14,000 members who have been laid off. He said he expected it to be necessary only until the economy improved or more Federal or state funds became available.
"It's not a permanent thing," Mr. Butler said. "It's like a relief. We've got members on the street and some who are about to be evicted. I'm concerned about protecting them and making sure they get some food in their belly and that they don't become homeless or go to a shelter."
If a shortened workweek is adopted, the city would seek to have the plan qualify under a state program in which employees might be eligible for state unemployment benefits for the portion of the week they do not work.
The program, known as Shared Work, basically allows employers who have to lay off a certain percentage of their workforces to reduce the employees' work schedules by the same percentage instead. But the program is governed by complex rules and cannot run more than 20 consecutive weeks, and the city might not qualify.
In effect, the program would be a variation on the unpaid furlough programs the city has been discussing for months but that the unions have resisted. City officials said a labor management team appointed by the Mayor was studying how much money might be saved.
Officials with other unions said they believed such a plan might not be so appealing to other unions. The hospital aides Mr. Butler represents are among the city's poorest paid workers. Many are one step away from welfare and they have a high turnover rate, so the union is especially concerned about protecting their jobs.

HEADLINE: For Haitians, Voyage to a Land of Inequality

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 12

 BODY:
Riding calm seas, with thunder crackling across a hazy night sky, 163 men, women and children jammed aboard a leaky Haitian fishing boat called Conail were 30 miles from Miami when they were stopped July 7 by the Coast Guard cutter Baranof on border patrol.
Following procedures, Coast Guard officers ordered the people off the Conail and on board the Baranof. Of the 163 people on board, 161 were Haitians trying to escape the grim poverty of their homeland. The other two were Cubans whose flimsy raft had been plucked from the water by the Haitians in a gesture of brotherhood. 
 But when the Cubans were allowed to stay while most of the Haitians were sent back, Haitians living in the United States were infuriated and called attention to a double standard in United States immigration policy.
The incident has reopened a longstanding dispute over the favored treatment that Cuban refugees have enjoyed in the United States since Fidel Castro came to power in 1959. Simply put, Cuban refugees are treated differently from immigrants of every other nation because the Cuban Government, unlike those of other nations, refuses to take them back.
The Cubans on the fishing boat that Sunday night, 26-year-old professors who are cousins, were brought to shore and were soon allowed to travel to New York to be with relatives. But all but 9 of the 161 Haitians, once so close to the United States that they could have seen the lights of Miami glowing on the horizon, were returned to Haiti by the Coast Guard.
Three of the nine are being considered for political asylum on grounds that they fear persecution if they return to Haiti. Six were so ill from the voyage that they were taken by helicopter to a Miami hospital.
"If this is a country of immigrants, then why are some immigrants treated like princes and others treated like dogs?" said Rolande L. Dorancy, executive director of the Haitian Refuge Center in Miami, a not-for-profit group that assists Miami's Haitian community. "The United States system is not our friend."
Immigration officials say they have no choice but to let the Cubans stay. The special treatment that only Cubans receive also extends to gaining residency. Under the Cuban Adjustment Act of 1966, Cubans who are not considered a threat to society are automatically granted permanent-resident status after being in the United States for one year.
Haitians, like Mexicans, Dominicans, Jamaicans, Salvadorans and the natives of other nations in the Western Hemisphere who arrive on United States shores illegally, all can be returned home. They usually are, unless they are granted political asylum here, which only a few manage to get.
The number of Haitians trying to enter the United States has dropped substantially since a democratic government was elected in Haiti in February. But after decades of dictatorship and poverty, many still make the risky voyage. At the same time, deteriorating conditions in Cuba have sent a wave of more than 1,200 refugees so far this year to Miami -- further inflaming the resentment of Haitians who watch their compatriots turned away while Cubans are given shelter.
 
Images of Inequity
 Such a policy sometimes creates searing images of inequity. Two Dominicans who recently survived being encased in a wooden shipping container for the passage from the Dominican Republic while six of their compatriots inside the container died, will probably be sent back to Santo Domingo, immigration officials said. But five Cubans who stole a crop duster and flew it to Miami last month are on the way to becoming permanent residents of the United States.
"If you compare Cubans to Haitians or to any other nationality in the world, they would not come out equitable," acknowledged Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington. "There's nothing perverse or discriminatory about it. It's the law."
But many people question why such a law exists for one group of people and not for another. "Here they are, two relatively poor island nations, both a few hundred miles from the United States, both having had authoritarian governments," said Anne Fuller, associate director of the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees, a nonprofit organization in New York. "There are so many parallels between Cuba and Haiti, and yet there's this difference in treatment. That's what's shocking."
Ms. Fuller said she believed that racism was partly to blame for the double standard, since many Cubans are white but all Haitians are black. She also said she thought that the Haitians were not protected because they lacked political power. Attempts in Federal courts to force the Government to change the policy have failed.
Estimates of the Haitian population in the United States range widely and often are inaccurate because so many immigrants do their best to stay hidden. But Ms. Fuller said the Haitian population in the United States exceeds 400,000. The largest community is in New York, where as many as 200,000 may live, Ms. Fuller said.
Miami's Little Haiti, about 200 city blocks of sun-bleached concrete buildings and an array of shops, is estimated to be 60,000 people.
Most of the Haitians in the United States are now legal residents. Some came through regular immigration channels and others who came illegally gained legal status under the recent immigration amnesty program .
In Miami, the Haitians are just one more group of immigrants in a city swept by waves of immigrants. So far the Haitians, separated by their color and their French-Creole language from many of Miami's Hispanic groups, have gained little economic or political power. Relations between the Haitians and the Spanish-speaking ethnic groups are often strained.
 
A Beating Is Protested
 Earlier this month, a group of 52 Haitian residents sued the City of Miami in Federal Court. They contend that police officers beat and unfairly arrested them a year ago when they demonstrated outside a Cuban-owned clothing store. They were protesting the alleged beating of a Haitian customer by the Cuban shopkeeper over alterations for a pair of pants.
Some Haitian residents said they believe tensions have worsened in Miami in recent years, especially between Haitians and Cubans, who often are seen as powerful and privileged.
"When I first came here, every people was happy," said Edward Ogeris, a 34-year-old dietician in a food-service department who came from Haiti in 1979, several years before the United States began to intercept the boats. "Today is a different story. Today, if there are 10 Cuban people and 10 Haitian people looking for a job, they make the Haitians fill applications and then never call them. The Cuban people fill the applications and get all the jobs."
With the exception of the massive Mariel boatlift in 1980, Cuban refugees since the Communist takeover have generally managed to fit into the United States. In 1988 a Cuban-American organization, the Cuban American National Foundation, entered a special agreement with the United States Government in which it essentially handles Cuban immigration policy.
 
Some Cubans Sympathize
 For the last three years, the foundation, with headquarters in Miami, has screened, selected and settled almost 8,000 Cuban "balseros," the name given to the desperate refugees who arrive in rafts, inner tubes, and anything else that floats onto the United States mainland. It was the foundation that, within a day of the arrival of the two Cubans on board the Conail, had interviewed them, located an aunt in New York and arranged for transportation and a job.
For most Haitians, the voyage to the United States is lined with fear and frustration. Those who are not turned away at sea are taken by immigration officials to the Krome Avenue Detention Center in Miami, where they can be kept behind barbed wire for months while their petitions for asylum are reviewed. Most are denied asylum and sent back home, but immigration officials said accounts of their fearful stays at Krome act as a deterrent to other would-be refugees.
After years of pressure from groups such as the Haitian Refuge Center, the Government recently changed some of its immigration policies. Starting last January, Haitians caught trying to come into the United States illegally have been given more extensive interviews, lasting about 20 minutes instead of 5 as before, to establish their claims for political asylum.
 
Asylum for Lucky Few
 In the 10 years before the change, some 23,000 Haitians were stopped as they attempted to enter the United States illegally, according to the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees. Of those, only eight were granted political asylum, even through the years when Haiti was ruled by the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier.
Since the longer interviews were begun in January, 17 Haitians have been identified as eligible for asylum. So far this year, six or seven Haitian boats carrying about 800 people have been intercepted, as against 1,196 in all of 1990, before democracy came to Haiti, and 3,368 in 1989, according to the coalition.
Many Haitians find a bitter irony in the changes coming now that Haiti for the first time has a democratically elected Government under Jean-Bertrand Aristide. But though the incident aboard the Conail has angered Haitians in Miami because it reminds them of the unequal treatment they receive, the new Government in Haiti, six months old and still full of promise, fills the shops and streets of Little Haiti with hope.
"Haitians know that surviving in Miami is tough," said Rev. Thomas G. Wenski, the Creole-speaking pastor of Notre-Dame d'Haiti Parish in Little Haiti. "The community has gone through a tremendous amount of things to be frustrated about. But the people are still on a little bit of a high because of their hopes for a Democratic Haiti."

HEADLINE: The Last Arms Accord?;
Both Sides Are Weary, and There Seems A Scant Constituency for Further Treaties

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Even as the United States and Soviet Union near completion of a landmark arms treaty, the momentum for future and more radical arms control agreements seems to have dissipated.
 It is not that the strategic arms treaty is unimportant. On the contrary, it is a milestone in arms control. It will be the first accord to reduce, rather than limit, the Soviet and American long-range nuclear arsenals. It will establish verification arrangements that could serve as a framework for future accords, big or small.
 
Agreement After So Long
 But the strategic arms accord will also leave each side with a formidable nuclear arsenal. Because Moscow and Washington have found it so difficult to wrap up this accord, it is unclear whether they can muster the necessary enthusiasm for pressing ahead with more far-reaching agreements. 
 The predominant mood, in fact, appears to be one of relief that these talks are finally being brought to an end after nine years.
When the Bush Administration took office, it looked as if Moscow and Washington would wrap up the strategic arms treaty, which by then was largely complete, and then move on to a more ambitious agreement that would make deeper cuts. But the new, cooperative superpower relationship created a paradox: While arms control treaties seemed easier to negotiate, the need for them also seemed less urgent.
 
Why Moscow Balked
 As it turned out, completing the treaty took more than two years. In Moscow, a surge in the influence of the military and the departure late last year of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, limited Soviet flexibility, while political and economic crises distracted the leadership.
The Bush Administration, for its part, never appeared to make completion of the treaty its top arms control priority. Instead, the Administration focused on completing an agreement reducing conventional forces in Europe. The gulf war also diverted attention from arms control.
Another factor hampering the strategic arms talks was that the national security bureaucracies on each side lagged behind the political leadership. Administration officials say the military and civilian experts often maneuvered for advantages and treated concessions as potential risks to security.
The talks on the strategic arms reduction treaty, or Start, began in June 1982. By the end of the Reagan Adminstration, the framework of the agreement, and many of its detailed provisions, had been established.
Under the accord, the overall number of nuclear weapons in each side's arsenal will be cut by 25 to 30 percent. The American arsenal will be reduced from about 12,000 warheads and bombs to about 9,000, while Moscow's arsenal is to be reduced from about 11,000 to about 7,000.
In terms of overall weapons levels, the treaty would maintain the expansion that has taken place over the last decade. But the force of 308 heavy SS-18 missiles that Moscow had when the talks began would be cut in half. The SS-18 has long been deemed by the United States to be the most threatening Soviet nuclear system because of its accuracy and throw-weight, or payload-carrying capacity.
 
Not a Total Solution
 By itself, the agreement will not eliminate the threat that Moscow's arsenal poses to the American land-based missile force. By limiting the magnitude of the threat, however, it can make it more practical for the United States to take steps to make its arsenal of long-range weapons less vulnerable to attack -- by developing mobile land-based missiles, for example.
In completing the accord, Moscow has put aside its demand that Washington agree to strictly limit the scope of "Star Wars" tests. The Soviet move reflects an apparent calculation that Congressional opposition to a space-based defense and budgetary constraints will effectively limit any push to develop the "Star Wars" system.
Moscow may, however, issue a statement when the Start treaty is signed, putting Washington on notice that the development of a "Star Wars" defense would cause the Soviet Union to reconsider its commitment to reduce its strategic arsenal.
Now that the two sides are resolving their differences over a long-range arms treaty, however, it is not clear if they have the desire to press on.
In Moscow, Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh said in an interview with the Soviet press agency Tass that the agreement "is a fantastically complex penetration into the heart of strategic balances and technologies, and I cannot exclude the possibility that this is also the last treaty of its kind."
 
U.S. Initiative Rebuffed
 Bush Adminstration officials say there has been little recent discussion within the Government about a treaty to make greater reductions in the two sides' long-range arms. Early last year, they proposed a ban on land-based missiles with multiple warheads as a possible follow-on agreement, but the Soviets rejected it as one-sided and the proposal was put aside.
The difficulties the two sides have had in completing the arms accord, Edward L. Warner of the Rand Corporation said, "does not augur well for an immediate drive to another big treaty, which produces deeper reductions."
And Richard R. Burt, the former strategic arms negotiator, said: "I suspect neither side will want to rush into a negotiation right away. There will clearly be a pause for reflection."
The sense that the nuclear-arms-control process is losing momemtum has set off a debate in the United States over how actively to seek a further agreement making far deeper cuts.
Many experts outside the Government have suggested seeking further reductions, to a level of about 3,000 to 4,000 warheads and bombs. The withdrawal of Soviet conventional forces from Eastern Europe, the improvement in American-Soviet relations and the costs of supporting a sizable nuclear arsenal, they say, all point to the need to make further cuts.
The Bush Administration has never said how far it thinks the American arsenal could be cut without eroding the ability to deter a nuclear attack.
But some some Administration officials are skeptical about the proposals to begin a drive for much deeper cuts.
They say that because arms control is no longer the centerpiece of American-Soviet relations, there is not a pressing need for new talks that could prove to be as difficult as the old ones.
In addition, some officials argue that deeper cuts would not necessarily reduce the risk of war. As long as each side has a deterrent force that can survive an attack, they say, a deliberate nuclear strike is unthinkable. Future arms control efforts, they argue, should focus less on reducing weapons and more on ways to improve the political and physical control over nuclear weapons and prevent their accidental launch, a growing concern given the domestic crisis in the Soviet Union.
The new arms treaty, they suggest, might be the last of the comprehensive strategic arms accords worked out by teams of negotiators in Geneva to regulate the superpower competition. Instead, they suggest, a better course might be to seek occasional changes in this treaty to improve its terms, including possible reductions.
 
Little Enthusiasm Seen
 Mr. Burt said that he thought deep arms reductions could be achieved without jeopardizing the American ability to deter an attack. But he said that new talks would prove to be very difficult, given the determination by each side to restrict the other's main areas of strategic advantage.
"I think we could go down to as low as 3,000 on a side," he said. "I just don't see a lot of enthusiasm for doing it."
The emerging dispute over the future of nuclear arms control, as much as the technical terms of the agreement, will be a central issue in the debate over Congressional approval of the treaty.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Europe, has said as much, arguing that the agreement should be regarded as a stepping stone toward deeper cuts to be worked out at formal talks that have the high-level backing of leaders in Moscow and Washington.
"The treaty favors the United States, but still leaves the superpower with Armageddon arsenals that far exceed any rational need," he said.

HEADLINE: Fishing and Pollution Imperil Coastal Fish, Several Studies Find

 BODY:
FISH are disappearing at an alarming rate in United States coastal waters, and nearly one-third of all species have declined in population in the last 15 years, researchers say.
In separate reports, a Massachusetts agency and two national environmental groups have reached the same conclusion about the fish population off the coast: unless the National Marine Fisheries Service imposes stricter conservation measures and fishing regulations, many fish species may decline or be wiped out in the next decade. 
 "The plundering of our coastal waters has imperiled most fish species," said Amos S. Eno, director of conservation programs for the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, a nonprofit conservation group in Washington, which recently issued a report on the management policies of the Federal agency.
From haddock and flounder off Georges Bank in New England to Spanish mackerel off the Gulf of Mexico to striped bass off California, many fish species are threatened by overfishing and an advancing tide of pollutants and urban development on the coastline that have degraded habitats and wetlands, which fish use as spawning and migrating grounds.
The National Marine Fisheries Service, which controls and regulates 2.2 million miles of coastal waters, says it is taking steps to control fish depletion, including tougher restrictions on net sizes and quotas.
"The bottom line is that there is a strong recognition that fish depletion has become a dire situation," said Roddy Moscoso, a spokesman for the agency. "The traditional belief that the fisheries are open to anyone with a boat does not work."
 
Fear Over Food Chain
 Scientists say that a change in the population of any one species of fish, particularly those at the top of the food chain, could have unforeseen effects on marine environments, disrupting ecosystems and affecting birds, marine mammals and smaller organisms that depend on fish and their habitats to survive.
Nearly one-fifth of the world's annual fish and shellfish harvests is caught within 200 miles of the United States coastline. Yet only 15 percent of those fish species are yielding stocks near their potential level, according to the report by the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation.
At least 14 species found off coastal waters are in danger of being depleted, including Atlantic salmon, swordfish, Pacific Ocean perch, shad, California halibut, mackerel, cod, haddock and flounder, the three studies found.
In New England, overfishing has devastated so many species that most highly valued fish are being replaced by those of lower value, which are better able to survive, the study by the Massachusetts Offshore Groundfish Task Force found.
"The 1990's will definitely be a time of reckoning in the fishing industry," said Brian J. Rothschild, a biologist at the University of Maryland. "Technically, you can stop overfishing as quickly as you can snap your fingers. But nobody is doing it."
All three reports, by the Massachusetts task force, the Center for Marine Conservation, and the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, recommend that the fisheries service restrict commercial catches to allow fish stocks to recover. It would take 5 to 10 years to recover depleted stocks with little or no fishing, said John P. Wise, author of the report by the Center for Marine Conservation, a nonprofit group based in Washington.
 
Pollution's Wide Effect
 Fish tend to be more resilient than wildlife, and few reach the point of extinction. But biologists say they are increasingly concerned about preserving habitats from pollution, development and energy projects.
Bays, estuaries and wetlands are among the most imperiled habitats. The study by the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation found that pesticide contamination has been found in 21 of 78 estuaries -- the coastal bays, inlets and rivers where fresh water mixes with shallow salt water to provide a rich environment for marine life and to support most of the nation's commercial catch.
In Puget Sound, groundfish like cod, haddock, flounder and pollack have had an alarming incidence of cancerous liver tumors caused by pollutants. In San Francisco Bay, the population of striped bass has declined 60 to 80 percent because of contamination.
In the Albemarle and Pamlico Sounds of North Carolina, low levels of dissolved oxygen in the water have suffocated hundreds of thousands of striped bass, crabs and eels.
Urban development continues its steady encroachment.
The Atlantic salmon, historically a vibrant denizen of wild, free-flowing rivers, had been eliminated from New England, except for Maine; its upstream passage to spawning grounds has been blocked by dams.
On the Connecticut River, Atlantic salmon must pass five dams before reaching good spawning grounds, and it is estimated that 40 percent of the fish never make it up stream.
Biologists are also tackling the problem of overfishing. They say that fishermen recognize they are just on the edge of destroying the marine environment and allowing it to survive.
In New England, overfishing has drastically changed the population of fish stocks, the the Massachusetts study found.
On Georges Bank, highly valued stocks like sole, pollack, yellowtail flounder and fluke, which composed 65 percent of all fish stocks in the 1960's, now make up only 25 percent of all stocks there. But now they have been replaced by lower-valued species like spiny dogfish, skate and shark, said Steven A. Murawski, head of population dynamics for the Northeast Fisheries Center in Woods Hole, Mass., a branch of the National Marine Fisheries Service, and an author of the Massachusetts study.
Mr. Murawski said that while fish populations tended to rise and fall in cycles, the current decline had permanently changed the dynamics of Georges Bank.
 
Scientist as Advocate
 "This isn't fiction, it's physics," he said. "It's uncomfortable for a scientist to be an advocate, but we are looking at the facts of a declining fish population."
Biologists are concerned that too many species are being depleted as factory ships tow large nets across the ocean, sweeping paths clean of all living creatures and leaving long, empty corridors in their wake.
In Alaska, once-abundant pollack populations have dwindled since the fish became popular in fast-food restaurants, where it is processed into fillets.
Anne Kinsinger, author of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation report, said:. "There is very little known about fish, how they survive and the effects on the ecosystems. Environmentalists don't want to touch the idea of fish conservation. People giggle if you talk about saving fish."
The report by the Center for Marine Conservation said that there were no biological or catch data for nearly 30 percent of all fish species, and that more species may be in decline but that there is little information on them.
Officials at the National Marine Fisheries Service blame foreign fleets that raided the fishing grounds before Congress passed the Magnuson Act in 1976, which banned foreign fishing within 200 miles of the coast.
But the reports state that the rise in commercial fishing came about because the agency's eight regional councils are dominated by local fishing interests. Industry representatives say they are simply complying with Federal rules.
"There is much talk about the poor fisherman dying on the vine, but they have brought it on themselves," said Giulio Pontecorvo, an economist at Columbia University who has studied the effect of overfishing on the economy. "It is largely the inability of the National Marine Fisheries Service to get the industry under control."

HEADLINE: SCIENCE WATCH;
Infestation by Worm Is Contained in Africa

 BODY:
A RAPIDLY growing, potentially catastrophic infestation by the New World screwworm in Libya has been contained by an emergency eradication effort, officials of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations say.
The infestation, the first ever outside North and South America, had raised alarms that the pest, if unchecked, would extend deep into the heart of Africa, devastating livestock and wildlife. 
 But an airlift of billions of sterile male screwworm flies, organized by the Rome-based Food and Agriculture Organization, has evidently stemmed the infestation, allaying the worst fears of an economic and environmental disaster.
"It looks as though we are going to succeed in stopping it in Libya," Patrick Cunningham, who heads the emergency effort, said in a telephone interview from Rome.
The New World screwworm, or Cochliomyia hominivorax, was once widespread in the United States and Mexico, attacking livestock and, less frequently, humans. Unlike less destructive varieties of screwworm, the New World adult fly lays an average 200 eggs in open wounds or breaks on the skin; after hatching, its larvae burrow into the flesh, causing sickness and eventually death.
American and Mexican officials announced last year that they had finally suppressed it after a 20-year, $750 million effort, but pockets of infestations remain in Central and South America.
The screwworm was found in Libya in 1989. Dr. Cunningham said that officials suspected it had arrived on sheep imported from South America, possibly Uruguay. The screwworms spread quickly, infesting sheep, cattle and camels in an area the size of Massachusetts surrounding Tripoli, on the northwest coast.
The eradication effort, aided by 20 nations, including the United States, which has no diplomatic relations with Libya, began last December. Each Friday 40 million sterile males have been flown on a specially equipped chartered flight from a laboratory in southern Mexico and dispersed in Libya and parts of Tunisia.
The sterile males mate with the fertile females, creating sterile offspring. Since the weekly airlifts began, the number of infected animals has fallen from a high of nearly 3,000 in September 1990 to one in April and none since. The flights will continue until October "to be absolutely sure there's no residual," Dr. Cunningham said.
"If it were to escape from Libya and spread to the rest of Africa, the cost would be incalculable," he added. "It would inevitably be fatal to large populations of wildlife," which could never be inspected or treated.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Skidmore Architect Firm Names Its First Chairman

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, one of the world's biggest architectural and engineering firms, has announced the election of the first chairman in its 55-year history.
He is David M. Childs and will serve for a two-year period. The 50-year-old architectural design specialist will continue to be one of the firm's design partners. 
 The decision to create the new post of chairman came about, Mr. Childs said, because the firm has grown, with offices and projects under way in many foreign countries as well as at home.
"But the slowdown in the domestic and overseas economies has made this a challenging time for every firm related to the real estate, design and construction industries," he said.
Given this situation, Mr. Childs continued, "our partners decided to place one partner in a lead role so that the firm could respond rapidly to new opportunities and adapt to changing conditions."
Among his current projects, Mr. Childs said in a telephone interview from the firm's New York headquarters, is the redesign of the Columbus Circle project, which has been held up by a dispute between community groups, New York City and the developers. He is also redesigning the Riverside South development, another project on the West Side of Manhattan involved in a controversy over its size, and is involved in redesign and expansion of Dulles International Airport near Washington.
The firm is known for design and engineering work on Lever House, an office building on New York's Park Avenue. Skidmore, Owings has also received many awards for its Sears Tower and John Hancock buildings in Chicago, and is currently involved in what may become the world's largest airport terminal under one roof. The 108-acre terminal is under construction in Jidda, Saudi Arabia.

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
A Painful Parting: Giants Waive an Injured Bavaro

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLORHAM PARK, N.J., July 15

 BODY:
In a move untypical for the Giants, who have traditionally been generous with injured players, the Super Bowl champions today waived Mark Bavaro, their onetime All-Pro tight end.
Bavaro and his agent, David Fishof, characterized the Giants' move as an economic decision. George Young, the Giants' general manager, said it was a medical decision. 
 The move came on the opening day of training camp. Ray Handley, the Giants' new head coach, confirmed that Bavaro had failed his preseason physical examination last Friday. In January 1990, Bavaro underwent reconstructive surgery on his left knee. Last February, he underwent another operation to replace dead bone in the knee with bone taken from his hip.
The Giants' announcement to the other National Football League clubs said they had dropped Bavaro by asking for "waivers -- failed physical." That was a warning to other teams that Bavaro was physically unsound, something those clubs knew.
 
Other Clubs Can Claim Him
 However, any club can claim Bavaro by 4 P.M. Tuesday. A club that takes him must pay his salary of $750,000 in what is the last year of a four-year contract. If Bavaro goes unclaimed, he can sign with any club for any salary he and the club agree on.
Bavaro said he intended to continue rehabilitation and wanted to play again, probably next season. If another club claimed Bavaro or signed him as a free agent, it could place him on the physically-unable-to-perform list until he was ready to play.
The Giants could have placed him on that list, too, but had they done so, they would have had to pay him his full salary. They could also have renegotiated Bavaro's contract, offering less money while retaining his rights. Instead, if no other club claims him, the Giants must pay him only a standard disability fee of $65,000.
"The doctor advised him against playing football again," Handley said. "The doctor didn't say he couldn't play football again."
Handley said that if Bavaro's knee became sound again, the Giants would be interested in signing him next year. Would Bavaro be willing to rejoin the team?
"Sure he would," said Fishof, his agent.
In his six seasons with the Giants, the 6-foot-4, 245-pound Bavaro became a prototype of the modern tight end. He was a fierce blocker and a sure pass receiver. He played despite frequent injuries, and last season he played on a swollen knee that left him in constant pain. Each week, he skipped a few practices to rest the knee.
Bavaro was soft-spoken today as he addressed the action taken by the Giants.
"These six years have been the best of my life," he said in a statement. "I have captured the American dream."
He has tried diligently to regain strength in the left knee. However, arthritis has caused the knee surface to flake off, the way asphalt flakes off a highway. The knee joints swell when Bavaro works on rehabilitation, and he is being treated with anti-inflammatory drugs.
Dr. Russell Warren, the Giants' orthopedic surgeon, conducted the examination Friday. For some time, Warren has urged Bavaro to retire and save the knee for normal living.
 
'No Chance to Play'
 The announcement of Bavaro's departure came at Handley's first training-camp news conference. Handley said the Giants were waiving Bavaro because "our medical people felt he had no chance to play this season."
Then Bavaro, who had stood behind Handley, read a statement:
"It was fairly obvious I wouldn't be ready for the season. I thought the Giants would let me rehabilitate. The Giants did not share that thought. I'd like to think they're cutting me more out of concern for my well-being than paying me for the last year of my contract."
In the statement, Bavaro thanked many people and had special praise for Bill Parcells, the head coach during his entire pro career.
"He was a man I sometimes hated but always respected," Bavaro said. "He took me in as a boy and made me a man."
When Bavaro finished the statement, he walked away before questions could be asked. So questions remained about his football future.
 
'Should Have Kept Him'
 Fishof said Bavaro was unhappy over the Giants' move.
"Mark feels the Giants should have kept him and put him on physically unable to perform," the agent said. "He thinks the Giants should have offered him a minimum of 50 percent of his contract. . . . Where most players would have quit last year, he played injured. The least the Giants could have done was pay part of his salary."
In recent years, the Giants have given contracts to such injured and ill players as Karl Nelson, Doug Kotar, Dan Lloyd, John Tuggle and Kevin Belcher. Of that group, only Nelson played for them again.
Young said the Giants waived Bavaro "for his well-being, not for financial reasons."
"The doctor said it was in his best interests to retire," Young said. "We have consultations with our medical staff and we make decisions."
With Bavaro gone, the holdover tight ends on the Giants are Howard Cross, who is unsigned, and Bob Mrosko.
Phil Simms, the Giants' quarterback during all of Bavaro's career, seemed sad about losing a favorite target.
"After the 1986 Super Bowl," Simms said, "I said the greatest tight end who ever played is a player for the Giants right now. I never saw Mike Ditka play, but a lot of people think if Mark continued to play at that pace, everyone would be compared to him."
 
 
 
EXTRA POINTS
 The Giants opened training camp minus 12 unsigned veterans, three unsigned draft choices and five signed players who failed to report on time. They did sign STEPHEN BAKER , the starting split end. They said they had also agreed to a contract with ZEKE MOWATT and expected him on the practice field Tuesday. Mowatt, a free agent, played tight end for the Giants from 1983 to 1989.
The unsigned veterans were JEFF HOSTETLER , OTTIS ANDERSON , DAVE MEGGETT , MARK INGRAM , STACY ROBINSON , HOWARD CROSS , JUMBO ELLIOTT , WILLIAM ROBERTS , PEPPER JOHNSON , MYRON GUYTON , REYNA THOMPSON and JOHN WASHINGTON . The unsigned draft choices are the first three picks: JARROD BUNCH , KANAVIS MCgHEE and ED McCAFFREY .
The signed players who missed Monday's meetings and wind sprints included LAWRENCE TAYLOR , STEVE DeOSSIE , ERIK HOWARD and LAWRENCE McGREW . LARRY MEDICE , a rookie free-agent guard, also did not report and did not pick up his plane ticket. Taylor arrived in the evening. He said he was delayed on a golf course, but he was not upset. He said he shot a 75.

HEADLINE: Summit in London;
Leaders of Wealthy Nations Open Conference in London

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 15

 BODY:
The leaders of the some of the world's wealthiest democracies began their 17th annual summit conference today with discussions of problems in Yugoslavia, the Middle East, the Persian Gulf, South Africa and most conspicuously the Soviet Union.
Prime Minister John Major of Britain, the host country for the three-day meeting, opened it with a ringing appeal for common efforts to "build a world partnership and strengthen international order." His key proposal called for "a stronger United Nations that is more of a peacemaker than a peacekeeper," which could respond more effectively to crises like that in Kurdistan this spring. 
 President Bush and his aides sought backing for his threat to bomb Iraq if it failed to destroy its nuclear-weapons installations. France endorsed the United States' position on Sunday, and Japan, Germany, Italy, Canada and Britain, the other conference participants, seemed ready to fall into line.
After a dinner meeting tonight at the Tower of London that marked the opening of the summit meeting, President Bush said he believed there "there would be strong, strong support" for military action to keep President Saddam Hussein from acquiring a nuclear arsenal.
 
'Terrible Danger'
 Although he cited only France and Britain as voicing public support for such action, he said he believed that "most countries, recognizing the terrible danger of this man going forward with a nuclear program, would be of the same mind."
British officials said the draft of a political declaration by the summit participants that will be released Tuesday would say that they note "the urgency and overwhelming nature of the humanitarian problems in Iraq" and that "they cannot stand idly by."
"As for the Iraqi people," the draft goes on, "they deserve the right to choose their leader openly and democratically."
Moving to exploit what President Bush described tonight as a Middle East "breakthrough" -- Syria's generally positive response on Sunday to American efforts to promote a peace conference -- the White House said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would travel to the region next week for the fourth time in recent months. The United States hopes to persuade Israel to rethink its opposition to a conference in light of Syria's latest declaration.
 
Last Obstacle to Arms Treaty
 While still here, Mr. Baker is expected to make one more attempt, in a meeting with Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh of the Soviet Union, probably on Tuesday, to resolve the final issue delaying agreement on a strategic arms treaty. If he succeeds, senior American officials said, Mr. Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might well be able to conclude arrangements when they talk on Wednesday for a meeting in Moscow late this month or early in August. Striking an optimistic note, Mr. Bush said the treaty was "99 percent of the way there."
"It's a close call," a ranking American official said when asked to assess the chances of reaching agreement, "because the last remaining technical question has significant political overtones for our side."
The question involves the definition, for treaty purposes, of what constitutes a new missile, and Mr. Bush and his political advisers want to make sure that the final language does not expose them to criticism, in the Senate and the electorate, if the Soviets develop a powerful new weapon.
Mr. Gorbachev's arrival late Tuesday, his luncheon with Mr. Bush on Wednesday and his expected appeal to the nations meeting here for help for his stricken economy has overshadowed other economic and political questions.
Japan, Canada, the United States and Britain are reluctant to commit much money to help Moscow and have expressed disappointment with the lack of specific commitments in the 23-page letter they received last week from Mr. Gorbachev outlining plans for liberalization. The Germans, French and Italians -- the big continental democracies that might have the most to fear from civil unrest or economic collapse in the Soviet Union -- are more eager to help.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said in his arrival statement that "an outbreak of instability in the Soviet Union cannot be in our interest."
The problem facing the Western leaders was how to resolve their differences, which almost certainly will mean minimal direct aid, while still sending Mr. Gorbachev away from London with his credibility intact at home.
According to officials of several countries, that will include limited membership of some sort in the International Monetary Fund, technical assistance and perhaps several other elements. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, briefing reporters tonight, said that the summit communique might call Soviet I.M.F. participation something less demeaning than "associate membership," which had been the original nomenclature.
Also under discussion were possible mechanisms for keeping track of Soviet progress toward a market economy, as an assurance to Moscow that the West was truly engaged in the question and ready to help as liberalization took hold. Canada proposed increasing the amount the Soviet Union would be permitted to borrow from the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Develoment.
Aides to Mr. Gorbachev stepped up the pressure on the leaders in advance of the Soviet President's arrival, with Yevgeny M. Primakov, a key Soviet envoy, declaring that his country faces the prospect of a "social uprising" if the rich Western countries do not help it. He also said on a British Broadcasting Corporation television program that failure here would weaken Mr. Gorbachev.
 
'A Grave Matter'
 Vitaly N. Ignatenko, Mr. Gorbachev's spokesman, went further, warning at a news conference that while no one expected "President Gorbachev to come away from this meeting with these black limos filled to the brim with money," it would be a grave matter if he was sent away empty-handed.
"If we do not achieve close cooperation, there could be turmoil not only in the Soviet Union but elsewhere," he said in an apparent suggestion that the Soviet armed forces and other right-wing elements might react badly. "There could be turmoil in the whole world. The internal situation in the Soviet Union would be rendered more complicated without Western help."
Vladimir I. Shcherbakov, the Soviet First Deputy Prime Minister, also said that in order to guarantee convertability of the ruble in the early phases of liberalization, so that foreign investors could export their profits, the Soviet Union would need a fund of about $10 to $12 billion from the West. He gave no details of how a fund would work.
Mr. Brady said there had been no previous discussion of such figures, even in the Gorbachev letter.
 
Dinner at Tower of London
 An American official who took part in today's discussions said the "range of differences has narrowed dramatically" between the United States and the continental Europeans on Soviet aid. But he conceded that "a certain ditch, if not a gulf" remained to be bridged.
Giulio Andreotti, the Italian Prime Minister, was quoted by aides as having said at the afternoon session, "No one wants to have it on his conscience that we didn't help" the Soviets.
"Nobody wants to send President Gorbachev away discouraged because we have all benefitted so much from the process of reform and want it to continue," commented Douglas Hurd, the British Foreign Secretary. "But equally I don't think anyone wants to start writing checks at this meeting."
Almost every delegation was pressing a pet political project. The Japanese, for example, were lobbying their allies for backing in their campaign to win control of disputed islands from the Soviet Union. Several countries proposed a register, under the control of the nations represented here, to keep track of arms sales, but the French reportedly resisted that.
Mr. Major's United Nations proposal, co-sponsored by the Germans, would set up an office to coordinate disaster relief, headed by an Under Secretary General reporting directly to the organization's chief.

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: Syria's Reply Buoys Bush, Who Now Looks to Israelis

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 15

 BODY:
President Bush said here tonight that Syria's response to his proposal for convening a Middle East peace conference represented a "very positive breakthrough" and could pose "a good test" of Israel's desire to negotiate peace with its Arab adversaries.
Mr. Bush made his remarks late tonight as he left dinner at the Tower of London with the leaders of six other major industrial democracies, who are gathered here for their annual economic summit conference. 
 A few hours earlier, the White House announced that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would return to the Middle East on Thursday to seize any new momentum generated by Syria's acceptance of Mr. Bush's proposals.
 
'A Coming Forward'
 In hailing the Syrian reply to his peace initiave, Mr. Bush cautioned that there could still be hitches. But he said Syria's decision to accept the President's compromise represented "a coming forward" by President Hafez al-Assad.
Although the text of the Syrian acceptance letter has not been made public, those familiar with its contents say that Damascus has in effect accepted the principle of direct negotiations with Israel. But that acceptance hinges on the terms under which any peace conference is convened -- itself an area of deep dispute between Arabs and Israelis.
And as an intially negative response by the Israeli Government quickly made clear, word of a "positive" step by Syria, as filtered through an Admnistration eager to push the Mideast process forward, is not the stuff of which instant bargaining sessions are made.
The effort for a compromise began in June, when President Bush sent Israel and Syria a plan aimed at bridging differences over how to convene and give shape to any regional peace conference.
First, Mr. Bush proposed that the United Nations be represented at any conference by a single observer, who would not be allowed to speak or actively participate. Israel has insisted that the United Nations have no role, deeming it biased against Israel, while Syria had demanded that the organization sponsor the entire conference.
Second, Mr. Bush suggested that the conference, which would be co-sponsored by the United States and the Soviet Union, should open with a ceremonial session, to be followed by separate bilateral meetings between Israel and the Arab parties. Then, at periodic intervals, and if all parties agreed, the full conference would reconvene to hear reports from the separate negotiating groups.
 Before reportedly accepting the Bush compromise, the Syrians had sought a conference with a formal opening and a permanent status, so that neither side could stall without any pressure for results.
Israel has said it wants any conference to have a purely ceremonial opening, with any subsequent direct talks between Israelis and Arabs evolving at their own pace. This way, there would be no outside authority empowered to monitor or assess the progress of the talks.
While Israel quickly rejected the new Bush Administration aproach, Syria spent the last six weeks asking Washington various questions to clarify the proposal. In a commentary on Syrian television on Sunday, President Assad was said to regard President Bush's proposals and the subsequent clarifications as "positive and balanced" and the "acceptable basis for achieving a comprehensive solution and a peace process in the region."
In Jerusalem today, Israel reasserted its earlier rejection of President Bush's peace plan, setting the stage for a possible new collision between Washington and Jerusalem when Mr. Baker arrives in Israel to try to persuade the Government to reconsider.
But Mr. Bush said tonight that he hoped that Israel would "get on board naturally."
He said Israel had "been wanting to talk with people in the area, and if all goes well here, that is exactly what will happen."
"They have made statements to us of wanting to do these things," he said, "so here will be a good test."
The Syrian move also puts pressure on Jordan and the Palestinians to form a single delegation for any peace conference.
In a letter delivered to the American Ambassador in Damascus on Sunday, President Assad said the American proposal constituted an "acceptable basis for achieving a comprehensive solution."
The text of the Syrian letter has not been released, and Mr. Baker said on Sunday that there were some points, which he did not specify, that Washington must still explore with Damascus.
Administration officials said in Washington that while the Syrian letter posed questions on various issues, it appeared to attach no conditions to accepting the American plan. The Administration does not plan to make the letter public, the officials said.
Mr. Bush also said today that his efforts to negotiate a treaty with the Soviet Union on reducing long-range nuclear weapons was "99 percent of the way there," and that a summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could still be held this month if a disagreement on a highly technical issue was ironed out.
Mr. Bush did not rule out resolving the issue during the London conference, where he will meet with Mr. Gorbachev and the other leaders, but he said he did not want arms control matters to overtake the summit agenda, which is primarily economic.
After his visit to the Middle East, Mr. Baker is expected to travel as scheduled next week to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to attend a meeting of Southeast Asian nations.
