HEADLINE: Budget Deficit Estimate Is Lowered

BYLINE: By DAVID ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that the Federal budget deficit in the current fiscal year would be somewhat lower than was forecast in January, but it predicted a $348.3 billion deficit next year, far and away the largest ever.
Much of the change has little economic consequence because it represents the method of accounting for the costs of the war against Iraq and a shift of spending for the savings and loan bailout to next year from this year. 
 But the Administration, in its annual midyear budget review, also said tax receipts were now expected to be about $20 billion lower in both fiscal years than was previously thought and more than $40 billion less each year by the middle of the decade.
Administration officials had no explanation for the drop in tax collections this year and next, but one White House economist said it had to do with "technical re-estimates" and not the state of the economy. The estimates of lower revenues in later years, a Treasury official said, resulted from rewriting computer programs to take account of new tax data.
The projections still show the deficit falling steadily after next year, but the Administration is no longer forecasting a surplus by 1996, potentially President Bush's last full fiscal year in office.
The new budget rules the President and Congress agreed on last fall make the deficit much less important politically than it used to be.
Under the old rules, a specific deficit ceiling was set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law, and across-the-board spending cuts were required if the deficit was projected to be above the limit. As a result, changes in the overall economy and unforeseen costs like the savings and loan failures touched off crises almost annually.
The new rules are intended to achieve a lower deficit. But instead of focusing on the deficit figure itself, they set precise spending limits and require that additional spending be offset by cuts elsewhere or tax increases.
Last year at this time, budget negotiations between the White House and Congress were deadlocked. Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and other top Administration officials held a news conference predicting dire consequences if the deficit could not be cut.
This year, reporters were handed copies of the report. Mr. Darman had no statement and was not available for interviews, and other Administration officials who deal with the economy would speak only off the record.
The report also contained the Administration's latest economic forecasts: increases in the gross national product of eight-tenths of 1 percent this calendar year and 3.6 percent next year; an inflation rate of 3.4 percent this year and 3.9 percent next year, and an unemployment rate of 6.7 percent this year and 6.3 percent next year. The figures represented very slight changes from the January forecasts.
 
War Costs Estimated
 The report estimated the cost of the war against Iraq at $42.2 billion through May, with an ultimate cost of over $61 billion, Allies have pledged to contribute about $54 billion through the end of this year, and $44.5 billion has been received, the report showed.
The Administration now forecasts the deficit for the current fiscal year to be $282.2 billion, less than the $318.1 billion that was predicted in January. For the fiscal year 1992, which begins Oct. 1, the $348.3 billion deficit now projected compares with a January estimate of $280.9 billion.
The largest deficit ever was $221 billion in the 1986 fiscal year.
Part of the change results from the fact that contributions toward the war are being being received this year and counted as income, but much of the money will not be spent until next year.
Not counting the war and the deposit insurance costs, the deficit is expected to be about $200 billion through the 1993 fiscal year and then fall below $100 billion by 1996.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Keeneland Sales Proceed Cautiously

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 15

 BODY:
M. C. Hammer and his two brothers weren't there, but Sheikh Maktoum bin Rashid al Maktoum and his three brothers were there monitoring developments on closed-circuit television as the first gavel fell today on the world's most important sale of thoroughbred horses.
It was the opening day of the July sale of yearlings at Keeneland race course, a kind of economic summit of the breeding and racing business and the surest barometer of the state of the horse business, which has been depressed for a half-dozen years. 
 During the first two days of the sale, 317 "selected yearlings" will be auctioned, and they are rated the prize pupils. On Wednesday, 150 other yearlings with less glamorous pedigrees will follow them into the ring.
The sale was expected to give the first clues to the ability of the horse business to bounce back from both the recession and the war in the Persian Gulf.
Sheikh Maktoum, the ruler of Dubai, directs a horse empire that spent $60 million for thoroughbreds last year in the United States alone.
Most horse people did not predict any radical turn in the slumping domestic market for horses this week. And none developed in the opening two sessions, when 113 yearlings were auctioned at an average price of $306,759, about $1,600 more than last year's first-day total. By contrast, seven years ago the yearling Seattle Dancer was sold for a record price of $13.1 million.
 
Million-Dollar Purchases
 Today, the first plunge of the sale was made by Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al Maktoum after eight yearlings had been sold for as low as $125,000. He bid $1.2 million for a King Ranch colt sired by Mr. Prospector. After nine more were sold at lower numbers, D. Wayne Lukas bid $1.15 million for a colt owned by Dr. William O. Reed and sired by Alydar.
But the day of the $13 million yearling is history, and horse people now are looking abroad for cash and comfort.
Even the catalogue listing the 467 horses was printed in Arabic, Japanese, French, German and English. And Keeneland distributed biographical sketches of Sheikh Maktoum and his brothers and of other "principal buyers," notably Prince Khalid Abdullah of the royal family of Saudi Arabia, Robert Sangster of Britain, Vincent O'Brien of Ireland, Zenya Yoshida of Japan, Dr. Koichiro Hayata of Japan, Lukas of California and the newest force in the business, the family of the rap singer M. C. Hammer. (Although members of the singer's family had said they intended to attend the sale, none were in sight on the first day.)
"All the major players are here," said James E. Basset 3d, chairman of the board of the Keeneland Association. "The strongest sales factor is that Keeneland horses are winning races all over the world. But we don't know how the sales will be affected by the recession or the war or even by the decline of Calumet Farm. You know, people may get into some gamesmanship, feeling out Calumet to see if they're vulnerable because they know Calumet's in no position to take their horses home."
Calumet, the most successful breeding and racing farm of the last half-century, bent under the weight of $93 million in debts last week and filed for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws. The farm's rise and fall gave an anxious tone to the market, and the farm offered only nine yearlings for sale.
But the most important sire at Keeneland this week was the Calumet champion Alydar, who died last November at a time when he was commanding stud fees that totalled $20 million a year. Twenty-seven of his offspring were being sold for various owners, more than any other sire.
People in the horse business were still betting that the Maktoum family and other foreign investors would sustain the horse sale, even at the low level of the last few years.
In 1984, at the peak of the horse market, the average price for a yearling in Keeneland's July sale was $544,681; last year the average was $352,009. Total sales in 1984 reached $175 million; last year, $82 million.
 
Glamour Still There
 Even so, the sale has kept its glamour. Two auctioneers in black tie sat on a high platform at the head of a plush auditorium, taking turns calling for bids in the chanting tobacco-auction style, while uniformed grooms led the yearlings into the ring before a high-level audience of 810 persons, who sat in reserved seats and gave hand-signals to raise the bids.

HEADLINE: Merging Police to Cut Costs: The Rub Is, Who's Boss?

SERIES: Common Solutions: Governments Cooperating -- Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEA GIRT, N.J.

 BODY:
This little seaside community and its neighbor across Wreck Pond, Spring Lake Heights, have started talks about merging their tiny police departments. And Tom Phillips, an 83-year-old resident of Baltimore Boulevard here, has a very basic question:
"Who will be in charge of setting the budget and deploying the cops?" 
 The inability to answer that question helped doom three other proposed police mergers in New Jersey recently. Now the bumpy search to resolve the question picks up here, with the debate echoing discussions taking place throughout the New York metropolitan area as governments seek economy and efficiency in such basic services as garbage collection, education and law enforcement.
Sea Girt, a square-mile image of oceanfront opulence with grand homes and broad lawns trimmed with flowers, has a nine-member police force. Spring Lake Heights, more middle class with an equal number of houses, condominiums and garden apartments in its 1.5 square miles, has 13 police officers.
 
Savings Would Be Shared
 Right now the plan is for Spring Lake Heights to send its officers to Sea Girt's department, along with enough money for their salaries and the cost of patrolling Spring Lake Heights. Savings, still uncalculated, would be shared equally, officials said. They promise no layoffs and no cuts in service.
But William Fury, the Police Chief in Spring Lake Heights, is angry, even though one of the borough's Councilmen, John E. Tully, an accountant, proposed the idea. The merger, Chief Fury says, would leave his department and community without a voice in future police planning. And he is fretting about what will happen to his department's three sergeants.
"They happen to have seniority over Sea Girt's two sergeants," Chief Fury said. "Will Sea Girt give them their seniority? Or are they going to be patrolmen?"
Sea Girt is noncommittal. "We want to do the fair and equitable thing," says Edward H. Ahern, Sea Girt's head of public safety and chief negotiator on the issue.
"What does fair and equitable mean?" responds Chief Fury. "That's no job guarantee."
 
Police Symbol Is Prized
 So goes the debate as the two shore towns, with 7,500 residents, nine police cars and minuscule crime rates, take on one of the most difficult problems of regionalization, itself never a simple matter. The uniformed police officer is a visible and coveted symbol of a community's safety, security and identity. Residents, and consequently mayors and other governing officials, abhor giving up "their own" departments, even though they are often the most expensive item in budgets, regional planners say.
Consequently 493 of New Jersey 567 communities have their own police departments. State police patrol the others.
Of the 493 communities, fewer than a dozen have tried police mergers. None got beyond the talking stage. The failed attempts involved Jamesburg, Spotswood and Helmetta in Middlesex County; Bridgewater and three neighbors in Somerset County; and Ridgefield and Fairview in Bergen County.
 
Other Mergers Studied
 Besides Sea Girt and Spring Lake Heights, governments now studying police mergers are Belmar and South Belmar, two small coastal towns near here, and Princeton Borough and Princetown Township.
It's not just attachment to home rule that can doom police merger plans. The logistics of merging police departments is far more complicated than an agreement to share a snow plow or a recycling center.
Which department's training regulations and hiring and promotion policies will be used? Which department's pay scale and health benefits package? Which radio frequency? Whose communications gear? Whose headquarters? Whose weapons, if one department uses .38-caliber revolvers and the other 9-millimeter automatics? Which chief will step aside for his colleague, usually his good friend, next door? And what will the merged department be named?
 
No Firm Guidelines
 "There is no book you go to that says 'this is how you do it,' " said Lars Oyen, the Police Chief in Ridgefield, N.J., and an advocate of regionalization on a limited scale. "I know a lot of the questions. But I don't have any answers. You have to have someone with the wisdom of Solomon to solve it."
Earlier this year Chief Oyen proposed merging Ridgefield's department with Fairview's in Bergen County. Fairview countered with a proposal to include three other towns. Chief Oyen considered a five-town merger far too complicated and pulled out.
"I told them, 'You call me back when the five mayors and the five councils merge and I can deal with one,' " he said.
Chief Fury of Spring Lake Heights is interested in a multi-town merger nonetheless, because he believes the current plan favors Sea Girt. He is trying to broaden the talks to include South Belmar and Spring Lake. He would lose his Chief's job in the proposed takeover plan, but he said he planned to retire in a year or two anyway.
His opposition to the merger with Sea Girt is centered on what will happen to his sergeants and his town.
"Our residents don't have any representation," he said. "Sea Girt will control where the cars go and how many men are on duty. They'd also dictate who's hired, fired and disciplined."
 
Insistence on Control
 Mr. Ahern, Sea Girt's Public Safety Director, said he had no objection to creation of a planning committee with a seat for Spring Lake Heights. But he said Sea Girt would insist on being in control and would reject any reversal of roles that would make Sea Girt's Police Department subordinate to that of Spring Lake Heights.
"It wouldn't be a popular concept in town, and it certainly wouldn't be a popular concept with me," he said.
Mr. Ahern said he would not approve any plan with annual savings of less than $150,000 for each town. Councilman Tully said that costs would increase slightly in the second year of a merger but that he expected them to drop after five years to 1991 levels as older officers retired and were not replaced and duplicated services, like dispatching and excess cars and communications gear, were eliminated. Mr. Ahern and Mr. Tully both insist police services would not be reduced.
The 1991 police budget for Sea Girt, which has 2,100 residents, is $548,000, nearly 22 percent of the borough's budget of $2.5 million. Spring Lake Heights, with 5,400 residents, spends nearly $783,000 for its police, or 25.2 percent of its 1991 borough budget of $3.1 million.
 
Filling in Gaps
 A merger could help fill gaps in Sea Girt's command structure. In April 1990 its police captain, lieutenant and a sergeant were arrested by state narcotics agents on charges of participating in a marijuana and cocaine ring here and in nearby shore towns. Spring Lake Heights would provide the men -- and the money -- to fill those still-vacant positions, a major plus for Sea Girt.
But Sea Girt might lose its police headquarters, old, cramped and hemmed in by pretty homes at Baltimore Boulevard and Fourth Avenue, in favor of Spring Lake Heights's newer and roomier headquarters building along busy Route 71.
That switch would be practical, said Richard K. Fruin, a retired New York City police lieutenant hired to rewrite Sea Girt's training and operating manuals in the wake of the drug arrests. But, anticipating grumbles, Mr. Fruin added: "People in Sea Girt might say, 'If we're taking over, why not house the headquarters here.' "
At this tentative stage of planning, residents seem at least open-minded about a joint force.
 
'There's Duplication'
 "It makes a lot of sense," said Mary Johnson of Sea Girt. "I'm sure there's duplication of a lot of things, especially administratively, that could be reduced."
Another Sea Girt resident, Deirdre Badach, said she favored the savings that a merger would produce but worried that new police officers in town might be less friendly and attentive.
"It's a nice small-town atmosphere here," she said. "That's what I'd hope would stay, but I don't know if they could do it."
In Spring Lake Heights, Tom Brahn said:, "As long as the protection's there and they don't lay anybody off, I don't mind."

HEADLINE: Patients of AIDS Dentist Seek Tests

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Deborah A. Brower, a 33-year-old nurse's aide from Long Island, saw her dentist three times in the last four months. Today she has a fourth medical appointment, this time to find out if the dentist infected her with the AIDS virus.
Ms. Brower is one of at least 200 patients who fear they were exposed to the AIDS virus by Dr. Philip M. Feldman of Coram, L.I., who died of pneumonia last month. The New York State Health Department has set up hot lines and clinics to offer counseling and testing to his patients and is investigating reports that Dr. Feldman did not follow proper infection-control practices, like sterilizing or disinfecting dental instruments between patients. 
 Publicity about Dr. Feldman's case, which was first reported in Newsday last weekend, coincided with yesterday's announcement by the Federal Centers for Disease Control of guidelines for health-care workers who are infected with the AIDS virus.
But the new Federal standards, which rely on the workers' willingness to voluntarily be tested for the virus and disclose their infection to patients, drew angry responses from people like Ms. Brower, herself a health-care worker, who said that testing should be mandatory and that those infected should be prevented from practicing.
"What dentist, what surgeon can you trust if there are people like these who allowed people to come in and bring their children in when he knew he had AIDS?" she asked. "I'm disgusted. I'm terrified."
But Dr. David E. Rogers, chairman of the New York State AIDS Advisory Council, said mandatory testing would consume "enormous amounts of money" for a very low yield, considering the low risk of infection from health-care workers to patients. The guidelines, he said, "put the emphasis where it should be, which is, what kinds of procedures are HIV-infected people using in taking care of patients?"
The inquiry into Dr. Feldman's practice is the first such official investigation of a health-care worker in a state with the highest number of reported AIDS cases in the country, 718 of them among health-care workers, state health officials said. The vast majority of these cases involved doctors, nurses and other medical personnel who do not perform the types of procedures that could lead to transmission of the virus, they said.
And even as they seek access to Dr. Feldman's records to insure that all patients are notified of the available help, the health officials called the risk of dentist-to-patient infection "exceedingly low" and said they did not expect to find a single instance in this case. Any patient who tests positive would be evaluated to rule out other known risk factors, such as sex with an infected partner, they said. Suffolk County health officials said 147 of the dentist's patients have scheduled tests and counseling. Those seeking appointments can call (516) 348-2749.
 
Special Evaluations
 In a statement released yesterday, the New York State Health Department said that the new Federal guidelines were similar to those that have been in place in the state since January for health-care centers and HIV-infected medical personnel. Both call for voluntary, rather than mandatory testing, and both recommend special evaluations of infected workers who engage in high-risk medical work such as dental and surgical procedures to determine whether they should continue performing them.
Department officials said they did not know the extent to which the guidelines were followed.
"The C.D.C. and the New York state guidelines set up a standard for a doctor to follow so one would expect health-care workers to follow standards that are explicitly stated," said Dr. Lloyd F. Novick, the State Health Department's director of community health and a consultant to the centers on the issue of HIV infection among health-care workers.
"What is the alternative?" he said. "The only other way to approach this is to know the HIV status of every health-care worker who's performing invasive procedures and to know it at repeated intervals. We've rejected that approach as unworkable because it would require repeated testing and would not give full assurances that the health-care worker is free of infection."
The department requires the state's 260 hospitals to adhere to infection-control procedures issued by the centers and violations are punishable with fines, said Frances Tarlton, a department spokeswoman. She said that hospitals had generally complied.
The state, however, does not have authority over individual practitioners, she said.
"The best protection for both patients and health-care workers is rigid infection control. Patients can make sure that dentists are wearing gloves. They can ask about their infection-control practices," Ms. Tarlton said.
"Anyone can ask point blank if the person is infected with HIV," she said.
Still, many say protection should not be left up to the patient.
"If they say testing is not economically worthwhile, do they realize the economic devastation to my family," asked Paul A. Pallmann, a 48-year-old exterminator whose wife and two sons, ages 22 and 14, were Dr. Feldman's patients.
" What about the human cost? People aren't replaceable with money."

HEADLINE: Forgive Debt, Finance Nature

 BODY:
Latin America owes the world billions of dollars -- much of which it can't repay. The world wants Latin America to stop destroying its priceless rain forests, ancient nurseries of life that also serve as a natural sink for greenhouse gases. These two conditions invite a deal -- debt-for-nature swaps that would channel some of Latin America's debt into conservation.
Swaps involving more than $100 million owed to private banks have already been arranged. And just a few weeks ago, Brazil gave the debt-for-nature idea a huge boost when it agreed to devote $100 million each year to saving the Amazon rain forest if banks would discount its debt. 
 The Bush Administration likes the idea and is backing a bill that would add money owed the Federal Government to the debt-for-nature pot. The bill is floundering in the Senate, and needs a timely push from the White House.
Debt-for-nature swaps sound complicated, but the mechanism is simple: Conservation groups, using private funds, buy foreign debt owed to banks. Since the debt may be uncollectible, the banks are happy to unload it at a fraction of its face value. The conservation groups then turn around and offer to forgive all or part of the debt in exchange for a pledge by the debtor nation to use the windfall for environmental purposes.
In the first swap, in 1987, Conservation International paid $100,000 to Citicorp for an uncollectible $650,000 owed to Citicorp by Bolivia. Conservation International then agreed to forgive the entire debt in return for Bolivia's promise to protect four million acres of tropical forests. Since then, 15 similar swaps have been carried out with a half-dozen countries.
These private ventures are modest in global terms. That's why Mr. Bush included debt-for-nature swaps in his 1990 "Enterprise for the Americas" initiative, an effort to pare debt, liberalize trade and boost investment in Latin America. Under his plan, a slice of $12 billion in Latin America's foreign aid debt would be forgiven; interest payments on the rest would flow to local environmental projects instead of the U.S. Treasury.
The payments would be made in local currency, enabling debtor countries to use their scarce hard currency for imports. The payoff for the U.S.? Debtors would have to streamline their economies, pledge to reduce their debts with other big creditors like the World Bank and open their borders to outside investors on favorable terms.
The House passed a bill similar to the Bush plan last month. The problem is in the Senate. A bill sponsored by Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, includes the swap idea but dilutes the potential impact by allowing debtor countries to spend the money on child nutrition, anti-drug efforts and secondary education.
These are worthy causes. But the Administration argues that they are already financed by existing A.I.D. programs, whereas environmental causes are not. Unless conservation is specifically targeted, debtor nations are likely to spend the money on projects with a quicker political payoff.
Still, the Dodd bill is better than no bill at all -- and it could be reshaped in a House-Senate conference. But first the Senate must act. At stake is a promising extension of an innovative way to reduce debt -- and enrich the planet in the bargain.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New Aid to Israel Can Only Hinder Peace;
Economy Gains

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I disagree with Robert Loewenberg, who states in "Why Prop Up Israeli Socialism?" (Op-Ed, June 24), "Israel's economy is stagnant because of the perpetuation of an antiquated socialist system, propped up by United States aid and Jewish philanthropy."
Mr. Loewenberg's description of Israel hardly reflects that Intel (United States) is adding a $95 million expansion to its $100 million investment in Israel. National Semiconductor (United States) is adding $50 million to its investment. Twenty-eight United States companies have recently selected Israel for research and development with Israeli companies. 
 Despite Mr. Loewenberg's criticism of the Israeli system, the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange is experiencing its biggest boom since the early 1980's. The share index of the largest companies, Tel Aviv's Dow Jones industrial average, has risen more than 50 percent since January.
These financial results negate fears that Israel is going down the tubes because of an "antiquated socialist system."
 
ELMER L. WINTER
Milwaukee, July 2, 1991
 
The writer is chairman of the Committee for Economic Growth of Israel, a nonprofit organization.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Competition In a Hothouse

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IF the smaller fry in the long-distance phone business cannot keep pace with A.T.& T., is it Washington's job to fix the race?
When the Justice Department forced the breakup of the national telephone monopoly in 1984, the Federal Communications Commission assumed that less competition would eventually mean more -- that A.T.& T. needed to be hobbled, lest it reach out and crush someone. 
 But both time and ideology are undermining the case. Fed up with rules that have made it easier for U S Sprint and MCI Communications to lure away some of its biggest accounts, A.T.& T. is asking the commission for equal footing in the market for business services. And with enthusiasic support from the White House, the F.C.C.'s chairman, Alfred Sikes, is inclined to go along.
The best guess now is that the commission will grant some of A.T.& T.'s wishes at its Aug. 1 meeting, and punt on the rest. This will give both sides a chance to claim victory. But it will not resolve the issue of when -- if ever -- Uncle Sam will let consumers decide the fate of the phone rivals.
The commission has come a long way from the days of hands-on, rate-of-return regulation in which every change in phone rates was weighed for its impact on phone company profits. Since 1989, A.T.& T.'s services have been lumped into broad baskets. The company need not ask for permission to raise or lower individual tariffs. But the average price within each basket remains capped, checking potential monopoly power and making it impossible for the phone giant to favor businesses at the expense of residential consumers.
The commission also responded to A.T.& T.'s plea to offer customized services to big clients at negotiated prices. The company has made roughly 80 of these "Tariff 12" deals, which now generate more than a billion dollars in revenue annually.
But the playing field is hardly level. U S Sprint, MCI and some 200 niche companies providing specialized services are effectively free to charge what they want to whomever they want, without making cost information available to rivals.
A.T.& T. is not challenging this asymmetry in the regulation of services for residences and small businesses. It is, however, asking for deregulation of the high-end market, where its share of the business has eroded to about 70 percent. Specifically, it wants an end to the price controls on big-business services, plus freedom to add "800" number services to customized business packages.
A.T.& T. would also like the commission to dump the obscure "equal charge rule" that requires local telephone companies to bill every long-distance carrier at the same minute-by-minute fee for connection to their exchanges. If charges were instead based on costs, A.T.& T. would save upward of $500 million annually. Costs for its smallest rivals, which make far greater use of local exchange equipment, might double or triple.
The F.C.C. will almost surely eliminate price controls on high-end services. And it will probably streamline disclosure regulations on customized offerings, denying U S Sprint and MCI the luxury of matching A.T.& T.'s deals before the big company has a chance to clear them with the commission. But partial deregulation of "800' number service will probably be delayed. And in an apparent bow to House Democrats inclined to fine-tune competition in the long-distance market, Mr. Sikes has decided not to touch the equal charge rule.
Big customers will pay less, little customers will not pay more and A.T.& T.'s rivals will live to fight another day. What could be wrong with that?
Nothing, perhaps. But it begs the question of when the economic logic of the Ma Bell breakup will be allowed to play out. The idea was to spin off local regulated phone monopolies, and then let long-distance companies flourish in more fertile competitive ground. But A.T.& T.'s two main rivals lobby hard for protection, and it is an open question whether Washington will ever be able to say no to these multibillion companies whose profitability -- and perhaps survival -- depends on a continuing regulatory edge.
Then there is the question of equal treatment under the law. So far, the phone giant has pushed for less regulation all around -- what Peter Pitsch, a former F.C.C. staff member and sometime consultant to A.T.& T., calls "good symmetry." But if it loses patience with the pace of change, A.T.& T. may well demand more regulation for rivals rather than less for itself.
That possibility is more than speculation. The F.C.C. ignored just such a warning from A.T.& T. a few years ago, and the company chose not to litigate. If A.T.& T. changes its mind, free marketers may be forced to abandon the dream of a truly competitive market in long-distance phone calls.

HEADLINE: In Likud, Levy Is Often Odd Man Out

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 16

 BODY:
David Levy says he never set out to be the one moderate in a Government whose other members are all staunch right-wingers.
As Israel's Foreign Minister, he is forever butting heads with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and others, and is attacked and maligned for trying to push Israel an inch forward here, another inch there, toward the American proposal for regional peace. 
 In the Prime Minister's office, officials like to say Mr. Levy is committing political suicide. After all, a moderate is a rare bird in the Likud. On occasion, Mr. Levy is forced to proclaim, "I am not a dove!"
In fact, Mr. Levy could hardly be described as a leftist. He supports the growth of West Bank settlements and holds the Likud party view that Israel should never give up the occupied lands. But he wants to offer concessions so the peace process can move forward, though no one else in the Government seems so inclined.
 
Success Tied to Israeli Peace
 On Monday he praised Syria's reported acceptance of President Bush's compromise proposals for a regional peace conference, again bringing himself into conflict with almost everyone else in the Government. They were trying to find fault or declare Syria's response a cynical bluff.
Mr. Levy, who was born in Rabat, Morocco, 54 years ago. is involved in a high-stakes gamble. He is an open candidate to be Prime Minister whenever Mr. Shamir steps down. And his chances depend in large part on whether he succeeds in his present job.
For his rivals, Housing Minister Ariel Sharon and Defense Minister Moshe Arens, success in their jobs is easy to measure. They need only build more homes and stop more terrorists. But for the Foreign Minister to succeed, he must lead Israel to peace. And with this Government, that might prove impossible. As it is, his fellow ministers rebuke him at every turn.
The best-known example came during one of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's recent visits here. Mr. Levy told him that, in one crucial matter under debate, Israel would allow the proposed regional peace conference to reconvene once every six months -- if all the parties agreed.
 
'They Changed Their Mind'
 But as soon as Mr. Baker had left, some other ministers began grumbling that Mr. Levy had gone too far. Soon Mr. Shamir joined them, even though he had approved the idea at first. And two days later the Government formally retracted Mr. Levy's commitment to Mr. Baker.
"They changed their mind," Mr. Levy said, showing a charitable side that was not in evidence at the time.
Mr. Levy has few friends in the Government. But that's not surprising; neither do most of the other ministers. As Foreign Minister, particularly a conciliatory one, Mr. Levy has become the favorite target.
Mr. Shamir and Mr. Levy have been rivals or enemies for a decade, or longer, and in another political system Mr. Shamir probably would have dismissed him long ago. But Mr. Levy holds a significant bloc of support in the Likud Central Committee, which chooses the party's leader. If Mr. Shamir were to dismiss Mr. Levy, he would be endangering his own position.
 
Rampage at Unemployment
 Some accuse Mr. Levy of hypocrisy. Now, speaking of Mr. Baker, the Foreign Minister likes to talk of "my friend Jim." But it was only a little over a year ago that he was a member of the "constraints troika," one of the three ministers who were bent on saying "no to Baker" and his effort to bring Israel's peace plan into action.
Mr. Levy says it is Mr. Baker who has changed. Whatever the truth, Mr. Levy's new attitude has given his enemies even more ammunition when they already had quite a lot. For years Mr. Levy's humble background and relatively unsophisticated manner have made him the target of ridicule.
As soon as the Levys arrived from Morocco 35 years ago, they were sent to Bet Shean, a scrub town in the north that was home only to immigrants who did not know any better. His wife worked as a housekeeper, and he was unemployed, when one day he went on a rampage, turning over desks in the unemployment office because he could not find a job. For that he spent 12 days in jail.
For several years he was a construction worker. Then he campaigned for the rights of immigrants from North Africa and the Middle East, the people known as Sephardim. This led to his election to the Bet Shean City Council. When Likud took power, Prime Minister Menachem Begin noticed Mr. Levy and made him Minister of Absorption, then Housing.
Still, the nation's Ashkenazim, whose roots are European, made fun of him. They pointed to his 12 children. They snickered at his relative lack of education; he finished high school in Morocco and that's all. They ridiculed his sermon-like public speaking manner and the fact that he was the only Government minister who did not speak English. In fact, David Levy joke came to be a common currency of urban dinner parties.
Much of that has changed now, though the television still likes to poke fun at him.
He was in London this spring, meeting with Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, and Israeli television seemed to glory in showing the footage of Mr. Levy's arrival. Both men were standing there, smiling for the cameras. A cameraman shouted, "Now shake hands, won't you!" Mr. Hurd immediately stuck out his hand, but Mr. Levy did not see it and had not understood. So he stood there smiling, unaware, for several excruciating seconds.
But it looks as though Mr. Levy might have the last laugh. He has a natural constituent base, Israel's Sephardic majority. And he appears to be counting on a notion that many other Likud politicians seem unwilling to grasp, that the largest portion of Israel's population is somewhat more moderate than its Government.
A public-opinion survey published this month showed that 69 percent of the public would be willing to exchange at least some part of the West Bank in return for peace. So Mr. Levy may be more cunning than he appears. In the end, will he be Israel's leader one day?
"Nothing is certain," he said with a shrewd smile. "We shall see."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Foreign Minister David Levy of Israel, a Likud moderate. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Volcano Stills City by Base In Philippines

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANGELES, the Philippines, July 16

 BODY:
This once-thriving city of nearly 300,000 people has begun to look like the ghost town that many residents fear it is now destined to become.
Hastily scrawled "For Sale" signs are set in the windows of shops and restaurants that have been shuttered since early last month, when a volcano showered Angeles with a dense layer of ash and forced the evacuation of the area's largest employer, the American-run Clark Air Base. 
 Now comes word from American officials that the United States plans to abandon Clark entirely because of the damage caused by Mount Pinatubo, a move that would mean economic catastrophe for Angeles and other cities and villages that have grown up in the shadow of the 89-year-old base.
"If the Americans close the base, I must close up my school," said Rolando Cataquian, a 32-year-old teacher whose school provided high-school level tutoring to the Philippine wives of American servicemen stationed at Clark. All but 3 of his 33 students in the summer term have been evacuated from the Philippines, and Mr. Cataquian says he will soon be forced out of business.
 
'People Will Suffer'
 "Some people say it will be a good thing if the Americans leave Clark," he said. "I can tell you that people in Angeles do not believe that. If the Americans leave, there will be so many people out of work. People will suffer."
Most of the 15,000 Americans have already left, driven away by Mount Pinatubo. With scientists saying eruptions may continue for several years, the economy of Angeles is already in grave peril. But a permanent shutdown of Clark would cost the jobs of 40,000 Filipinos employed at the base before the eruption and result annually in the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue to local businesses.
The Philippine Government once proposed that Clark be replaced by a civilian airport or by an industrial park, but those plans have been put on hold because of Mount Pinatubo.
Angeles has long had a reputation among American servicemen as a city of vice -- of massage parlors and 24-hour honky-tonk bars -- and to some degree that reputation is deserved.
The main streets of the city are lined with businesses that cater exclusively to the licentious pleasures of American air men. It is for that reason alone that some prominent Filipinos, appalled by the prostitution and public drunkenness around the base, are pleased at the prospect of an American withdrawal. Others see the bases as an unwelcome vestige of the days when the Philippines were a United States colony.
 
Streets Clogged With Ash
 Yet a walk through the city, along wide streets still clogged by the talc-like volcanic ash, would suggest that few critics of the base are to be found among the residents of Angeles. Directly or indirectly, most Filipinos who live here depend on Clark for their livelihood, and they are frightened by the American threat to pull out.
"The Americans have brought influences that are good and bad," said Carlos de la Cruz, secretary of the Clark Field Baptist Church, which is a few hundred yards from the entrance to the base, and a block from a cluster of saloons and a massage parlor.
"Personally, I believe there is much more good because of the Americans," he said. "Isn't it good that the Americans can provide jobs?" Since the eruption, the church has lost the American half of its 300-member congregation, and Sunday offerings are down from $1,500 a week to less than $300.
The church's American pastor has gone home to the United States, and it is not clear whether a permanent replacement will arrive. Mr. de la Cruz said the church may soon have to lay off some of its six Philippine workers.
Because of jobs created by the base, Angeles has long been an affluent city in a nation in which the per-capita income is less than $1,000 a year.
 
Pizza Hut and Dunkin' Donuts
 The American influence is everywhere in the city. There is a McDonald's, a Pizza Hut, a Kentucky Fried Chicken, a Dunkin' Donuts, a Bank of Boston branch office, a Goodyear auto center. All employ many Filipinos.
"I am very pro-bases," said Len Medina, a 27-year-old Angeles native who is the day supervisor at the Pizza Hut. "These are good jobs we have."
Residents of Angeles are conversant in the details of base negotiations between the Philippines and the United States. They seem well aware that the United States is closing military bases at home, and that many Americans are losing jobs because of Pentagon cuts.
But Mariz de Jesus, a 35-year-old hostess at the U & I Canteen, said the plight of Filipinos would be far more bleak. "It is not the same," she said. "If the Americans leave from Clark, there is no hope for us. We cannot go someplace and look for better jobs. There are no other jobs."

HEADLINE: Net Falls 21.7% At Honeywell

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, July 16

 BODY:
Honeywell Inc., citing a weak market, today reported a 21.7 percent drop in its second-quarter net earnings, to $77.6 million.
The international controls maker, based in Minneapolis, said its earnings per share totaled $1.10, compared with earnings of $99.1 million, or $1.29 a share, for the second quarter of last year, which included $6.7 million from discontinued operations. 
 The 1990 second-quarter results also included an adjustment for a significantly lower annual effective income tax rate in connection with the sale of a Honeywell unit's common stock.
Honeywell's worldwide sales in the second quarter were $1.52 billion, down 2 percent from $1.55 billion in the second quarter of last year. Excluding results from businesses divested that year, sales increased 5 percent.
"Some of our business units, such as commercial flight systems and industrial systems, are doing well despite the economy," said James J. Renier, Honeywell's chairman and chief executive. "Others, such as industrial components, and residential and commercial buildings, are impacted by the recessionary conditions in their markets."
The stock of Honeywell, which provides products, systems and services for homes and buildings, industry and aviation, declined on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $60.125, down $1.125.

HEADLINE: U.S. Indian Colleges Get First Big Corporate Gift

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Struggling against isolation and inadequate government financing, Indian tribal colleges are about to receive substantial help from corporate America.
The colleges, most of them situated on remote reservations in 12 Western and Midwestern states, will receive a total of $1 million in assistance this year from the USWest Foundation, the charitable arm of United States West, a telecommunications corporation. 
 Financial help for the colleges from the Denver-based foundation will total $2 million by the end of next year, said Richard D. McCormick, president of United States West, in announcing the program in Washington yesterday.
With most of them established in the past decade, the colleges are too new to have attracted help from private foundations or from companies more accustomed to supporting prestigious universities. So a major aim of the USWest initiative is to enable the American Indian College Fund, which represents 27 of the tribal colleges, to mount a national fund-raising campaign.
 
'Competent and Professional'
 "The American public, if they think of Indians at all, largely has the perception given to them by Hollywood," said Jane Prancan, executive director of the USWest Foundation. "We know the Indians to be self-reliant, competent and professional and the tribal colleges are further developing these attributes. We hope the fund-raising campaign will portray the tribal colleges as we know them."
The 27 colleges served by the college fund have about 12,000 full-time or part-time students and range in size from 80 to 1,800 students. Most are two-year schools and are chartered by their respective tribes.
All the colleges are primarily financed by the Federal Government, which was authorized under a 1985 law to pay them $5,820 annually for each full-time student. But the actual appropriation of funds for the growing enrollments of the colleges was just above $3,000 a student last year, having dropped to less than $2,000 a student in the late 1980's.
Congress appropriated $20.9 million in 1990 for all of the tribal schools, with the biggest share, $6 million, going to the Navajo Community College in Tsaile, Ariz. Established in 1968, it is the largest of the tribal colleges. Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the Hawaii Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs, said yesterday in a statement that the colleges are severely underfinanced and that Congress should increase their money for 1992.
The Bush Administration has urged the colleges to look for financial support from private sources, but until recently most have had little success. The MacArthur Foundation gave $3 million in 1989 to 18 colleges run by Indian tribes and the Bush Foundation of St. Paul, Minn., created by the chairman of the the 3M Corportion, Archibald Bush, has given $1.5 million to tribal schools.
"I would be surprised if more than 1 percent of all philanthropy is directed toward the tribal colleges," said Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.
In 1989, a two-year study of tribal colleges by the Carnegie Foundation underscored the financial predicament of the schools. "Most of the colleges operate on a little bit of nothing from the Federal Government," said Paul Boyer, who wrote the Carnegie study. "What USWest is doing could be part of a movement creating a partnership between the philanthropic community and the colleges desperately needing their support."
A number of presidents of tribal colleges said the Carnegie report helped increase interest among foundations. But the philanthropic community has generally not given much money to American Indians.
The country's top 472 foundations, which account for 44 percent of all philanthropy in this country, provided $3.2 billion in charitable grants in 1989, the most recent year studied by the Foundation Center in Washington. In that year, American Indian causes received only $16.1 million of all grants of more than $5,000 each, and that total included funds for education, housing, civil rights, the arts and economic development.
To secure a larger share of support, the American Indian College Fund has been created, modeled on the United Negro College Fund. It hopes to raise $10 million in the next two years in the fund-raising campaign designed by the advertising agency Wieden & Kennedy of Portland, Ore., said Barbara Bratone, its director. The organization began full operation in 1989 and so far has raised $2 million, including the grant from USWest.
It also has received a $75,000 three-year grant from the Exxon Education Fund and smaller amounts from other corporate foundations. Among private foundations, its support has come mainly from the Ford, Rockefeller and Andrew Mellon Foundations, Pew Charitable Trusts and the Lilly Endowment. The Knight Foundation of Miami, Fla., gave $150,000 earlier this month.
The USWest grant will provide $732,000 to 19 tribal colleges to help improve computer services and libraries, strengthen curriculums and help students to transfer successfully to four-year colleges. The American Indian College Fund itself will receive $70,000.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Optimistic On Economic Outlook

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, named last week to another four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, gave Congress today one of the most optimistic assessments of the economy he has offered in years.
He proclaimed the recession over, reported "promising signs of a slowing in inflation," predicted "marked progress on the deficit" and said he expected the debt of individuals and companies to flatten out after the surge in the 1980's. 
 "At this stage," Mr. Greenspan told a House subcommittee, "we are well on the path of actually achieving the type of goals which we've set out to achieve: a solid economic recovery with the unemployment rate moving down to its lowest sustainable, long-term rate, with growth at or close to its maximum long-term sustainable pace, with inflation wholly under control."
 
'Rather Limited' Evidence
 Typical of Mr. Greenspan, who talks publicly about the economy with the precision of the Oracle at Delphi, not all of his news was glowing. At one point, for example, he said that "convincing evidence of a dynamic expansion is still rather limited," and that "we must remain alert to the chance that the recovery could be muted or could even falter."
He also characterized the Fed's current policy as "a posture of watchful waiting," presumably meaning that changes in interest rates are not in the offing soon. The Fed has not touched the rates it controls since it last cut them in April.
But by and large, Mr. Greenspan, the Government's most important economic policy maker, has rarely been so upbeat, and he looks fit and healthy. He was hospitalized overnight last weekend after he suffered dizzy spells, but his staff said he was released after tests proved normal.
 
No Surprises in Forecasts
 Mr. Greenspan appeared before the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Policy to testify, as required by law every six months, about the state of the economy and the outlook for monetary policy. His economic forecasts contained no surprises.
He said that he and other Fed officials expected the gross national product to rise between three-quarters of a percent and 1 percent this year, inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index to rise 3 1/4 percent to 3 3/4 percent and the civilian unemployment rate in the fourth quarter to be 6 3/4 percent to 7 percent. The Bush Administration's most recent forecast, released Monday, is within those ranges.
For next year, the Fed is slightly less optimistic than the Administration, projecting a G.N.P. rise of 2 1/4 percent to 3 percent, compared with the Administration's prediction of 3.6 percent.
Nonetheless, Mr. Greenspan's forecast and the tone of his comments could hardly have been sweeter music to a President gearing up for a run for re-election in 1992. He also put in a good word for Mr. Bush's grasp of economic matters. "He's very knowledgeable about these issues," the chairman said. "A lot of times you think you're giving him new information, and he's heard it 10 times before, and he often knows a good deal more about certain issues than you do."
Although Mr. Greenspan and top Administration officials have occasionally been at odds over the chairman's refusal to allow interest rates to fall as fast or as far as the other officials want, Mr. Greenspan has never made bones about being a partisan Republican.
He confirmed last week's reports that Fed policy makers had voted early this month to maintain growth of the money supply, as measured by M-2, at between 2 1/2 and 6 1/2 percent next year. M-2 consists primarily of checking, savings and money-market accounts and small certificiates of deposit.
 
Ideal Money-Growth Rate
 In answer to a question, Mr. Greenspan suggested that the ideal long-term growth rate of M-2 would be about 4 percent a year. That would accommodate economic growth of about 3 percent and inflation of about 1 percent. In theory, growth in the money supply should equal the rates of economic growth and inflation, but that is not always the case over short periods of time.
An inflation rate in the neighborhood of 1 percent is necessary, Mr. Greenspan said, because the quality of products in the United States improves each year. One reason the West overestimated the strength of the economy in the Soviet Union for years, he added, was that American economists did not take account of the fact that the quality of Soviet products did not improve the way American products did, and thus Soviet inflation was more serious.

HEADLINE: New York at Work;
Rats Are His Bread, Roaches His Butter

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
Now that he has annihilated millions of cockroaches and rodents, not to mention preposterous quantities of silverfish, cereal mites, carpet beetles, bedbugs, ants, wasps, termites and a few snakes, Sam Bloom figures he knows a thing or two about pest control. Don't serve beer to the cockroaches. Make sure the rats don't get into the bulldozer seats. Stick your empty soda cans in the dishwasher.
Mr. Bloom runs Standard Exterminating in Long Island City, one of the city's oldest exterminators. It will gladly eradicate pests anywhere within the five boroughs. Occasionally, it will dispatch someone into the suburbs for a good flying ant or earwig problem. "And we don't really charge anything for our service," Mr. Bloom likes to say. "Just a dollar apiece for the little funerals." 
 Exterminating is one of the hardiest professions in New York, for the simple reason that New York pests are impressively obstinate. Yet over the years, the war on bugs has got appreciably more refined, as Standard Exterminating, enemy of insects since 1929, knows well. Exterminators don't even like to be called exterminators anymore. They prefer pest-control technicians.
 
They're Everywhere
 There's no mistaking a pest-control technician's office. Just study the walls. Exterminators usually don't go in for those pictures of fruit or verdant farm fields. They like pest art. As you enter the offices of Standard Exterminating on Steinway Street, there's a fairly flattering portrait of a cockroach next to a picture of a good-looking silverfish. Down the way a bit come the rat drawings. At home, Mr. Bloom continues to add to a sizable collection of mice and rat figurines. "To other people, they're pests," he said. "To me, they're bread and butter."
Mr. Bloom, a cheerful, roostery man 67 years old, got into exterminating in 1960, when he took over Standard from his father-in-law. He runs it with his son, Gil, and employs 16 technicians. He's treated every imaginable place where creatures crawl -- air-traffic control towers at Kennedy International Airport, funeral parlors, sports stadiums, the lower deck of the George Washington Bridge. He wiped out fungus gnats inside the vaults of a jewelry company.
"No facility is pest-proof," he said the other day while holed up in his office. "If it were, and you walked in there with a cup of coffee in a paper bag, you just breached that pest-proof area. Because there is probably a roach inside the folds of that paper bag."
Cockroaches, which inhabit New York in infuriating density, remain the leading opponent of exterminators. They have been around for some 400 million years, give or take a few million, and each can bear thousands of offspring in its two-year lifespan. Roaches develop immunity to poisons, and thus scientists must concoct fresh poisons to combat them. Standard puts down a variety of organic phosphates and boric acids, and since the mid-1980's, amidinohydrazones have become popular for their success in abbreviating cockroaches' lives.
Still, the exterminating profession has some slipshod practitioners, known for waddling into an apartment and spraying along the bottoms of the walls and hoping for the best. They are mocked as "baseboard jockeys."
"You have to put the spray where the roaches are," Mr. Bloom explained. "That means in the cracks and crevices, not just along the baseboards.
"One of the things about this business today is you find roaches in places you didn't find them before," he said.
Mr. Bloom has encountered roaches in television sets and in the linings of a refrigerator. He has sprayed lottery machines at candy stores. Roaches are not fussy eaters. They can survive on toothpaste. They savor the grease from a refrigerator motor. They will settle for a decent toupee. If nothing tastier turns up, they'll eat the newsprint of the article you're now reading.
Mr. Bloom is all for recycling, but in his line of work recycling has meant aggravation. Garbage bags and empty cans make splendid homes for roaches. "People keep 30 or 40 bags lying around," Mr. Bloom said. "The glue that glued the bags together is food for roaches. There could be spilled coffee in a bag. As far as I know, roaches don't drink coffee, but they eat the sugar in the coffee. And the bag is warm and dark, just what roaches like.
"Empty cans are breeding grounds, too. No one washes the food residue out of empty cans. You're not going to put empty cans in the dishwasher, though you should. Beer cans are the worst. Roaches love beer. It's full of dense carbohydrates and roaches are big on heavy carbohydrates."
The blazing sun suffused the interior of Joe Entler's Chevy truck. He was heading east on the Grand Central Parkway, working the Jamaica-Queens Village route for Standard Exterminating. How does it compare with other areas? "It's full of bugs," he said.
Mr. Entler came to exterminating 13 years ago, after shimmying under cars as a mechanic for Mercedes-Benz. He admits it takes a while to become hardened to the life. When he began, he used to have recurrent "crawly" dreams, and he would dart home during the day to take showers. Now he's mellow about all the creatures he meets.
He does chafe at the environmentalists who denounce the chemicals exterminators put down. What's more, it annoys him that people are always holding their noses when he comes along, and yet they expect him to stampede over at 4 in the morning if they spy an ant crawling on the floor.
"You get nutty stuff in this job," Mr. Entler said. "Not with the insects. With the people. Last week, I went to a woman's house and she's screaming at me, 'Look at all the roaches crawling over the floor.' I look down and I see one roach. I tell you, a lot of this is public relations."
One change in extermination has been a shift toward low- or no-odor chemicals. The noisome odor of pesticides used to be a problem. The lack of odor is also a problem. "After we put down a no-odor spray, people call up and complain that, hey, nothing was done," Mr. Entler said. "They say we're just spraying water. So we have to explain that odor doesn't kill bugs."
 
A Bedbug Boom
 He rolled up to a recycling center, where he threw down poison for rats and mice and slapped down a few glueboards. If a mouse happens to scamper across a glueboard, it won't be going anywhere for a while.
Standard also treats construction sites. Rats like to dine on the seats of tractors and bulldozers in pursuit of the salt in the sweat of the operators who had been sitting on them. Bulldozer seats are not cheap.
Recently, Standard has seen a rise in bedbugs. "Bedbug jobs almost disappeared for 10 or 12 years," Mr. Bloom said. "In the last three years, we've seen a rise. It's a deterioration in personal hygiene -- not washing yourself and not washing your clothes."
Mr. Entler pulled up to a psychiatric hospital, where the head of maintenance was worrying. He had ants in one room, a wasp nest "big as a basketball" outside a third-floor window and wasps or bees or who knows what swarming around an entrance.
"Maybe they're cicada killers," Mr. Entler suggested.
"What?" the man said. "Psychotic killers?"
Just when you think you've got a building licked, you run into the holdouts. Standard calls these "reservoir apartments" because they become reservoirs of infestation. There are people who refuse to have their bugs wiped out because it is against their religion. Then there are individuals who are rather fond of pests. There was a man who used to cook food for the mice in his apartment. He would put music on for them.
Pigeons, squirrels and raccoons are also formidable New York problems. Sticky repellants that pigeons detest walking on will often ward them off. Squirrels and raccoons have to be trapped; Mr. Entler favors cat food as a bait. Standard treats a potato-chip company that receives large wooden crates of potatoes. Every now and then some snakes come along as a bonus. Glueboards spoil their day.
Mr. Entler stopped at a good-sized apartment house with a potential termite problem. He stalked through the basement, where, sure enough, termites had been holding a banquet on the wooden window frames. The building itself was brick, but if left untreated, the termites were likely to nibble away at the wood floors of the apartments. People on the fourth floor might wake up on the third floor. Standard has discovered termites in steel-and-glass skyscrapers, dining on phone books and toilet paper. In fact, termites will chew the label off a bottle of wine, polish off the cork -- and not even take a sip of the wine.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts a Slight Rise After Greenspan Comments

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose in cautious trading yesterday, supported by comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, but held in check by fears of central bank intervention.
Gold prices edged lower. In New York, gold fell 20 cents to close at $368.90 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $368.75, unchanged from Monday. 
 Mr. Greenspan told a House Banking subcommittee yesterday that the United States central bank would not move interest rates lower in the near future. He also said he found no evidence to suggest the recovering economy might slip back into recession.
His comments helped lift the dollar, which is strengthened by higher interest rates that increase foreign demand for American investments.
 
Threat of Intervention
 Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with the Bank of New York, said traders made a mild attempt to push the dollar higher, but that they were mindful that central banks, which intervened in the market on Friday to stop the dollar from surging, could band together again should the currency climb too much.
The market nudged the dollar past 1.800 German marks, but did not press further, and the dollar ended the day in New York at 1.8000 marks, up from 1.78895 on Monday. In earlier European trading, the dollar rose to 1.7980 marks from 1.7895.
The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen. In New York, the dollar advanced to 137.25 yen, from 136.935 on Monday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 136.95 yen, down 0.05 yen from Monday's close, and in London, it closed at 137.11 yen.
The British pound fell to $1.64305 in New York, from $1.65375 late Monday. In earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.6458 from $1.6510.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Monday's late prices, included: 1.56275 Swiss francs, up from 1.5483; 6.1070 French francs, up from 6.0745; 1,339.25 Italian lire, up from 1,332.00, and 1.1474 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1462.
In the precious metals market, gold fell in London to a late bid of $368.50, from $368.85 late Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $368.60, from $368.80 late Monday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold dropped $1.08 an ounce to close at $368.77.
Silver rose 1.5 cents to close at $4.367 a troy ounce. In London, silver fell to a late bid of $4.37, from $4.38 late Monday.

HEADLINE: Nationwide Revolution in Education Is Giving Handicapped a Headstart

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
In a landmark expansion of an educational mission that traditionally begins with kindergarten, all the states but two have committed themselves to providing extensive free preschool programs for handicapped children from 3 to 5 years old.
From Hawaii to Maine, school districts are identifying children who need special help and putting together teams of specialists to provide it. By July 1, all the states but Oregon and Alabama had qualified for Federal subsidies that will deliver millions of dollars to help pay for special classes and other services for children with learning disabilities, speech or language impairments, retardation or severe physical or emotional problems. 
 Many states, their budgets strained by recession, are having trouble coming up with their share of the money for these programs. And many schools are having trouble finding specialists to provide the services. Another problem is that diagnosing developmental problems in children so young is an inexact process, and it is therefore difficult to make decisions about precisely what services mildly handicapped children need.
But despite these obstacles, states are moving to comply as fully as they can because they are in danger of losing Federal financing if they do not.
 
A National Strategy
 Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, in Princeton, N.J., called the addition of the preschool program "a dramatic advance and the final step in a national education strategy that has been developing for over two decades" for disabled children. Dr. Boyer is chairman of an advisory committee to the National Governors Association on reaching the first of President Bush's six education goals: that by the year 2000 all children should start school ready to learn.
"Not long ago," Dr. Boyer added, "children who needed the most help were ineligible for any help. Now we've come full circle and children with handicaps are getting more help than other children."
As a result, Dr. Boyer and other educators predict, the widespread compliance with Federal law on preschool programs for the handicapped may be a milestone on the road to an even more ambitious goal: free and mandatory preschool education for every 3- through 5-year-old in the country.
The Federal preschool program also pushes public education further into the private domain. Until now, mandatory public education in this country began with first grade for 6-year-olds. Rather than start their own preschool programs, most school districts needing to serve handicapped children who are 5 years old and younger have contracted with private preschool programs to include those children in their regular classes. Visiting therapists and specialists then provide the children with extra help.
Decades of research show that the sooner a handicapped child receives help, the better off the youngster and the school budget are likely to be. Early intervention speeds recovery, reduces the need for special education services later and improves a child's chances of success in school and life. According to a 1985 study of Head Start, the Federally subsidized preschool program for poor children and handicapped children, every dollar invested in Head Start returns almost $5 in public savings.
But finding the money to begin with can be daunting. In Philadelphia, for example, the city and state are disputing which of them should pay for preschool programs for the handicapped, and city officials are openly advising parents to sue the state if they want a preschool program for their children.
"I don't want to sue the state -- I want a preschool for Nicholas," said Maria Sol Antonoulis, whose 3 1/2-year-old son is developmentally delayed in speech and motor skills.
Even though state and Federal laws now entitle Nicholas to a free preschool program, including sessions with speech, physical and occupational therapists, Philadelphia has nothing to offer. Mrs. Antonoulis and her husband, Constantinos, a restaurant manager, pay $270 a month to send their son to a private preschool program, but they cannot afford any therapy. They are considering moving out of the city to a suburban county that provides a complete program.
Such programs are expensive. In Pittsburgh, a local school district pays $7,000 a year to send Hailey Erdlen, a 4-year-old with Down syndrome, to a private preschool program for disabled children. "We would never have been able to afford preschool," said her mother, Lynn A. Erdlen.
 
A Proven Record Of Helping Disabled
 Private preschool programs have such a proven record for helping disabled children and saving education dollars in the long run that states have been phasing in the programs at an increasing pace since 1986. That year Congress greatly increased the financial incentives for establishing preschool programs, incentives first provided in the Education of the Handicapped Act of 1975.
Some pioneering states, including New Jersey, Connecticut, Iowa and Nebraska, using mostly their own funds, have provided preschool services to all disabled preschool children for more than a decade. But until now most states provided mandatory aid only to severely impaired 3- and 4-year olds, and limited supplementary assistance to disabled 5-year-olds in regular kindergarten classes.
To continue receiving Federal financing, states had to enact laws by July 1 that entitled every developmentally delayed or disabled child from 3 through 5 years old to a full range of therapeutic and preschool programs. These range in annual per-pupil cost from $5,800 a year for a typical state like Iowa to $14,700 in New York State, which has the nation's most expensive program. In the last year alone, 26 states enacted these laws, making the states eligible to receive about $1,100 a year per handicapped child in combined Federal grants.
Early help for handicapped children is considered by experts to be so critical that the 1986 Federal disability law also provided incentives for states to evaluate and treat children, from birth through 2 years old, who are deemed at risk of developmental delays or disabilities. All states are now phasing in this early intervention program and, within three years, states must offer comprehensive therapy to all eligible children to continue receiving Federal subsidies.
 
A Million Children May Be Eligible
 Nationwide, about 10 percent of all school-age children are enrolled in special education programs for the handicapped. Although no official estimates have been given for the number of preschoolers who will be eligible for the new comprehensive programs, if a similar percentage applies, about one million children would be eligible.
In the 1989-1990 school year, states provided some kind of services to 388,000 handicapped preschoolers, according to the latest Government report, which counted as services everything from a half-hour a week of speech therapy at home to full-day kindergarten programs.
Most states provided programs to whatever extent funds permitted; now states must provide each child with every service that a team of specialists prescribe in each child's individual education plan. States are required to seek out eligible children and provide services promptly, usually within 60 days of a parent's initial inquiry to the local school district.
States vary considerably in the number of disabled preschoolers they serve, but none reach 10 percent of the preschool-age population. Only Kentucky and Idaho served more than 6 percent of children of preschool age. Of those states with preschool programs for the handicapped, Hawaii served the fewest children, 752 preschoolers or 1.5 percent of the age group, and California, which mandated services just last year, served the most children, 37,000, or 2.6 percent of its preschool population.
Educators in a half-dozen states acknowledged that efforts to publicize the program had ranged from spotty to nonexistent. "In some parts of Texas people are not informed about what services are available," said Al Stewart, a spokesman for the state division of special education.
But Mr. Stewart also said that school districts served relatively few 3- and 4-year-olds, in part because parents tend to deny that their young children have impairments, and in part because it is difficult for specialists to identify mild impairments in such immature children.
 
Issue of Enforcement Touches Off Debate
 Advocates for the handicapped, who have lobbied for these preschool programs for years, applaud the Government's leadership. But they also criticize Federal officials for not authorizing stringent enforcement procedures.
"There is a long history in special education of nonenforcement by the Feds," said Thomas K. Gilhool, a former state secretary of education in Pennsylvania and a lawyer who specializes in issues concerning children with disabilities.
"I am sorry to disagree," said Robert R. Davila in response to Mr. Gilhool's criticism. Mr. Davila, the assistant United States Secretary of Education for the Office of Special Education and Rehabilitative Services, said: "States are scrambling to make whatever modifications and changes are required to come into compliance. And if a state is found in noncompliance, we will withhold funds for any part of the law that the state is not complying with."
Mr. Gilhool characterized as a "mirage" some state plans, including Pennsylvania's, to provide appropriate services to all eligible preschoolers.
Some states are beginning the program with so little money that it raises questions about whether their efforts will comply with Federal law. In South Carolina, the state's Department of Education requested $10.4 million for the preschool program this year, and the Legislature provided $1.6 million."We're just going to do the best we can," said Mary E. Ginn, a preschool consultant to the state's Department of Education.
California, which faces a $14 billion budget deficit for the fiscal year 1992, has started the mandatory preschool program, but gave itself an escape hatch if the program gets too expensive: a state law links state funds for the program to adequate Federal financing.
Congress has already shortchanged the states by providing only $293 million for the program this year, or about $60 million below target levels written in the 1986 Federal law, said Paul D. Hinkle, a spokesman for California's Division of Special Education. "Our Legislature is leery about getting into this program," he said.
Two states were so leery that they declined to participate in the program this year.
Oregon legislators, who are mopping up after a property tax revolt at the polls last November left the state education budget $630 million short, decided to postpone offering the full preschool program until after July 1992. The postponement will save the state $29 million, but force it to lose about $4 million in Federal grants. The state's program is now limited to severely disabled children, said Mike Bark, coordinator of the state's Early Intervention Services.
In Alabama, state legislators are still debating whether to mandate a statewide preschool program. Many school officials, still suffering from a 6.5 percent midyear reduction in state aid, oppose any expansion of preschool programs. "Our feeling is that if we can't fund the programs we already have, then maybe we don't need to begin a new program," said Don Fulbright, Superintendent of Schools in Clay County in central Alabama, one of the state's poorest school districts.
Even if states had no financial problems, they would be unable to provide adequate preschool programs to all handicapped preschoolers because of a nationwide shortage of special education teachers and therapists.
Government reports for the 1988-89 school year, the latest available, show that more than one in seven financed positions for special education preschool teachers is vacant, and there are very high vacancy rates, up to 60 percent, in positions for occupational, physical and speech therapists.
"Nothing much has changed since then because there hasn't been a lot of money put into university training programs," said Gloria L. Harbin, the associate director for the Carolina Policy Studies Program, a research organization at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill that is under Government contract to monitor the states' progress in providing services to preschoolers.
