HEADLINE: 2 Merging Banks Turn to Consumer Questions

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Now that Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover have decided to merge, they are beginning to deal with the issues that concern consumers, such as what interest rate to charge on bank credit cards (Chemical's are lower) and how much will a customer have to keep on deposit to have a no-fee checking account ("Manny Hanny's" $1,500 minimum or Chemical's $3,000.)
"We don't have any idea yet how we'll answer these questions," said Alan M. Silberstein, Chemical's executive vice president for consumer banking. 
 Such issues will not be settled until the banks officially merge early next year, the banks said. But just 24 hours after the merger announcement, customers calling hot lines yesterday were getting a few answers. Bank spokesmen sometimes referred to a question-and-answer sheet put together in anticipation of the biggest consumer concerns.
 
Deposit Insurance Questioned
 One answer was for the depositor who kept, say, $70,000 at Chemical and $60,000 at Manufacturers. The total once the banks merge -- $130,000 -- will exceed the $100,000 maximum amount covered by Federal deposit insurance. Neither Manufacturers Hanover nor Chemical wants the $30,000 excess to migrate to another bank, so they explained how deposit insurance could be preserved.
"We are telling people to put the money in different family names," said Judy Walsh, a Manufacturers spokeswoman. Under present law, a husband can have $100,000 insured in his name, his wife another $100,000 in her name and jointly they can keep on deposit still another $100,000 that is also insured. But these changes need not be made immediately; the law says that deposits insured before the merger will continue to be covered until six months after the merger is completed, or at least until mid-1992.
The really difficult issues arise from the natural tendency of neighboring banks to try to steal each other's customers by offering better deals. Thus Chemical Bank's credit cards -- Chem Plus, Chem Gold Card and a no-frills card -- currently charge interest rates ranging from 16 percent to 18.4 percent. The Manufacturers Hanover range on cards is 17.8 percent to 19.8 percent. Manny Hanny, on the other hand, requires that a customer keep only $1,500 on deposit to avoid a monthly checking-account fee, while the Chemical minimum is $3,000.
Rates on home equity loans, car loans, mortgages and many similar commercial loans also differ. Any long-term loan or certificate of deposit still outstanding on the day the two banks actually merge will be honored, terms unchanged. Only the rates and rules for new business "will have to be ironed out in the merger process," John Meyers, a Manny Hanny official, said.
 
What About Checks?
 Other problems are more easily solved, such as what to do when Manufacturers Hanover ceases to exist early next year and a customer still has 1,000 Manny Hanny checks with his name and address printed on them. Go right on using them until they are gone, then reorder. That is standard merger practice.
"Two or three years from now, checks with Manny Hanny's name will still be valid and still floating around," Mr. Silberstein said. "Many banks have gone out of existence in the last few years, and their checks still clear."
Mr. Silberstein said some callers were asking whether their local bank branch would be among the 80 to be closed, and if so, what should they do. The answer: Their accounts will automatically be transferred to a nearby branch, with no change in account number or password for Automatic Teller Machine cards.
Some 60 percent of depositors at Chemical and Manny Hanny use A.T.M. cards that work in either bank's machines, and many of them rarely visit a branch officer, the banks said.
Finally, the banks must figure out how to merge their back offices. Which one's computer system wil generate the monthly bank statements, the credit card bills and the numerous other calculations involved in banking?
"We haven't any idea," Mr. Silberstein said. "We have teams of people waiting to get together, as soon as they get the signal, to compare how the two operations work and to make suggestions to senior management."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the decision to merge behind them, Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover now are turning their attention to the needs of their retail customers. On Monday, after hearing of the merger, a customer at a Manufacturers Hanover branch in Manhattan questioned a teller about the deal. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: G.E. Net Climbs by 3.7% Despite Weakness at NBC

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The General Electric Company reported an earnings increase of 3.7 percent in the second quarter, bucking the recession and weakness at its NBC broadcasting network.
Earnings rose to $1.13 billion, or $1.30 a share, from $1.09 billion, or $1.22 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Sales in the quarter increased 2.8 percent, to $14.8 billion from $14.4 billion. 
 The per-share earnings were slightly better then analysts' consensus forecast of $1.29 a share. Nevertheless, the company's stock price declined $1.50 a share, to close at $73.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
John F. Welch Jr., G.E.'s chairman, attributed the increase to strong performances by the company'selectrical equipment, jet engine, medical device and financial services units. "Despite the U.S. recession and a weakening global economy, G.E.'s operating margin of 12.9 percent equaled the record margin recorded for the second quarter of 1990," Mr. Welch said in a statement.
 
Financial Services Unit
 He said the company's GE Financial Services unit increased earnings 16 percent over the 1990 quarter.
But he also said NBC was a drag on the company. "NBC had a significantly negative quarter-to-quarter comparison reflecting lower ratings and the weak advertising market," Mr. Welch said. The company said the unit remained profitable, however, and enjoyed "a modest increase in revenues" as a result of broadcasting the professional basketball playoff games.
G.E.'s earnings per share in the period were up 7 percent as a result of a stock buyback program announced a year and a half ago. The company said it bought back 2 million shares in the second quarter.
A company statement said the jet engine, electrical equipment and medical instrument segments had all received major orders in recent weeks. Orders for $4 billion in commercial jet engines were booked in the last 60 days and orders for medical instruments are running 15 percent ahead of the comparable period in 1990. The backlog for electrical equipment totaled $8.4 billion on June 30, compared with $7.8 billion at year-end 1990.
Profits at all three divisions were reported to be higher than last year.
G.E. said the strong results posted by financial services were assisted by "improved performance" by its Kidder Peabody and Employers Reinsurance units.
Profits from the home appliances division were reported to be "flat" on lower revenues as a result of a slump in demand in the United States.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The semiannual report by Alan Greenspan to Congress on the economy and monetary policy, normally an event of some note in the credit markets, was greeted with a yawn yesterday, and prices of Treasury securities were little changed in very slow trading.
In his remarks to a subcommittee of the House Banking Committee, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board painted a portrait of an economy climbing out of recession while inflationary pressures continued to moderate. 
 "He basically recapped what is a fairly broadly held consensus on the economy and inflation trends," said Joseph Liro, senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "The fact that he didn't break any new ground meant that his comments were not a catalyst of any significant change in the bond market."
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed in conducting monetary policy "has adapted a posture of watchful waiting" as economic data have increasingly suggested the economy is recovering.
 
Short-Term Interest Rates
 Traders interpreted those comments to mean that the Fed was highly unlikely to lower -- or raise -- short-term interest rates in coming months, and perhaps not for the balance of the year.
"He said that it's starting to look like a recovery, but that's what we want, and we won't try to abort it," said Robert Barbera, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers.
With Mr. Greenspan's testimony containing few surprises, traders said the market's focus shifted to the release today of consumer price data for June, as well as coping with huge amounts of new Treasury securities.
"In the next six weeks we either have an announcement of a new debt sale, or an auction," one government securities trader said. "That adds up to a lot of supply. And coping with that supply will be the issue confronting the market."
Today the Treasury is expected to announce the size of two-year and five-year note auctions to be held the week of July 22.
Between now and the end of the month the Treasury will sell another issue of new one-year notes, and will tell market participants how many securities it intends to sell at its quarterly refunding auctions in early August. All told, over the next six weeks the total could add up to more than $72 billion in new bills, notes and bonds.
"It's a big, big number," the trader said.
But the looming supply had little noticeable impact yesterday on price movements in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 15/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.44 percent, the same level as late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 9/32 in late trading, up 1/32, to yield 8.25 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/4, up 1/32, to yield 6.85 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved modestly higher.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.57 percent, up three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a like amount, to a late rate of 5.71 percent.
In other developments, the Resolution Trust Corporation priced its second offering of mortgage-backed securities through an underwriting group led by the First Boston Corporation.
The $579 million issue consists of adjustable rate mortgages from three California-based institutions in RTC conservatorship, the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, County Bank FSB and the Santa Barbara Savings and Loan Association.
The securities were sold in two parts, and for the first time were priced off the one-month London interbank offered rate, a feature that underwriters said allowed the securities to be offered to a broader investor base, including overseas buyers.
The first $437 million worth of the securities, which carry an average life of 2.1 years, were priced at 55 basis points above the prevailing one-month Libor rate at the time of pricing.
The remaining $142 million of securities, which have an average life of just over five years, were priced at 68 basis points above the prevailing yield on one-month Libor.
Rates on the securities will be reset monthly. The issue is rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Investment-Grade Bonds
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, South Carolina Electric and Gas offered $145 million worth of 15-year first mortgage bonds through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 percent bonds were priced at $99.55, to yield 9.055 percent, 80 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricig.
The securities, which mature July 15, 2006, are noncallable for life. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said an unexpectedly large increase of $1.029 billion in Citicorp's loan-loss reserves had a negative impact on prices of the banking company's outstanding debt obligations. Prices of some Citicorp securities fell by as much as 1 3/4 points after the company released its second quarter earnings report.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: Yields Off Slightly At Banks

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields were down slightly on certificates of deposit and money market accounts for the week ended yesterday.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., the midyear economic recovery so many had expected has not come, despite some rosy economic indicators. "A full recovery is still six to nine months away," said Robert K. Heady, the publisher. 
 Bank depositors may only experience a gradual or faint rise in rates during this period, analysts said.
 
Rates Narrowly Down
 At the Treasury Department's weekly auction on Monday, average discount rates were narrowly down. The three-month bill slipped two basis points, to 5.56 percent, while the six-month bill slipped a basis point, to 5.70 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The largest yield change at New York area banks this week was at the Bank of New York, which cut the yield of its money market account by 11 basis points, to 5.23 percent. The commercial bank also cut 16 basis points from its three-month certificate of deposit, to 5.55 percent. The Anchor Savings Bank raised the yield on its six-month certificate by 18 basis points, to 5.65 percent.
Among commercial banks, an average money market account fell by two basis points, to 5.15 percent, with three-month certificates off by a similar amount, to 5.45 percent. The longer, six-month certificate fell only by one basis point, to 5.64 percent.
 
Down by a Basis Point
 This week, depositors at savings institutions saw the average yield on a money market account and three-month certificate fall by one basis point, to 5.54 percent and 5.74 percent, respectively. The yield on a longer, six-month certificate did not change, remaining at 6.01 percent.
By comparison, at 20 large banks around the country, all of which are outside the New York market, the average money market yield was down two basis points, to 5.25 percent, while the average yield on a six-month certificate fell one basis point, to 5.70 percent.

HEADLINE: STRAUSS OPPOSES BROAD SOVIET AID

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Robert S. Strauss, the Ambassador-designate to Moscow, said today that he was opposed to providing the Soviet Union with a large-scale aid program, arguing at his Senate confirmation hearing that the Soviet Government remained too unwieldly to digest large amounts of assistance.
At a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing marked by joviality and soft questioning, the former Democratic Party chairman gave a skeptical assessment of the prospects for a smooth Soviet transition to democracy and capitalist development. He stressed that American business executives were justifiably cautious about investing in the Soviet Union. 
 "The economy is in free fall," Mr. Strauss said. "The bureaucracy is in decay. There is disillusionment among the people." Under such circumstances, "pouring money in there without something stronger in place would be like pouring it down a well."
"However," he added, "if they do begin to make the hard choices necessary to get economic reform on track, and if they keep democratizing and maintain their policy of cooperation, then I believe we should be prepared to respond, step by step, with assistance."
 
'Create Some Sprouts'
 Although he said "the U.S. Embassy ought to help American businesses make capital investments," Mr. Strauss rejected the view that there were business opportunities waiting to be seized on by imaginative American entrepeneurs. "What I hope to do is help start tiny projects where we can create some sprouts," he said. "That's the best I can hope to do."
Mr. Strauss has promised to step down from seven corporate boards and sell his stock in Pepsico and Archer Daniels Midland, two companies with substantial investments in the Soviet Union, should he be confirmed.
The 72-year-old Mr. Strauss, a former Carter Administration envoy responsible for trade and Middle Eastern affairs, conceded that he lacked expertise in Soviet affairs. "I do not speak Russian or any other native language of the Soviet peoples," he said. "I am not a specialist in Russian and Soviet history and culture. I have not traveled widely in the Soviet Union."
But Mr. Strauss suggested that he would be an activist Ambassador who would seek to broaden contacts with opposition figures, including leaders of the Baltic republics, whom he pointedly referred to as "heads of state." His priorities, he said, would include speaking out against "intimidation in the Baltics" and Soviet "support for Castro's brutality in Cuba."
Some senior Democrats have expressed disappointment that the former chairman of the their party would accept the diplomatic post just as the Democratic Party is revving up a difficult presidential campaign. Sen. Hank Brown, Republican of Colorado, said: "Republicans have been trying to stop Bob Strauss from raising money for the Democratic Party for years. I think we now have finally done it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert S. Strauss, Ambassador- designate to Moscow, listening to Senator Lloyd Bentsen introduce him at confirmation hearing. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Riegle Offers A Third Bill On Banking

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee introduced a plan today to revive the ailing banking system that would keep far more contraints on the industry than either the version proposed by the Bush Administration or the bill adopted last month by the House Banking Committee.
The outlines of the legislation emerged last week, but today Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, provided details, which he said represent "a consensus that accommodates the broad views of many of my colleagues." 
 The three measures would dramatically rearrange the banking landscape.
Mr. Riegle's measure is considerably more sympathetic to smaller banks, bank consumers of modest means and the insurance industry than either the House or Administration measures. It is harder than the other versions on money-center banks and many large investment banks.
 
Would Curb Interstate Moves
 The Senate measure, like the Administration and House banking versions, would eliminate barriers to interstate banking. But in the Senate measure, state lawmakers can, if they act within three years, forbid out-of-state banks to open branches in their jurisdictions.
Many of the key elements of Mr. Riegle's legislation have been embraced by the ranking Republican on the Banking Committee, Senator Jake Garn of Utah, although Mr. Garn is said to prefer giving regulators more authority to decide how to bail out banks. He also opposes a number of consumer-oriented provisions in the Riegle legislation that would require banks to offer basic services to poor people and cash checks issued by the Government, like those for medical benefits and Social Security.
So far this year, however, banking issues in Congress have generally not been decided along party lines. Anticipating that some committee members will want to change portions of the complex 559-page package, Mr. Riegle told reporters that he had not yet decided when the committee would vote on it.
"I'd like to do it before the August recess," he said, "but I don't know whether we will be able to do it or not."
 
Administration Cautious
 Giving the Administration response to the Riegle measure, Treasury Under Secretary Robert R. Glauber said, "We think it's good that it's as comprehensive as it is," but added, "Obviously there are elements that we would like to see changed."
The Federal banking laws under attack by the Administration and the House Banking Committee go back more than six decades, and were aimed at eliminating the speculative excesses that led to the banking crisis of the 1930's.
The Riegle measure would eliminate the Depression-era restrictions, imposed by the Glass-Steagall Act, that prevent commercial banks and investment banks from merging. But as a practical matter this would have limited impact on Wall Street because the measure upholds current restrictions on industrial ownership of commercial banks, and a number of Wall Street's largest investment banks are owned by industrial enterprises.
 
Special Assessment Proposed
 Mr. Riegle's legislation would also hit the money center banks, notably J. P. Morgan, harder than other banks by changing the formula for contributions to the rapidly dwindling fund that insures bank deposits. By some accounts, that fund is already virtually insolvent. Mr. Riegle has proposed that the first $10 billion that the fund borrows from taxpayers be repaid through a special assessment on banks that would be based on foreign deposits, as well as domestic deposits.
The proposed legislation also differs from the other versions by ending the Government's policy of bailing out banks considered "too big to fail." It would adopt other measures intended to discourage the Federal Reserve from lending money to ailing banks through the discount window.
Treasury officials are particularly unhappy with the Riegle provision that would remove from Treasury the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates nationally chartered banks, and the Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates savings associations, and convert them into a new independent agency.
"It would be a mistake," Mr. Glauber said. "The public expects the Government to have some influence over the reglators. This would strip it away."
For individual depositors, Mr. Riegle decided to abandon his earlier view of imposing some modest restrictions on the current law, which protects deposits of up to $100,000 but permits families to increase their coverage substantially through the use of joint and trust accounts.
The House bill also retains the existing law on individual coverage. The Administration had proposed eliminating the use of joint and trust accounts to increase coverage beyond $100,000 plus retirement accounts of up to $100,000 per person per bank.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., who yesterday intoduced his plan to revive the banking system. (Paul Conklin)

HEADLINE: A New Commodity to Be Traded: Government Permits for Pollution

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Ever searching for new ways to make markets and money, commodity exchanges have broadened their horizons from familiar products like soybeans and wheat to concepts like Eurodollar futures contracts that only a business school graduate could love. Now the nation's largest commodity mart has gone a step further, approving trading in Government permits to pollute.
The Chicago Board of Trade voted yesterday to create a private market for rights to emit sulfur dioxide. The rights are to be issued to electric utilities by the Environmental Protection Agency as part of Washington's strategy to reduce acid rain. 
 Besides providing a service to the electric power industry, such a market would allow trading by individuals, letting them stake investment money on a rise or fall in the value of pollution rights, much as they now speculate on stocks and bonds.
 
Offshoot of Clean Air Act
 Such a market was made possible by the Clean Air Act of 1990. In a departure from traditional regulatory practices, Congress gave polluters the right to meet sulfur emissions standards by buying and selling allowances that the Environmental Protection Agency will allot to individual plants.
While Federal officials are unwilling to comment on the Board of Trade initiative before they examine the details, there is every reason to believe the Bush Administration will hail the board's action.
Free-market proponents say they think the new market will make it cheaper and easier for utilities to do their part in reducing acid rain. "We are anxious to establish a bona fide private market," said William G. Rosenberg, an assistant administrator at the E.P.A. Initially, no Government approval is required for the trading.
 
Could Serve as a Model
Many environmental analysts say, moreover, that the new market could serve as a model for least-cost controls on other pollutants -- notably the smog-producing chemicals that bedevil most American cities. And it could presage a far more ambitious effort to limit emissions of gases that are widely thought to be warming the earth's atmosphere.
The Clean Air Act limits total emissions of sulfur dioxide gas from 110 power plants in 1995. Five years later, a much more stringent limit will force the industry to reduce emissions to less than half of the 1991 level. Dan Dudek, an economist at the Environmental Defense Fund who helped to draft the rules, argues that by allowing polluters to trade their emissions allowances, individual utilities in different markets with different types of power plants will not be locked into a single cleanup strategy.
One company may find that it pays to install smokestack scrubbers on aging coal-fired boilers, bringing its emissions below the requirements, and then sell the surplus allowances. Another may leave untouched a heavy sulfur polluter that is otherwise efficient, and will buy allowances to cover the excess emissions. Still another may subsidize customers' purchases of energy-efficient appliances and lighting equipment, thereby cutting electricity demand and permitting it to shut down its offending boilers.
But Richard Sandor, an executive managing director of Kidder, Peabody & Company, notes that the freedom to buy and sell allowances will not yield the maximum possible benefits unless utilities have an easy way to exchange them at a price that reflects the lowest possible cost of removing sulfur from the air. That is where the Chicago Board of Trade's initiative fits in.
 
Trading to Start in 1993
 Under the plan, the exchange will begin trading "cash forward" contracts in 1993 -- simple agreements to deliver allowances after they are issued in 1995. It will also ask the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for permission to establish a continuing "futures" market, permitting anyone to gamble on emissions rights in standardized 25-ton allotments up to three years in advance.
A utility might, for example, buy 100 contracts due in 1997, thereby nailing down the right to spew an extra 2,500 tons of sulfur dioxide that year. The seller might be another utility that is planning to close down an old coal plant in 1997. Or it might be a mutual fund run by a brokerage house, whose manager thinks the price of allowances will fall, and is prepared to risk clients' money on the bet.
Mr. Sandor estimates that contracts will initially trade at about $400 a ton and will fluctuate with factors ranging from the demand for electricity to the state of scrubber technology. The price could not rise above $2,000 because utilities always have the option of exceeding their legal emissions and paying a fine of $2,000 a ton.
Not everyone is convinced that the plan will work smoothly. John Palmisano, the president of Aer-X, a Wash ington firm that is a pioneer in the private trading of local pollution allowances for smog-creating chemicals, says he thinks the market will be hard to establish. Most of the exchanges in sulfur allowances, he suspects, will be made directly between utilities, in large blocks. He worries, moreover, that some state regulators will balk at allowing utilities to participate in a national market for pollution rights.
The volume of trading may be light by the standards of the Board of Trade, acknowledges Mr. Sandor, who drafted the proposal along with Philip Senechal, chief executive of the Bellefonte Lime Corporation in Bellefonte, Pa. On a typical day, futures representing 200,000 bushels of corn and 150,000 bushels of soybeans are traded on the exchange.
But computerized trading could be used to match buyers and sellers at low cost. And in any case, notes Jim Thompson, the former Governor of Illinois who, along with Mr. Sandor, served as co-chairman of the exchange committee analyzing emissions allowances, noted that "the Board of Trade has social benefits as well as members' profits in mind."
Those benefits could spill into market-based approaches to environmental regulation that are just now reaching the public agenda. Southern California regulators are pondering the wisdom of creating a computerized market for business permits to emit volatile organic chemicals. Dozens of other cities, hard-pressed to meet Federal air-quality standards, will also be seeking the least intrusive ways to regulate emissions of these smog-producing gases.
 
A Head Start
 Mr. Sandor said the Board of Trade's venture might prove invaluable both in designing these local markets for emissions permits and gaining legitimacy for the concept with local regulators. It would also give them a head start in producing computer software for operating such markets cheaply and fairly.
The experience could pay even greater dividends, should Washington decide to limit emissions of greenhouse gases as part of a global commitment to slow atmospheric warming. The principal greenhouse gases -- carbon dioxide, methane and refrigeration chemicals -- are emitted in large quantities by thousands of businesses. The possible means of mitigating their effects, everything from energy conservation to planting trees that trap carbon, are many and varied.
Mr. Dudek of the Environmental Defense Fund says that strategies for controlling greenhouse gases that try to second-guess private efforts are bound to be wasteful. His group is now pressing for legislation to limit utilities' emissions of carbon dioxide -- which could become more fodder for the Board of Trade.

HEADLINE: Dispute Over '90 Census Heads for Courts, Again

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
In 1988, New York City went to court to force the Federal Government to adjust the 1990 census count using a procedure that had never been tried. Today, the city is back in court, but this time as an advocate of a procedure that has now been found by Government experts to improve the count for most of the nation.
While Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher was making his rounds on Capitol Hill, defending his refusal to adjust the census before a friendly panel of Senators and a somewhat more skeptical House subcommittee, lawyers for New York and other cities were beginning their review of a new mountain of material that may bolster their case that their clients have been shortchanged in the census. 
 Mr. Mosbacher and the executive branch had their say on the issue on Monday. The Democrats who control Congress, including two important subcommittee chairmen, are split into unlikely factions by the politics of the numbers and seem unable to trump this decision with a veto-proof bill ordering an adjustment. That leaves the Federal court system as the final and most important stage, the place where the arcane and important drama of the census will have its denouement.
 
No Changes Soon
 Some things will not change, at least not soon. Mr. Mosbacher's decision makes it clear that 1992 Congressional and state legislative races, and the three state legislative races that take place in 1991, will be conducted on the basis of the raw census counts.
Any of the Federal funds given out to states and cities on the basis of population counts will use the original census figures, which showed that 248.7 million people lived in the country on April 1, 1990. Those funds are estimated to be about $59 billion annually, said Michael P. Murray, a professor at Bates College in Lewiston, Me.
The Census Bureau estimates that its counts are missing about five million people, but Mr. Mosbacher and his top aides at the Commerce Department say the missing people cannot be located with certainty and that this uncertainty makes it too risky to change a count based on the traditional methods.
The Constitution calls for an "enumeration" of the population. Wendell Willkie 2d, the Commerce Department's general counsel, told the Senate subcommittee on government information and regulation today that laws and court cases offer "very little guidance" on the legality of statistical adjustment of the count.
 
Plenty of Plaintiffs
 While a settlement was reached in 1989 on the cities' request for an injunction to force the Federal Government to prepare for an adjustment, the underlying suit was never withdrawn or dismissed, and now will be rejoined.
This means the plaintiffs and their lawyers now step back into leading roles in the drama, which has enough actors for a Cecil B. De Mille extravaganza.
The original list of plaintiffs was not small; it included New York City, the State of New York, Los Angeles, the State of California, Houston, Chicago, Dade County, Fla., the National League of Cities, the United States Conference of Mayors, the League of United Latin American Citizens, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and eight individuals.
As the problems with the original census became widely publicized, cities that feared undercounts lined up to join the fray. Joining the suit were the states of New Jersey, Florida and Texas and the cities of Phoenix; Cleveland; Denver; New Orleans; Oakland and Pasadena, Calif.; Philadelphia; San Antonio; San Francisco; Broward County, Fla., and Inglewood, Calif. -- by census measures, the most undercounted city in the country.
 
Next Step May Be Trial
 Peter Zimroth, a lawyer with the New York offices of the Washington law firm Arnold & Porter, said the next step was getting Judge Joseph M. McLaughlin of Federal District Court to agree to a trial on the issue.
The Justice Department has opposed a trial, and the legal discovery proceedings that would allow the plaintiffs to make extensive inquiries about the decision-making process. The department says that the judge should be able to rule on the basis of the voluminous material already submitted and the new record on which Mr. Mosbacher based his decision.
That material, about 15 pounds of documents released by the Commerce Department this afternoon, shows that seven people of a nine-member panel of census experts recommended adjustment and that Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant also told the Secretary that "I believe that statsitical adjustment, while far from a perfect procedure, will on average increase the accuracy of the 1990 census."
But she said there remained "2 percent of the population who cannot be reached by enumeration efforts."
Can those missing 5.3 million people be accurately located around the country through use of a post-census survey of 400,000 people? According to the calculations made by bureau experts and Michael R. Darby, Under Secretary for Economic Affairs at Commerce, two-thirds of the country lives in jurisdictions that would be made more accurate by adjustment.
Even so, "in my professional opinion," Mr. Darby wrote in his recommendation, "we do not have the tools at this point to improve the distribution" of the population over the original count.
His calculations and the bureau's showed that an adjustment would give some of the cities involved in the lawsuit -- including New York, Chicago, Phoenix, Houston and San Antonio -- more than their fair share of population and that their final counts would be less accurate than the original undercount.
One of the issues on which Judge McLaughlin will probably be asked to rule is whether the relative unfairness of such overcounts, the result of adjustment, is better or worse than the relative unfairness of the acknowledged undercounts.

Darby, Commerce Under Secretary, and Barbara Everitt Bryant, the director of the Census Bureau. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dow Stocks Slip by 6.71; Volume Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks edged lower yesterday, but trading picked up sharply.
Even the bank stocks, which enjoyed a one-day flurry Monday after Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover announced a merger plan, gave way. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 6.71, to 2,983.90, while the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index fell 0.85, to 381.54. Both declines were so inconclusive as to suggest that investors were not enthusiastic about either buying or selling.
Trading activity rose to 183 million shares, from 161.8 million the day before, but only 250,000 shares of yesterday's volume came in the additional hour of trading added in June. Big Board advances narrowly led declines, with 840 stocks rising in price while 755 fell.
Traders said that in view of the lagging economy, they wanted to get a better idea of second-quarter earnings before moving more heavily one way or the other.
 
Looking to Greenspan
 Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to whom investors look for guidance on interest rates, had little new to say in testimony before a House banking subcommittee yesterday, and as a result had only a minor impact on the market.
In remarks interpreted to mean that the Fed would not cut interest rates to stimulate the economy further, Mr. Greenspan said that on monetary policy, the central bank had "adopted a posture of watchful waiting as economic indicators have pointed increasingly toward recovery."
David M. Jones, chief economist for Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said, "Almost everything he said was anticipated in the bond market, so there was no follow-through to stocks."
"The economy's recovering," Mr. Jones said, "and that's what Greenspan emphasized. But we already knew that."
The Dow was choppy for most of the day, setting up a volatile market dear to the pocketbooks of Wall Street's program traders. The blue chips rose at the opening bell, immediately fell back, and rose again. By a little before noon, the Dow was in negative territory for the second time, but it steadily began fighting back. By 2:30 P.M., the Dow managed to edge into positive territory, only to drop precipitously in heavy program selling.
Birinyi Associates, which monitors computer-activated programs, spotted three selling waves that clipped the Dow 18 points. In the biggest wave, the Dow slid 12.5 points in a 27-minute selling spurt that began at 2:59 P.M.
Among the banks, Wells Fargo, which rose 6 1/4 on Monday in the euphoria over other possible bank mergers, lost 3 1/8, to 73 1/2. It reported substantially lower second-quarter profits. Most of the others changed only slightly, but Chase Manhattan, regarded as one of the strongest merger contenders, rose 3/8, to 20 1/4, after Monday's 1 7/8-point gain.
Chemical, whose name will survive in its merger with Manufacturers Hanover, fell 7/8, to 25 3/4, giving up part of its 2 3/4-point gain on Monday.
After the merger announcement, George Salem, banking analyst for Prudential Securities, recommended both Chemical and Manufacturers, and the Reuters news service quoted him as saying he had not recommended buying either in 20 years.
 
Big Percentage Gain
 In one of the biggest percentage gains on the Big Board, Triton Energy rose 4 3/4, or 19 percent, to 29 3/4, with 2.5 million shares changing hands. It rose 3 1/2 last week and 1 1/2 on Monday. Last Friday, British Petroleum told analysts of a big new oil discovery in Colombia in which Triton has a 20 percent interest. Monroe Helm of Morgan Stanley said the price could go to $38.
Steel stocks were strong, with Lukens, which reported record second-quarter profits, rising 3, to 47 1/8. Geneva Steel rose 2, to 19 1/4, after an Oppenheimer recommendation, and USX-U.S. Steel rose 1, to 24 5/8.
 
New I.B.M. Low
 Technology stocks had another bad day. I.B.M. fell 2 5/8 in heavy trading, to 96 5/8. It also sank during the day to a 52-week low of 96. Thomas Rooney of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette recommended sale of the stock before its second-quarter earnings report on Friday. He forecast that the company could report a loss by the third quarter.

HEADLINE: Summit in London;
Gorbachev's Big Gamble

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 16

 BODY:
In his special plea to the world's industrial powers, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is attempting one of the most ambitious strategies of an adaptive career: he is trying to move the withered economic heart of the Soviet domestic agenda into the theater of global politics, where he flourishes.
He has no such touch at home, where he faces cynicism toward himself and his reconstruction program. In turning to the world forum, he is seeking a morale lift from the world at large for the sagging national spirit, as much as traditional foreign aid. 
 With varying degrees of sympathy, the Group of Seven leading industrialized democracies will sit as a capitalist Round Table to hear out the irrepressible guest from the east, who was reported still pondering and editing his ultimate plea to the economic summit meeting as he arrived tonight.
In an advance token of the Group of Seven's concern, the group announced that it would introduce annual meetings between its chairman and the Soviet President. The group thus created a special status for Mr. Gorbachev, whose chief point in demanding an audience was that the Soviet Union retains superpower potential in a world of intermeshed economies.
 
Economic Hedges and Caveats
 But at that, President Gorbachev's credibility was being called into question even before he landed. His advance summary letter to the Group of Seven was criticized by some as being a sweeping but vague mix of free-market promises and imprecise timetables, lacking the substance to right a national economy now estimated by some Western experts to be reeling under an annual inflation rate in excess of 100 percent.
It is a rapidly shrinking economy of plummeting production, ballooning deficit and lost credibility symbolized by the tattered ruble. It is an economy haunted by the separate pressures from the nation's 15 republics to find greater power sharing and free market opportunities with Mr. Gorbachev's cooperation or without it.
"The rate of decline is fantastic," said Stanley Fischer, an economist with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who is involved in pressing on the Kremlin a high-speed plan for a radical free-market shift. Not even in the Great Depression in America was there a rate of collapse to rival what is now taking hold in the Soviet Union, according to Dr. Fischer, who warned that there is no time for further procrastination and well-meaning study by either Mr. Gorbachev or the Group of Seven.
On Wednesday, the Soviet President has the audience he pleaded for. The overnight mood of expectancy here was riveted on the mind of Mr. Gorbachev: Will he retreat from the critical free-market leap of faith, as he did last year, or will he come up with a convincing plan for dealing with the declining Soviet economy?
When last heard from, Mr. Gorbachev's enthusiastic talk of joining the world economy was hedged with several caveats about fully introducing private property and shackling the remains of the bureaucratic monolith of the Communist economy.
But perhaps the best indication of Mr. Gorbachev's intentions was the aide who did not accompany him to London tonight -- Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the free-market economist whose standing with Mr. Gorbachev is watched by the world as a kind of litmus test of whether the Soviet President has shed his past proclivity for compromising too much with Communist tradition in making his vows for a free-market future.
 
Sense of Urgency
 At last report, Mr. Yavlinsky chose to stay in Moscow in what was seen as a protest.
But Mr. Gorbachev first made believers of the world when he stepped up to the global table and began making disarmament credible. Now he is back at the table with a different agenda, the need to make the end of economic Communism believable in order to finally lead his mammoth nation away from collapse and toward a share of the world's prosperity.
His task touches countless factors beyond the terrible reality of the careering Soviet economy. Those range from the complex political needs of the Group of Seven leaders -- their separate budget constraints and electoral anxieties -- to the simple image of the beggar's bowl that one Soviet newspaper depicted poignantly waiting for Mr. Gorbachev amid a banquet table set sumptuously for seven.
All that, plus an undeniable sense of urgency, is in the air as Mr. Gorbachev gets his audience.
"No one can say what the results will be, but even now we have achieved a great result in the very fact of Gorbachev meeting with the G-7," said Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir I. Shcherbakov. "This is a historic achievement."

HEADLINE: Coalition to Aid Dinkins Seems To Break Away

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
A liberal, labor and minority coalition that began several weeks ago as an effort to strengthen Mayor David N. Dinkins's hand in dealing with the newly empowered New York City Council and the city budget is now apparently breaking with the Mayor because of his budget cuts affecting city workers and social-welfare programs.
Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union -- a coalition leader, along with his close friend, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch -- has said the group "is not a Dinkins coalition." 
 The group, he predicted, "will come forward with programs inconsistent with the Dinkins administration," including proposals for higher commuter taxes, no layoffs and the taxing of Columbia University and other institutions that are tax exempt.
Unlike the outspoken Mr. Rivera, many City Council candidates, still collecting nominating petitions due to be filed by next Monday, were wary of antagonizing City Hall and thus cautious in assessing the impact of the Mayor on the coming primaries and elections.
 
'Very Divisive'
 Some privately agreed with Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens that Mr. Dinkins would be a political albatross for them. But others, particularly in minority areas, echoed Mr. Lynch, who contended that the Mayor's support would be an asset.
"To some degree, the Mayor will be very divisive," said Mr. Rivera who was a major figure in the Dinkins mayoral campaign. He said the hiring of Hulbert James, a City Hall aide of Mr. Lynch, as the coalition's executive director was not further evidence of a Dinkins connection. "He was an activist long before he was associated with David Dinkins," Mr. Rivera said.
The coalition had billed its formation as an effort to elect enough pro-Dinkins members to the expanded Council to give the Mayor more leverage against Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and his mostly middle-class Democratic organization allies in the Council.
Now, the coalition leaders are confronted with the political and fiscal reality that the Mayor and Mr. Vallone teamed up to pass a budget that represented a compromise. It struck a balance between higher taxes on income and real estate that most affect the middle and upper economic classes, and cuts in social-welfare programs and municipal worker layoffs, whose impact is primarily on the lower end of the economic spectrum, the constituents of the coalition -- particularly labor and minority leaders.
Even before the coalition's distancing from the Mayor, some critics questioned whether the group is a paper tiger. Henry Stern, president of the nonpartisan Citizens Union civic group, noted the absence of such politically influential unions as District Council 37 of the municipal workers' union, the teachers' union and the teamsters' union that were critical elements of the Dinkins victory in 1989.
"It's puzzling to announce a coalition that just calls attention to how many of the old partners aren't there," he said.
The informal coalition, which includes Borough President Ruth W. Messinger and Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, both of Manhattan, and Representative Major Owens of Brooklyn, is putting together a liberal policy statement to emphasize restoration and expansion of social-welfare programs and city services and serve as a platform for Council candidates to be endorsed and helped by the group.
Ms. Messinger, citing the "grueling budget process," said the coalition would de-emphasize the Mayor and concentrate on electing "a more diversified, full-time Council interested in solving the city's long-term problems."
 
'Very Dangerous Position'
 Coalition members and critics acknowledged that identification with the Mayor could be a handicap to Council candidates in many districts. "The Mayor would be in a very dangerous position if he turned this into a referendum, " Councilman McCaffrey said.
Sam Meyers, president of Local 259 of the United Automobile Workers, conceded that there "has been some shifting" in the coalition goals. "If we're going to fault the Council, we can't allow Dinkins to go without criticism," he said.
Another coalition labor leader, Arthur Cheliotes of the Communications Workers, said he was "troubled with the ongoing relationship with Bill Lynch," who is so closely identified with the Mayor. He and Mr. Rivera agreed that Mr. Lynch might be put in the position of choosing between the Mayor and the coalition.
Mr. Lynch said his choice would be the Mayor, but he hoped "we can work out any differences" with the coalition.
Two other major labor leaders in the Dinkins mayoral campaign -- Stanley Hill of the municipal workers' union and Barry Feinstein of the teamsters -- have refused to join the coalition, contending that they are satisfied with the Council and its leadership.
"They've been doing fine," Mr. Hill said.
"I would fight any attempt to make the Council beholden to the Mayor," Mr. Feinstein said. He added that he still considered the coalition a Dinkins front despite the new disclaimers. "If it looks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's a duck," he said.

HEADLINE: Weicker Goes On TV to Press For Income Tax

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 16

 BODY:
In an unusual prime-time televised speech from the Governor's mansion, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. conceded tonight that his budget plans had failed to win over the legislature and appealed to residents to end Connecticut's drawn-out fiscal crisis by pressuring their representatives to accept an income tax.
He appeared to be digging in his heels in his battle with the legislature and gave no hint that he was ready to drop his insistence on a plan that most of the lawmakers have never even come close to accepting. 
 He urged state residents and lawmakers to accept the "bitter pill" of his budget plan, even though the non-income-tax alternatives offered by the legislature might seem more appealing on the surface.
"The choice is between what works and what feels good," he said.
 
'A Fair Compromise'
 He also offered what he called "a fair compromise" to automatically end the income tax in December 1993 and threatened to impose deep but unspecified spending cuts if lawmakers insisted on passing over his objections a "dishonest" budget.
"What you insist upon will happen," he told residents in a sometimes angry and emotional 15-minute address. "Families and friends of Connecticut, you're not out of the loop on this budget business."
But the speech appeared to fall flat among lawmakers, who administration officials said earlier in the day were one of the main targets of the address.
Leaders in the legislature, including even some of those sympathetic to Mr. Weicker's views on the tax system, dismissed the speech as contributing nothing new or providing no help to resolve the crisis that has gripped the state government since July 1 without a budget. Others said the Governor's harsh criticism of the legislature, which he called "the gang that couldn't count straight," would damage whatever good will he still has among lawmakers.
"The Governor has taken his one last shot at trying to convince somebody," said the House minority leader, Representative Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., Republican of Bristol, an income-tax opponent. "The public will certainly reject this latest proposal as well."
 
Too Little, Too Late
 The Speaker of the House, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat who supports the income tax, said the so-called sunset provision for ending the tax at the end of 1993 was "nothing new" and said the proposals were really too little, too late. "I don't really see it going anywhere," he said. "I wish I were wrong."
In many ways it was a crucial speech for Mr. Weicker, given at a moment that hangs heavy with possible long-term implications for both the state and his six-month-old administration.
Just 24 hours earlier, Senate Democrats killed what many lawmakers believe was the last possible budget compromise that would include an income tax. And as the lawmakers continued their meetings at the Capitol today, there was a palpable sense of despair in many voices and renewed resignation that the only way out may be to simply thwart Mr. Weicker and override his most recent budget veto.
 
Revenue Overhaul
 Mr. Weicker has vetoed two non-income-tax budgets over the last six weeks, most recently on July 1, when he killed the legislature's budget as his first official act of the new fiscal year. He proposed earlier this year a sweeping revenue overhaul that would lower most of the state's existing taxes as a way to stimulate the economy, then make up the difference with a 6 percent flat income tax, later amended to a 6.75 percent progressive-rate tax.
Connecticut is one of only 10 states with no tax on wages, though it does tax income earned from dividends, interest and capital gains.
An override vote, which would require a two-thirds majority in both the House and the Senate, would avoid the income tax and resolve the state's huge revenue shortfall instead through a huge expansion of the existing revenue system. The 8 percent sales tax in particular, already the highest statewide rate in the nation, would be applied to millions of new transactions, from car repairs to dry-cleaning services and taxi rides.
 
An 'Unemployment Act'
 The plan includes about $1 billion in new taxes. Mr. Weicker has called it an "unemployment act" that would cripple the state's already weak economy.
Lawmakers say that overriding Mr. Weicker's July 1 budget veto would also resolve in the bitterest possible way the tensions that have simmered for months between the Democratic-controlled legislature and Mr. Weicker's independent third-party executive branch and would kill perhaps for years the hopes, especially among many Democrats, to overhaul a tax structure that they say is unfair to the poor. Next year is an election year for almost every member of the 187-member General Assembly.
"I don't think anybody at this point has any new twists," said the Senate President pro tem, John B. Larson, an anti-income-tax Democrat from East Hartford. He said he would push to override the veto as early as Thursday.
The House Speaker, Mr. Balducci, said he believed that many lawmakers would be "upset" by the critical tone directed at the legislature. He said that the sunset provision ending the income tax was considered months ago and dismissed, but that, in fairness to the Governor, he would bring it forth again on Wednesday at the party caucuses.

HEADLINE: Summit in London;
7 Nations Voice Support for Gorbachev

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 16

 BODY:
On the eve of their potentially pivotal meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the heads of the seven leading industrialized democracies voiced support today for his reform efforts, agreed to special status for Moscow in the International Monetary Fund and promised that their chairman would meet each year with the current Soviet leader.
But as Mr. Gorbachev arrived in London, reportedly with fresh economic proposals in his briefcase, Western leaders were still divided on just how far they were willing to go to help the Soviet Union, short of immediate large-scale infusions of cash, which they have all ruled out as impractical. 
 The very fact of Mr. Gorbachev's coming in search of help from his erstwhile adversaries has made this a unique meeting, something that would have been unthinkable a few years ago.
 
Moscow's Main Backer: Germany
 Germany, which has been the Soviet Union's main supporter during the summit conference here, kept pushing for more than technical aid.
The Germans were backed by France and Italy, but others were less enthusiastic, and a senior British official said the United States was "behaving in a most obstinate way, making it hard to assemble a package."
What has been agreed to so far, said Gianni De Michelis, the Italian Foreign Minister, "is not enough" to match so momentous an occasion. He insisted at a briefing tonight that "we must launch some new signal" of commitment to Soviet well-being and, by implication, to Mr. Gorbachev's political survival.
 
Few Specifics From Baker
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d responded that Mr. Gorbachev "will not leave empty-handed," but he offered few specifics other than promising expert advice and small grants from the West to help the Soviet Union reform its archaic food distribution system, attract investments in oil and gas and convert its defense industries to civilian use.
In their annual political declaration, the seven leaders set out a number of proposals designed to foster "a peaceful, just, democratic and prosperous world." Most of the proposals grew out of the war in the Persian Gulf and reflected the successful use of the United Nations, once seemingly moribund, as a vehicle for joint international action. [Excerpts, page A10.]
The seven called for a stronger peacekeeping role for the United Nations as well as improved United Nations relief services and urged the establishment of an international register of arms sales, but stopped short of advocating even a temporary ban on such sales in troubled areas. The group also backed United States efforts to promote a Middle East peace conference and to insure that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq cannot develop nuclear weapons.
"We are going to make sure, one way or another, that Iraq does not become -- does not even create the danger of becoming -- a nuclear power," said Douglas Hurd, the British Foreign Secretary, in presenting the group's declaration. Asked whether that meant his country would join the United States in military action if needed, he answered, "Yes, it does mean that."
At their meeting this afternoon, the leaders took up environmental questions, with Prime Minister John Major of Britain pressing Mr. Bush hard to set targets for reductions of carbon dioxide emissions from vehicle exhaust and industrial pollution, which the President has so far been unwilling to do. Mr. Major also called, amid some skepticism, for all the leaders to agree to attend next year's United Nations summit conference on the environment.
 
Sparring Over Trade
 The seven nations -- France, Italy, Canada, Japan, Britain, Germany and the United States -- also continued to spar over the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Negotiations to expand and strengthen GATT have been stalled for years, and no more than a plea for redoubled efforts to get an agreement in the next 12 months is likely to emerge from here.
After the final formal session of the summit conference on Wednesday, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will sit down for lunch together, and American officials hope that they will be able to agree on a date for a superpower summit meeting in Moscow later this month or early in August. That will depend in part on whether Secretary of State Baker and Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Soviet Foreign Minister, can find a way at their talks, also on Wednesday, to resolve the last technical issue barring a strategic arms reduction treaty.
Mr. Baker cautioned that there was no guarantee that a deal could be concluded here this week.
Praising Mr. Gorbachev's goals of political and economic change, the document issued by the seven leaders said, "Our support for the process of fundamental reform in the Soviet Union remains as strong as ever."
In a 23-page letter sent last week to the conferees, Mr. Gorbachev said he was "pinning high hopes on the upcoming meeting in London." He said he feared that without Western aid, the bleak Soviet economic outlook could lead to "major social conflicts and pose a threat to democratic reform."
 
Gorbachev's Plans Criticized
 But the plans for introducing a market economy outlined in the letter have been criticized as too nebulous to justify Western aid by several of the governments represented here. Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the co-author of a more ambitious reform program, said in Moscow that he had refused to accompany Mr. Gorbachev to protest what he termed the "imprecise nature" of the plans.
Leonid M. Zamyatin, the Soviet Ambassador in London, said Mr. Gorbachev would "add many things" to his written text once he sat down for three hours of conversation with the seven leaders on Wednesday. The diplomat added, "He will answer their questions, and he will ask some of his own."
Membership for Moscow in the International Monetary Fund, of a limited character still to be worked out, and access to larger loans from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development were among the gestures to the Soviet Union that the leaders reportedly discussed in detail today. Dieter Vogel, the German spokesman, said that only the United States and Japan had argued against increasing the Soviet borrowing quota from the European bank.
"There is still disagreement about how to follow up" with direct financial support, the German Finance Minister, Jurgen Mollemann, said late this afternoon. The Germans want to set up a working group within the 24-nation Organization for European Cooperation and Development in Paris to coordinate support for the Soviet Union, but the United States opposes that on the grounds that it would create pressure for assistance before that was wise.
 
Dispute Over Fund Membership
 The United States was also reported by the Europeans to oppose promising the Soviet Union now that it would soon be given full membership in the monetary fund. With evident exasperation, Mr. De Michelis said tonight that he and his continental European colleagues could not understand why the United States insisted on denying full membership to the Soviet Union when "107 other countries already are in."
In proposing a broader role for the United Nations, the seven leaders said the world organization "showed during the gulf crisis that it could fulfill its role of acting to restore international peace" and argued that "the international community must now build on this new spirit of cooperation not only in the Middle East, but wherever danger and conflict threaten."
The conferees pledged themselves to make "preventive diplomacy a top priority" within the United Nations and urged the appointment of a high-level official at the organization to make its relief operations more effective.
In the postwar Middle East, the seven nations declared, sanctions should be maintained against Iraq not only until it had met the terms of United Nations resolutions, but also until "the people of Iraq as well as their neighbors can live without fear of intimidation, repression or attack." That seemed to imply that the sanctions would last until President Hussein had been ousted.
 
Putting Pressure on Israel
With Mr. Baker planning to return to the Middle East later this week on his fifth trip since the war ended, the leaders stepped up the pressure on Israel, urging it to join Syria in agreeing to peace talks. They also said that the Arab boycott of businesses trading with Israel should end and called for the end of Israeli settlements in occupied territories.
The proposal for an international arms register was included in a separate statement, reflecting the difficulty in reaching agreement. France, which has historically resisted turning the Group of Seven into anything even vaguely bureaucratic or institutional, held out until Mr. Major agreed to drop any role for the group in setting up or monitoring the register. Instead, the group supported a United Nations register of all arms sales to "alert the international community to an attempt by a state to build up holdings of conventional weapons beyond a reasonable level." Another Iraq must be avoided, members said.
But the problems with such a register would be numerous. Cheating would not be difficult for secretive and often duplicitous arms dealers, and no means of enforcing notification to the register were specified. Moreover, "a reasonable level" of armaments would be a highly subjective judgment.
 
Argument Over the Environment
 Some of the hottest exchanges reported by officials present at the closed sessions today dealt with the environment. Mr. Bush has already come under attack in Britain from Michael Heseltine, the Environment Minister, for resisting stricter curbs on carbon dioxide emissions, and today Laurens Binkhorst, the European Commmunity's Director General for the Environment, said the United States, "which emits twice as much CO 2per capita as anyone except the Eastern European countries," needed to rethink its position in the next few months.
The Bush Administration, and especially John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, have expressed deep suspicions about the contention, accepted by the European governments, that carbon dioxide is the principal factor in causing global warming. Hoping to avoid being branded anti-environment, the United States has circulated brochures here listing its accomplishments in the last year.

HEADLINE: SENATE COMMITTEE DELAYS HEARINGS ON C.I.A. NOMINEE

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
The Senate Intelligence Committee today delayed until mid-September confirmation hearings on the nomination of Robert M. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence, a serious but not necessarily fatal setback for Mr. Gates.
The committee said the postponement was needed for it to investigate whether Mr. Gates, President Bush's deputy national security adviser, knew more than he has acknowledged about the Iran-contra affair when he served as deputy C.I.A. director in 1986. The extra time also gives the committee a chance to examine other potentially troublesome issues that have surfaced in recent days. 
 The delay may prove costly to Mr. Gates because it exposes him to two more months of questions and the potential for new disclosures while he waits until September to make a formal, sworn response before the committee.
 
Embarrassment for Bush
 For Mr. Gates, a further loss of momentum toward confirmation raises the possibility that his support in the Senate will wither and that he will face the same fate he suffered more than four years ago when he withdrew his nomination for the same post amid unanswered questions about his role in the then-unfolding Iran-contra affair.
The postponement was reluctantly agreed to by the White House, but was an embarrassment for Mr. Bush, who has severely criticized the committee for foot-dragging and lobbied its members to confirm Mr. Gates quickly. Mr. Bush has argued, correctly so far, that there is no hard evidence to automatically disqualify Mr. Gates from winning confirmation.
Senior Administration officials acknowledged that the White House and crucial Republican lawmakers had been split on how wise it was to push for early hearings and that today's decision by the committee leaves them divided about what strategy to pursue now.
"There are many explanations about what the delay means," said a senior Administration official involved in the process, "but certainly it's not a positive development or the best scenario for Gates. There are those who believe that it's over except for the fat lady singing, that we've given in to these guys. There are others who say that we just have to let the committee work for another few weeks and then press forward again. The only strategy we have forged for now is to wait."
In announcing the delay after a closed-door meeting of the committee this afternoon, the committee chairman, Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, said the decision was made with the concurrence of Mr. Bush and Mr. Gates. "The committee's scheduling decision should in no way imply a negative attitude toward the nomination," Mr. Boren said, "but simply reflects the committee's responsibility to the Senate and the American people to be as thorough as possible."
 
'A Covey of Quail'
 The announcement came just four days after Mr. Bush demanded "fair play" for Mr. Gates, arguing at a news conference in Kennebunkport, Me., that a delay in the confirmation hearings was improper because it allowed time for rumors and innuendo.
Mr. Bush's attack on the committee, particularly his accusation that its members should not "panic and run like a covey of quail" when confronted with new allegations, was in sharp contrast to his laudatory remarks about the committee on May 14 when he announced Mr. Gates's nomination.
The President's criticism continued today, committee members said, with a statement read to the panel that complained of an unnecessary "start and stop" delay on the hearings.
Senator Dennis DeConcini, an Arizona Democrat who sits on the committee, said, "The President has put the nomination in more trouble, and it might not have happened if he hadn't started calling us names for no good reason."
Accusing Mr. Bush of "boisterous demagoging" and playing politics, Mr. DeConcini added, "If he had read all the testimony we have, he would concur that we have not stonewalled and we are not a covey of quail."
Mr. Bush's official statement to the committee was released later today in London, where the President is attending a meeting of the seven major economic powers. Its tone was milder than that of the draft read to the committee, said Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio.
 
Long Interval for Nominee
 The official statement explained that although the White House concurred in the decision to delay the hearings there were still "concerns" that a drawn-out confirmation process would be unfair to Mr. Gates, and it urged the committee to move forward "expeditiously and without interruption."
The interval between Mr. Gates's nomination and completion of the confirmation process already promises to be one of the longest, if not the longest, since the C.I.A. was established in 1947. Most nominees for Director of Central Intelligence have been approved by the Senate within a month to six weeks of their selection by the President. Those who have withdrawn in the face of opposition, including Mr. Gates in 1987 and Theodore C. Sorensen, who was named by President Jimmy Carter in 1976, have done so quickly.
If the committee begins its hearings in mid-September, it would be four months after Mr. Bush nominated Mr. Gates, with further delay possible before the panel votes and the nomination is taken up by the full Senate. William H. Webster, the current Director, has said he will remain on the job until a successor is confirmed.
The date for beginning the hearings was a compromise between the White House and the committee after lengthy consultations that included lawmakers on and off the committee, Administration lawyers and Mr. Gates.
The committee resisted the President's request to vote on Mr. Gates's nomination before Congress's August recess. But it essentially agreed that if Mr. Bush insisted it would begin the hearings this month, with the understanding that they would probably have to be interrupted so crucial witnesses could be called to testify. When it became apparent that the committee would not agree to complete the hearings or vote until sometime in the fall, the White House was faced with a dilemma: have a lengthy, indefinite gap in the midst of the hearings or agree to a delay.
Some lawmakers, like the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, argued for the hearings to begin immediately. "I feel strongly that Bob Gates is a victim," Mr. Dole said. "It's unfortunate that the hearings will be postponed."
 
Comparison With Tower
 But the view of other senators, particularly William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, prevailed. In discussions with Mr. Gates, senior White House officials and committee members, Senator Cohen, who until January was vice chairman of the Intelligence Committee, argued that to begin a process that would have to be interrupted would subject Mr. Gates to the same kind of problems that plagued John G. Tower when he was under consideration as Secretary of Defense.
"I argued that Gates could be left twisting in the wind for months," said Mr. Cohen, who is no longer on the committee. "In effect what you'd be doing is putting Bob Gates out there like in the Tower nomination, which just went on and on and on with more allegations and no prospect of it being completed in a reasonable timeframe."
As part of its effort to gather as much information as possible about Mr. Gates's knowledge of the Iran-contra affair, Mr. Boren said, the committee also voted today to grant immunity from prosecution to Alan D. Fiers Jr., the former C.I.A. official who pleaded guilty last week to withholding information from Congress about the secret arms sales to Iran and the illegal diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels.
Mr. Boren added that the committee would also subpoena two officials whom Mr. Fiers said he told about the arrangements: Clair E. George, who was deputy of operations for the C.I.A. at the time, and Jerry Gruner, a C.I.A. official who was chief of the agency's Latin American division.
Mr. Gruner now serves in an overseas post for the agency, and until today he had not been clearly identified in connection with the Iran-contra affair. Mr. George has left the agency and is working as a security consultant.
 
A New Allegation
 The committee had originally hoped to begin hearings last Monday, and the delay has already produced new allegations that touch Mr. Gates.
Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, for example, urged today that the Senate defer action on the nomination until the C.I.A. answered questions about its involvement with the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, which was seized this month by international regulators. He said Senate investigators learned that in 1988 Mr. Gates, as deputy director of the C.I.A., released to the United States Commissioner of Customs an agency memorandum about the bank's activities.
Mr. Kerry said Mr. Gates had "apparent knowledge about the bank's activities" like money-laundering before law-enforcement agencies did.
Mr. Gruner did not testify to Congress during its investigation of the Iran-contra affair. But lawyers closely following the investigation said that in appearances before a grand jury in 1987 and earlier this year he has acknowledged that Mr. Fiers told him about the diversion. Mr. Gruner has said, however, the discussion with Mr. Fiers occurred later, in October or November.
Mr. Gruner's lawyer, William Hundley, said today: "We would very much like to cooperate the the committee. But we would urge the committee to hold off as long as they can until my client's status is clear with the independent prosecutor."

Lopez/The New York Times) (pg. A18)
