HEADLINE: Profits Fall At Citicorp In Quarter

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
As a second wave of big banks reported earnings yesterday, results for the second quarter continued to be generally weak. Citicorp, the nation's largest bank, said that its earnings for the period plummeted 83 percent.
On the West Coast, Wells Fargo and Security Pacific also reported sharp declines for the three months. Meanwhile, Banc One, a big Midwest bank, showed a gain. 
 Despite the relative weakness of the earnings, Ronald I. Mandle, a bank analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said the industry's nonperforming assets might finally be reaching their high point.
Following are the details of the banks' results:
 
Citicorp
 Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said its second-quarter earnings fell to $43 million, after a $48 million charge related to the sale of its municipal-bond insurance division.
The earnings compared with profits of $248 million, or 64 cents a share, in last year's second quarter.
When dividends on preferred stock are deducted from the final net income, however, Citicorp had a $9 million loss in the quarter.
A big factor was a hefty addition to Citicorp's loan-loss reserves of $1 billion, up from $473 million in the comparable quarter last year. The latest addition, together with chargeoffs of $1.68 billion, much of which were needed to cover problem loans to the third world, brought the bank's total loan-loss reserves up to $3.9 billion.
But the earnings news did not hurt the price of Citicorp's stock, which closed up 12.5 cents, to $14.875 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts pointed out that Citicorp, based in New York, had reduced operating expenses by about $113 million, or 4 percent, in the second quarter from the same quarter last year. Analysts said aggressive cutbacks had reduced worldwide employment at the bank by about 5 percent.
 
Wells Fargo
 Wells Fargo said it earned $14 million, or 21 cents a share, compared with $232 million, or $4.40 a share, in the second quarter of 1990. Last year's quarter included a $69 million extraordinary gain related to a joint venture with Nikko Securities.
Although Wells Fargo had predicted that its second-quarter performance would be poor, the market expressed its displeasure. The stock fell $3.125 a share yesterday, to $73.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Continued speculation about possible mergers in the banking sector caused the stock to rise $6.25 the day before.
Of greatest concern to investors seemed to be the $400 million increase in nonperforming assets at Wells Fargo, which brought the bank's total to $2 billion. Loan-loss chargeoffs, the amount the bank actually has to write off in any quarter, also shot up in the second quarter, to $183 million, from $45 million in the period last year.
The chairman and chief executive of the San Francisco bank hinted of more bad news to come. "Because of continuing uncertainties in the economy and the banking environment, we cannot be sure that further significant increases in the allowance for loan losses will not be required," Carl E. Reichardt said in a statement.
 
Security Pacific
 The Security Pacific Corporation, also afflicted by weaknesses in its loan portfolio, reported earnings of $46.7 million, or 30 cents a share, down 76 percent from the $195.2 million, or $1.59 a share, it reported a year earlier.
In addition, the Los Angeles-based bank said it had added $409 million to its loan-loss reserves, versus the $161 million it set aside in the same quarter of 1990. Nonperforming assets rose to $3.9 billion, up sharply from the $2.4 billion it reported a year earlier and the $3.2 billion it had in the first quarter.
Over all, the earnings came very close to what the bank had predicted.
"The nonperformers were in line with what they said they'd be, but the loan-loss provision was a bit higher than what they'd said," said Mr. Mandle, of Sanford Bernstein.
The company's stock fell 75 cents on the New York Stock Exchange, to $23.875.
 
Mellon Bank
 Quarterly earnings for the Mellon Bank Corporation were $70 million, or $1.20 a share. That compared with a profit $142 million, or $2.80 a share, in the quarter last year. The 1990 figures include a $74 million gain related to the sale of a consumer finance company.
The results exceeded many analysts' estimates, and the stock rose 12.5 cents, to close at $32.875 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
"We were looking for $1.05, so they beat our estimate handily," said Kenneth Puglisi, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods who revised his 1991 per-share projection from $4.40 to $4.90.
Analysts were impressed that the bank, which is based in Pittsburgh, had roughly sustained the higher net interest margin that it had reported in the first quarter, a ratio that reflects the difference between the bank's cost of funds and the price of its loans. The bank now makes 3.83 percent on its interest-earning assets, versus 3.16 percent in the second quarter last year.
 
Banc One
 The Banc One Corporation, based in Columbus, Ohio, reported earnings that were slightly ahead of estimates. Second-quarter profits were $131 million, or 79 cents a share, up from $104 million, or 70 cents a share, in the comparable period last year.
The stock moved up 12.5 cents yesterday, closing at $42.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts credited the performance to the company's well-entrenched position in the profitable consumer finance business.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Living Desk

LENGTH: 1708 words

HEADLINE: A New Getaway: Bed, Breakfast, Spirituality

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
You say you've had your European tour, your Caribbean cruise, your Club Med, your spa. You say you've bed-and-breakfasted New England, barged through Burgundy, hiked the Rockies. And now, you say, your Lewis and Clark response to summer vacation is interrupted by recurring visions of Walden Pond.
You are not alone. Thousands of Americans are packing for a different kind of journey this summer. Destination: a higher spiritual plane. 
 Guest rooms in abbeys, convents and monasteries across the country are tightly booked. "It's gotten to the point we can't handle the number of requests for individual retreatants," said Don George, director of La Casa de Maria, a Roman Catholic retreat in Santa Barbara, Calif.
Jangling reservation lines are piercing the silence of an austere Zen monastery in the Catskills, at a Trappist monastery in Colorado, at an Episcopal monastery perched on the Hudson River. Hyatt, Holiday Inns and the rest aren't exactly sweating the competition. There are fewer than 2,000 guest rooms in monasteries across the country, as against 3.1 million hotel and motel rooms, according to Lodging Industry Profile, a publication of the American Hotel and Motel Association.
But travel experts say that monasteries now have a lower vacancy rate than hotels. And while there are no statistics for the number of guests at religious retreats, clerics and travel agents say they have seen a dramatic rise in the requests for rooms.
"Everybody is posing Camus-type questions," said Dena Kaye, whose cable television program, "A Sense of Place With Dena Kaye," is broadcast daily on the Travel Channel. "It depends," she said, "on whether you want to think it out on a superyacht or someplace a little simpler."
Most monasteries offer tidy, quiet rooms, three home-cooked meals a day and all the spirituality you want for about $50 a day. Some have such secular pleasures as tennis courts or swimming pools. But most appeal to the spirit more than the senses, offering austere tranquillity.
"Every time there is a crisis, we fill up," said Mr. George, who retired from a lucrative business career to volunteer at La Casa de Maria. "There is a pretty close parallel between Las Vegas and retreat centers. People know there is something wrong. They need to get away. They need hope."
Of course, religion in the summertime is nothing new. Church retreats, tent revivals and religious camps are as much a part of the nation's landscape as amber waves of grain. But the new hospitable monasteries eschew evangelism in favor of solitude and scenery. For the monasteries, guests are an economic shot in the arm, and a chance for a low-key ministry.
There are about 600 small monasteries in the United States with guest rooms. Some are training grounds for the newly frocked, while others house retired clerics or religious communities. A handful of modern refuges were once grand homes that are now dedicated to hospitality.
"These aren't preachy places," said Marcia Kelly, who, with her husband, Jack, has written "Sanctuaries" (Bell Tower, 1991), a guide to lodging in monasteries in the Northeast. "They are time out from a driven, aggressive world." The book -- which began with a serendipitous stop -- is becoming the Michelin guide of the retreat set.
"We were visiting a friend at Big Sur and fell for a monastery there," said Mr. Kelly, who calls himself a "retired Catholic" (his wife is Jewish). The sojourn set the couple monastery-hopping, and they have now visited more than 200 retreats.
Some offer solace in their setting. The Carmelite House of Prayer in Oakville, Calif., a former family mansion with 11 guest rooms, sprawls between the terraced ripples of the Napa Valley. "I come up here to hear myself think," said Jason Erlicsohn, a 37-year-old banker from San Fransisco. From his spartan room he can also hear water that dances from a Versailles-like fountain in the monastery's backyard, the gentle clang from the belfry, the chirp of sparrows.
"I used to go over to the health spa when I got stressed out," he said. "Now I just sit here and listen. I end up in better shape after a weekend."
Other retreats do their soothing through a stubborn connection to bygones. The contrast of modern, secular life with ancient, contemplative ways is clear as one steers along the Tokenekee Trail to the Convent of St. Birgitta in Darien, Conn. The road weaves through a land of tennis courts and horses, of designer weekend wear and $2,000 weekday commuter garb. Nearing the convent, time loops back. Gray robes flapping, black veils billowing under starched white crowns, the Sisters of St. Birgitta look like Beguines welcoming returning crusaders as they run to greet arriving cars.
In addition to taking vows of poverty, chastity and obedience, the nuns pledge themselves to "hospitality as an ecumenical effort," said Sister Dolores, mother superior of the convent. Along with seven other sisters, her days begin at 6:15 A.M. with community prayers.
For guests who haven't risen for early prayers, the day begins around 8 with breakfast: steaming bowls of cereal, eggs cooked to order, homemade muffins, waffles, a compote of fresh fruit and an elegant, never-empty silver coffee urn. The 16 guests gather around the formal dining table and are served as if in a home of the butlered gentry.
"I feel well cared for," said Julia Macbeth, a retired librarian who lives in Brooklyn and says she has visited the convent for weekends and vacations for 10 years. "The sisters can't do enough for you."
Between cooking and serving, polishing the convent's museum-quality furniture and tending the nine acres of grounds, the nuns gather to sing prayers in the convent's chapel. Guest attendance is optional. But after several days of quiet attention and home-cooked meals, even the least inclined are drawn from their reading or from walks along Long Island Sound to the lilting chants. "After a few visits you start to hear a calling," Miss Macbeth said.
Another clarion call for inner peace is sounded at Holy Cross Monastery, a rambling red-brick mansion perched on a grand knoll in West Park, N.Y., overlooking the Hudson. "People are soothed by living in harmony with an ongoing religious order," said Brother Timothy, prior of the Episcopal monastery, which has 39 guest rooms. Noting that except for honoring "the Great Silence," from 9 P.M. to 8:15 A.M. daily, participation in all religious service is optional, he said. "If guests hear a calling, it is the part of themselves that modern society has forgotten."
In contrast, guests can't help hearing the call at Dai Bosatsu Zendo, a Zen monastery that looks like a relocated chunk of traditional Japan at the end of a 10-mile dirt road outside Livingston Manor, N.Y., in the Catskills. Other than the gentle brush of bare feet against the monastery's well-polished wood floors, often the only sound heard is the gong that announces the chanting and meditation sessions or a meal. Joining in is not mandatory, but it is the rare camper who chooses the comfort of his futon over participation.
"Sitting," a kneel-squat position that is assumed for two to four hours of meditation, is the central activity for guests. Some of the best sitters, like Junpol Dennis Kelly, vice abbot of the Catskill monastery, study yoga to develop endurance for sitting; he urges the newly initiate to "stay with the uncomfortableness" as a means of transcendence.
A crick in the knee, a strain in the back, the frustration of chopsticks ferreting a lentil stew from a lacquer bowl -- these eventually conquer the anxiety of the type-A existence that most visitors are retreating from. "Sometimes it's the foreignness of what we do that allows Americans to get past their distrust of organized religion," said Mr. Kelly, who greets about 4,000 guests a year. "That opens the door for inner peace and true relaxation."
For some retreats, the public quest opens the door for fiscal growth as well. "A lay person left us this mansion and we need to take in more guests to support it," said the Rev. David Costell, standing in the grand foyer at the Carmelite House of Prayer under the scaffolding that he and three other priests are using to repair a leaking roof and peeling paint.
Throughout Europe, insolvent monasteries are often turned into luxury hotels. The prestigious Relais & Chateaux group has half a dozen former monasteries in France. Rina Annousi, president of the Travel Business in New York City, represents four plush former monasteries in Spain and several in Italy. "In Europe, the most sophisticated traveler who wants expensive luxury with character might ask for room in an old monastery," she said. "The people who call about American monasteries usually have free tickets from frequent flier."
Jack Kelly says that he's met "stock brokers, bank executives, school teachers and social workers in monasteries." Most are looking for the same thing: "They are trying to get past the coat-and-tie-on-Sunday mentality and to bring a spiritual element back to their daily lives," he said. The Kellys are working on a second volume about monasteries in the West and Southwest.
The proliferation of former voyagers who have become seekers poses some problems inside religious communities.
"We are a quiet community," said Brother James, a spokesman for the New Skete Communities, an Eastern Orthodox refuge in Cambridge, N.Y., that takes in a small number of guests. In declining an interview, he explained: "The phone rings so much that it would be hard to do our work and pray if we didn't place some limit."
Other ministers of hospitality worry about the nature of their success. The Rev. Thomas Keating, a Trappist at St. Benedict's Monastery in Snowmass, Colo., developed Contemplative Outreach, a program aimed at helping weekenders and vacationers carry spiritual awareness back to their daily lives. His seminars are now offered at monasteries throughout the country and are wildly popular.
The response is gratifying, Father Keating said, but he has a horror of being seen as a sort of Howard Johnson of the Holy Host.
"We're not serving up some high-class tranquilizer," he said. "This is no vacation; it's a way of life."

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
A False Goddess: Thinness for Women

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN

 BODY:
In "The Famine Within," an eye-opening documentary about American women's collective obsession with body weight, Katherine Gilday makes a thorough and cogent case for the larger importance of this issue. "Every age has its own idea of perfect virtue for women," her film says, and it contends that our current ideal demands the triumph of will power over nature. Faith in weight loss, the film maintains, has for many women taken on the power of religious conviction. And yet the standard to which so many women aspire "really has less to do with beauty than with the deep cultural meaning of body type."
Ms. Gilday's film, which opens today at the Film Forum, is an effective mixture of sobering statistics, perceptive observations and desperately sad anecdotes. Chris Alt, the heavier sister of Carol Alt, the successful model, describes seeing a photograph of Karen Carpenter in the last stages of starvation and thinking "she was very lucky." Ms. Alt recalls having "wondered how I could get that skinny without dying." Another woman remembers dieting frantically as a teen-ager because she had a chance to meet Elvis Presley in Las Vegas and indeed being complimented by Elvis on her good looks. That accomplished, she ballooned back up to 200 pounds. 
 "In many respects it's a critical brain drain that we have," someone in the film observes, commenting on the amount of feminine energy and intelligence that are caught up in concern over weight loss. Various surveys cited here indicate that the majority of American women are more unhappy about weight than ever before, that they are happier about losing weight than about career advancement or success in love, and that they fear being fat more than they fear death.
Building her argument clearly and methodically, Ms. Gilday begins by examining the physical ideal that is celebrated by the media. It is radically different from the national norm. The average 5-foot-8-inch Miss America contestant weighed 132 pounds in 1954 and 117 in 1980; meanwhile, the average North American woman is about 5 feet 4 inches tall and weighs 144 pounds. The standard proportions for a good fashion model are "highly unusual among the general female population," the film tells us, as it watches models at work and remarks upon the enormous influence of the media and the fashion world. In contemplating the image of a single svelte high-fashion beauty, the film notes that "hours and hours of the collective effort of a large team go into the manufacture of the illusion."
The film moves on to consider the effects of such images on the general population. For instance, 80 percent of fourth-grade girls have already been on their first diets. It examines the aerobics craze, the stigma attached to obesity and the pathology of bulimia and anorexia. Ms. Gilday, who is as interested in the psychological and cultural aspects of such conditions as in the medical, calls upon interesting and articulate experts to provide analysis. "Sadly, the cult of the body is the only coherent philosophy of self that women are offered in this society," one says. A woman who lectures on these issues observes that when she discusses anorexia, someone in the audience usually turns up afterward to tell her, "I wish I could have that, just for a little while."
The film's ultimate point, which it develops very well, is that women struggling to balance careers and families have few useful role models and are desperate for control over their lives; this may lead them to banish the obviously feminine aspects of a full figure and emphasize the lean, masculine ideal. By dieting strenuously, one speaker says, "we are reassuring the culture that it still has the upper hand over us and over nature."
By comparison with Henry Jaglom's recent "Eating," a comic film on this subject, the speakers in "The Famine Within" sound a far more serious and less narcissistic note. The final effect of Ms. Gilday's persuasive and important film is to make the point that her subject goes far beyond vanity, and truly into matters of life and death.
On the same bill, and doing nothing to enhance the impact of Ms. Gilday's potent argument, is "We're Talking Vulva," a five-minute work of feminist art by Tracy Traeger and Shawna Dempsey, in which Ms. Dempsey wears a suit representing gigantic female genitalia and delivers a rap song. The lyrics, when audible, are notably lacking in wit. And anyway, it's a little early for Halloween.
 
The Famine Within
 
Directed, written and produced by Katherine Gilday; cinematographer, Joan Hutton; edited by Petra Valier; a Direct Cinema Ltd. release. Running time: 90 minutes.
 
We're Talking Vulva
 
Directed and produced by Tracy Traeger and Shawna Dempsey; music by Bad Tribe; a Zeitgeist Films Release. Running time: 5 minutes.
 
At Film Forum 1, 209 West Houston Street. These films have no rating.

HEADLINE: Iraq Steps Up Pleas to End Trade Ban

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 16

 BODY:
Iraq stepped up its campaign today to bring about some easing in the United Nations trade embargo imposed on this country. It made public a market survey showing that the price of many basic foods has risen by 2,000 to 3,000 percent on the free market since the sanctions took effect a year ago.
Saying poor Iraqis are simply unable to afford food at today's prices, Trade Minister Mohammed Mehdi Saleh said at a news conference that the United States, Britain and France were trying to starve the Iraqi people into a revolt against President Saddam Hussein by refusing to let Iraq sell oil to buy food. 
 "The decision of the U.S., France and Britain is that all the Iraqi people should die," he said.
Iraq has asked the sanctions committee of the Security Council for permission to sell $1 billion worth of oil to finance the central imports of food and medicine. But the committee has not yet made any decision.
 
Prices Called Out of Reach
 The new survey, taken on July 7, compares the average price of basic foods in the free market with the much lower price charged by the state for the monthly food ration it has given all citizens since sanctions were imposed.
But this ration represents only 55 percent of the calories most people would consume in normal circumstances, forcing families to supplement it with purchases from the free market, the minister said.
But prices on the free market have soared since sanctions until they have passed out of reach of many people in Iraq, where the average salary is between 150 dinars and 200 dinars a month, equivalent to $450 to $600 a month at the official rate of exchange.
Prices are soaring because Iraq used to import some 70 percent of its food before the Persian Gulf crisis broke.
The Security Council has said Iraq could import as much food as it needed provided it notified the Council's sanctions committee in advance. The Trade Minister said that private businessmen are bringing in some food into Iraq.
But this has not been sufficient to prevent a price explosion on the free market because the Government cannot afford to import basic staples in order to raise the monthly ration to the level people need to live on, thus reducing dependence on the free market.
The Trade Minister said Iraq had already signed a contract to buy $1 billion worth of grain from Australia. But it cannot take delivery of this food because it does not have the money to pay for it unless the Security Council allows it to start selling oil again.
The survey shows that the cost of flour on the free market, for instance, is now 2,073 percent higher, at 2.5 dinars a kilogram or 2.2 pounds, than the price the Government charges for rationed flour, which is the same as it was before sanctions were imposed.
 
Rice and Baby Milk
 But the monthly flour ration is only eight kilograms or 17 pounds for each individual.
On the free market the price of rice is now 1,130 percent higher than the price charged by the state for ration supplies at 4 dinars per kilogram, or 2.2 pounds.
The same quantity of baby milk costs 2,500 percent more at 15 to 20 dinars a can than the single can provided each small baby every week by the Government as part of the family rations.
The price of cooking oil has now risen 3,070 percent on the free market since the imposition of the trade embargo, in which sugar is up 1,900 percent. Meat has risen 750 percent, chicken 550 percent and a half pound of detergent 650 percent.
Last week a United Nations team recommended that the Security Council allow Iraq to sell some oil to pay for urgently needed imports of food and medicine but said the United Nations should monitor these transactions to make sure the money was correctly spent and that the goods were fairly distributed in the country.
Alternatively, it said the United States and other countries holding some $5 billion of Iraqi Government funds in frozen bank accounts could release part of this money for such humanitarian purchases.
Only Switzerland has released some frozen Iraqi funds, but the $70 million made available in this way is not sufficient to make much difference, he said.
[In Bern, a spokesman for the Swiss Economics Ministry, Claude Gerbex, said he was not aware of any decision by the two Swiss departments concerned, economics and foreign affairs, to lift Swiss economic sanctions on Iraq, The Associated Press reported. The sanctions include freezing Iraqi assets. Mr. Gerbex said he doubted the banks would have acted on their own. ]
Members of the United Nations team confirmed that food prices had indeed risen by several thousand percent in the case of some basic staple. Elliot Richardson, a former United States Attorney General and a member of the United Nations mission, told reporters that he had met a woman in a suburb of Baghdad who had sold 1,500 dinars worth of gold jewelry to buy milk for her small child on the free market, because the Government ration was not sufficient.

LENGTH: 1565 words

HEADLINE: Climb the Jagged Mountain

BYLINE: By Clarence Thomas

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a commencement speech that Clarence Thomas, President Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court, gave at Savannah State College on June 9, 1985.
I grew up here in Savannah. I was born not far from here (in Pinpoint). I am a child of those marshes, a son of this soil. I am a descendant of the slaves whose labors made the dark soil of the South productive. I am the great-great-grandson of a freed slave, whose enslavement continued after my birth. I am the product of hatred and love -- the hatred of the social and political structure which dominated the segregated, hate-filled city of my youth, and the love of some people -- my mother, my grandparents, my neighbors and relatives -- who said by their actions, "You can make it, but first you must endure." 
 You can survive, but first you must endure. You can live, but first you must endure. You must endure the unfairness. You must endure the hatred. You must endure the bigotry. You must endure the segregation. You must endure the indignities.
I stand before you as one who had the same beginning as yourselves -- as one who has walked a little farther down the road, climbed a little higher up the mountain. I come back to you, who must now travel this road and climb this jagged, steep mountain that lies ahead. I return as a messenger -- a front-runner, a scout. What lies ahead of you is even tougher than what is now behind you.
That mean, callous world out there is still very much filled with discrimination. It still holds out a different life for those who do not happen to be the right race or the right sex. It is a world in which the "haves" continue to reap more dividends than the "have-nots."
You will enter a world in which more than one-half of all black children are born primarily to youthful mothers and out of wedlock. You will enter a world in which the black teen-age unemployment rate as always is more than double that of white teenagers. Any discrimination, like sharp turns in a road, becomes critical because of the tremendous speed at which we are traveling into the high-tech world of a service economy.
There is a tendency among young, upwardly mobile, intelligent minorities to forget. We forget the sweat of our forefathers. We forget the blood of the marchers, the prayers and hope of our race. We forget who brought us into this world. We overlook who put food in our mouths and clothes on our backs. We forget commitment to excellence. We procreate with pleasure and retreat from the responsibilities of the babies we produce.
We subdue, we seduce, but we don't respect ourselves, our women, our babies. How do we expect a race that has been thrown into the gutter of socio-economic indicators to rise above these humiliating circumstances if we hide from responsibility for our own destiny?
The truth of the matter is we have become more interested in designer jeans and break dancing than we are in obligations and responsibilities.
Over the past 15 years, I have watched as others have jumped quickly at the opportunity to make excuses for black Americans. It is said that blacks cannot start businesses because of discrimination. But I remember businesses on East Broad and West Broad that were run in spite of bigotry. It is said that we can't learn because of bigotry. But I know for a fact that tens of thousands of blacks were educated at historically black colleges, in spite of discrimination. We learned to read in spite of segregated libraries. We built homes in spite of segregated neighborhoods. We learned how to play basketball (and did we ever learn!), even though we couldn't go to the N.B.A.
We have lost something. We look for role models in all the wrong places. We refuse to reach back in our not too distant past for the lessons and values we need to carry us into the uncertain future. We ignore what has permitted blacks in this country to survive the brutality of slavery and the bitter rejection of segregation. We overlook the reality of positive values and run to the mirage of promises, visions and dreams.
I dare not come to this city, which only two decades ago clung so tenaciously to segregation, bigotry and Jim Crowism, to convince you of the fairness of this society. My memory is too precise, my recollection too keen, to venture down that path of self-delusion. I am not blind to our history -- nor do I turn a deaf ear to the pleas and cries of black Americans. Often I must struggle to contain my outrage at what has happened to black Americans -- what continues to happen -- what we let happen and what we do to ourselves.
If I let myself go, I would rage in the words of Frederick Douglass: "At a time like this, scorching irony, not convincing argument, is needed. Oh! Had I the ability, and could reach the nation's ear, I would today pour out a fiery stream of biting ridicule, blasting reproach, withering sarcasm and stern rebuke. For it is not light that is needed, but fire; it is not the gentle shower, but thunder. We need the storm, the whirlwind and the earthquake."
I often hear rosy platitudes about this country -- much of which is true. But how are we black Americans to feel when we have so little in a land with so much? How is black America to respond to the celebration of the wonders of this great nation?
In 1964, when I entered the seminary, I was the only black in my class and one of two in the school. A year later, I was the only one in the school. Not a day passed that I was not pricked by prejudice.
But I had an advantage over black students and kids today. I had never heard any excuses made. Nor had I seen my role models take comfort in excuses. The women who worked in those kitchens and waited on the bus knew it was prejudice which caused their plight, but that didn't stop them from working.
My grandfather knew why his business wasn't more successful, but that didn't stop him from getting up at 2 in the morning to carry ice, wood and fuel oil. Sure, they knew it was bad. They knew all too well that they were held back by prejudice. But they weren't pinned down by it. They fought discrimination under W. W. Law [a Georgia civil rights leader] and the N.A.A.C.P. Equally important, they fought against the awful effects of prejudice by doing all they could do in spite of this obstacle.
They could still send their children to school. They could still respect and help each other. They could still moderate their use of alcohol. They could still be decent, law-abiding citizens.
I had the benefit of people who knew they had to walk a straighter line, climb a taller mountain and carry a heavier load. They took all that segregation and prejudice would allow them and at the same time fought to remove these awful barriers.
You all have a much tougher road to travel. Not only do you have to contend with the ever-present bigotry, you must do so with a recent tradition that almost requires you to wallow in excuses. You now have a popular national rhetoric which says that you can't learn because of racism, you can't raise the babies you make because of racism, you can't get up in the mornings because of racism. You commit crimes because of racism. Unlike me, you must not only overcome the repressiveness of racism, you must also overcome the lure of excuses. You have twice the job I had.
Do not be lured by sirens and purveyors of misery who profit from constantly regurgitating all that is wrong with black Americans and blaming these problems on others. Do not succumb to this temptation of always blaming others.
Do not become obsessed with all that is wrong with our race. Rather, become obsessed with looking for solutions to our problems. Be tolerant of all positive ideas; their number is much smaller than the countless number of problems to be solved. We need all the hope we can get.
Most importantly, draw on that great lesson and those positive role models who have gone down this road before us. We are badgered and pushed by our friends and peers to do unlike our parents and grandparents -- we are told not to be old-fashioned. But they have weathered the storm. It is up to us now to learn how. Countless hours of research are spent to determine why blacks fail or why we commit crimes. Why can't we spend a few hours learning how those closest to us have survived and helped us get this far?
As your front-runner, I have gone ahead and taken a long, hard look. I have seen two roads from my perch a few humble feet above the madding crowd. On the first, a race of people is rushing mindlessly down a highway of sweet, intoxicating destruction, with all its bright lights and grand promises constructed by social scientists and politicians. To the side, there is a seldom used, overgrown road leading through the valley of life with all its pitfalls and obstacles. It is the road -- the old-fashioned road -- traveled by those who endured slavery, who endured Jim Crowism, who endured hatred. It is the road that might reward hard work and discipline, that might reward intelligence, that might be fair and provide equal opportunity. But there are no guarantees.
You must choose. The lure of the highway is seductive and enticing. But the destruction is certain. To travel the road of hope and opportunity is hard and difficult, but there is a chance that you might somehow, some way, with the help of God, make it.

HEADLINE: Milk Quotas for U.S. Dairies Make No Sense

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Can you imagine the United States Government requiring the registration of every dairy farmer in the nation for the purpose of assigning quotas that dictate how much milk each one can sell? The Livestock, Dairy and Poultry subcommittee of the House Agriculture Committee has just approved such a bill. In exchange for this Government-imposed straitjacket, dairy farmers would receive a 25 percent increase in the milk-support price. 
 A little history is in order to understand what is going on here. The Federal Government supports the price of milk by maintaining an open-ended commitment to buy all surplus butter, nonfat dry milk and cheese offered to it at the support price. Historically, the support price was kept low to discourage surpluses.
But in 1977, under pressure from the dairy lobby, Congress changed policy and dramatically increased the support price. The support price rose from $8.26 a hundredweight of milk in 1977 to its peak of $13.49 in 1981. Predictably, high milk prices coupled with a guaranteed government market caused tremendous overproduction.
In 1981, Congress and the new Reagan Administration realized they had a monster on their hands, and they began to reduce the support price gradually, as well as to sponsor voluntary milk supply reduction programs. It took nearly seven years, but by mid-1988 supply and demand were in close balance.
Then the Middle West drought occurred, temporarily reducing the supply of milk. The market responded by increasing production, and the production increases outlasted the temporary shortage caused by the drought. The market demanded an adjustment in the milk supply, so milk prices collapsed last October. The last nine months have been difficult for dairy farmers and thus the pressure on Congress to do something about milk prices.
The good news is the milk supply has been adjusted. The price of cheese and nonfat dry milk is substantially above the support price, and farm milk prices are beginning to recover. The market works, and we should not be surprised by that. The adjustment probably would have happened sooner, but with Congress flirting with the milk quota idea, dairy farmers were reluctant to reduce production, and thereby reduce the quota they might receive.
Congress should resist the dairy lobby's attempt at self-destruction. Having the Government interfere in the marketplace and arbitrarily raise milk prices at the cost of putting all dairy farmers in a straitjacket will probably always be popular with some down on the farm. But as history has shown, when Congress forsakes market-oriented economic principles for the quick fix, the country ends up with a mess. Let's hope the full House will see the foolishness of the dairy subcommittee's action.
 
GEOFFREY VANDEN HEUVEL
Chino, Calif., July 8, 1991
 
The writer is a dairy farmer.

HEADLINE: Greek Chief Hopes Bush Will Help on Cyprus

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, July 17

 BODY:
Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis says he is looking to President Bush to settle the 17-year-old dispute between Greece and Turkey over Turkish military occupation of part of Cyprus. After two discussions about the issue, Mr. Bush has agreed to help, he said.
Mr. Bush will arrive here on Thursday from the summit in London. He will then travel to Turkey on Saturday. 
 The Prime Minister said that at a time of great instability in Yugoslavia and growing international concern over the volatile Balkan region, it is vital to settle the feud between the two NATO allies.
"The problem is now ripe to be solved," Mr. Mitsotakis said. "The role of the United States can be determining, and Mr. Bush can be the catalyst." A settlement could be reached soon, he added, "maybe by this fall."
Mr. Mitsotakis will also be seeking United States support for his new proposal to create a demilitarized zone along the common borders of Greece, Bulgaria and Turkey, an effort to lessen tensions in a region where the three neighbors have long kept large concentrations of troops and offensive weapons. Bulgaria, he said, immediately responded "warmly" to the five-day-old proposal, but no reply has yet come from Turkey.
While Greece has put the Cyprus issue at the top of its agenda, American officials have tried to play down speculation that the United States has a master plan to deal with the bitter feud that has defied many previous mediation efforts. Mr. Bush has publicly said that he is ready to help but that the United States has "no magic wand."
Since the Turks invaded Cyprus in 1974, in the midst of a Greek effort to take over the island, it remains cut in half by a United Nations-patrolled line that separates about 170,000 Turkish Cypriots in the north from almost 650,000 Greek Cypriots in the south.
The continuing tensions between Athens and Ankara have long troubled Washington because the two nations make up the eastern flank of NATO.
It is also a longstanding irritant to the European Community, in which Greece, a full member, has often tried to press it partners into adopting positions against Turkey, which has associate membership. Many United Nations mediation efforts on Cyprus have failed, and Mr. Bush, a former United States delegate to the United Nations, is said to know the issue well.
Speaking in his residence here on Tuesday night, Mr. Mitsotakis argued that the time for a settlement is now.
"We have just gone through the gulf war, and the attention of the world and particularly of the United States is toward this part of the world," he said. "The war was waged by all to protect the international order and carry out the United Nations decisions. Now is the time for these principles to be applied in Cyprus as well. Seventeen years has been too long."
The Prime Minister has just visited Nicosia, the Cypriot capital. "It's the only place now where there is a dividing wall," he said of the sandbags and barbed wire that run through the city. The Turkish troops, north of the dividing line, he said, "are now the only occupation army left in Europe."
Referring to the two occasions when he has discussed Cyprus with Mr. Bush, Mr. Mitsotakis said: "I asked his assistance in solving this problem, and I explained to him that the United States can play the primary role. This is certainly the case today, after the gulf war that has left the United States the undeniable and only superpower. President Bush said he will help, and that's extremely important."
The main sticking points in Cyprus are how much land will be returned to the Greek Cypriots who were forced out of the occupied zone by Turkish troops and what form of government and what rights for the two groups will be acceptable.
The Bush visit is the first by an American leader since President Eisenhower's in 1959. It will be a boon to Mr. Mitsotakis, who took over in April 1990 from Andreas Papandreou, the Socialist who was a critic of American policy. The conservative Prime Minister has since been mending fences with Washington and is rolling back the role of the state in favor of a market economy.

HEADLINE: All Eyes on Cuba at Ibero-American Summit

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, July 17

 BODY:
Setting aside his domestic troubles for two days in the diplomatic limelight, President Fidel Castro of Cuba is to make a rare foreign appearance at an international summit conference here this week, seeking to shore up regional support for his Government.
The first Ibero-American Summit Conference, which will bring together leaders from 21 Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries on Thursday and Friday, has been billed as an important new vehicle for regional cooperation and economic integration. The list of confirmed participants includes President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua, King Juan Carlos of Spain and President Alberto Fujimori of Peru.
 
Castro the Focus of Attention
 But ever since Mr. Castro announced his intention to attend, preparations have been dominated by speculation about how the Cuban leader will be received by regional leaders whose friendship now looms as a vital lifeline for the weakened Cuban economy. 
 "This is a crucial opportunity for him to reach out, practically and symbolically, to the rest of Latin America," a foreign diplomat in Mexico City said. "It is the only important base he's got left." As Cuba's network of Communist allies and trading partners around the world has collapsed, forcing Havana to impose strict rationing of basic goods, regional trends toward greater democracy and more conservative economic policies have left Mr. Castro increasingly estranged from the new generation of Latin American leaders.
Cuba's isolation has been encouraged by the Bush Administration, which has missed few opportunities to impress its Latin American allies with its demands that the Castro Government accept broad democratic changes and free elections before it receives help in its current crisis.
But for heads of state like President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, who has made his reputation on tight fiscal discipline and closer ties to the United States, Mr. Castro's presence is a useful demonstration of diplomatic neutrality and regional independence.
Mexican officials, who see a politically and economically valuable role for their country as Cuba's link to the outside world, have repeatedly rejected any suggestion that the summit meeting be used as a tool for forcing Mr. Castro to change.
Emphasizing their commitment to what they describe as diplomatic diversity, Mexican officials have responded to criticism of their ties with Mr. Castro by noting that the summit talks will also include President Guillermo Endara of Panama. Mr. Endara's Government has been kept at arm's length by Mexico, which withdrew its Ambassador from Panama after the United States invasion in December 1989.
Strapped by enormous debt burdens and regionwide economic difficulties, Latin American nations are not in a position to offer direct aid to Cuba. Regional diplomats say points for possible discussion will include closer trade ties, support for Cuba's crash efforts to encourage tourism, and demonstrations of warmer diplomatic relations.
The meeting is envisioned as the first in a series of annual events. Spain is to play host to next year's conference as part of its celebration of the 500th anniversary of the arrival of Spanish explorers in the New World. The 1993 conference is to be held in Brazil.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off as Traders Study Summit-Talk Implications

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell slightly yesterday as traders awaited further signals about the economy and the Group of Seven industrial nations' stand on exchange rates.
Gold prices rose, with a troy ounce climbing 80 cents in New York to close at $369.70 on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $369.30, up 55 cents. 
 Analysts said the dollar continued to trade in a narrow range, with profit taking responsible for the currency's lower levels.
Jeff Mondschein, managing director of foreign exchange for the Continental Bank in Chicago, said traders were "waiting through the summer months to see the ultimate outcome of G-7, the implications of their meeting, which aren't known now."
 
Leaders End Meeting
 Leaders of the Group of Seven nations, including President Bush, concluded their three-day meeting in London today. Their talks on economic issues, including foreign exchange rates, were overshadowed by their agreement to provide assistance to the Soviet Union.
If the nations want the dollar held in check, the central banks of the seven countries could enter the markets -- as they did last Friday -- to keep the currency from advancing.
Mr. Mondschein said currency traders were also waiting for further clues about where the United States economy was headed and whether the Federal Reserve might ease interest rates. The direction of interest rates are crucial for the dollar, which like other currencies is supported by higher yields.
Overseas dealers said the dollar was hurt by fears that the German central bank would intervene to hamper its ascent.
The British pound gained against the dollar. In New York, sterling rose to $1.6495, from $1.64305 late Tuesday, and in earlier London trading the pound rose to $1.6515 from $1.6458.
The dollar fell to 136.95 Japanese yen, from 137.25 late Tuesday in New York. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 0.22 yen, to 137.17 yen, and in London it closed at 136.85 yen.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell in New York to 1.79135 marks from 1.8000.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5557 Swiss francs, down from 1.56275; 6.0780 French francs, down from 6.1070; 1,331.15 Italian lire, down from 1,339.25, and 1.14805 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1474.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Jumps to Highest Level Since Last Days of the War

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The price of oil jumped yesterday to its highest level since the final days of the gulf war, surprising traders, who said a mix of news, rumors and speculation stirred the rally.
"It's kind of like the domino effect -- one thing starts building up, then another kicks in," said Victor Yu, vice president of futures at Refco Inc. 
 Crude oil for delivery in August settled at $22.14 a barrel, up 49 cents, at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil for next-month delivery had not closed that high since Feb. 14, when the final price was $22.32 a barrel.
Unleaded gasoline for delivery in August settled at 64.66 cents a gallon, up 1.34 cents. Home heating oil for delivery in August settled at 59.83 cents a gallon, up 0.60 cent.
Market analysts said the buying had come on rumors of various oil production problems around the globe, as well as in reaction to an American Petroleum Institute report released Tuesday night that showed the nation's supply of gasoline shrank last week.
That was taken as an indication that demand could be building, after staying sluggish for months because of the recession.
Once the prices started moving higher, traders began making deals intended to push prices up even further, enabling them to rack up quick profits by buying oil and selling it shortly thereafter.
"The market moved a lot higher on speculation," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J.
But the intensity of the rally surpised many participants.
"I'm still skeptical in the sense that volume is nothing exceptional," Mr. Blakeslee said. In any financial markets, price movements can be exaggerated in thin volume.
Some of the strong buying began at the International Petroleum Exchange in London, which helped bolster prices in New York. North Sea Brent blend crude oil for delivery in September settled there at $20.21 a barrel, up 49 cents.
At the mercantile exchange, natural gas futures finished mostly higher, with contracts for delivery in August settling at $1.235 for 1,000 cubic feet, up 3.0 cents.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Looking for Clues In Options Prices

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
LIKE David W. Mullins Jr., a governor of the Federal Reserve who is studying the prices of Treasury bond options for clues about inflation expectations, individual investors and corporate treasurers may also benefit by studying options price movements.
Because the options market measures traders' changing perceptions of an asset's volatility, investors can use the measure to spot changes in the relative riskiness of the assets -- stocks, bonds, foreign currencies -- in their portfolios. 
 Keeping an eye on implied volatility is "a way for investors to get a free ride on options traders' expertise," said Steven P. Feinstein, an economist at Boston University. "If you know how to read the forecast out of options prices, you can figure out what the pros are forecasting."
Mr. Mullins watches an indicator based on weekly price changes in Treasury bond options. Expressed as a percentage, the measure indicates the expected amplitude of price swings over a period of several months up to a year.
Broadly speaking, a 10 percent implied volatility means that options investors believe that most of the time the asset's price will fluctuate within bounds that are 10 percent higher or lower than today's price. Investors or corporate treasurers can use the measure to help them buy options when they are cheap and postpone buying when options are unusually expensive.
In the market for Treasury bond options, the indicator's current low reading makes options look like a bargain. Implied volatility has been around 8 percent lately, about one-third below its average level. Over the last 10 years, implied volatility has been higher about 90 percent of the time," said David Lerman, manager of options at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
By contrast, the implied volatility of the S.& P. 500 index is slightly higher than average. Buying stock options last summer after Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait would have been like "buying disaster insurance after the disaster," Mr. Lerman said. "The time to buy options is in anticipation of increased volatility, and sell in anticipation of decreased volatility."
Of course, all this doesn't mean that an investor can necessarily make money buying options when they are cheap. Traders often bet that unusually high or low volatility signals an imminent return to average values. That is not always the case. Implied volatility of Treasury bonds stayed below 9 percent for nearly a year and a half, beginning in 1989 until the Iraqi invasion last August.
Someone trying to decide whether to shift funds among investments like cash, bonds or stock can get a better handle on the riskiness of each investment. Given comparable rates of return, most investors would probably prefer to invest in an asset when its implied volatility is low. "If you see relative risks change," Mr. Feinstein said, "that could influence your decision on where your money ought to be." It is not, incidentally, possible to compare risk across classes of assets just by looking at the options price. That is because options prices also depend on other variables, namely the strike price, the expiration date, the market interest rate and the price of the underlying asset.
Implied volatility may be a better guide than actual past volatility. "What you need is a forecast of future risk, not an estimate of how risky the investment was in the past," Mr. Feinstein said. "Implied volatility is almost always forward looking."
Implied volatility data are available from brokers, electronic data bases or even the Chicago options and futures exchanges for everything from T-bond options to D-mark options to S.& P. 500 index options. Investors can purchase software and make their own calculations from daily closing prices of options, if they wish.
Here are the whys and wherefores of the implied volatility measure: Options are rights to buy or sell assets -- D-marks, T-bonds, stocks -- at a specific time and price. Companies, banks and individual investors use them like insurance to protect themselves against unfavorable price changes. "When the environment gets riskier the price of insurance goes up," Mr. Feinstein said.
Two University of Chicago finance professors, Fischer Black and Myron Scholes, invented a formula in 1973 for how much this insurance, the option, had to cost based on how risky the environment was. The wider the range that investors expect an asset's price to fluctuate, the more volatile, hence riskier, the investment and the more costly the insurance.
Even sophisticated investors and corporate treasurers are often unaware of the indicator. "Two-thirds of the calls I get are from people who either don't know anything about implied volatility, but should, or people who want to know more," said Mr. Lerman at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Wendell Cherry Is Dead at 55; Hospital Leader

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Wendell Cherry, vice chairman of Humana Inc., operator of a nationwide chain of hospitals and provider of health insurance for 1.6 million people, died on Tuesday at his home in Louisville, Ky. He was 55 years old.
He died of lung cancer, said a spokesman for Humana. 
 Mr. Cherry, who founded Humana in 1961 with David A. Jones, had many interests outside the health-care field. He owned the Kentucky Colonels basketball team and was president of the American Basketball Association before its absorption into the National Basketball Association. He was also an art collector who once paid $5.3 million for a self-portrait of Picasso and a Broadway producer whose shows included "The Secret Garden," a Broadway musical this season.
Born in Kentucky's rural Hart County, he was a graduate of the University of Kentucky and its law school. In 1959 he began practicing law in Louisville and taught economics at the University of Louisville.
 
Chain of 82 Hospitals
 Two years later, he and Mr. Jones founded Humana, which operates 82 hospitals and is one of the world's largest providers of integrated health-care services, with annual revenues of $6 billion.
Over the years Mr. Cherry was identified with many activities in Louisville. He was the lawyer for a group of Louisville sportsmen who sponsored the boxer Cassius Clay, a Louisville native. The boxer went on to win the world heavyweight championship in 1964 and later became Muhammad Ali.
In the late 1960's Mr. Cherry headed a campaign to finance a number of Louisville projects, including rebuilding of the Louisville General Hospital into the Humana Hospital-University of Louisville, one of four Humana medical centers in that city.
He was a pivotal figure in raising $13.5 million to build the Kentucky Center for the Arts, which was completed in 1983, and served as its board chairman from 1980 to 1987.
Mr. Cherry's interest in art resulted in what some critics have called the greatest collection of 20th century sculpture being placed in Humana's headquarters and the neighboring Kentucky Center for the Arts. Included are Henry Moore's "Reclining Figure," Alberto Giacometti's "Large Standing Woman II" and Alexander Calder's "The Red Feather."
At a Manhattan auction in 1981, Mr. Cherry outbid other collectors and paid $5.3 million for the Picasso self-portrait "Yo," at the time the highest price ever paid for a work by the artist.
Mr. Cherry is survived by his wife, the former Dorothy O'Connell; two daughters and two sons from a previous marriage, Angela Gehegan of San Diego, Alison Alvarez of Charlotte, N.C., Andrew of Louisville and Hagan, of San Diego; his mother, Geneva, of Bowling Green, Ky.; a stepdaughter, Jennifer Morton of Yarmouth, Me.; two stepsons, Jonathan and Timothy Morton, both of Louisville; two sisters, Ruth Ann Holland of Montclair, N.J., and Sue Ellen Lloyd of Bowling Green; a brother, Layman of Alvaton, Ky., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Industries and Towns Clash About Who Pays To Get Rid of Poisons

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

 BODY:
Years ago, before the perils of dumping poisonous chemical wastes were well known, some of the nation's largest industrial corporations disposed of them in hundreds of municipal landfills around the nation.
Now, after more than a decade in which the Federal Government has been singling out these polluters and making them pay for cleaning up those landfills, the companies are trying to force cities and small private businesses to share the costs. 
 In 14 cases, the corporations are suing towns, school districts and small businesses that dumped garbage in the same landfills. The corporations, among them Exxon, Du Pont, B. F. Goodrich and Weyerhaeuser, want them to pay based on their share of the volume of wastes that were dumped. The defendants say toxicity, not simple volume, should be the criterion.
Recognizing the nationwide problem, the Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday that it would develop guidelines on municipal liability by this fall, after holding a conference on the issue. "We do not seek to exempt municipalities entirely," Mary Mears, an E.P.A. spokeswoman, told The Associated Press. "We in no way want to grant blanket exemptions to anybody."
One issue is how dangerous ordinary garbage is compared with toxic wastes. At stake are billions of dollars. The amount in dispute at one California site is more than $650 million, and the liabilities some towns face could cause them to default. For example, Alhambra, Calif., which has a $55 million annual budget, could be liable for $20 million over a decade.
The corporations argue that even garbage contains hazardous materials, and that if a landfill has to be cleaned up, any business or governmental body that dumped there should help.
Many cities and towns have banded together to bring the issue before Congress. They argue that less than 1 percent of municpal wastes are considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency. They say it was not their waste that turned the landfills into toxic dumps, and therefore they should not have to pay. It will not be clear for some time how much cities and towns will have to pay in light of the agency's announcement yesterday, or what effect the announcement will have on the lawsuits.
The companies have complained about the Federal "Superfund" law, which requires cleanups of toxic dump sites, since it was passed in 1980. Advocates for the towns say this latest tactic is a way the big polluters hope to get the attention of Congress in their drive to weaken the law.
The large corporations have ample motivation: they know that some 1,300 toxic-waste sites, one-third of them the municipal disposal sites in question, have been identified, and that the E.P.A. expects another 700 toxic-waste dumps to be identified by the end of the decade. The average cost for cleaning up a site is $25 million to $30 million, the agency says.
Local government officials are furious. "All we did was send ordinary garbage to one dump, and we are sued as though we were equal partners in the toxic pollution," said Gerald Lucas, the first selectman of Killingworth, Conn. His community is one of 24 being sued for more than $50 million of the $70 million it will cost to clean two landfills in Naugatuck Borough.
Killingworth, a town of 4,814 with a $1.6 million annual budget, has spent $45,000 in two years defending itself. If the towns lose, its share of the liability would be about $1 million, a figure based on the volume of refuse it dumped in the early 1970's.
A Federal judge hearing the case has given a partial victory to B. F. Goodrich, the Upjohn Company, General Electric and Atlantic Richfield, the companies suing the 24 towns. Although the case is still pending in some respects, the ruling in January said that the towns were partly responsible for landfill contamination.
 
What Congress Intended
 The principal author of the Superfund law says such findings are not what Congress had in mind. "The very clear intent of the law is that corporate polluters are to be made responsible for cleaning up toxic wastes," said Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, who served in Congress from 1975 to 1990 and wrote the law. "Congress never contemplated that solid municipal waste was toxic and municipalities would be responsible for cleanups."
"This is just one more tactic corporations are using," Mr. Florio added.
In the 11 states where suits have been filed, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the defendants face agonizing choices -- to settle, or to spend huge amounts on legal fees.
The 1980 law, officially the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act, which set up requirements for cleaning up toxic dumps and established a "Superfund," financed by polluters and the Government, to pay for it.
The law, enacted shortly after the Love Canal environmental disaster near Niagara Falls, N.Y., was in response to threats to public health and the environment from industry's most poisonous byproducts, left in waste lagoons, hidden disposal sites and abandoned dumps. The bulk of these poisons were disposed of in legal, if unregulated, ways from the mid-1940's through the mid-1970's, before the dangers became widely known.
 
The Definitions Are Crucial
 As the Superfund program has evolved, it has become clear that some of these wastes also were disposed of in ordinary landfills, where cities dump their trash and garbage. Some 400 locations where industrial toxic wastes were mixed with municipal refuse have been discovered.
The cities may be vulnerable because of the broad liability provisions and the equally broad definitions of hazardous waste in the Superfund law.
"The law says that anybody who sent hazardous waste to a dump, regardless of their size or economic viability, can be held liable for cleanup costs," said Stanley M. Spracker, a lawyer in Washington who has represented industrial clients in cases involving the Federal law. "If Joe's Pizzeria sent hazardous material to a dump site, they are just as liable as Chevron."
If the industrial plaintiffs are successful, virtually every city in the country and tens of thousands of small businesses could be liable. Critics of this tactic have expressed fears that ordinary homeowners might also be dragged into legal struggles, although the E.P.A. yesterday said that it would make formal its longstanding policy not to sue homeowners "unless they in some way have contributed to the contamination" at a Superfund site.
 
'Unintended Consequences'
 Declaring that he will introduce legislation to amend the Superfund law, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, said the lawsuits by big companies are "a case of unintended consequences taking precedence over the intent."
At issue in all but one of 14 Federal Court cases around the country is whether ordinary trash and garbage are hazardous wastes under the definitions of the 1980 law.
In 1989, the E.P.A. said that less than 1 percent of municipal wastes were hazardous, so it would not sue cities for cleanup costs. But corporate lawyers say that the Superfund law broadly defines 700 to 800 chemicals as hazardous, and that its broad liability provisions can be used against cities and small businesses if their wastes contain any of those chemicals.
The corporations argue that some municipal trash contains toxic chemicals, and they say municipal practices often worsen the problem, for two reasons: first, cities manage many landfills, and haphazard management may contribute to toxic pollution; second, the municipal wastes act as a sponge, absorbing hazardous liquids dumped by the large companies.
The case that corporations hope will be a model, and that defendants and potential defendants fear most, is unfolding in upstate New York. This year, 41 towns and school districts and more than 400 private small-business owners in and around Utica agreed to pay $1.8 million, subject to judicial review, to settle a lawsuit brought by Chesebrough-Pond's USA, a pharmaceutical manufacturer, and Special Metals Corporation, a maker of metal components. Both companies were sued by the E.P.A. to help pay for a $9 million project to clean up a landfill in Clayville, near Utica, where the companies had for years dumped toxic wastes, and where cities disposed of refuse.
In Southern California, 64 companies, including Shell, Exxon, Chevron and McDonnell Douglas, are suing 29 cities in a case involving one of the most polluted sites in the country, the Operating Industries Landfill in Monterey Park. The 200-acre dump was used by the cities to dispose of millions of tons of municipal refuse and by the corporations to dump 300 million gallons of toxic wastes. The E.P.A. sued the companies for the cost of restoring the land, estimated at $600 million to $800 million. The companies are seeking to compel the cities to share the cost.
One defendant is the City of Alhambra, a suburb of Los Angeles. City Manager Kevin J. Murphy said that if Alhambra and the other defendants lose, it could be liable for $20 million to $30 million over the next decade. Alhambra has spent $180,000 defending itself.
 
Give In or Spend on Fees
 Eighty-five percent of the defendants in the Utica-area case have settled. Louis S. Petrone, the industrialists' lawyer who sued 603 defendants, said those settling include the owner of a pizzeria and a food store.
Among the defendants that did not settle was the New Hartford Central School District, which plaintiffs say should pay $28,000. "They're fighting it because they feel they didn't do anything wrong," said Alan S. Burstein, a lawyer in Syracuse who is defending the school district. "Dick and Jane's school lunch isn't hazardous."
Eighty-six cities have formed American Communities for Cleanup Equity to lobby for amendments to the Superfund law that would end their liability. Rena Steinzor, the group's Washington representative, said the lawsuits against cities were "designed to make Superfund a joke."
The Superfund's slow pace and high costs have periodically raised Congressional interest. The Superfund law was last amended in 1986.
Although $11.2 billion has been spent in 11 years, just 63 waste sites have been cleaned up.
"More money is being spent on lawyers and administrative costs and endless studies than is being spent for cleanup, and if it continues this way it will be the death knell of the Superfund act," said Mr. Torricelli, who helped to update some of the law's provisions.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sixty-four companies are suing 29 cities to help pay for the restoration of one of the most polluted sites in the country. The Operating Industries Landfill in Monterey Park, Calif., which closed in 1984, was used by the cities and the corporations to dispose of trash and toxic wastes. (Scott Robinson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Profits Are Down by 92% at AMR

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Second-quarter earnings of the AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, plummeted 92 percent, to $10.3 million, from $129.2 million a year earlier. While the sharp decline underscored the continuing weakness of the airline industry, analysts said they were not surprised and predicted gradual improvement in the industry beginning later this year.
AMR's earnings, reported yesterday, reflect an $11 million charge relating to the retirement of Boeing 737's. 
 Earnings per share for the Dallas-based corporation fell to 15 cents, from $2.05 for the comparable 1990 period. Revenues in the quarter rose 7.4 percent, to $3.19 billion, from $2.97 billion a year earlier.
For the six-month period, AMR reported a loss of $185.3 million, in contrast to earnings of $109.9 million, or $1.75 a share, in the 1990 period. Revenues came to $5.96 billion, up from $5.66 billion.
 
'Very Unsatisfactory'
 Acknowledging that the results were "very unsatisfactory," Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of AMR, cited a combination of factors, ranging from widespread discounting, the lingering effect of a year-end labor dispute, the continued absence of more than 200 pilots serving in the Persian Gulf war and the reallocation of equipment required to fly recently acquired routes to London.
"Those factors have prevented us from using our assets as efficiently as we'd like," Mr. Crandall said. "However, we now expect to have all our pilots home by mid-September and expect that the adverse effects of all these changes will ease substantially by the end of the third quarter and be eliminated by year's end."
Paul Karos, an airline analyst at the First Boston Corporation, said that AMR's earnings were "pretty much on target" with analysts' expectations and that a gradual recovery appeared under way. "I expect to see modest profits at United, Delta and Southwest, and a loss at USAir," he said. "I think the third quarter will be better, although the year over all will be nowhere as robust as I thought a few months ago."
Philip Baggaley, an airline analyst at Standard & Poor's, said he did not find AMR's results "terribly alarming," because of the pending economic recovery. "But unfortunately," he added, "the industry has already sold discount tickets for much of the summer, its strongest period."
 
Stock Declines
 Shares of AMR, however, fell $2.625, to $61.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
AMR's poor financial performance reflects the troubles that began for the industry with last year's economic downturn and the turmoil in the Persian Gulf, which caused aviation fuel prices to double. By year's end the industry had lost $4 billion, including AMR's loss of $36.9 million, resulting in the worst business year ever for United States airlines.
Air traffic fell 5.5 percent through May of this year, compared with the period a year ago. Since last fall, five United States carriers, which account for about 25 percent of combined systemwide capacity, have gone into bankruptcy or default, and Eastern Airlines ceased operations altogether last January.
The International Air Transport Association recently reported that airline industry losses worldwide in 1991 already total $2.5 billion just through March, the latest month for which figures are available.

HEADLINE: Stung by Prostitution, Town Shames Customers

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WYANDANCH, L.I.

 BODY:
Many residents of this struggling hamlet have come around to feeling sorry for the prostitutes who haunt its streets and, desperate for crack money, charge less than $20 for their services. But that sympathy does not extend to the men who come from out of town looking for sex.
"It's upsetting to the point where it's like a disrespect of you," said Daria Cooper, telling how she avoids even walking to the store because the out-oftown men often assume that any Wyandanch woman on the street is a prostitute. For a neighborhood straining to pull itself up from a morass of poverty, drugs and crime, such an attitude is more than many residents can bear. 
 Tired of the prostitutes on the corners and the men propositioning their daughters, and frustrated by police sweeps that have not solved the prob lem, the Wyandanch Civic Association took a drastic step this winter. Using a list provided by the police, it sent letters to the homes of 63 men arrested for soliciting prostitutes, with the words "Patronizing a prostitute" written in bold red ink on the envelope and, inside, a copy of the police report, with the accused man's name highlighted.
"This is to let people know that we do not want you to use our community as a playground," said Muriel Simmons-McCord, secretary of the civic association.
Humiliating the clients of prostitutes as a way to attack prostitution is a controversial tactic that has been used with limited success in the past. In 1979, in one of the most publicized instances, Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York directed the city's public radio station, WNYC, to broadcast the names of men arrested for soliciting prostitutes. But the plan was dropped after one day because so many people complained.
After receiving the letters from Wyandanch, many of the men telephoned members of the civic association to complain that their rights and privacy had been violated. One man, calling himself "John," appeared on the Sally Jesse Raphael television show to declare that he was a sex addict struggling to reform and that the letter had made him miss the chance to confess to his wife. (She wasn't too pleased, either; she left him for six weeks.)
"It's one thing if you're going to be arrested, and it's another thing if they're going to be harassing you at home," said Samuel Ackerman, who received one of the letters. Mr. Ackerman, who lives in the nearby community of Plainview, said prostitution should be legalized but acknowledged that his is an unpopular view here. "This was embarrassing, to say the least," he said.
But residents wonder whose dignity is more important -- theirs or that of the prostitutes' customers.
"This is Long Island; you're supposed to be able to enjoy your privacy, and it's being invaded on a day-to-day basis," said Daria Cooper, who grew up here when Wyandanch was a typical middle-class suburb of homeowners. But now, she says, she is struggling to hang on, as her block falls prey to pros titutes, drug dealers and transient welfare recipients who rent from absentee landlords.
How can she instill pride in her children, she asked, when outsiders treat their home with such disdain? "It's like it's O.K. to come into Wyandanch and dishonor it and then go home to your own neighborhood," she said.
The letter-writing campaign was one of the first actions taken by the civic association, founded last year to deal with deteriorating conditions in Wyandach. An unincorporated village, meaning that it has no government of its own and depends on services from the town of Babylon, the once mostly white community grew rapidly in the 1950's and 1960's, when blacks from New York City moved into inexpensive prefabricated houses built during Long Island's boom years.
As the blacks moved in, the whites moved out. Now the community is about 75 percent black, with a large Hispanic population and a small minority of whites. And, residents say, Wyandanch became a dumping ground -- for unpopular civic projects, like the town incinerator, and for a disproportionate number of welfare families who brought down its tax base and drove up unemployment, crime and drugs.
 
Matter of Race
 A group of residents is fighting to incorporate Wyandanch as a village, hoping for greater control over its future. And there are other signs of a renewed spirit, the most tangible being the new $1.4 million public library on Straight Path Road in the middle of town. But it is something of an oasis. The librarian, Wendell Cherry, can look out his windows and see drug dealers on one corner, prostitutes on another.
The residents are trying to play down the racial aspect of the anti-prostitution efforts, saying that they just want prostitution to end, no matter who is doing it. But race suffuses their thinking, and the members of the civic association recently parted company with its former president, Elizabeth Layton, who is white and who organized the letter-writing campaign, saying that she could not serve as a good community spokeswoman because of her color.
Ms. Layton says the community should focus on the prostitution, not on race, and that she has long served as an advocate for both blacks and whites in Wyandanch. But many of the black members of the civic association say that Wyandanch would not be disdained by outsiders if it were a white community. Nor, they feel, would white men assume they could proposition women at will.
"These white men feel it is no different from the slave days, when they kept their women at home and at night they would go out back to the slave quarters and take their pick," said Clyde Davis, co-director of the civic group. "These are the same people who will go back to their neighbors and say, 'Those niggers -- they're worthless, they're lazy.' "
Ms. Simmons-McCord, who said her 15-year-old daughter had twice been propositioned by a black man, said that she was reluctant to bring ace into it but that it was inevitable because so many of the men were white.
Trying to gauge the usefulness of the letter-writing campaign, Inspector John Compitello, the commanding officer of Suffolk County's First Precinct, which takes in Wyandanch, acknowledged that traditional police sweeps often did little to address the problem. The prostitutes just move to another corner, and their customers return later.
Civil libertarians said they deplored what they considered an invasion of privacy, especially for people who had not been convicted, but they said they did not think the civic association was acting illegally.
