HEADLINE: Oil Use Slumps by 4.1% In Sharp 6-Month Drop

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
With the economy in recession, oil demand was 4.1 percent lower for the first half of this year than in the 1990 period, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
Bucking recent trends, production rose slightly in the first half and imports fell. 
 Although June was stronger than the earlier months, the decline in consumption, to 16.3 million barrels a day from 17 million, was the sharpest for a six-month period since 1983, said the institute, the industry's main trade association. Gasoline consumption hit a five-year low.
 
Recession Is Main Reason
 There were several factors but recession was the biggest, said Edward H. Murphy, director of finance, accounting and statistics at the institute. "If we were growing at the same rate as the first six months of last year, with no price changes, the decrease would have been eight-tenths of a percent," he said. Another factor in the decline in demand was the spike in crude oil prices earlier this year, caused by the war in the Persian Gulf.
 Prices have been lower since the war ended, but in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, crude oil for delivery next month hit $22.32, up 49 cents, the highest level since the war ended. In the longer term, however, oil company executives have recently been predicting stable prices.
The results for the first half of this year were not affected much by weather. The weather was warmer than usual for the first half of this year, which normally cuts the demand for heating oil and for oil for utility boilers, but in this case weather was not a factor, because the weather was warmer than normal in the first half of 1990, too.
Mr. Murphy, in a telephone interview, said that oil demand would not increase unless economic growth reached about 3 percent a year. "Some people are forecasting growth in that range, and others are not, but it's fair to say that even when the recession ends -- or if the recession has ended -- that very minor growth in the economy will not lead to growth in oil," he said.
Over all, according to the institute, the American economy now consumes 1.45 barrels of oil for each $1,000 of goods and services produced. In 1978, the figure was 2.2 barrels. Part of the reason is increased efficiency; for example, the mileage of the car fleet is increasing by 2 to 3 percent a year, because cars built in the 1990's are replacing those built in the 1970's. Also, industries continue to substitute natural gas or coal for oil.
With the trend in cars and in industry, the chairman of the Amoco Corporation, H. Laurance Fuller, said in an interview yesterday that "over all the demand for liquid fuel will not show much increase in the United States."
 
Domestic Output Up
 But this will not mean self-sufficiency for the American economy, he added, because over time domestic production will continue to decline and imports to rise.
In the first half of this year, however, domestic production rose, by six-tenths of a percent, to 7.43 million barrels a day from 7.39 million. Driven by high prices and the threat of more interruptions from the Persian Gulf, producers pumped everything they could in the early part of the year. This was in sharp contrast to the trend of the prior five years, during which time domestic production declined 18 percent.
With demand down and production up, imports fell sharply, by 13.3 percent, compared with the first half of 1990, to 7.34 million barrels a day from 8.47 million. Imports had been nudging the 50 percent mark, but were down to 45 percent for the first half.
The sharpest drop in demand was in heavy fuel oil, the kind used in factories and utility boilers, as well as in heating large buildings. It was down 11.3 percent. Deliveries of home heating oil and diesel fuel, which are essentially the same material, were down 4.5 percent, and gasoline was down 2.1 percent, the institute said.
 
Jet Fuel Down
 Jet fuel was down by 5.5 percent, the first six-month drop in nine years, the institute said. Among the factors was Eastern Airlines' ceasing of operations, said the institute, which concluded that passengers were finding empty seats on other airlines, with few flights added.
Gasoline prices, the institute said, were up 7 to 8 cents above the level at the middle of last year. But that includes a Federal tax increase of 5 cents, and state tax increases that average an additional penny, the institute said. It added that the rest of the increase, the part realized by oil companies as revenue, was far smaller than the increase in crude cost.
Since the beginning of this year, prices have fallen about 10 cents a gallon, the institute reported.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Note and Bond Prices Decline

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A report showing that conditions in the housing industry improved more than expected in June, and concerns about coming auctions of new securities prompted credit market participants to sell Treasury notes and bonds yesterday.
The housing report, which showed that housing starts rose 5.2 percent in June, to slightly more than a million units at an annual rate, was somewhat stronger than most economists had forecast, though analysts noted that the improvement did not suggest that housing was undergoing a robust recovery. 
 "The fact that housing starts showed an increase is somewhat surprising," said Michael Carliner, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders, which issued the report.
 
Price Report Discounted
 Traders said consumer price data issued yesterday showing that inflation at the retail level rose by just two-tenths of 1 percent last month was not a big factor in trading.
Despite the favorable overall number, the so-called core rate of inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in June, slightly higher than economists had anticipated.
Even with the increase, the core rate of inflation rose by just 3.2 percent at an annual rate in the second quarter, well below the annual rise of 6.8 percent of the first quarter.
If anything, the housing and inflation numbers seemed to conform with the view of a mild economic recovery accompanied by low inflation. Those factors are often the catalyst for a bond market rally. The fact that yields remain high is worrying to some portfolio managers.
"Given the confluence of reasonably good news on inflation, slow money growth and the economy, the bond market has had every reason to see yields move below 8 percent," said Thomas J. Steffanci, director of fixed income at the Fidelity Management and Research Company in Boston. "The fact that yields have not fallen to those levels should worry bond investors."
 
An Simple Explanation
 Traders say the explanation for why yields have not fallen is fairly simple.
"The market has nothing to focus on except supply," said David R. Duerson, manager of trading at the Security Pacific Corporation. "Under those conditions, the market needs to back up a little bit in order to absorb the new issues."
Attention to the expected flood of new issues began in earnest late yesterday, when the Treasury announced it would auction $12.5 billion of new two-year notes on Tuesday and $9.25 billion worth of five-year notes on Wednesday.
In when-issued trading after the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.94 percent, and the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.94 percent.
While traders are concerned about bidding on what is likely to be an ever-increasing supply of new Treasury issues over the next 12 months, some analysts predict the new issues will be absorbed quite easily, and that yields will fall.
"We think bonds are cheap, and that the Federal deficit will be easier to finance than most people currently believe," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at the Paine Webber Group. "We will see enough money around at the auctions. Dealers will see better demand than they currently expect. But it will take time to overcome their current worries."
 
30-Year Yield Rises
 By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96, down 15/ 32, to yield 8.49 percent, up from 8.44 percent late Tuesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 1/32, down 1/4 point, to yield 8.29 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent three-year notes were offered at 100 14/32, down 1/8 point, to yield 7.47 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates inched slightly higher. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.58 percent late yesterday, up one basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.72 percent.
 
Philadelphia Bonds
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, roughly $1 billion in new securities were priced. Among the issuers was the cash-short City of Philadelphia, which came to market with its first offering of general-obligation bonds since May 1990.
Philadelphia offered a total of $224 million worth of securities at negotiated bid through an underwriting syndicate led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.
More than $170 million of the bonds were insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation and the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company.
However, $50 million worth of 25-year bonds maturing in 2016 were not insured, and carried no debt rating. The insured pieces of the offering were rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The uninsured securities carry an 8 5/8 percent coupon and were priced at 97.719, to yield 8.85 percent.
"We came to the market with the objective of pricing the last series of bonds at less than 9 percent, and we were successful," said Ben Blakney, Philadelphia's treasurer. "It seems the market feels the city is on the road to recovery."
Underwriters said the issue had been oversubscribed.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were narrowly mixed.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most securities dipped by about 1/8 point, according to market participants.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rose 0.2% in June

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose modestly in June, the Government said today in a report indicating that the economic recovery was causing few inflation problems.
The Labor Department's Consumer Price Index was up only two-tenths of 1 percent, after a three-tenths of 1 percent rise in May. A decline in energy costs helped to offset a sharp gain in the prices of fruits and vegetables. 
 Some analysts said they were concerned because prices outside the volatile food and energy categories rose four-tenths of 1 percent, but others noted this "core rate" was driven in part by a jump in tobacco prices and other factors that were not directly connected to the state of the economy.
 
Weekly Earnings Up
 "I consider these price trends very favorable," said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group, a Washington consulting firm.
The mild price rise helped to lift the inflation-adjusted weekly earnings of United States workers by nine-tenths of 1 percent in June after a 1 percent increase in May.
"For a stronger recovery, two things are required," Ms. Shaber said. "One is more jobs, and one is better prices. This is one of those two major elements."
The inflation report, along with a Commerce Department report that housing starts rose 5.2 percent in June, supported the optimistic view that was presented to Congress on Tuesday by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. He pointed to "compelling signs that the recession is behind us" and "promising signs of a slowing in inflation."
For the first half of 1991, consumer prices increased at an annual rate of 2.7 percent, well below the 6.1 percent advance for all of 1990, which was the worst in eight years.
The price swing from 1990 to 1991 was largely attributable to oil prices, which fell steeply after surging when Iraq invaded Kuwait last August. But the Labor Department said food prices and prices excluding food and energy were also advancing at a slower rate this year.
In June, food prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent after no change in May. A 6.1 percent jump in fresh fruits and vegetables accounted for 95 percent of the advance.
 
Weather Factors
 Mark Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., said orange and avocado prices were still affected by a freeze in California early this year. Lettuce and tomato prices have been hurt by excessive rain in the Southeast, and rain has washed out the cherry crop in Washington state.
Energy prices fell 1 percent, with declines registered for gasoline, fuel oil and natural gas and electricity. In the first half of the year, petroleum-based energy costs fell at an annual rate of 30 percent, after rising 35.4 percent in 1990.
The various changes left the Consumer Price Index, before adjustment for seasonal variations, at 136 in June, 4.7 percent higher than the 129.9 level a year ago. That means a market basket of goods and services costing $136 last month would have cost $129.90 in June 1990.
Here are some details concerning the June prices:
*New car prices edged up two-tenths of 1 percent, and used-car prices jumped 1.1 percent. These were somewhat offset by a 1.8 percent decline in automobile financing charges.
*Airline fares rose six-tenths of 1 percent in June after dropping 9.7 percent over the previous three months.
*A six-tenths of 1 percent increase for women's and girls' clothing was offset by lower prices for jewelry, watches and footwear.
*Medical care expenses were up six-tenths of 1 percent, in line with the usually steep increase in that area. Costs were 8.8 percent higher than a year ago.
*The prices of home furnishings and toiletries each fell six-tenths of 1 percent.
*Out-of-town lodging expenses jumped 1 percent, tobacco prices climbed 2.1 percent and tuition and school fees were up eight-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Utility Pressed by Creditors

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHOENIX, July 17

 BODY:
The Tucson Electric Power Company, the struggling Arizona utility, said today that it was unnecessary for creditors to have filed petitions seeking to force the company to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
Six creditors filed the petitions on Tuesday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Phoenix. The case has been transferred to Tucson. 
 The company has 30 days to respond to the petition, said George Miraben, Tucson Electric's vice president.
The filing will not affect service, staff or payments to creditors, Mr. Miraben said. State regulators have said they are concerned about the possible effect on Tucson Electric's 270,000 customers, especially regarding the utility's rates.
The utility, facing $2.7 billion in bank debt, supply contracts, leases and additional obligations, has been in default on payments to some creditors since Jan. 31.
Analysts say Tucson Electric's problems stem from actions by earlier management, which sold off some electricity-generating plants and used capital to diversify into other industries, like real estate and automobile financing. The diversified investments have fared poorly in the recession, and Tucson Electric is shedding them.
The utility, which has been trying to avoid a Chapter 11 filing, said on Tuesday that the filing was premature and unnecessary.
Ira Adler, its senior vice president and chief financial officer, said the filing would be more costly.
The six creditors named in the petition were the Emerson Finance Company, the IBM Credit Financing Corporation, the Philip Morris Capital Corporation, Harvey Hubbell Financing Inc., the United States Trust Company and the Ford Motor Credit Company.
Jon Harmon, a spokesman for Ford Motor Credit, said that since the company was unable to meet its many interests under a reorganization plan, "an organized bankruptcy procedure under Chapter 11 is the best way for all those needs to be met."

HEADLINE: Gephardt Makes It Official: He's No '92 Candidate

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Citing the press of duties as House majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt announced today that he would not seek the 1992 Democratic nomination for President.
In a two-page letter sent to his Democratic colleagues in the House, Mr. Gephardt said President Bush could be defeated in 1992, but that someone else would have to do it. 
 "In the end, how a public servant can best serve the causes in which he or she believes cannot be determined by polls, and cannot be resolved even with the best intentioned advice of others," the Missouri Congressman wrote.
In an interview later, Mr. Gephardt said he made his decision in the last few days after being persuaded to "take one more look" at the possibility of running.
Mr. Gephardt's announcement ended months of speculation about his future plans. He had repeatedly said that he was not running for office and that it was impossible to do his job as majority leader and run for President at the same time. But Mr. Gephardt had continued to raise money for and solicit advice privately about the wisdom of another campaign.
 
Gore Considering the Race
 Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic consultant in Washington, contended, "If he had run, he clearly would have been the most formidable candidate in the race."
At a breakfast meeting with reporters today, Senator Al Gore, a Tennessee Democrat who also sought the Presidency in 1988, said he is seriously considering running again and would make a decision by September.
"I honestly believe that this time around, the conventional wisdom right now is dead wrong," he said. "I think that President Bush is not only beatable, I think that he is going to start a decline in the polls that will last up to the November election. And I think he deserves to be beaten."
Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House, said he would have supported Mr. Gephardt "enthusiastically" had he chosen to seek the Presidency.
"But from the standpoint of the House, this is a decision in which all Democrats can take great pleasure," Mr. Foley said. The decision would lend "continuity, stability and exceptional leadership" to the chamber.
In recent weeks, the top Democratic leadership has been reshuffled in the aftermath of the decision by Representative William H. Gray 3d,, the House majority whip, to leave Congress.
Mr. Gephardt, 50 years old, sought the Presidency in 1988 in a grass-roots effort and on a platform that emphasized trade issues. He dropped out of the race in March of that year after he was badly beaten in the 20-state Super Tuesday primaries.
 
Shifting Role for Gephardt
 The chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Ronald H. Brown, said in a statement that Mr. Gephardt's decision would only shift his role in the Presidential nominating process, not eliminate it.
"As majority leader, he will continue to spearhead the Democratic effort to provide economic recovery for America and leadership to those most hurt by George Bush's extreme policies," Mr. Brown said.
Only one Democrat has announced his intention to challenge President Bush next year, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts.
Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia have said they are exploring the possibility of running. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York are also considered possible candidates.
Mr. Gephardt said that holding a leadership position in the House had changed his priorities this year and he felt the House was the best place to lay the groundwork for domestic issues that the Democrats would need to challenge President Bush.
 
Easier Decisions for Others
 "I don't understand how leaving now and destalizing the place would help that end," he said.
Mr. Garin speculated that Mr. Gephardt's announcement would help crystallize the decision-making process for other Democrats who are considering running.
"The fact that he's not running means this will be very much a wide-open affair now," Mr. Garin said.
Mr. Gephardt said he would help Democratic Presidential candidates "shape, define, and advance the Democratic message" on economic, education and productivity issues.
An aide to Senator Rockefeller said Mr. Gephardt called him at noon to inform him of his decision. Mr. Rockefeller praised the majority leader and said he expected Mr. Gephardt to "continue to contribute ideas and to shape the debate" within the party as the Presidential campaign season begins.

HEADLINE: Senate Backs Bill Allowing Abortion Counseling

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
The Senate voted today to overturn a Federal regulation that prohibits abortion counseling in federally financed family planning clinics. But the voice vote, conducted in a rush with only a few senators on the floor, was an inconclusive indicator of whether the measure would survive a Presidential veto.
The bill, sponsored by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, would bar the Department of Health and Human Services from enforcing the regulations, which it wrote in 1988. Those regulations were upheld by the United States Supreme Court in May. 
 But the measure passed today raised nearly as many questions as it answered. Two amendments approved by the Senate take opposite approaches to the issue of whether parents of minors seeking abortions should be notified before the procedure is performed.
One version, sponsored by Senator Daniel R. Coats, Republican of Indiana, would force clinics to notify the girl's parents; the other, sponsored by Senator George J. Mitchell, the Maine Democrat who is the majority leader, would allow adults other than the parents to determine whether a girl is mature enough to make the decision on her own.
 
Similar Bill in House
 The House has passed a similar measure allowing abortion counseling as part of a larger appropriations bill. But the House has not addressed the issue of parental notification.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Energy Subcommittee on Health and Environment, which is considering a separate bill to allow abortion counseling, said today that the Senate vote "created much confusion."
Referring to the current ban on abortion counseling, Mr. Waxman added: "But amidst all this confusion, one thing is also clear. The Congress is determined to overturn the gag rule."
 
Why a Voice Vote?
 The vote today on the Chafee bill was also less than decisive because of the last-minute negotiations that led to an agreement to hold only a voice vote. Both sides gained from a voice vote. Supporters of abortion rights had been sure the Chafee bill would pass, but less confident they would receive the two-thirds majority needed to override a Presidential veto. Abortion opponents had been worried that they would be badly beaten on a roll-call vote after an Administration alternative was defeated 64 to 35 on Tuesday.
That alternative, sponsored by Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, would have continued to ban abortion counseling at federally financed clinics but would have allowed patients to be referred to other hospitals or clinics that performed abortions.
"The thought was, Seek result; get it passed," Mr. Chafee said today.
The Chafee bill gained additional support today when it was amended to exempt seven states that already have parental notification laws from the effect of the Coats and Mitchell amendments. Those states are California, Connecticut, Maine, Maryland, Florida, Oregon and Wisconsin.
Mr. Chafeee said reaching a two-thirds majority on the bill today would not have guaranteed that senators would override a veto.
At least two Republicans, Senators Orrin Hatch of Utah and Jesse Helms of North Carolina, said today that they had talked by telephone this morning with John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff who is in London with President Bush at the economic summit meeting. Mr. Hatch said Mr. Sununu assured them that the President still intended to veto the counseling measure if it passed.
 
Reaction to Vote
 Lobbyists on both sides of the issue expressed disappointment and confusion about the outcome.
Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, praised the Senate for what she described as a decision to "renounce Government intrusion into the doctor-patient relationship." But she said the conflicting parental notification provisions "raise serious concerns about the health and well-being of young women facing crisis pregnancies."
Douglas Johnson, legislative director of the National Right to Life Committee, said he was hopeful that a Presidential veto might be sustained and that the Senate passed the Coats parental notification amendment. But he also called it "regrettable" that the Senate passed the Chafee bill, which he said would "require promotion of abortion as birth control in federally funded clinics."

HEADLINE: Earnings Up at United Telecom and Pactel

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
United Telecommunications Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter profit more than doubled from a year ago, largely because of better earnings at its U S Sprint long-distance phone company.
Separately, the Pacific Telesis Group reported a 10 percent rise in its second-quarter profit but said most of the increase resulted from one-time gains. Meanwhile, Ameritech, another regional phone company, said its profit slipped 14 percent. 
 Following are details of the results:
 
United Telecom
 United Telecom said net income increased to $89 million, or 41 cents a share, from $41 million, or 18 cents a share, in the quarter last year.
In the period a year earlier, United Telecom's profit was reduced by a one-time charge of $72 million. The charge primarily covered the cost of a restructuring at Sprint that included the elimination of 1,000 jobs.
Revenue totaled $2.21 billion in the second quarter, up 7 percent from $2.07 billion in last year's comparable period.
United Telecom's' shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $29.125, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Sprint's operating income rose to $73 million on revenue of $1.36 billion. That was in contrast to an operating loss a year earlier of $42 million, after the $72 million charge, on revenue of $1.24 billion.
"We're pleased with the improvement in Sprint's operating results," said William T. Esrey, United Telecom's chairman and chief executive officer. "We remain focused on improving Sprint's margin and containing costs."
 
Pacific Telesis
 Pacific Teleis earned $316 million, or 80 cents a share, for the three months ended June 30, compared with $287 million, or 72 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1990.
The results of the San Francisco-based company were helped by the sale of cellular telephone holdings, the settlement of a lawsuit in St. Louis and the sale of the company's stake in Microtel, a communications partnership in Britain.
The one-time gains amounted to 7 cents a share. Without them earnings would have been up a penny, about 1 percent.
Revenue was $2.52 billion, up 4 percent from $2.43 billion in 1990's second quarter.
Sam Ginn, the chairman and chief executive, said he was pleased by the results, calling them solid in spite of the sluggish economy.
Pacific Telesis stock closed unchanged, at $40.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Ameritech
 Ameritech, based in Chicago, said it earned $303.9 million, or $1.15 a share, in the second quarter, down from $352.3 million, or $1.33 a share, a year earlier.
Revenue rose 2.2 percent, to $2.74 billion from $2.68 billion.
William L. Weiss, chairman and chief executive officer, attributed the earnings decline to increased costs, particularly for higher depreciation and support of increased levels of business. Among the costs was the installation of a new customer billing system.
Ameritech stock rose 25 cents, to $58.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: HOUSE VOTES LIMIT ON HIRING IN STRIKE

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
By a substantial but less-than-veto-proof majority, the House today passed a bill that would prohibit employers from hiring permanent replacements for union members on strike.
The vote followed five hours of debate in which Democrats repeatedly contended that the right to strike was disabled if employers could permanently take strikers' jobs away, and Republicans argued that the bill would tip the labor-management balance toward unions, cause more strikes and diminish American competitiveness. 
 The vote 247 to 182, with 230 Democrats, 16 Republicans and one independent in favor and 33 Democrats and 149 Republicans opposed. The total in support was 43 short of the 290 required to override a veto if all House members vote.
Throughout the debate, Republicans reminded the House that President Bush had threatened to veto the bill. "Everybody in this chamber knows H.R. 5 is going nowhere," insisted Representative Tom Ridge, Republican of Pennsylvania.
 
Bill Seen as 'Detrimental'
 Both Lynn Martin, the Secretary of Labor, and the Office of Management and Budget said again today that the President's senior advisers would urge him to veto the bill. Ms. Martin said the bill "would be detrimental to the nation's economic health." She said it would destroy the balance that now exists by "insulating employees from the traditional risks that have checked strikes."
Representative William D. Ford, the Michigan Democrat who heads the committee on Education and Labor, insisted "the survival of collective bargaining in the United States is at stake." Representative Major R. Owens, Democrat of Brooklyn, said the bill was necessary to change the law to make it match what most Americans thought it already provided: "You can't get fired for striking."
Democrats argued that even though the hiring of permanent replacement workers had been approved by the Supreme Court in 1938, it had not been a widespread practice until the 1980's, when the airlines began using it frequently. Mr. Ford said "more and more employers each year are turning to the threat or use of permanent replacements as a way to coerce and intimidate union workers."
Republicans disagreed. Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, said the bill "will hasten the closedown of many businesses." Representative Don Ritter, Republican of Pennsylvania, said the bill made strikes easier. He said the country needed fewer strikes if it was to "meet the global competitive challenge."
For the American Federation of Labor and Congres of Industrial Organizations, this bill remains one of its two or three most important legislative priorities. Bob McGlotten, director of the federation's Labor Department who lobbied outside the House chamber, said the measure "goes to the heart of the labor movement's existence."
The bill, the Workplace Fairness Act, would prohibit employers from permanently replacing union workers who are striking over wages, benefits and working conditions. Temporary replacements during a strike would be allowed. Employers would also be barred from giving any advantage on the job to a striking worker who returns to work.
Current law prohibits the hiring of permanent replacements in strikes over unfair labor practices or illegal conduct by employers.

HEADLINE: Three Big Military Contractors Report Profits for Quarter

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 17

 BODY:
The General Dynamics Corporation and the Northrop Corporation, two of the nation's largest military contractors, reported higher profits today for the quarter ended June 30. Another big aerospace company, the Rockwell International Corporation, posted a decline in earnings.
General Dynamics said its net income for the quarter was $211 million, or $5.04 a share, compared with a $240 million loss in the corresponding period last year. Reflecting the decline in Pentagon spending, sales for the quarter were down almost 7.7 percent, to $2.42 billion from $2.62 billion. 
 The results for this year's quarter were helped by a one-time gain of $140 million from a favorable tax adjustment. Results for the quarter last year reflected a charge against earnings of $330 million to account for troubles on two big military contracts.
General Dynamics, based in St. Louis, said the tax adjustment stemmed from the completion of an audit by the Internal Revenue Service of its results for 1977 through 1986. The company said it would be permitted to use certain investment tax credits, research and developments credits and other tax credits. As a result, General Dynamics said, it was able to reduce its reserves for income taxes by $140 million, giving it a gain of that amount in the quarter.
Like most military contractors, General Dynamics is concentrating on wringing more profits from the weapons programs it has and on avoiding costly technical risks. Like many of its competitors in recent quarters, General Dynamics's earnings looked good compared with the quarter a year ago simply by not having any write-offs for technical problems and delays.
General Dynamics also benefited from improved profitability in its tank-building division and its Cessna small airplane business.
The company's stock gained 50 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $44.
Following are the details of the other companies' results:
 
Northrop
 Northrop said its net income for the quarter was $36.2 million, or 77 cents a share, a 23.5 percent increase over the period last year, when the company earned $29.3 million, or 63 cents a share.
Northrop's sales for the quarter declined by 6 percent, to $1.33 billion from $1.41 billion.
Northrop, based in Los Angeles, said its earnings for this year's quarter included an after-tax charge of $8.4 million to settle accusations that it had defrauded the Air Force by improperly testing missile components. The financial charge amounted to $21.8 million on a pretax basis and included $11.8 million to replace hydraulic fluid in the guidance devices for the Air Force's cruise missiles. Northrop has acknowledged that the fluid may freeze at temperatures higher than those demanded by Air Force specifications.
Northrop attributed the decline in sales to a slowdown in deliveries on the F/A-18 fighter program, the end of the company's effort to win a new Air Force fighter contract and decreased demand for military electronics. The declines were partly offset by higher sales of missiles and of components for the Boeing Company's 747 jetliner.
Northrop's shares closed at $28.625 on the Big Board today, up $1.
 
Rockwell International
 Rockwell International said its earnings for the quarter, the third of its fiscal year, declined 11.6 percent, to $151.4 million, or 65 cents a share, from $171.2 million, or 71 cents a share. The company has fewer shares outstanding this year because of a share-repurchase program.
Rockwell said its sales fell 4 percent, to $2.99 billion for the quarter, from $3.13 billion in the similar period last year.
The company, based in Los Angeles, said earnings in its electronics segment declined 18 percent, largely because of lower demand for industrial automation and avionics products. It said the automotive components business was weak because of depressed worldwide markets, as was its graphics business, but that earnings in military electronics and aerospace remained strong.
Donald R. Beall, Rockwell's chairman, said the company now expects its earnings for the year to dip slightly from last year, excluding a one-time gain from the sale of a business, primarily because of the national recession.
"We do not now see our businesses benefiting significantly from an economic recovery in this fiscal year," Mr. Beall said.
Rockwell's shares lost 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange, closing today at $27.125.

HEADLINE: Mixed Earnings Picture Is Presented by Banks

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
As the nation's banks report their second-quarter earnings, a mixed picture is emerging. Earnings are generally down, hurt by the banks' need to set aside money for future bad loans. But a few banks appear to have put their worst problems behind them.
Two banks reporting lowered earnings are among those involved in the recent spate of mergers. The Fleet/ Norstar Financial Group yesterday reported quarterly earnings of $28 million, or 23 cents a share, down from $54.1 million, or 47 cents a share, in the 1990 period. And the C&S/Sovran Corporation, engaged in merger talks with the NCNB Corporation, reported earnings of $64 million, or 45 cents a share, off from $79.8 million, or 57 cents a share, a year earlier. 
 C&S/Sovran's earnings announcement came late Tuesday night after the bank's chairman issued a statement indicating that his directors were still not fully committed to the NCNB merger. Bennett A. Brown, the bank's chief executive, repeated that statement yesterday and said that C&S/Sovran's board had "not made a decision to depart" from its "strategy of being an independent institution" and that there were "still important issues" between the two institutions to be "negotiated and resolved."
 
Real Estate Troubles
 C&S/Sovran has been plagued by a large number of nonperforming real estate loans, particularly in the Washington area. During the quarter, nonperforming assets increased by $153.8 million, to $1.3 billion. At the same time, the bank set aside $169.5 million for future bad loans, compared with $183.3 million in the first quarter and $123.6 million a year ago.
What happened at C&S/Sovran, is a tale retold at some -- but not all -- banks that reported yesterday: Bad real estate loans and third world debt are forcing banks to set aside more money for future loan write-offs, which cut into earnings. Only a few strong banks appear to have bucked this trend.
"It's really mixed," said Michael Starr, an analyst at Duff & Phelps in Chicago. "Industry earnings are down. But what we see is that at higher-quality banks, some of the problems seem to be subsiding. At the lower end, we still see a deterioration in loan quality that is impairing earnings."
C&S/Sovran's stock gained 62.5 cents yesterday, closing at $25.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The following also reported earnings yesterday:
 
Fleet/Norstar
 Fleet/Norstar Financial Group's quarterly earnings do not include results from its acquisition of the Bank of New England, which is still being integrated into the company. A spokesman said the bank may begin to report earnings on a consolidated basis in the next quarter.
On its own, J. Terrence Murray, Fleet's chairman, said the bank was "still feeling the effects" of the recession. Still, he said he was "particularly encouraged" that the growth in nonperforming assets during the quarter was the smallest of the last seven quarters.
During the quarter, nonperforming assets rose $57 million, to $1.5 billion. The bank set aside $114.5 million during the quarter for bad loans, up from $89.7 million a year earlier.
The bank's shares gained 25 cents, to $25.625.
 
First Interstate
 First Interstate Bancorp, the largest bank in Los Angeles, reported yesterday that it was taking a $295 million provision for bad loans, and as a result had a large loss for the quarter -- $80.3 million. "We are truly disappointed with these results," said Edward M. Carson, First Interstate's chief executive.
The loss is in contrast to a profit of $95.1 million, or $1.42 a share, in the 1990 second quarter. In that period, the bank set aside $117 million for future bad loans.
Mr. Carson said the bank's total nonperforming assets decreased slightly, to $1.8 billion.
First Interstate's shares were unchanged at $31.
 
Republic New York
 Results were brighter at the Republic New York Corporation, where earnings rose slightly, to $56.4 million, or $1.48 a share, from $52.6 million, or $1.43 a share, a year ago.
At the same time, the bank's board authorized a 3-for-2 stock split, which will be put before shareholders in September. During the quarter, the bank increased its provision for loan losses by $16 million. The bank has total nonperforming assets of $183.2 million.
The bank's stock closed at $64.50, up $1.25.
 
Continental Bank
 The Continental Bank Corporation in Chicago also had a positive report, with second-quarter earnings of $31 million, or 41 cents a share, in contrast to a 1990 second-quarter loss of $57 million. The bank took several one-time charges in 1990.
Compared with the 1990 first quarter, when the bank earned $28 million, or 35 cents a share, however, Continental's performance was relatively flat.
"Due to the impact of the recession on our customers, we have incurred higher loan charge-offs, and, continuing to be prudent, we further increased the provision to bolster the reserve for credit losses," the chairman and chief executive, Thomas C. Theobald, said.
The bank has $770 million in nonperforming assets. In the quarter, it set aside $63 million for future bad loans.
Continental's shares added 12.5 cents, to $13.50.
 
Shawmut National
 The Shawmut National Corporation, one of New England's leading banks, lost money, but less than in the first quarter. The bank lost $58.7 million, in contrast to a profit of $30.2 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. In the first quarter of 1991, it lost $116.7 million.
The bank set aside $101.6 million during the quarter for bad loans, almost four times the $25.9 million in the 1990 second quarter. The bank's nonperforming assets declined slightly, to $1.6 billion.
Shawmut's stock gained 25 cents, closing at $6.125.
 
Barnett Banks
 In Florida, Barnett Banks Inc. reported that earnings fell to $29.2 million, or 42 cents a share, in the quarter, from $58.5 million, or 93 cents a share, a year earlier. During the quarter, the bank's loan-loss provision totaled $85.6 million, up from $45.6 million a year earlier.
The bank's shares lost 87.5 cents, to $29.

HEADLINE: Loss for Apple; Record Profit at Intel

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 17

 BODY:
Apple Computer Inc. today reported increased revenues but a net loss for its third fiscal quarter because of lower profit margins and charges associated with layoffs and reorganizating.
Apple also said that while growth in shipments of its Macintosh personal computers remained strong, the growth rate fell to 60 percent, from 85 percent in the quarter a year earlier. 
 In its second-quarter report today, the Intel Corporation reported record revenues and earnings, defying the slowdown affecting many of its computer industry customers.
For its third fiscal quarter, ended June 28, Apple had a loss of $53.1 million in contrast to earnings of $119.8 million, or 96 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. The loss reflected a one-time restructuring charge of $224 million, or $138.9 million after taxes. Revenues rose 12 percent, to $1.53 billion, from $1.36 billion in the third quarter of the 1990 fiscal year.
Doug van Dorsten, an analyst with Shearson Lehmann Brothers in San Francisco, said it was clear from Apple's second-quarter results that estimates for this year and next would have to be adjusted downward, but he said the company was still on track.
"The charge was staggering, but it isn't for anything bad, like obsolete inventory or equipment," Mr. van Dorsten said. "They're still growing at way greater than the industry rate," which is 8 to 10 percent compared with Apple's 60 percent, he said.
Apple shares closed at $42.50 today, down $1.25. The earnings were announced after the market closed.
Apple laid off 900 employees during the quarter and plans to lay off about 600 more as part of efforts to reduce costs. While unit shipments of the Macintosh have continued to grow, the growth has mostly come from the low-priced Macintosh Classic model, which is sold at a lower profit margin. Sales of Apple's high-end models have been sluggish, putting further pressure on profits. Apple said its restructuring and cost reduction efforts would continue over the next 12 to 18 months.
"Apple's market share is growing as we continue to post significant increases in unit shipments and revenue," John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "Now, we are taking important steps to lower our costs because success in this industry in the future will depend on increasingly cost-effective operations in addition to technological and market leadership."
Mr. Sculley said that Apple's restructuring, while painful in the short run, would make the company more competitive. In another effort to increase its competitiveness, Apple recently announced plans to collaborate with the International Business Machines Corporation in software, microprocessor and multimedia technology.
"The personal computer industry is undergoing fundamental changes that will shape the global information economy far into this decade," Mr. Sculley said. "We are committed to redesigning Apple's infrastructure and financial model so that they are both sustainable advantages within the dynamics of this changing industry."
 
Intel
 For the quarter, Intel had earnings of $230.8 million, or $1.10 a share, up 35 percent from $170.7 million, or 84 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues rose 29 percent, to $1.25 billion, from $968.3 million in the second quarter of 1990. Per-share figures reflect an increase in shares outstanding to 209.8 million from 203.8 million.
Intel shares fell $1.50, to $44.25, in over-the-counter trading. Analysts said the decline might have resulted from Intel's hints that demand was easing for its 386 DX and 386 SX microprocessors. Intel's share price had dropped three weeks ago when some semiconductor distributors said they had an oversupply of 386 chips.
"It appears we're catching up with demand for our Intel 386 DX and SX microprocessors," Andrew W. Grove, Intel's president and chief executive, said in a statement. "As this occurs, we're moving more capacity to our new Intel 486 and Intel 386 SL microprocessors, which are still supply-constrained." He added that expanded output had eased the tight supply of 386 DX and SX chips.
Intel has also faced its first competition on the 386 with the introduction earlier this year of 386 clones made by Advanced Micro Devices Inc. While sales of these chips have helped revive Advanced Micro's results, analysts say they have not shipped in sufficient numbers to have a significant impact on Intel.
Millard Phelps, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist, said the quality of Intel's results was a matter of perception. "There are probably an equal number of people raising and lowering numbers out there," he said, referring to estimates for the third and fourth quarters. "I raised mine."
Mr. Phelps added that the easing of demand for the 386 did not appear to have bloated inventory levels and that the company was successfully shifting customers to the 486.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Multimedia Profits Up; Tribune and Others Off

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Three big media companies -- the Tribune Company, McGraw-Hill Inc. and the Pulitzer Publishing Company -- reported declines in second-quarter profits yesterday, but Multimedia Inc. reported a 50 percent increase.
Most media companies have been hurt by the recession, which has depressed demand for broadcast and print advertising. 
 Following are details of the results:
 
Tribune
 Tribune, based in Chicago, said second-quarter profits declined 4 percent, to $53.7 million, or 77 cents a share, from $56.1 million, or 78 cents a share, in the quarter last year. Revenues dropped 18 percent, to $540 million, from $656 million last year.
Operating profit rose 1 percent, to $102.4 million, but net interest expense rose 43 percent, to $12 million.
The newspaper division's operating profit was up 11 percent, to $60.4 million. Results a year earlier included losses at The Daily News in New York, which was sold to the British publisher Robert Maxwell in March.
Second-quarter advertising revenue was down 9 percent, including a 16 percent drop in classified ads, while circulation revenue rose 5 percent. Comparable results a year earlier do not include those of The News.
Operating profit dropped 9 percent, to $45 million, in the broadcast and entertainment group, and dropped 20 percent, to $2.4 million, in newsprint operations.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Tribune's stock gained 12.5 cents a share, closing at $45.75.
 
McGraw-Hill
 The publishing, broadcasting and business-information company based in New York earned $34.9 million, or 71 cents a share, down 6.2 percent from $37.2 million, or 76 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter slipped two-tenths of 1 percent, to $456.9 million, from $457.8 million a year earlier.
Joseph L. Dionne, chairman and chief executive, said the recession's impact in key markets was a major factor. The financial services unit, which includes the Standard & Poor's Corporation, a credit-rating service, was the only unit to post a significant gain in revenue and profit for the quarter.
Operating profits in information and publication services, including Business Week magazine, fell 28.2 percent, partly because of a weak ad marketplace. Operating profit in broadcasting fell 3.9 percent, and was off slightly in educational and professional publishing.
On the New York Stock Exchange, McGraw-Hill's stock lost 25 cents a share, closing at $58.75.
 
Pulitzer
 The publisher, which is based in St. Louis, said second-quarter earnings dropped 12.3 percent, to $4 million, or 39 cents a share, from $4.6 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue slipped to $102 million from $103.9 million.
Full-run advertising linage was down 14 percent at the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and 7 percent at The Tucson (Ariz.) Daily Star, the company said.
Pulitzer's broadcasting revenue declined 4.4 percent, reflecting generally weak advertising demand, particularly in automotive and political advertising.
Pulitzer's stock gained 50 cents a share in over-the-counter trading to close at $22.50.
 
Multimedia
 The company, based in Greenville, S.C., earned $14.4 million, or 39 cents a share, in the second quarter, up 50 percent from the $9.6 million, or 26 cents a share, earned in the quarter last year. Revenue rose 8.6 percent, to $134.6 million, from $123.9 million a year earlier. The 1990 results included an extraordinary loss of $3.1 million on debt refinancing.
Newspaper revenue was down 4.6 percent in the quarter, to $34.6 million, but revenue was up 11.3 percent from broadcasting, to $42.4 million; 14 percent higher from cable, to $33.7 million, and climbed 17.7 percent from entertainment, to $25.5 million.
Multimedia's stock lost 75 cents a share, closing at $28.75, in over-the-counter trading.

HEADLINE: Reed Sees No Big Problem If Citicorp Falls From No. 1

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, said yesterday it was quite possible that the merger trend among large regional banking companies would eventually knock Citicorp from its position as the nation's largest banking company.
But Mr. Reed also said at a meeting of Wall Street analysts that a drop in rankings "because of regional combinations would be of little importance to us." What would be worrisome, he said, would be an erosion in Citicorp's share of the national consumer banking market or its position as the leading international bank. 
 Despite the rapid growth of regional banks, their business has been limited to local consumers and businesses. None have emerged as challengers to Citibank as the only banking company to have a large enough consumer operation to afford national advertising or a brand identity.
Speaking of the bank's position as the leading international bank, Mr. Reed added, "That is a great economic benefit to us." As other banks have retreated from foreign operations, he said, businesses are finding fewer alternatives.
 
Lead in Consumer Banking
 He saw little impact on Citibank, except in the New York consumer market from the merger announced earlier this week by Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover, which would create the nation's second-largest banking company with $135.5 billion of assets. He noted that Citibank, which has overall assets of $217.3 billion, would remain the largest consumer bank in New York by a narrow margin, but would fall to second place if lending to small businesses were included.
Trading of foreign exchange and arranging complicated interest rate swaps and related financings is another area where the No. 1 ranking is important, but not threatened by the growth of regional banks, he said.
On other matters, Mr. Reed said the peak in the banking company's troubled loans "still lies ahead of us." Although troubled commercial loans, which are not accruing interest, rose only $21 million in Japan, Europe and North America, down from a $752 million increase in the first quarter, he warned that such loans would probably increase by a larger amount in coming quarters. He said Citicorp's internal measures of troubled loans showed problems increasing in California and other Western states.
Mr. Reed said the company was 40 percent of the way toward achieving its goal of cutting expenses by an annual rate of $1.5 billion by the end of 1992. Expenses were $113 million less in the second quarter than a year earlier, and he said the decline was the first he could recall in his 26 years at the company.
 
Expenses Are Being Cut
 To cut expenses further and improve the company's financial strength, Mr. Reed said there were still "12 to 15 entities around the world which we are trying to get rid of."
Thomas Johnson, Citicorp's chief financial officer, said the second quarter's $225 million gain on securities sales, without which Citicorp would have shown a large loss for the quarter rather than a profit of $43 million, came from investments held by the holding company under the direct control of Mr. Reed.
Mr. Johnson declined to elaborate, except to say that there were substantial remaining investments with an unrealized profit.

HEADLINE: Health-Care Companies Post Gains

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Reports of double-digit profits growth during the second quarter continued flowing in from pharmaceutical companies yesterday, lustrous in the sea of earnings declines pouring out of banks, chemical companies, paper companies and airlines, among others.
Wall Street analysts were not surprised, however, by the 17.3 profit increase at the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and the gains by three smaller phramaceutical concerns. 
 "This isn't an unusual quarter," said Steven Gerber, who follows the pharmaceutical companies for Oppenheimer & Company. "Pharmaceuticals are a predictable growth industry."
 
Trend of Higher Profit
 The profit increases reported yesterday ranged from 14.9 percent at the Warner-Lambert Company and 16.2 percent at the Schering-Plough Corporation to 24.6 percent at Marion Merrell Dow Inc. The trend is expected to continue when Merck & Company, the industry leader in prescription drugs, and a number of other concerns report their second-quarter results.
Baxter International Inc., the leading hospital-supply company, also continued to prove itself recession-proof for many of the same reasons as the drug companies, reporting a net income gain of 28.2 percent.
Analysts say a stream of new products, the ability to increase prices steadily at modest rates and the aging population in the industrialized world all contributed to the pharmaceutical industry's success in recent years.
Regulatory and pricing pressures are growing, but the pharmaceutical industry is also beginning to pay much closer attention to the efficiency of its operations. Savings in manufacturing and distribution are offsetting the pressures on earnings.
Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
Bristol-Myers Squibb
 Bristol-Myers Squbb, the largest domestic company in the health-care industry, earned $489.5 million, or 94 cents a share, in the quarter that ended June 30, up 17.3 percent from $417.3 million, or 79 cents a share, a year earlier. Second-quarter revenues grew 9.9 percent, to $2.73 billion, from $2.48 billion in 1990.
Bristol-Myers Squibb's gains were fueled by strong domestic sales, which rose 12 percent, double the rate at which overseas sales grew, said Richard L. Gelb, the New York-based company's chairman and chief executive. Mr. Gelb said sales of prescription drugs and medical devices were particularly strong.
Bristol-Myers Squibb sells a variety of cardiovascular, antibiotic and anticancer agents, but it is best known to consumers for products like its Excedrin pain killers, Miss Clairol cosmetics and Windex glass cleaners.
The company's shares lost 50 cents yesterday to close at $82 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Baxter International
 At Baxter, thanks to lower interest payments and cost-cutting measures, second-quarter net income rose to $141 million, or 48 cents a share, up 28.2 percent from $110 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier. Operating income, however, increased just 11 percent. Sales increased about 10 percent, to nearly $2.2 billion, from $2 billion in the 1990 quarter.
"Our revenue growth continues to be strong, and gross profit margins have improved as a result of better pricing and manufacturing efficiencies," said Vernon R. Loucks Jr, chairman and chief executive of the Deerfield, Ill., company. The increase in operating income was below the 15 percent to 18 percent that Mr. Loucks predicted last year the company would achieve through 1993, but he described the Baxter as "on track with that projection."
Sales of hospital products and services were up 8 percent, to $1.08 billion. while its home health-care group reported sales had grown 19 percent, to $539 million.
Baxter's shares gained 75 cents, to $34.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Schering-Plough
 Schering-Plough's net income rose to $167.4 million, up 16.2 percent from $144.1 million a year earlier. Sales for the quarter were up 5.7 percent, to $912.9 million, from $864 million in the 1990 quarter. Schering said revenues would have been up about 14 percent it it had not divested its Maybelline cosmetics business a year ago.
Earnings per share rose 20.3 percent, to 77 cents, from 64 cents a year earlier, because the company repurchased eight million shares.
Schering's domestic drug sales were led by strong gains from its Proventil asthma treatment and anti-cancer drugs. Sun-care products and antifungal products also did well. The Madison, N.J., company's Wesley-Jessen vision-care products posted lower earnings, said Robert P. Luciano, the chairman and chief executive.
Schering's shares fell $1, to $51.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Warner-Lambert
 Warner-Lambert posted a 14.9 percent gain in net income on sales increases of just 7.2 percent, led by successes in its prescription drug lines. Net income grew to $154.6 million, or $1.15 a share, from $134.5 million, or $1 a share a year earlier. Sales for the quarter rose to $1.24 billion, from $1.15 billion in 1990.
The 13 percent increase in prescription drug sales, to $425 million, was led by Lopid, a cholesterol regulator, which had sales of $112 million, up 18 percent from 1990. Joseph D. Williams, chairman and chief executive, who is scheduled to retire Aug. 1, said the Morris Plains, N.J., company would rely on prescription drugs to fuel future growth. Several analysts say the company is probably too small to support the research necessary for such a strategy in the long run and is a leading candidate for a merger.
Warner-Lambert said its Halls cough tablets were the leading performer in its over-the-counter health-care business, which includes Listerine mouthwash and Rolaids antacids. Overall sales for the business rose just 3 percent, to $372 million. Sales of gums and mints, led by Clorets and Trident gum, grew 4 percent, to $288 million. Other products, including Schick razors and blades, grew 8 percent, to $153 million.
Warner-Lambert's shares fell 50 cents, to $67.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Marion Merrell Dow
 Led by strong gains for its Seldane antihistamines, Marion Merrell Dow earned $162 million, or 57 cents a share, in the second quarter, up 24.6 percent from $130 million, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier. The Kansas City, Mo., company's sales for the quarter rose 14.1 percent, to $718 million, from $629 million in the second quarter of 1990.
"Marion Merrell Dow products are showing excellent growth in our newer markets and those that are in more mature markets are holding their own very well," said Joseph G. Temple Jr., chairman and chief executive. Sales of Seldane were up 31 percent from a year earlier.
The results included the performance of Nordic Laboratories Inc., a Quebec-based pharmaceutical manufacturer that has been 85.6 percent owned by Marion since April. A year ago, Marion owned just 50 percent of the Canadian concern and did not consolidate its earnings. Nordic added about 1 cent a share to net income in the recent quarter.
Marion Merrell Dow's shares rose 87.5 cents, to $36, on the New York Stock Exchange. The Dow Chemical Company owns about 69 percent of the stock.

HEADLINE: Philip Morris Profits Up 21.6% in 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products company and the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, reported yesterday that profits in the second quarter rose 21.6 percent, to $1.15 billion, or $1.24 a share, from $948 million a year earlier, or $1.03 a share. The rise was at the low end of analysts' expectations.
Much of the revenue and profit rise was attributed to last year's $4.1 billion acquisition of Jacobs Suchard A.G., a giant Swiss company that makes coffee and expensive candies like Toblerone. 
 Aided by sales of discount cigarettes, Philip Morris's tobacco business continued to grow, especially internationally. But the company's domestic food business was relatively sluggish, as expected, because of the recession.
The company's Miller beer business turned in an unexpectedly strong performance, despite higher prices resulting from new excise taxes. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday Philip Morris fell $1.625, to $66.625.
One unexpected factor in depressing an otherwise strong performance was a slight rise in Philip Morris's tax rate to 43.7 percent, from 43 percent in the quarter a year ago. The tax rate of the company will vary because of its wide variety of foreign suppliers and markets, where tax rates may change more rapidly than those in the United States.
Quarterly revenue rose 15.9 percent, to $14.77 billion, from $12.74 billion a year ago.
At Kraft General Foods, the nation's largest food company, with scores of familiar trademarks in nearly every category of the supermarket, results were mixed. Operating profit rose at Kraft USA.
Lawrence Adelman, an analyst who follows Philip Morris for Dean Witter Reynolds, estimates that while food profits rose 19 percent, excluding the Jacobs Suchard acquisition, food profits rose only 10 percent, a still relatively strong gain. Philip Morris had told analysts that it hoped for an 11 percent gain in food profits.
In the company's mainstay cigarette business, international growth, especialy last year's sale of huge quantities of cigarettes to Russia, was nearly double the rate of revenue growth for the still strongly profitable domestic market.
Foreign tobacco sales grew 23.6 percent in the quarter, to $3.13 billion, and foreign tobacco profit grew 24.3 percent, to $440 million.
But domestic cigarette sales in dollars, including the powerhouse Marlboro brand, rose 12.7 percent, to $3.19 billion, and domestic profit rose 16 percent, to $1.3 billion. Volume was relatively flat, as it has been for years, with a two-tenths of 1 percent rise in volume of actual cigarette packs sold.
Sales of discount cigarettes accounted for much of the maintenance of sales, as higher excise taxes encouraged smokers to trade down to cheaper brands.
Miller beer appeared to be benefitting from higher taxes on beer, as higher prices announced at nearly the same time as the excise taxes appeared to be accepted by most beer customers. Beer dollar sales rose 17.6 percent, to $1.13 billion, and beer profit rose 20 percent, to $108 million.
Mr. Adelman of Dean Witter estimates that actual sales of Miller six-packs rose 3 to 4 percent in the quarter, about triple the industry rate.

HEADLINE: Chapter 11 For Taj Mahal

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in a prearranged deal with creditors to reduce its $675 million "junk bond" debt.
Under the debt reorganization plan, filed Tuesday in Camden, N.J., Mr. Trump will give up half his ownership in the casino in exchange for lower interest rates on its junk bonds.
The plan also calls for a reduction in the interest rate on the casino's first-mortgage bonds from 14 percent to 11.35 percent, with some interest paid in additional bonds instead of cash.
The $1 billion Taj Mahal, which opened last year, is the largest of Mr. Trump's three casinos in Atlantic City. It was his first Chapter 11 filing.
The plan still must be confirmed by the bankruptcy court in Camden.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Rose 5.2% in June

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Builders broke ground for new houses and apartments at an annual rate of 1,040,000 in June, the third straight increase and the first million-plus month since November, the Census Bureau reported today.
The 5.2 percent advance included a sharp rebound in the Northeast, albeit from very depressed levels, with the West being the only region to show a decline. 
 At the same time, permits for future construction rose 4 percent, to a annual pace of 1,002,000, the fastest since last August.
 
'A Mild Recovery'
 But while the rise in activity was somewhat stronger than expected, analysts continued to view housing as a relatively subdued contributor to an economic rebound that itself is likely to be lackluster.
"The housing market continues to improve, but it's improving slowly, and it's improving by less in this recovery than in previous recoveries," said David W. Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. He said housing would "lead" the economy in coming months but, with starts at about two-thirds the pace of the mid-1980's, would not be strong enough to "pull" it.
"This fits with our preception of a mild recovery," added Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Today's housing figures were published as the Labor Department reported that consumer prices last month rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent over all, but a mildly unnerving four-tenths of 1 percent excluding food and energy. [Page D10.]
This was seen as consistent with modest economic reovery and not as grounds for the Federal Reserve to either relax or tighten monetary conditions.
June's 1,040,000 pace of housing starts consisted of 868,000 single-family homes and 172,000 multifamily units, according to the bureau. The total compared with 989,000 in May, a pace revised upward from the 982,000 that was initially reported.
 
No Trend Established
 The Northeast posted a sharp increase to an annual rate of 148,000, a pace 29.8 percent faster than May's 114,000 rate. Government and private analysts cautioned, however, that monthly starts figures were highly erratic and that it may take three months or more to establish even a national trend.
At their June pace, starts in the Northeast returned to the levels of last October and November.
Starts climbed 17.5 percent, to a 255,000 rate, in the Midwest and by 6 percent, to 389,000, in the South. In the West, the decline was 14.8 percent, to 248,000, offsetting a May surge.
During the first half of the year, there were 487,700 starts, 25 percent less than for the same period of 1990.
Without seasonal adjustment, nationwide starts were 104,100 last month, about twice the January low of 52,500.
 
Permits Up in All Regions
 All four regions posted gains in permits at a seasonally adjusted annual rate -- to 115,000 from 105,000 in the Northeast; to 231,000 from 221,000 in the Midwest; to 392,000 from 379,000 in the South, and to 264,000 from 261,000 in the West.
For the first six months of 1991, 470,200 permits were issued, 26 percent under the comparable period last year.
Today's report also showed that manufacturers shipped mobile homes at a 174,000 annual rate during May, 1,000 fewer than in April and 16,000 fewer than in May 1990.
Early this month, the Government reported that sales of new single-family houses fell to an annual rate of 474,000 in May. This is little more than half the level of single-family starts this year, the apparent discrepancy is explained by the fact that sales figures do not include custom-built homes for which sales contracts are signed in advance.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Housing Construction" shows new private housing starts and permits authorized, Jan. 1990-June 1991 (Source: Commerce Department) (pg. D10)

HEADLINE: 6 Industrial Companies Report Declines in Their Earnings

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Industrial companies continued to report generally depressed second-quarter earnings yesterday. Most of them cited the effects of the recession as the primary cause.
Some executives, however, said they saw signs of an upturn during the remainder of the year. 
 Following are the details of the companies' results;
 
Georgia-Pacific
 The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a lumber, paper and building products company, based in Atlanta, reported that its earnings declined 69.2 percent, to $33 million, or 38 cents a share, from $107 million, or $1.25 a share. Sales were down 15.3 percent, to $2.98 billion from $3.52 billion.
The current earnings were improved by a one-time gain of $29 million, or 34 cents a share, from the sale of 49,000 acres of timberland near Bellingham, Wash.
"Pulp and paper markets weakened during the second quarter, but there are some encouraging indications business is beginning to improve," said T. Marshall Hahn Jr., Georgia-Pacific's chairman. In addition, he said, there have been price increases in some wood building materials as a result of a "modest increase" in new home construction and reduced logging. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Georgia-Pacific closed at $55, unchanged.
 
Owens-Corning
 The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, based in Toledo, Ohio, reported a 61.5 percent decline in net income to $15 million, or 34 cents a share, from $39 million, or 92 cents a share. Sales declined 3.4 percent, to $745 million from $771 million.
"These results reflect the continued weakness in most of our major markets in the U.S., Canada, Europe and Brazil," said Max D. Weber, company chairman.
Like some other building products company executives, Mr. Weber said that it appeared as if the worst of the housing slump had passed and that modest increases in sales of those products have been recorded. He said a housing recovery in Canada seems somewhat stronger but that conditions in Europe and Brazil remain lackluster.
Sales of reinforcement materials the company supplies to the automotive and pleasure boat are expected to improve in the second half, as automobile production is expected to increase, Mr. Weber said. Owens-Corning's stock gained $2.50, to $29.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
TRW
 TRW Inc., based in Cleveland, reported that earnings declined 61.9 percent, to $24 million, or 39 cents a share, from $63 million, or $1.02 a share. Sales declined 5.7 percent, to $1.98 billion from $2.10 billion.
The company said the major cause of the earnings decline was the divestiture of its European piston ring and cylinder sleeve business, which resulted in an after-tax charge of $18 million, or 29 cents a share. It also cited "continued weak market conditions" in the automotive component and information services business it operates.
"While our space and defense segment continues to perform well, the recession has been difficult for our automotive and information businesses," said Joseph T. Gorman, the company's chairman.
The company said sales of its automotive segment fell 2 percent, to $1.04 billion, and operating profit declined 63 percent, to $31 million from $84 million. Space and military were down 11 percent, to $746 million, while operating profits were reported up slightly, to $62 million. Sales of information services rose 1 percent, to $192 million, but operating profit was down 17 percent to $15 million from $18 million. In Big Board trading, TRW's stock closed at $44.25 yesterday, up $1.
 
Maytag
 The Maytag Corporation, based in Newton, Iowa, said net income declined 38.2 percent, to $18.8 million, or 18 cents a share, compared with $30.4 million, or 29 cents a share, a year ago. Sales were down a little over 1 percent, to $777 million from $788 million.
The company said the quarter's performance was affected by a one-time charge of $10 million in connection with the closing of a plant that made vending machine equipment.
Daniel J. Krumm, the company's chairman, said he was encouraged by the fact that the second-quarter's sales exceed the $738 million recorded in the first quarter. But he warned that economic recovery in this country "is likely to be a slow, gradual process" and noted that recessions continue in other countries, including Canada and Britain.
The company said its major appliance sales in North America declined eight-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter, to $475.2 million from $478.9 million, while European sales increased 9 percent, to $122.1 million from $110.7 million. The company sells appliances under the Maytag, Magic Chef, Hoover, Jenn-Air, Admiral, Hardwick and Norge brands. Maytag stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $15.625, up 87.5 cents.
 
Champion International
 The Champion International Corporation, a pulp, paper and wood products producer, based in Stamford, Conn., reported that earnings plunged 92.9 percent, to $4.5 million from $63.5 million, or 61 cents a share. Because of preferred stock dividend requirement, the slender profit for the quarter was reported as a loss of 2 cents a share of common stock.
Sales fell 6.3 percent, to $1.18 billion from $1.26 billion.
The company said price weakness for pulp and a broad spectrum of paper grades led to the poor results. "Our mills ran very well, but we've been hammered on pulp and paper prices due to the overall weakness of the economy and new industry capacity," said Andrew C. Sigler, the company's chairman.
The company said income from operations in its paper segment was down 56 percent, to $33 million from $75 million. The company said pulp prices were soft, that uncoated papers continued to decline and that its newsprint operations has a "slight loss."
Operating income of the wood products segment was down 34 percent, to $11.6 million from $17.8 million. The company said timber shortages were helping firm prices in that market. In Big Board trading Champion's stock closed at $28.50, up 37.5 cents.
 
United Technologies
 The United Technologies Corporation of Hartford said earnings declined 79.1 percent, to $43.4 million, or 28 cents a share, from $207.5 million, or $1.52 a share. Sales declined 5.4 percent, to $5.38 billion from $5.69 billion.
"The weak economy continues to affect our core businesses even though we have made substantial progress in reducing costs," said Robert F. Daniell, the company's chairman. "Our cost-cutting efforts will continue, despite some early signs that the econmomy might be picking up."
Mr. Daniell cited expected increases in airline passenger traffic and automobile production as indicators of a possible upturn.
The quarterly results include a one-time, pre-tax charge of $148 million some restructured contracts which was partially offset by $100 million in added fees at the company's Pratt & Whitney aircraft engine division.
Operating profit at the company's power segment, which includes Pratt & Whitney, declined 54 percent, to $123 million from $266 million. The flight systems segment reported a loss of $72 million, compared with a profit of $19 million, as a result of the contract difficulties.
Income at the company's building systems segment declined 10 percent, to $124 million, largely as a result of lower profit margins at the Otis elevator operation. The company's industrial segment was off 52 percent, to $28 million, as a result of lower car and light-truck output in North America and reduced revenues because of businesses divested last year.
United's stock closed on the Big Board at $46.75, up 25 cents.
