HEADLINE: Summit in London: Reporter's Notebook;
Leader of the Free World, or Just Plain 'Geoffrey'?

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 17

 BODY:
George Bush tried not to let it bother him that Mikhail S. Gorbachev was getting the lion's share of attention at the London talks, but on Tuesday night, the President's ego took a real blow.
At Queen Elizabeth's dinner at Buckingham Palace for the seven world leaders attending the talks, Bush aides recounted, the wife of a foreign minister came up to the President and greeted him warmly. 
 "Oh, Geoffrey," the woman said. "It's so nice to see you."
"I'm George Bush, the President of the United States," Mr. Bush replied.
"Well, you sure look a lot like Geoffrey," she sniffed, drifting away.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d did not let Mr. Bush forget today that even the leader of the free world can fail to make an impression. They called the President "Geoffrey" all day.
 
Off With His Headline!
The British press had a field day reporting President Bush's "royal gaffe" today, printing pictures of Mr. Bush sitting down before Queen Elizabeth at a photo session preceding the dinner at Buckingham Palace.
The papers reported that the Queen was "not amused" and glared at Mr. Bush until he got up, allowed her to sit and then formally requested permission to take his seat by her side.
After a thorough investigation of the Case of the Missing Royal Protocol, the question arises: did the Queen set up the President?
The Queen was embarrassed on her recent trip to Washington when she was dubbed "the talking hat" after Mr. Bush failed to pull out the box that would have let the 5-foot-4-inch monarch stand properly at the White House lectern. As it was, newspapers and television showed the Queen's hat bobbing above the lectern, but not her face, and the British press called it a slight by the White House.
The Queen has been known to do tit-for-tat. When the Union Jack was flown upside down on her visit to San Francisco to see Ronald Reagan in 1983, she flew the Presidential flag upside down when Mr. Reagan visited her on her royal yacht, Britannia.
The First Lady told inquiring Bush aides that her husband told her that the Queen had invited him to sit down before her. He did, but got up again when he realized that no one else was ready to sit down. Elementary, Watson: A gaffe for a gaffe.
 
Better Read Than Dead?
But for President Bush, the most embarrassing moment of the summit meeting came at his news conference today with the Soviet President at the United States Ambassador's residence.
White House sound engineers pushed the wrong mixer button and the Russian translation, which was supposed to go to Soviet television, was accidentally sent to the American and British networks. A booming Russian voice drowned out the President's English, and confused anchormen were left scrambling to explain.
"It was mortifying," moaned a senior aide to Mr. Bush. "The President of the United States speaking Russian in front of the whole Western world."
After all, it was Mr. Gorbachev who was supposed to be coming around to Western ways, not the other way around. "Friendship is one thing," deadpanned Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman. "But we're not doing Berlitz school."
 
Mikey Likes Babs
Asked at the embassy news conference after his lunch with Mr. Bush whether he was looking for "a bundle of cash," Mr. Gorbachev made a noise of disgust and ended the session abruptly, barking "spasibo," or "thank you" in Russian.
The Soviet leader left a surprised President Bush standing at the lectern and walked over to kiss Barbara Bush. He spoke to the First Lady in Russian and she replied in English. Asked what Mr. Gorbachev had said, Mrs. Bush reported that he had made a date for the Moscow meeting later this month.
"He said he's going to take me to a lot of nightclubs," she said. Mrs. Bush later confessed that she was kidding. "I said, 'Give my love to Raisa,' and he said, 'She's having another schedule today.' I mean, we knew what each other said. That's sort of what happens in these meetings."
 
Gorbachev Agonistes
Was it a laughing harrumph or a harrumphing laugh? Was it a snort, a grunt or a guffaw? Was his voice tinged with irony or ire? Was the cast of his face serene or sullen?
It was a day for taking Mikhail Gorbachev's temperature, and the new arms control agreement was not analyzed more closely than the Soviet leader's sighs and whispers.
The frantic efforts of the other world leaders to stop Mr. Gorbachev from stealing the show was futile, of course. All anyone wanted to know was, Is "Gorby" going home on Friday strutting or slouching?
Indeed, it was less an Economic Summit than an Economic Bar Mitzvah for Mr. Gorbachev, a coming-of-age ritual in which the seven industrial powers officially allowed the Soviet leader into the capitalist tribe.
"He is crawling before he walks, moving out toward privatization," Mr. Bush said, sounding like a proud uncle and adding that Mr. Gorbachev had sounded "pretty darn positive -- let's rejoice!"
The London tabloids portrayed Mr. Gorbachev as a tattered beggar this week, and the cover of the satirical magazine Private Eye depicted him flying into town and importuning, "Got the price of a cup of tea, Guv?"
But the Soviet leader was swathed in so much respect and promises of support that while he didn't cart away cold hard cash, he was able to play statesman more than supplicant. At his news conference this evening with Prime Minister John Major of Britain, Mr. Gorbachev was not cadging a cup of tea. Rather, he observed grandly, "Whether you help us or not, that's not the point."
 
Fed Up, but Well Fed
Before his lunch with Mr. Bush at the American Embassy, Mr. Gorbachev offered reporters his philosophy: "In my position I have to be optimistic. I have to be optimistic. Otherwise, I wouldn't endure this." After lunch, the glasses of red and white wine sat, nearly full, at each place on the table in the elegant dining room.
The lunch had not been particularly liquid and the two Presidents did not talk liquidity or other nitty-gritty economic problems as they ate with their top advisers. After clinching the arms control agreement, they got right to the heart of the superpower relationship and talked about fear.
In a rare spate of listening, the usually didactic Mr. Gorbachev asked Mr. Bush, "What do you want of us?"
President Bush told Mr. Gorbachev that he wanted the Soviet Union to become a country that Americans were not afraid of, and that he wanted the United States to become a country that the Soviets were not afraid of.
Mr. Bush said he wanted to reach the point where no missiles were "staring at New York," and where Mr. Gorbachev could not show him a map of the Soviet Union encircled by American military bases.
"You're success is paramount to us," Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev, according to Mr. Bush's spokesman, Mr. Fitzwater. "We care about your success. We want to reach the point where neither of us truly believes that the other would push the button."
The two men banished their fears enough to relax at the dinner at 10 Downing Street tonight. Little of substance was discussed. Some of the leaders sang tunes, off key, that they heard the night before at the Buckingham Palace dinner. And the leaders traded menus autographed with all their names, including that of the newest member of the economic club.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN LONDON;
PACT IS REACHED TO REDUCE NUCLEAR ARMS; BUSH AND GORBACHEV TO MEET THIS MONTH; 7 POWERS GIVE SOVIETS NEW ECONOMIC ROLE

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 17

 BODY:
After nine years of negotiation, the Soviet Union and the United States reached agreement today on a strategic arms treaty, the first to mandate reductions by the superpowers, and President Bush immediately agreed to meet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow late this month.
Then Mr. Gorbachev, the proud leader of the nation where Communism first flowered, sat down with the heads of the seven most powerful capitalist nations and asked them for help in reforming an economic system that has all but collapsed. Almost 75 years after the Bolshevik Revolution, the Soviet President's pleas represented an admission of economic failure. 
 Mr. Gorbachev laid his plans before the Western leaders in what another participant described as "an eloquent performance." Officials taking part in the closed meeting reported that Mr. Gorbachev insisted that Soviet progress toward a market economy and private ownership of property was irreversible, but that he made no new proposals.
 
Gorbachev's Courage Hailed PHE>
 Nevertheless, Mr. Gorbachev won praise from the leaders of the seven countries -- the Group of Seven. Mr. Bush said the Soviet leader had shown "enormous courage" in pushing ahead with reforms.
"It's not going to be quick or easy to implement change in the Soviet Union," Mr. Bush said after the meeting, "but we believe President Gorbachev has made an irrevocable commitment."
Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, who played host to the group's 17th annual economic summit meeting, said: "This has been a day I believe that history may well see as a landmark. It will be seen as a first step toward helping the Soviet Union become a full member of the world economic community." [Excerpts from the Bush-Gorbachev and Gorbachev-Major news conferences, and from the summit's economic declaration, are on pages A10 and A12.]
The Moscow meeting was tentatively scheduled for July 30-31.
Under the provisions of the arms treaty to be signed there, the overall number of nuclear weapons in each side's arsenal will be cut by 25 to 35 percent. The American arsenal will be reduced from about 12,000 warheads and bombs to about 9,000, while Moscow's stockpile is to be reduced from roughly 11,000 to roughly 7,000.
While Mr. Gorbachev made no specific requests for immediate financial assistance, officials of several nations said, and left little time for questions, he asked the group to "take a step forward" in developing greater cooperation with his country.
"The ice has started moving; the icebreaker is on its way toward renewal," the Soviet leader told reporters later. But he quickly added, "There is need for movement from the other side," meaning the West.
Mr. Gorbachev came away with the prospect of a bit more Western aid than had seemed likely a few days ago, including pledges of a "special association" with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, extensive programs of technical assistance and an early visit to Moscow by the group's finance ministers to discuss further measures. But he won no promise of major infusions of cash.
In addition, German officials promised that they would invite the Soviet leader to attend next year's economic summit conference in Munich, and President Francois Mitterrand of France said that he favored ultimately asking the Soviet Union to join the club, making it a Group of Eight.
At the news conference tonight, Mr. Major said the meeting had established "a partnership with the Soviet Union on a new and better footing," as a first step toward Moscow's integration into the world economic system.
Mr. Gorbachev called the three-hour session "one of the most important meetings of our time."
"Today has meant a lot," the seemingly weary Soviet leader said.
"It's been a good day for the United States," Mr. Bush replied.
 
A Qualified Success
 Merely by winning admission to the forum of capitalist leaders this week, Mr. Gorbachev can claim a victory. But some things that most of the participants would have liked to give him, including full membership now or soon in the International Monetary Fund and greater drawing rights at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, were blocked by the United States and Japan.
Mr. Gorbachev had to overcome American opposition and that of hard-liners in his own country to gain an invitation to London. Still, some members of the Gorbachev delegation expressed open disappointment today with what he had achieved. One said that "the Soviet Union doesn't understand Western economics, and the Western nations don't understand Soviet politics."
Still, the arms accord is likely to help Mr. Gorbachev with his increasingly restive people, as it will free scarce resources for domestic concerns.
By the time that the strategic arms reduction treaty is carried out, probably in 1999, the number of American warheads on weapons that can reach the Soviet Union will drop by about 25 percent, and the comparable Soviet total will fall by about 35 percent. The treaty puts sub-limits on various weapons systems and is particularly tough on the Soviet SS-18 missile, the most powerful in either arsenal.
For two days, the prospect of Mr. Gorbachev's arrival here had hung over those attending the conference -- the leaders of Britain, the United States, France, Canada, Italy, Germany and Japan. Today, as his motorcade of Zil limousines flashed across central London from one meeting to another, he utterly dominated the scene, eclipsing and in some cases eliminating debate on other issues.
The summit conference never really came to grips with the environment, referring discussion of global warming and the rain forests to a United Nations conference next year on the subject and thus avoiding an all-out clash between the United States and the Europeans, especially Britain.
 
Tariff Issue Deferred
 On another difficult matter, described by everyone as crucial, the group merely pledged to complete by the end of the year the current round of talks designed to bring up to date the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. This is precisely what was promised in Houston a year ago and not delivered.
Mr. Major, who presided over this week's sessions in a bright and breezy way that contrasted sharply with the stern, hectoring manner of his predecessor, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, said it had been "a friendly and very frank summit." He added, "People did speak their minds clearly and comprehensively and on occasions in an unforgettable way."
Much of the groundwork was laid before today. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Soviet Foreign Minister, had resolved all outstanding questions on the all-important arms treaty, except one technical issue, at a series of meetings in Washington that ended Sunday. That related to the definition of a new missile, in terms of its throw-weight, or destructive capacity, for treaty purposes.
White House aides said Mr. Bessmertnykh asked this morning for a meeting with Mr. Baker just before Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev were to meet for lunch at the United States Ambassador's residence. A senior American official said the Foreign Minister brought new proposals, and after a flurry of conferences, the President and his advisers agreed that the final obstacle had been overcome.
 
'Our Hospitality'
 Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev spent most of their lunch discussing economic and other matters, then slipped into an adjoining room to ratify what had been agreed to on arms.
Beaming, the two men met briefly with reporters, Mr. Gorbachev saying that his country was "ready to give our hospitality to the President of the United States and Mrs. Bush." He had sought the Moscow meeting for the last year.
"Before you change your mind, we accept with pleasure," replied Mr. Bush, who had held out for the treaty as a condition for making the trip.
Neither side was willing to specify what the final arrangement was, because neither wanted to appear to have made the final concession, lest it be seen as soft by the legislative hard-liners in Washington and Moscow whose backing will be needed if the treaty is to be ratified.
British and American experts said the difficulties in reaching agreement were more political than military. The Soviet Union is believed to be developing a more advanced, more powerful version of one of its missiles.
The Administration wanted to head that off, remembering the deployment of the SS-19 after the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty. Critics of the 1972 agreement charged that its negotiators had failed to get tight enough language.
 
Gorbachev Explains His Country
 At his meeting with the Group of Seven, Mr. Gorbachev made no specific requests for monetary aid.
"He really was trying to explain more what was going on inside the Soviet Union, what the pressures were, what he was up against in terms of history, if you will," Mr. Bush reported. "He really stopped short of what some predicted might be on his agenda."
Mr. Major reportedly opened the meeting by telling the Soviet leader: "You are among well-wishers. The challenges you face are formidable, but the opportunities are limitless."
He said candidly, however, that the West expected reform in property rights, market prices, the breakup of state monopolies and the establishment of a Western-style legal system.
Mr. Gorbachev, in turn, spoke of the need to dismantle barriers to the Soviet economy, including trade restrictions and lack of access to loans.
Daniel Bernard, the French spokesman, described the Russian's presentation as a "particularly rich" 30-minute speech that dealt with the relationship of the Soviet republics to the central Government in Moscow and with his own reform intentions.
A British official said Mr. Gorbachev's explanation of his economic policies today was not significantly different from the plan detailed in a 23-page letter he sent to the seven leaders last week.
According to one official, Mr. Gorbachev's one-hour opening statement this afternoon and his remarks at the news conference tonight were not "very specific on details."
He left unclear, this official said, the answers to such questions as exactly how the Soviets intended to privatize state-owned enterprises and liberalize controlled prices.
"There was movement in the right direction," an official said, adding that Mr. Major would try to get clarification during his talks with Mr. Gorbachev here Thursday.
In a briefing tonight, Mr. Gorbachev's chief spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, disclosed few details of the private discussions today. He did say that Mr. Gorbachev had discussed the need to create a stabilization fund to bolster the ruble, as a way to more quickly complete the conversion of the ruble on international currency markets. However, he did not seek Western aid for such a fund. "Today was not the occasion" for that, Mr. Major explained.
 
Status of Soviet Republics
 Mr. Ignatenko said Mr. Gorbachev spoke at length about the relationship between the central Government and the republics, and assured Western leaders that he had a mandate to speak for all the Soviet Union in his attempts to press forward with an agenda of economic reform.
A six-point program of assistance was ultimately agreed on, but some of the points struck economists as imprecise and redundant, an attempt to make a small package look bigger. The Western summit partners committed themselves to these goals:
*Setting up the special relationship with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, leaving it up to the institutions and the Soviet Union to negotiate the terms.
*Urging other international organizations to make their knowledge and skills available to Moscow.
*Offering technical assistance to help the Soviets exploit energy resources, improve food distribution, increase nuclear safety, make their transportation system more efficient and convert military industries to civilian ones.
*Helping expand trade with the West and with Eastern European nations.
*Sending Mr. Major to Moscow before the end of the year to check on the progress of reform and, if appropriate, to recommend further Western aid.
*Sending the finance ministers' group to Moscow very soon.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, which has supplied most of the Western aid to the Soviet Union in the last year, had hoped for bolder action. But he spoke of "a good start."
Mr. Mitterrand said "we must, really must, reach out," and his aides said that he, too, would have liked to do much more to help the beleaguered Mr. Gorbachev than was agreed to in London.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
July Sales Were Down, but Not Spirits

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
Racing officials reported yesterday that prices were down nearly 11 percent in the final tally of the prestigious July sale of selected yearlings at Keeneland race course in Lexington, Ky.
But they expressed relief that there had been no worse decline in a market that had already plunged 40 percent in the preceding five years. 
 They also acknowledged again that the market was still being saved by heavy spending by investors from the Arab nations and Japan, who once more dominated the two days of auction sales that closed Tuesday night.
 
Encouraging Message
 The three brothers of the ruling Maktoum family of the Persian Gulf oil emirate of Dubai combined to buy 50 of the 231 yearlings sold and spent close to $25 million of the $73.5 million grossed in the auction.
"Gloom and doom were forecast before the sale," James E. Bassett 3d, chairman of the Keeneland Association, said by telephone from his office at the track.
"There was much apprehension, reflecting the national recession. But good horses brought top prices. The sale serves as a barometer of public interest, and it should send a message of encouragement to the industry. The buyers were generally pleased at the stability of the sale."
 
231 Yearlings Sold
 "It was a quality-intensive market," said Leroy Jolley, the trainer of two Kentucky Derby winners and the star filly Meadow Star. "The good ones sell high; the others don't."
The bottom line after two days of auctions showed 231 yearlings sold for a total of $73.5 million at an average price of $319,578. Last year, 234 horses were sold for $82.3 million at an average price of $352,009. At the peak of the market in 1984, yearlings were bringing $544,681 on the average at the Keeneland sale.
Blockbuster sales also softened a bit. Nine of this week's yearlings commanded $1 million or more; last year, 11 went over $1 million.
This week's high price was $2.6 million paid for a colt whose sire was the French champion Nureyev and whose grandsires were Northern Dancer and Alydar. The colt was sold by William S. Farish's Lane's End Farm to the agent Morio Sakurai, who was representing Yoshio Asakawa, a developer and manager of golf courses in Japan.
Last year's highest price was $2.9 million; the record price paid for a yearling was $13.1 million in 1985.
The biggest spender at this week's auction was Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al Maktoum, the Minister of Defense for both Dubai and the United Arab Emirates, who bought 35 yearlings for $18 million.

HEADLINE: Summit in London;
Clearing the Final Hurdles To a Strategic Arms Accord

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 17

 BODY:
In a brief encounter in the living room of the American Ambassador's residence off Regents Park, President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today ended one era in United States-Soviet relations and ushered in another.
Speaking through their interpreters, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev reached a compromise solution on a highly technical issue of throw weight on new missiles, the last remaining issue holding up the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty -- the first arms control agreement that will lead to an actual reduction in long-range nuclear weapons. 
 It was rather symbolic that, minutes after Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev sealed the deal, they immediately went on to the meeting between the Soviet leader and the leaders of seven major industrialized democracies to discuss Mr. Gorbachev's plans for economic liberalization and what the West can do to help. That is going to be the core issue in the coming era of Soviet-American relations. That is really what brought Mr. Gorbachev to London. That is why the Soviet leader wanted to get the arms treaty behind him.
 
A Different Soviet Union?
 Many American officials believe that the treaty could be the last nuclear arms control treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union, because by the time another major arms control accord is negotiated, the Soviet Union as it is now constituted, probably will no longer exist.
These officials feel that it will either be a smaller confederation of republics or a much looser confederation of independent republics, in which Moscow's ability to conclude sweeping nuclear and conventional arms control agreements with the United States will be greatly constricted.
This memorable day in United States-Soviet relations began at 9:30 A.M., when the telephone rang in Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's suite at the Churchill Hotel. It was the secretary of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, asking that Mr. Baker meet with Mr. Bessmertnykh for 15 minutes in Winfield House, the American Ambassador's residence, to share with him a "new position" the Soviets had come up with for resolving the last issue holding up the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty.
 
Definition of New Missile
 That issue was how to define what consitutes a nuclear missile's throw-weight. Throw-weight is critical to determining what will be considered a "new type" of missile under the treaty which, in turn, determines how many warheads could be deployed in a crisis.
Nine years of negotiations had failed to resolve this critical technical issue.
At 11:10 A.M. , according to American officials, Mr. Bush summoned his senior foreign policy advisers, including Mr. Baker and the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. The group sat around a white wrought-iron table in the backyard of Winfield House and went over their own "bottom line" position on the throw-weight issue and tried to guess what Mr. Bessmertnykh might come in with, a senior Administration official said.
At 11:40 A.M. Mr. Bessmertnykh arrived and laid out to Mr. Baker his country's new formula for settling the throw-weight issue, which was close to what the American side had been seeking. Mr. Baker told Mr. Bessmertnykh that he thought the Soviet proposal would probably be the basis for a "mutually satisfactory" solution.
 
Defusing Domestic Opposition
 The details of the Soviet proposal have not been disclosed, as each side has been anxious to cloud the issue of who gave the most at the end in order to avoid charges from their respective right-wing constituencies that they gave away too much to get a treaty.
One reason that Mr. Bessmertnykh was anxious to tie up the accord with Mr. Baker in Washington last week, he told American officials, was to avoid the appearance -- particularly in the eyes of the Soviet military -- that he and Mr. Gorbachev were trading the treaty for economic aid in London.
At 11:55 A.M., Mr. Baker walked back into the dining room in Winfield House and shared with Mr. Bush and Mr. Scowcroft the position outlined by Mr. Bessmertnykh, who was waiting in the hall. They agreed that this indeed was a basis for resolving the issue. Mr. Bush and Mr. Scowcroft then went out into the hall and confirmed with Mr. Bessmertnykh that as far as they were concerned the deal was done, pending final discussions with Mr. Gorbachev and pending a check with American arms control experts at home.
While Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev lunched around the American ambassador's dining table, American arms control experts in the Pentagon combed through the Soviet proposal and then telephoned Mr. Baker to tell him it met their concerns. Mr. Baker then slipped that message to the President. After Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev completed their lunch, to which both of their delegations were invited and which focused on economics, the two Presidents retired to a private living room alone -- save for interpreters -- and there, with a handshake, they confirmed the arms agreement.
Once the technical experts "signed off on it," Mr. Bush said later, "we got the thumbs up and we agreed that we had a deal."
Throw-weight is a formula that defines all those parts of the nuclear missile other than the booster rocket that sends it into space. The payload is essentially the missile nose cone, the guidance equipment that directs it to its target, as well as the individual nuclear warheads.
Under the treaty, the Soviet Union alone is committed to reducing the average throw-weight of all its missiles by 50 percent across the board. This is because the Soviets have many more of the heaviest, most lethal missiles, than the United States.
 
Shrinking Soviet Missiles
 As a result, since the beginning of the talks, the American side has tried to define throw-weight as broadly as possible -- as half the total launch weight of a missile -- since that would require Moscow to shrink its missiles that much more. The Soviets wanted to minimize the formula to spare their missiles -- especially some new ones they are now developing -- from being too sharply constricted by the treaty. In the end, they apparently somehow split the difference.
In addition, the throw-weight issue held up agreement on the treaty was because it was an essential ingredient in determining what would be defined as a "new type" of missile.
The treaty stipulates that each nuclear missile or bomber system will be allowed to carry a certain number of nuclear warheads. For instance, the Soviet submarine-launched ballistic missile, the SS-N-18, will be listed as carrying three nuclear warheads.
The treaty also says that neither side can test a missile with more warheads than it is listed as having in the treaty unless it is declared a "new type."
Once declared a "new type," the missile would be allowed to carry its own specific number of warheads, which would then be counted against the total number allowed for each side.
 
Counting Warheads
 This is important because if a missile listed by the treaty to be able to carry up to one warhead, for example, is slightly modified so that it can also carry three warheads both the modified missile and its old type would be automatically attributed as being able to carry three warheads. This is because the modification was so slight that in the event of a crisis, and one side wanted to break out of the treaty, it could easily quickly increase the number of warheads on that particular missile to three all across the board.
The only way for one side to avoid this problem and not have all of its existing missiles and their modified versions counted as carrying the same number of warheads, was if the modifications were more significant and therefore deemed more difficult to accomplish in any short period of time.
If, for instance, the throw-weight had to be changed significantly or the diameter of one of the rocket stages had to be expanded, then the missile would be declared a "new type," with its own specific number of warheads that applied only to it.
Therefore, Mr. Baker and Mr. Bessmertnykh spent a great deal of time wrangling over how significant must be the changes ina missile -- in its throw-weight and other dimensions -- to be declared a new type. They eventually agreed that it must have a 21 percent difference in throw-weight to be declared a new type, but they could not agree on what pieces of equipment should be counted as throw-weight.
This was akin to agreeing that a car's body had to be changed by 21 percent to be declared a new model car, but not being agree whether the body included the mirrors, the windows and the engine. The question was 21 percent of what? It was this "what" that the two leaders agreed on today, and in so doing brought nine years of negotiations to a close.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Bush's Faint Worries

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
With Desert Victory under his belt and a Start treaty on the verge, George Bush looks as if he might be able to walk rather than run to re-election next year. On Capitol Hill, however, troubles that now seem little bigger than a man's hand could blow into a political storm.
The most recent comfort for Mr. Bush was provided by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, who issued an optimistic economic forecast for 1992. A flourishing economy is virtually a prerequisite for Presidential re-election. 
 Mr. Greenspan said the recession was over and predicted a growth rate next year of 2 to 3 percent. That's slightly lower than the Administration wants but probably enough -- if such growth materializes -- to blunt Democratic economic criticisms.
One of the stronger potential opponents for Mr. Bush, meanwhile, was reported in The Washington Post to be about to announce that he would not run. Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, was not quoted; but the story said he had "indicated to friends" that he was "decisively leaning" against a campaign.
Mr. Gephardt's knowledgeable friends naturally left open the possibility that he might run. But these ectoplasmic confidants said he had polls showing Mr. Bush to be exceptionally strong, and feared defeat in 1992 would dim his chances for 1996.
Another of the usual suspects, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, cast further doubt in a recent television interview that he would make a White House run next year. It's hard to see why he would, if he didn't in 1988.
That year, no incumbent President was running; next year, Mr. Bush will be a heavy favorite. Mr. Cuomo won overwhelming re-election in 1986, compared with his modest victory in 1990. Then, he had no debilitating problems in Albany to mar his record; this year, he has been constantly in acrimonious battle to close a huge budget shortfall.
He refused to enter in 1988, moreover, on grounds that he could not be Governor of New York and run for President at the same time. That's as true now as then, and more evident; and it would make little sense for Mr. Cuomo to resign a powerful office he already holds for another he might well not be able to take away from a strong incumbent.
That leaves Paul Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, as the only confessed Democratic Presidential candidate. Undoubtedly, more and stronger aspirants will enter later, but time's getting short to raise the necessary money and build the necessary organization. The longer Mr. Bush seems to have no strong opponent, the stronger he'll look himself, and the less eager any Democrat will be to take him on.
In Congress, however, more trouble may be brewing than now seems likely. Robert Gates, Mr. Bush's choice to be director of the C.I.A., has run afoul of plea-bargain stipulations by a former C.I.A. official. That reawakened interest in the Iran-contra scandal, which embarrassed the Reagan Administration and conceivably could threaten Mr. Bush.
The controlling Democrats now have delayed hearings on the Gates nomination until September -- which, for Mr. Bush, is getting uncomfortably close to his re-election year. And as Senator David Boren, chairman of the Intelligence Committee, pointed out, "No one can predict whether the nominee will be helped or hurt" by the delay. That goes for Mr. Bush too.
The Senate also has rejected White House attempts at a "compromise" on the Administration rule, recently upheld by the Rehnquist Court, that prevents federally financed clinics from giving clients information about abortion. As a result, Mr. Bush may be forced to carry out his threat to veto a bill to overturn the rule.
Such a veto might not be sustainable; the bill passed the House with 353 votes, enough for an override, and the compromise was rejected by 64 senators, just three short of two-thirds. But whether upheld or not, a Presidential veto would identify Mr. Bush more specifically than anything else he has done as a personal opponent of abortion rights -- an unwelcome development on the eve of his re-election campaign.
These concerns are only latent. But as Alan Greenspan conceded, despite his current optimism, recovery "could be muted or even falter" -- another way of saying that in the economy as in politics, anything can happen.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Are Mixed on Money Market Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.
Bank money market accounts, which compete with the money funds, were unchanged, at 5.25 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index. 
 Tax-exempt money fund yields took a moderate downturn for the week. The category remains under pressure by a supply-and-demand problem, which has lowered yields substantially. Portfolio managers in search of higher yields are now seeking longer maturities and the average number of days left to maturity in portfolios rose to 59, from 51 last week, analysts said.
 
Tax-Exempt Assets Fall
 Total assets of tax-exempt funds fell $1.4 million for the week ended yesterday, to $87.2 billion.
The seven-day average tax-exempt compounded yield was down 10 basis points, to 3.52 percent, with the simple yield down a similar amount, to 3.46 percent. During the same reporting period, the compounded and simple 30-day yields each fell by 5 basis points, to 3.75 percent and 3.68 percent, respectively.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent for the current seven-day compounded yield is 4.88 percent, while the equivalent for investors in the 31 percent tax bracket is 5.1 percent.
Among the funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's with assets of better than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund, which buys a fair amount of securities that for some investors may be subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax, continues to be the best performer for a string of 12 consecutive weeks. The fund is distributed by Strong/Cornelison Capital Managment Inc. Last week's return was 4.71 percent, down from 4.8 percent the previous week.
Assets of taxable funds fell by $1.3 billion, to a total of $451.3 billion.
Total assets of consumer funds remained unchanged, at $340.8 billion. Donoghue's analysts said they believed that last week's outflow from the funds was a seasonal factor and not related to interest rates, which are not expected to change significantly for a while.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield rose by a basis point, to 5.62 percent, and the seven-day simple yield was up a similar amount, to 5.47 percent. The 30-day compounded yield was unchanged at 5.63 percent: the 30-day simple yield was also unchanged, at 5.48 percent.
The taxable fund with the best return for the eighth straight week was Olde Premium Money Market Series, with a yield of 6.38 percent, unchanged from a week ago. The fund's distributor is the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit.

HEADLINE: California Stalemate Ends in a Budget

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 17

 BODY:
California's long stalemate over the largest budget gap ever faced by a state has ended with an unwieldy package of new taxes and cutbacks in a dramatic reversal of fortunes for a state that just three years ago was debating what to do with its surplus.
As a result, children must now pay taxes on candy, fees for the California State University system will rise by 20 percent, income taxes will go up for the very wealthy and for renters and the state will lay off large numbers of employees and cut back on services. 
 With only 16 minutes before a midnight deadline, the Legislature on Tuesday night reluctantly passed the last of $7.7 billion in tax increases needed to cover a $14.3 billion gap. Moments later, Gov. Pete Wilson signed the overall budget of $55.7 billion for the fiscal year that began July 1.
Thus, California avoids the kind of chaotic shutdown of services that occurred in Maine and Connecticut this month, but at a price that substantially raises the cost of living in what is already one of most expensive states at a time of recession.
 
Wilson Is Upbeat
 The potential political cost in the state that led the tax revolution 13 years ago can only be speculated on for now. Governor Wilson, a moderate Republican, now has the unwanted distinction of presiding over the largest tax increase in California history.
This morning, he put the best face on what he called "a very, very difficult budget" as Californians were grousing over confusing new levies that meant sales taxes on jellyrolls but not muffins, cheese puffs but not Saltine crackers, the latter in an almost metaphysical exercise in trying to tax "snacks" but not "foods."
"The bottom line," he told a news conference, "is that the Legislature and I, working together, have passed more reforms in one budget than all the cumulative reforms within recent memory."
The Legislature also agreed to Mr. Wilson's plan to reorganize California's environmental-enforcement programs. He signed papers today creating the California Environmental Protection Agency, a cabinet-level office brings under one unit the responsibility for air quality, toxic-substances control, pesticide regulation and environmental health-hazard assessment. These had previously been scattered throughout other agencies.
 
Reilly Watches Swearing In
 In the presence of William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, Mr. Wilson swore in the new California Secretary for Environmental Protection, James M. Strock, formerly with the E.P.A. in Washington.
The final budget package embodied only a few of the "structural" changes the Governor had demanded to control costs. To gain the cooperation of the Democratic-controlled Legislature, he retreated substantially on many priorities, like legislation pushed by business interests to reduce the number of stress-related claims under workers' compensation.
In the end, the budget was balanced by a combination of $7.7 billion in higher taxes, $5.1 billion in service cuts and various bookkeeping devices.
The new taxes include a 1.25 percentage point increase in the sales tax, which was also broadened to include snacks, newspapers and magazines; increases in vehicle registration fees; elimination of a renter's credit on income taxes for single persons earning more than $20,000 and couples earning more than $40,000 a year; and raising the state income tax rate from 9.3 percent to 10 percent for those earning more than $100,000 (or $200,000 for a couple filing jointly) and to 11 percent above $200,000 ($400,000 jointly.)
Fees for enrollment of state residents in the California State University system will increase by 20 percent in the fall, from $780 a year to $936. The Unversity of California system has increased its fees from 40 percent, from $1,624 to $2,724 a year.
 
Pain to Spread Around
 The cuts included a 4.4 percent reduction in welfare grants, along with elmination of cost-of-living increases for five years; reduction in contributions to state workers' retirement funds, and reductions for the state university systems that have meant a 40 percent increase in fees at many schools.
In all this, the Governor received scant support from his own party. In the final tax votes Tuesday night, only 9 of the 31 Republicans in the Assembly and 5 of the 13 Republicans in the Senate backed Mr. Wilson. Unlike almost all other states, budget matters require a two-thirds vote in both houses.
There was little enthusiasm from either party in the Legislature as the final pieces of the puzzle were jammed in. Many said the taxes were structured so that they would cause major new fiscal problems in three to five years.
"We never anticipated that we'd end up with a bill this bad from our own Republican Governor," said Kenneth L. Maddy of Fresno, the popular and influential Republican leader in the Senate. "This bill is in the tank in about the third year. We're in trouble."
 
'A Horrible Year'
 But Mr. Maddy said he would vote for it anyway. "What it comes down to is, we have only two hours left," he said. "This has been a horrible year. There's nothing we've done we've liked. I urge you to vote 'aye' so we can get out of here."
And over in the Assembly, it was also the Republicans who had the harshest words for the Republican Governor. Governor Wilson obtained a small concession from Democrats on workers' compensation, a provision that prevents stress claims during the first six months of employment, as part of his agreeing to increase income tax rates for those earning more than $100,000. Mr. Wilson had earlier vowed to veto any income tax increase.
Assemblyman Tom McClintock of Thousand Oaks, a staunch Republican foe of taxes, called the workers' compensation measure "a small fig to cover a very big tax increase."
"God help us if he ever sits across the table from the Russians in negotiations," Mr. McClintock said of the Governor.
 
'Windfall' for Business
 The Democrats were particularly incensed over the Governor's measure to aid businesses by extending a state law, due to expire Jan. 1, 1992, that allows a business to carry over losses in a bad year to future years to offset future profits when it comes to paying corporate income taxes.
The Governor's proposal, passed by the Legislature Tuesday night, prevents any use of this provision during the 1991-92 fiscal year. Therefore, it results in an estimated gain of $560 million this year, but $5.3 billion in tax losses from 1993 to 2000.
"Business is given an absolute windfall," complained Senator Daniel E. Boatwright, a Democrat from Concord, who said the bulk of the increases would be borne by lower and middle income people. "This recession does not automatically end today. You are going to face a budget crisis next year."
The added sales tax, according to the Senate Office of Research, will cost a family with an annual income of $49,900 an extra $218 a year, an increase of about 20 percent over the current $1,047. Also, the fee for registering a new car that cost $10,000 will rise to $200 from $170.
 
An Issue Is 'Elevated'
 By reviving the perennial issue of workers' compensation in the last two weeks, Governor Wilson risked upsetting the entire budget compromise. Business interests had demanded relief from what they consider excessive and fraudulent compensation claims for stress as a price for their agreeing to an income tax increase for the wealthy.
Mr. Wilson at first wanted to forbid such benefits unless the worker could prove that at least 50 percent of his psychological disability resulted from work, compared with the current standard of 10 percent.
The Democrats countered with a demand to eliminate a rule that they said unfairly guaranteed large profits for insurance companies by letting them add 33 percent of their overhead expenses to the premiums paid by employes. Ultimately, Mr. Wilson agreed to retain the 10 percent standard, but his press secretary, Bill Livingstone, said the debate at least "elevated the issue to the front pages," and that it would return later.
The entire budget package seemed near collapse Tuesday night in the Senate, where the first roll-call on the final package, for $2.3 billion in additional taxes, fell 10 votes short of the 27 needed. There followed nearly an hour of tense arm-twisting on the floor until one by one the 'aye' votes built up.
Finally, a call was placed to Senator William A. Craven, ill at home in Oceanside, near San Diego. He expressed his willingness to vote 'aye,' and one of his fellow Republicans who had voted no changed to 'aye' as a "courtesy" to Mr. Craven.
With that begrudging assent from his own party, the tax bill was sent downstairs to Governor Wilson, who signed it only eight minutes before midnight.

HEADLINE: High Rating For Weicker But Tax Goal Isn't Reached

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 17

 BODY:
The televised speech by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. on Tuesday night about the state budget crisis drew almost as many viewers as would typically watch "Entertainment Tonight," "Jeopardy" and "Hard Copy" combined, local television programmers said. It was a clear success in the ratings.
But the Governor's call for state residents to rise up and yell for the income tax, and thus avoid the no-income-tax budget being considered by the legislature, appeared to strike an ambivalent chord, at best. 
At WTNH (Channel 8) in New Haven, which pre-empted its top-rated "Jeopardy" game show for the 7:30 P.M. speech, the news department's switchboard began lighting up about 7:45.
 "The predominant feeling was anti-income tax," said the station's director of news operations, Larry Manne. "But people from all sides of the issue were calling just to vent."
 Around the state, Mr. Weicker's 15-minute address seemed to have stirred up emotions all over again on the issue of the income tax and the budget stalemate, which has now pushed the state 17 days into the new fiscal year without a permanent budget in place.
 Mr. Weicker, who proposed an income tax plan in February, spent much of the speech berating the legislature, which he characterized as "the gang that couldn't count straight." He said that unless residents rose up and made their voices heard in favor of the Governor's plan, the legislature's "sleight of hand" budget could take effect.
 The legislative budget would avoid the income tax and close the gap between the state's revenue and spending through a $1 billion package of increases in a variety of taxes. The 8 percent sales tax would be extended to previously exempt items and services like inexpensive clothing, car repairs and haircuts. The package also includes new taxes on residential mortgages and commercial leases.
 Mr. Weicker vetoed that plan on July 1, saying the tax increases would devastate the state's economy. But lawmakers in the weeks since have been unable to muster majorities for any budget based on an income tax in a form the Governor would approve. They have thus been meeting to move forward on a vote to override Mr. Weicker's veto and impose their budget over his objections. Late tonight, a preliminary count among House Democrats showed insufficient support for an override vote.
 A vote to override a veto would require a two-thirds majority in both the House and the Senate, and lawmakers said the margins would be close.
 "This is the same old Weicker," said Joseph Leavitt, a 32-year-old construction worker taking his lunch break on the town green in Fairfield. "He never bends. He digs in, the legislators dig in and the rest of us get buried in acrimony. Weicker has to pass a conventional budget and get on with it."
 "Weicker was trying to shake the tree in his speech," said Karen Daden, owner of Athena Photo, a film processing lab in Bridgeport. She supports the income tax, as long as it is coupled with business tax cuts proposed by Mr. Weicker. And she abhors the legislature's plan about as much as the Governor does. "Taxing everything won't get us out of this mess," she said.
 At the Capitol, few lawmakers seemed to be experiencing any new blizzard of pro-income tax calls, though some did report an increase in them. But several said Mr. Weicker's speech had put them on the defensive on the vote to override.
 
Sunet Provision
 Most agreed that the speech's central "compromise," to automatically end the income tax after two and a half years, was nothing new because the Governor had said months ago on several radio call-in programs that he would accept a sunset provision. "By throwing it onto the table, he looks like he's moderating," Senator George Jepsen, a Stamford Democrat, said. "It's a ball-in-your-court kind of thing."
 Mr. Weicker's office received 489 calls on the speech in just over eight hours today, with 331 calls in support and 158 calls in opposition.
 The Governor also said at a news conference today that he would not let up, even if "left in the dust" by a vote to override his veto, regardless of the public response. Lawmakers, he said, would be called back into session at the first sign that their plan was not raising enough revenue.
 "I am going to fight every step of the way," he said.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Rise

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment insurance rose slightly in the latest week, the Government said today, but economists said the overall employment picture continued to brighten.
The Labor Department reported that first-time applications for state unemployment benefits rose to 395,000 for the week that ended July 6, from 388,000 the previous week, when the number of claims was at a nine-month low. 
 The increase was the first since the week that ended June 8, when new claims rose by 47,000. But economists linked the latest increase to special factors tied to the start of the third quarter and said the figures did not change their outlook for a gradual improvement in the labor market and economy.
While the jobless claims figures jump from week to week, the four-week moving average, which tends to smooth out special factors, has continued to fall. In the latest report, the average fell to 409,250, from 422,500 in the prior four-week period.
"This is the ninth consecutive week the moving average has declined," said Douglas Schindewolf, economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. He also noted the average had fallen in 14 of the last 15 weeks.
The unemployment rate was at 7 percent in June, compared with 5.3 percent a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Hidden Costs Of Mexico Plants

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
TO supporters of the proposed free-trade agreement between the United States and Mexico, one of the primary benefits to American companies would be greater access to Mexico's low-wage work force. By moving some or all of their manufacturing and assembly operations to Mexico, the argument goes, companies could reduce their costs and become more competitive on a global basis, ultimately helping the economy in the United States.
To opponents of the proposal, any benefits would come at the cost of American jobs. They envision companies closing up in this country and rushing south of the border in search of inexpensive labor.
To George Baker, both sides are missing a key point. Mr. Baker, an economist who is a visiting scholar for the Program on Mexico at the University of California at Los Angeles, believes manufacturing in Mexico is not nearly so inexpensive or cost-efficient as the relatively low wage rate might make it seem.
Mr. Baker argues that looking only at direct labor costs -- the wages paid to workers by employers -- does not take into account many hidden costs of doing business in Mexico. By his accounting, actual labor rates in Mexico could exceed $15 an hour when ancillary costs are factored in, rather than the $1.50 an hour or less that opponents and supporters of the proposed accord presume.
"Companies are reacting prematurely in thinking they're going to cut labor costs by three-quarters," Mr. Baker said.
Officials of both countries began formal negotiations last month on the proposed agreement, which would eliminate almost all tariffs and other trade and investment barriers between the two nations. The talks also include Canada, which already has a free-trade agreement with the United States and would become part of a three-way agreement if a deal between Mexico and the United States is concluded. The proposed agreement is strongly supported by the Bush Administration and by President Carlos Salinas de ortari of Mexico.
Mexico is the United States' third-largest trading partner, after Canada and Japan. Many American companies, ranging from auto makers to electronics producers, are considering plants in Mexico if the agreement is completed.
They are interested both in getting better access to the Mexican market and in lowering their costs on products to be exported back to the United States or elsewhere. They would join nearly 1,800 American-owned maquiladora plants already operating in Mexico, employing half a million workers. Maquiladora plants are those owned by foreign companies. They enjoy lower trade barriers.
Gabriel Szekely, an economist at the Center for United States-Mexico Studies at the University of California at San Diego, said the problem of hidden costs in Mexico had long been of concern to American and other foreign companies considering opening plants there.
"The question is whether those hidden costs keep companies from moving to Mexico," he said. "The evidence is that they do not," Mr. Szekely said, noting the rapid growth in the number of maquiladora and other foreign operations in Mexico.
Still, Mr. Baker said, American companies need to understand that doing business in Mexico may be far more expensive than they expect.
Mr. Baker, who worked for two years for the NCR Corporation in Mexico during the mid-1980's and still consults for American companies with operations there, said moving an operation to Mexico involved considerable financial risk and costs that would be borne directly by the company and that should be considered part of the labor-cost equation, Mr. Baker said. They range from the costs of high employee turnover to inefficient mail service and a substandard telephone system, both of which decrease productivity, he said.
"Is it still cheaper to move to Mexico when you factor out social costs and include a risk factor?" Mr. Baker asked. "I'm trying to get U.S. manufacturing management to ask themselves that question."
Mr. Baker cites the example of a maquiladora plant in Chihuahua City, south of Texas. The plant, Mr. Baker said, claimed an employee turnover rate of 3 percent a month, relatively low at maquiladora plants. But even at that rate, nearly 800 of the company's 2,200 workers leave each year. It costs $333 to recruit and train a new worker, meaning the annual cost of employee turnover is $264,000.
Mr. Baker said there were other hidden costs at the maquiladora plant. The company pays the city for bus service for the workers and provides a subsidized cafeteria and on-site medical and dental care.
But those costs, Mr. Baker said, are only part of the story. "When you go into an area like this you have to apply a risk factor to reflect the fragility and inadequacy of the infrastructure," he said. "There are always unexpected delays and costs. Your budgets always have a shadow over them. You believe it will cost $100, but it could cost $300."

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Grows Slightly As Exports Remain Strong

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit widened slightly in May for the second straight month, the Government said today. But the $4.6 billion imbalance reflected strong exports and was the third-best showing in eight years.
The gap with Japan, long the largest segment of the deficit, narrowed to $2.4 billion for the month. The figure was the slimmest difference with Japan since a $1.8 billion gap in February 1984. In May, imports of Japanese cars dropped by $302 million from the previous month. 
 The Commerce Department report showed that the May imbalance was up 1.5 percent from a revised April gap of $4.5 billion. The April figure was originally reported at $4.6 million. The deficit had fallen to $4.1 billion in March, the lowest since it reached $3.96 billion in June 1983.
Exports in May were off nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $35.3 billion, but still posted their second-best showing on record after April's $35.6 billion pace. Imports totaled $39.9 billion, down six-tenths of 1 percent from the previous month and well below the $44.5 billion record set last October.
The Bush Administration and many private analysts look to exports to help pull the economy out of recession. Exports account for more than 16 percent of the United States economy and represented about 40 percent of its growth in 1990.
 
Strong Trade With Europe
 Some fear, however, that a weakening global economy will reduce foreigners' ability to purchase American goods. They also fear a stronger dollar, which makes American goods more expensive overseas.
But Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, cited the $1.3 billion surplus with Western Europe in May.
"Exports to Europe continue to lead the charge despite the recession in the United Kingdom and a slowing of European growth," he said.
Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington economic forecasting firm, agreed. "It's most impressive," he said. "Exports pretty much kept up their pace," despite the dollar and the world economy.
While the global economy may threaten exports, the weak United States economy apparently cut into American purchases of foreign-made goods. The sluggish economy "continues to hold imports down," Mr. Jasinowski said.
 
Under $100 Million for '91
 For the first five months of 1991, the overall deficit has been running at an annual rate of $62.5 billion, better than the $90 billion forecast by the Bush Administration earlier this year.
If the forecast proves true, it would be the first annual deficit under $100 billion since 1983. The trade deficit peaked at $152.1 billion in 1987 and totaled $101.7 billion last year.
Contributing to the slip in exports was an $800 million drop in capital goods exports, including $400 million in aircraft. Exports of consumer goods also fell. Exports of industrial supplies, motor vehicles and grain increased.
America's foreign oil bill rose 15.3 percent in May to $4.6 billion. The volume of oil imports was up 13.9 percent, while the price rose 15 cents, to $16.55 a barrel.
Also contributing to the decrease in imports were drops in purchases of capital and consumer goods and of motor vehicles, which fell $280 million over all.
 
Deficits With Taiwan, China
 In addition to its deficit with Japan, the United States ran an $800 million gap with Taiwan and a $700 million imbalance with China.
Some members of Congress are trying to force President Bush to remove China's most-favored-nation trade status until the country improves its human rights, trade and labor policies. Removing most-favored-nation status, would lift the prices of many Chinese goods, reducing United States imports. The trade deficit with China totals $3.6 billion so far this year.
In addition to Western Europe, the United States posted surpluses of $200 million with both Mexico and Egypt and $100 million with the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
From Yale Days to Bank Lobbyist, a Friend and Adviser to the Bushes

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
At Yale, when George Bush was "Poppy" and Thomas William Ludlow Ashley was "Lud," they began their lifelong friendship.
When Mr. Bush began his first oil exploration company, Mr. Ashley was an investor. When the Bush children arrived, Mr. Ashley bounced them on his knees. And after George Bush became President and his son son Neil ran afoul of Federal regulatory agencies, Mr. Ashley was there with advice. 
 Mr. Ashley, 68 years old, an affable lobbyist and former Democratic Congressman from Toledo, Ohio, has been advising Mr. Bush since early 1989. That was shortly after the Office of Thrift Supervision began investigating what it said was Mr. Bush's "unsafe or unsound practices" as a director of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. Silverado collapsed in December 1988, at a cost to the taxpayers estimated at $1 billion.
 
Coaching for Testimony
 Mr. Ashley, who is also a lawyer, coached the President's son before he testified before Federal investigators and the House Banking Committee, worked with Mr. Bush's lawyer to develop political and legal strategies, and even set up a legal defense fund to help him pay his expenses.
Mr. Ashley declines to discuss how much has been raised, by whom and from whom, other than that the contributions came from the Bush "family and close friends." Although he says that he manages the fund, he says the actual solicitations were made by others, whom he declines to name. The White House says that President and Mrs. Bush were not involved in setting up the fund and had made no contributions.
Mr. Ashley's expertise in guiding Neil Bush through his troubled times came through experience. He was a longtime member of the the House Banking Committee and is now president of the Association of Bank Holding Companies, which represents the nation's largest banks, including Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover and Morgan Guaranty.
 
Helped Bring a Light Penalty
 By all accounts, Mr. Ashley's tactics helped Neil Bush receive the lightest penalty that could have been imposed by the Office of Thrift Supervision. The office merely ordered him to avoid future conflicts of interest in the banking industry. Mr. Ashley is also credited with helping settle a $200 million negligence suit against Mr. Bush and other Silverado directors in a manner that is not expected to bring Mr. Bush any significant out-of-pocket costs.
Did Mr. Ashley keep the President appraised of the progress of his son's cases? "He's entitled as a father to be kept informed," Mr. Ashley said, adding, "We're in regular touch."
Meanwhile, Mr. Ashley has been lobbying for the Bush Administration's bill, which he helped write, that would overhaul the banking system. Mr. Ashley is not unaware that some lobbyists resent his close relationship with the President. They say it gives him an edge not enjoyed by opponents of the Administration's bill, not to mention lobbyists for Medicaid recipients.
"Am I supposed to quarantine myself?" asked Mr. Ashley in a flat Midwestern voice laced with incredulity. "Of course some people have greater access than others. But I've known George Bush ever since college, and Neil Bush ever since he was a child."
 
Blurred Work-Social Lines
 Most lobbyists in Washington -- where blurred lines between social and professional life are an essential part of the fabric of work -- would mortgage their souls for Mr. Ashley's access. He not only maintains regular telephone contact with his college friend, Mr. Ashley said in an interview in his wood-paneled office with views of the Treasury, Washington Monument and Jefferson Memorial, but also is an occasional guest at Bush family dinners at the White House; and he makes periodic visits to Camp David and the Bush family compound at Kennebunkport, Me.
The President has been known to invite his longtime friend, on short notice, to shmooze on topics ranging from Neil Bush to banking to politics and old times.
"People in Washington have a commonality of purpose," Mr. Ashley said. "It's just natural that your friends are people you've come in contact with professionally. Everybody has left home and hearth to come to Washington to pursue a purpose.
"Lobbying is part of bringing about change."
 
Small Banks Don't Like It
 Ed Yingling, head of government relations of the American Bankers Association, said, "Most people in the industry think it's good to have people who have access to those high places."
But the relationship between the lobbyist and the President troubles Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, which represents small banks.
"What Lud brings to the White House, which the President has bought, is a very narrow approach benefiting a narrow constituency," Mr. Guenther said. "He has been a brilliant, successful lobbyist, to the detriment of the existing financial and economic structure of the United States.
"Since Lud has this very special relationship with the President," Mr. Gunther said, "we have to build broad Main Street coalitions to try to undo what the Bush-Ashley relationship has done."
"This century started with Teddy Roosevelt and his trust busters, and ends with President Bush working with his good friend Lud Ashley putting these same trusts back together."
Mr. Ashley insists that he has the President's ear on banking matters not simply because they are old friends but because they think alike on business and financial issues, and because Mr. Ashley represents a constituency that warrants respect no matter who is in the White House.
As to Mr. Guenther's assertions, he responds with a skilled smoothness. "One has to appreciate that Ken represents the smaller, independent community bankers," Mr. Ashley says. "He uses lovely purple language, but we aren't putting trusts back together, we're lifting 50-year-old restrictions that have strangled the industry.
"The fact is that the Texas banks have disappeared from the scene because they didn't have any outreach," he said. "Interstate banking has become a reality."
As for banking legislation, he said: "I'm in touch with the President on banking matters, but I'm also in touch with the Secretary of the Treasury. The Treasury people talk to me, not because I'm a pal of the President, but because I'm president of an association whose members represent 70 percent of the bank assets in this country."
And as for his help to Neil Bush, Mr. Ashley disputes those who lay it to the old school tie connection.
At a session with Federal regulators in December 1989, documents show, Neil Bush said that Mr. Ashley initially got in touch with him at "dad's request."
But Mr. Ashley insists that Mr. Bush's memory was faulty. "I called Neil," Mr. Ashley said. "Neil needed help. I said that I was available for advice and counsel, and I thought he was going to need some."
 
Liberal Democrat in House
 As an old hand in the capital, Mr. Ashley knew the territory. As a liberal Democrat who spent 13 terms in the House before his constitutents decided in the 1980 election that he had become more of a Washingtonian than an Ohian, Mr. Ashley had been chairman of a special committee that coordinated House action on President Jimmy Carter's energy legislation, played a leading role in persuading the House to provide funds to fiscally stricken New York City and championed subsidized housing.
It was part of the background that made him uniquely qualified to steer Mr. Bush through the treacherous shoals of bank regulatory agencies.
He recalled the summer of 1990, when Neil Bush had invited journalists to Denver to give his side of the story. "I told him, 'you can keep on talking to the press, or you can keep your (expletive deleted) mouth shut," Mr. Ashley said, making it clear that he had strongly urged the latter course, which prevailed.
 
'The Wisdom of His Age'
 When Mr. Bush testified before Mr. Ashley's former colleagues on the House Banking Committee, which was making political hay by investigating the son of the President, Mr. Ashley, who had coached him on his testimony, was in the audience.
Throughout, Mr. Ashley remained in contact with Jim Nesland, Mr. Bush's principal lawyer. "He gave me his input with respect to the overall political issues that were created primarily during the period of time that the House Banking committee was looking into this," Mr. Nesland said. "He has the wisdom of his age, and of somebody inside the Beltway, which is especially valuable to somebody far away and as young and inexperienced in politics as Neil and me."
Mr. Ashley said that he and the President were aware that their friendship could be misinterpreted.
"I wouldn't dishonor this friendship by mistreating it," Mr. Ashley said. "We are careful."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Issues Up a Bit in a Quiet Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in dull, thin trading yesterday.
The strongest activity took place late in the session, after the Federal Reserve Board reported that a key monetary aggregate posted a larger than expected decline of $6.9 billion during the week ended July 8. 
 Aside from the money numbers, credit market participants said the day's developments provided little reason to establish or liquidate positions.
"This was an absolutely typical summer day," one government bond trader said.
An increase in initial unemployment claims for the week ended July 6, the first weekly rise in nearly a month, provided a brief lift early, but prices later retreated.
Similarly, traders were unmoved by a widening in the nation's trade deficit or the decline in the dollar against most currencies, and a further slide in commodity prices. At other times, those factors might have spurred trading activity.
"The weakness in commodity prices should offer some support for bonds," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. "But it hasn't really happened, even though in recent weeks the weakness has spread from agricultural to industrial commodities."
 
Decline in Money Supply
 In its weekly money supply report, the Fed reported that two of the three monetary aggregates it tracks declined during the week ended July 8. M-3, the broadest aggregate, rose by $300 million.
Analysts said the sharp $6.9 billion decline in M-2, the aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, was a source of concern. The drop was the third in succession, and placed M-2's growth since the fourth quarter at 3.1 percent, in the lower portion of the Fed's 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent target growth range for the year.
"One would think this would concern the Fed," said Wayne Smith, an economist at Reid Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn.
Given the declines in M-2 in the last three weeks, Mr. Smith said there was not likely to be any growth in M-2 in July. Sluggish money growth is another factor that could retard the pace of recovery, he added.
"Before last week, I was saying that if you had M-2 growth at 4 percent for the year, you conceivably could get about 1 percent real growth in gross national product for the year," he said. "As M-2 growth continues to slow, I am starting to question whether or not that will be the case."
M-2 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking acounts and non-bank traveler's checks plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds.
 
Fed Move Doubted
 Mr. Smith and other analysts said the money supply numbers made it increasingly unlikely that the Fed would move to tighten credit. That view was reflected in prices of short-term maturities.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at a price of 100 9/ 32, up 3/32, to yield 6.84 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to down slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.58 percent, unchanged from late Wednesday. Six-month bill rates fell by a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.71 percent. And one-year bill rates dipped by 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.89 percent.
Among longer-dated Treasury maturities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at 96 6/32, up 5/ 32, to yield 8.47 percent, down from a yield of 8.49 percent late Wednesday. And the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 18/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.27 percent.
A number of new long-term issues were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market, including $300 million worth of 30-year debentures for the UAL Corporation.
The 10 1/4 percent securities, which mature July 15, 2021, were priced at $99.134, to yield 10.343 percent, 1.85 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager on an offering of $250 million worth of 30-year debentures for the Canadian Pacific Railway.
The 9.45 percent debentures, which mature Aug. 1, 2021, were priced at $99.875, to yield 9.462 percent, 97 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing. The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and AA-minus by S.& P.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices of most issues were unchanged in light trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said prices of most actively quoted securities were unchanged to down about 1/4 point.
