HEADLINE: Weakened Kohl Frustrated by Summit Colleagues

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 18

 BODY:
For Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who only a year ago seemed to be emerging as Europe's most powerful leader, the summit meeting here this week was a rude lesson in how quickly the world balance can change.
At the 1990 summit talks in Houston, Mr. Kohl was welcomed as the leader of a mighty nation on the brink of unification and superpower status. This year, he found himself much weakened and unable to win support for his most cherished proposals, chief among them a plan for vast Western aid for the Soviet Union. 
 Mr. Kohl's loss of power and status reflects his own deepening problems at home, but also the renewed strength of the United States. The London summit meeting made clear that, largely as a result of its success in the Persian Gulf war, the United States has recaptured the dominant world role that some thought it had lost.
In the 19 months since the Berlin wall fell, Mr. Kohl has become President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's strongest political ally. In that period, according to figures released by the German delegation here, Germany has provided 40 percent of the foreign aid sent to the Soviet Union and the nations of Eastern Europe. Japan and the United States were said to have provided less than 7 percent each.
 
Kohl's Diminishing Position
 "The balance is just not right," Economics Minister Jurgen Mollemann said this week.
But there was no suggestion at the London summit talks that either Japanese or American officials share the German view. Chancellor Kohl realized several months ago that he was no longer in a position to press other leaders into approving a vast aid program for the Soviets. At the summit meeting, he confined himself to seeking more limited help.
But even those efforts proved less than successful. The world leaders who met here agreed to give the Soviets an undefined "special status" in the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, but refused to commit themselves to giving the Soviets full membership at some future point, as Mr. Kohl had urged. Nor would the other leaders accept Mr. Kohl's proposal that the Soviets be offered new credits from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
The other area in which Mr. Kohl had hoped for greater support was protection of the global environment. He failed to win clear financial support for a German-backed pilot program intended to protect rain forests in Brazil. His plea for new actions to protect the earth's ozone layer also fell on deaf ears.
 
Slumping German Economy
 Commentaries in the German press today portrayed the London summit conference as a difficult moment for Mr. Kohl. The economic newspaper Handelsblatt called the summit meeting "anything but a success" for him, and asserted that his appeals on behalf of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe had been greeted with "icy silence."
Next year's economic summit meeting will be held in Germany, and Mr. Kohl hopes to be in a position to press his views more forcefully there. But the aura of glory and success that surrounded him during the heady days of German unification appears to have faded.
Germany's economy, though still the strongest in Europe, is slumping under the burden of vast expenditures needed to rebuild the eastern part of the country. Mr. Kohl's personal popularity has been falling steadily, and his Christian Democratic Union has lost a series of local elections.
 
Fear of Total Soviet Collapse
 Over the last year, Mr. Kohl's Government has expended great amounts of money and effort trying to raise the former East Germany up from ruin. Aides say the Chancellor thinks that experience has given him a special understanding of how difficult it is to rebuild nations that lived for decades under Communism. That belief, as well as his unusually close political friendship with Mr. Gorbachev, has made Mr. Kohl the strongest and most vocal advocate of Western help for the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries.
German leaders have been candid about their reasons for supporting Soviet appeals for Western help.
First and foremost, Germans recognize that without Mr. Gorbachev's assent, their nation could not have been unified last year. Second, they are acutely aware that 300,000 Soviet troops remain on German soil, and are eager for them to be withdrawn by 1994 as Mr. Gorbachev has promised. Third, they feel a lingering sense of guilt over Germany's invasion of the Soviet Union 50 years ago.
Finally, the Germans fear what would happen to their own country if the Soviet Union collapsed. At the very least, hundreds of thousands of Soviet refugees would pour across their borders. It is cheaper, they reason, to aid Soviet citizens in the Soviet Union than to wait until they flood into Germany.
At the London summit meeting, it appeared that the French and Italian leaders shared some of Mr. Kohl's sense of urgency. But they were easily outweighed by other leaders, especially President Bush, who say the Soviets have not made enough political and economic reforms to justify a major infusion of aid.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark But Gains in Yen Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower against the German mark yesterday, still recoiling from last week's concerted central bank intervention.
The dollar ended at 1.7745 German marks, down from Wednesday's close of 1.7910 marks. It closed at 137.65 Japanese yen, up from Wednesday's finish of 136.95 yen. 
 Last Friday, concerted dollar-selling by 15 central banks discouraged players from buying dollars. Since traders could not make money buying the United States currency, they decided to try selling it, said Bob Hatcher of Barclays Bank.
The dollar's fall through 1.7850 marks prompted stop-loss selling during European trading that accelerated the descent, dealers said. The dollar reached a low of 1.7650 marks in early United States trading before it recovered.
"The key question is whether that support at 1.7650 came from profit taking by speculators or real demand for dollars," Mr. Hatcher said.
The main issue now is whether a lower dollar will attract corporate players and investors to buy, he added.
Dealers said the currency market ignored the May trade data released yesterday. The Government reported that the deficit widened slightly to $4.6 billion in May from a revised $4.5 billion in April. Economists on average had forecast a $4.9 billion gap for May.
The Canadian dollar went into a tailspin after charges of fraud and obstruction of justice were brought by a private citizen against 16 high-level Canadian officials. The individual charged that Conservative politicians had asked for kickbacks on Government contracts.
The United States dollar ended at 1.1580 Canadian dollars, compared with 1.1480 on Wednesday. The Bank of Canada intervened to stem the decline.
The British pound closed at $1.6655, up from $1.6495 on Wednesday. The dollar ended at 1.5400 Swiss francs, compared with 1.5555 Wednesday. The dollar also closed at 6.0230 French francs, down from 6.0770 francs Wednesday.
Gold for August delivery rose 40 cents, to $370.90 an ounce, on New York's Commodity Exchange.

HEADLINE: In an Age of Bland Politics, Eccentricity Lives On in Louisiana

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La.

 BODY:
For years, people have been predicting that Louisiana's political culture would one day become as bland and predictable as the sound-bite politics practiced everywhere else. But for better or worse, this is shaping up as yet another vintage year for Louisiana's reputation as a place where politics and theater seamlessly blend and where the past is never quite gone.
There has been talk of exhuming the remains of Huey P. Long's assassin. The Legislature is studying the idea of allowing New Orleans to secede from Louisiana. For months the political system, and now the legal system, have been convulsed by debate over the nation's most restrictive abortion law. 
 Still to come is a governor's race among a former Governor, Edwin W. Edwards; the current Governor, Buddy Roemer; a former Klansman, David Duke, and a cast of thousands. It is a campaign that is shaping up as a cross between "All the King's Men" and "The Gong Show."
Some say too much is made of Louisiana's reputation for outlandish politics.
 
A Place Apart
 "I don't think our politics are as colorful or as nasty and despicable as some outsiders would have you think," said Mr. Edwards, who is considered Louisiana's most influential politician since Mr. Long and is often cited as Exhibit A in the case for Louisiana as a place apart. "We never had three transvestites go on television and say they had sex with the Democratic candidate the way they did in Mississippi a few years back."
But the best description of Louisiana politics may still have come from the writer A. J. Liebling, who described Louisiana in the 1950's as "the westernmost of the Arab states" and said the state's politics were "of an intensity and complexity that are matched, in my experience, only in the Republic of Lebanon."
The result can be wildly contradictory. Thus, a state with a well-deserved reputation for a live-and-let-live ethos finds itself in the national spotlight over a restrictive abortion law. But if simple categorizations are hard to find, there is no shortage of explanations for the peculiarities of what Liebling, using the South Louisiana pronunciation, liked to call "the Gret Stet of Loosiana" or "the Gret Stet" for short.
Explanation No. 1 begins with the state's origins in French and Spanish rather than Anglo-Saxon explorations and the distinctive political and legal traditions that emerged from it.
"If you go back to 1811 and and 1812 and read the arguments about Louisiana becoming a state, there was a great argument in the House that they couldn't possibly allow that to occur because those foreigners would never make good Americans," said former Representative Lindy Boggs of New Orleans.
Explanation No. 2 goes back to the state's historic reliance on oil companies to pay the tax bills, leading to a political system in which no one got too upset about routine corruption.
"Up until 15 years ago, Louisiana had a government that was funded by the oil companies, not the people of the state," said Wayne Parent, a political science professor at Louisiana State University. "So the government and the politicians could be less accountable. It wasn't Louisiana's money. It was Texaco's money. So what if they were playing around with it?"
Explanation No. 3 starts with the state's Balkanized population, roughly one-third black, one-third Cajun and one-third Bible Belt Baptist. There is distrust between Protestant northern Louisiana and Catholic southern Louisiana. There is distrust beween blacks and whites. And there is distrust between New Orleans and everyone else.
"We don't have a dominant ethnic majority in this state," said John Maginnis, editor of The Louisiana Political Review. "It makes a big difference. You can't really shoot for the middle. You have to figure out how to play the angles, the way Edwin Edwards does in putting the blacks and the Cajuns together."
Explanation No. 4 is the personality cult that has dominated Louisiana politics ever since Huey Long gained sole control of state government from his election as governor in 1928 until his assassination in 1935 in the State Capitol he built.
Worthy heirs to his notoriety, if not always his populist politics, have been Gov. Jimmie H. Davis, best known for warbling country ballads like his own "You Are My Sunshine"; Long's brother Earl, who spent part of his tenure as governor in a Texas mental institution, and Mr. Edwards, Louisiana's only three-term Governor and the only Cajun governor since Reconstruction, who was tried twice but never convicted of Federal fraud charges.
 
An 'Out of Step' System
 Also figured in is a decade of economic decline that has added an overlay of frustration and one of the lowest levels of educational achievement in the nation.
"All those things come together to create a political system that's just kind of out of step with everyone else," said Joe Walker, a political poll taker in New Orleans.
If Mr. Roemer, and his no-fun reformer's sensibilities, constitute an argument that the old era is ending, the governor's race figures to be Louisiana politics in its unadulterated form -- "The race from hell," in Mr. Maginnis's words.
The four main contenders are likely to be Mr. Roemer; Mr. Edwards; David Duke, a current State Representative and former Ku Klux Klan leader, and Clyde C. Holloway, a conservative who is strong supporter of the anti-abortion law. After Mr. Roemer switched from the Democrats to the Republicans, amid much rejoicing in the White House, Louisiana Republicans turned around and instead nominated Mr. Holloway for Governor.
Under Louisiana's unusual open primary, Mr. Roemer can run anyway. Candidates compete regardless of party designation in the Oct. 19 primary. If no one gets 50 percent of the vote, the two top finishers meet in a runoff on Election Day.
Like character actors in a soap opera, the supporting cast includes Kathleen Blanco, the Public Service Commissioner, and one of the few high-ranking women in state government; Fred Dent, a former state banking commissioner who is partial to seersucker suits and red suspenders a la Earl Long in the movie "Blaze," and Sam Jones, the Mayor of the small south Louisiana town of Franklin, who bills himself as the only candidate willing to take on Mr. Duke and is fond of saying the only difference between him and Mr. Duke is that "I've never had plastic surgery, I don't hate anybody and I work for a living."
 
Politics as Entertainment
 There is much to like in the state's traditions. Mr. Duke notwithstanding, Louisiana has less of a history of racial politics than most Southern states. Moreover, the entertainment value and populist tradition have kept interest in politics at a higher level than in most places in the country.
Mr. Jones, a 38-year-old former sheriff's deputy, will be lucky to get 5 percent of the vote, but when he checks at what's called the Little City Hall behind Oray Rogers' Radio Shack store in Franklin or the 2 O'Clock Coffee Club at the Holiday Inn in Morgan City there is no shortage of advice on how to hit the big time.
"People want a man who says I'm going to give you this, I'm going to give you this, I'm going to give you that," Nina Guzetta told Mr. Jones as they walked from the Holiday Inn. "That's what Huey Long did and what Earl Long did. You need to get on television and tell people you're going to take the tolls off the damn bridges."
But much has changed from the days of the Longs. Oil no longer pays all the bills, so there is less tolerance for corruption or spare change for Long-style state spending. The economic and environmental problems are so serious, that the fun and games often have a hollow ring. Mr. Maginnis says the Legislature has gradually become more responsible over time and campaign finance reforms pushed through by Mr. Roemer threaten to change state politics by making money harder to raise, adding to the power of incumbents.
 
No Money, No Fun
 "My theory is that Buddy Roemer is the death of Louisiana politics," Mr. Maginnis said. "He's wringing the money out of it. He's taking the fun out of it. We didn't realize that was part of the bargain."
And some say that although Louisiana maintains a surface eccentricity, its politics now diverge from the nation's more in style than in content, with an ugly undercurrent of race and a total inability to come to grips with festering economic, social and educational problems.
Still, if politics gets depressing, people in Louisiana can always take solace in the church. Testimony has begun in New Orleans in the $90 million libel suit between the rival preachers Marvin Gorman and Jimmy Swaggart, with its expected allegations of adultery, exorcism and other diversions.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Huey Pierce Long; Richard Webster Leche; Earl Kemp Long; Sam Houston Jones; Jimmie Davis; Russel B. Long.
 
Chart: "Kingfish & Company"
 
Memorable politicians from Louisiana's past.
 
Huey Pierce Long/1893-1935
The Napoleon of Louisiana politics. As Governor from 1928-32, came close to absolute power over the state. His projects to pave roads, control flooding and eradicate illiteracy earned him a reputation as a man of the people. His administration was accused of bribery and misapppropriation of funds, and he was threatened more than once with impeachment. "The Kingfish" moved on to the United States Senate and was planning to run for President, when he was assasinated in Baton Rouge at the height of his power, apparently by the son-in-law of an enemy.
 
Richard Webster Leche/1898-1965
A Huey Long protege who took over his political machine and became Governor in 1936. Better remembered for his time in prison than in office. Resigned in 1939 in a scandal involving graft, corruption and misuse of public funds. Convicted of mail fraud, sentenced to 10 years, released in 1943. Operated Bayou Gardens, a tourist attraction, until returning to practice law after an official pardon from President Harry S. Truman.
 
Earl Kemp Long/1895-1960
Governor 1939-40, 1948-52 and 1956-60. Brother of Huey, and an heir to his populist legacy: he raised spending for welfare and education, and abolished the Civil Service system. In his final term he had a mental breakdown, chronicled in the Paul Newman movie "Blaze"; his wife had him committed to the state hospital for the insane, but he used his power as governor to replace the director with a doctor who signed his release. Died of a heart attack 10 days after his election to the House of Representatives.
 
Sam Houston Jones/1897-1978
Governor 1940-44; in his first 60 days in office, he dismantled the extraordinary powers built by Huey Long and his political heirs. Increased social welfare payments 80 percent, teachers' salaries 30 percent and state aid to public schools 50 percent, yet slashed the cost of state government, leaving a $15 million surplus in the treasury.
 
James Houston Davis/1902-
 The singing Governor (1944-48 and 1960-64). A schoolteacher who began singing on a Shreveport radio station in 1938, he collaborated on "You Are My Sunshine," among other songs. May be the only governor who is also a member of the Country Music Hall of Fame.
 
Russell. B Long/1918-
United States Senator, 1948-86. Son of Huey Long and heir to his father's name, reputation and valuable oil royalties. As longtime chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, an invincible supporter of the oil and gas industry; creator of the voluntary tax checkoff that finances Presidential campaigns and the earned income tax credit, which benefits the working poor.
 
(Sources: Biographical Dictionary of the Governors of the United States; Politics in America, 1986)

HEADLINE: Search Is Long and Grim for Canada's Jobless

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, July 18

 BODY:
The lines start forming on the sidewalk well before the Danforth Toronto East unemployment center opens.
Bill Goller, who arrived in Canada three months ago from Lima, Peru, with his wife and two children, is one of the early risers. He has taken the train, bus and subway from the industrial suburb of Scarborough. 
 Bruce Caldwell, a former night worker in a candy company who was laid off 10 months ago, is also in line.
They are two of the 527,000 unemployed people in Ontario. The number has risen by 90 percent over the last year as Canada has experienced what is already at least the second worst economic slump since the Great Depression of the 1930's.
For the nation as a whole, joblessness is at 10.5 percent of the work force, 3.4 percentage points above the rate in the United States.
 
Despair Is Real
 The numbers resound here in anger, despair, loss of self-confidence, the atrophy of skills.
To survive, Mr. Caldwell lives at home with his parents on welfare checks of $240 a month. "It affects me really hard," he said. "The people who don't have it are down a couple of notches. It keeps you in your place."
Mr. Goller and Mr. Caldwell are in their early 40's and looking for work as general laborers. Mr. Goller had been a telephone exchange supervisor in Lima, but knows that that kind of work is unlikely here.
What brings them to the Danforth center, as opposed to the 17 other offices in Toronto, are the 10 computerized black boxes known as job banks, installed in January as part of a federal pilot program for speeding job information to the jobless.
Mr. Goller, Mr. Caldwell and hundreds of other men and women will hunch over the machines like gamblers in front of slot machines, pushing buttons in response to personal questions from the computer. For those who press the right buttons, job data is printed out with instructions on whom to call and the phone numbers.
 
Jostling Around Job Boards
 At the other centers, job notices are on bulletin boards, around which workers jostle each other to take notes. Moreover, Mr. Caldwell said, the posted notices "tend to disappear."
On a recent morning, the number of job opportunities in the system was only 2,100, said Charles M. Salonia, acting manager of the Danforth center. The new jobs just added totaled 127.
Only about 20 percent of the total jobs available go through the federal job placement machinery, and those tend to pay lower wages. For higher paying jobs, many employers use private agencies, or just word of mouth.
But for Toronto, with nearly 3 million inhabitants, the numbers, however stretched, are pitifully small.
Canada's basic economic statistics have recently turned upward. Lower mortgage rates pushed up home sales in June for the fourth straight month. Exports are stronger. In London during the summit meeting of industrialized democracies, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said, "We've had a tough recession in Canada, but we seem to be out of it now."
But at no unemployment office in Toronto, Canada's largest city, is there any sign of economic recovery. The Ontario Federation of Labor has counted 250,000 jobs in the province that it says are gone forever.
To Mr. Salonia and his deputies, the key to re-employment is now retraining.
The Danforth center expects to process 27,000 unemployment claims this year. They entitle workers to a maximum of $408 a week, usually for up to 30 weeks, after which they go on welfare. The center has its own retraining specialists, who are seeking more bookkeepers and data-entry operators.
Mr. Salonia is a product of retraining. A former floor trader on the Toronto Stock Exchange, he found himself on the street after a market crisis.
Like those in line, he went to one of the Canada employment centers.
"They told me they were looking for people like me to train as employment counselors," he said. "I grabbed the opportunity."

HEADLINE: 2d-Quarter Earnings Down At Nynex and BellSouth

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Two of the nation's seven regional phone companies, Nynex and BellSouth, said today that their profits declined in the second quarter.
Nynex earnings fell 3.3 percent from the comparable quarter last year and BellSouth net income dropped 17.9 percent. 
 Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
Nynex
 The Nynex Corporation said it earned $290.8 million, or $1.44 a share, in the second quarter, down from $300.6 million, or $1.52 a share, a year earlier.
Revenue totaled $3.36 billion, off 2.4 percent from $3.44 billion.
Results from the period a year ago included charges for an early-retirement program and other one-time events that reduced profit. Without the charges, the profit a year ago would have been $332.3 million, or $1.68 a share, and the decline in profit in the most recent quarter would have been steeper.
Nynex, owner of the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone Company, blamed the economy and an increase in interest costs for its profit drop.
Nynex shares on the New York Stock Exchange rose $1.50 yesterday to close at $73.
 
BellSouth
 The BellSouth Corporation, the Atlanta-based telecommunicatins giant, blamed regulatory activity, the recession and increased competition for lower earnings in the second quarter.
The company reported net income of $365.3 million, or 76 cents a share, down from $445.2 million, or 92 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1990.
Revenue totaled $3.58 billion, down marginally from $3.62 billion.
John L. Clendenin, company chairman, said the same factors that influenced earnings so far this year appear to be in place for the rest of 1991.
"We remain on course for the long term, however, with a good cash flow, a healthy balance sheet and a leaner, more efficient operating structure," he said.
Mr. Clendenin said that the company plans to merge its telephone operating units -- Southern Bell and South Central Bell -- next year in an effort to streamline them. BellSouth has already combined its cellular units into one operation.
On the New York Stock Exchange, the company's stock fell 12.5 cents, to $47 a share.

HEADLINE: Texas Lawmakers Confront School Financing Issue Anew

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
After two decades of courtroom skirmishes over the financing of public schools, the Texas Legislature last spring finally produced a new formula intended to end the disparity in wealth between school districts.
But now the Legislature has been called into special session to confront more problems with the plan. This time, it is at odds with itself over how best to raise the money. 
 The effort in Texas, whose years of attempting to overhaul an outdated school finance formula have attracted national attention, is certain to be difficult. The plan will cost the state an additional $1.6 billion for the two-year period starting Sept. 1, yet Gov. Ann W. Richards and most other state officials oppose the creation of personal and corporate income taxes to support it.
And a group of prosperous school districts has filed suit against the state, calling the new plan a "Robin Hood" approach that skims property tax revenue from rich districts and gives it to poor ones.
 
Strains in Other States

In many ways, Texas reflects the difficult straits in which other states find themselves.
In Mississippi, another state where efforts at restructuring education have attracted national attention, the legislature similarly failed for a second time, in regular session this spring, to raise $150 million to support higher spending for more education programs.
New Jersey, which was forced by state courts to overhaul its school finance formula, is now back in court. In the new suit, critics maintain that the plan's redistribution of state money did not remedy the problem of disparate spending between rich districts and poor ones. A ruling is expected by late fall, school finance experts said.
All told, the school finance formulas of 19 states are at various stages of litigation, and prospects look dim, given the sour economic climate, that any of the states will be able to revamp school finance formulas without raising some taxes, school finance experts said.
Kentucky, however, remains an exception. That state's education overhaul and financing package, ordered by the state Supreme Court, is now entering its second year. Even though it resulted in higher state personal and corporate taxes, the Kentucky plan also required the participation of teachers, parents and politicians, and many say that is why it is proceeding reasonably smoothly.
"Kentucky worked because everyone felt like thay had a stake in its success," said Mary Fulton, a school finance analyst with the Education Commission of the States, a Denver policy research organization representing governors, legislators and state education officials. "When you have a Robin Hood approach like Texas, it leaves a sour taste in some people's mouths."
 
Headaches in Texas

Indeed, the plan approved by the Texas Legislature last March has created nothing but headaches for virtually everyone involved. Under the plan, the state created 183 education districts closely following county lines. Property tax revenue from all school districts within each education district is to be pooled, with poorer districts getting more money than they had previously and rich school districts actually losing some of their own tax revenue.
The plan also calls for more state aid to school districts overall, and the Legislature this spring was bitterly divided over how to best raise the $1.6 billion cost of the package. In the current special session, which began Monday, that problem is expected to be just as serious, given officials' opposition to adopting state personal and corporate income taxes.
Gov. Richards has repeatedly voiced opposition to both, and has said the money for the financing plan can be raised through spending cuts and consolidation of overlapping state agencies and services. That, the governor said through a spokesman, Bill Cryer, must occur before she will consider exploring additional revenue sources.
She would be happy to institute a state lottery, as well. But many religious groups in Texas oppose lotteries, and the Legislature defeated a proposal for one in its last session.
"School funding is going to be a down-to-the-wire issue," said Al Kauffman, a lawyer for the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Education Fund, which sued the state 23 years ago to repair the disparities in per-student spending between rich and poor school districts. "It's not going to be easy."

GRAPHIC: Photo': Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas, who opposes the creation of new personal and corporate taxes to finance public schools. (Paul Conklin)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Marketing Expert To Run Laura Ashley

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
What does a former automobile and electronics salesman know about selling flowered frocks and perfumed potpourri?
"I know what a consumer is," says Jim Maxmin, 48 years old and the new chief executive of Laura Ashley Holdings, the beleaguered purveyor of genteel household furnishings, toiletries and clothing that evoke the style of an English country manor house. 
 Mr. Maxmin, an expatriate American who has lived in Britain since 1964, learned the marketing business selling soap door to door in London's East End. "That's tough -- every sale was a hard one," he recalled.
Reviving Laura Ashley could be equally tough. The company posted pretax losses of $11 million for its 1990 fiscal year ended Jan. 26, compared with a loss of $7.2 million the previous year. And it has laid off a fifth of its work force and closed seven factories in Britain and Ireland. The company blamed poor exchange rates, the recession and high inflation, but retailing analysts said it needed to update its image.
"Young women under 35 who have been working out and sweating buckets to slip into cat suits are not about to start wearing granny-length dresses in floral prints," said Alan G. Millstein, publisher of Fashion Network Report, a fashion and retail trade newsletter.
Mr. Maxmin disagreed, saying most Laura Ashley customers have remained loyal and introduced their daughters to the company. "That's the essence of niche marketing," he said. "You're not trying to reach everyone."
Nonetheless, Mr. Maxmin said his task was to protect the brand name and image while making sure consumers understand that every item in the Laura Ashley collection "doesn't have flowers on it."
He acknowledged that the company had had difficulty in its transition from a family-run business to a specialty retail chain of more than 500 company-owned stores and 200 franchised stores manned by more than 7,000 employees in 24 countries. Most of the stock is held by the family. A Japanese supermarket operator, the Jusco Company, holds a 15 percent stake.
Mr. Maxmin's strategy involves expanding business in Asia and Europe, increasing advertising and enhancing or adding products to attract new customers.
Mr. Maxmin started in retailing with Unilever and in 1973 joined Volvo Concessionaires U.K., rising through the ranks to become chief executive of the British subsidiary and later joint chairman. A decade later he joined Thorn-EMI P.L.C. as chief executive of television rentals. He was named president of Thorn in 1988 and led its $600 million acquisition of Rent-A-Center Inc., an American consumer electronics rental company.
Mr. Maxmin has a home in London but spends half his time in Boston. His wife, Shoshana Zuboff, teaches at Harvard Business School. He has four children, ages 8 to 20, from his first marriage.

HEADLINE: A.T.& T. Expects Big Write-Off

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced better-than-expected second-quarter earnings yesterday, but at the same time it issued a stunning warning that it would take pretax charges of as much as $4 billion against earnings before the end of the year.
The charges will cover expenses related to its takeover of the NCR Corporation and a number of cost-cutting programs. 
 Wall Street decided it was all good news. The earnings demonstrated that the company could do well in a tough economic climate, and the write-offs, analysts said, signaled its intention to move aggressively to get rid of unprofitable operations and real estate holdings.
 
'Headed in the Right Direction'
 "You can finally say, eight years after they started to break up the old A.T.& T., that the ship has turned and is headed in the right direction," said Jack Grubman, who follows the telecommunications industry for Paine Webber.
Investors apparently agreed. A.T.&T.'s stock, which has long been the nation's most widely held, rose $1.625, to $39.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The earnings report was one of many that helped to invigorate the market, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average 37.56 points, to 3,016.32. [Page D8.]
The write-off would be the third huge charge against A.T.&T. earnings in less than a decade. In 1983, in anticipation of its breakup as part of its antitrust settlement with the Government, the company recorded $7.3 billion in pretax special charges, the largest write-off ever by an American company. It took a $3.2 billion pretax charge against earnings in 1986 to cover the cost of reducing its work force and merging various operations.
 
MCI Revenue Up, Net Off
 A.T.&T. said that this year's charge would end up costing the company about $2.5 billion after taxes, absorbing much of its profit for the year. But the write-off will also improve A.T.&T.'s cash flow and not affect the company's ability to pay stock dividends, according to Robert E. Allen, the A.T.&T. chairman.
In related earnings news yesterday, the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance phone company after A.T.& T., said that its revenues had grown rapidly but that much higher expenses had led to a sharp decline in income from the second quarter of 1990.
Analysts said that the figures suggested that long-distance calling had grown at an annual rate of about 6 percent during the quarter. It appeared that A.T.& T. had virtually halted the erosion of its market share at about 65 percent and that MCI, with about 15 percent, had been gaining some market share from U S Sprint, which has been concentrating on improving profitability.
The details of the companies' earnings follow.
 
A.T.& T.
 A.T.&T.'s net income rose 26 percent, to $828 million, or 75 cents a share, from $657 million, or 60 cents a share, in 1990's second quarter. Over half the gain came from the company's $140 million pretax profit on the sale last month of a stake in Sun Microsystems Inc. Operating income rose 11 percent, to $1.3 billion, from $1.17 billion a year ago for the company, which is based in Basking Ridge, N.J.
The strong gains in operating income reflected a blend of revenue growth -- up 5.4 percent, to nearly $9.53 billion from $9.04 billion in 1990 -- and effective cost controls. Expenses rose just 4.5 percent, to $8.23 billion, as declining telecommunications operating costs partly offset an 8.8 percent increase in selling and administrative expenses.
"Efforts they initiated as long as five years ago are starting to bear fruit," said Joel D. Gross, who follows the company for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "It's basic blocking and tackling."
A.T.&T.'s telecommunications services revenue rose 3.9 percent, to $5.01 billion, based on a combination of lower prices and a 7 percent increase in volume. WATS, "800" numbers and international services led the growth.
Sales to GTE and overseas offset declining phone equipment sales to the regional operating companies, lifting total phone equipment and systems sales 8.9 percent, to $1.94 billion. Sales of private exchanges and other business equipment grew just 1.7 percent, to $855 million. One reason was a decline in computer sales that A.T.&T. attributed to uncertainty during much of the quarter over the impact of the NCR acquisition.
Rental revenue fell 4.1 percent, to $1.11 billion. Revenue from financial services and leasing, which includes the company's Universal credit card, jumped 93.6 percent, to $289 million.
Mr. Allen said that A.T.&T. decided to disclose the possibility of large charges against earnings before completing its plans because of investors' uncertainty over the NCR deal. The preliminary estimate that it will cost up to $1.5 billion to meld the operations and product lines of the two companies was, in effect, a total write-down of A.T.&T.'s computer operations to allow NCR to start with a clean slate, according to Jack Grubman, who follows telecommunications for Paine Webber.
 
MCI Communications
 MCI Communications, which is based in Washington, said that its net income in the second quarter was $137 million, or 50 cents a share, down 22.6 percent from $177 million, or 67 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter. Revenues rose 12.4 percent, to almost $2.10 billion, from $2.03 billion a year ago, driven by an 18 percent increase in calling volume. An unspecified part of that increase resulted from the acquisition last August of Telecom USA Inc.
MCI's operating income fell 7.7 percent, to $276 million, from $299 million in the second quarter of 1990, in large part because of a 16.2 percent increase in expenses to $1.82 billion. Many of the expenses were associated with new product introductions and MCI's drive to increase market share.
MCI's stock fell 62.5 cents, to $28.25, in over-the-counter trading yesterday.

HEADLINE: Senators Call Raise an Issue of Equity

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Members of the Senate, many of them openly defensive about their decision to grant themselves a $23,200 raise in a vote on Wednesday night, said today that they had cast their votes in the name of pay equity, ethics reform and fairness in government.
But others appeared torn about the vote and complained that it would be hard to justify it to voters during a recession that has forced several states into budget crises. 
 "It's an issue of merit pay," said Senator John Seymour, Republican of California, who is running to retain the seat he was appointed to last year and who voted against the raise. "If you're running a business, you don't give yourself a raise when you're in the red and your firm isn't producing."
But in the 53-to-45 vote at 9:50 P.M., the wary Senators were outnumbered by those who had become convinced that their vote could be justified as a way to put their salaries up on a par with those of House members and at the same time limit income they received from outside employment and speakers' fees.
 
'It's Kind of Amusing'

"I have no problem with my salary being equal to the House," said Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, who voted for the raise. "It's kind of amusing from our point of view. We haven't seen the world fall in as a result of the House getting their raise."
When the Federal fiscal year begins Oct. 1, senators will earn $125,100, if the House approves the measure. That is the same amount the House voted itself in 1989 when it banned the acceptance of speaking fees and limited earned outside income.
The Senate backed away from following the House's lead in 1989 in the face of vocal opposition from their hometown constituents that precipitated a flood of angry mail and demonstrations in front of the Capitol. The Senate voted instead for a 10 percent raise, and to limit the amount of money they could accept in outside speaking fees. Senators now earn $101,900 but may accept $23,068 in speaking fees each year.
Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, praised the Senate's action of Wednesday as a "wise, if overdue, action." He said the House will concur with the Senate.
Senators have long complained that it is demeaning to earn less than their counterparts in the House and even some staff members.
"No one can fail to grasp the significance of the fact that there are staff members on the House side making more than U.S. Senators, that Federal judges make more, that Federal bureaucrats make more," said Senator J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, who voted for the raise.
The discontent spilled over onto the floor during the debate Wednesday night and again in the halls outside the Senate chamber.
Some Senators, like Tim Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, and Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, said they would contribute their raises to charities in their home states. Mr. Wellstone voted against the raise; Mr. Wirth voted for it.
"All I'll get to take is the heat," said Mr. Wirth, who said he supported the measure because it was a way to ban the acceptance of speaking fees.
Senator Steven Symms, Republican of Idaho, said, "The fact is, my constituents already thought I was getting paid $125,000, because that's what they read Congress makes." Mr. Symms and Mr. Murkowski were two of the eight Senators seeking re-election this year who voted for the raise.
Representative Richard Stallings, the Idaho Democrat who plans to challenge Senator Symms this year, said it was "inappropriate " for the Senate to vote itself a pay raise "in the middle of a recession when families are cutting corners all over the place."
Twenty-five others who are facing re-election campaigns this year voted against the raise. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, voted for the raise in 1989 but changed his mind this time.
 
'Not the Proper Time'

"I just felt this particular time with my state in the state it's in, it is just not the proper time to vote for a pay increase," said Mr. Dodd, who sponsored an unsuccessful attempt to ban speaking fees earlier this year.
Over all, 28 Democrats and 25 Republicans voted for the raise, and 27 Democrats and 18 Republicans opposed it.
The consumer advocate Ralph Nader castigated the Senate's leaders, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, and Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, for quietly lining up the votes they needed for the raise and orchestrating the measure's passage on the Senate floor within two hours.
The leaders, Mr. Nader said, "led a narrow majority of avaricious Senators to a huge pay increase directly in the face of massive deficits, cutbacks in critical programs, S.& L. bailouts, scandals and rising unemployment."
According to figures compiled by the National Governors' Association, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, who earns $130,000 a year, is the only state chief executive who will earn more than a member of the Senate once the raise takes effect. And among big-city mayors, Coleman Young of Detroit and Kathryn Whitmire of Houston each earn $130,000 a year, and David N. Dinkins of New York makes $123,500.

HEADLINE: Arkansas Congressman Struggles With Debt

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 18

 BODY:
Representative Bill Alexander of Arkansas was meeting with constituents a few days ago when several of them praised him for bringing Federal aid to the state. "I guess I'm better at doing it for myself," he replied.
The 57-year-old Mr. Alexander, a Democrat who has served 12 terms in the House of Representatives and is a member of the House Appropriations Committee, is deeply in debt. He invested in a 10-acre condominium project that went sour in Boulder, Colo. Two Arkansas banks are seeking to foreclose on his condominium at an Arkansas lake resort and on undeveloped commercial property in his hometown, Osceola. Mr. Alexander is selling his house in Washington to meet his bills. 
 His financial troubles belie the public's image of wealthy lawmakers immune to downturns in the economy.
"This is just like a farmer who didn't make a crop," Mr. Alexander said in a recent interview. "You just work hard and make another one."
 
Growing Liabilities

Since 1986, Mr. Alexander's liabilities have outpaced his assets. Congressional financial statements are imprecise, but Mr. Alexander's report shows liabilities of $865,000 to $1.9 million. He lists his assets at $171,000 to $491,000. He said he owes at least $348,000 in interest and principal to the two Arkansas banks.
After questions were raised in Arkansas recently about Mr. Alexander's investment in a planned hotel and underwater park in Key Largo, Fla., he asked the House ethics committee to review it, and it obliged him. The development is next to a nonprofit research foundation that received more than $1 million in Federal grants through the House Appropriations Committee. The foundation is operated by Mr. Alexander's business associates in the planned development.
The ethics committee found that he broke no House rules but warned that members of Congress should closely examine their official actions and personal business dealings. Mr. Alexander gave the stock back to the company.
In a recent interview, Mr. Alexander said he would not file for bankruptcy. "That's not my style," he said. "My dad lost a crop in the 1950's, and I had to drop out of college and return on the G.I. Bill to finish," Mr. Alexander said.
 
Struggling in Congress

Mr. Alexander said he had struggled financially during his 22 years in Congress because the demands of the job were too great for him to tend to his personal business adequately. "At times a job in Congress costs more than it pays," he said. In 1990, Mr. Alexander received $122,900 in salary and in fees for public appearances. He received from $11,003 to $33,700 in other income, his finance reports show. He described his way of living as modest and said it had not changed with his recent financial problems.
In November, Mr. Alexander formed a company, First Preferred Investments, with his wife, Debi, a researcher in the Washington office of the Chicago law firm, Hopkins & Sutter, to consolidate his debts for tax purposes. She owns the company and the losses are in her name, but Mr. Alexander is the guarantor of the debts, making them his liabilities. Mr. Alexander would not give details about the company's holdings, but he said he had received no loans from it.
His financial difficulties began in 1985 when he and seven other Arkansas investors paid $1.2 million for the Colorado site and started building, but accummulated $3.4 million in debt before selling it in 1990. Investors said the project fell prey to a downturn in the Colorado economy when the oil and gas industry faltered.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Conceptualism From California

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
FOR people who eat and sleep contemporary art, as well as for those who rarely touch the stuff, the retrospective of the work of John Baldessari that opens at the Whitney Museum of American Art today will be both a pleasure and a surprise. It is a terrific show, well paced and handsomely installed, with illuminating quotations from the artist printed directly on the wall. It provides New York with its most extensive look at the achievement of this influential Californian, now 60 years old, a Conceptual artist par excellence whose interweavings of language and appropriated photographs made him a major precursor to the art of the 1980's.
To walk through this exhibition is to see premonitions of the 80's efforts of David Salle and Eric Fischl (both of whom were students of Mr. Baldessari's when he taught at the California Institute of the Arts in Valencia), as well as Barbara Kruger, Jenny Holzer and Cindy Sherman. The work on view dates from the late 1960's to the present and covers almost the entirety of Mr. Baldessari's art, which started out strong and has gotten consistently better, more accessible and also more profound. In this regard, the show as a whole has a traditional and eminently satisfying shape, despite Mr. Baldessari's penchant for eccentric materials and processes that some may find unconventional or even "anti-art." 
 Organized by the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, it includes rarely seen early paintings, which he commissioned other artists and sign painters to make, and a selection of the artist's videotapes and books. And, while tracing Mr. Baldessari's growth as an artist, it also teaches much about the roles of photography and popular culture in contemporary art. Few artists have found as many different and amusing uses for photographs as Mr. Baldessari, who has transferred them to canvas, drawn on them, arranged them in cinematic "story board" sequences and, most recently, spliced them into big collage-like images.
These last works dominate the powerful second half of this display of nearly 90 works, which moves chonologically, gallery by gallery, through the artist's different styles and phases. Deploying enlarged Hollywood film stills, these works resemble visually skewed, extra-intelligent movie posters -- and should have special appeal for old movie buffs. As one wall label announces, their abrupt juxtapositions of imagery and startling additions of bright disks of color (usually over people's faces) create "multi-leveled narratives." But for all their post-modern ambiguity, they take on the themes -- life and death, good and evil -- that have concerned artists down through the ages, restating them in a contemporary vernacular. It is not by chance that intense gazes between people are a frequent motif; for all their obvious Hollywood glamour, they also bring to mind the focused eye contact in hundreds of religious paintings -- of the Annuciation and Last Supper -- from Giotto forward.
The monumental 1986 work titled "Heel," which confronts visitors as they step off the elevator, demands to be read like a puzzle, with each image adding a new twist of possible meaning. The dominant picture is a 1930's street scene in which a crowd of students or workers seems caught on the verge of action, about to riot or be herded away by nearby policemen. Smaller framing images focus on individual people or on feet, often in ways that imply pain (scarred or bandaged heels) or power (one man tying up another's feet). A tremendous tension builds as, one by one, the images iterate the helplessness of the individual.
In the double images of "Bloody Sundae," where an art heist seems to be in process, the tension is more theatrical, like a good suspense movie. On top, two men attack a third beside a stack of paintings; on the bottom, a couple lounges on a bed, a breakfast tray between them. One wonders: are they the next victims or did they plan the whole thing? That all five faces are obliterated by circles of color only increases the unease.
In art circles, Mr. Baldessari, who was born in National City, Calif., is well known without being completely understood, especially in terms of his early work. He began his career in the key of Duchamp, where the deadpan, the random and the ironic are frequently used notes. One of his best-known early works, something of a "classic" of Conceptual art dating from 1970, consists of the carefully documented act of cremating all the paintings still in his possession that he had made between 1953 and 1966.
The artist's subsequent works often took an irreverent view of modern art or the mundane aspect of life in Southern California -- or both. One series of eight photographs from 1974, each an image of four red balls caught in motion against a bright blue California sky, is titled "Throwing Four Balls in the Air to Get a Square (Best of 36 Tries)." This is not exactly the way Mondrian did things.
In many respects the significance of California in Mr. Baldessari's work should not be underestimated, likewise the fact that for many years he supported himself teaching art, first at a National City high school and later at the California Institute. His work has a freewheeling irreverence that is something of a local product and shared by California artists like Edward Ruscha, Bruce Nauman and even William Wegman, a New York-based artist who began his career in Los Angeles. In addition, like an unusually skilled teacher, Mr. Baldessari is constantly prodding the viewer to expand his or her notion of what art can be.
Especially in the early years, Mr. Baldessari seemed determined to expunge all mysteries and ineffability from his art, as well as any sense of the artist's hand or his esthetic decisions. He has said he wanted to be "less artful than Rauschenberg and Warhol: this is a photograph, here's a text. That's it."
He drove his car around National City, taking blurry photographs (while driving) that he later transferred to canvas and had a sign painter add an identifying caption, like "Econ-O-Wash, 14th and Highland." Related paintings took wry potshots at the art world, as in a canvas featuring an image of an issue of Artforum magazine over the caption "This Is Not to Be Looked At." It's unclear if this injunction refers to Mr. Baldessari's canvas, the art magazine or the abstract painting by Frank Stella pictured on its cover.
But despite Mr. Baldessari's surface of deadpan and cool, this exhibition betrays that the artist has a restless, ambitious energy that, after the mid-70's in particular, becomes more and more assertive. (The ambition is also palpable in the catalogue, written by Coosje van Bruggen, which documents an even greater array of work and analyzes everything in detail.)
The powerful second half of this exhibition reveals that Mr. Baldessari hit his stride when he stopped taking his own photographs and started enlarging and cutting up and coloring the thousands of movie stills he had collected over the years. Especially in the 80's, his sudden additions of flat bright color to these images speak more of a reverence than an irreverence for modernism, a love of the power of primary colors as strong as Mondrian's. At the same time, the purely formal drama of the colored spheres, which sometimes recall the tossed red balls of the artist's 1974 photographs, is matched by the human drama of the movie images.
Art history, movie culture and real life buzz through these works at a furious rate, fueled by each viewer's own reactions and emotional responses. In a 1987 work titled "Two Stories," for example, the life of Christ is clearly the subject of the left row of vertical images, while those on the right, of different figures running through fields, seems to mix moments of danger with ones of extreme joy. As the artist himself has said: "We bring all our baggage to it, what we've seen of life, and on television, and so on. There's just enough there to activate the mind, but not enough to provide completeness." So in the the end, the mysteries and ineffability have returned to Mr. Baldessari's art, and he is putting them to good use.
"John Baldessari" remains at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, through Oct. 20.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Bloody Sundae," by John Baldessari, is part of a retrospective of the artist's work at the Whitney Museum of American Art. (Whitney Museum of American Art)

HEADLINE: Next Target for Bush: Accord on Cyprus

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, July 18

 BODY:
As the United States Administration works on the problems in the Middle East, President Bush took on another unyielding area today: Cyprus.
"In the new world I have discussed, none of us should accept the status quo in Cyprus," Mr. Bush said in a speech to the Greek Parliament. "And today I pledge that the United States will do whatever it can to help Greece, Turkey and the Cypriots settle the Cyprus problem, and do so this year." 
 "Today, with new leaders of vision, your nations enjoy a unique opportunity to overcome the misunderstandings of the past," Mr. Bush said. "You can begin to heal the deep wound that scars Cyprus, that divides families and friends on that island."
At a news conference after a two-hour meeting with Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis of Greece, Mr. Bush said: "I don't want to suggest that the United States can wave a wand, a magic wand, and solve a problem that has plagued this part of the world for a long time. But we are going to try."
 
Security at Its Tightest
 In Athens security precautions were even tighter than usual today, because of a series of terrorist bombings that have shaken Greece recently. Armored vehicles rolled onto the airport runway as the President and his staff landed. And officials advised members of the traveling White House press corps not to exhibit their American nationality openly, either by jogging or openly wearing their press passes on the street.
According to Reuters, the Greek Government has "imposed the most Draconian security system seen in Athens in peacetime."
More than 3,000 police officers, army troops and a special anti-terrorist squad were on full alert for the President's visit. Police officers told the Athens News that 1,000 American security agents had been sent to Greece.
About 2,000 demonstrators, mostly students, crowded into a city square downtown, protesting about Cyprus and calling for American aid in expelling the Turks from the island. The police used tear gas to control the crowd.
 
'A Historic Opportunity'
 Tonight, a bank with an American Express office was firebombed and several protesters were arrested.
On Tuesday, the Turkish charge d'affaires and two other Turkish employees were wounded as terrorists set off a bomb near their car in downtown Athens.
[In Istanbul, Turkey, where Mr. Bush is to arrive on Saturday, bombs went off Thursday night and damaged five banks despite heavy security measures, The Associated Press reported.]
Regarding Cyprus, Mr. Bush said that it was not his role to "spell out steps and procedures" but that he felt he could spur the process at a time the Prime Minister called "a turning point."
"I told him that if we could be a catalyst who could help solve the problem of Cyprus, we would willingly fulfill that role," Mr. Bush said.
He said he believed that "a historic opportunity" exists now, because both sides seem to be more optimistic about a possible settlement through the United Nations.
The Greeks have compared the Cyprus problem to the invasion of Kuwait, and Mr. Bush seemed taken aback when he was asked by a Greek reporter why he did not "liberate" Cyprus from the Turkish troops, as he "liberated" Kuwait.
Administration officials had previously been reluctant to allow Mr. Bush to be drawn into another intractable political argument, trying to settle the long-running feud in the Eastern flank of NATO.
But in an interview this week, Prime Minister Mitsotakis said that Mr. Bush had acceded to his request to get involved in the Cyprus problem.
Turkey invaded Cyprus in 1974, fearing that the Greeks were trying to take over the island. It remains riven by a border enforced by the United Nations, leaving 40 percent occupied by 29,000 Turkish troops.
 
Turkish Role in Gulf War
 But Prime Minister Mitsotakis said that he pressed Mr. Bush in two conversations because he believed that the unrest in the Balkans, including the Yugoslav civil conflict, had intensified the need to bring stability to Cyprus.
Mr. Bush arrived in Athens on a steamy 90-degree morning. He had left a rainy London at dawn after the end of the Group of Seven's economic summit meeting, where he reached an arms control agreement with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and scheduled a Moscow summit meeting for the end of the month.
The President's two-day visit to Greece is part of a sensitive balancing act before a two-day visit to Turkey, where he wants to express solidarity with President Turgut Ozal of Turkey.
Mr. Bush wants to thank President Ozal for taking the risky step of acceding to his request to shut down the Iraqi oil pipeline that runs through Turkey and allowing allied planes to make bombing runs from Turkey's NATO bases. The closing of the pipeline, which cost Turkey $2.5 billion, insured the early success of the coalition against Saddam Hussein.
The Greeks contributed a frigate to the Persian Gulf effort, but now they fear that a Turkey favored by Washington could use its new postwar clout to the detriment of Greece. Mr. Bush does not want to offend either the Greek Prime Minister or the many Greek-American voters in America.
The Greek armed forces have a long shopping list to buy jet fighters, war ships, tanks and other equipment. Mr. Bush said it is "our intention to do what we can to strengthen the Greek armed forces."
The visit by Mr. and Mrs. Bush to Greece, was the first by an American President since Dwight D. Eisenhower's in 1959.

He reviewed an honor guard with President Constantine Caramanlis of Greece after arriving yesterday in Athens. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Art in Review

BYLINE: By Roberta Smith

 BODY:

'Explorations II:
The New Furniture'
American Craft Museum
40 West 53d Street
Through Aug. 4
Sometimes a chair is just a chair and sometimes it's a work of art. In "Explorations II: The New Furniture," a survey of the work of 11 furniture makers, the chair-as-art is at the forefront, along with the table, chaise, lamp, bench and grandfather clock. The show is chockablock with objects whose overwrought silhouettes and exquistely crafted surfaces seem to have "esthetic" written all over them. The result does not feel entirely welcoming to those of us who think that form should follow function as directly as possible or that superlative craftsmanship and the savvy quotation of past styles don't necessarily add up to originality. 
 Still, this is a lively, even argumentative exhibition; it provides a valuable glimpse of a rich terrain where art, craft and design overlap. It boasts an impressive range of sensibilities. It should make all viewers sort out what they like and don't like in furniture, and why.
For those who think that Darth Vader was the last word in style, there is the rather sinister drawing room of Alex Locadia, a former car customizer, whose taste runs to black leather, aluminum and Surrealist suggestiveness. His "Vega" chair has fanglike legs and a profile reminiscent of a motorcycle; his chaise longue suggests nothing so much as an unusually svelte shark. If rustic or Adirondack furniture is more your style, there are Daniel Mack's one-of-a-kind chairs, which incorporate the roots or branches of trees (with or without bark), or old woodworking tools -- all of which, frankly, deserve a better fate. And fans of clever wordplay will undoubtedly appreciate the grandfather clock designed by Edward Zucca. It is covered with $1 bills, which interject the Father of Our Country into the proceedings, and is titled "Time Is Money."
The interest in Americana that runs through the exhibition is well expressed in Wendy Maruyama's playfully painted and carved "Two-Patterned Blanket Chest," and turns hilarious in Allan Wexler's "Screen Chair," which combines porch swing and screen porch with the modernist angularity of Gerrit Rietveld.
For the most part, the designs that speak more softly and anonymously, that look as if they might actually be lived with and used, make the most lasting impression. David Ebner's refreshingly reserved "Wine Table," a combination of tripod legs and circular top -- in a dark wood called wenge -- balances adeptly between the modern and the traditional. Dakota Jackson's straightforward "Saturn Stool" evokes an Art Deco dentist's office without looking dated; more designed than crafted, it is also one of the few objects here that seem ready for mass production.
The moments when form and function fuse into a thing of useful beauty are too rare in this exhibition; the instances of overbearing artistic ego too plentiful. But this shouldn't stop anyone from looking and learning. In addition, the contributors to the show's well-written catalogue, headed by John Perreault, senior curator at the museum and the exhibition's organizer, make impressive cases for the work of each artist.
 
'When Objects Dream and Talk in Their Sleep'
Jack Tilton Gallery
24 West 57th Street
Through August
The poetic title of this group exhibition -- "When Objects Dream and Talk in Their Sleep" -- suggests that objects, like the rest of us, have an unconscious that surfaces after the lights go out. Not surprisingly, the assembled artworks imply that what surfaces often pertains to childhood or sexuality.
This exhibition of work by eight artists reflects the appeal, among the younger generation, of casual arrangements of ephemeral signifiers of popular culture. Paula Hayes's scattering of objects, titled "Cool Bride or Bruce Lee Is Dead," suggests a teen-age fan in mourning, while Karen Kilimnik's "Castle Gloom" conjures flimsy romance with a Scottish flavor.
Maureen Connor's installation, "Ensemble for Three Female Voices," actually speaks, or at least laughs a lot. It consists of three casts of a human esophagus made of lipstick -- a luscious yet gruesome effect that evokes a lifetime of talk and makeup. Emanating from each are chuckles, laughs and guffaws whose different timbres suggest three generations -- child, mother and grandmother. Collier Schorr conflates innocence and its loss in a plaster cast of a little girl's dress that hangs high on the wall; looking up into it the viewer becomes a voyeur and also discovers primitive scrawls and graffiti -- pleas, accusations and childhood taunts -- written on its inside surface.
The other artists in the exhibition are Polly Apfelbaum, Meg Cranston, Steven Evans, Annette Messager, Donald Moffett and Kiki Smith, and their contributions all have something to say.
 
'Drawing Acquisitions, 1980-1991'
Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris
120 Park Avenue (at 42d Street)
Through Sept. 5
This delightful display of 27 drawings represents less than 10 percent of the Whitney Museum of American Art's drawing acquisitions during the past decade. If any conclusions are to be drawn from it, it is that the museum intends to treat all 20th-century art, early and late, with an even hand.
From the first half of the century are Cubist drawings by Stuart Davis and John Marin, grouped effectively with a 1937 watercolor by Lee Krasner that takes Cubism back to its Cezannesque beginnings. From mid-century comes an image of three dark levitating orbs by Myron Stout, its figural presence drawn out by the neighboring "Daisy's Dream," a glowering 1989 pastel by Elizabeth Murray.
Recent works by Mike Kelley and Christopher Wool exploit full-bodied contrasts of black and white, while Jasper Johns deals in gradations of gray. Works by Jackson Pollock, Alan Saret and Cy Twombly are all linear bravura. And in "Head of a Woman With a Hat," Elie Nadelman, a master of the economic line, fills in his forms completely, creating the semblance of a hot, summertime flush.
Unusually sensitive juxtapositions and pairings, by which the drawings speak to each other as well as to the viewer, make this exhibition especially worthwhile.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Ebner's "Wine Table," at the American Craft Museum. (Gil Amiaga/American Craft Museum)

HEADLINE: Cyanamid Net Up 18.9%; Caterpillar Posts a Loss

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
American Cyanamid reported record second-quarter earnings and sales yesterday, but two other industrial companies, Dow Chemical and PPG Industries, announced sharp earnings declines, and Caterpillar Inc. reported a loss. 
 Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
American Cyanamid
 American Cyanamid, the Wayne, N.J., specialty chemicals manufacturer, earned $132 million, or $1.41 a share, for the three months ended June 30, up 18.9 percent from $111 million, or $1.16 a share, a year earlier. Quarterly sales totaled $1.42 billion, up 16 percent from $1.23 billion.
George J. Sella Jr., chairman and chief executive, said the performance reflected strong growth in the company's medical and agricultural-related businesses.
American Cyanamid's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $68.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
 
Caterpillar
 Caterpillar Inc. said it lost $17 million in the second quarter, in contrast to a profit of $46 million, or 46 cents a share, a year earlier.
The company attributed the loss to the recession in most of the industrialized world and in Brazil, where Caterpillar has two manufacturing plants.
The manufacturer of tractors and earth-moving equipment said sales for the second quarter were $2.69 billion, down 8.8 percent from $2.95 billion last year. Domestic sales fell 22 percent while sales outside the United States were up 2.6 percent.
Caterpillar took a nonrecurring charge of $22 million against earnings in the quarter related to the write-off of surplus assets and job reductions outside the United States.
The company's shares climbed by 62.5 cents, to $48.375, on the Big Board yesterday.
 
Dow Chemical
 The Midland, Mich., company said second-quarter results totaled $233 million, or 86 cents a share, down 36 percent from $364 million, or $1.34 a share, a year earlier. Sales were basically unchanged at $4.79 billion, against $4.80 billion.
Dow blamed lower selling prices and higher manufacturing costs for the declines.
Dow's stock fell 37.5 cents, to $54.125, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
 
PPG Industries
 PPG Industries, the giant chemical, paint and glass manufacturer, said its second-quarter earnings dropped 43.9 percent because of declines in United States auto production and construction starts.
After-tax profit totaled $79.1 million, or 75 cents a share, on sales of $1.48 billion, compared with earnings of $141 million, or $1.31 a share, on sales of $1.57 billion a year earlier.
The chairman, Vincent A. Sarni, said slow business for auto makers and the construction industry meant sales and earnings declines for PPG glass products.
The stock of PPG rose $1.375, to $58.625, on the Big Board yesterday.

HEADLINE: Blacks Spar Over Endorsing Thomas

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
The discord among black groups over Judge Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court escalated today as black conservatives accused his opponents of holding him to an unfair political standard because of his race.
Buster Soaries, a New Jersey pastor who leads a coalition of black conservatives that declared its support for Judge Thomas here today, said, "Black organizations and individuals in positions of leadership do a tremendous disservice to our community when they use their offices to condemn Clarence Thomas for his philosophy and essentially, for departing from liberal orthodoxy." 
 But members of the Congressional Black Caucus today laid out their reasons for voting last week to oppose the nomination, warning that it would be a mistake for black people to support Judge Thomas solely because he is black.
It was not clear whether that Mr. Soaries's news conference and a second one by other supporters of Judge Thomas were orchestrated by the White House in response to the caucus's.
It was also not clear what prompted the formation of the black conservative coalition, but there was no suggestion it was orchestrated by the White House. In addition to Mr. Soaries, the group is being led by Robert L. Woodson, president of the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise, a group that helps communities deal with their social and economic troubles.
 
A Broadening Debate

Today's exchange was the latest round in an intellectual and political debate that was sparked by the Thomas nomination, but has grown to embrace broader questions about the legacy of the civil rights movement and the political diversity of the minority population.
David A. Bositis, senior research associate for politics at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a leading black research organization, said the Thomas nomination has underscored a problem for many black people: they want to see a black replace Thurgood Marshall, the Court's first black justice, but they do not want a conservative.
"There is certainly an element of uncomfortableness," Mr. Bositis said. "There are a lot of people who long for the days of 'We Shall Overcome,' when we all stood together. But part of the consequence of the civil rights movement is that it allowed for a much greater measure of differentiation in the black community. They're not used to it right now, but they will get used to it."
Flanked by other black House members, Representative Edolphus Towns, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the black caucus, read a statement today declaring that the group's opposition to Judge Thomas was based on his philosophy and background.
"We cannot ignore or excuse Clarence Thomas's record, views, values, merely because he is an African-American," Mr. Towns said. "His view of constitutional rights as he has articulated them as jurist, administrator and before the nation's press are inconsistent with the interests of the people we serve."
 
'No Profile in Courage'

Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Democratic caucus member from Manhattan, said, "All people would feel a sense of pride if they feel that one of their own has been selected." But he emphasized that they should not be blindly supportive, saying, "Our job is to make certain that that's an educated decision that they're making."
The caucus's opposition to Judge Thomas "is no profile in courage," Mr. Rangel said, adding, "There is no support in our communities for this man."
 
Defense From a Republican

Caucus members said they were particularly concerned about Judge Thomas's record on affirmative action, and argued that he was insensitive to minorities during his tenure as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in the Reagan Administration. Judge Thomas now sits on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
But Representative Gary Franks of Connecticut, the only black Republican in the House and the only one of the 26 members of the black caucus to support Judge Thomas, defended him today at a news conference with other conservative lawmakers.
Mr. Franks accused caucus members of unfairly rejecting the notion that there were many black conservatives in the country. "Many people would say that because of my conservative positions that the black community would not be supportive of my candidacy," Mr. Franks said, "and I proved them wrong. I carried seven of the eight predominantly black precincts."
Mr. Woodson accused the caucus of "demanding that blacks be politically correct" and added, "They're looking at life through an elitist perspective."
As evidence of the ambivalence about the Thomas nomination among organizations representing black people, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the National Urban League and the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights have yet to announce their positions on it.
