HEADLINE: Europeans Continue to Favor More Generous Financial Help to Soviets

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 18

 BODY:
France, Germany and Italy continued to make clear today that they were willing to go further than their allies in providing direct Western involvement in rescuing the Soviet economy.
At this week's London summit meeting, these three European countries went along with the the joint statement agreed to by the United States, Britain, Canada and Japan, which offerred Moscow new association with international financial institutions, technical assistance and greater market access, but fell short of what President Mikhail S, Gorbachev had wanted. But the three Continental powers also have stressed they wanted to do more than their their partners in the Group of Seven industrial powers. 
 "We formed a sub-group that carried out a job of persuasion," one French official said, noting that France's President Francois Mitterrand, Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Italy's Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti lunched privately before Mr. Gorbachev met the Group of Seven.
The official added that, while as host of the summit meeting, Prime Minister John Major of Britain was intent on building a consensus among the Group of Seven, he also left no doubt that he leaned towards the more flexible approach favored by the other three European leaders, but had to go along with the less generous approach favored particularly by Washington.
The United States has repeatedly stressed that aid should be limited until the Soviet Union has actually taken the hard political moves to take it into a more market-oriented economy. It is always possible, of course, that President Bush, when he goes to Moscow at the end of the month for a summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, may loosen up on the question, but American officials say that beyond going ahead with seeking most-favored-nation tariff treatment for Moscow, it it unlikely that Washington will go beyond what was agreed to in London.
Political experts noted that, because of their proximity to the Soviet Union, the European members of the Group of Seven believe the collapse of Mr. Gorbachev's liberalization effort would affect them much more severely than it would the United States, Japan and Canada.
 
Early Recognition of Gorbachev

They also recalled that, after Mr. Gorbachev took office in 1985, Britain, France and Germany were far quicker than Washington in recognizing, in the words of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, that they could "do business" with him.
Further, no less than President Bush, Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl both believe they have a special relationship with Mr. Gorbachev, with the German leader particularly grateful that he permitted the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and accepted the unification of Germany.
France, Germany and Italy backed early Soviet entry to the International Monetary Fund as a full member -- instead of an undefined period of associate membership -- as well as more credit from a new European Development Bank. They were blocked by the United States, Japan and Canada.
 
Follow-Up in Moscow

But they considered it a victory that the relationship with Moscow was institutionalized through annual meetings between the rotating president of the Group of Seven and the Soviet President. And they noted that finance ministers from the Seven will soon travel to Moscow for further talks.
Still more important for Mr. Gorbachev, the three governments have stressed that the London summit is merely the first step. Refering to the decision to give Moscow only associate membership of the I.M.F., Mr. Andreotti noted today: "The problem is not closed of course."
In Bonn, while German newspapers described the summit as a personal failure for Mr. Kohl, Germany's Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said the Group of Seven had "begun a process which would have as its conclusion the full integration of the Soviet Union in the world economy."
On Wednesday, Mr. Mitterrand went out of his way to praise Mr. Gorbachev and noted that, when it comes to helping Moscow, "France belongs to those who believe it is better to assume the risk now than to accept the alternative risk that could lead the experience to failure."
French officials said that the European powers had no plan to launch an independent initiative to step up aid for the Soviet Union, but would continue to work in that direction in other forums, including the 12-nation European Community and international financial organizations.
The London summit's failure to promise direct aid to Moscow, however, was seen as a setback for Germany. Since the Germans currently provide around 60 percent of all Western aid to the Soviet Union, Mr. Kohl had hoped to persuade his Group of Seven partners to assume a greater share of this burden.

HEADLINE: Protest Tangles Airport Traffic For Rush Hour

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
Using more than 30 tractors and other pieces of heavy construction equipment, about 60 demonstrators -- demanding contracts and jobs for blacks -- brought traffic to a halt yesterday afternoon at the height of the rush hour on the road leading to Kennedy International Airport.
Beginning at 4:30 P.M. and blocking all three lanes on the Van Wyck Expressway, the protest tied up traffic for 2 1/2 hours, forcing some passengers to leave their cars in the 99-degree heat and lug their baggage on foot for a mile to try to make flights. Fourteen demonstrators were arrested on disorderly conduct charges by the Port Authority police, which confiscated four tractor-trailers, a front-end loader and two vans. 
 Earlier in the afternoon, the organizations sponsoring the action -- United Black Enterprise, a group of black truckers and contractors; the Jamaica branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and the Queens Urban League -- picketed outside the World Trade Center, the site of the Port Authority's executive offices. They were joined there by State Senator Alton R. Waldon Jr., Assemblywoman Vivian Cook and the City Council majority whip, Archie Spigner, all Democrats of Queens.
"We are concerned about the lack of contracts for any businesses and vendors in the airports," said Ed Lewis, assistant to the president of the Jamaica branch of the N.A.A.C.P., last night. "There are unfair and different requirements for African-American contractors, and there has been an exclusion of the southeast Queens community in the economic developement of the J.F.K. 2000 project and the rebuilding of La Guardia Airport. We are just looking for our fair share of the economic base in the borough."
L. B. Griffin, president of United Black Enterprise and a heavy-construction contractor in Jamaica, said the protesters were seeking job equity.
"There are no black contractors for the $2 billion expansion project at Kennedy and La Guardia. There are zero bona fide -- that is, not working for a white front -- black contractors working on major construction sites for the Port Authority," he said, adding, "We intend to go back again until someone speaks to us about black participation in the Port Authority."
Calling the action "irresponsible and deplorable" in a statement released last night, Stanley Brezenoff, executive director of the Port Authority, denied that the agency discriminated in employment or business opportunities for minorities and disputed Mr. Griffin's contentions.
"The Port Authority has a long record of creating such opportunities," he said. "In April and May of this year, construction employment at J.F.K. rose to 375, of which 107 jobs went to minority group members, about 29 percent. Since the beginning of 1990, about $19 million, or some 19 percent of all redevelopment contracts, have been awarded to minority-owned businesses. Simlilar results have been obtained at La Guardia and Newark International Airports."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Lawyer Whose Client Was Racial Justice

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

A Season for Justice
The Life and Times of Civil Rights Lawyer Morris Dees
By Morris Dees with Steve Fiffer
Illustrated. 355 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.
 Morris Dees, a white lawyer who grew up in Mount Meigs, Ala., population 400, became a millionaire in 1967 by publishing and selling cookbooks to schools, churches and women's groups. He was named one of the "Outstanding Young Men in America" by the Jaycees, on a notable list that included Ralph Nader. The next year, he was on his way to Chicago, where he intended to start a trade-book publishing house, when a snowstorm diverted his flight and he found himself spending the night on a hard bench in the Cincinnati airport. There, he picked up a paperback copy of "The Story of My Life," by Clarence Darrow, a reprint of the original 1934 autobiography of the famous American defense lawyer. In "A Season for Justice," Mr. Dees says that Darrow's book changed the course of his own life. 
 Unfortunately, the author's rather convenient epiphany in an airport waiting room has an after-the-fact feel to it. A more likely explanation appears in his book. He grew up in a progressive Southern family and came of age at a time when the colleges and the country had reached a point that legal, if not economic and social, equality became acceptable and necessary.
Mr. Dees and his co-author, Steve Fiffer, a lawyer and writer, have constructed a sympathetic account that should be useful background to understand the clashing views today by those trying to narrow or broaden civil-rights laws. It's about the extraordinary achievements of a courageous minority of black and white people, risking their necks in the streets and their careers in the courts, to break down the entrenched racist system during the last quarter of a century.
The book is subtitled, "The Life and Times of Civil Rights Lawyer Morris Dees," but the times are far more revealing than the author's life and motivations. And what historic times they were! Marches by demonstrators, bus boycotts and sitdown strikes, nonviolent resistance inspired by Gandhi, eloquent speeches by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and crusading preachers; on the other side, violent resistance by sheriffs with police dogs and fire hoses, beatings and killings that were inspired by the Ku Klux Klan as well as by the rhetoric of racist governors and senators, slavishly waving the Confederate banner in the 20th century.
Much of the story in "A Season for Justice" is built around the role of the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Ala., in attacking segregationist institutions and the Ku Klux Klan. In 1971, Mr. Dees and his law partner, Joseph Levin Jr., founded the center. Twenty years later, it remains a nonprofit legal and educational foundation that serves as an advocate for the oppressed all over the South. Often at personal risk, and without the monetary rewards of their colleagues in private practice, the center's lawyers continue to be in the forefront of civil-rights battles, mainly for blacks but also for new immigrants.
Even the most obvious injustices -- for example, membership restrictions for the Y.M.C.A. in 1969 -- required a lawsuit to achieve desegregation in Montgomery. Mr. Dees relates how pressure was brought by community leaders, including a threat to have him disbarred. He was offered a deal: the case against him would be dropped if he called off the lawsuit. He continued to press ahead; again and again, the author shows that he loved a good fight and knew how to use public-relations methods to combat segregationist diehards. Mr. Dees says that because the Y.M.C.A. case hit so close to home for many in Montgomery, some people began to call him a "Commie lawyer."
Other center lawyers began to win precedent-setting cases that established new gains for powerless citizens. Steve Ellmann litigated a case involving inhuman conditions in Alabama mental institutions. Ira Burnim broke new ground in obtaining financial benefits for cotton-mill workers suffering brown-lung infection caused by an excess of cotton dust. John Carroll and Dennis Balske assembled a trial team to train lawyers trying capital cases. More than 50 death-penalty cases were brought by the center; in some cases, inmates were saved from execution and received their freedom. In one highly publicized case that lasted 12 years, a black Marine sergeant who shot two white Georgia law officers in self-defense was eventually released from prison.
After the center established Klanwatch 10 years ago, Mr. Dees, his family and colleagues became assassination targets of the Klan and neo-Nazi groups. The center itself was fire-bombed in 1983. Four years later, the center achieved a major victory when it brought a lawsuit on behalf of the family of a 19-year-old black who was lynched by Klansmen in Mobile, Ala.; the largest Klan organization in the country, the United Klans of America, was bankrupted when it lost the $7 million case. Last year, the White Aryan Resistance, based in Fallbrook, Calif., was ordered by an Oregon court to pay $12.5 million in damages to the family of a black Ethiopian immigrant killed in Portland in 1988 by two skinhead members of a group called East Side White Pride. The center's lawyers had argued that the White Aryan Resistance had encouraged the skinheads.
"A Season for Justice" appears at a moment when the battleground has shifted, once again, to Congress and the United States Supreme Court. Although the book seems glossed-over as a personal story, it holds up as a report on the achievements of the Southern Poverty Law Center in the field of civil rights during the last 20 years.

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:

Budget Dim Sum
 Past the throngs of tourists and sidewalk shopkeepers, tucked away along cluttered and colorful Division Street in Chinatown, is a Cantonese restaurant renowned among Chinese residents of the neighborhood for its diverse and budget-priced dim sum. Eight-year-old Lan Hong Kok Seafood House looks as if the contractors who built the place quit in midstream. The front room has soot-brown walls, Formica wainscoting and big glass-covered tables; the unfinished-looking back room is stunning in bright red, with a solitary chandelier in the middle. 
 Diners are ushered to big communal tables, where one presumes it could be fun to sit as patrons swap comments on different dishes. The only problem was that none of our dining companions spoke English. Servers who stroll around the room holding dim sum trays are no more helpful. The most detailed description of a dish I got was "pork."
 Left to our own devices, we enjoyed some gelatinous pork meatballs vibrant with fresh coriander, coriander-flecked steamed pork dumplings, fresh and delicate shrimp dumplings and crisp fried shrimp dumplings ($1.35 each). Pork spare ribs are served in an unusual way, cut into tidbits and served in a slightly sweet sauce ($1.35). Shrimp and bits of lobster in a gossamer wonton skin were delicious and impeccably fresh, but fried scallops were too heavily breaded ($2.50 each). For $35, a couple can eat until they need a kneeling bus to get home.
Lan Hong Kok Seafood House, 31 Division Street, serves dim sum from 7:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. daily; dinner from 4 to 11:30 P.M. daily. No credit cards. Telephone: (212) 431-9063 or (212) 226-9674.
 
Staying Closed
 Toscana, the Italian restaurant at 200 East 54th Street in Manhattan, which was to be converted to a casual and less expensive spot, will not reopen, said Sergio Bitici, one of the owners. The restaurant closed in March for renovation, but Mr. Bitici said the state of the economy made such a venture impossible.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Presenting the Issues For Viewers' Decisions

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Can a half-hour television program touch the heart and stir the brain cells at the same time? Before you burst out laughing at the idea, tune into Channel 2 at 8:30 tonight for "Whose Side Are You On?"
This first of three CBS News specials digs into the issues involved in a husband's killing of his terminally ill wife. Next Friday brings the question, lately raised by the rape charges against William Kennedy Smith, of whether the name of a woman who says she has been raped should be made public. The final program, on Aug. 2, deals with public opinion and the right to parole. 
 The innovative format, which may turn up again on CBS News if the response is what it should be, works. Opposing lawyers present the pros and cons with the help of people directly involved, others who have had related experiences, and experts. In effect, the lawyers, abetted by the CBS producers, offer their own mini-documentaries.
In tonight's case, which Mike Wallace, presiding, calls "killing with kindness," Robert Harper, a Michigan man who admitted to giving his wife sleeping pills and then putting a plastic bag over her head, says he did what she would have wanted. Their daughter, who was in the room, remembers the scene as "peaceful, tender, loving." A doctor who specializes in geriatric care reports that patients are typically terrified by the prospect of months in a hospital and painful treatment, and a lung-cancer sufferer pleads with doctors to help her "to die with some dignity."
The other side introduces the argument that in expressing a wish to die, Mrs. Harper might actually have been asking for support and sustaining love from her husband and daughter. A man who was told four years ago that he would soon be dead of cancer says he drew strength from his family's assurances that they wanted him to live. A specialist in the ethical implications of "right to die" cases warns, "We do not want people given the right to kill other people even with love."
A panel of four people, at least one or two of them likely to be recognizable to viewers (Arthur Ashe, the former tennis champion, and the actress Meredith Baxter Birney), then weighs in, evidently expressing opinions the participants held before watching the cases unfold. The panelists, even the celebrities, seem reasonably thoughtful, but in the manner of panels, the fastest and loudest talkers tend to dominate. The half-hour ends with the scene, captured by a camera in the courtroom, of the Harper jury delivering its verdict.
Next week, Susan Estrich, a law professor at the University of Southern California and a rape victim herself, makes the case that given the shame that attends rape victims, exposure in the press and on television is "devastating," while Alan M. Dershowitz of Harvard Law School argues that only when women come forth will the crime be treated like any other crime and the stigma be erased. It is a question that apparently divides feminists. Among Mr. Dershowitz's witnesses is Karen DeCrow, a past president of the National Organization for Women, who holds that the accuser's name should be publicized just like the name of the accused. Charles Kuralt moves matters along.
Yes, it would have been more daring if the producers had chosen to lead off with less celebrated cases, but if this bow toward popularity helps them to do other programs in as intelligent a spirit, the compromise will have been justified.
 
'20/20'
Channel 7
Tonight at 10
Tonight on "20/20," Hugh Downs offers a pilot's-eye view of the nation's most dangerous airports. Drawing on responses to a question in Professional Pilot Magazine, he finds the danger spots to be bicoastal: La Guardia Airport in New York City; National Airport in Washington; Los Angeles International Airport; San Diego Airport, and John Wayne Airport in Orange County, Calif.
The hazards include congestion, maneuvers required to cut down on engine noise and, in the case of La Guardia, short runways. A Federal Aviation Administration official responds that the airports are closely regulated and safe, and despite scenes of crashes and dire reports of disasters barely averted, you may be left with the feeling that "20/20" is indulging in a little scare mongering. Still, the pictures from the cockpit should raise travelers' appreciation of the pilots' skill.
 
'The Treasure of the South Pole'
Channel 4
Sunday at 7 P.M.
Antarctica's pristine beauty and its imported rubbish are on display Sunday in "The Treasure of the South Pole." The hourlong documentary tells of the efforts of dozens of countries to get footholds on the vast, icy and as yet unexploited continent in hopes of benefiting economically, politically and militarily.
The report, narrated by Keith Morrison, is sympathetic to Greenpeace, the environmental group that wants to leave the area to its native inhabitants -- penguins, walruses, seals and whales -- but it does not simplify a complicated matter. It leaves open the question of how long the lure of possible oil, gas, coal, platinum and who knows what other riches can be resisted.
 
Whose Side Are You On?
Catherine Lasiewicz, senior producer; Andrew Heyward, executive producer. At 8:30 tonight on CBS.

HEADLINE: The Best Way to Save the Banks

BYLINE: By Charles E. Schumer; Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, is a member of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The megamerger of Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover vividly illustrates the changes rocking the American banking system. These two giants were falling further and further behind in the fiercely competitive global marketplace. Although no one knows if they will survive as one entity, they would likely have failed without this consolidation. The deal is certainly a harbinger of more mergers.
We make a grave error, however, if we believe that consolidation, in and of itself, is a solution to the underlying problems of the banking industry. We cannot make one healthy bank merely by combining two or more sick ones. And big is not necessarily better, as the problems of Citibank in New York and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in Japan illustrate. 
 If we do not assert more control, banks will continue to do what they can to survive -- pursue mergers and other self-help measures, raise interest rates to attract deposits, invest in speculative ventures, and so on in an endless spiral. We can, through several simple, straightforward steps, create a market environment for banks that will act as a self-governing check on the industry.
The problem is rooted in the 1980's, when bank interest rates were deregulated to compete with money-market funds and other magnets for investor dollars. Because much of their traditional business was being ripped away, banks had to look for new, often riskier investments.
Under normal circumstances, an industry faced with these problems would have shrunk, but because of the safety net of Federal Deposit Insurance the banking industry continued to grow.
Chock-full of insured dollars, without the market discipline to force them to be careful about where they placed these funds, banks fell behind when they entered new, strange and complex fields like investment banking and commercial real estate. For a decade, Congress and regulators looked the other way.
But in the late 1980's, the chickens came home to roost. Banks became much weaker, and taxpayers were faced with billions of dollars in losses.
The problem of shaky and failed loans is sure to continue into the 1990's unless we change the way banks do business.
Certainly, we can give regulators more authority and better tools to intervene when banks get into trouble, and the current bank reform legislation, recently passed by the House Banking Committee, does that. But even the most competent regulator is no match for market scrutiny when it comes to getting a balance sheet into shape.
We need only give the following instructions to our banks:
First, if you accept federally insured deposits, invest them in relatively safe ways. Any one loan from a federally insured bank should be limited to no more than 3 to 4 percent of the bank's capital. No single equity investment of more than 5 percent should be allowed.
Second, the interest on all deposits should not exceed a floating interest rate cap. Weak banks would be prevented from recklessly raising interest rates to lure depositors (a way of staying liquid while trying to climb out of trouble) and would not be allowed to capitalize on the bonanza of a Government guarantee.
A floating interest rate cap and a maximum loan limit would make banks kick their deposit insurance addiction by limiting the Federal Government's safety net to core banking functions needed to serve small borrowers, individuals and midsize companies. The higher-yield, riskier activities would continue, but in separate uninsured affiliates that depend on private investors to raise funds.
Core banking would force banks to become healthy and strong precisely because it would steer them to the markets to raise funds for their newer and riskier investments.
We cannot fail to enact these changes. Mergers, regardless of how numerous or large, will not cure the illness that ails our banks.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Tax Cows of New York

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The good news for New Yorkers is that real estate prices are collapsing and that the President does not give a damn about the city.
 If the prices of one-family homes in Queens and co-op apartments on Park Avenue were holding up, a lot more taxpayers would cash them in and leave than already have. 
 The evidence about Mr. Bush's attitude toward the crisis in New York is what White House and newspaper reference computers show he has said about it -- not a thing.
 That is good news because New Yorkers can stop wasting time fantasizing that Mr. Bush will ever be of help. Gorbachev yes, Dinkins no.
So we know that if anybody is going to help the city it will have to be the people who make their living in it: us.
Everybody says New York will have to "restructure" itself. God help us, we even have another committee to study it. First, we should restructure our own heads.
I will start with mine. Until recently I thought New Yorkers should just pay more taxes for the privilege of living in the city, and shut up about it. I know now that people want to leave New York not because of taxes but because they are not getting the decent money's worth for them that self-respect demands.
 Seven percent of the households pay 50 percent of the city's personal income taxes. Fewer than 1 percent pay 20 percent. About 1,000 out of 350,000 companies pay 50 percent of the corporate income tax. These high-tax payers benefit directly from only about 12 percent of the $29 billion budget -- the money that goes into police and fire protection, street cleaning, as it is laughingly known, and "amenities" like museums, parks, cultural groups.
Now, that is also the 12 percent of the budget that makes possible the city's major industry: tourism. But how long will tourists pay good money for the joy of consulting changing schedules to find out what museums are closed on which days, as they pick their way among stinking mountains of garbage bags and try to edge around the muggers, hoodlums and confidence men who have taken over Broadway or the professional beggars and cheapjack peddlers who are turning Fifth Avenue into a flea market?
When the supply of masochistic tourists runs out, jobs in restaurants, hotels, entertainment will vanish with them. We will be singing "The Sidewalks of Pompeii."
For New York to cut back on museums, parks, Lincoln Center and performing groups is like an electronics store owner deciding to stock only pencils and expecting shoppers to keep coming in and paying computer prices for them.
Decent streets and protection against crime and fire are the bedrock services that a local government must deliver -- the contract with City Hall. In New York, add culture as economic lifeblood that must not be spilled.
The rest -- decent public schools and hospitals, child care, welfare -- are redistribution of wealth by democratic consent. It is a relatively modern concept, born out of Western enlightenment movements and revolutions. Perhaps that will be mentioned in multicultural courses when they get around to rotten old Western society for a chapter or two.
I am still willing to go on paying ever-higher taxes to live in New York, no matter what. But it has finally sunk into my New York-loving brain that other taxpayers are not as professionally or emotionally tied to New York. Expecting them to go on paying ever more to live in a smelly, dangerous city that gives them ever less is not boosterism -- it's arrogance.
Once Mr. Dinkins has demonstrated to the people who pay the taxes that a decent minimum will be guaranteed to make the city livable for them, he can reasonably say, here is the rest of the news:
One, costs will be cut and management sharpened and here's how. But two, the city will still probably have to charge you more for schools your children will not attend, hospitals you will not enter and welfare you are fortunate enough not to need.
Treated as urban milch cows in a dirty ramshackle barn, many New York upper-bracket taxpayers will try to escape. Given protection and respect for their own needs, I believe, they will stay and pay what is necessary to respect everybody's needs.
 President to city: New who?
 City: York. Come see us sometime; we'll be here. Bring the wife, see the shows.

HEADLINE: Rowe Journal;
Near Old Nuclear Plant, Town Keeps the Faith

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROWE, Mass., July 16

 BODY:
Tucked discreetly into the northern Berkshires, Yankee Rowe is the oldest and perhaps the most picturesque nuclear power plant in America. The trout waters of the Deerfield River cut a glistening path around the containment dome. Bright orange butterflies flutter in and out of the barbed wire fencing.
For three decades, the residents of Rowe have treated their atomic neighbor with the best sort of Yankee hospitality. They have built houses nearby, taken their children on tours and used the plant's taxes to buy services most small towns cannot even dream of. 
 But recently, unsettling news has come from the plant. Several scientists have questioned the safety of Yankee Rowe's reactor vessel, and earlier this month, the new chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission called the possible dangers at the plant his most pressing concern.
Now, many residents of Rowe, population 357, are disturbed. Not because they are seriously worried about an accident at the plant, in the northwest corner of Massachusetts. They are annoyed, they say, by the interference of people who obviously are not like themselves.
"I call them radicals," one Rowe resident, Robert Kenney, said of those calling for the plant to be shut down. "They look like they got their latest clothes out of a Salvation Army box. They go around with pigtails."
Another resident whose husband works at the plant and who insisted that she not be identified, said: "It's yuppie panic. They're people who want you to quit smoking and eat tofu."
And James O'Brien, chairmen of Rowe's Board of Selectmen, said, "They're intellectuals."
By today's standards, 31-year-old Yankee Rowe is a diminutive plant. It generates just under 200 megawatts of electricity, slightly less than one-quarter of what Shoreham, the unopened nuclear plant on Long Island, was supposed to produce.
But Yankee Rowe's significance to the atomic power industry far exceeds its size. The plant is licensed to operate until it turns 40; in the next year it is expected to become the first in the country to apply to extend its life through relicensing.
But the plant may not ever make it that far.
Engineers with the Union of Concerned Scientists say Yankee Rowe's reactor vessel has become so brittle after three decades of nuclear bombardment that it could rupture in an emergency, and they have called for the plant to be shut immediately. While the plant's owners, a consortium of New England utilities, deny the allegations, members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission have expressed reservations and are expected to take up the issue later this summer.
Here in Rowe, most people seem to place more faith in the workers who run the plant than in the outsiders who are casting aspersions. These workers are friends and neighbors and relatives, and with the jobless rate in the Berkshires approaching 10 percent, expressing doubts about Yankee Rowe is seen as tantamount to wishing those workers onto the unemployment line.
"I am concerned about the embrittlement," said Dick Quinn, a Rowe resident. "But I trust the people that work there. I don't want to see anybody lose their jobs, especially these days."
Hard times have hit Rowe just as they have the rest of New England, but not quite as hard.
Between the nuclear plant and a major hydroelectric project in town, 85 percent of Rowe's taxes are paid by utility companies. This has made the town the object of more than a little envy in the area.
"They've got the golden egg," Dorothy Stetson, a resident of nearby Heath, said bitterly. "It's just too bad they don't share a little of that."
Rowe may not have much to offer in terms of commerce; the town's only store is a cross between a camping outfitter and a candy shop. But it does have a new firehouse, a library, an elementary school and a newly remodeled town hall. Driving into Rowe, one cannot help appreciating the work of the town's busy highway crew; right at the town line the rutted roads of the Berkshires suddenly become smooth.
Local officials are quick to point out that even if Yankee Rowe were to shut down, the town would still be collecting good money from the hydroelectric plant. This realization has gone a long way toward steadying nerves in town.
As Mr. Kenney, a member of the highway crew as well as the town forest warden and deputy fire chief, put it, "If the plant ever closed, we wouldn't be down the pooper scoop -- Pardon my language."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Big Loss Faced By General Tire

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, July 19

 BODY:
General Tire, a unit of Continental A.G., the German tire maker, is facing a $100 million loss and is exploring cooperation with the Pirelli Armstrong Tire Company, an Ohio newspaper reported today. Like other tire companies, General Tire has had slumping sales because of the recession, and the company has said that it expects to lay off 600 salaried employees this year, as well as about 175 of the 1,000 workers in its Akron offices.
Alan Ockene, General Tire's president, told The Beacon Journal in Akron that his company and Pirelli Armstrong, a unit of the Italian tire maker, were discussing possible cooperation agreements between certain operations. "Without a merger, if we can save $20 million, why don't we do it?" Mr. Ockene was quoted as saying. He said the negotiations were limited to those concerns. General Tire's losses could reach $100 million this year, Mr. Ockene said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Down in Slow Day; Gold Prices Edge Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled yesterday against most major currencies in light dealings that traders said were driven mostly by internal influences in the foreign exchange markets.
Gold prices edged higher. In New York, gold for current delivery edged up 40 cents an ounce, to $370.60, on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank quoted a bid for an ounce of gold at $370.40 as of 4 P.M., up 70 cents from late Thursday. 
 The dollar drifted lower this past week in the aftermath of concerted efforts a week ago by several central banks to curb its rise. Mindful of that unexpected wave of dollar-selling, currency traders have sold dollars themselves, testing the lower end of the dollar's recent trading range. A summertime lull in activity accentuated yesterday's moves.
Francoise Soares-Kemp, a vice president who follows the currency markets for Credit Suisse in New York, said last week's intervention showed traders what the central banks would like to see as the highest levels for the dollar, so the market has "started to look for the bottom."
"This is not based on fundamentals," she said. "It is purely technical trading in a thin market."
Christa Bleyleben, vice president in currency trading at the Bank of Boston, said many large currency traders had changed their trading strategies over the last week "from buying on dips to selling on rallies." She said rumors that the Federal Reserve might reduce interest rates circulated briefly, but no one appeared to pay much attention to them.
Trading was "more technically fueled" than it was influenced by speculation on the economy and interest rates, she added.
The dollar dropped to 136.40 yen in New York, from 137.65 yen late Thursday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar fell to 136.92 yen from 137.17 yen and was quoted later in the day in London at 136.40 yen.
Against the German mark, the dollar fell more than two and a half pfennigs, to 1.7480 marks from 1.7755.
The British pound rose to $1.6900 in London, from $1.6515 late Thursday. In New York, the pound rose to $1.69425 from $1.6645.
Selected dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.51125 Swiss francs, down from 1.5405; 5.9360 French francs, down from 6.0270; 1,303.75 Italian lire, down from 1,322.50, and 1.15975 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15775.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
MNC Financial Names New Chief Executive

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
MNC Financial Inc., a Baltimore-based banking company that has been hurt by commercial real estate loans, yesterday named Frank P. Bramble chief executive officer. He has been an executive vice president at the company.
He fills a post that has been vacant since the retirement last September of the chairman and chief executive, Alan P. Hoblitzell Jr., who was replaced as chairman by MNC's largest shareholder, Alfred Lerner. 
 Mr. Bramble, who is 43 years old, becomes the youngest chief executive of any banking company as big as MNC, whose $19.2 billion in assets make it te nation's 33d-largest bank holding company. MNC owns the Maryland National Bank and American Security Bank, Washington.
Those two banks were so deeply involved in that region's real estate boom of the 1980's that by 1990 about 26 percent of all MNC loans were for commercial real estate projects, a high portion for a company of MNC's size. Today, those loans account for the majority of the company's nearly $1.82 billion of nonperforming assets -- either loans that are badly delinquent or real estate the company acquired through foreclosures on bad loans.
Mr. Bramble was not directly involved in the real estate lending, but he has taken part in the efforts to correct past mistakes. The activity has been so hectic "that I feel older than 43," he said. He noted that the cost savings from MNC's merger with American Security Bank in 1987 and Equitable Bank of Baltimore in 1989 -- both of which he arranged -- "are hard to find now that they have been buried under all the real estate problems."
To remove the cloud created by the bad real estate loans, Mr. Bramble said MNC must do more than reduce costs by $100 million, as has been planned, and adopt new central controls over lending.
"We have to continue our efforts to sell the bad assets," he said, and maintain MNC's already large business with local consumers and small businesses. Although demand for business loans in the region remains weak, Mr. Bramble said that consumer confidence in the bank was improving, and deposits had been increasing gradually since February.
Nancy Bush, a banking analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, noted that with nearly 15 percent of its assets consisting of badly delinquent loans or foreclosed real estate, the only hope of MNC for sustained profits was "to get rid of the problem loans in huge chunks."
Mr. Bramble said the company was looking at ways to sell the bad loans "in bulk" but declined to describe what progress had been made. Over the last year nonperforming assets have more than doubled from $756.7 million in July 1990. But in the most recent quarter, Mr. Bramble said the pace of deterioration had slowed, so that the increase in the second quarter was only $24.8 million.
"We have identified the problems," he said. "The timetable for disposing of them depends on the market."
Mr. Bramble graduated from Towson State Univeristy with a bachelor's degree in 1976 and attended the University of Wisconsin's graduate school of banking. He lives in Baltimore with his wife and four children.

HEADLINE: 2 Baby Bells' Profits Drop; Third Is Flat

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Three regional phone companies yesterday reported second quarter earnings, with Southwestern Bell and Bell Atlantic posting drops and U S West reporting flat results.
Following are the details of the results:
 
Southwestern Bell
 The Southwestern Bell Corporation said its second-quarter profit fell 34.2 percent, largely because of a one-time charge. 
 For the three months ended June 30, the company earned $172.6 million, or 57 cents a share, down from $262.5 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier.
Even without the one-time charge of $80.7 million, profit would have declined by 3.5 percent primarily because of two regulatory decisions that reduced earnings at its phone company by $14 million.
Revenue rose 3.2 percent, to $2.24 billion from $2.17 billion.
The one-time charge accounted for fees and charges associated with refinancing $732 million in long-term debt that carried interest rates of 11.5 percent to 12.75 percent. The debt was replaced with shorter-term notes with interest rates of 8.3 percent and 7.7 percent.
"The company took advantage of the lowest interest rates in several years and will realize significant savings in interest expenses over the long term," said a spokesman, Jerrell Ross.
"We see solid progress in the last half of this year," said Edward E. Whitacre Jr., chairman and chief executive. "The key indicators of our business are strong."
The St. Louis-based company provides phone service to Missouri, Oklahoma, Kansas, Arkansas and Texas. It also supplies paging equipment, cellular telephone service and phone directories.
The stock closed down 50 cents yesterday, to $53.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
U S West
 U S West Inc. reported earnings of $276.6 million for the second quarter, virtually unchanged from $276.4 million in the second quarter of 1990.
But earnings per share decreased to 70 cents, from 72 cents, largely because the company sold 16.1 million shares of common stock in May 1990, it said.
Revenue rose to $2.5 billion, from $2.41 billion last year.
"Results of our telephone operations were essentially flat, with rate reductions offsetting volume increases," said Richard D. McCormick, president and chief executive. "Increased earnings of certain diversified businesses were offset by higher start-up losses of U S West's international joint ventures."
U S West, based in Englewood, Colo., provides phone service to many Western states. It also owns companies involved in communications, marketing and financial services.
U S West's shares fell 75 cents yesterday, to $34.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
 Bell Atlantic

The Bell Atlantic Corporation, based in Philadelphia, reported a 2.1 percent dip in its second-quarter profit, saying a cutback in expenses prevented a steeper decline.
Profit totaled $355.1 million, or 91 cents a share, compared with $362.8 million, or 92 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue was unchanged at $3.08 billion.
"Although our second-quarter results contain some encouraging signs, we have not yet seen across-the-board indications of economic growth," said Raymond W. Smith, chairman and chief executive.
The results include income and expenses from Bell Atlantic's investment in the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand.
Bell Atlantic is the parent of local phone companies providing service to New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia and Washington. It also provides mobile phone service, financial services and computer services.
The company's stock rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $48.25 on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Zenith Posts Wider Loss in Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GLENVIEW, Ill., July 19

 BODY:
The Zenith Electronics Corporation reported today that it had a $26.9 million loss for the second quarter, blaming the recession and continued planned reductions in inventory for its sixth straight quarterly loss.
The latest loss compares with a loss of $11.2 million for the second quarter of 1990. Sales dropped 17.7 percent, to $275 million, from $334 million a year earlier. 
 Zenith, the last United States-based television maker, said it cut costs by $13 million in the quarter but that the cuts were more than offset by lower sales.
"Results in the second quarter were in line with our earlier statements that the first half of 1991 would be difficult," said Jerry K. Pearlman, Zenith's chairman. "The second half of the year is normally stronger for consumer electronics sales. And if economic and industry conditions improve, we expect better results in the second half."
For the first half, the company reported a $50.6 million loss, compared with a $15.2 million loss in the 1990 period. Sales fell 16.1 percent, to $578.7 million, from $689.8 million last year.
 
Investment in Advanced TV

Zenith invested about $4 million in the second quarter in two high-definition television technologies on which it has staked much of its future, up from less than $3 million a year ago.
One of the technologies is the company's unique flat-screen tube that promises sharper, glare-free pictures; the other is a digital transmission system for HDTV signals.
Zenith has joined with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in a proposal to develop a national standard for HDTV. Five other companies are competing to set the standard.
In 1988, Zenith posted its first annual gain in four years, and analysts said the positive result could signal a turning point. But the company has had losses totaling $140 million in nine of the ten quarters since then, broken only by a $4 million gain in the fourth quarter of 1989.

HEADLINE: Omaha: Talk, Talk, Talk of Telemarketing

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OMAHA

 BODY:
If Detroit is the Motor City, then Omaha must be the Motor Mouth City. This low-key community of 350,000 people on the western bank of the Missouri River would never embrace such a saucy slogan, but the fact is that Omaha sets the pace for the world when it comes to making a living on the telephone. And that's just how the city's leaders planned it.
"They put together an exceedingly effective economic development program to attract telecommunications companies at a time when everyone else was concentrating on industry," said Robert Ady, president of the PHH Fantus Corporation, a Chicago-based corporate relocation consulting concern. 
 Cheap real estate, relatively low wages and living costs and a well-educated, reliable work force are also among Omaha's major selling points. Omaha has shown that state-of-the-art telecommunications can be a 20th-century advantage comparable to sitting aside a railroad line in the 19th century. The city best known for its slaughterhouses now has well over 10,000 jobs in telecommunications -- more than double the number of meatpackers -- and an unemployment rate below 3 percent.
During the 1980's, the city's telemarketers gained a nationwide reputation for their ability to handle any special event, any crisis. After Johnson & Johnson found that some of its Tylenol capsules were laced with cyanide, the company chose Omaha as the communications center for its program to exchange capsules for tablets. The Eastman Kodak Company did the same for its instant camera exchange and refund program after a Federal judge ruled that the company had infringed the Polaroid Corporation's patents. And Omaha telemarketers have handled fund raising for the Farm-Aid and Live-Aid rock concerts.
Omaha today is home to a number of large hotel and travel reservation operations, including those for Marriott, Hyatt, Radisson and Westin hotels, as well as the traffic information center for Greyhound bus lines.
It is also the base of operations for three of the nation's five largest telemarketers, as enterprises that sell products and serve consumers over the phone are known. And First Data Resources, a local subsidiary of the American Express Company, is the largest contract processor of credit-card transactions for the nation's banks, handling tens of thousands of charge authorization calls and telephone data transfers daily.
 
Other Successful Uses
 Omaha's use of telecommunications as an economic development tool is hardly unique. Britain has used the privatization and decontrol of its telecommunications industry to help London stay ahead of Frankfurt, Zurich and Paris in the competition to be Europe's financial capital.
New York City and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are partners with private investors in Teleport, a real estate development on Staten Island linking offices there to a satellite transmission park and fiber optic telecommunications systems.
The developers of the planned community of Heathrow, Fla., teamed up with Northern Telecom and the Southern Bell Telephone Company to install fiber optic and digital phone lines to help lure the wealthy to its home sites and businesses to its industrial park. The American Automobile Association said the town's telecommunications helped persuade it to move its headquarters from Fairfax, Va., to Heathrow.
Even tiny Breda, Iowa, a town of 500 that lost its only rail connection to the outside world during the 1980's, managed to attract new business after the privately owned Breda Telephone Corporation built 13 miles of fiber optic lines as links to the A.T.& T. and U S West fiber optic networks. A transportation broker who specializes in helping companies move electronics equipment around the nation now employs 24 residents, and the phone company itself has 100 part-time workers handling calls subcontracted to it by the Omaha-based Sitel Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest telemarketer.
Omaha's drive to make a name for itself as a telecommunications center seems like an obvious strategy in retrospect. The decision of the Federal Government to locate the Strategic Air Command here after World War II made Omaha home to one of the world's most advanced and secure phone systems. That endowed the region with engineers and workers who could also apply their knowledge to local public service.
Two other key advantages were already in place. Because of Omaha's location in the central time zone, it is more convenient to call either coast during the work day than to call from one coast to the other. And the local speech is described by consultants like Mr. Ady as "pure American," easily understood everywhere.
As Steven Idelman, chief executive of Idleman Telemarketing Inc., said, "It's no accident that Johnny Carson, Tom Brokaw and Walter Cronkite all come from this region of the country."
 
 Some Added by Design
 Other elements were added by design. Over the years, state regulators granted local phone companies wide latitude to deploy new services rapidly. Metropolitan Community College developed telecommunications-related courses and training programs. The Chamber of Commerce decided to keep track of the telecommunications capacity of every office building in the city.
The city also benefited from phone companies' investments in switches that protect the area's networks from service interruptions. And Northwestern Bell, the local operating company of U S West, has long made rapid customer service one of its highest priorities.
"We can get a WATS line installed in 20 minutes," said Timothy Placzek, senior vice president of client services at First Data Resources. Mr. Placzek recalled that within four hours Northwestern Bell repairmen wired new lines directly to all 60 desks normally served by an automatic call distributor that had broken down. The major telemarketing companies say Northwestern Bell routinely gives them the home phone numbers of the repairmen who service them.
Omaha's telecommunications drive became so intense during the early 1980's that one American Telephone and Telegraph survey concluded that telemarketing call volume was eight times higher here than in Atlanta, the next most active city. After the A.T.&T. breakup, U S West, the phone company whose 14-state territory includes Nebraska, adopted the slogan "Dial 800 and get Omaha" to promote its services.
 
 Some Advantages Gone
 Some of Omaha's advantages have been lost in recent years. New tariffs since the A.T.& T. breakup have evened out long-distance billing rates, which once favored Omaha and other Midwestern cities. The city sat astride one of the first junctions of east-west and north-south fiber optic lines; now most major cities have their own fiber optic hubs.
The loss of these advantages has hurt. "Charles Schwab recently chose Indianapolis over us for its communications center when it decided to move out of Chicago," said Red Keenan, director of marketing and business development for Omaha. "Ten years ago, they would have come here."
More important, perhaps, companies looking for the most modern telecommunications are more likely to be looking just as hard for broad computer skills as well. In this area, Omaha has far less to offer than communities with big universities or major computer companies.
 
 Companies Continue to Come
 Nevertheless, companies like the Ford Motor Company's credit subsidiary continue to arrive. Ford chose Omaha last year to consolidate 132 offices that answer consumer questions about Ford loans. It will eventually have 325 employees here handling six million calls annually, according to Susan Seidenfeld, director of employee relations.
Meanwhile, established telemarketers seeking low-cost labor have been moving some of their operations out to neighboring Kansas, Iowa and Colorado. But they are adding more advanced services here to exploit Omaha's phone structure.
Today, the city boasts more than 25 telemarketing and reservations companies. Related industries, like printing brochures or making credit cards, have sprung up to serve consumers who respond to telemarketing.
Many more Omahans work at insurance companies or companies like the Union Pacific Railroad. For these companies, the city's superior telecommunications are a secondary but important attraction.
City officials concede that many of the telecommunications jobs offer lower wages than the declining, unionized sectors of the local economy, like meatpacking. Reservations clerks, most of them women or students, earn about $5 an hour and job turnover is about 50 percent annually. Those with more difficult telephone sales jobs can earn as much as $13 an hour, plus benefits and bonuses. The trend, telemarketing executives here say, is toward more extensive services, higher wages and benefits and less staff turnover.
At WATS Marketing of America Inc., a calling program to generate lists of consumers who want American Express card applications mailed to them has been supplanted by a program in which WATS employees fill out the applications while callers are still on the line. The employees must be able to answer a wide range of questions about the cards' benefits and limits.
"Our work is getting much more interactive," said Charles Brooks, president of WATS, which was acquired by American Express in 1980. "We are 75 percent full time now, compared to less than 50 percent just five years ago."
Supporting such businesses is a reservoir of telecommunications engineering talent that telemarketing executives say is unmatched by any other small city in the nation.
"It's not just the equipment but the concentration of know-how that makes a difference," said Mary Swenson, senior vice president in charge of operations for Utell International, a British-owned reservations company that specializes in booking overseas hotels for travel agents. Utell moved to Omaha from New York City in 1986. "The vendors have seen so many telecom centers that they understand the nuances and can give you helpful advice. And when we go out to recruit a telecommunications manager, we get twice as many qualified applicants as in comparable cities."

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Net Fell 91.9% In Quarter

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. reported yesterday that earnings dived 91.9 percent and revenue declined by 10.7 percent in the second quarter. At the same time, however, the company raised hopes that it might be able to ride a sluggish United States economic recovery during the second half of the year, saying it saw some new strength in domestic markets.
But the company also sounded a bleak note about the international economy, saying it had seen further deterioration in its Asian and European markets. Over all, I.B.M. said it was still grappling with a difficult global economy and competitive pressures in many of its product lines, as well as trying to manage a difficult transition to new products in several of its major businesses. 
 The company warned Wall Street of the impending poor quarter in a June 20 conference call, and there were rumors earlier in the week that it would report a loss, analysts said. As a result, the stock market reacted positively yesterday to the earnings announcement. I.B.M.'s share price rose $2.25, to $100.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Several Analysts See Daylight

Moreover, several analysts said they believed that the company had hit bottom during the last three months and would begin making progress toward a financial turnaround in the third quarter.
"I think they've reached the inflection point," said Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential Securities. He added that he had changed his rating on I.B.M.'s stock to a "buy" after the company held another conference call with analysts yesterday.
"The real key is the phrase, 'the U.S. is starting to show some positive momentum,' " he said.
The International Business Machines Corporation said that earnings for the second quarter fell to $114 million, or 20 cents a share, from $1.41 billion, or $2.45 a share, for the comparable period last year. Revenue fell to $14.73 billion from $16.5 billion.
Part of the momentum may come from the company's continuing restructuring effort, which has led more I.B.M. employees than originally expected to take an early retirement plan option. The computer maker has been saying that it expects 10,000 workers to leave during 1991, in addition to 4,000 who left as part of the leveraged buyout of I.B.M.'s typewriter and keyboard division. Yesterday, the company said that an additional 3,000 would leave by the end of the year.
"We have accelerated our restructuring efforts," said John F. Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman. "And we expect to reduce our worldwide work force by at least 17,000 employees this year." The company began the year with 373,000 employees worldwide.
The impact of the employee departures is a special second-quarter charge of $200 million, or about 20 cents a share, according to the company.
 
 Revamping Expected to Help

"I.B.M. is doing a better job," at reducing its cost structure, said Daniel Mandresh, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, adding, "even though they have yet to use the word that everyone wants them to use, that is, 'layoff.' " Analysts predicted that the company would benefit from revamping during the second half of the year.
Mr. Mandresh said that the company was also likely to benefit during the third quarter from the first shipments of its new top-of-the-line water-cooled System 390 mainframes. The machines are the heart of I.B.M.'s new high-end computer generation, and many large corporations have been waiting until these systems are ready before upgrading to the new computer family. The company, based in Armonk, N.Y., said yesterday that the machines were on schedule for a third-quarter introduction.
Several analysts said that I.B.M. had now shipped about a dozen of the systems as part of a field testing program and that shipments would increase throughout the second half of the year.
 
 Billions More in Revenue Possible

The company could realize between $3 billion and $4 billion in additional revenue before the end of the year if the new computer line is successful, Mr. Martin said.
I.B.M. has also introduced a number of new desktop models that it hopes will stop the erosion of market share it has seen during the first six months of 1991.
But this progress in introducing new product lines may be offset by foreign economic declines. Last week, a senior I.B.M. official in Japan said that the second quarter had been even worse than the first. Mr. Akers was quoted last month in an internal memorandum, calling that quarter in Japan a disaster. The Japanese executive said that the company's "big ticket" mainframes had simply stopped selling during the second quarter and that the rest of Asia was also seeing new declines.
 
 'I.B.M.'s Worst Nightmare'

"This has to be I.B.M.'s worst nightmare," Mr. Mandresh said. "This is a company with 60 percent of its revenues from foreign sales."
I.B.M. may be particularly vulnerable in Japan because its business is concentrated in the banking and financial services sectors -- traditional purchasers of the largest computers. These businesses have recently been hard hit financially.
The impact of foreign currency values on the company was essentially neutral in the second quarter, said James Clippard, I.B.M.'s director of investor relations, who spoke with Wall Street analysts in a conference call yesterday morning.

HEADLINE: G.M. to Close Two Plants, Cut 6,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 19

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that it would close two North American assembly plants, one in Van Nuys, Calif., and one in Scarborough, Ontario, putting almost 6,000 people out of work.
G.M.'s move is in line with the pledge by Robert C. Stempel, the chairman, to balance the productive capacity of the No. 1 auto maker with demand for its vehicles by 1992. Despite several plant closings since 1986, dwindling G.M. vehicle sales in the United States and Canada have resulted in more plant space and output than the company needs. 
 Automotive analysts said, however, that G.M. must close three or four more assembly plants in order to fulfill Mr. Stempel's goal. Jerry Paul, automotive analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, estimated G.M.'s North American capacity at about 6.2 million cars and trucks, with expected 1992 sales in the neighborhood of 5.4 million.
A spokesman said G.M. probably would not have to take an additional write-off to cover the costs of closing the two plants, since an adequate reserve was established last year.
Edmond Dilworth, a G.M. spokesman, said G.M. had tried and failed to make a business case for assembling one or more car or truck models at Van Nuys, which will build the current models of the Pontiac Firebird and the Chevrolet Camaro until the summer of 1992. Then it will be closed. The Scarborough plant will continue building a G.M. van until 1993 before closing.
About 2,700 workers will be laid off at the Van Nuys plant. Already, 900 employees have been temporarily dismissed.
Although G.M. workers had received hints that the plants were vulnerable to shutdown, the announcement about the Van Nuys plant nevertheless provoked anger from the United Automobile Workers union. Workers at the Scarborough plant are represented by the Canadian Automobile Workers union.
Stephen P. Yokich, a U.A.W. vice president, accused G.M. of "shamelessly breaking commitments" to workers in Van Nuys. G.M. managers had often asked workers to cooperate with innovative, Japanese-style work-place practices, saying they would help preserve the plant's competitiveness and the workers' jobs.
 
 Workers' Seniority Rights
 Some Scarborough workers may be able to exercise seniority rights to move to other jobs in G.M. plants in Ontario, the company said. George Peapples, president of G.M. Canada, said the announcement was being made two years early so that workers would receive "the fullest opportunity for planning for their future."
The closing of the Van Nuys plant, the last assembly plant owned by a Big Three auto maker in California, reflects in some measure the loss of status of G.M. vehicles on the West Coast. Mr. Dilworth said G.M.'s market share was about 15 percent in California, compared with about 35 percent nationwide.
The ripple effect of the plant closings may cause layoffs at G.M. parts plants elsewhere. Steel body stampings for the Camaro and Firebird are shipped to the West Coast from G.M. plants in Marion, Ind., and Grand Rapids, Mich.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From U.S. Letter Rejecting Redistricting Plan

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Assistant Attorney General John R. Dunne's letter to the New York City Districting Commission:  
 In our view, the New York City Districting Commission was faced with a job of staggering proportions, namely, to divide a city of over seven million people into 51 new Council districts while addressing the historical inability of the many minority communities in the city to elect candidates of their choice.
We also know that this enormous task necessarily involved many compromises and difficult choices; yet the Commission has made great strides in drawing Council districts which greatly enhance minority voting strength overall. In many areas of the city minority voters will now have an opportunity to participate in the political process and to elect candidates of their choice to office for the first time. Thus, we have concluded that most of the districting plan satisfies the pre-clearance requirements of Section 5.
We are concerned, however, with the choices made throughout the districting process with regard to Hispanic voters. The 1990 Census reveals that the minority population of the city has increased dramatically, particularly the Hispanic population. However, it seems that in at least two areas of the city, the inappropriate choice was made to draw particular districts at the expense of Hispanic voting strength. . . .
In one area, the proposed configuration of district boundary lines appears to have been drawn in such a way as to minimize Hispanic voting strength. Specifically, we refer to the overconcentration of Hispanic population in the Williamsburg area in Brooklyn (District 34) at the expense of Hispanic voters in the adjacent district in Bushwick and Cypress Hills (District 37). We are aware that the Commission rejected available alternatives that would likely result in an additional district, which would provide Hispanic voters in Bushwick and Cypress Hill an equal opportunity to participate in the political process and to elect candidates of their choice to office. . . .
Additionally, with regard to proposed District 8 in the East Harlem-Bronx area, serious allegations have been raised that as in District 37, a series of boundary line changes were made over the course of the districting process which ultimately resulted in a district that was purported to be an Hispanic district but which will likely result in a district in which Hispanic voters will not be able to elect a candidate of their choice.
In light of the consideration discussed above, I cannot conclude, as I must under the Voting Rights Act, that the city's burden has been sustained in this instance. Accordingly, on behalf of the Attorney General, I must object to the 1991 districting plan for the City of New York, only with regard to the manner in which it treats the Williamsburg and Bushwick areas and the District 8 (East Harlem-Bronx) area. . . .

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. REJECTS NEW YORK PLAN FOR CITY COUNCIL DISTRICTS; FINDS HISPANIC VOTERS HURT

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
The Justice Department today blocked use of a new districting plan for the New York City Council, saying that it "consistently disfavored" Hispanic voters in violation of Federal law.
The redistricting plan for an expanded and more powerful City Council was a central element of New York's historic effort to make its government more reflective of the city's racial and ethnic diversity. Today's decision threw that process into at least temporary disarray, casting doubt on whether the city could hold elections for the new Council on schedule in September and November. 
 Mayor David N. Dinkins and other New York political leaders scrambled tonight to salvage the elections. But Hispanic groups vowed to seek a postponement and send the entire plan back to the drawing board. [Page 23.]
 
'Job of Staggering Proportions'
 The Bush Administration is trying to appeal to Hispanic voters across the country, but in objecting to the New York City plan, Assistant Attorney General John R. Dunne couched his concerns in legal language, citing court precedents and statutory standards.
In redistricting a multiracial city of more than seven million people, Mr. Dunne said, New Yorkers faced "a job of staggering proportions" and met their responsibilities in many parts of the city.
But he said that New York made an "inappropriate choice," to the detriment of Hispanic voters, in several parts of the city. He formally objected to three of the 51 districts proposed for the new City Council: District 34, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn; the adjoining District 37, in the Bushwick-Cypress Hills areas of Brooklyn, and District 8, which combines East Harlem with a predominantly Hispanic part of the Bronx.
 
New Enforcement Vigor
 The redistricting plan was submitted by the city in June, a tortuous decade after the filing of the lawsuit that ultimately killed New York's Board of Estimate and gave birth to the new Council. In 1989, the United States Supreme Court ruled that New York's government, with its powerful and idiosyncratic board. discriminated against minority groups by violating the constitutional principle of one person, one vote.
Under the Voting Rights Act, the city may not use its Council districting plan until it is revised and approved by either the Justice Department or the Federal District Court here.
The objections to the New York plan provide further evidence of the new vigor with which the Justice Department is enforcing the Voting Rights Act as cities, states and counties redraw election maps to take account of the 1990 census results. In the last three weeks, Mr. Dunne, who is in charge of the civil rights division of the department, has objected to redistricting plans for both houses of the state legislatures in Mississippi and Louisiana and for the Virginia House of Delegates.
Mr. Dunne said the department would work with New York City to review a revised plan as swiftly as possible, so as not to disrupt this year's election schedule.
"I don't think it should delay the election," Mr. Dunne said at a small news conference here this evening. He said the problems "could be corrected by relatively simple adjustments," and he said he was "committed to turn around in 24 hours" any revised plan submitted to the department for review.
 
Proportional Representation
 A spokeswoman for the City Districting Commission, Leah C. Johnson, said the Justice Department action "could put the election in jeopardy." But she said members of the commission "most definitely" want to see the election held on schedule.
Mr. Dinkins said he, too, was hopeful, noting that the Government had rejected only three districts. But once the commission convenes, it has the power to redraw any of the lines anywhere in the city. And the commission's decisions are likely to be marked by the same political contentiousness that characterized the entire mapmaking process.
Mr. Dunne adamantly denied that the Justice Department required proportional representation on the Council for members of minority groups. The law "insures fair election opportunities and does not require that any jurisdiction attempt to guarantee racial or ethnic proportional results," he said in a letter to Judith Reed, counsel to the Redistricting Commission, an independent agency that adopted the plan on June 3.
Mr. Dunne, a Long Island Republican who served for 24 years in the New York State Senate, said Justice Department lawyers were concerned with "choices made throughout the districting process with regard to Hispanic voters."
"The 1990 census reveals that the minority population of the city has increased dramatically, particularly the Hispanic population," he wrote. "However, it seems that in at least two areas of the city, the inappropriate choice was made to draw particular districts at the expense of Hispanic voting strength, causing the Hispanic electorate to be unfairly underrepresented on the Council."
 
'Serious Allegations'
 In northern Brooklyn, Mr. Dunne wrote, "the proposed configuration of district boundary lines appears to have been drawn in such a way as to minimze Hispanic voting strength." He said there was an "overconcentration of Hispanic population" in District 34 at the expense of Hispanic voters in District 37.
The city reported that Hispanic people accounted for 50.2 percent of the voting-age population in District 8, which includes East Harlem and a small piece of the Bronx. But Mr. Dunne said the city had failed to disprove "serious allegations" that Hispanic voters there would be unable to elect a candidate of their choice.
Under Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act, certain states with a history of discrimination must obtain approval from the Justice Department or the Federal District Court here before they may make any change, however minor, in voting laws or election procedures. This "preclearance" requirement applies to nine states and portions of seven other states, including three boroughs of New York City: Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.
Representative Jose E. Serrano, a Democratic member of Congress from the Bronx, said he was "very pleased" with the Justice Department's decision. "It is a significant victory for the principle of equitable representation in government for all of our citizens," said Mr. Serrano, who was born in Puerto Rico.
In his letter, Mr. Dunne praised the efforts of the Districting Commission.
"In many areas of the city," he said, "minority voters will now have an opportunity to participate in the political process and to elect candidates of their choice to office for the first time."
Thus, he said, "most of the districting plan satisfies the preclearance requirements of Section 5." But those words of praise have no immediate practical effect, for the plan as a whole is, as Mr. Dunne said, "legally unenforceable."
Next Monday was the deadline for candidates to file nominating petitions with the City Board of Elections. The primary is scheduled for Sept. 12, with the general election to follow on Nov. 5. Council members elected this year would serve two-year terms. Elections for regular four-year terms would be held in 1993.
 
Alter's District
 In an unusual coda to his letter, Mr. Dunne discussed a controversy involving Susan D. Alter, a Councilwoman from Brooklyn who has filed a lawsuit asserting that she was discriminated against because she is white. In the past, she has won re-election in a district dominated by members of minority groups. Under the new plan, she would have to run in a white-majority district where another incumbent, Noach Dear, has stronger white support.
Referring to Ms. Alter's situation without naming her, Mr. Dunne said it was wrong for anyone to suggest that Justice Department policy required the city to draw districts to insure that Council members would have the same race and ethnic background as a majority of the people in their districts.
Census figures show that New York, the nation's largest city, had a population of 7.3 million in 1990. There were 2.1 million blacks, accounting for 28.7 percent of the city's population, and 1.8 million Hispanic people, accounting for 24.4 percent of the city's population.
