HEADLINE: U.S. Backs Taiwan on Trade Agency

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
In a reversal likely to win votes in Congress for trade preferences for China, the Bush Administration said today that Taiwan should join the main international organization that oversees world trade.
The policy shift comes after weeks of sometimes strenuous interagency debate, and despite China's warning that such a move would be "totally unacceptable," leading to concerns among some that China would retaliate against United States imports. 
 But Harry Harding, asenior fellow and China specialist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said that China's protests might be mostly oratory, because Taiwan has applied to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade as a "customs territory" and not as a sovereign nation.
China and Taiwan have been increasingly willing to compromise on sovereignty issues in recent years and join the same institutions, Mr. Harding said. Taiwan increasingly uses the name of its capital, Taipei, in international forums. Taiwan's athletes now compete in the Olympics as representatives of "Chinese Taipei," while its bankers serve at the Asian Development Bank as officials from "Taipei, China."
 
Wooing Anti-Communist Senators
 Mr. Harding said that he knew of no evidence of a deal between Taipei and Beijing, but that the President's letter would give each capital what its leaders wanted. China would retain its access to the United States market, while Taiwan would enter the trade organization.
The Adminstration's new position was made public today in a letter from President Bush to a group of 15 senators led by Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on International Trade, who had demanded the change, along with four other, less controversial concessions in exchange for their support for an unconditional renewal. The President's letter also addressed the other four concessions in general terms.
In terms of domestic politics, the Bush letter not only represents a calculated attempt to woo anti-Communist senators who support Taiwan but it provides political cover for Democratic farm-state senators to cross party lines to support the Administration. Constitutents of those senators have been concerned that China could cut off American agricultural imports if Congress revoked China's trade status or renewed it with conditions.
Almost all the United States' trading partners, including Iraq and Libya, have most-favored-nation status, which allows imports from those countries to enter the United States at the lower of two tariff rates for each type of product. Revoking China's most-favored-nation status would increase tariffs on average about eight times for its exports to the United States.
But many members of Congress have been appalled by China's human-rights record, ballooning trade surplus with the United States and reluctance to restrict arms exports.
Reacting to the military crackdown on the democracy movement in June 1989, the House of Representatives voted last year to renew China's trade status but made future renewals conditional on human-rights improvements, but the Senate never acted on the bill.
Last week, the House voted by a narrow margin to revoke most-favored-nation status for China, and by a vote of 313 to 112 to attach conditions to any renewal.
Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine and the Senate majority leader, has introduced a bill to attach conditions to the renewal. Mr. Mitchell announced today that he had scheduled debate on the bill to begin on the Senate floor at 3 P.M. on Monday, and that a vote would be held no earlier than 7 P.M. the same day.
 
'It Is a Strong Signal'
 Reaction in the Senate to the President's letter was mixed today. Mr. Baucus praised the letter and said he would support the Administration next week, defying his party's leadership to do so.
"This is a significant breakthrough in United States policy," he said. "It is a strong signal that the U.S. will not allow China to dictate its policy toward Taiwan."
But Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico and a co-signer of Mr. Baucus's letter, said he was inclined to support Mr. Mitchell because the President's response did not go far enough in addressing his concerns about China's poor human-rights record, arms exports and trade surplus with the United States.
An Administration official who insisted on anonymity said several senators had said a change in policy toward Taiwan would be critical to their votes on China's most-favored-nation status. Republican vote-counters have estimated that for Monday's vote, they have the support of at least the 34 senators needed to sustain a veto, and might win up to a dozen more votes on any effort to override a Presidential veto.
 
Letter Called Inadequate
 Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California and the sponsor of the bill to attach conditions, said today that the President's letter was inadequate and that she would continue to push for conditions.
"The letter does not say anything except on the Taiwan issue, which is in our bill anyway," she said.
Changing the United States policy toward Taiwan will do little if anything to free students imprisoned after the military crackdown or address other human-rights violations in China, she said.
Taiwan applied to the trade organization on Jan. 1, 1990, but no action has been taken on its application as member countries have been reluctant to antagonize China. But this spring, France indicated that it might be willing to support Taiwan's application.
That alarmed trade officials in the Administration, who became concerned that France would curry favor for its companies in Taiwan's recently announced six-year, $300 billion public-works program.
China applied to the trade organization in 1986, and a working group has been set up to review its application. But membership requires a country to give equal treatment to foreign and domestic companies, and China's economy remains so centrally controlled that trade experts consider it unlikely that China will be able to join the organization in the next several years.

HEADLINE: PRETORIA ADMITS MAKING PAYMENTS TO MANDELA FOES

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, July 19

 BODY:
The South African Government admitted today for the first time that it secretly gave money to the black political organization Inkatha in its often violent rivalry with the more popular African National Congress.
The admission, following disclosures in a weekly newspaper, was one of the strongest confirmations of repeated charges leveled by the congress and others that the white-dominated Government of South Africa had been using its resources to bolster the congress's principal black opponent. President F. W. de Klerk said today that such covert aid had been cut off by his Government in March 1990. 
 Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok, after the appearance of the newspaper report, said that the Government had paid for two political rallies held by Inkatha, despite Pretoria's assertions of impartiality at the time. He was responding to a report in The Weekly Mail, the country's leading anti-apartheid newspaper, that the security police channeled nearly $100,000 to finance the Inkatha rallies on Nov. 5, 1989, and March 25, 1990.
 
Documentation for Charge
 The weekly newspaper said it had acquired a lengthy police memorandum, letters, deposit slips and bank receipts to back up its assertions that the police were using Inkatha and its leader, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, to counter the rising influence of the African National Congress.
The leaked documents constitute the first detailed evidence of assistance by the security forces to the Inkatha Freedom Party. They lend fresh credibility to numerous allegations of police bias in favor of Inkatha, whose supporters have been fighting supporters of the African National Congress and its allies. By one estimate, 10,000 people, virtually all of them black, have been killed in the political violence since 1986.
Mr. Vlok conceded that money was given to Inkatha for the rallies but denied that it came through the police, despite documents to the contrary obtained by The Weekly Mail. He said the Government had budgeted the money for a campaign to combat Western economic sanctions.
"Both overt and covert assistance was, on request, provided to a wide spectrum of persons and institutions in South Africa in an attempt to combat sanctions effectively," Mr. Vlok said. "Mass gatherings by an organization such as Inkatha would have made a significant contribution to the fight against sanctions."
Inkatha has opposed sanctions, contending that they hurt blacks by depriving them of jobs. The African National Congress supports sanctions as a weapon against the white minority Government. The United States last week lifted its package of sanctions imposed by Congress, and some other countries are following suit.
The disclosure today focused new attention on the charges by Government critics like Nico Basson, a former army major who alleged that the South African military supplied automatic rifles to Inkatha supporters for use in their fights with congress supporters.
"It is evident to us that the Government is pursuing a double agenda of talking peace while it wages war on the A.N.C. and the democratic movement," Nelson Mandela, the congress's president, said.
Speaking to journalists before flying abroad on a tour that will take him to Latin America and the Caribbean, Mr. Mandela said the police should confine themselves to maintaining law and order. He said there was no point in talking to the Government if it could not restrain the police. He said he had brought instances of police complicity in the ongoing violence to the Government's attention, but without result.
Chief Buthelezi has presented Inkatha as the moderate alternative in black politics and the disclosure dealt a severe setback to the Zulu-based organization's credibility and his own political ambitions. Tonight in a statement issued at his headquarters in Ulundi, Chief Buthelezi acknowledged that Inkatha had a bank account in Durban, as The Weekly Mail alleged, but denied knowledge of police payments.
"I knew nothing about these transactions," Chief Buthelezi said. "I was never involved in them and I had no idea whatsoever that money had been deposited in a Durban Inkatha bank account."
The Weekly Mail, in reporting the story, said that "there is no conclusive evidence that Buthelezi or members of Inkatha knew that the money deposited came directly from the security police."
But President de Klerk lent credence to the account by recalling in his own statement today that on March 1, 1990, he had ordered an investigation into secret funds and projects. Subsequently, he said, "numerous covert operations were canceled in an orderly fashion."
Mr. de Klerk said it was not the Government's policy to support any political organization directly or indirectly.
The Weekly Mail's allegations center around a 10-page memorandum written in Afrikaans by Maj. Louis Botha, a senior security police officer in the Durban region, to police headquarters in Pretoria. In the memorandum, Major Botha requested about $50,000 to finance Chief Buthelezi's rally at King's Park in Durban on March 25, 1990, "to show everyone that he has a strong base." President de Klerk legalized the African National Congress on Feb. 2, 1990, and released Mr. Mandela nine days later.
 
Payments by Police
 "It should also be accepted that Inkatha does not have the financial means to arrange such a gathering on its own," said the memorandum allegedly written by Major Botha. An unsuccessful rally, it warned, could have "far-reaching implications" for South Africa as well as Chief Buthelezi, who might end up allying Inkatha with the African National Congress.
The police actually paid about $60,000, according to the receipts. But only 10,000 people came to the Inkatha rally, a far smaller turnout than more than 100,000 who showed up to hear the newly freed Mr. Mandela at the same venue a month earlier. The Inkatha rally was followed by a vicious new outbreak of fighting between Inkatha and congress supporters in central Natal.
Another letter, allegedly written by Brig. J. A. Steyn, the deputy regional commander of the security police in Natal, said Chief Buthelezi was grateful for another payment of about $40,000 for the Inkatha rally on Nov. 5, 1989, which was addressed by the Zulu King, Goodwill Zwelethini.
"Chief Buthelezi was very emotional when a copy of the receipt was given to him," the letter said. "He could not say thank you enough and said that he had not expected it."
The security police, who focused on political rather than criminal offenses, were officially disbanded and reassigned to criminal investigation earlier this year, but suspicions remain that some are still involved in covert operations.
Anton Harber, the Weekly Mail's editor, said it obtained the documents earlier this week and that a team of reporters spent two days scrutinizing them before the article appeared. Mr. Harber declined to say where they came from but affirmed that the documents and their source were authentic.

HEADLINE: Cardinals, Throngs and Carnations Put End to Rizzo Era in Philadelphia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 19

 BODY:
They were young and old, but mostly over 50. They were black and white, but mostly white working people from ethnic neighborhoods. They were Republicans and Democrats, but nearly all were Rizzocrats, the name given to tens of thousands of Philadelphians who religiously voted for the former Mayor, Frank L. Rizzo, no matter where the Democrat-turned-Republican was on the ballot.
Yesterday and today Rizzocrats and others came to pay respects to the cop-turned-mayor who became a legend in Philadelphia politics. Mr. Rizzo, who was 70 years old, died of a heart attack on Tuesday in the midst of his fifth campaign for mayor. 
 Today, in a funeral presided over by two cardinals and worthy of a head of state, about 2,000 people crowded into the Cathedral Basilica of SS. Peter and Paul, a 145-year-old cathedral on Benjamin Franklin Parkway, Philadelphia's showcase boulevard lined with trees, fountains and museums.
About 300 mourners stood outside in the 90-degree heat in the hope of being able to get inside the Roman-Corinthian-style structure.
 
Praise From Cardinal
 Inside, mourners heard Anthony Cardinal Bevilacqua of the Philadelphia Roman Catholic Archdiocese praise the blunt, no-nonsense politician as a compassionate, caring man who, for so many people, was "God's answer to the call of the needy."
Cardinal Bevilacqua was joined by his predecessor, John Cardinal Krol, 80 years old and in frail health, who was rolled into the cathedral in a wheelchair.
Virtually all the major figures of Pennsylvania politics had assembled inside the cathedral, along with Dick Thornburgh, the United States Attorney General who is a former Pennsylvania Governor. They included Gov. Robert P. Casey, Senators Arlen Specter and Harris Wofford and Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia.
After the mass, a procession of more than 100 cars slowly moved along a nine-mile route, taking a final circle around City Hall, to the Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in Cheltenham Township, just outside the city limits. Thousands of people along the route stopped what they were doing to watch the procession and Mr. Rizzo's hearse, which was decorated with a floral display in which "Frank Forever" was written in red carnations. In the background of the display was the city's skyline, cut out of blue Styrofoam.
Mr. Rizzo, whose roller-coaster political career polarized the city, died a winner. His last triumph was an upset victory in the Republican mayoral primary in May. But he died without having to test his strength against the Democratic candidate, former District Attorney Edward G. Rendell, in the November general election. He had lost his last two attempts to recapture the mayor's office, which he held from 1972 to 1980, and the consensus among political analysts was that he would have run a very good race, but would have lost again. The Republicans now appear to be at a loss to replace him.
In his eulogy at the cathedral, the Rev. Richard J. Skelly, a longtime Rizzo ally, spoke of the mystery of death and the special confusion it sows when the deceased is someone as vibrant as Mr. Rizzo. "With the death of Frank Rizzo, that booming voice is silent," he said. "The hands that so many thousands clasped move no more."
Hundreds of police, from as far away as Chicago, sat holster-to-holster in the pews, paying respect to Mr. Rizzo, who became one of the nation's most well-known police commissioners in the racially turbulent 1960's and early 1970's.
Many national figures -- including former Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Jimmy Carter, Vice President Dan Quayle, Sylvester Stallone and Frank Sinatra -- had all inquired about the services but did not come. "I know the Nixon people were worried about the heat," said Joseph Cascerceri, Mr. Rizzo's press secretary.
On Thursday, the body of Mr. Rizzo, wearing his eyeglasses and customary pinstripe suit, was laid out in a flag-draped coffin for a public viewing. About 14,000 mourners and others queued up in a line that at its peak at 7 P.M. wound about a half-mile around the cathedral. Ten people collapsed from heat exhaustion, and the enormous bronze doors on the brownstone cathedral did not close for seven hours until the last mourner in line passed through them at about midnight.
No sooner did the doors close than a crowd of about 200 disappointed people materialized in the darkness, mostly blue-collar workers who had just got out of work. "Frank definitely wouldn't be happy about this," said a disgruntled mourner.
Why all these people came to the viewing and funeral says as much about their lives and Philadelphia as it does about Frank Rizzo and his dual reputation as both a tough police official with big heart and also as a racist.
Some came to mourn the end of a political era in which politicians like Mr. Rizzo tirelessly handed out favors to constituents and formed public policies without the aid of opinion polls. "He wasn't like a normal politician who lies through his teeth," said Denise L. DeRosa, a 37-year-old restaurant manager from South Philadelphia, where Mr. Rizzo grew up.
"He helped my cousin with muscular dystrophy get a wheelchair," said Frank D. Punzo, a financial analyst who also lives in South Philadelphia. "There had been a waiting list and everything and Frank Rizzo pushed it along. He was always there to help the normal person."
Many mourners said they came to savor for one last time the special sort of civic pride that Frank Rizzo sparked among them. "When I was a teen-ager in the late 1970's, Frank Rizzo was in control and the city was in control and you were proud to be a Philadelphian," said John A. Hosovsky, a 30-year-old restaurant manager. "Now I'm ashamed to say I'm from Philadelphia, there is so much crime and poor leadership."
 
Back When Teams Won
 Joseph A. Pizzo Jr., 31, a mechanical engineer and a distant cousin of Mr. Rizzo, agreed. "Philadelphia is a national joke now," he said. But that was not all that mattered, said Mr. Pizzo, who grew up in Philadelphia but now lives in Cherry Hill, N.J. "Frank Rizzo wasn't a technician in city finance but at least he gave the feeling that he was doing the best he could. The sports teams were winning back them, too."
Among the mourners were some blacks. They either dismissed the charges of racism against Mr. Rizzo or, more often, said they forgave. "If it was back in the 1970's, I wouldn't be in this line," said Gregg M. Ford, 40, a probation officer. "But I think he mended his ways."
Ron Dixon, who said he was honored to be one of the police officers guarding the coffin, said, "All I know is hearsay about racism and brutality."
"I loved him," said Tresa M. Brown, 39, an unemployed nurse's aide, who said Mr. Rizzo showed his concern about the black neighborhoods by providing highly visible police protection. "He was not at fault for the police brutality," she said. "He was in his office and he had no idea what some of his police officers were doing."
Frank Rizzo knew how passionately people felt about him. "I would want them to think of me as a man who tried to make this city better and their lives better," he once said, referring to his supporters. "And for my detractors, I would want put on my tombstone, "He's really dead."'

Rizzo, the former Mayor of Philadelphia, to pay their respects yesterday at his funeral. Family members followed his coffin as it left the Cathedral Basilica of SS. Peter and Paul. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
I.B.M.'s earnings plunged 91.9 percent and revenue declined by 10.7 percent in the second quarter. At the same time, however, the company raised hopes that it might be able to ride a sluggish United States economic recovery during the second half of the year, saying it saw some new strength in domestic markets. [Page 31.] 
 Moody's is lowering its ratings on six life insurers: John Hancock, Massachusetts Mutual, Mutual Life of New York, New England Mutual, the Travelers and Principal Mutual. [31.]
The owners of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station can begin dismantling it without conducting an environmental impact study, an appeals court ruled. [1.]
General Motors said it would close two North American assembly plants, one in Van Nuys, Calif., and one in Scarborough, Ontario, putting almost 6,000 people out of work. [31.]
An F.D.A. panel recommended that an AIDS drug be approved for marketing even though the Bristol-Myers Squibb product has not been thoroughly tested in clinical trials. [1.]
People have been dusting off Pan Am's obituary for a long time. But Pan Am may yet again prove that reports of its death are greatly exaggerated. [32.]
Zenith Electronics reported that it had a $26.9 million loss for the second quarter, blaming the recession and continued planned reductions in inventory for its sixth straight quarterly loss. [33.]
Southwestern Bell and Bell Atlantic reported drops and U S West had flat results. [33.]
Mobil said the I.R.S. was seeking to increase the company's payment of back taxes in a decade-old dispute over the pricing of oil from Saudi Arabia. [33.]
 
The Economy
Omaha put together an economic development program to attract telecommunications companies when other cities were concentrating on industry. Now Omaha has over 10,000 jobs in telecommunications and an unemployment rate below 3 percent. [1.]
 
International
More than a dozen of Japan's biggest industrial manufacturers -- including Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and members of the Hitachi and Toyota empires -- have been accused of industrial espionage. [31.]
The Bush Administration said that Taiwan should join the main international organization that oversees world trade. [5.]
 
Markets
Stocks turned in a mixed performance in heavy trading. The Dow ended unchanged on the day at 3,016.32 but ahead 35.55 points, or 1.2 percent, for the week. [34.] The number of Big Board shares sold short and not yet covered for the monthly period ended July 15 fell 3.1 million, or four-tenths of a percent, to 709.7 million. [44.]
Prices of Treasury securities firmed, helped in large part by signs of a slowing in the growth of the nation's money supply. [34.]
The dollar tumbled against most major currencies in light dealings that traders said were driven mostly by internal influences in the foreign exchange markets. [40.]
Prices of corn futures slipped lower again as weather forecasts continued to promise at least some rain for the parched Middle West. [40.]

With a push of a button, people can now politely deflect calls from salespeople. An insurance agent in Melville, L.I., has invented a device that activates a recorded message that explains why the call cannot be accepted. Patents. [32.]

HEADLINE: Banks in a Shadow

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The proposed alliance between Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover puts other full-service New York banks under increased pressure to improve their operations, either by finding partners or cutting expenses, or both.
 The new Chemical, which will be the second- largest American bank, after Citibank, will threaten nearly every business line of the other large New York banks. In consumer banking, Chemical's new size will give it the muscle to spend more to advertise and develop new products and the larger scale to deliver its services inexpensively. A bigger Chemical will also be able to cut prices to take market share from its rivals.
 
 Mergers May Help Profits

William T. Gregor, a consultant at the MAC Group, a Boston consulting firm, noted that because banks were suffering from sluggish loan demand and too much competition, "mergers, and the savings they produce, are perhaps the best way for a large bank to show good earnings growth." 
 In corporate finance, the improvement in Chemical Bank's financial strength and credit ratings should make it much more attractive to corporate treasurers, who prefer to deal with the strongest banks when arranging long-term foreign exchange trades, borrowings and cash management services.
Because of the estimated $650 million of annual cost savings from the Chemical merger, and the extra $1.25 billion of fresh capital it expects to raise next year, "the new Chemical Bank is well positioned to become the first New York bank to break out of the New York market in a big way and acquire large banking companies in the New England or mid-Atlantic states," said Robert B. Hedges Jr., a MAC Group vice president.
The challenges posed by the Chemical merger are different for each of the large New York banks, depending on their own condition and strategy. Least affected, analysts say, are Bankers Trust and J. P. Morgan, which do not cater to consumers, preferring to concentrate on corporate banking services.
At Citicorp, executives say they are sticking with their plans to cut costs internally and to shed non-essential businesses, like the municipal bond insurance unit that was sold last week. Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, expects the fastest growth in consumer banking to come overseas. Although Citicorp has recently improved its financial condition enough to meet next year's minimum capital standards, its stock price remains too low for it to make large acquisitions without issuing so many new shares that existing stockholders would suffer. (Citicorp shares closed at $15.125 yesterday, down 12.5 cents.) The bank also lacks the capital to make purchases in cash.
For Chase Manhattan and the Bank of New York, the merger of Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover will be a serious challenge. Chase and Bank of New York are now a distant third and fourth, respectively, in the rankings of New York consumer banks and they are bound to suffer in competition with the new Chemical for corporate business.
"Bankers like to be large, and for Chase Manhattan and Bank of New York, whose rankings in the New York market and the national lending market are eroding, the other mergers have to be causing some hard thinking," said Richard Pike, a banking specialist at Chancellor Capital Management, an investment advisory firm in New York.
James J. McDermott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm specializing in banks, said, "There are more reasons why Chase and Bank of New York would not merge with each other" than reasons why they would, "but it is clear that the other merger in town will cause them to think harder about the whole possibility."
 
 Equals Merge More Easily
 He said that one of the main problems of such a combination was that unlike Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover, which could merge essentially as equals, Bank of New York is less than half the size of Chase.
If Chase and Bank of New York do decide to grow through acquisitions outside New York, there will be plenty of cost-savings opportunities.
Out-of-region bank mergers do not save as much in costs as local mergers, but analysts say they could still produce significant savings. Mr. Hedges of the MAC Group estimated that savings from trimming executive staffs and combining computer systems equal between 10 and 20 percent of the acquired bank's non-interest expenses.
As a rule, banking analysts say the greatest cost savings are realized from mergers within a single market. Certainly the Bank of New York's ability to reduce expenses by $150 million in 1990, after the 1988 merger with Irving Bank, was one reason Wall Street took seriously the $650 million in savings projected from the Chemical merger.
 
 Chase Studies Its Options
 Michael Esposito, chief financial officer of Chase, said on Tuesday that the company was studying its strategic options. Besides mergers, those options include joint ventures with non-bank companies in any of Chase's main lines of business. Frasier Seitell, a Chase spokesman, added that as the company's earnings improved, "one of our options is to remain as we are and continue to strengthen ourselves from within."
Allen R. DeCotiis, president of PSI, a Tampa, Fla., research and consulting firm, said, "Chase has to decide whether it wants to compete for the main mass of the consumer business or to concentrate on certain products and niches where it is very strong and very profitable, such as credit cards or private banking services to the affluent consumers." Mr. DeCotiis noted that Chase was more successful than its rivals in reaching wealthy customers, through its emphasis on large mortgages, luxury car loans and investment advice.
 
 Merger Talk Lifts Stocks
 Wall Street's conviction that mergers are good for banks caused a widespread rise in bank stocks across the country after the Chemical deal was announced. With the additional help of stronger than expected earnings in the second quarter, Chase Manhattan shares rose $1.875 each, to $19.875, on the day of the announcement, and have since advanced to close at $20.125 yesterday. The Bank of New York closed yesterday at $30.75 a share, up from $29.375 on July 12, before the Chemical announcement.
J. Carter Bacot, chairman of the Bank of New York, said before the Chemical merger that his plans might not include another deal like the Irving merger, despite the benefits. Loan troubles caused the Bank of New York to cut its dividend by 28 percent earlier this year, and generated a $2.7 million loss for the first half, compared with a profit of $172.7 million in the first half of 1990.
The lending problems were compounded after the Irving merger, Mr. Bacot said, because the Bank of New York took advantage of its larger size to make larger loans and to be more competitive with much bigger banks.
But despite the problems, Mr. Bacot said he had not lost his desire to grow. Expansion into Connecticut and New Jersey would be nice, he says, but the economic downturn in the Northeast has made him more mindful of the advantages of diversifying the bank's business.
"A large bank will be more stable if its middle-market corporate business and consumer banking are not limited to a single market," Mr. Bacot said.

HEADLINE: 6 Insurers Have Cut In Ratings

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service, a leading Wall Street rating agency, said yesterday that it was lowering its ratings of six of the country's largest life insurers: John Hancock, Massachusetts Mutual, Mutual Life of New York, New England Mutual, the Travelers and Principal Mutual.
What links the insurers downgraded yesterday is that they all have large exposures to commercial real estate, either to the actual properties or to mortgages backed by those properties. Moody's declared that real estate was a "deteriorating" asset and that it expected property values to continue to fall.
 
 Adjustments Were Small

The changes in Moody's ratings, which are the firm's assessment of the insurers' ability to pay the claims of policyholders, were very small. The insurers downgraded yesterday ranked high in Moody's 17-notch rating system, and they fell only a notch or two. But the move could have a big effect on all six companies because many policyholders, as well as brokers and agents, want to do business only with insurers rated at the top, or just a notch below. 
 Aware that its changes come amid extreme policyholder edginess about the health of all insurers, Moody's emphasized that the great majority of insurers, including those downgraded yesterday, remained strong.
But the agency said that property values, particularly of commercial buildings, had continued to fall in the first half of 1991 and that it thus had no choice but to conclude that the insurers' ability to pay policyholders had eroded. Moody's said additional downgradings could be expected if its prediction of further real estate declines proved true.
 
 'We Have to Do It'

"We don't want people to think that the end of the world is coming, because we definitely do not believe that," said Kenneth J. H. Pinkes, director of financial institutions research at Moody's. "And while it is difficult to make rating changes in situations like this, we have to do it because the risks have increased. Our sense is that real estate is deteriorating and will continue to deteriorate."
Industry experts say the number of people expressing concern about insurance companies has increased in the wake of state takeovers this year of Executive Life, First Capital Life, Monarch Life, and most recently Mutual Benefit Life Insurance.
Thus, these industry experts say, the downgrading will likely present a serious public-relations challenge for the affected companies. They were already receiving calls from policyholders, agents and brokers made nervous by the takeover this week of Mutual Benefit, based in Newark.
No sooner had Moody's made its announcement than the six companies began contacting agents and brokers, instructing them on how to keep policyholders calm. David Hurd, chairman and chief executive of the Principal Mutual Life Insurance Company, said the Moody's action "does not give enough weight to our different approach, our foreign record, our excellent current status and our carefully projected expectations for real estate."
At Massachusetts Mutual, Eustis Walcott, a spokesman, called Moody's move "a reaction to the times." He added that the downgrading was undeserved but that in any case the company had more than $6 billion in investments that it could easily convert to cash.
New England Mutual Life Insurance seemed to take the downgrading in stride, emphasizing that Moody's still left it with what it called an acceptable rating. "In a a poor economy, we are happy to be awarded a rating that says we have excellent financial strength," said Peter N. Harrington, vice president of public relations. He said New England Life still expected a profit of $25 million to $30 million this year.
Experts said the volume of calls from customers is likely to increase when the companies open for business on Monday. A small amount of capital could flow out of the affected companies to insurers whose claims-paying rating remains Aaa.
"You will get a few panic-stricken customers who will react," acknowledged Mr. Hurd of Principal Mutual, That company, formerly known as Bankers Life, is the nation's 11th-largest life insurer.
Principal Mutual's real estate portfolio is in extremely good shape; in dollar terms, less than 2 percent of its loans have gone bad. But that is not true at companies like the Travelers. Its $2.5 billion in troubled mortgages now exceeds its net worth, or its cushion against losses. The situation is only slightly better at companies like the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, for which troubled real estate now amounts to 50 percent of its net worth.
Moody's concern, in short, is that real estate values will continue to decline. While the companies will continue to earn profits from insurance, those profits have been shrinking because of competition. So one risk is that the impact of declining real estate values on the insurers' net worth will swamp positive developments, further diminishing the insurers' ability to pay claims.
 
 Details of Changes
 The following ratings changes, none of which were to less than investment grade, were made by Moody's late yesterday:
*John Hancock from Aaa (exceptional) to Aa2 (the middle of the excellent category).
*Massachusetts Mutual from Aaa (exceptional) to Aa1 (the top of the excellent category).
*Mutual Life of New York from A2 (good) to Baa1 (the top of the adequate category).
*New England Mutual from Aa1 (the top of the excellent category) to Aa3 (the bottom of excellent).
*Principal Mutual Life from Aaa (exceptional) to Aa1 (top of the excellent category).
*Travelers from A1 (the top of the good category) to A2 (the middle of the good category).
The Moody's downgrading poses an immediate question for the other leading insurance ratings, A. M. Best and Standard & Poor's, which will now have to decide whether to follow Moody's lead and lower their ratings. If they do not, it could cause confusion among consumers, since it is common to rely on at least two ratings agencies in choosing an insurance carrier.

HEADLINE: Foley Calls for Extension of Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
Speaker Thomas S. Foley pushed today for Congressional action to extend unemployment benefits, saying he wanted the House Ways and Means Committee to address the problem.
His statement came three days after a proposal by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, to declare an emergency, as provided by last year's budget law, and to lengthen the benefit period, relying on the $8 billion Federal unemployment trust fund. The benefits now exceed 26 weeks in Alaska, Maine, Rhode Island and Puerto Rico. 
 With leading Democrats in the House and the Senate now moving to extend benefits, Congressional action could come in September. Mr. Foley, Mr. Bentsen and others have argued that even if the recession was coming to an end, unemployment was still at 7 percent in June and would remain high for several more months.
They say that the Government should move against a domestic disaster like unemployment under budget emergency provisions, just as it helped distressed people overseas like the Kurds and Bangladeshis.
 
Selective on Emergencies?
 At a breakfast meeting with reporters, Mr. Foley commented that to President Bush, "everything outside the country is an emergency." But when it comes to the "problems of American workers," he said, "those are never emergencies."
The Speaker, a Democrat from Washington, said he would prefer an approach like that of Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island. Mr. Downey's measure would change the unemployment compensation system, making it harder for states to deny benefits to unemployed workers, and paying for those changes with higher taxes on employers.
But if there were not enough votes to support a plan including a tax increase, he said, he would support an approach like Senator Bentsen's, under which benefits could be provided for a year without raising taxes.
Mr. Foley's remarks were apparently directed at Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. The remarks were seen as a mild prod to act on the issue. The two leaders had discussed the matter earlier this week.
Mr. Downey introduced his proposal in March. Mr. Rostenkowski has been unwilling to bring it up in committee without being sure that he has the votes to pass it. Nor has it been clear that there was sufficient support for the measure in the full House even if he could get it out of committee.
Some Democrats have contended that this issue is important enough as a symbol of the party's commitment to disadvantaged workers that it should be pressed, even if it faces defeat. But Mr. Rostenkowski is known for keeping bills off the floor until he is sure they can pass.
In an interview today, Mr. Downey conceded there was not enough support in the panel or in the full House to enact his initial proposal because it included a tax increase.
He said a vote by the committee for an approach like Mr. Bentsen's was likely before the end of this month. Such a short-term approach was the only one with a chance of passage, he said, "given the fact that no one wants to pay for this, in either chamber."
 
A Problem Demanding Urgency
 Mr. Bentsen also deplored the lack of willingness to raise taxes for unemployment benefits. "I'd rather do pay-as-you-go and do permanent reform," he said in a telephone interview. "But it will take time to do that, and we need to deal with the suffering now."
Mr. Bentsen said he was not sure when he would seek action from the Finance Committee, but he conceded, "it will be damn tough to get it done."
Under current law, unemployment benefits for as many as 26 weeks are paid through state taxes on employers. Extended benefits, for an additional 13 weeks, can be paid through a program financed equally by Federal and state unemployment taxes.
A state becomes eligible for that program when at least 5 percent of its workers covered by unemployment insurance apply for benefits, and the rate of unemployed insured workers exceeds the average of the last two years by at least one-fifth. If the rate is at least 6 percent, a state can choose to pay extended benefits without regard to the last two years.
Mr. Bentsen's proposal would finance extended benefits entirely from the Federal trust fund. The fund includes $8 billion and is growing despite the recession because few states are now eligible to use it.
His program would be in effect until June 30, 1992.
The program would offer four levels of extended benefits.
If the jobless rate was 8 percent or higher, an additional 20 weeks could be provided. If a state's unemployment rate was 7 percent, it could provide 13 weeks of benefits. If the rate was 6 percent, it could provide seven weeks of extended benefits.
All other states would be allowed to provide four more weeks of benefits.

HEADLINE: U.S. Appeals Court Clears Way To Dismantle Shoreham A-Plant

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Rejecting a last-ditch effort by the Bush Administration to keep the $5.5 billion Shoreham Nuclear Power Station alive, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the plant's owner could begin dismantling it without conducting an environmental impact study.
The decision, by the United States Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia circuit, grants Shoreham's owner a new license that allows it to begin taking apart the fully operational, 809-megawatt plant. The owner, the Long Island Lighting Company, said that it would quickly move forward to decommission the plant, making the chance that it will ever operate as a nuclear plant decidedly remote. 
 The decision is a major blow to the Department of Energy, which has portrayed Shoreham's operation as an important symbol of its commitment to nuclear energy. Earlier this month, the Justice Department, acting for the Energy Department, argued that the environmental consequences of other power sources, like fossil fuels, should be studied before the plant was abandoned.
 
No Environmental Study Needed
 Yesterday's ruling rejected that argument and let stand a decision by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission saying that no environmental study was needed before the new license, known as a "possession only" license, could be granted. The new license took effect at 12:01 this morning.
The plant's supporters said they would continue fighting the nuclear commission's decision and appealed yesterday evening to the United States Supreme Court for an emergency stay.
But with the new license in effect, Shoreham is be on an almost irrevocable path to destruction, officials say. Trying to run it now would take two to three years and cost $300 million, they say, and the time and cost will multiply once the process of dismantling begins.
Richard M. Kessel, chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, the state agency formed to take over and take apart the plant, said decommissioning could begin as early as October and would take about two years and cost about $186 million.
Joanne Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Energy Department, said she would have no comment on yesterday's ruling. In January, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins called the decision not to operate the plant "tragic" and warned that it would have "adverse consequences on energy security and reliability, the environment, the ratepayers of Long Island and the New York State economy."
But New York State, which is waiting for approval from the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission to take over and dismantle Shoreham, applauded the ruling and said it was a warning to the Federal Government not to meddle in local decisions about nuclear energy.
"I would hope that the Bush Administration would now cease its efforts to try and delay the decommissioning of Shoreham," said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in a prepared statement.
In 1989, after intense pressure from Mr. Cuomo and officials in Suffolk County, who argued that Long Island could not be safely evacuated in the event of a nuclear disaster, the lighting company agreed to turn the plant over to the state for $1 in return for 10 years of rate increases.
Conceived in 1966, completed in 1984, and granted a full-power operating license in 1989, the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station was originally billed as an answer to Long Island's energy problems. The plant, able to provide 809 megawatts of power, or enough electricity for about one-third of the Island's 903,000 homes, was seen by proponents of nuclear power as a clean and safe alternative to the messy, aging fossil fuel plants on the Island.
 
Never Allowed to Operate
 Though the plant, on a rural road in a remote village on the north shore of Suffolk County, performed successfully in low-power tests in 1985 and 1987, it was never allowed to operate. Originally budgeted at $269 million, it ended up costing $5.5 billion.
In June 1989, after years of bitter debates and court battles on both sides, Lilco signed its agreement with New York State, which vowed to take over and then take apart the plant.
But transferring and dismantling a power plant is hardly simple. Every modification, from the most trivial to the most-far reaching, has to be reviewed by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
As a result, though the nuclear fuel has been removed from the reactor and is being stored in a spent-fuel pool inside the plant, Shoreham has been sitting in a more-or-less pristine condition for the last two years.
 
2 Groups Fight for Plant
 Meanwhile, a case for Shoreham was made in the courts and before the nuclear commission by the plant's supporters, most particularly the Shoreham-Wading River Central School District, which depends on the taxes the plant generates, and a group called Scientists and Engineers for Secure Energy, Inc.
Last month, when the nuclear commission said that it planned to grant a possession-only license to Lilco, the two groups asked the United States Court of Appeals to stay that decision. The Department of Defense, represented by the Department of Justice, joined in that request, and it was that motion that was rejected yesterday. The school district and the scientists' group made the final appeal to the Supreme Court last night.
Under its full-power license, Lilco was required to maintain Shoreham almost as if it were an operating plant. Many employees had to spend as much as one in six working shifts in training sessions and many of the operating systems had to be kept up.
Joseph W. McDonnell, a Lilco spokesman, said Shoreham's cost under the full-power license was $400,000 a day, with about half going to taxes and half to maintain the plant. Under the new license, he said, Lilco will immediately begin saving $48,000 a day.
 
Lilco Can Shift 100 Workers
 The new license relieves Lilco of many of its previous requirements. Mr. McDonnell said it would enable the lighting company to shift 100 Shoreham workers to new jobs, either in helping to decommission the plant or in other parts of the company. It will also allow Lilco to vacate many parts of the plant it had been required to maintain, though it will still follow strict safety requirements for the spent fuel and the contaminated areas. Those will be dismantled and disposed of when decommissioning begins.
Now that it has agreed to the possession-only license, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is free to consider the next two issues before it: Lilco's request to transfer Shoreham to the Long Island Power Authority, a state agency, for $1, and the power authority's request to decommission it.
It is unclear what will happen to Shoreham then. A business group on Long Island has proposed using the property as a terminal for a new ferry across Long Island Sound. The Long Island Power Authority has said it would be feasible to convert the plant to a 413-megawatt natural gas-fired plant, but that would require a developer with $215 million.

HEADLINE: French Protest New Taxes on Art

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 19

 BODY:
Having long cossetted the world of culture with subsidies and privileges, the Socialist Government of France has suddenly become the target of furious protests from art dealers and painters over an increase in the sales taxes on art and antiques.
With auction houses and art galleries already feeling the squeeze of economic recession, the dealers have charged that the new taxes will further discourage sales and dash any hopes that Paris may have of joining London and New York as a major international art market. 
 "It comes at a very bad moment," said Yo-Yo Maeght of the prominent Galerie Maeght. "Paris was just in the process of becoming an art capital again. And it's a great pity it is being done by a Socialist Government, because it's contrary to what it has done for culture so far."
Applying pressure on the Government to reverse itself, France's largest auction house, Drouot, has threatened to take some of its business abroad. More than 100 art galleries also held a one-day protest strike on July 2 amid warnings that some may be bankrupted by the new rules.
"It's going to be catastrophic for painters," said Martin Guesnet of the Galerie Beaubourg in Paris. "It's trying to turn painters into accountants. Can you imagine van Gogh or Picasso trying to work out the sales tax on their works?"
 
The Value Added Tax
 But the Government is showing no signs of budging. Clearly embarrassed by the row, the Culture Minister, Jack Lang, has chosen to remain silent. But a statement from the Economy Ministry said that "it is not abnormal to seek an effort of solidarity" from buyers of highly priced works of art.
The law incorporating these measures was approved by Parliament on July 4 and is expected to go into effect on July 29, although some of the new taxes will not be levied until October 1992. Ever hopeful, a spokesman for Drouot said negotiations with the Government were continuing.
The new rules relate mainly to a Value Added Tax, or V.A.T., which is the principal form of indirect taxation used in the 12-nation European Community. A minimum 15 percent V.A.T. rate will go into effect throughout the region when it becomes a single trading market on Jan. 1, 1993.
The proposed regulations exclude private sales of paintings but for the first time will require painters as well as writers to add a 5.5 percent sales tax to the price of their works. To shield young and struggling artists, though, the first $40,000 of income each year will be exempted.
"It's all immensely complicated," Ms. Maeght said. "Painters are going to have to declare their V.A.T. every month. It means that every time they buy a brush or paint, they must keep the receipt. This law was voted without having been thought through properly."
 
New Rate Is 18.6 Percent
 Until now, the V.A.T. rate for galleries has been 5.5 percent, while auction houses paid only a 2 percent registration fee. But both will now be required to charge 18.6 percent V.A.T. on sales. Art sent abroad for sale will not be taxed here, but French citizens buying imported art will also pay the 18.6 percent V.A.T.
Complaining about "inexact presentation" of its plans, the Economy Ministry's statement insisted that "the new V.A.T. rules will not penalize France on the international market, nor will it turn foreigners away from the French market, nor will it encourage the French to buy abroad."
But a spokesman for Druout responded, "That is false, absolutely false." With revenues down by 35 percent so far this year, Druout's president, Joel Millon, has already said the auction house will carry out its major sales abroad, either in New York or Geneva, if the new law goes into effect.
In an interview with Liberation, Mr. Millon even raised the possibility that Drouot's main Paris auction house on the Avenue Montaigne might eventually be forced to close. "If in 10 years all the major sales are taking place outside France, this could happen," he said.
 
Politicians Join Outcry
 One auctioneer, Jacques Tajan, said the new rules could bring a 20 percent decline in business. Another, Guy Loudmer, said they would scare away foreigners seeking to sell valuable paintings in France. "This will penalize France's chances of enriching its national heritage," he said.
Art galleries, in contrast, argue that they will suffer because the new law will stimulate untaxed direct deals. "Big-name artists will use foreign agents," one gallery operator explained, "and other painters will sell to clients who come to their studios. Only the black market will grow."
The tax dispute has even prompted the conservative opposition leader, Jacques Chirac, to join the fray by charging that the tax on "works of the spirit" will damage French creativity. "There is something very shocking about these hasty decisions that aim only to swell the state's coffers," he said.
Piqued by his criticism, the Economy Ministry recalled that when Mr. Chirac was Prime Minister from 1986 to 1988, he cut the Culture Ministry's budget, which this year will exceed $2 billion. "In matters of culture, he is not well placed to give us lessons," the ministry statement added.

HEADLINE: Sports Leisure;
Road Racing Finds Bumps Along the Way

BYLINE: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE

 BODY:
Real estate prices in Fairfield County, Conn., may have retreated, but not the costs of running road races. Entry fees have climbed here -- as they have in other communities in the metropolitan area -- from $7 and $10 a decade ago to $12 and $14. Race organizers in the county say entry costs have increased because expenses have gone up, the number of sponsors has gone down and runners are more demanding.
The number of informal, grass-roots races has diminished and, while no one counts, the perception is that the number of runners has stayed about the same compared with five years ago. These kinds of road-running events are found in every corner of the United States, three- and five-mile distances being most common, with an occasional 10-kilometer for variety. 
 About 100 such races are run in Fairfield County each year, and Jim Gerweck, who puts on 15 of them, sees a drop-off. "There was a shake-out two and three years ago," he said. "The clubs that know what they're doing stuck around, and they make a buck. Other races dried up."
Are road races supposed to be profitable? Is the traditional giveaway T-shirt necessary? Are the runners really demanding yogurt, salads and juices as free post-race goodies? These are some of the questions being asked by runners and organizers alike.
"Who needs another T-shirt?" asked Augie Diamantini, a veteran road racer from Brookfield who favors Spartan events and lower entry fees.
 
In Praise of Amenities
 Diamantini helps run Brookfield's James O'Brien Memorial race, a Lions Club benefit on New Year's Day. Even with the obligatory T-shirt this event has managed to hold to a $7 entry fee, as has the Ridgefield 5-K, held in June.
"I boycott most races with $10 and $12 entry fees," said John Dugdale, a prominent masters marathoner from Ridgefield, who helps organize that race. "But I make exceptions for big races that provide a lot of amenities."
Those amenities are meaningful, said John Bysiewicz, who runs Connecticut's largest race, the New Haven Labor Day event that draws 3,000 competitors. "The trend is toward bigger races that attract more attention," he said. "And people have come to expect the extras."
David Singer, a race organizer who is the director of Mohonk House in Westport, a housing and support program for troubled teen-agers, was skeptical that no-frills races with low entry fees would succeed. "There is a core out there, maybe 10 percent, that absolutely insists on T-shirts," he said.
 
'Happy to Break Even'
 If there were no T-shirts, race sponsors would lose their best billboards, said Mickey Yardis, who runs several events in behalf of Threads and Treads, a Greenwich sportswear store. And sponsors, providing cash or products, have become precious in tougher economic times.
"We have 600 runners, 500 preregistered for a $10 fee. The others pay $15," said Yardis of the popular five-mile Point Perspective races overlooking Long Island Sound at Greenwich Point. "We make sure everyone gets a T-shirt, ones that cost us $5 to $6. Ten years ago they were $2.25. We're happy to break even and regard the event as a promotion for the store."
He said that Threads and Treads makes money on its biathlon and triathlon races, which have entry fees of $25 to $30 and $30 to $50.
Jeff Palmer of the Pequot Runners in Southport said, "We don't want to make a profit." That group's Thanksgiving Day five-miler is one of the county's most popular races; last year it drew 1,763 runners who paid $18,000 in entry fees.
But with cash also coming from a primary sponsor, Runners Roost, and donated food, the race makes money -- Palmer would not say how much. Substantial contributions from the proceeds go to the Wakeman Boys and Girls Club, which serves as race headquarters, and to Mohonk House.
Mohonk House also runs its own races, a five-kilometer and 10-kilometer, on Father's Day. This year, with the weather hot and the field smaller than usual, the income from entries was $4,020; the costs came to $3,820.
"It's an inefficient, rotten fund-raiser," said Singer, Mohonk's director. "But our kids like to help organize and run it, we make a lot of friends and I love running."
Gerweck agrees that the smaller road races seldom make good fund-raisers.
The Minute Man Five-Miler, held by the Westport Young Woman's League in April, is an exception. This year it had 54 sponsors who contributed money, services or goods in kind. A field of 1,285 runners paid entry fees of $6 to $14 for a total of $11,653. Expenses came to $10,235. But sponsors added $10,789, so the profit was $12,206, according to Eileen Peterson, the chairwoman. The money went to the benefit of organizations such as Mohonk House, the Police Athletic League and Westport Senior Center.
But runners apparently don't care to know where their money goes. None of the organizers could recall ever being asked for a profit-and-loss statement or even an expense breakdown.
"They care about the course and the amenities," said Bysiewicz. "And that's about it."
