HEADLINE: Rockefeller's Assets

BYLINE: BY ROBIN TONER; Robin Toner is national political correspondent of The New York Times. Her profile of Senator Bob Kerrey appeared in this magazine in April.

 BODY:
IN THE BLOOD SPORT OF POLITICAL TALK shows, John McLaughlin's "One on One" can be one of the bloodiest, but Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th was holding his own. McLaughlin was pummeling Rockefeller on his health-care proposals, raising the prospect of another big-spending Democratic program driving under a nation of virtuous small businesses. Rockefeller was countering with a barrage of eye-glazing detail on cost shifting, first-dollar coverage and the per capita cost of health care in Canada.
The West Virginia Democrat had that special glow of a fledgling Presidential contender, that adrenaline rush of "Hey, I can do this," skimming along from health care to civil rights legislation to indexing capital gains. He was dropping in a cocky "Well, John" here and a chummy "No, John" there. His press secretary, watching from the control booth, began to uncoil and settle back in her chair just a little. Then McLaughlin turned the questioning to money. And Rockefeller's smile, that well-bred but earnest smile forged in a lifetime of campaign picnics and town meetings, that smile that says, "Yes, I'm a Rockefeller, but I understand," suddenly got very tight. 
 McLaughlin opened the subject by repeating a joke Rockefeller tells on himself as he makes the rounds of Democratic meetings these days: "The good news is I have 100 percent name identification in Iowa. The bad news is one-third of the people think I'm the banker who foreclosed on their farm, one-third think I run the oil company that raised the price of gasoline and one-third think I'm the guy who sold Manhattan to the Japanese."
Rockefeller said evenly: "This is a good joke, but it's my joke, John. Remember that."
McLaughlin was in full cry: "And you are one of the Rockefellers, and I read recently that you live in a house that's worth $15.3 million after the remodeling you put on it, and it's got 11 bathrooms on the first floor."
The guys in the control room were perking up. "Eleven bathrooms?"
Rockefeller ducked the bathroom question, but McLaughlin kept pushing.
"Are you the wealthiest man in the Senate?"
"I don't know, John. I'm not poor, O.K.?"
The show cut for a commercial, and McLaughlin throttled back, leaned over and said, man to man: "I did you a favor. You get this stuff out, you're better off." Rockefeller looked unconvinced and faintly peeved. He wanted to talk about the Presidency, about important public-policy issues, about the failings of the Bush Administration. But in the end, of course, it always comes down to questions like this: How many bathrooms does a Rockefeller have? This is the price of dynasty in a democracy.
JOHN DAVISON ROCKEFELLER 4TH, A.K.A. JAY, THE eldest son of the eldest son of the eldest son of the founder of Standard Oil, is doing what the pundits have predicted he would do ever since he entered politics in the 1960's: testing the waters for a Presidential campaign. He has two hot issues: health-care reform and the state of the nation's children. He has a solid base in West Virginia, where he was re-elected to a second Senate term last fall. He has a respectable record in the Senate, on top of eight years (1977-1984) as Governor.
His party, panicky over the lack of Presidential contenders, is pathetically grateful for any major politician who looks interested in the nomination. In all, it is a ripe moment for a man with the name, the numeral, the legacy and the money.
Like Kennedy, it is one of the few names in America with the power to shape a life. When he came of age in the 60's, when his uncle Nelson was Governor of New York and his uncle Winthrop was Governor of Arkansas and his uncle David was head of the Chase Manhattan Bank, many of his generation in the family "were in kind of full retreat from the name Rockefeller," the Senator recalls. Not him.
If he ever had any doubts, any guilt, any shrinking from 100 years of power and privilege, monopoly and philanthropy, he does not acknowledge them. His parents named him John Rockefeller and raised him with the nonthreatening, one-of-the-guys nickname Jay; at the age of 21, while studying in Japan, he wrote to his grandfather and asked the stern old patriarch's permission to use the full name and numeral.
"I wanted that name very much," he says. "I thought it represented certain levels of public service, integrity, the sense of you've got to go at it, you know, that there's no such thing as leisure."
In politics, the name means instant, often remarkably premature, credibility: the last profile of Jay Rockefeller in The New York Times Magazine declared, "If money, looks, brains, a fashionable social conscience and a lovely wife are still the making of a President, it could be a significant story of the 70's and 80's." It was 1970, and Rockefeller was the 33-year-old Secretary of State of West Virginia. The name also means unusual opportunities, like the time in 1968 that Uncle Nelson offered him a vacant United States Senate seat from New York.
But Jay Rockefeller did not move as fast as the pundits expected. The Kennedys followed an extraordinary arc -- soaring, crashing, burning, washing ashore in the tabloids. Rockefeller plodded along, step by step, struggling with setbacks. His second term as Governor coincided with a wrenching recession. He barely won his 1984 Senate race against a political novice, even while outspending him 12 to 1. Rockefeller then spent his first term in the Senate in careful, penitential devotion to West Virginia concerns, with almost no profile in national politics. Some of his friends said they had concluded he had given up the dreams of his youth. Then, a couple of years ago, he began edging toward the limelight, speaking out on some of the nation's most pressing domestic needs. In May, he suddenly declared, "The door is open," and he was looking hard at a Presidential campaign.
He can seem, at times, a strangely unconflicted man -- relentlessly earnest, doggedly putting one foot ahead of another, blithely comfortable with his vast wealth even as he champions the poor, able to live in a sprawling mansion in Washington and yet assail "the obscene contrasts" of wealth and poverty in the nation's capital. "He is who he is, he's accepted that for a long time," says his wife, Sharon Percy Rockefeller. "He's not metaphysically tied up in knots." His poll taker, Geoffrey Garin, describes the Senator, his wife and their four children as "the Cleavers with a lot of money."
Yet there are deeper currents here: Of all his generation of Rockefellers, usually referred to as "The Cousins," he may be the only one who reaches for the kind of power and prominence attained by his uncles, his grandfather and his great-grandfather. He has not only accepted the name, he has used the money with a vengeance. He spent close to $12 million in his 1980 gubernatorial campaign alone, enough to buy every man, woman and child in West Virginia a $6 dinner.
His critics assert that he has simply bought a political career, the way other rich men buy estates or islands. They say he has scant ideology beyond a vague intention to do good and little sense of how most Americans live their lives. They say his motivation, at root, springs from an overweening sense of entitlement. They say he is not ready, may never be ready, for the big leagues. "His strengths?" says David B. McKinley, chairman of the West Virginia Republican Party. "His name is Jay Rockefeller. That really is his greatest strength."
If he runs in 1992, and leaves the small pond of West Virginia politics, he will be measured against great expectations. And he will face the question that haunts any scion, but perhaps especially a Rockefeller, the question that has run throughout his political career in West Virginia, but will be writ large in the unforgiving arena of a Presidential campaign: Would he be here without the name and the money?
IT WAS NOT HEAVY LIFTING, AS FAR AS political events go -- a gathering of senior citizens in Parkersburg, W.Va. But Rockefeller was paying careful, almost slavish, tribute to his constituents. "I do not forget ever who put me in the Senate," he said. It is the mark of a man who spent much of his political career defending himself against the charge of carpetbagging.
It always was an unlikely match, Rockefeller and West Virginia, from the moment he arrived in 1964 as a 27-year-old Vista worker. The people of the state are often described as "poor but proud," but the cliche does little justice to a state that seems a microcosm of the roughest economic history. In much of West Virginia, for much of this century, the coal mines were the best source of employment for those who loved the land and wanted to stay. But the industry could exact a harsh price: more than 20,000 have died in West Virginia mining accidents this century. And the industry's grim cycle of boom and bust forced waves of out-migration over the years.
Into this setting came young Jay Rockefeller, who grew up in Manhattan and Westchester County, who prepped at Exeter, studied in Japan, graduated from Harvard. His father, John D. 3d, was a philanthropist who was instrumental in creating Lincoln Center; after his death in 1978, one estimate placed his lifetime giving, before bequests, at $94 million.
Jay Rockefeller, his only son, was on track for a career in international affairs. But he came to West Virginia, he says, because "I didn't know a darned thing about my country." In the argot of the times, and in the full glow of Kennedy fever, he wanted to "make a difference."
He moved quickly into politics, running for the West Virginia House of Delegates in 1966 -- as a Democrat. He went to New York to break this news to his uncle Nelson, a rather prominent Republican at the time as Governor and past contender for the Republican Presidential nomination. "He was very busy, so I had about five minutes in a long black limousine," Rockefeller recalls. "I cannot say it to you definitively but I will suggest, I think, that there was not only approval from him but a sense of wistfulness."
In 1968, after the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy, Governor Rockefeller offered his nephew a short cut to the Senate. "I got a call from Uncle Nelson offering me Bobby Kennedy's seat," he says. "And I said no, immediately.
"He didn't put a party restriction on it," Rockefeller says. "But I said no. I said, 'I don't think that's good for you, and I'm here, and I'm going to stay here.' "
By 1972, Jay Rockefeller was running for Governor against the incumbent, Arch Moore, a wily and pugnacious Republican who delighted in tweaking the rich young aristocrat. One of Moore's television spots that year became a classic, featuring man-on-the-street interviews in which New Yorkers were asked how they would feel about a West Virginian as their Governor: "That makes as much sense to me as having the next Governor of West Virginia be a New Yorker," said one woman. Rockefeller tried to cast himself as a reformer, most dramatically by advocating the abolition of strip mining, which put him in direct opposition to the state's powerful coal interests. It was a rough campaign, and he took hits from many sides, but the message was simple: He is not one of us. At one point, signs appeared that said simply, "Remember Ludlow," referring to the 1914 massacre of striking miners, women and children by state militiamen at a Colorado coal company controlled by the Rockefellers.
He lost, badly. Today, he tries to cast it as a growth experience. "You know, people lose constantly in life, every day they lose," he says. "Rockefellers usually don't lose."
CONFOUNDING predictions that he would leave the state, Rockefeller took a job as president of a small college, West Virginia Wesleyan, and came back to win the governorship in 1976. There was a difference: this time, he was no longer a strip-mine abolitionist. Rockefeller says that, thanks in part to his efforts, reclamation laws and practices had changed enough to make strip mining acceptable. Indeed, state and Federal environmental regulations did tighten in the 70's. But Rockefeller's critics have always seen his strip-mining flip as proof of breathtaking expediency.
Rockefeller's eight years as Governor began with high hopes -- the seemingly promising coal market, the prospect of a major Federal effort to produce synthetic fuels from coal, the chance, finally, for some economic stability. Rockefeller stoked those expectations by touting his clout with the Carter Administration and in the board rooms of major corporations around the country. But he ended up struggling with a national recession that struck West Virginia with harrowing force. Unemployment, by his second term, shot up to 21 percent in his state, highest in the nation, and his administration became a grim round of budget cuts. Rockefeller will have no West Virginia miracle to trumpet if he seeks the Presidency.
Any assessment of Rockefeller's governorship must be tempered by the times. David J. Greenfield, editor of The Charleston (W.Va.) Daily Mail, says: "In retrospect, I thought he was an acceptable governor. He got good people in his administration. His honesty was unquestioned. His intentions were beyond reproach."
Don Marsh, editor of the more editorially liberal Charleston Gazette and a longtime friend of Rockefeller's, says: "Jay did not impress a lot of people as a dynamic decision maker. He was scandal-free and a solid performer who had an average or better-than-average set of officials."
Around West Virginia political circles, the line on Rockefeller was "too rich to steal." There was a serious point to this joke in a state regularly buffeted by corruption; the former Governor Arch Moore, for example, is currently in Federal prison for extortion. But Jay Rockefeller faced another character issue -- how he spent his own money. John R. Raese, who ran against Rockefeller in 1984, asserts, "He bought the Governor's office in 1980, and in 1984 he bought the U.S. Senate seat."
WE ARE SITTING IN the sunlit living room of Rockefeller's hilltop home in Charleston, and I am having an attack of deja vu. As a reporter for The Charleston Daily Mail, I covered Jay Rockefeller as Governor, in the late 70's and early 80's, when a major issue was his use of personal money in his campaigns (he spent more than $11 million in 1980, more than $12 million in 1984, most of it his own money -- a remarkable amount in a state of just 1.8 million people). It gave rise to regular, almost ritualistic, press questions about just how much the Governor was worth. (Estimates have varied widely, but according to a Forbes assessment in 1986, he and his three sisters have assets of more than $760 million.) He would not say. He is not saying now.
"We're just going to have to wait on that one," Rockefeller says with a well-mannered but implacable smile. If he runs for President, he says, he will make a disclosure. Until then, "I'm rather private on family stuff."
When he ran a second time against Arch Moore in 1980, one of the most popular bumper stickers declared, "Make Him Spend It All, Arch." A popular comeback was, "At Least It's His." In fact, Rockefeller's poll taker, Geoffrey Garin, says, "There's just a lot of evidence that if you have to spend somebody's money, voters prefer that you spend your own rather than special-interest money." His critics, though, argued that Rockefeller spent such huge amounts that it fundamentally distorted the electoral process. Who, after all, can afford to run against a Rockefeller?
Rockefeller always defended his spending, but by the time he ran for re-election in 1990, he had announced that he would not use his own money. "I think he felt he had to do it, to prove he could do it," a friend says. Rockefeller says he actually found he enjoyed raising money. As it turned out, however, his opposition was largely token.
He could, if he ran for President, decline Federal matching funds, thereby exempting himself from spending limits, and reach into the Rockefeller fortune once again. Asked about that approach, he responded, somewhat cryptically, "Let's wait until that either happens or doesn't."
Unlike some of his cousins, Jay Rockefeller lives, unapologetically, like a Rockefeller. In addition to his house in Charleston, he and his wife have an estate in Pocahontas County in West Virginia and a mansion near Rock Creek Park in Washington. Some Republican strategists gleefully predict that Rockefeller could make the plutocratic President look downright prole.
For all of that, Rockefeller has a taste for class-oriented politics, including the attacks on the tax policies of the Reagan and Bush Administrations that propel so many Democrats these days.
When I note that he comes from a background not dissimilar to that of George Bush, he says icily, "For whatever reason, George Bush, in my judgment, has never engaged in the inner workings, in the inner feelings, of what goes on in America."
The difference, Rockefeller asserts, is that he began his career as a Vista volunteer in the hardscrabble town of Emmons, W.Va., not as a Texas oilman. "It wasn't Houston, and it wasn't, you know, whatever the name of that oil club is on the top of whatever the building is, where it is," he says, with a trace of disdain.
HIS FIRST TERM AS SENATOR seemed almost subterranean, from the perspective of national politics. Shaken by the rocky end of his governorship, and by his 52-percent-to-48-percent election to the Senate, he hunkered down and devoted himself to learning the folkways of the institution and catering to the people back home, on issues like alternative-fuels legislation. Like his sojourn at Wesleyan, it was another period of proving his fealty to West Virginia.
He compiled a fairly liberal voting record: In 1990, he was more liberal than 71 percent of his Senate colleagues on economic issues, than 60 percent on social issues, and than 69 percent on foreign issues, according to the rankings by the National Journal. Like most of his fellow Democrats, he voted against the resolution authorizing the use of force in the Persian Gulf.
In the past few years, Rockefeller moved toward more national prominence by seeking and winning the chairmanships of two blue-ribbon commissions -- one on health care, one on children, the kind of domestic issues that Democrats hope will someday bring them back to power.
The United States Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care -- often known as the Pepper Commission -- produced a plan last year to provide universal health insurance and extensive new long-term nursing-care benefits. But its proposals would cost $66 billion a year in Federal funds, and the chances for legislative enactment any time soon are considered slim.
The National Commission on Children, in its report last month, called for major new initiatives to combat poverty among the young, including a $1,000 income-tax credit for each child in America. The Bush Administration, citing fiscal constraints, has been less than enthusiastic.
In his initial forays into Presidential politics, Rockefeller seemed ill prepared to handle the fundamental question most liberals face these days: Who will pay for their good intentions? Rockefeller has a powerful belief in government as an instrument of social good; he sometimes seems unaware of how many Americans no longer share that view, how much the Reagan revolution has altered the political landscape. Like Michael S. Dukakis, he has been insulated by a political career spent in one of the most Democratic states in the union.
(Indeed, during an interview, Rockefeller declared: "This is controversial to say, because Michael Dukakis took a terrific fall. We'd be a much stronger country today if Michael Dukakis were President. You print that." It is an opinion rarely voiced in political circles, even by those who believe it.)
On the campaign trail, Rockefeller often has the air of a patrician camp counselor or social worker, peering down, empathetically, from his 6-foot-6 1/2-inch height, trying to do good. His speeches are often very long and only lightly organized, but deeply felt. ("I'm very proud -- deeply proud -- deeply moved -- fiercely moved -- about what we did on the Pepper Commission.") He can, however, turn imperious and chilly when the business turns to politics; when I first asked about his old rival Arch Moore, Rockefeller said distantly, "I don't even remember the name of the prison he's in."
Rockefeller does not have the kind of powerhouse staff that one might expect from a Rockefeller; only three of his staff workers have experience in Presidential campaigns, none at a senior level. Rockefeller's political consulting firm is Squier, Eskew & Knapp, headed by political veteran Bob Squier, but it is not clear whether they would handle a Presidential campaign; they have other clients who are potential candidates, including Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee.
Like many other potential candidates for the Democratic nomination, Rockefeller would begin a Presidential campaign with major weaknesses -- untested in national politics, unproven in foreign policy, with no real base outside West Virginia. "He is a long shot, but they're all long shots," says William Schneider, a political scientist at the American Enterprise Institute. "It's a field of long shots unless and until Mario Cuomo decides to run." But Democratic oddsmakers, by and large, see Rockefeller as someone who would also begin with a certain star appeal.
The name piques considerable interest as he travels among Democrats around the country. Peter Collier, the co-author of "The Rockefellers: An American Dynasty," says, "We'll see what the baggage of the name is once he gets out there with it." But, Collier argues: "Those vulgar Marxist conspiracy theories that hung over the name like static electricity are gone. This notion that they got in one small room every morning and decided what the fate of the world would be is just gone."
As he struggles with his decision, Rockefeller talks incessantly about the effect of a campaign on his wife, Sharon, and their four children: John 5th, 22; Valerie, 20, who is named after Sharon's slain sister, Valerie Percy; Charles, 18, and Justin, 12. "Sharon has spent her entire life being a good soldier to me, for me, with me," he said, somewhat guiltily, at the end of a speech not long ago.
The daughter of Charles Percy, the former Senator from Illinois, Sharon Rockefeller is a veteran of 22 statewide campaigns between her father and her husband. In West Virginia, some feel she has the better political instincts in the marriage. Rockefeller has struggled with the number-of-bathrooms-on-the-first-floor question; when a reporter posed it to his wife, she said: "Oh, come on. I can personally testify, there are two."
In recent years, she has increasingly reached for a separate career; she is now president and chief executive officer of WETA, the public television and radio station in Washington. As her husband began exploring a race for the Presidency, she recused herself from all planning meetings for political coverage, but thinks she can keep her job if he runs. She says she is ready to be a good soldier again. "The family's unified around Jay," she says. "There's no question of what we would do if this is the way he goes"
ROCKEFELLER LIKES TO project himself as the untroubled cousin, the one at peace with John D. I and II. Yet on a recent summer afternoon, he wants to tell about his speech last year to a convention of the United Mine Workers of America, now headed by Richard L. Trumka. "It was a wonderful speech," Rockefeller says, "and after it was over they were cheering, and I turned to Rich Trumka, and we were just in this great bear hug, and I said, 'It's a long way from Ludlow, isn't it, Rich?' And he said, 'It sure is.' "
Rockefeller tells this story with great pleasure and intensity, and in that moment it is hard not to feel the weight of this name. He brushes away all the psychological theories of guilt and expiation that surround the Rockefeller family, the getting of its fortune and the giving away. But he clearly wants a place in the family pantheon. His niche, if he has his way, will be as the voice of compassionate government, provider of health care, nurturer of children. It would be a long way from Ludlow.
It is a logical evolution for this fourth-generation Rockefeller, this philanthropist's son, but it may be out of sync with the times -- the straitened budgets, the acute sensitivities to taxes, the suspicions of "big government." One can easily imagine some opponent declaring that while a Rockefeller might be able to afford the programs he advances, the average taxpayer could not.
His Presidential ambitions have a certain inevitability to them; a political Rockefeller will always be urged into the big game. But once the game begins, Presidential campaigns have a way of stripping away mystique and reputation and all the protection that a great name ordinarily provides; his uncle Nelson could attest to that.
If he runs, sooner or later, his campaign will all come down to him -- his wits, his beliefs, his intellect, his drive. It will be only Jay Rockefeller stepping up to his moment.

PUB-DATE: July 21, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Page 13; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Nowhere to Go: The Palestinians After the War

BYLINE: By Judith Miller; Judith Miller is a Times senior writer and the author, with Laurie Mylroie, of "Saddam Hussein and the Crisis in the Gulf."

 BODY:
ZIAD ABU ZAYYAD, A 51-YEAR OLD Palestinian journalist, sat with his wife and eight children under a framed embroidery that his wife had finished sewing only the day before. "There is no place like home," the embroidery read, in English.
 For Zayyad, it was his first day at home in the West Bank town of Bethany in six months. He had just been released from an Israeli prison where he had shared a cell, 13 feet by 11 feet, with seven other men who, like him, were being held without formal charges or a trial. 
 Israeli officials deny that they used the gulf crisis as cover to step up their repression of Palestinians, people like Zayyad, who publishes a Hebrew-language newspaper about Israeli-Palestinian relations. But no Palestinian believes those denials.
The Persian Gulf war was over, Zayyad argued, but the lopsided war between Israel and the Palestinians continued. He had met one of its victims in prison: a middle-aged man -- he called him Ahmed -- who had already served 20 years of a life term. When he was sentenced by an Israeli court two decades ago, Ahmed had released the woman he loved from their engagement. During the gulf war, a new prisoner had sought Ahmed out. "I send you greetings from my mother," the teen-age prisoner said. The teen-ager turned out to be the son of Ahmed's one-time fiancee; the son, Zayyad said, that Ahmed might have had.
Now, Zayyad added, the teen-ager's generation was also being sacrificed to the relentless, devastating war between Arabs and Jews. "How many more generations will be wasted?" he wondered sadly.
For Palestinians, the people who come from or whose ancestors came from the land that Israel now inhabits and occupies, the war has significantly complicated the answer to that question. Saddam Hussein did succeed in focusing the world's attention on the more than five million Palestinians who for more than 40 years have lived in a diaspora depressingly similar to that of the Jews who now inhabit their land. And as some have noted with bitter irony, the war has left the United States, as the pre-eminent power in the Middle East, with new responsibility for the Palestinians' welfare. But the Palestinians' open and enthusiastic support for Iraq turned the Israeli public -- even the doves -- against them, undermined their cause in the eyes of the world and added immeasurably to their misery.
It also devastated the Palestinian economy, which relief groups estimate has lost $350 million since last August. Some of the wealthiest Palestinian communities, particularly in Kuwait, are barely functioning. Critical safety valves of employment and "safe haven" in sympathetic countries have been closed off. At least a quarter of a million Palestinians have fled Kuwait and Iraq since last Aug. 2.
Politically, the war's effects on the Palestinians are harder to measure. America's overwhelming victory weakened the Palestine Liberation Organization and its chairman, Yasir Arafat. Yet the P.L.O.'s terrible miscalculation of backing Saddam Hussein appears to have given West Bank Palestinians the latitude to enter negotiations for autonomy, rather than for immediate statehood.
At the same time, the gulf war widened divisions among Palestinians, splitting them openly for the first time, not just ideologically but geographically and economically. And the growing number of stabbings of Israelis by Palestinians and murders of Palestinians by Palestinians suggest that extremist forces, particularly in the occupied territories, are also on the rise.
Mostly, the war has deepened the despair of Palestinians -- everywhere. But it is most noticeable in the occupied territories and in Kuwait, long a key source of support for the Palestinian people and their organizations. Kuwait -- once home to the third-largest Palestinian community outside of Israel and the occupied territories, and surely the wealthiest -- now rivals only Israel in its loathing of Iraqi "collaborators." Most of the Palestinians still in Kuwait remain in limbo, jobless, stateless and in fear for their lives.
The war has also triggered a new diaspora. Many of the more than 200,000 Palestinians in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf region are being methodically replaced by Asians, Egyptians and other politically more "reliable" workers.
The Palestinian sympathy for Saddam Hussein has placed a heavy burden on Jordan, which, according to King Hussein, has in recent months received 200,000 Palestinian refugees. Some 50,000 Palestinian children have swelled school enrollments; unemployment, in a country where Palestinians account for roughly 50 percent of the population, has soared above 30 percent, more than double what it was before the war. Nearly all of the refugees need daily assistance, something that Jordan -- having lost about $600 million in aid from Saudi Arabia and the gulf states for having backed Iraq in the war -- is unable to provide.
And the war has compounded the daily suffering of the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied territories. The Palestinian economy, already crippled by the four-year-old intifada -- the locally organized uprising against Israel -- was virtually obliterated by Israeli war-related restrictions. These included an unprecedented 40-day curfew -- a de facto house arrest of the entire population -- a travel ban, severe work restrictions and other ostensibly security-related measures.
"Conditions in the West Bank and Gaza are as bad or worse than I have ever seen them, probably worse even than the aftermath of the 1967 war," concluded Peter Gubser, who heads American Near East Refugee Aid, a private relief group.
What the gulf crisis seems not to have done is prompt a sustained soul-searching among Palestinian leaders and intellectuals. Few will admit that backing Saddam Hussein was a huge mistake, the latest in an almost uninterrupted series of self-defeating miscalculations by Arafat and his leadership. Many privately concede that it has undermined their support in Europe and, among a far smaller constituency, in the United States. But few will acknowledge, at least publicly, that their support of Iraq undermined the legal and moral basis of their own cause: the unacceptability of the seizure and occupation of territory by force.
Although many Palestinians now openly criticize Arafat's leadership -- in many cases for the first time -- Palestinians say he still commands enormous support. And despite the worst discord in P.L.O. ranks in years, there is no serious effort to replace him, largely because there are no plausible alternatives.
Paradoxically, many Palestinians now see the United States as a prospective savior, the only nation capable of persuading Israel to grant what they call a fairly modest request -- an area equal to 20 percent of what was historically Palestine. They are not taking to their rooftops to applaud President Bush's vow to help resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Far from it. Few in fact, believe that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's dogged efforts can succeed. But in their utter despair, many still hope that America, Israel's patron, will deliver what countless United Nations resolutions and years of struggle have not.
A sense of powerlessness, as well as hopelessness, is now palpable among Palestinians everywhere. "We didn't commit the Holocaust," said Hanan Ashrawi, a professor and writer who reflects mainstream P.L.O. thinking. "We do not want to drive Israelis into the sea, to wipe them off the face of the earth. Since 1988, the P.L.O. has accepted the notion of a two-state solution, of Israel's right to exist as a nation state. The problem is that Israel won't acknowledge ours. It does not want to trade territory for peace with us.
"Look, the peace process we worked so hard to build collapsed in the spring of 1990. The U.S. let Yitzhak Shamir bring the Israeli Government down in March rather than force him to implement his own peace proposal. In June, following the renegade Palestinian beach raid in which no Israeli was killed, the U.S. broke off its dialogue with the P.L.O. You stopped even talking to us! In August, Iraq invaded Kuwait and promised the Palestinians, who had lost hope, the faint possibility of liberation. Many knew it would not work. But if they dreamed of an Arab liberator on a white horse, if, in their despair, in the absence of any semblance of a peace process, they clung to this reed, can you really blame them?"
 IN MAY, KUWAIT WAS STILL A SMOLDERING wreck. Some 100,000 Kuwaitis had fled, deciding that a country in which you could taste the air was no place for their children. For many Palestinians, however, there has been no escape.
According to estimates from the Kuwaiti Government and independent sources, about 10 percent of the Palestinians who remained in Kuwait during the occupation collaborated with the Iraqis, 80 percent just tried to get by and 10 percent actively resisted. Nevertheless, while every Kuwaiti seems to know individual Palestinians who helped during the occupation, Kuwaitis now appear to remember only Arafat's embrace of Saddam Hussein.
More than a third of the Palestinians remaining in Kuwait are huddled in an area called Hawali, a Palestinian neighborhood in Kuwait City that was transformed by the liberation into a slum. The Kuwaiti and Saudi checkpoints that ringed this ghetto to snare collaborators were gone by mid-May. But Hawali still resembled a prison camp, without the barbed wire.
Only children played on the filthy streets, in front of the graffiti-scrawled apartment buildings. Teen-agers and adults were afraid to go out. Tawfik Oqal, a 26-year-old Palestinian who was born in Kuwait, explained why.
On March 9, his brother, Walid, 27, left to buy food and gasoline. He was stopped and arrested at a Kuwaiti checkpoint; no reason was given. He was severely beaten at a police station and urged to "confess" to collaboration, which he refused to do. He was burned with cigarettes and his nails were beaten and pressed by weights until they turned black. Twenty-one days later, he was released, and then only after the intervention of an American colonel.
"My father has been here for 40 years," said Tawfik, a soft-spoken young man with a neatly clipped beard, clad in jeans and a grey "Daytona Beach" T-shirt. "He was a crane operator. He came here when they had nothing; he helped build Kuwait. Walid and I went to college in the States. But we both loved Kuwait and chose to come back here in 1989. I would still stay if I could find work. But they don't want us."
It is in families like this that one hears the harshest criticism of Arafat. "I don't care about him," Tawfik said of the P.L.O. leader. "What has he done for us? All I want is my own country where I can live freely. You can't imagine what it is not to have a state, to be an eternal guest, threatened and humiliated wherever you go."
Even if they could leave, there are few places to go. Only Palestinians essential to Kuwait's reconstruction are being called back to work. Most of those who agree to forgo back pay and possessions can leave for Jordan. But between 20,000 and 40,000 Palestinians -- estimates of their numbers vary wildly -- hold Egyptian travel documents. Egypt refuses to admit them, and they are unwelcome in Jordan or any other country. They are literally stranded.
Among the few mandatory excursions for Palestinians are the humiliating trips to the Kuwaiti centers established to register all foreigners. Each day since mid-April, Palestinians have formed long lines in front of the centers, squatting amid garbage, the men on one curb, the women on another.
As they sat under the smoggy rising sun one day in May, Kuwaiti soldiers in desert camouflage swaggered among them at the sand-bagged entrance to the Jabriya branch of the Ministry of Interior. A New York Times reporter stationed in Kuwait witnessed what he called a typical incident: a young Kuwaiti man plucked out of the line and beaten. They dragged him into the ministry building. By midafternoon, he had not emerged.
The new Government of Kuwait, a reshuffling of members of the ruling al-Sabah family, denies it has mistreated Palestinians. "My house was burned," said Ahmed Hamoud al-Jaber al-Sabah, the Interior Minister. "So I've been trying to get some of the rooms painted. Some of my workers are Palestinian. If I had anything against Palestinians, would they be working in my house?"
For the moment, the Kuwaiti Government has forbidden the return of the 200,000 Palestinians who fled the Iraqi invasion, people whose life savings are held in Kuwaiti banks and whose children know no other society. But no decision has been made about the fate of the Palestinians remaining in Kuwait. "They want them to leave, but they need them," a veteran European diplomat said. "It was Palestinians, not Kuwaitis, who made this society work."
Worse still, Palestinians have nowhere to turn. P.L.O. officials burned all the documents in their embassy, and then the building itself, before fleeing as Iraqi troops left the city. The embassy has not reopened. So Palestinians are at the mercy of what is widely regarded as a disorganized, inept and vindictive Kuwaiti Government.
 UNDER THE UNFORGIVING FLUORESCENT LIGHTS of his sparsely furnished office in Tunis, Yasir Arafat, the living symbol of Palestinian aspirations, looked old. His left hand was bandaged, the result of a skin disease. The usual three-day stubble had turned patchy white; his stomach drooped over the belt of his olive-green fatigues; he seemed smaller than his 5-foot-4-inch frame, dwarfed by machine-gun-toting bodyguards and stacks of faxes. "Bills, bills, bills," he complained.
The P.L.O. is running short of cash. Funds that once flowed from Persian Gulf governments and from a tax on Palestinian workers in Kuwait and some other gulf states -- estimated at more than $250 million a year -- were cut off after the crisis erupted.
The P.L.O. also appears to be running short of political steam. Its morale has been shattered by the war, and most recently by the expulsion of Palestinian guerrillas from southern Lebanon, the P.L.O.'s last stronghold. Another critical blow was the series of Israeli and Palestinian assassinations of P.L.O. leaders. In January, Salah Khalef, or Abu Iyad, the P.L.O.'s No. 2 man, who was unhappy about the alliance with Iraq, was killed by an extremist Palestinian bodyguard. His picture, smiling beatifically, still hangs in most P.L.O. offices, a grisly reminder of the group's inability to protect its own.
None of the fear and anxiety so evident in many P.L.O. officials in Tunis was apparent in Arafat's demeanor. "We are at a peak," he declared with almost surreal conviction. "At the peak of support with the Arab masses, with the Muslim nation, with the third world."
All he had tried to do, Arafat said, was to mediate an end to an Arab quarrel. The United States had wanted war with Iraq. Washington wanted to deal with Arab "puppets," and, if it could find them, with Palestinians who would relinquish their national claims. He would not do so. And he would not step down, unless his critics had "50 percent plus one" of the votes to oust him. The P.L.O., he said, was an "oasis" of democracy.
Besides, he continued, he had only followed his people in supporting Saddam Hussein. "What else could I have done?" he asked. "It's impossible to be a democratic leader without following your people." The Saudis and the gulf states knew that and would ultimately come around, he insisted. No Arab could afford to abandon the Palestinian cause. "They made excuses for King Hussein because he has so many Palestinians," he said. "O.K., I have all of them."
Palestinians had championed Saddam Hussein because they had nothing to lose, he argued. "I gave all that the Amercans wanted. What more striptease can I do? Until now, nothing has been offered us."
It is President Bush's credibility, not his, that is now at stake, he asserted. The United States, he said, appealing once more in typical Palestinian fashion to his archenemy, has to resolve this conflict now. And it has to do so with him, not with "ghosts."
If Arafat had second thoughts about the war, he didn't betray them. If in the twilight zone of Tunis he was aware of the hatred so many Palestinians in Kuwait and in Jordan felt for him, he never admitted it. If he knew they called him King Yasir, or that many no longer referred to him as Abu Ammar, his nom de guerre, but as Abu Kharab, or father of ruin, he wasn't letting on. If he recognized that the P.L.O. had become paralyzed by factionalism, he gave no indication.
"You have all written him off so many times before," said Farouk Khadoumi, the P.L.O.'s foreign minister, "that doing so now is not credible."
Barring his murder or resignation, Arafat will probably remain as the P.L.O. head, despite the likelihood of challenges from prominent Palestinians in exile. "If elections were held in all Arab countries, few Arab leaders would remain in office," said Marie Colvin, who covers the Middle East for The Sunday Times of London. "But even today, a majority of Palestinians would keep Arafat in office."
But Arafat's support of Saddam Hussein damaged the P.L.O.'s unity, independence and relevance, which he had fought so long to build. True, leaders in the West Bank and Gaza said they would neither meet with Baker nor negotiate with Israel without the P.L.O.'s authorization. But experts on the P.L.O. say that Arafat had no choice but to grant permission.
If pushed, some local leaders were prepared to meet with Baker anyway, West Bankers say. Even those who insist that local leaders would never dare disregard a P.L.O. command agree that in sanctioning the meetings -- as well as the participation of West Bankers in a Jordanian delegation to peace talks with Israel -- Arafat has, in effect, acknowledged that Tunis no longer directly controls the West Bank Palestinians.
Some say that Arafat's growing vulnerability has made him even more obstinate, megalomaniacal and reluctant to share power, much less to designate a successor. "He simply will not let go," said one P.L.O. leader. "The world is coming down around our ears, and he hears nothing. I've worked for this cause all my life. But now, I'm truly fed up."
 WITH WORLD ATTENTION DIVERTED BY THE gulf crisis, Israel seemed to step up its repression of the Palestinians, despite official denials. In October, at least 17 Palestinians were killed and 100 wounded after Israeli police opened fire on demonstrators at the Temple Mount in Jerusalem. When the deaths prompted a rash of stabbings of Israelis by Palestinians -- at least 10 Israelis were stabbed to death during the gulf crisis -- the Shamir Government cracked down, declaring a 24-hour curfew, among other security measures.
"What would you call occupiers who explode American-made sound bombs that deafen children for weeks inside schools?" asked one diplomat, referring to the riot-control device meant for use outdoors. "What do you call an occupation in which, for more than a month, people cannot go to school or work or even leave their houses for half a day to buy food for more than a month?"
Of all the Palestinian communities outside of Kuwait, Gaza was hurt the most by the war. It is home to 700,000 Palestinians, 300,000 of whom are crowded into eight refugee camps, among the poorest, most densely inhabited areas of the world. Gaza was placed under 24-hour curfew for 52 days -- 12 days longer than the West Bank.
"I saw illness I had rarely seen here," said Mohammed Moussa Abu Lehia, the senior Palestinian doctor in Jabalia camp, a Palestinian Calcutta. "We saw diseases of developed societies -- hypertension and depression, triggered by anxiety over the war and the restrictions -- and the ills of the poor, such as scurvy, malnutrition."
 With the Israeli curfew and travel bans, most of the 120,000 Palestinians from Gaza and the West Bank working in Israel lost their jobs. Many of those jobs were filled by the thousands of Soviet Jewish immigrants flooding into Israel. By May, only about 50,000 Palestinians had received passes enabling them to return to work in Israel, or even to pass through Jerusalem.
Since the north and south of the occupied territories are linked by roads through East Jerusalem, the West Bank was divided in half, with the capital virtually off-limits to most Palestinians. In May, three months after the war's end, checkpoints manned by Israeli soldiers still ringed Jerusalem. Israeli cars with yellow license plates were permitted to pass; Palestinian cars with blue plates were turned back, except for the lucky few with passes.
 "They have used the gulf crisis to isolate Jerusalem from the rest of the territories," said Hanna S. Siniora, a Palestinian editor. "Israelis are shy about discussing expelling Palestinians from this land, but that's the effect if you deny us the ability to feed our children."
A spokesman for Israel's Defense Ministry in the occupied territories denies that Israel used the gulf crisis to punish or drive out the Palestinians. He acknowledged that tear gas and, on one occasion in Gaza, a sound bomb, had been used. But after the sound bomb incident the authorities banned the use of such weapons in closed quarters, though Palestinians insist that the practice continues. The spokesman insisted that during the curfew Palestinians were permitted to leave their homes for a few hours a day to buy food or take sick family members to hospitals and infirmaries. "There were cash flow problems -- largely from the absence of funds from Kuwait -- but never any starvation," he said.
The curfew was needed to curb what otherwise might have been a "stabbing spree in Tel Aviv," given what Palestinians were prepared to do, he asserted. Military authorities had intercepted letters and messages ordering leaders of the intifada to attack Israeli targets, "and not just stone-throwings, but murders with guns." The curfew was extended, he said, only after the military intercepted messages from Palestinians indicating that they were unable to carry out these terrorist attacks because of the curfew.
Since the gulf crisis, Israel has placed new restraints on Palestinians. A military spokesman said that some 10,000 "green cards" have been issued to Palestinians, barring those convicted of crimes or who have what he called "terrorist files" from working in, or even visiting, Israel, including Jerusalem. Palestinian employment has also been limited by a new order requiring employers of Arabs to supply transportation from the territories to and from work, since Palestinians now need special permits to drive their cars into Israel proper.
Israeli officials say they recognize the danger to stability posed by the ravaged Palestinian economy, and they say they are loosening restrictions and adopting rules to promote development. Two more Palestinian financial institutions were recently licensed, and Israeli officials said the Government would soon permit the opening of 25 new Palestinian factories. The Draconian limits on movement have been eased a bit, but will be lifted only when the stabbings stop, Israeli officials said.
Yet the easing of the oppressive occupation has done little to allay Palestinian concerns about the steady growth of Israeli settlements in the territories. By both Israeli and Palestinian accounts, Israel now effectively owns more than 50 percent of West Bank territory. If current settlement activity continues, Palestinians will within three years become a minority in East Jerusalem, which was Arab until the 1967 war. Washington has not recognized Israel's annexation of East Jerusalem, and has protested settlements as illegal. But it has provided $750 million in emergency aid to help Israel settle Soviet Jews, aware that some are being settled in East Jerusalem and the territories.
 "The settlement activity is tantamount to the liquidation of the Palestinian people, acre by acre," said Ibrahim Mattar, a Palestinian economist who monitors Israeli settlements. "The giant condos are more than an obstacle to peace; they are facts we cannot change."
The gulf war has exacted a dire political toll as well. Israeli and Palestinian peace activists agree that the two communities have never been as divided. "Many Israelis are still afraid of venturing into Arab parts of East Jerusalem and the territories, and the Palestinians can't come here," said Menachem Brinker, a professor and member of Israel's Peace Now, a leading dovish group. "The massive Palestinian support for the Scud attacks on Israel damaged our cause," he conceded. "But we are slowly rebuilding our bridges to one another."
 Avishai Margalit, a professor and a Peace Now activist, goes further. "The Palestinians made a mistake," he said. "But we morally ambushed them. We waited for them to blunder, and then we said 'We knew you were rotten.'
"Their daily lives had become so rotten -- day-to-day humiliations, harassment, arrests, detentions, beatings and torture if you believe the detailed reports we've seen -- that I understand -- not accept, but understand -- why they acted as they did. In a sense, the Palestinians were entitled to their irrationality. We cannot delegitimize them simply because they or their leaders made a mistake. Our occupation is tragically emulating South African apartheid."
Moreover, given the increasing extremism among Palestinians and Israelis, many argue, moderate Palestinians willing to negotiate with Israel are a precious resource that Israelis should not lightly write off.
 The danger to these Palestinians is already evident. Faisal Husseini, who has been meeting with Baker, was recently forced to leave his home when teen-age neighbors noticed a car with yellow Israeli license plates parked in front of his house. Much embarrassed, Husseini explained to an Israeli journalist that it would be safer if they went elsewhere.
During the war, local Palestinian leaders dared not urge moderation in their compatriots' zeal for Saddam Hussein. "We would have been killed for trying," said one leader, who insisted on anonymity. "Intellectual terrorism has taken root here."
In Nablus, the largest and most intensely political West Bank town, Palestinian desperation -- and its political evolution -- is literally written on the walls. The earliest slogans one sees are those of the Unified National Leadership, the ostensibly P.L.O.-directed intifada, written in black and blue spray paint. Many of these have been painted over with the increasingly vicious threats of the Islamic Resistance Movement, known as Hamas, the major Islamic-inspired radical movement in the territories. Some of these, in turn, have been covered by the slogans of Al Jihad, an even more extremist Islamic group.
 "There have been about 20 murders in Nablus -- and 164 in the territories -- since the gulf crisis," said Haitham Hamad, a Palestinian journalist who works for The Associated Press. "Most have been of Palestinians, by Palestinians. This is the ugly side of the intifada."
 Said one Palestinian analyst, "The P.L.O. still represents the Palestinians politically, but Hamas increasingly reflects their despair."
 Despair took hold after the intifada failed to end Israeli repression or to produce peace talks. And it is becoming stronger still after the gulf war, part of a self-defeating political cycle that Israeli hard-liners use to justify a policy of not dealing with the Palestinians who supported Saddam Hussein and are now knifing Israelis in the streets.
"In this sense, the gulf war stance can legitimately be seen as the latest stage of the intifada," said Radwan Abu Ayyash, a leading Palestinian journalist who was imprisoned by Israel for five months during the crisis without trial or formal charges.
 The mostly moderate Palestinians who have been meeting with James Baker agree with Husseini that the Baker peace mission is a "last chance" before Israeli settlement activity and repression create new and even uglier political dynamics. It is the last time, they say, that a relatively moderate P.L.O. will still be able and willing to make a deal that involves territorial compromise. And it may be the last chance before Palestinians become so desperate, so full of hate for Israelis and so radicalized that Hamas, Jihad and other groups advocating "no negotiation, no compromise" come to reflect the majority view in the territories.
An endless succession of Palestinian suicide strikes against Israel, in turn, could provide a pretext for evicting more and more Palestinians from the territories, as many Jewish fundamentalists advocate and Palestinians fear.
"I'm pleading while there is still time," said Husseini. The United States and Israel have to deal with Arafat because he still represents the Palestinians, because he is "flexible and moderate and because he can deliver," Husseini said. "I would deal with Yitzhak Shamir precisely because he, too, can deliver."
 "If we don't succeed," Husseini said, "if Baker abandons this effort as he did before, leaving only his telephone number behind, one thing is sure: When he returns, he won't be interested in talking to me. He'll have to talk to people who know the language of the jungle better than I do."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 23; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1457 words

HEADLINE: It's Cornstock, Not Woodstock

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT; WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, a London correspondent for The Times, is a frequent visitor to Minnesota.

 BODY:
ON most summer evenings, the only sounds carrying across the shallow lakes of northwestern Minnesota are the whine and sputter of outboard motors, as anglers set out through the twilight, trolling for pike and walleye.
But for three days beginning Aug. 2 in Detroit Lakes, Minn., the hazy northern nights here will be broken broken by other, less familiar, sounds: the distant riff of amplified guitars and the muffled bass backbeat of drums, drifting clearly through the woods and over the windless surfaces of lakes. 
 Since 1983, this little tourist crossroads 60 miles east of the North Dakota border has become the site of what is called WE Fest, one of the nation's largest outdoor camping and country and western music festivals.
 The 271-acre Soo Pass Ranch, which is usually the site of riding stables, a restaurant and bar, will be turned into a kind of country and western Woodstock, a temporary community of some 25,000 raucous adults who gather around tents and motor homes in six relatively primitive campgrounds to drink beer, cook hamburgers, swap stories and savor some 36 hours of nearly nonstop music from more than 25 groups, including big-name acts like Kenny Rogers, Reba McEntire and George Strait, all of whom are scheduled to appear this year. The festival is the creation of Jeff Krueger, a former rock and roll promoter from Minneapolis and a veteran of Woodstock, the 1969 outdoor concert that drew 300,000 to a farm in upstate New York.
Along the way, the visitors will snarl traffic hopelessly on local roads and cause gridlock at supermarkets and liquor outlets. They will get sunburned when they are not being drenched by afternoon thunderstorms.
But for most of the audience, a large proportion of whom are middle-aged and well-behaved, the event will mark the high point of the summer, a kind of annual celebration of friends and family, marked in time to the rhythms rolling off the stage.
More than 80 percent of those surveyed at last summer's festival said they had been to a WE Fest before. And while some campers come from as far away as Texas, Canada and California, the overwhelming majority are residents of the Upper Middle West: Minnesota, Iowa, Wisconsin and the Dakotas.
The WE in WE Fest represents nothing more than its ordinary usage as the first person plural pronoun, a formulation intended to suggest that the event is as much about the audience as it is about the performers.
Some people organize their summer vacations around the concert and stake out the same campsites year after year, marked by signs and flags declaring their arrival: the Peterson Family or the Corner Gang" or the Lake Park Country Club.
For the most part, the crowd is adult, and the festival's own promotional literature gently tries to discourage people from bringing their children. "There are large crowds day and night, alcoholic beverages are sold on site and there are no activities strictly for children," advises one bit of published material. The point is indirectly reinforced a few paragraphs later, in a blunt reminder that anyone caught carrying or brandishing weapons will be immediately ejected.
 In 1983, sensing there was now more profit to be made off country and western than rock, in a mostly rural region of the country where nearly every small town has its own country AM radio station, Mr. Krueger, the organizer, assembled a group of investors and hit paydirt on his first try: he landed Alabama, one of the hottest groups in the nation, to headline the original WE Fest.
 Attendance has continued to grow since, and the large and enthusiastic audiences at what Mr. Krueger and his own partners now refer to internally as their Cornstock, have guaranteed an all-star lineup every time.
Last year, for example, when the festival drew a record one-night crowd of 40,000, the headliners included Randy Travis, Barbara Mandrell and Dolly Parton, who appeared with a 100-member chorale assembled from local churches.
The choir joined Ms. Parton in the concert finale, a stirring rendition of the recent gospel song, "He's Alive," that brought down the house.
"The common denominators are rural and mid-America," said Chyrll Weimar Sparks, another former rock and roll promoter who found salvation in country and western. "We're appealing here to simple, genuine people who have their heads screwed on straight."
While country and western is more commonly associated with the regional cultures of the South and Texas, the music has a wide following across the rural Midwest.
The performers at WE Fest appear on a large stage facing a broad, dusty hillside, on which fans set up lawn chairs and settle in for some 12 hours a day of nonstop music. The best views of the stage go not only to those who get there earliest, but to the fleetest among them. Each morning at 9 the gates are opened as a loudspeaker blares the "William Tell Overture," and the hundreds who have been waiting in line begin a mad sprint across the hillside, racing to stake out their favorite spots.
Between acts, Tom Katt, a country music disk jockey from Minneapolis, struggles to keep the sometimes unruly crowd in line, telling jokes or helping them burn off energy by leading a determined competition in which one side of the audience is exhorted to shout "tastes great!" more loudly than the other half can howl "less filling!"
Meanwhile, ringing the audience are dozens of small shops, beer gardens and assorted diversions, including teams of Indian dancers in tribal dress, and a wide variety of stands selling everything from fluorescent baseball caps and hand-tooled leather belts to $20 straw cowboy hats.
THERE is also a stand that sells framed paintings done on black velvet, with a selection that aims straight for the heart of any country and western fan, including moody portraits of Willie Nelson, Elvis and John Wayne.
For Detroit Lakes, a town whose wintertime population of about 7,000 swells to some 21,000 on warm summer weekends, the WE Fest has been a major boon to business, pumping millions of dollars into the local economy.
It has also added a whole new element to a tourist trade that, until recently, relied primarily on the loyalties of fishermen and the vacation dollars of Midwestern families, drawn to one of the largest concentrations of water slides, fast food outlets and kiddie parks between Minneapolis and Billings, Mont.
Local merchants are among the festival's most enthusiastic backers, and sponsors line up for a listing in the local WE Fest program, a roster that not only includes the usual group of local restaurants and motels, but the town's optometrist and well driller.
 
 
 
TIPS FOR COUNTRY MUSIC FANS
 The WE Fest site is on the Soo Pass Ranch, which is about two miles south of Detroit Lakes, Minn. It is reachable by either U.S. 59 or county road 22.
Beginning Aug. 1, a three-day admission ticket can be purchased at the gate for $50. Before Aug. 1, a ticket can be purchased for $45 from merchants and participating ticket outlets in Minnesota. Single-day tickets cost $20. Parking is $3 a day.
A limited number of reserved box seats immediately in front of the stage are also available, at $300 each, for the entire three days.
 
Camping
 Permits to hook up campers or pitch tents at campgrounds on the site cost $50 to $75, depending on the campground, and are good for the duration of the festival. Campgrounds open at noon on Thursday, Aug. 1, and close at noon on Monday, Aug. 5. Sites are usually available right up to the beginning of the festival, according to its organizer, but reservations are recommended.
In addition, limited camping spaces are available in a V.I.P. area immediately behind the main stage, for $200 for the duration of the festival, including electrical hookups.
Like the music area, where there is no protection from the weather and the only toilets are portables, most of the surrounding campgrounds are pretty basic. About 500 campsites bordering nearby Lake Sallie are served by a shower house and a small general store, but the rest of the campgrounds is Minnesota rustic: open fields or wooded areas that serve the rest of the year mostly as open horse range for the Soo Pass Ranch.
There are no electrical hookups for campers in these areas and the only running water is what you draw off a pumper truck that roams the campgrounds.
 
Information
 For information on other lodging, including campsites and motels outside the Soo Pass Ranch, call the Detroit Lakes Regional Chamber of Commerce at (800) 542-3992. For further information on the WE Fest itself, including campsite reservations, telephone (218) 847-1340. W. E. S.

LENGTH: 1326 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Central Park South;
Change, but Not at the Coliseum

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
FROM Columbus Circle to Grand Army Plaza, Central Park South presents a motley face, grandeur mingled with mediocrity. Like the physical setting, the commercial real-estate scene is decidedly mixed.
The most obvious transformation now under way is at the Essex House, near Seventh Avenue, which Nikko Hotels International hopes to turn from dowdy to deluxe, spending more than $75 million. At Fifth Avenue, the Sherry Netherland Hotel has also embarked on a renovation. The General Motors Building is undergoing a three-year, $7.5-million facelift, including the replacement of some 400 of the 44,000 marble panels in which it is clad. And Donald J. Trump still plans to add new penthouse suites to the great mansard roof of the Plaza Hotel. 
 The most obvious transformation that is not under way is at Columbus Circle, where the New York Coliseum and 10 Columbus Circle office building still stand, five years after they were to be demolished to make way for Mortimer B. Zuckerman's 2.2 million-square-foot Columbus Center project.
That project was critically, if not mortally, wounded 11 days ago when Judge Shirley Wohl Kram of Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled that it would be halted next year unless the city had by then taken certain measures to insure compliance with national air-quality standards. The judge said that fines of at least $15 million would be imposed if the deadline was not met.
"It is a very serious blow to the viability and future of the project," said Morri Berman, a spokesman for Boston Properties, Mr. Zuckerman's real-estate concern.
Unless her decision is overturned on appeal, it would not seem possible that a builder could find lenders or tenants for a project on such tenuous footing. Nor would it seem likely that the city's Industrial Development Agency could attract investors for the tax-exempt bonds that are to help finance it.
"I don't see how one could expect to sell those bonds if you've got the threat -- if not the likelihood -- that the project would get stopped midstream," said John T. Van Der Tuin, of Stults Balber Horton & Slotnick, who represents the opponents of the project.
Victor A. Kovner, the city's Corporation Counsel, found comfort in Judge Kram's denial of several claims against the project, including the use of Industrial Development Agency bonds. "We have cleared out most of the underbrush," he said, "and are left with one ruling which, in terms of remedy, I respectfully believe is erroneous."
Opponents of Columbus Center -- neighborhood residents, local businesses, community leaders and elected officials, including Representative Ted Weiss and State Senators Manfred Ohrenstein and Franz S. Leichter, all Manhattan Democrats -- had argued, among other things, that the project violated the Federal Clean Air Act.
They said the city was already in violation of the act because of its repeated failures to meet national standards. They said the Columbus Center environmental impact statement had identified a "hot spot" on East 59th Street where the carbon monoxide concentration would be increased by the project. And they said the project must mitigate any carbon monoxide violation identified in the environmental assessment.
"Plaintiffs' strongest argument in favor of their claim to enjoin the project under the Clean Air Act," Judge Kram wrote, "is that the Environmental Protection Agency requires that new projects must mitigate existing carbon monoxide violations, even those carbon monoxide violations not of the project's own making."
The defendants, including the city and the developer, argued that New York was not violating the Clean Air Act because Congress had extended the deadline for compliance until 1995. They said the project would not have a legally significant effect on the "hot spot." And they said that the city's overall control program offered sufficient proof of its commitment to improve air quality. Part of that program is a traffic study, now under way, that is to be used in the state's air-quality plan, due in November 1992.
But Judge Kram apparently was not persuaded by governmental assurances. "The Court concludes from reviewing the record that the City is far from implementing any guidelines for the attainment of air quality standards," she wrote.
Judge Kram said she "will not permit the city to persevere undeterred in its violation of these Congressionally mandated and agency-implemented deadlines." Therefore, she declared, if the traffic study was not ready in time to be incorporated in the 1992 plan, "the Court will enter an order enjoining any further work on the project."
WHILE the legal battle was being fought, the city cleared the plaza in front of the Coliseum of a large encampment of homeless people that had more or less claimed the entryways and the apron in front of the building as their full-time residence.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which controls the site, plans to lease the space for use as an outdoor, fast-food cafe. The operator would be Plaza Caterers of Manhattan, headed by Michael Giovanni, who runs a similar concession on St. Andrew's Plaza, behind the Municipal Building.
Aspirations to higher cuisine are part of Nikko's makeover of the Essex House, which will include two new restaurants created by Christian Delouvrier, who earned his reputation as the chef at Maurice, in the Hotel Parker Meridien, 118 West 57th Street.
Nikko, a subsidiary of Japan Air Lines, bought the 45-story hotel from the Marriott Corporation in 1984. "They want to bring the experience of the hotel up to the address of the hotel," said Louis R. Hedgecock, a partner in Brennan Beer Gorman of Manhattan, architects of the renovation. The interior design is by Pierre Yves Rochon International of Paris and the general contractor is Tishman Construction of New York.
"Although this is not a complete rehab, as at the St. Regis, we tore out and reconfigured the interior," Mr. Hedgecock said. "A lot of rooms have gotten a lot bigger and there will be more suites." As a consequence, the number of rooms will drop to 591, from 690.
"The only request the client made from the beginning was larger bathrooms and better air-conditioning," said John A. Fitler-Ellis, vice president in Rochon's New York office. Through-the-wall air-conditioners, which contributed to a motel-like ambiance, were replaced with central air-conditioners.
Asked when the hotel had last been renovated, Mr. Fitler-Ellis smiled and answered, "It looked like about 100 years ago."
One big complication in reconfiguring the interior was that Marriott had sold more than 100 rooms as condominiums. Not only did the owners have to be paid to leave during the renovation but the design and construction had to be squeezed between and snaked around these units, which are scattered somewhat randomly through the tower.
"When you wanted to move a toilet, you had to make sure you weren't over someone's living room," Mr. Hedgecock said. "That made for a task -- in spades."
The architects and designers made a point of expanding the lobby and the views it affords, exploiting the fact that Central Park is just out the front door. "Before, you came in and couldn't see the park any more," Mr. Hedgecock said. "A lot of this work has been to open it up so that wherever you are, you are tied back into the park."
The hotel, which has been closed since last year, is to reopen Sept. 24, 60 years (almost to the day) after it was inaugurated.
At the Sherry Netherland, the management was not very forthcoming, other than to say that more than half of the 160 transient guest rooms are to be renovated.
At the Plaza, Mr. Trump said he "anticipated a start" over the next 12 months on the penthouse addition, which was announced three years ago. He said a plan to sell rooms as condominiums to investors, which was announced in April, would be filed "probably sometime by the end of the year."

HEADLINE: Focus: Omaha;
Thriving Through Both Boom and Bust

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

DATELINE: OMAHA

 BODY:
IN the late 1980's when Conagra, the giant food-processing company whose labels include Swift, Hunt, Wesson and Chun King, was seeking a suitable site for a new corporate headquarters, this former cattle and railroad junction on the prairie hardly seemed fitting.
A study commissioned by the company to determine the best location had placed its existing base in Omaha 18th. 
 Yet it was also a moment when the excesses of the 80's were drawing to a close. And some key Conagra executives whose roots were in the Midwest considered the down-home lifestyle that this city evoked to be more in harmony with the less pretentious 90's.
"The trend towards conservatism and simplicity became part of the appeal," said Janet Richardson, vice president for corporate facilities and services.
 Further, the public schools were in good shape, the air was clean, the traffic sparse and housing relatively cheap -- the Omaha Area Board of Realtors says the average single-family house still costs about $80,000.
 With a population of 350,000, Omaha was not as strained by the severe social and environmental problems overwhelming larger, more sophisticated urban areas. Moreover, Congagra had its origins in Nebraska.
 The result was the $60 million, 30-acre Conagra corporate campus completed in the fall of 1990. Replacing a decayed warehousing area downtown, the project is only one of a growing number of new developments in a community that has been largely untouched by the commercial real estate collapse infesting the rest of the country.
 Total office space completed in downtown Omaha in 1990 reached 5 million square feet, an increase of 38.9 percent over 1989, according to the city's Planning Department. And even though the overall vacancy rate for Class A, B and C office space now hovers around 18 percent, there is "very little left for anyone needing more than 10,000 square feet," said Thomas Peschio, president of Peschio and Company, commercial brokers and one of this city's business leaders.
 The vacancies, he said, are mostly centered among the smaller B and C spaces recently vacated by rapidly growing companies like Conagra which have been custom building of late. Rents, excluding operating cost, average $12 a square foot, an increase of 20 percent over the last five years.
 City officials are quick to say that the construction figures do not represent a speculative building boom. "We tend to be too small for the major promoters, and not glamorous enough for the investors from abroad," said Mayor P. J. Morgan.
 Rather, the pace of building is being generated by the expansion needs of companies already in town, many of which -- like food processing and telemarketing -- just happen to be shaping up as growth industries of the 90's.
Indeed, so many catalogue companies, credit-card servicing centers and hotel reservation services are consolidating their 800-number operations in Omaha that the city -- whose geometric towers rise from the pancake-flat surrounding prairie like the fabled Emerald City of Oz -- might easily qualify as the toll-free capital of America.
 U. S. West, the regional telecommunications company, has just completed a 300,000-square-foot, 15-story, office tower attached to a low-rise, 469,000-square-foot data processing center. Oak View Mall, a $22 million project now under construction, will provide the city with 450,000 square feet of new retail space when it opens later this year. The Gallup Organization established a polling center in 8,000 square feet of space here last spring.
IDELMAN TELEMARKETING, a local company, recently expanded into 20,000 square feet of space vacated by the Hyatt Hotel organization, which built a $3.5 million reservation center for its own expanding needs.
And initial plans are moving ahead for Gateway III, a public and private partnership with a 20-year plan for reviving 250 acres of rusting railroad repair yards adjacent to the Missouri River.
 As demand permits, the aim of Gateway III is to produce multi-use developments of office and retail space, residential units, a manmade lake and a marina and botanical center, said Michael C. Wiese, exeuctive director of the Omaha Development Council. Gateway I and II have already transformed other aging areas of the town's former marshalling yards and warehousing core into a modern mix of commercial uses, interwoven with plazas.
 Omaha is pushing ahead unburdened by excess office inventory in large part because of its farming roots. While so much of the rest of the nation was enjoying an orgy of a speculative office building Omaha's business leaders were being shaken by the sight of neighboring farmers loosing thousands of acres to the farm foreclosures that swept the Midwest during the mid 1980's. "If something like that could happen to our solid midwestern family farms we felt it could happen to anyone," said Gary Pryor, Omaha's planning director. "Psychologically, it made everybody cautious."
 Further, he added, nobody had much faith in the value of the Federal tax advantages driving the speculative boom elsewhere. "We'd already seen our farmers getting whiplashed from changes in Federal policy," added Mr. Pryor. And by the time the farm economy had recovered, the dangers of the speculative excesses in other regions had become all too apparent.
 The value of the Midwestern labor pool, with its old-fashioned work ethic, has also been treated with renewed respect in recent years, prompting corporations to expand rather than shut down smaller units already located in Omaha. "Our people were proving dependable," said Mr. Wiese. "They showed up for work. They were trainable. They had no regional accent so they were excellent for phone operations."
 Slowly but steadily Omaha's economic base began shifting gears from cattle and crops to communications. An example is the building of the U.S. West complex, which opened in June. Beta West, a development company from Denver that handled the project, built 70 percent more office space in the tower than the U.S. West communications company needed, anticipating a general demand for expansion.
"We felt downtown still lacked the sort of new space that offered more efficient operating costs and better access to modern telecommunications," said Bob Cardell, vice president of asset management at Beta West. Leases are in negotiation on two-thirds of the available space, he said.
CONAGRA took steps to make its move to a new headquarters cost-effective. As a major employer it was able to lobby the state legislature to provide the needed tax incentives for companies like itself interested in relocating or expanding in Nebraska. It also encouraged the city to use municipal powers of eminent domain plus tax dollars to help assemble the 107-acre parcel it needed. The tract holds the company's 500,000-square-foot, four-building, low-rise complex plus a new county park with a manmade lake and fountains that adjoin and adorn the downtown site.
"Our campus has became such an attractive place people want to hold weddings in the front lobby of the main building," Ms. Richardson said.
