LENGTH: 1761 words

HEADLINE: Fans Call Games a Bargain (Even With Peanuts and Cracker Jack)

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
WITH a big brood in tow, Phil Skrzyniarz of Cheshire entered Beehive Field in New Britain on a recent balmy evening. His group included five of his six children and two of their friends. They were all in high spirits, eager to watch the New Britain Red Sox play the Reading (Pa.) Phillies in an Eastern League baseball game and equally eager to besiege the concession stands for hot dogs, sodas and souvenirs. Mr. Skrzyniarz had spent $14 for tickets -- $1.50 for each of the children, who ranged from 5 to 13 years old, and $3.50 for himself. That total is $2 less than the price of a single field box seat at Fenway Park, where the New Britain team's parent club, the Boston Red Sox, play. Though he is a Boston fan, Mr. Skrzyniarz said, he seldom takes his family to a game there. "Much too expensive," he said.
A trip to a game in New Britain "is a much better deal," said Mr. Skrzyniarz, a purchasing agent for the Milton Bradley toy company. Counting refreshments for his group of eight, he said, a night out at Beehive costs about $45. "At Fenway, it would be at least three times as much," he added. 
 Mr. Skrzyniarz, who visits Beehive Field several times a season, is among the growing number of Connecticut residents who say that the state's only minor league baseball club is a good bargain for fans. "It's a pro team, and it's good baseball," he said of the class AA Eastern League, which is two steps below the big-league level.
Even though the team is in last place in the eight-team league, more than 20 games out of first place, the New Britain Red Sox are averaging 2,029 fans a game. And they are at a pace to exceed last year's attendance of 117,000. The Britsox, as the team is popularly known, are in striking distance of their record season attendance of 130,433, set in 1983, when the team moved from Bristol to New Britain. And that figure included the league playoffs, which New Britain is unlikely to reach this season. So why is the team doing so well at the box office while it is in last place, and the state is in the midst of a recession? Because it offers "a nice, wholesome night out at very reasonable prices," said Lois Schumey of Vernon after she entered the clean, compact ball park with her husband, Steve, and their children, Matt, 9, and Tricia, 4.
"We spent more than $100 to go to one game at Fenway Park in June," said Mr. Schumey. "And we paid $15 to park, which is more than it cost the four of us to buy tickets here. And to the kids, the quality of the baseball here is major league."
Baseball experts know that the level of play in New Britain is somewhat below the majors. But as the team's longtime owner, Joe Buzas, said, "When you come to Beehive Field, you get to see the stars of tomorrow today."
As owner, Mr. Buzas leases the stadium from the city and takes care of marketing the team, but the players and coaches are employees of the Boston team, which pays their salaries and can move them within its farm system, call them up to the parent club or trade them.
In recent years, the New Britain roster has included current Boston players like Roger Clemens, the star pitcher, and the outfielder Ellis Burks, as well as two Norwalk residents, Maurice (Mo) Vaughn, a first baseman, and Kevin Morton, a pitcher. Another promising player from the state, Jeff Bagwell of Killingworth, had a superb season at New Britain last year, earning Most Valuable Player honors and coming within a point of winning the league's batting title, too. Mr. Bagwell, who played college ball at the University of Hartford, was traded by the Red Sox to the Houston Astros and is having an outstanding rookie season with the team.
Before moving to New Britain in 1983, the farm club played for 10 years at Muzzy Field in Bristol, where future Boston stars like Jim Rice and Fred Lynn prepared for the big time.
"This is a fun place and a great place to take the family," said Mr. Buzas, who has owned more baseball teams (63 at last count) than anyone else in the game's history. "People are discovering that minor league baseball is terrific entertainment at a good price.
"And you know, the recession has helped us, because of our prices. You spend big, big bucks when you go to a big league game, particularly an entire family."
 
State's Surviving Franchise
 For a while in the 1970's and 1980's, Connecticut had three teams in the 68-year-old Eastern League -- in Bristol, West Haven and Waterbury. But attendance declined sharply in the 70's. The West Haven and Waterbury franchises folded in the 80's, leaving only New Britain since 1987.
In the last decade, attendance in the Eastern League, as in the minor leagues in general, has risen dramatically. It reached record heights the last two seasons, when the league drew more than a million spectators for the first time since 1949, the tail end of the minor leagues' heyday. Given its current pace, the league may set an attendance mark for the third year in a row.
Soaring ticket prices at major league stadiums, plus an increase in unruly fan behavior, have helped cozy little ball parks like Beehive Field thrive in recent years. Easily accessible via several interstate highways, Beehive, in the city-owned Willow Brook Park, offers free parking.
Concession prices are much lower than at big league stadiums. A new feature this season are picnic benches alongside a fence close by the hot dog, pizza and nacho stands.
With a capacity of 4,200, Beehive puts the fans close to the playing field.
"This is more like what I remember as a kid going to Ebbets Field in Brooklyn, where you always felt safe," said Bill Admirand, an advertising executive from Redding, as he entered Beehive Field for the first time with his wife, Peggy, their six children, ranging in age from 3 to 11, and some friends.
For most minor league players, Double-A ball marks the end of the road. Those who do go on to the next echelon -- in the case of the Red Sox, Pawtucket, R.I. -- are within a step of making it to the majors.
 
Asset for the City
 "It's a great opportunity to see young players who may go all the way," said Joe Mangiafico, a member of the New Britain Parks and Recreation Commission who rarely misses a home game. "And having the team here means a lot to the city of New Britain."
Just how much the city benefits economically from the ball team is difficult to assess. But it is a tangible asset in that it draws people to the city, if only to see a game and buy refreshments, and it focuses media attention on New Britain. In addition, players, live in the area from early April through August, and the visiting teams stay in nearby motels and eat in local restaurants. Under its current three-year contract the city also leases Beehive Field for $16,000 a season.
Promotional deals with local businesses are the lifeblood of minor league baseball. And the New Britain Red Sox do their share, under the leadership of Gerry Berthiaume, who is in his eighth season as vice president and general manager of the club. Promotions have produced the season's two biggest crowds. On June 26, Southern New England Telephone Company Night at Beehive, the company bought and dispensed all of that evening's tickets, and 3,400 fans turned out. Two days earlier, on WTIC Night, a near capacity crowd of 4,189 jammed into Beehive.
Other promotions range from food stores buying and distributing most tickets on a specific night to the appearance of celebrities like Max Patkin, billed as "the Clown Prince of Baseball," who will perform on Aug. 15. On Aug. 5 the Hall of Fame pitcher Bob Feller will take the mound in a Cleveland Indians uniform and toss pitches (now eminently hitable) to fans.
For years, most people attending Britsox games were from the New Britain and Hartford areas. But interviews before and during a recent game against the Reading Phillies found spectators from as far west as Bethel and as far south as Redding.
"Having players like Mo Vaughn and Kevin Morton play here drew more attention to the team in the southern part of the state, and that can mean more fans," said Mr. Berthiaume, himself a former minor league player. "We've noticed that we're getting people from farther away."
 
'12 to 14 Hours a Day'
 With a full-time staff of only three people, including himself, along with two summer interns, Mr. Berthiaume has to work long weeks and long hours.
"When the club is home, I'll put in from 12 to 14 hours a day, seven days a week," said Mr. Berthiaume who lives in nearby Berlin with his wife, Jenny, and their two young children. "But so will our other people."
Even with a part-time staff of 25 concession workers, ticket takers and ushers, Mr. Berthiaume is at times shorthanded, he said. When that happens, he and Mr. Buzas may dispense hot dogs, popcorn and Cracker Jack.
"You really get to know the fans when you're the general manager of a minor league ball club," Mr. Berthiaume said.
As an investment, the New Britain Red Sox are a blue-chip property. Mr. Buzas was given the franchise in 1957 when the Red Sox Double-A farm club was in Allentown, Pa. and floundering financially. He later operated the club in York and Reading, Pa., in Pittsfield, Mass., and in Pawtucket before moving to Bristol in 1973.
How much is the club worth today?
"I was offered $5 million for it last year, but I'm not going to sell," said Mr. Buzas, who also owns the Portland Beavers of the Triple-A Pacific Coast League and was the opening-day shortstop for the New York Yankees in 1945, his only season in the big leagues. "I'm having too much fun. How many people can make a living at their hobby as I've been doing for 35 years?"
 
 
 
How to Go to a Game At Beehive
 Where: Beehive Field, the home of the New Britain Red Sox, is about 12 miles southwest of Hartford. From the southern part of the state take the Merritt and Wilbur Cross parkways to Route 9 north. Then take Exit 24 in Kensington, which leads directly to Willow Brook Park. From the west and east take Interstate 84 east to Exit 35, then Route 72 east to Route 9 south, getting off at the Ellis Street exit. Then make lefts at the first two traffic lights to Beehive Field.
When: Night games start at 7:15 P.M. Day games (usually only on Sundays) are at 2 P.M.
 Parking: Ample free parking is available in front of the ballpark.
Tickets: General admission seats are $3.50, $1.50 for children 16 years old and under, and $2 for the elderly. Box seats are $4, $4.50 and $5.
For more information, call 224-8383.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Gaining Ground

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
The freefall of the real estate market may have others nervously pondering the future, but Dave Liniger, co-founder and chairman of Re/Max International Inc., is fairly sanguine.
A recently released survey of residential real estate transactions involving brokers showed Re/Max picking up the most market share of the country's seven biggest franchise brokerage chains. The survey by Real Trends, an industry newsletter, reported that Re/Max, the second-biggest chain, increased its share to 7 percent in 1990, from 6.1 percent in 1989, edging up on the industry leader, Century 21, which dropped slightly to 10 percent, from 10.2 percent. 
 Unlike many of its competitors, Re/Max has continued to open offices during the recession. The 18-year-old company, based in Englewood, Colo., now has more than 1,800 offices.
Mr. Liniger says Re/Max's unusual franchise structure -- in which agents form partnerships much in the way lawyers do, rather than split commissions -- draws experienced agents with established client lists.
Now, Mr. Liniger, 45, has earmarked the relocation business as Re/Max's next growth area. Mr. Liniger acknowledges that Re/Max, with just 2,000 transactions last year geared to executive transfers, is small in comparison with giants like Coldwell Banker and Prudential, which may each do as many as 50,000. But he says a new emphasis on such transfers has already produced 3,500 transactions this year for Re/Max.
"The likelihood that they will become one of the top five players in relocations, without an acquisition, is very, very limited, but they will have the ability to grow," said Steve Murray, co-editor of Real Trends. "I expect they will be good competitors."

HEADLINE: Business Diary

 BODY:
COMPANIES
 
Chemical Takes On a Partner, and a Giant Is Born 

The consolidation that has melded regional banks over the last year has blown into New York and the money center banking community. Ending more than a year of on-again, off-again speculation about such a marriage, Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover last week agreed to combine in a $2.2 billion stock swap that will create the country's second-largest banking company, after Citicorp, with $135.5 billion in assets. From weakness, they hope, will grow strength. Their hangups: More than 17 percent of Chemical Bank's commercial real estate loans are nonperforming, while Manufacturers' mistakes are problem third-world loans. The banks say a merger could save $650 million. But the savings will not come without labor pains. Up to 70 of the pair's combined 660 branches will be closed and 6,200 of their 45,411 employees will lose their jobs. Chemical's banner will fly once the merger is complete later this year, but John F. McGillicuddy, Manny Hanny's chairman, will be the new chairman -- until his scheduled retirement in 1993. Then Walter V. Shipley, Chemical's current chairman, is slated to move into his office.

Bank Profits Tumble
 
Bank stocks rallied as investors speculated on other bank matches. Second-quarter earnings showed why there may be more. While a few big banks, including Manufacturers, Chase and BankAmerica, reported gains, many were hurt by the need to squirrel away more money to cover future loan losses. Earnings slipped at Chemical, Fleet/Norstar and Security Pacific. Among the poorest performers was Citicorp, whose profits plunged by 83 percent, in part because of a $1 billion addition to its loan-loss reserve. But some analysts believe the banks' nonperforming assets have finally reached their peak.
 
 Rain on Insurers' Parade
 
When Executive Life, the "junk bond" lover of the West, was seized by regulators, industry officials argued that it was a fluke rather than a red flag that insurers were headed for a savings-and-loan-style crisis. So the seizure by New Jersey regulators of Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company last Monday was sobering. Among the nation's most conservative and respected insurers, Mutual Benefit's bad real estate loans have wreaked havoc with its portfolio of assets, valued at $13.5 billion last December. Many of its 400,000 policyholders have cashed in their accounts. And to prevent the largest insurance failure in history, regulators moved in and froze withdrawals. The savings crisis, it's not. But stay tuned to a new debate in Washington over the need for more potent regulation of insurers.
 
Another insurer with a sinking portfolio got a helping hand. Groupe Axa S.A., a leading French insurer, invested $1 billion in hobbled Equitable Life, a sum that could eventually translate into a 49 percent stake.
 
A.T.& T. Wins a Big One
 
To those who have ridiculed as hair-brained its computer strategy -- and its $7.48 billion plan to acquire the NCR Corporation -- American Telephone and Telegraph now has a powerful response: a $1.4 billion computer contract with the Internal Revenue Service. A.T.& T. and its partner, Pyramid Technology, beat out both International Business Machines and Lockheed for the contract, one of the largest of its sort awarded by the Government. Pyramid, whose stock flew up $3.75 on the news, to $18 a share, will supply 3,200 high-performance computers under terms of the deal, which also calls for 50,000 work stations and products to link them together. If only doing business with Uncle Sam were more profitable.

Another arrow for A.T.& T.'s quiver: Despitea promised $4 billion charge against earnings sometime this year for its purchase of NCR, the company's shares jumped $1.625, to $39.625, on Thursday after it announced a 26 percent rise in second-quarter earnings, signalling Wall Street's approval of its direction.
 
The Top It's Apparently Not
 
Warner Books has given Donald Trump's latest book, "Surviving at the Top," published by Random House before the developer's run-ins with the banks, a humbling facelift. The paperback version sports a trumped-down title: "The Art of Survival."
 
Pale Profits at I.B.M.
 
The International Business Machines Corporation has big blues. Battered by heavy-duty world computer competition, its second-quarter earnings dropped 92 percent, while revenues fell 10.7 percent. The company said it would be forced to cut its head count by 17,000 this year, making a total of 64,000 displaced workers since 1986. Yet its shares rose $2.25 on Friday, to $100.50, for how could the blues get bluer?
 
Brokers Rake It In
 
The payoff of a winnowed Wall Street? Record earnings at Merrill Lynch & Company and Smith Barney, Harris, Upham & Company. Cost cutting, added to the recent vitality of the equities markets, contributed to a smart-looking season.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY


Greenspan's Good News
 
Alan Greenspan delivered something of a thank you note to President Bush for his reappointment to a four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve. In one of his most upbeat forecasts, he told Congress last week that the recession was over, inflation was quieting, the deficit narrowing and that consumer and corporate debt would soon level off. A dynamic recovery it may not be, but a solid one it might, he said. What better way for the President to open the 1992 re-election season than with a rebound?

Housing's Mild Upswing
 
Consistent with the predictions of a tepid recovery, housing starts rose a mild 5.2 percent in June, the third straight monthly increase. While June was the first million-plus month since November, with 1,040,000 new starts, the new activity is less impressive than that of previous recoveries, economists warned. The West was the only region with a decline for the month, while the Northeast showed the sharpest rebound, of nearly 30 percent.
 
 Trade Horizon Lightens
 
Although the trade deficit widened slightly in May, the imbalance was the third best showing in eight years. And the trade gap with Japan, long the largest contributor to the deficit, narrowed to $2.4 billion for the month, the slimmest difference since February 1984. May was also the first month in which petroleum consumption returned to pre-Persian Gulf War levels. And despite slowing growth abroad, exports dipped only moderately.
 
Factories Churn It Out
 
Auto sales put a tiger in the economy's tank in June, when production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities climbed for the third consecutive month -- by seven-tenths of 1 percent. The increase, though, was broad-based. One reason: companies have had to start restocking inventories that have been shriveling since February. June auto sales, for instance, outpaced production by 1.3 million units, according to C. J. Lawrence. The brokerage firm says the auto inventory-to-sales ratio is the lowest since 1986.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
No Grand Prize for the Soviets
 
The seven leading industrialized nations sent Mikhail S. Gorbachev begging. While the Soviet President left the economic summit meeting without the direct aid he had sought, there was a consolation prize: technical assistance in areas like oil-field management, food distribution, defense industry conversion and associate membership in the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. Throwing money at a system as moth-eaten as the Soviet Union's, the Group of Seven concluded, would be wasteful. But generous Western aid could follow if the Soviets make concerted strides, under the tutelage of international lending agencies, toward a market-oriented system.
 
The Group of Seven leaders also pledged to complete by the end of the year a round of negotiations, stalled in December by a clash over farm subsidies, to set new rules for more than $1 trillion in world trade.
 
A New Chain of Corruption
 
The plot of corruption in Japan thickens. The last round of scandal involved questionable compensation payments made by four of the country's biggest brokerages to their clients. Now a new wave. More than a dozen of the country's biggest manufacturers have been accused of industrial espionage. Police in Tokyo and Osaka have confiscated records that press reports say suggest that several companies paid an industrial spy for information about Komatsu Ltd., a maker of construction equipment. Documents also may have been stolen from a joint venture of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and Caterpillar Inc. Judging from the past, resignations in high places, as officials rush to take the rap and restore corporate honor, will follow.
 
B.C.C.I.'s Connections
 
How deep were the political tentacles of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International? The bank, which was seized by regulators in seven countries earlier this month and is now under investigation for fraud, contributed $8 million to charitable organizations created by former President Jimmy Carter and used Andrew Young, the former Mayor of Atlanta, as a consultant. The bank has built ties with American public officials to help it do business, although there is no suggestion that Mr. Carter performed any favors.

HEADLINE: About Cars;
In a Small World, Mirage Is an Oasis

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
ONE of the nice things about the mail is that it carries pats on the head. But it also carries brickbats, and I have been catching a few of those lately from people who are mad at the Japanese.
For one thing, these folk do not forgive World War II. But they appear to be even madder about the fact that the Asians build world-class cars.
That ability is certain, however, and nobody -- least of all the automakers in Detroit -- will quibble with Japan as a tough competitor. Japan is beating the Motor City's brains out, and its biggest club is not, as some believe, a misguided public perception of foreign quality. Like it or not, the quality is there. 
 The Power Report, published by J. D. Power and Associates, reaffirmed that this month with its latest and much-vaunted Customer Satisfaction Index, in which Nissan's Infiniti and Toyota's Lexus pushed Acura out of first place, a spot that the Honda Division had held firmly for the past four years.
 Mercedes was three slots down on the Power survey, and the German luxury car was followed in order by Acura, Honda and Toyota. In fact, eight of the first 14 nameplates were Japanese. Only three, Cadillac, Buick and Oldsmobile, were domestics.
And, if you rent various makes or have other occasion to drive a lot of different cars, it is easy to put credence in the Power figures, which are calculated from a poll of thousands of owners of new automobiles.
No question, the Japanese do know how to do it, and one model, new for 1991, is a case in point. It is the front-wheel-drive Mitsubishi Mirage GS, a four-door sport sedan that ought to please commuters, young families and anyone else who wants space and economy in a small car with a bit of flare.
The GS is the top of the subcompact Mirage line, the others being the base Mirage and Mirage LS four-doors and a couple of hatchback coupes. The lesser cars carry transversely mounted 1.5-liter engines that put out 92 horsepower, but the GS offers a 1.6-liter four with multipoint fuel injection and 16 valves working off roller rocker arms to produce 123 horses.
For '91, all Mirages have what Mitsubishi calls a new "corporate-identity grille," but the GS is distinguished by its red accents on the bumpers and side moldings, by a bit of chrome around the windshield and by twin tailpipes, the extensions of a stainless-steel exhaust system.
The tester was painted Laguna blue metallic, and most of the trim was of the blackout variety, with alloy wheels as bright points of reference. The optional 14-inch wheels also carried fat Goodyear Eagle tires, part of a suspension package that has been tuned for performance.
Stopping power comes from four-wheel disk brakes, and a five-speed stick is standard, with an electronically controlled four-speed automatic as an optional transmission. Even without options, the car is well equipped, and most of the accessories that are missing can be ordered for surprisingly little money.
The blue GS had a gray cloth and plastic interior and the wheel was wrapped in vinyl, but those were minor deviations from what otherwise might be considered a luxury cabin. There is actual legroom in back, and the rear bench is split so that either side can be folded flat to extend cargo capacity.
The back seat also has a folding armrest in its center, and there are deeply bolstered buckets up front. The driver's seat adjusts three ways, and there is -- wonder of wonders -- a steering wheel that both tilts and telescopes.
 Unfortunately, the four-spoke wheel does not possess an air bag, and that means the Mitsubishi has passive restraints, a k a. annoying and dangerous mechanized seatbelts. That is one of the few complaints about this car, however, and the Mirage shows what can be done with relatively little space.
Standard equipment includes tinted glass, intermittent wipers, on-board diagnostics, power sideview mirrors, remote releases for fuel-filler door and the lighted trunk, a rear defroster and vanity mirrors on both front visors.
Also standard are two of those nice little touches that make you laugh and then keep smiling. The joke is the 150-m.p.h. speedometer. What keeps you smiling is a "chameleon" instrument panel that uses black-on-white numerals during the day and that averts eye-strain by changing to green on blue at night.
An optional "convenience package" adds power equipment, and an air-conditioner is the biggest extra with a pricetag of $756. But, with it all, the Mirage GS adds up to a good buy. The base is $10,509, and the test vehicle had a sticker that, with cruise control and a top-of-the-line radio, was a mere $13,117.
Oh, I almost forgot. There is one other nice thing about this Japanese car. It is made by American workers at the Mitsubishi-Chrysler plant in Normal, Ill.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mirage GS: The top of Mitsubishi's subcompact line. New for '91, the Mirage GS four-door offers a passenger compartment that is relatively roomy for a small car. The rear seatbacks split and fold individually to add cargo room. (Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America)

HEADLINE: All About/Beer;
Behind All the Bonhomie, the Brewing Industry Gets Tough

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Sometimes it's hard to tell if the beer stein is half full or half empty. Just ask a brewer.
United States beer shipments increased 2.8 percent in 1990, to 193.2 million barrels, after years of essentially flat sales, according to Market Watch, an industry magazine. Per capita consumption also rose, to 24.9 gallons last year from 24.4 gallons in 1989. But shipments fell steeply in the first quarter of 1991 and are expected to be down again in the second quarter. 
 Industry analysts say both the increase and the decline are aberrations prompted by a doubling of the Federal excise tax, from 16 cents to 32 cents a six-pack, which went into effect at the beginning of the year. Many brewers also tacked on their own price increases, which they had been planning anyway, but then offered deep discounts to wholesalers who would buy in volume before the end of the year.
The result was a big increase in fourth-quarter shipments, which left wholesalers with a surplus in the first quarter, prompting a decline in sales. At the retail level, the tax hikes and price increases produced sticker shock, particularly for imports, some of which rose to $7 a six-pack.
"Between the last quarter of 1990 and the first quarter of 1991, if you averaged what happened, you'd wind up just about even or slightly down," said Paul Gillette, publisher of the California Beverage Hotline, an industry newsletter. Brewers "are not going to increase per capita consumption; it will probably decline slightly," he said. "There will still be growth, but it will not be equal to the growth in the population."

 
 
Falling Consumption
The Big 3: Strength Begets Strength
 The three biggest brewers now command 75 percent of the American beer market. In an environment of falling consumption and essentially flat sales, strong producers grow by taking market share away from weaker ones.
According to Market Watch, Anheuser-Busch Inc. increased its market share to 43.5 percent in 1990 from 42 percent in 1989; the Miller Brewing Company to 22.2 percent from 22 percent; and the Coors Brewing Company to 9.9 percent from 9.4 percent. At the same time, the Stroh Brewery Company dropped to 8 percent from 9.3 percent; and the G. Heileman Brewing Company dropped to 6.1 percent from 6.6 percent. Imports also lost share.
One area where the big three gained was in secondary, lower-priced brands, particularly lower-priced light beers, like Anheuser-Busch's Busch Light Draft, which shipped 2.4 million barrels in its first year, and Coors' Keystone Light, which shipped 1.4 million barrels, said Benjamin Steinman, associate publisher of Beer Marketer's Insights, an industry newsletter. "This was occurring even prior to the recession, but the recession, if anything, accelerated the trend," he said.

 
 
Drier and Lighter
Extending the Line To Gain Share
 A common strategy for gaining market share is extending an existing line of beer, typically adding a lower calorie, light version, usually called a "dry" beer, which means that it has less aftertaste. Thus, Budweiser begat Bud Light and Bud Dry Draft, the latter a double extension, featuring less aftertaste and no pasteurization, a feature further marketed as a "draft" beer.
Extensions are considered an easier sell than entirely new brands because they build on established customer loyalties. Advertising for the extension also increases consumer exposure to the whole brand family. But extensions carry their own risks, including customer confusion and cannibalizing the parent brand. Coors Light now outsells Coors by two to one. Miller Genuine Draft's steady gain in share matches Miller High Life's decline.
"The brewing industry has become much more of a new product game in the last two years, and it is a lot easier to create brand recognition if you have an established name attached to it," said Mr. Steinman. With the exception of Keystone from Coors, and the non-alcoholic Sharps from Miller and O'Doul's from Anheuser-Busch, the successful new products of the last two years have all been extensions, he said.
Line extensions do not come cheaply. Market Watch reports that Anheuser-Busch spent $70 million in advertising and promotion for Bud Dry, which is the No. 1 beer in the dry segment, with 1990 shipments of 3.2 million barrels. And some of those shipments may have come at the expense of Budweiser: shipments fell by 200,000 barrels in 1990, to 48.3 million.
As extensions are piled on extensions, some analysts fret that the brewers are creating confusion among customers and weakening long-term brand allegiance. Confronted someday with a "Dark Lite Dry Draft" brew, the fear is that bewildered consumers might retreat to a Coke or a Pepsi.
"When there are so many hybrids, brand loyalties begin to suffer," said Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark Inc., a Los Angeles-based consultant to the beverage industry. "The genuine new product is where the gold has always been," he said.

 
 
Non-alcoholic Beers
Brewed for the Taste Not the Kick
 Perhaps the most unlikely new product success has been the non-alcoholic brews. Long a niche product aimed at recovering alcoholics and people who for religious or health reasons abstained from alcohol, these brews joined the mainstream in late 1989 with the entry of Miller and Anheuser-Busch. The brews are made so that they contain no more than one-half of 1 percent alcohol, which fulfills the legal definition of non-alcoholic.
Miller and Anheuser-Busch use different processes. Miller brews Sharps at a low temperature to retard alcohol production while Anheuser-Busch makes O'Doul's as a regular beer and then filters out the alcohol. But both have promoted their non-alcoholic brews as products for the drinker of regular beer.
"The drinker profile for Sharps is people who are predisposed to beer and the taste of beer," said Thomas Cardella, Miller's category director for allied brands. "The product provides an additional menu selection to the beer drinker," at times when other alternatives are likely to be bottled waters or soft drinks, he said.
Non-alcoholic brew sales grew from 9.6 million cases in 1989 to over 18 million cases in 1990, according to Market Watch. Sharps was by far the market leader, at 5.5 million cases, ahead of O'Doul's at 3.3 million and Kingsbury, from Heileman's, at 3.2 million. The entire category still accounts for just 1 percent of the beer market, but early indications are that strong growth has continued in 1991.
Advertising has played a big part. "Certainly the fact that you had Miller putting $14 million into media on Sharps and Anheuser-Busch $7 million on O'Doul's had an impact," said Mr. Steinman. Timing was another factor. "Given the shifting societal attitudes towards alcohol, the timing couldn't have been better," he said.
 
 
 
THE MICROBREWERIES' MACRO IMPACT
 Just as the boutique wineries which blossomed in California in the 1960's and 1970's revitalized the wine industry, a proliferation of microbreweries is bringing new excitement to the beer industry. While each brewery is by definition tiny, they collectively account for about 500,000 barrels.
"The brewing industry needs every brewer it can get," said Fritz Maytag, who as proprietor of the Anchor Brewery in San Francisco is considered the father of the micro movement. While Anchor may lose an occasional sale to one of the new upstarts, "I think we are building the category together," he said. "I don't think we hurt each other at all."
In some markets, notably Northern California, Oregon and Washington, micros account for one or two percent of market share. The United States now has 89 microbreweries and 149 "brewpubs," which are microbreweries attached to restaurants, up from 64 micros and 107 brewpubs at the end of 1989, according to the Association of Brewers in Boulder, Colo.
"What these breweries are offering are specialty beers to people who are more aware of the qualities of the food and beverages they consume and are willing to pay," said Charles Papazian, director of the association There has been "a recognition by the American consumer that what people used to believe was import quality beer can be brewed in this country," he said.
Microbrewer products tend to be heavy ales more like Watneys Red Barrel or Bass than Budweiser, and even the lagers have more hops and, therefore, a more bitter, herbal taste than typical American beers. "You may not like the style, but you will find consistent quality and big flavor," said Tom Pirko of Bevmark, a beverage industry consultant. The growth of the category "will depend on the money invested and how long they can maintain the quality," he said.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 17; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1023 words

HEADLINE: Help the Russians, Not Gorbachev

BYLINE: By Bill Bradley; Bill Bradley, a Democrat, is Senator from New Jersey.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The London economic summit meeting ended without the leaders of the Group of Seven committing massive sums of money to prop up the Soviet political system and economy. But American taxpayers should remain vigilant: the Bush and Gorbachev administrations will get together again to look for ways to finance the Soviet future. The U.S. appears more committed to Mr. Gorbachev than to a set of principles.
Before the Soviet economy can be reformed effectively, democratic values and methods must be allowed to sink deeper roots. The Gorbachev regime faces a crisis of legitimacy. It does not have popular support. Otherwise, why would President Gorbachev avoid a vote like the one that elected Boris Yeltsin as leader of the Russian republic? Only with democratically elected leaders does the Soviet Union have a chance of taking the steps necessary to avoid catastrophe, much less to raise its people's living standard. 
 The old machine of party members, K.G.B. fossils, discredited bureaucrats and elements of the military still holds power, but it lacks legitimacy. Conditions worsen but it refuses to do what needs to be done, especially cutting Government spending.
Mr. Yeltsin told U.S. Senators recently that the Russian republic will reduce its payment to the central Government from 70 billion to 25 billion rubles. The result will be a bigger Soviet deficit in addition to a distribution system that has broken down and a G.N.P. in a free fall. The bloated Soviet military not only threatens us, but also the Soviet economy. Military spending has to be cut. Without action, the mammoth deficit will lead to hyperinflation.
The leadership also faces a dilemma on internal security. To obtain cooperation on economic reform and to acquire respectability in the community of nations, it must rein in the security forces that murder unarmed citizens in the Baltics and elsewhere. Repression destroys the dreams of freedom and hopes that the Soviets have changed. Citizens who are being persecuted are also unlikely to make economic sacrifices. Yet, once the totalitarian methods go, the political machine itself will be in danger.
To prevent national disaster, the old machine must yield more of its authority to the grass-roots groups -- democrats, religious believers, environmentalists, independent trade unionists, entrepreneurs, nationalists and others -- that have legitimacy but no power. How quickly that transfer occurs and in what form will determine the nation's future.
The recent accord between the presidents of the central Government and the republics represents the beginning, not the end, of conflict. Who controls natural resources? Who holds power to tax? Whose laws take precedence? None of these questions has been answered. Revolutions have been fought over such issues at other times and in other places. It will not be easier for the Soviet Union.
Letting markets emerge and function with a pricing mechanism, a banking system and pay based on productivity will do more for the average Soviet family than massive Western aid. For example, the Soviet Union last year lost 100 million metric tons of grain to corruption and inefficiency in the distribution system. Yet, trade in grain is still illegal. In June, over my strong objections, the Administration guaranteed $1.5 billion in credit to the Soviet Union to buy four million metric tons of grain. Instead, if the Soviets would decriminalize trade in grain, they would recover far more grain than we give them, without cost to U.S. taxpayers.
Now Mr. Gorbachev tells the world that he considers his unelected regime "entitled" to even more aid from U.S. taxpayers. Some in the West have suggested guaranteed loans, subsidized interest rates and guaranteed investment in the Soviet Union. None of that will make much difference to the Soviet future but it will certainly drain the U.S. Treasury. It reminds me of the S.& L. scandal, except that when things go bad in the Soviet Union we won't have a Resolution Trust Corporation to take control of the assets.
We could help the Soviets with technical assistance, exchange programs, and an associate membership in the International Monetary Fund, but first we owe them candor. Joining the international economy means tough competition. So long as private property is not protected by law and state monopolies are preserved by force, the Soviet future will be bleak. We should dispel the illusion that economic reform will be achieved by the shortcut of political deal-making. In an open world economy, capital flows to places with higher rates of return. No President can order U.S. businesses to lose money in the Soviet Union. Only the citizens, laws and institutions of a new society can make it attractive for investment.
Finally, we must not undercut our message about democracy with actions that jeopardize legitimate democratic movements, such as those in the Baltic states. The Administration's support for the Baltics has been limited to feebly reaffirming that the U.S. never legally recognized their annexation into the Soviet Union.
If President Bush soon sends a Soviet trade agreement to Congress, we will have a chance to test the sincerity of those words. We have most-favored-nation treaties with all three Baltic nations, but they were suspended in 1951 to prevent the special treatment from rewarding Stalin. Now it is likely that the Administration will ask for that status for the whole Soviet Union. The longstanding agreements with the Baltics will be forgotten, out of fear of offending Moscow. If we believe what we say about the Baltics' separate status, then any trade pact with the Soviets should be accompanied by reinstituting the agreement for the Baltics.
The course ahead will be difficult for that continental nation rich in natural resources and human talent. It must be chosen freely by the Soviet people. They are in control of their own destiny. Our influence lies in our willingness to join them in reducing military spending and in the example of our economic and political values -- not in the size of the check we write to Mr. Gorbachev.

HEADLINE: Dong Beijing a 2d Favor?

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 20

 BODY:
As the Senate prepares to vote on whether to suspend trade advantages for China, many experts say the initial beneficiaries of such a cutoff would be the very hard-liners that the sanctions are aimed at.
 The Senate is expected to vote soon, perhaps Monday, on revoking most-favored-nation trade advantages. The goal of the cutoff would be to encourage China to free dissidents from its prisons, end the use of torture, and ease the repression that prevails from Tibetan monasteries in the west to universities in eastern cities like Shanghai and Harbin. 
 The problem for the United States is that a cutoff of most-favored-nation trade status would probably strike hardest -- at least at first -- at budding capitalists, whose factories might close; pro-Americans, who would have to lie low during the denunciations of Yankee treachery; and moderates in the Government, who would probably lose ground to the hard-liners.
"There's no doubt in my mind that revoking M.F.N. would only strengthen the hard-line constituency and worsen the human rights situation," said David L. Shambaugh, a China scholar from the University of London. "It would fuel the xenophobic impulses of the ideologues who seek to close China's doors."
 
Outcome Is Hard to Predict
 To be sure, it is nearly impossible to predict what will happen in China over any length of time, and the gain to the hard-liners might not last long.
In the longer term, the economic distress might even work against them, by bringing an abrupt coup in the Central Committee or a revolution in the streets. The result could be democracy, or something less palatable.
"Cutting off M.F.N. leaves you with two possibilities," a Western diplomat said. "The first is an even more hard-line regime still thumbing its nose at the rest of the world. The second is 'Apocalypse Now': they can't keep a lid on things, there's chaos in the streets, and they come up with a new system, whether it's a military dictatorship or something else."
It is difficult to be sure of public opinion in China. But the overwhelming majority of people with whom the topic was discussed in scores of conversations in recent months said they hoped the trade status would be extended.
But they often admitted that they were torn: on the one hand, they would like the United States to punish Prime Minister Li Peng and make the hard-liners "lose face"; on the other hand, they do not want to suffer economic hardship.
 
Some Favor a Bluff
 Many intellectuals say they hope the trade benefits will be extended only after a long struggle. That would put the Beijing Government on notice that it had better improve its image or risk losing most-favored-nation status next year. They say they favor trade sanctions as a bluff, but not their actual use.
An outright cutoff of the current low tariffs is considered unlikely, in part because President Bush is determined to maintain trade links with China. One possibility is that most-favored-nation status will be prolonged conditionally, with future extensions granted only if China makes progress on human rights issues.
Most Chinese do not seem familiar with the idea of conditional renewal of the trade status. When the issue was explained, some said they favored it -- if the conditions were ones that China would be likely to meet.
Many Chinese seem more enthusiastic about Western denunciations of human rights abuses than they are about trade sanctions. Many favor measures that would make their own leaders lose face without losing trade.
 
A 'Radio Free China'
 Another proposal batting around Capitol Hill that fits in with the thinking of many Chinese intellectuals is a "Radio Free China," modeled on Radio Free Europe. The State Department opposes this idea, however, because it would certainly sour diplomatic relations with Beijing.
Both advocates and opponents of most-favored-nation status argue that their approach is the best one for improving the human rights situation in China. But history suggests that the West, whatever it does, is unlikely to have a major impact on China.
The United States' efforts against China in the 1950's only made the country more radical, and the Soviet Union found at the end of that decade that economic leverage was useless in trying to prod China in the directions it wanted.
The only country that has truly succeeded in molding China for any prolonged period is Mongolia, which in the 13th century took the extreme approach of invading China and establishing its own dynasty.

HEADLINE: Northeast Notebook: Lewes, Del.;
A New Old Inn On the Shore

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD

 BODY:
THIS quaint seaside community that has for years been in the shadow of its southern neighbors is beginning to come into its own, thanks in part to the $2 million restoration of a former boarding house on the city's main street.
The New Devon Inn is getting to be a major lodging attraction in this city of 2,245, particularly for couples without children who want to spend a holiday on the Atlantic Coast. 
 "The inn has been a big plus," said Betsy W. Alwood, a Washington transplant whose husband, John, a former high school principal, opened a neighborhood bookstore a year ago. "It provides quality accommodations for tourists who like the nostalgia of Lewes."
The former Valley of the Swans Hotel was restored by a local real estate agent and a Washington attorney.
D. Dale Jenkins, a Delaware realtor who had been doing condominium conversions of older properties, felt that the boarding house, which had declined steadily since the 1970's, was a key deterrent to the revitalization of the city's downtown.
Built in 1926 by the Lewes Hotel Company and named the Caesar Rodney Hotel, for the 18th-century Delaware patriot, it had been an attraction on the Delaware shore as late as the 1950's.
By the time Ms. Jenkins brought her investor partner, Bernard Nash, to look at the property, it had become a residence hotel with efficiency apartments and a pool hall in the basement.
The pair bought the property in the late 80's for $387,000, then gutted the three-story building, with Ms. Jenkins acting as the general contractor. She removed everything but the main staircase and the pine floors in the guest rooms. Efficiency kitchens for the boarders were removed, and bathrooms were added for each of the 24 new rooms and two suites.
Ms. Jenkins furnished the hotel with antiques so that each guest room has a different character. The renovation includes six shops, most already leased, exhibiting space for the local art league and still-vacant space for a restaurant.
The management does not encourage booking of children under 16, and television sets are available only on request.
The occupancy rate of the new hotel has been strong, increasing steadily since the reopening early last year. The hotel was completely booked for New Year's Eve, when Lewes holds its own version of the New York City ball dropping.
"Lewes is getting on the map," said Mayor Alfred A. Stango, who led the city for 24 years. "The hotel has helped a lot."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The New Devon Inn, the renovated seaside attraction in Lewes, Del. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Israelis, Talk or Pain

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 20

 BODY:
No matter what happens when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visits on Sunday, for the people of Israel his stop in Jerusalem will likely bring a profound change in their lives.
 Of course, if the Israeli Government says yes, makes the requested concessions and agrees to attend a regional peace conference, there is the chance that at long last many Israelis could realize their fondest wish, to make peace with all their neighbors. But the answer is widely expected to be no, meaning a worsening of tensions with the Arabs and expected economic repercussions from Israel's main benefactor, Washington. 
 Shimon Peres, head of the opposition Labor Party, was not just promoting party politics this afternoon when he said, "I estimate that nothing will happen, and I regret it very much."
Early this week the small parties that give Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir his governing majority plainly told him they would withdraw their support, meaning the Government would fall, if he agrees to Mr. Baker's terms.
 
Hard for Shamir to Say Yes
 Mr. Shamir's record suggests that he is not likely to ignore the warning. Most people here say they believe he will give Mr. Baker a maybe, saying he wants more time to think things over.
The Prime Minister probably cannot say yes, even though Mr. Baker comes with only two, seemingly small procedural requests -- accept a passive United Nations observer at the conference, and allow the conference to reconvene periodically.
It is true that the Government opposes both ideas on their face. But the underlying problem is that by agreeing to them, the right-wing Likud party would have to attend the conference. Once there, every other participant would ask Israel to do what the Likud has vowed never to consider -- to give up territory in exchange for peace.
But even as Mr. Baker makes his way here to discuss peace, the talk across the nation this week has been on the possibilities of war.
 
Israel to Ask for $10 Billion
 When President Bush warned that the United States would attack if Iraq did not disclose the location of its nuclear weapons research installations, Eli Eshet, the Tel Aviv city manager, announced that the city was making a fast check of its bomb shelters. Many Israelis fear they would be victimized by Scud missiles once again, if the United States bombs Iraq.
But the more certain threat is not military but social and economic. Even as Mr. Shamir weighs whether to rebuff the United States and evoke the entire world's ire, Israel needs America's friendship just now as much as at any time in recent years.
The problem is finding jobs and homes for the Soviet Jews who have immigrated here en masse. In just over a month, Israel will make its planned request for $10 billion in American loan guarantees to build Soviet Jewish housing. And the certain wisdom in Jerusalem is that Washington will say no if Mr. Shamir turns Mr. Baker down now.
 
Draconian Financial Plan
 If that occurs, Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai has plainly warned the nation that life in Israel would be much less comfortable for years to come, so draconian is the financial contingency plan he has prepared.
"If we have to implement the plan, a very heavy burden will fall on the shoulders of the Israeli citizen, both the present and the future," he said. "I hope we won't have to do it."
In his plan are tax increases, though Israel already has among the world's highest tax rates. The Government would have to cut its budgets for education and health care, though professionals in both fields say funding has already slid below the red lines. In addition, prices on a wide range of Government-subsidized goods and services would have to be raised.
But even with all that, Michael Bruno, head of the Bank of Israel, warns that none of it would be enough. His staff predicts that unemployment nationwide would rise to about 18 percent. And in the end, the Soviet Jews would simply stop coming. That, President Chaim Herzog said in an interview, would be a calamity in many ways as painful as any war.
 
'It Would Be a Tragedy'
 "It would be a tragedy very great indeed," he said. "It will discredit Israel in the eyes of world Jewry and cause great social unrest here."
The Bank of Israel predicted in a recent report that not only would immigration stop, but emigration would pick up too; tens of thousands of Israel's young people would move away.
A few weeks ago, Rafi Melnick, a Bank of Israel official who wrote the report, said: "I can imagine that Shamir is not preoccupied these days with economics, but he should be. The Government is busy with other things, negotiations with Baker."
Three days later, when Mr. Shamir retracted a pledge Foreign Minister David Levy had made to Mr. Baker on an important procedural point for the proposed regional conference, the Prime Minister said he was not so preoccupied with Mr. Baker after all.
 
Not Enough Jobs and Homes
 "I have more serious preoccupations now," he said. "My thoughts are dedicated mainly to the absorption of Soviet immigrants."
Whatever Mr. Shamir's thoughts, the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel has already slowed quite a lot. A new Soviet passport law and the new bureacracy that came with it are making emigration more difficult. But in addition, thousands of the immigrants already here have written back to their friends and told them not to come, at least for now, since there are not enough jobs and homes.
In fact, as city officials cleaned out bomb shelters in preparation for a possible attack, they discovered that homeless Soviet Jewish families had moved into some of them.
Defense Minister Moshe Arens told the nation last week that Iraq was unlikely to fire Scud missiles here again.
But the concern now is not just Iraqi Scuds. Even as Mr. Baker heads here with word that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria is prepared to talk about peace, a mood has swept the country -- discussed at dinner parties, argued at work -- that soon Israel will be at war with Syria.
 
Israel Fears Attack From Syria
 Israelis have watched with alarm as Syria used the aid it received for joining the allied cause against Iraq to buy more and greater arms, including more Scud missiles of its own. And people here fear Syria has only one use for all that weaponry, to attack Israel.
With that fear in the background, few Israelis are talking about using this moment to make peace with Syria. To most Israelis, Mr. Assad is irredeemably evil. And so his present overture, they believe, is probably just a clever bluff. No matter the heavy price Israelis know they will have to pay, most seem too wary to accept Mr. Baker's terms.
Yossi Olmert, head of the Government Press Office, summed up the view this afternoon.
"One has to have some historical perspective," he said. "I hope very much that those who are heaping lavish praise on Mr. Assad -- the butcher from Hamma, the one who is annexing Lebanon and so on -- will not regret it in the future, because we know that these same people leaped lavish praise on Saddam Hussein just two or three years ago when it seemed at that time he was doing a good job for the West."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Israelis demonstrating yesterday near Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's home in Jerusalem. They called for the Government to accept the peace initiative when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visits Israel today. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Castro Gets Attention, but Not Money, From Latin Leaders

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, July 20

 BODY:
Received with courtesy and little else by his fellow Latin American leaders, President Fidel Castro prepared to return to Cuba today after gaining only token gestures of friendship for his beleaguered Government.
During a two-day conference of leaders from all 21 of the world's Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking nations, Mr. Castro pressed his requests for financial aid and other support to help Cuba pull out of its deep economic slide. He also delivered familiar denunciations of the United States and its policies toward the third world. 
 But while many leaders welcomed Mr. Castro's presence as a symbol of the conference's political diversity, they made little effort to play down the Cuban leader's deep estrangement from most of the region's governments, which are democratically elected and economically conservative.
"Let us permit the parliaments and the people to write their history in a sovereign fashion," declared Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, as Mr. Castro shifted uncomfortably in his chair, "and relegate guerrilla adventures to the tales of the imaginative novelists that this continent has in such great supply."
Before the formal opening of the conference on Thursday, Mr. Castro scored some achievements, winning re-establishment of consular relations with two former political adversaries, Colombia and Chile.
The conference's host, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, went out of his way to emphasize his commitment to giving Mr. Castro a respectful hearing, using the Cuban leader's presence as a political counterbalance to the pro-American economic policies his own Government is pursuing.
But suggestions that the conference would serve as a forum for negotiating democratic changes in Cuba's Communist system were quickly set aside in the initial hours of the conference, when Mr. Castro took the offensive, attacking the United States and other economic powers for creating Latin America's problems.
"The policies of the great economic powers and the international financial institutions under their control have not produced development, but have brought poverty to more than 250 million people," Mr. Castro declared in his speech at the inaugural session. "The world is heading in a still worse direction, toward world political hegemony by a superpower that has often made excessive use of force."
Despite the characteristic power of his oratory, several regional leaders did not even bother to applaud Mr. Castro's remarks, and many used their own speeches to hammer away on the themes of self-sufficiency and democracy, two subjects of particular sensitivity for the Cuban leader.
Diplomats who sat in on Mr. Castro's private meetings with other leaders said no commitments of financial help had so far been made to him.
As reporters surrounded him after the opening session, Mr. Castro began to relax and enjoy himself. But when a correspondent asked whether he planned to permit free elections in Cuba, he angrily waved away further questions, denouncing what he described as an "interminable campaign of defamation" against him.
In a concrete step toward the conference's goal of regional economic integration, Venezuela, Colombia and Mexico announced agreement to eliminate trade barriers and create a three-way free trade zone.
On another regional matter, 30 of the most prominent literary figures from the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking world made a joint plea that the leaders take action to save the rain forests.
The statement, presented by the Colombian Nobel laureate Gabriel Garcia Marquez and a Mexican poet, Homero Aridjis, was signed by writers across a wide political range -- from the conservative Mexican poet and Nobel laureate Octavio Paz to the leftist Uruguayan writer Mario Benedetti.

HEADLINE: BUSH, IN TURKEY, MUTES WAR TALK

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, July 20

 BODY:
President Bush expressed concern today about reports of fighting in Iraqi Kurdistan, but said he did not anticipate using the American-led rapid deployment force being set up in Turkey in the current fighting.
Arriving in Turkey for a two-day visit, Mr. Bush sought to play down the reports of hostilities, adding that he thought President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would not do anything that would bring the allied intervention that followed Iraqi reprisals against rebellious Kurds in northern Iraq. 
 "Anytime there's a conflagration of that nature, it's a matter of concern to us," Mr. Bush said at a news conference after meeting with President Turgut Ozal. "I understand that the matter is, hopefully, getting resolved."
 
Hope for Lessons Learned
 "Let me say that the rapid deployment force is to guard against a repeat of horribly brutal events in the North," Mr. Bush said. "And we are not anticipating that that force will be used. We are thinking that Saddam Hussein, having learned his lesson once, will hopefully not embark on the kind of carnage that resulted in our having to do what we did in the past with Turkish cooperation."
Mr. Bush also discussed American aid to Turkey that was given to the Ozal Government in recognition of its support for the American-led coalition that ousted Iraqi forces from Kuwait. He and Mr. Ozal also presumably spoke of Cyprus. Turkey is the final stop on the President's trip, which began with a stop at the summit meeting of leaders of industrial nations in London and went to Greece.
 
Fitzwater's Assessment
 Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said that the Kurdish situation did not appear to be of "imminent concern."
"We hope it won't continue," he said.
One Administration official in Turkey who is tracking the reports from Iraq said that matters there remained "tense" but that there seemed to be a "de-facto truce" at the moment.
"We're keeping an eye on it," the official said. "But it's Iraqi territory."
Mr. Bush sent troops to northern Iraq last spring after the Kurds fled their homes when their uprising against the Hussein Government was crushed during the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war. The last of those 7,000 American troops pulled out of northern Iraq on July 14.
The new force, to be made up of mostly American, British and French troops, is being set up to protect the Kurds against reprisals by Government forces.
 
Protecting Turkish Borders
 President Ozal, standing beside Mr. Bush, said the force would also "be used to protect the Turkish borders" from the kind of "big inflow of refugees" Turkey got last April.
Turkish officials felt the rest of the world unfairly focused on Kurds huddling in filthy camps on the Turkish border, rather than on the Turkish aid brought to the refugees' remote mountain havens and on the burden imposed by the influx of Iraqi refugees into the country's poorest region.
On Cyprus, Mr. Bush supported the Turkish position of a four-part negotiation about the divided island that would include the leaders of Greece and Turkey, as well as representatives of the Greek and Turkish Cypriots. He made his remarks today on the 17th anniversary of the Turkish invasion of Cyprus.
Greece has firmly objected to such an important role in the talks for the Turkish Cypriots. Turkey is the only country that recognizes the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. Turkey has 16,000 troops on Cyprus, occupying the northern third of the island.
 
Military Aid Pledged
 As in Greece, Mr. Bush promised military aid for Turkey's help in the Persian Gulf war.
The President pledged his support for Turkey's military modernization program, including its 160-plane F-16 development program to modernize its Air Force. Mr. Bush said he and Mr. Ozal "agreed to build a new strategic relationship based on closer political, security and, yes, economic links."
Mr. Ozal, thanking the United States and other nations for the $3 billion they had given Turkey for its war-related expenses, said that while "it doesn't meet our requirements" the sum was considerable.
Administration officials said that, although Congress has said that for every $10 in aid that Turkey gets, Greece must get $7, that they plan to try to "break" that rule. They said they would seek $700 million in aid for Turkey and $350 million for Greece.
Security for Mr. Bush was tight here as it was in Greece. Police in riot gear surrounded the Prime Minister's residence. The United States Ambassador's residence, where the Bushes are staying, is across the street from the Prime Minister's residence, and there were no demonstrators as the Bushes arrived in Ankara.
 
'A Little Bit Tired'
 At the news conference, Mr. Bush, who recently suffered heart fibrillation caused by a thyroid condition, was asked about his health and how he has maintained his usual frenetic schedule.
"I'll confess to being a little bit tired -- a lot of evening acion out there coupled with getting up pretty early," he said. "So I'm 67 still, and I have to confess that from time to time I get tired."
But the President is not one to dwell on weakness for long. "Generally speaking, I feel good," he concluded. "I feel up for all of this."

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Omaha's Becoming the Emerald City of the Plains

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

DATELINE: OMAHA

 BODY:
In the late 1980's when Conagra, the giant food-processing company whose labels include Swift, Hunt, Wesson and Chun King, was seeking a suitable site for a new corporate headquarters, this former cattle and railroad junction on the prairie hardly seemed fitting.
A study commissioned by the company to determine the best location had placed its existing base in Omaha 18th. 
 Yet it was also a moment when the excesses of the 80's were drawing to a close. And some key Conagra executives whose roots were in the Midwest considered the down-home lifestyle that this city evoked to be more in harmony with the less pretentious 90's.
"The trend towards conservatism and simplicity became part of the appeal," said Janet Richardson, vice president for corporate facilities and services.
 Further, the public schools were in good shape, the air was clean, the traffic sparse and housing relatively cheap -- the Omaha Area Board of Realtors says the average single-family house still costs about $80,000.
 With a population of 350,000, Omaha was not as strained by the severe social and environmental problems overwhelming larger, more sophisticated urban areas. Moreover, Congagra had its origins in Nebraska.
 The result was the $60 million, 30-acre Conagra corporate campus completed in the fall of 1990. Replacing a decayed warehousing area downtown, the project is only one of a growing number of new developments in a community that has been largely untouched by the commercial real estate collapse infesting the rest of the country.
 Total office space completed in downtown Omaha in 1990 reached 5 million square feet, an increase of 38.9 percent over 1989, according to the city's Planning Department. And even though the overall vacancy rate for Class A, B and C office space now hovers around 18 percent, there is "very little left for anyone needing more than 10,000 square feet," said Thomas Peschio, president of Peschio and Company, commercial brokers and one of this city's business leaders.
 The vacancies, he said, are mostly centered among the smaller B and C spaces recently vacated by rapidly growing companies like Conagra which have been custom building of late. Rents, excluding operating cost, average $12 a square foot, an increase of 20 percent over the last five years.
 City officials are quick to say that the construction figures do not represent a speculative building boom. "We tend to be too small for the major promoters, and not glamorous enough for the investors from abroad," said Mayor P. J. Morgan.
 Rather, the pace of building is being generated by the expansion needs of companies already in town, many of which -- like food processing and telemarketing -- just happen to be shaping up as growth industries of the 90's.
Indeed, so many catalogue companies, credit-card servicing centers and hotel reservation services are consolidating their 800-number operations in Omaha that the city -- whose geometric towers rise from the pancake-flat surrounding prairie like the fabled Emerald City of Oz -- might easily qualify as the toll-free capital of America.
 U. S. West, the regional telecommunications company, has just completed a 300,000-square-foot, 15-story, office tower attached to a low-rise, 469,000-square-foot data processing center. Oak View Mall, a $22 million project now under construction, will provide the city with 450,000 square feet of new retail space when it opens later this year. The Gallup Organization established a polling center in 8,000 square feet of space here last spring.
 Idelman Telemarketing, a local company, recently expanded into 20,000 square feet of space vacated by the Hyatt Hotel organization, which built a $3.5 million reservation center for its own expanding needs. And initial plans are moving ahead for Gateway III, a public and private partnership with a 20-year plan for reviving 250 acres of rusting railroad repair yards adjacent to the Missouri River.
 As demand permits, the aim of Gateway III is to produce multi-use developments of office and retail space, residential units, a manmade lake and a marina and botanical center, said Michael C. Wiese, exeuctive director of the Omaha Development Council. Gateway I and II have already transformed other aging areas of the town's former marshalling yards and warehousing core into a modern mix of commercial uses, interwoven with plazas.
 Omaha is pushing ahead unburdened by excess office inventory in large part because of its farming roots. While so much of the rest of the nation was enjoying an orgy of a speculative office building Omaha's business leaders were being shaken by the sight of neighboring farmers loosing thousands of acres to the farm foreclosures that swept the Midwest during the mid 1980's. "If something like that could happen to our solid midwestern family farms we felt it could happen to anyone," said Gary Pryor, Omaha's planning director. "Psychologically, it made everybody cautious."
 Further, he added, nobody had much faith in the value of the Federal tax advantages driving the speculative boom elsewhere. "We'd already seen our farmers getting whiplashed from changes in Federal policy," added Mr. Pryor. And by the time the farm economy had recovered, the dangers of the speculative excesses in other regions had become all too apparent.
 The value of the Midwestern labor pool, with its old-fashioned work ethic, has also been treated with renewed respect in recent years, prompting corporations to expand rather than shut down smaller units already located in Omaha. "Our people were proving dependable," said Mr. Wiese. "They showed up for work. They were trainable. They had no regional accent so they were excellent for phone operations."
 Slowly but steadily Omaha's economic base began shifting gears from cattle and crops to communications. An example is the building of the U.S. West complex, which opened in June. Beta West, a development company from Denver that handled the project, built 70 percent more office space in the tower than the U.S. West communications company needed, anticipating a general demand for expansion. "We felt downtown still lacked the sort of new space that offered more efficient operating costs and better access to modern telecommunications," said Bob Cardell, vice president of asset management at Beta West. Leases are in negotiation on two-thirds of the available space, he said.
 Conagra took steps to make its move to a new headquarterscost-effective. As a major employer it was able to lobby the state legislature to provide the needed tax incentives for companies like itself interested in relocating or expanding in Nebraska. It also encouraged the city to use municipal powers of eminent domain plus tax dollars to help assemble the 107-acre parcel it needed. The tract holds the company's 500,000-square-foot, four-building, low-rise complex plus a new county park with a manmade lake and fountains that adjoin and adorn the downtown site.
"Our campus has became such an attractive place people want to hold weddings in the front lobby of the main building," Ms. Richardson said.

HEADLINE: Brazil Abortions: Illegal in Name Only

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20

 BODY:
In a hillside shantytown here, Selma, a 46-year-old cleaner, has a personal reproductive history that seems out of character for Brazil -- three children and 13 abortions.
On paper, abortion is illegal in Brazil, Latin America's most populous country. In March, a Brasilia jury convicted a woman of having an abortion. In June, the Sao Paulo police raided a succession of underground clinics. 
 Yet in a startling example of a gulf between law and reality, new estimates indicate that Brazilian women have abortions at a rate equal to or greater than women in the United States, where abortion is legal.
Each year, the United States records roughly 3.9 million live births and 1.6 million abortions. Brazil records about four million births annually and somewhere between 1.4 million and 2.4 million abortions, researchers for the Alan Guttmacher Institute say.
"Although abortion is illegal in every Latin American country except Cuba, induced abortion is being widely practiced throughout the region," Susheela Singh and Deirdre Wulf wrote recently in International Family Planning Perspectives, a publication of the New York-based institute. "For every 10 women giving birth, three to four in Colombia and Brazil and two in Peru terminate their pregnancies."
On a recent afternoon at a state hospital serving Rio's shantytowns, a third of the women in the maternity ward were admitted for complications resulting from abortions.
"The poor woman is alone, and she sees herself as without a way to avoid pregnancy," said the director, who asked not to be identified by name. "When she gets pregnant, she resorts to what she sees as the easiest way to solve her problem: abortion."
Even with underreporting of complication casess by hospitals, an estimated 400,000 women are admitted each year to recuperate from abortion attempts. Of these, hundreds die. In contrast, in the United States, about 10,000 women are admitted each year because of abortion complications.
"Complications from abortion are identified as the second largest cause for admission in state hospitals -- and yet society pretends it doesn't happen," said Jose Genoino, a member of the Brazilian Congress from the left-wing Workers Party. Seeking to break the silence, Mr. Genoino has proposed a bill that would allow abortion on request in Brazil during the first 90 days of pregnancy -- the first trimester.
But in a nation that claims to have the world's largest population of Roman Catholics, few politicians are willing to risk the wrath of the church hierarchy by advocating expanded access to abortion.
Technically, abortion is permitted in Brazil in cases of rape or danger to the mother's health.
But judges usually delay issuing orders until it is too late. At the Rainha Silvia Maternity in nearby Itaborai, a 12-year-old who asked to be identified only as Renata recently became a mother. First, she was raped by her stepfather. Then, she was a victim of the slow-moving court system.
In interviews, health professionals here could only recall two legal abortions performed in this city of six million in the last three years.
"Doctors are terrified of performing an abortion without written judicial permission -- no one will do it," said a prosecutor, Branca Moreira Alves.
Jaqueline Pitanguy, a feminist leader, said, "In the case of rape, the great majority of women have clandestine abortions."
Until a recession hit last year, surveys showed that abortions in Brazil were divided roughly evenly between back-alley abortions and clinic procedures.
"Less women are using clinic services now; more are using the dangerous self-induced methods," said Sarah Hawker Costa, who researches women's health issues at the National School of Public Health.
Although there are sporadic crackdowns, like the one in Sao Paulo last month, Rio's affluent beachfront neighborhoods have an estimated 100 full-time abortion clinics.
"There is a silent acceptance of these clinics, and everyone knows where they are located," said Katherine D. LaGuardia, who studied complications from illegal abortions in Rio de Janeiro in 1988.
"It appears that part of the population uses abortion as a means of fertility regulation," said Ms. LaGuardia, who noted that the women she surveyed in the middle-class clinics had had an average of four to five abortions.
Presenting a barrier to poor Brazilian women, the cost of clinical abortions is around $150 -- roughly double the nation's minimum monthly salary.
Traditionally, poor women turned to neighborhood midwives who attempted to induce abortions with knitting needles, coat hangers or sticks. Rosangela Novaes dos Santos, the Brasilia woman convicted of having an abortion in March, was admitted to a hospital suffering from a hemmorrhage caused by a piece of wire left in her uterus.
Without any action expected to allow safe, legal abortions, health experts predict that the abortion rate will remain high until birth-control information and supplies are universally accessible.
Surveys show that 90 percent of Brazilian women who use birth-control pills buy them over the counter at pharmacies, with little or no instruction. Ms. Costa's surveys of women recovering from abortion complications found that 40 percent became pregnant while trying to use some form of contraception, largely the pill.
 
Some Can't Afford Condoms
 In addition, condoms sell for 50 cents apiece -- a luxury item for poor people in this country. A new study by the Population Crisis Committee, a private Washington group, says that condoms in Brazil are six times as expensive as in the United States, as a percentage of per-capita income.
A Government family-planning effort, the Program of Integral Assistance to Women's Health, suffers from national budget constraints. Still, Education Minister Carlos Chiarelli recently announced that sex education would start next year in primary schools.
But at the state-run slum clinic where Selma works as a cleaner, neither birth-control devices nor counseling are available.
"Women don't abort because they don't love their children; they do it because of necessity," said Selma, who underwent a sterilization operation after her 13th abortion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A police officer in an illegal abortion clinic in Rio de Janeiro after it was raided. It is estimated that Brazilian women have abortions at a rate at least as high as women in the United States, where abortions are legal. (O Globo-Hipolito Pereira for The New York Times)
