HEADLINE: Where Minorities Rub, It's 'Us' Against 'Them'

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
The political mapmakers call this block of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn a "majority minority" area. But to the Puerto Ricans gathered outside La Borinquena Grocery, the Dominicans in the Cibao bodega or the blacks gathered under a revivalist's tent across the street, political reality is a little more complicated.
"I know if we are given our own representatives who understand our needs, then we will feel more involved; we would feel more like citizens," Thomas Figueroa, a 59-year-old factory worker, said as he stood outside La Borinquena. 
 "They don't give us any power here."
The issue is who residents mean by "we."
When Mr. Figueroa and his friends outside the grocery, all natives of Puerto Rico, speak of "we," they say they are speaking exclusively of Puerto Ricans.
The same political parochialism was reflected in interviews with various residents in the last two days, whether they were blacks, who have sought political power in the neighborhood for generations, or Central American immigrants who have only just arrived.
Their political prospects are now uncertain. After spending a month studying the city's new districting map that would triple the number of districts where minorities are in the majority, the Justice Department on Friday blocked the use of the city's plan.
The Government said the map "consistently disfavored" Hispanic voters in District 34 in Williamsburg, in the adjoining District 37 in the Bushwick-Cypress Hills area and in District 8, which combines East Harlem with a heavily Hispanic part of the Bronx.
In announcing the rejection, Justice officials said drawing district lines to reflect the makeup of the city was "a job of staggering proportions."
Halfway up the block from La Borinquena, the Ecuadorean, Colombian and Panamanian customers streaming through Alex Fermin's Cibao Grocery are testament to the complexity of ethnic change in the city.
"I don't know much about politics in this country," said Mr. Fermin, a 32-year-old Dominican. "But it seems everybody looks out for your race."
Given the choice, Mr. Fermin said, he would take political power over wealth.
"Through the vote we can get our representation, and they can move the rest of us up," he said. From his storefront, Mr. Fermin could see hundreds of blacks across the street beneath an expansive green tent set up for a four-week revival meeting by the Brooklyn Tabernacle Deliverance Center.
The new Hispanic influx has already made blacks a distant second in political influence, and the new lines of District 34 have widened the gap. It makes blacks 18.11 percent of the total population, 18.38 percent of the voting age population and 25.74 percent of the registered voters.
This hodgepodge of a neighborhood is replicated block after block across a swath of Brooklyn encompassing Districts 34 and 37. Their gerrymandered lines were meant to assure a minority victory in a City Council race.
But in many ways and among many people, the district lines have heightened tension between the racial and ethnic groups and frustrated the community's two established minorities -- blacks and Puerto Ricans.
"I can foresee the future economically and politically, where Hispanics will push the blacks out of the picture completely," said Earl Mann, who is black and who lives just off Broadway in Bushwick.
Mr. Mann's home falls in District 37, where the Government said the districting lines could have been drawn to widen the Hispanic majority that numbered 53 percent of the total population, 51 percent of the voting age population and 44 percent of the registered voters.
 
Blacks Could Lose Clout
 Any increase in Hispanic strength would inevitably reduce the political clout of the area's blacks, who make up 34.45 of the total population and 34.55 of the voting age population but 44 percent of the registered voters, matching the Hispanic numbers.
"Hispanics already have a heavy pull on the district," said Mr. Mann, a 59-year-old semi-retiree who moved to Brooklyn 39 years ago from his native North Carolina. He recalled the days when the area was a largely segregated one of blacks and whites.
"Politically and economically, they have advanced pretty rapidly," he said of the Hispanic residents. "The blacks are going under the rug because of this explosion."
Puerto Ricans in the area expressed similar frustrations.
"We're represented, but not adequately," said Ramon Torres, 55, a messenger wearing a T-shirt emblazoned with the flag of Puerto Rico.
From the sidewalk business to automobile part stores to department stores, Hispanic businesses have made their mark in the neighborhood.
"I believe that blacks would have more control if they controlled more," said Arthur Roper, who is black.
Mr. Roper and his 28-year-old son, Wayne, who operate a cosmetics company, Deparee's Beauty Products, were making their rounds delivering supplies to shops along Broadway.
Mr. Mann, who is in his late 50's, said he grew up in South Carolina and Brooklyn believing that political empowerment was the way to advancement. But he has seen the area's population shift, and he now counsels his son to first seek economic power.
"If I had to do it over again, maybe I would choose politics again," he said. "But the political balance has changed. There are a lot of Hispanics, and it's very hard to try to overcome that."

HEADLINE: Chicago Journal;
Artists Try to Recreate a Great Street

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 18

 BODY:
Under a giant tent in what used to be a vacant three-acre lot in the middle of downtown Chicago, 15-year-old Melvin Roberson is making plaster of Paris masks. They are inspired by the nightmares that roused him as a child growing up in a tough neighborhood on the city's South Side. One mask has bloated eyeballs and dead bodies falling from its mouth.
Melvin is one of 259 inner-city teen-agers who are turning their experiences into art in a pioneering effort to shoot some economic life into Chicago's old downtown, the city's original retail center before it was eclipsed by the glamor of North Michigan Avenue. 
 Instead of letting the land lie unused while securing tenants for a two million-square-foot office and retail complex that is planned for the lot on the State Street mall, the city and the block's owner, FJV Venture, decided to build an open-air arts-education center to give teen-agers a chance to create and sell their art.
Each day for six weeks, high school students go to a gravel-floored esthetic oasis named Gallery 37 for the number given the block on city maps. Seven tents serve as classrooms for painting, two-dimensional design, ceramics, sculpture, printmaking and metal tooling.
"We thought about ice-skating rinks and ferris wheels or a mini-golf course," said Lois Weisberg, the city's cultural affairs commissioner. "But the developer and our office wanted to do something meaningful."
The students, who were all recommended by art teachers in the schools, are paid $4.25 an hour for a six-hour day in the summer. And their work is sold to the public upon completion.
"'This makes you feel like you're really doing something," said Dujuan Austin, 15.
Flanked by Daley Plaza and City Hall to the west and Michigan Avenue to the east, the block lies in the city's North Loop, once a flourishing urban hub. Government, retailing and other business were rooted there and in time, grew outward like spokes. But a decade ago, many of the neighborhood's buildings had become decrepit and abandoned.
"State Street was a street of rundown movie theaters on the west and aging department stores on the east," says Michael A. Tobin, project director for FJV Venture, a partnership of two Chicago-based development companies, JMB Realty and Metropolitan Structures, and the Levy Organization, a restaurant management company. "There was no new investment since before the war."
But in the last few years the North Loop has seen an aggressive fight against deterioration. Two of the city's big retailers, Marshall Field and Carson Pirie Scott, have pumped considerable amounts of money into their State Street stores in the hopes of stealing back some of the business lost to North Michigan Avenue. And a new player, Boston-based Filene's, will open a store just down State Street from Gallery 37 this fall.
Two blocks north of Gallery 37, Stouffer's Hotels, Chicago Title and Trust and the Leo Burnett Company, among several other corporations, have invested in real estate along the Chicago River in the last few years. "The downtown area is definitely on an upswing," Ms. Weisberg said. "Everybody's betting on it."
Before 1989, when demolition began on the block that Gallery 37 now occupies, about one-third of the buildings on the site were vacant, Mr. Tobin said. Some were abandoned, some were burned down and some still had ground-floor retail shops.
The lot remained unused for about six months before Maggie Daley, the Mayor's wife, proposed the art-program plan. Private and public sponsors contributed money, materials, services and instructors. All told, the project cost about $800,000, though the Department of Cultural Affairs could not say how much of that was city money.
It is hard to predict whether the pilot program will attain its long-term goals: to expose passersby to what some talented low-income teen-agers can do and to nudge the economy of the neighborhood. The sponsors of the program are hoping it will improve the image of the mall area, and thereby foster more interest in it among potential developers.
Even if this does not happen, the program may at least develop a few careers in art.
Dujuan's oil pastel of the Chicago skyline, for example, is selling for $125. And he said he would keep on drawing.
"I never seen this many people doing art before," he said. "People notice you out here, a lot. It makes you feel big."

HEADLINE: SAUDIS WOULD LIFT BOYCOTT IF ISRAEL HALTS SETTLEMENT

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 20

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia announced today that it would support Egypt's offer to suspend the 43-year-old Arab boycott of Israel if Israel would suspend settlement-building in the occupied territories.
The Saudi announcement marks the first time any Arab nation besides Egypt has offered to end the boycott, albeit conditionally, before a full peace settlement between Israel and its Arab neighbors. 
 The Saudi move, made during a visit here by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, came after Lebanon had announced that it would join Syria in supporting President Bush's proposal for an Arab-Israeli peace conference.
 
Pressure on Israel
 The Saudi and Lebanese actions were orchestrated by the United States and were designed to increase pressure on Israel to drop its opposition to the American-designed peace conference on the eve of Mr. Baker's arrival in Jerusalem on Sunday.
On Friday, during Mr. Baker's stop in Cairo, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt called on Arab nations to suspend the boycott in return for a suspension of settlements.
Mr. Baker is hoping that if he can line up enough Arab overtures of this nature, he will be able to convince Israelis that the Arab world's mood has changed on reconciliation with Israel and make it politically very difficult for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to continue to opposing the peace conference.
 
Rejected by Shamir in Past
 Up to now, Mr. Shamir has categorically rejected any trade-off between the Arab boycott and Israeli settlement-building.
There was no official reaction in Jerusalem to the Saudi move.
The Arab economic boycott of Israel has been in effect since the nation was born in 1948. All 21 members of the Arab League take part in the ban, except for Egypt, which signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979. Saudi Arabia, as the first Arab nation besides Egypt to endorse a conditional end to the boycott, is clearly taking a certain political risk both at home and abroad.
After talks tonight between Mr. Baker and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Government issued a statement saying: "The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia has closely followed both the positive position adopted by the Syrian Arab Republic under the leadership of President Hafez al-Assad to promote the peace process by agreeing to participate in the forthcoming peace conference, as well as the statements made by His Excellency Hosni Mubarak, President of Egypt, indicating that Israel should suspend the building of settlements, and in such a case it would be possible for the Arab countries to take an appropriate step by suspending the Arab boycott of Israel."
The Saudi declaration continued: "Saudi Arabia supports the statement made by His Excellency President Hosni Mubarak."
Mr. Mubarak first proposed the trade-off involving a suspension of settlements in the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Israeli-annexed East Jerusalem on Friday. But Cairo, unlike Saudi Arabia, already has peaceful relations with Israel and no longer honors the boycott.
American policy has been to oppose further settlements, and the American-Israeli differences over the issue have been a source of tension in recent years and especially in light of the influx of Soviet Jews. Since the 1967 war, tens of thousands of Israelis have settled on land taken from Arabs.
 
Baker Is Pleased
 Reacting to the Saudi announcement, Mr. Baker said: "We are pleased to see this step by the Saudi Government because it indicates a willingness to take concrete steps toward Israel, if Israel is willing to reciprocate. A suspension of the boycott, of course, would signal for one thing a willingness to reconcile with Israel, and clearly reciprocal confidence-building moves of this nature have got to improve the climate for peace. Hopefully, they will make the possibility of progress towards peace much greater."
The Arab boycott has two basic elements: a ban on all trade with Israel, and a secondary boycott that prohibits Arab nations from doing business with any company that does business with Israel.
A senior Saudi official briefing reporters after the announcement today said it was "too early" to say whether the boycott suspension being proposed would apply to both the primary and the second boycotts. Indeed, it was clear from his briefing that the whole idea has not been very fully thought out by either Arab or American officials and that for now it is designed more for its political effect than its immediate applicability.
Saudi officials conceded that it was still not clear how many other Arab nations would be ready to join in this offer and particularly whether Syria would. The Arab League boycott office is in Damascus.
Before today, the Saudis had resisted American appeals to make such an offer, and the Israeli Government had also spurned the idea when it was broached by Mr. Baker several months ago. Politically, it is virtually impossible for Mr. Shamir to accept since settlement building is central to the ideology of his Likud Party, and the idea of suspending new housing in East Jerusalem would be anathema to Israelis across the political spectrum.
Lebanon's announcement came earlier in the day during talks in Cairo between Lebanon's Foreign Minister, Fares Bouez, and Mr. Baker. Mr. Bouez gave Mr. Baker his country's endorsement for the peace conference, which came as little surprise since Syria, which in effect dominates the Lebanese Government these days, gave its go-ahead on Thursday.
"Lebanon is supporting the American proposition based on 242 and 338, resolutions of the United Nations, and is ready to be present at the peace conference raised on these subjects," Mr. Bouez said. Resolution 242 calls for Israel to trade lands occupied in the 1967 war in return for secure and recognized boundaries with its Arab neighbors. Resolution 338 calls for talks to put Resolution 242 into effect.
Mr. Bouez said Lebanon would be ready to enter two-way negotiations with Israel in the context of such a conference.
The Foreign Minister added, though, that Lebanon would also want to raise its insistence on the immediate and unconditional implementation of United Nations Resolution 425, which calls on Israel to withdraw from southern Lebanon.
The United States has commitments from Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Syria and Lebanon to take part in the proposed peace conference, which would be sponsored by the United States and the Soviet Union.
The way American officials envision the conference is as follows: There would be an opening session in which Israel and all of its immediate Arab neighbors -- Syria, Lebanon, Jordan and a delegation of Palestinians -- would take part and make speeches laying down their opening positions. Also attending would be observers representing the United Nations Secretary General, the European Community and the Gulf Cooperation Council.
After this one-day opening, the parties would break up into separate, direct bilateral negotiations. Shortly afterward, Israel would also open direct talks on regional issues like arms control and water problems. At the moment, only Saudi Arabia and the other five members of the Gulf Cooperation Council have committed themselves to such regional talks.
 
Parley Could Reconvene
 The full conference, as the Americans have proposed it, would reconvene after the opening only if all the parties agree to do so, and even then only to hear reports about the progress of negotiations.
Israel, Jordan and the Palestinians have still not agreed to attend. Israel objects to certain procedural elements of the conference -- the fact that a United Nations observer would be able to attend and that the conference could be reconvened occasionally. The Israeli Government argues that the United Nations, which has declared that Zionism equals racism, is unalterably biased against Israel and that any potential for the conference to reconvene would also be dangerous because it might impose solutions on Israel.
Up to now, the Jordanians have wavered because they wanted to see whether Syria, would agree to attend. Mr. Baker will discuss Jordan's position with King Hussein on Sunday.
The Palestinians are inclined to take part, but they are split over how they should represent themselves.

HEADLINE: After 16 Years of War, Beirut Tentatively Reclaims Peace

BYLINE: By IHSAN A. HIJAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20

 BODY:
Thousands of people gathered at a concert in the war-scarred center of this city not long ago to sing for peace.
Mona Hrawi, the wife of President Elias Hrawi, opened the event with a speech in which she compared Lebanon to a flower growing out of a rock, her description of the nation as it emerges from 16 years of civil war. Then musicians, standing at the foot of a statue in the square near the Green Line that once divided the city into its Muslim and Christian sectors, sang, "Give peace a chance." 
 Suddenly a shot rang out, and the crowd stampeded. Mrs. Hrawi was whisked away by her bodyguards, and the prominent guests hurried off in their limousines.
 
Syrian Soldiers Help
 "I felt the knot in the pit of my stomach that brought back the memory and agony of those terrible years of the civil war," said Hussein Jahshan, an 18-year-old student who had come to Martyrs Square for the concert.
For the first time in years, the people of Beirut are living in something close to real peace. The Hrawi Government, with the aid of tens of thousands of Syrian soldiers, has moved to re-exert control over the country's territory for the first time since the spring of 1975, when tensions between Christians and Muslims broke into the open with intenseclashes that heralded what turned into the Middle East's longest-running civil war.
 
15 Year in Athens
 But the shot at the peace concert -- the result of an argument between Lebanese security guards and a Syrian soldier -- is also something of a symbol of Lebanon's new peace. People are returning after years of exile, but many of those who come back do so with grave trepidation. Business is picking up, and foreign delegations are considering opening offices here again. Yet such moves, by and large, are tentative, as one might expect in a nation where truce after truce has fallen apart and 150,000 people have been killed.
One of the recent returnees was Joseph Melki, who looked dazed after landing at Beirut Airport one afternoon this month. Perspiring profusely, he clutched a briefcase in one hand and his newly issued Lebanese passport in the other as he answered routine questions from the Lebanese officer on duty at the emigration counter.
When asked where he was coming from, Mr. Melki answered, "Athens."
"How long have you been away?"
"Fifteen years," Mr. Melki replied.
"This is a long time to be away from home," the officer commented.
Mr. Melki did not reply.
Then the officer stamped his passport and said, "You are most welcome."
Thus Mr. Melki returned to his native country for the first time since he left his home at Karm el Zaitoun, a Christian suburb of Beirut, and relocated his insurance business to the Greek capital in 1976, a year after the war broke out.
Like many of the returnees, Mr. Melki is not sure he will stay.
"I will decide when to bring back my wife and two children when I can determine whether I want to relocate my business in Beirut," he said.
It is the Syrian soldiers standing behind the Hrawi Government who will have a very real effect on Mr. Melki's future. Damascus has supported the Lebanese Government in its effort to recover control of the nation's territory as part of the Arab-brokered pact negotiated by Lebanese legislators at the Saudi resort of Taif in 1989. The pact brought unity to the two sectors of the capital late last year, the first step in a process that also brought an end to the Palestine Liberation Organization's guerrilla presence near the southern port of Sidon recently.
Syria has 40,000 soldiers spread over about 70 percent of Lebanese territory, enforcing the terms of the political pact, which reordered the Lebanese power equation by removing the Christians' advantage in Parliament.
 
Airlines Return to Beirut
 The Government has focused particularly on improving security in the area of the airport in the southern suburbs, once a hotbed of Shiite Muslim militants and an area in which a number of foreigners and Lebanese Christians were kidnapped during the worst of Beirut's lawlessness.
As Lebanese continue to come back to test the new peace, foreign airlines have been resuming flights to this capital that were halted long ago because of the fighting.
So far, 13 airlines have taken the risk of using Beirut Airport again, including Air France, Austrian Airways, Cyprus Airways, the Soviet airline Aeroflot, Egyptair and several East European airlines.
The Lebanese national carrier, Middle East Airlines, is still the busiest. Its chairman, Salim Salam, says more than 300,000 Lebanese are booked to return home this summer. While no accurate figures are available about the number of people who fled during the war, official estimates put the total at three quarters of a million out of a population of three and a half million.
Mr. Salam said the airline's 15 flights fly 3,000 passengers a day.
 
Lifetime Friends Missed
 One of the returning Lebanese, Abdel Rahman Alayli, a 35-year-old Muslim, said he had sold his restaurant in Canada and returned with his family for good.
"What I missed the most in Canada were my lifetime friends," he said. "Besides, I want my children to catch up on their Arabic."
Musa Ayoib, a Christian who has just returned with his family from 10 years in Cyprus, said, "If the present peace survives to the end of this year, Lebanon would be over the hump, and the expatriates would no longer be afraid to stay."
Although Lebanese are returning in larger numbers than ever, Mr. Salam, the Middle East Airlines chairman, complained that Washington still refuses to end its ban on Beirut Airport and flights by the airline to New York.
The American quarantine of Beirut Airport and suspension of Middle East Airlines flights were imposed after the hijacking of a Trans World Airways plane to Beirut by Shiite gunmen in 1985. At the same time the State Department imposed a ban on travel by Americans to Lebanon, which remains in effect.
In any case, most Westerners are very apprehensive about travel to Beirut because of the potential for hostage-taking. Six Americans and six other Westerners who are missing in Lebanon are believed held by clandestine Shiite factions affiliated with Iran.
 
Hostages Hurt Prospects
 Western officials who visited here recently to look over conditions and examine the chances of freeing the captives, told the Lebanese Government that their plight would continue to hurt efforts to convince foreign businesses, diplomats and journalists to return to Beirut.
Nonetheless, business teams from Japan and Europe -- including bankers from France, Belgium and Luxembourg -- have come to explore the possibility of reopening offices in Beirut, the Middle East's banking and commercial center before the civil war.
Business people say the Japanese are primarly interested in investing in rebuilding Beirut's seaside hotels, which were destroyed in the early stages of the civil war. But the Japanese, too, are cautious. A major Japanese company, Sumitomo, reportedly sent a team of senior executives to Cyprus to study the possibiity of a return to Lebanon.
American Express sent its representative in Cyprus to Beirut to report on whether to sell travelers' checks again in Beirut. The sale of the checks was suspended a decade ago.
 
Feelers by Other Countries
 The French, the Germans and the British have also sent out feelers about what opportunities the Beirut market can now offer, people in business circles say.
Lebanese economists are skeptical about quick recovery. One, Kamal Hamdan, said it might take as long as 20 years for equilibrium to return. Estimates by the Government and private business put the total repatriated capital so far at only $200 million, a fraction of the $15 billion Lebanese are believed to have accumulated abroad in the last decade and a half.
Most of the money brought back went in to real estate, widely regarded as a fairly secure investment under the uncertain political conditions.
High-rise apartment buildings are being built, but they are doing very little to ease housing shortages, because condominums are offered for sale at high cost and are not for rent. A three bedroom apartment sells at about $200,000, a cost that is out of reach for most Lebanese.
 
Squatters Face Eviction
 Landlords of older buildings face the problem of evicting squatters who occupied apartments after they had been driven out of their homes in other parts of the country by the violence.
As the squatters face eviction to accommodate returnees, many other Lebanese who stayed have been enjoying life as they have been unable to do with any consistency since the war started 16 years ago.
The beaches and mountain resorts are packed. The St. George's Yacht Club in the predominantly Muslim western part of the city, as well as the Kaslik Yacht Club near the Christian port of Junieh, have reopened.
The golf club near the airport has published newspaper announcements asking members to pay their dues. Golfers are seen daily on the course.
 
An Evening Out
 When night falls, couples and sometimes whole families take off for the nightclubs or theaters to listen to an Arabic crooner or watch a belly dancer, who appears to a drum roll as the hall resounds to whistling and shouting. Women, young and old, get caught up in the excitement, wrapping scarves around their hips and joining the dancer in the gyrations.
At many of Beirut's nightspots, an evening out ends with everybody joining in what is now the most popular Lebanese song, a paean of hope including the words, "Lebanon is being rebuilt and will be better and more beautiful than ever before."
That sentiment was echoed at the concert at Martyrs Square, held in the devastated heart of the city that was for years a wasteland peopled only by killers who lived in the shadow of ruined buildings and piles of rubble.
And the reaction of those attending the event was perhaps symbolic of Beirut's past and its future: Although almost half of the crowd fled, the others stayed, and the concert continued for two hours after the shot was fired.
As Maha Samara, a Beirut journalist, said: "What we have is not an ideal peace. But it gives us something to build on."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The people of Beirut are once again experiencing peace and can enjoy activities like swimming (Peterson/Liaison) (pg. 1); the Government, with the aid of Syrian soldiers, has restored peace in Beirut. Although vendors are surrounded by ruins, they are once again able to sell their wares as business picks up in Lebanon. (Peterson/Liaison) (pg. 10)

HEADLINE: The Region;
Comparison to '75 Makes Too Much of a Bad Thing

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
THROUGH the twisting negotiations that led to a New York City budget a few weeks ago, estimates of deficits, revenues and tax projections came and went like the odds on a racetrack tote board. But one number remained fixed, looming grimly above the others: 1975.
That was the year, with the city's near bankruptcy and sweeping layoffs and service cutbacks, that has become accepted shorthand for municipal disaster. And no matter what their agendas, virtually all the players in this year's budget process had an interest in evoking 1975. 
 Yet despite the pain, discomfort and cost in any budget with thousands of layoffs and higher taxes, this budget year was far different -- and far milder -- than 1975. In fact, 1965 or 1970 or any of a half dozen other pre-1975 years offers closer parallels to the current year than the darkest one in the city's recent fiscal history.
The point is more than incidental. Planning in a crisis is hard enough. Planning in a panicky crisis is even harder, with meat axes too often taking the place of scalpels.
"The mid-70's crisis as it's gone into history has been very fundamentally misunderstood," said Samuel Ehrenhalt, regional director of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "It's been seen in an economic vacuum without a recognition that it was fundamentally an outgrowth of an economic crisis. Expenditures and municipal employment kept going up even while revenues were being cut by a major economic crisis."
 
A Pattern of Borrowing
 For more than 25 years, the city has been dealing on and off with budget deficits roughly comparable to the $3 billion-plus gap in this year's $28.5 billion budget, which was closed with $735 million in new taxes, $2 billion in service cutbacks and $500 million in supposed productivity increases.
In 1965 the city faced a $255.8 million gap in a budget of $3.87 billion. And in that year it established a pattern for closing deficits that eventually contributed to the near bankruptcy of 1975. It borrowed. At the behest of Mayor Robert F. Wagner, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and the Legislature approved a plan enabling the city to close its gap by borrowing against estimates of anticipated revenues.
 By 1970, when the city's short-term debt had doubled to $1.3 billion, and its long-term debt stood at $5.2 billion, its biggest economic downturn since the Depression took place.
After years of steady job growth that left the city with its highest employment total ever -- 3.8 million -- a string of unprecedented job losses unfolded. In 1970, 52,000 jobs were lost. By 1977, the city had lost more than 600,000 jobs -- close to 20 percent of its total -- largely in factories.
Yet the city, with the approval of the state, its underwriters and the bond rating agencies, kept enlarging its budget -- increasing it by nearly 20 percent in 1970 alone -- along with its work force, and it kept borrowing to pay for everything. When disaster struck in 1975, the city was carrying more than $12 billion in long- and short-term debt.
The results were sudden and brutal: 20,000 layoffs including police and firefighters, a gradual reduction of 85,000 jobs, elimination of the entire capital budget and the introduction of formerly verboten changes, including tuition for the City University.
 
'Not Doomsday'
 This year's crisis appears to have more in common with the 1970 or 1971 crunch than it does with 1975. After the strongest economic boom here since World War II, the city lost roughly 120,000 jobs between October 1989 and last May. Between 1969 and 1971, by comparison, the city lost a total of 186,000 jobs.
Yet there are differences in the way the city has reacted this time. First, because of sweeping budget safeguards enacted after 1975, the city couldn't spend extravagantly if it wanted to. In comparison to the close to 20 percent increase in the budget in 1970, there was barely a 2 percent increase this year. Furthermore, the city's budget is not saddled with the overbearing accumulation of short-term debt of the 1970's. And rather than experiencing a budget crunch on a different order from that of all but a handful of other governments, it is living out its version of a malady afflicting state and local governments from Maine to California.
Perhaps most significantly, despite the thousands of lost jobs anticipated in the expected demise of Pan American Airlines and the merger of Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover banks, many economists doubt the local downturn will approach that in the 1970's.
"Is New York City's pain greater than a lot of local areas?" asked Maury Cooper, senior vice president of Standard & Poor's, the bond rating agency. "I would argue no, it isn't. In terms of the overall functioning of the city, it will result in an erosion, but it's certainly not doomsday."
Mr. Ehrenhalt says while job losses continue, the rate of decline has been slowing. Some economists predict that the losses will bottom at 200,000, a third the size of the 1970's contraction.
The city still faces billions of dollars in potential budgetary shortfalls in the next few years. And even if it didn't, its array of social needs, from housing to AIDS treatment to education, would create compelling arguments for more assistance than the city could ever provide.
But in the absence of hyperbole, New York can at least address its budgetary issues in a more nuanced way: since the municipal work force expanded by 50,000 in the 1980's, is there room for further trimming? Is it possible to talk about "downsizing" government without gutting service?
As John H. Mollenkopf, who teaches political science at the City University Graduate Center, said, "In retrenchment you can force agencies to work together in different ways and have more results-oriented criterion."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Under the Voting Law, Citizens' Rights Get More Than Lip Service

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FROM the barrios of Harlem to the bayous of Louisiana to the cotton fields of the Mississippi Delta, the poorest part of the nation's poorest state, the long arm of the Federal Voting Rights Act is being felt once again.
Flexing its muscle, the Justice Department has objected to redistricting plans for both houses of the State Legislatures in Mississippi and Louisiana. On Friday, John R. Dunne, the Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, blocked use of a new districting plan for the New York City Council, saying it tended to "minimize Hispanic voting strength" in parts of the city. 
 The law, which represents an extraordinary Federal interference in state and local affairs, will be fodder for debate in the next year as Justice Department lawyers review more than 1,000 redistricting plans for any trace of discrimination against voters who are black, Hispanic or of other minority groups.
The Bush Administration, seemingly ambivalent in its general approach to civil rights and vehement in its opposition to the appearance of racial quotas, is a vigorous enforcer of the Voting Rights Act.
To be sure, the Administration wants to appeal to Hispanic voters across the country, and some Republicans want to maximize black voting strength in urban districts, on the theory that Republican candidates would then fare better in nearby suburban districts.
But there are other, perhaps more compelling, reasons to bolster the Voting Rights Act, including a long series of pertinent judicial decisions. In addition, the Justice Department has a small group of career Government lawyers with vast experience in scrutinizing the handiwork of wily local politicians. And in the last nine years, Congress and the Supreme Court have made it easier for minority groups to prove violations of the voting rights law. The Administration could be embarrassed if the Justice Department approved a redistricting plan and a Federal court later found that the plan violated the law.
In an interview last week, Mr. Dunne called the Voting Rights Act "probably the most important civil rights law on the books." He added, "The whole spirit of the Voting Rights Act is that a particular group cannot gang up to deprive individual members of a protected minority of their rights."
Abigail M. Thernstrom, a political scientist who has written a book on the law, sees it differently. "We are racially gerrymandering the whole country, on the assumption that the law requires the maximum number of safe black and Hispanic districts," she said. The assumption "rests on the pernicious premise that black and Hispanic voters are never adequately represented except by a black or a Hispanic, that whites cannot properly represent blacks," she said.
In ruling on the New York plan, the Justice Department said there was no requirement for "racial or ethnic proportional results."
 The law requires states with a history of discrimination to obtain approval from the Justice Department or the Federal District Court here before they can make any change in voting laws or election procedures. This "preclearance" requirement applies to nine states and to portions of seven others, including three New York boroughs: Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. Preclearance may have been necessary in the 1960's, but is it needed today, when there are more than 7,000 black elected officials nationwide?
 
'Still a Lot of Mischief Going On'
 "I am encouraged that the trend appears to be that we are headed toward a day when we will not need preclearance," said Mr. Dunne, a former New York State Senator. "But I think that we are a long way from that day," he added, because "there is still a lot of mischief going on out there."
The voting rights law, originally passed in 1965, eliminated literacy tests and poll taxes. But Federal judges found that such flagrant discrimination was replaced with electoral devices that tended to nullify and dilute the black vote. These devices included at-large voting schemes, multimember districts and racial gerrymandering of district lines to favor whites. When the Justice Department reviews a redistricting plan today, it typically focuses on such questions as whether the proposal packs members of a minority group into one district or disperses them among several districts so as to dilute their voting strength.
 Frank R. Parker, director of the voting rights project at the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, who has represented Mississippi blacks in court cases for 20 years, argues that the law now requires state and local authorities to create majority black and Hispanic districts "wherever possible."
The Mississippi plans rejected by the Justice Department last month would have increased the number of State House and Senate districts in which blacks account for a majority of the population. But Mr. Dunne, in objecting to the plans, noted that the State Legislature had rejected alternatives that would have created even more black-majority districts.
Mr. Parker said the voting rights law was "widely viewed as the most successful piece of civil rights legislation ever enacted by Congress," and he said that it was "an instrument of its own perpetuation." For "as blacks registered to vote and gained political participation at state, county and local levels," he said, "members of Congress from those states opposed the Voting Rights Act at their peril."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
For Lagging American Banks, Survival Means Consolidation

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
ANY doubts about the future of American banking were pretty much settled last week. The Chemical Banking Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, two of the industry's giants, announced they were merging to pare costs and get in shape financially for the coming era of national banking. It was a bellwether.
The 1990's, by all accounts, will be a decade of wrenching consolidation for the nation's 12,300 banks. And the Chemical-Manufacturers Hanover merger will undoubtedly prompt other banks, large and small, to start browsing for partners. 
 The pace of the move toward fewer, bigger banks is a matter of debate, but the trend is inevitable. Compared to other major industrial countries, the United States is brimming with banks. Japan, Germany, France, Britain and Canada have strong national banks. Their branch networks are spread nationwide and in each nation a handful of banks are dominant. But since the early 19th century, American policy supported the Jeffersonian ideal of small community banks, protecting the little guy from the perceived twin dangers of Eastern financiers and concentrated economic power. The result has been a hodgepodge of regulation that, among other things, gives states the power to prevent out-of-state institutions from coming in.
Today, the American approach looks parochial and outdated. The big money center banks have been kept from establishing national branch networks. With their horizons in consumer banking limited, Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and others tried riskier fields, like lending to third world countries, to commercial real estate and to finance corporate takeovers -- the sources of most the big banks' bad loans these days.
"If we had had nationwide banking in the '70s, the banking world would be very different today," said Robert E. Litan, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
 
Moving Toward Change
 Foreign banks, with their national deposit-gathering networks, surpassed the American majors in size during the 1980's. In 1982, for example, Citicorp was the world's largest bank. Last year, Citicorp (assets: $217 billion) ranked 18th, trailing banks from Japan, France, Germany, Britain and the Netherlands.
The United States, with more banks, also has more bank failures. Again, the geographic restrictions are partly to blame. Banks legislatively confined to one state or region are hostage to local markets, as banks in Texas and New England found to their regret. The benefits of scale and diversity in banking have been proved repeatedly over the years. In the Depression, the United States lost thousands of banks. By contrast, the Canadian banking system, dominated by 10 national institutions, did not have a single Depression-era bank failure.
After the savings and loan fiasco and the rising number of bank failures, the Administration and Congress are moving to reform bank regulation. The House and Senate are both working on legislation. And while much remains uncertain, it seems clear that Congress will permit banks to set up national branch networks and offer new services, such as selling stocks and bonds to customers. In return for the new powers, regulation will likely stiffen so that banking supervisors move in quickly if a bank's capital cushion against losses or credit rating falls below certain benchmarks.
 
The Winnowing Process
 Both economics and policy, then, are fueling the consolidation in banking. McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm, estimates that the top 125 largest banking companies, which hold two-thirds of the industry's $3.2 trillion in assets, may be winnowed down to no more than 15 companies by the mid-1990's.
While they control most of the assets, the 125 biggest companies account for only 10 percent of the nation's banks. The vast majority of American banks are tiny by comparison; about 9,000 banks have assets of $100 million or less. In their home markets, they are often quite strong. That is a major reason why even analysts who say that the number of banks will eventually shrink to 2,000 or less figure the process may take several decades.
Jeffrey Gerhart, the president of First National Bank of Newman Grove, Neb., is the archetypal community banker, who fears that communities will eventually suffer from the banking consolidation, because lending decisions will be made elsewhere. "I see a lot of problems, even if it is inevitable." he said.
Most rural banks, like First National of Newman Grove, should have little to fear from national banking. But the big banks are likely to make inroads in larger metropolitan markets as they set up large regional and, later, national networks. Already, big regional banks like Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, and NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., have taken advantange of gradually easing state laws to move into nearby states. Some of these so-called superregionals are quite profitable and innovative in terms of services.
For consumers, the transition to greater competition nationally promises a different banking experience. To gain market share, for example, Banc One branches in many locations often stay open into the evening during the week and keep weekend hours to accommodate people's shopping habits. "In the future, banks are increasingly going have to win customers with better service just like in any other business," said John B. McCoy, chairman of Banc One.
Bigger will not necessarily be better in the new world of banking. And in industry after industry, big mergers like the Chemical-Manufacturers combination have proved to be difficult to manage successfully. But analysts say those that emerge from the Darwinian process of elimination will be stronger and offer better service to customers than the banking industry of today.
"We should have world-class institutions that can really make a difference in how our economy functions," said Lowell Bryan, a director of McKinsey.

HEADLINE: Headliners;
The Senate Grits Its Teeth and Says Yes

 BODY:
IT reached the floor of the Senate at 8:47 P.M., and by 9:50 the vote was over, and it had passed. Remarkable speed for a body known for a deliberateness bordering on the ponderous. But then, the bill at hand was a pay raise.
By a 53-to-45 vote, senators decided that they could forgo the $23,068 they are allowed to earn from speaking fees each year as long as they simultaneously raised their pay by $23,200. With that, they will earn $125,100 a year. That is the same amount members of the House voted themselves in 1989, and that apparently stuck in the craws of many senators. Not only did the 435 members of the House earn more than the nation's 100 senators did, but so did some Federal judges, officials, and even some House staff members. 
 Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, one of those who marshaled votes for the bill, said it was demeaning for senators to earn less than representatives and warned his colleagues: "Now's not the time to run from a tough decision."
But another aspect of wanting to keep up appearances was also responsible for the raise. Members of Congress have been under pressure for years to give up the substantial honoraria they earn for making speeches. Those speeches are usually to gatherings of people who want something from the Senate, and, as Mr. Byrd noted: "There's nothing honorable about honoraria. It's simply a way for special interest groups to gain access to senators."
The consumer advocate Ralph Nader was not swayed, and called the quick debate and vote a "pre-midnight raid on taxpayers" that "stiffed the American people."
And senators who voted against the pay increase said they were reluctant to accept one in the middle of a recession. "It's an issue of merit pay," said Senator John Seymour, Republican of California. "If you're running a business, you don't give yourself a raise when you're in the red and your firm isn't producing."
For the raise to take effect when the Federal fiscal year begins Oct. 1, the House must also approve the legislative appropriations bill to which the measure was attached, and President Bush must sign it. The first step, at least, would seem to be assured -- under the circumstances, would the House dare say no?

HEADLINE: The World;
Syria's Tactical Leap Into the Peace Process

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria

 BODY:
IMMEDIATELY after the gulf war ended, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d set off on his first Middle East peacemaking mission, buoyed by a simple supposition: that the American defeat of Saddam Hussein had opened a new "window of opportunity" for a peaceful resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflict. What Mr. Baker seems to have discovered five trips later, though, when Syria finally accepted the American peace conference proposal, is that he was right about the window of opportunity but wrong about what had opened it. It was not the end of the gulf war. It was the end of the cold war.
More than any other Arab regime, the Syrian Government led by President Hafez al-Assad has been a creature of the competition between the United States and the Soviet Union. Syria lived off the cold war for three decades, milking billions in economic and military aid from Moscow in return for being its most loyal Middle East ally and for allowing the Soviet Navy to use Syria's Mediterranean ports, from which it could better compete with the United States Sixth Fleet. The Syrians could always count on the Soviets to protect them from the Americans in the diplomatic sphere, and to rearm them after every war with Israel. 
 And then, in 1985, came Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the thaw in the cold war. Two years later, while on a state visit to Moscow in April 1987, Mr. Assad got his first Soviet cold shower. In a toast to the Syrian President at a state dinner, Mr. Gorbachev raised his glass and told a stunned Mr. Assad that it was time to end the war with Israel. The world was changing, said Mr. Gorbachev, and Syria would have to change with it. Privately, Mr. Assad was told that Syria's hopes for achieving "strategic parity" with Israel were a chimera, best forgotten.
Two years later, the Soviet Union was effectively driven back to its borders in Europe by popular revolutions from Berlin to Bucharest. This not only confirmed and hastened the diminution of Soviet power, but also deprived Syria of the bloc of Eastern European Communist regimes it had been able to count on for economic and military backing beyond what Moscow could deliver.
By 1990, Mr. Assad had awakened, looked around and discovered he was an orphan. He had two choices: Try, like Fidel Castro in Cuba, to be more radical than the Soviets, or begin to swim with the tide. Ever the Machiavellian prince, Mr. Assad started to swim, and last week he floated right into the waiting arms of Mr. Baker. The Syrian leader, who had always rejected direct talks with Israel, said he was prepared to take part in a peace conference with Israel on American terms -- which meant direct negotiations.
Mr. Assad does not appear to have been driven to this change by an epiphany that the Jewish people really are entitled to a state in Palestine. In his own unique style, he explained his policy shift during a press conference last week. The reason, he indicated, was simply that he had no choice but to bow to the American imperium, or, as he put it: "In Arabic we say, 'Do you want grapes or do you want to fight the vineyard keeper?' We want the grapes."
 
A No-Lose Proposition?
 For the Syrian leader, accepting the American terms could turn out to be a no-lose proposition. If the Israelis actually drop their objections to the American-proposed conference, he might get back some or all of the Golan Heights -- a strategic highland occupied by Israel in 1967 in a war initiated by Syria. If not, he has a chance to be welcomed anyway into the Western fraternity, with all of the strategic and economic benefits that implies. The warmth of that welcome will depend on how much Washington cares to press him on other issues, notably Syria's support for terrorists.
Mr. Assad's strategic move in foreign policy has also been reflected in domestic policy. A new commerce law was just passed, opening the door wide to foreign investment, and there is now much vague talk in the ruling Baath Party about instituting political pluralism. Mr. Assad is advertising the next Baath Party conference -- it is not clear when it will be held -- as the "Second Corrective Movement." (The first "Corrective Movement" was his seizure of power in 1970.) It surely is not Jeffersonian democracy that Mr. Assad has in mind to install, but diplomats in Damascus say he clearly recognizes that some greater degree of power sharing is probably necessary.
 
A Peace of Sorts
 From Israel's point of view, the outcome of the gulf war, if anything, has diminished all the more any desire to do a deal with Mr. Assad. To put it simply: By destroying Iraq's army and almost all its weapons of mass destruction, the United States has removed the greatest strategic threat to Israel's existence. Never has the regional balance of power been more in Israel's favor. By resisting America's invitation to trade land for peace with the Arabs, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is asking in effect: Why take chances now?
Mr. Shamir understands that the Syrian leader has not suddenly gone through therapy. And Mr. Shamir already has the only peace he feels he needs from Syria -- a peace based on a favorable balance of power, with Israel sitting atop the Golan Heights. Mr. Assad could sing the Israeli national anthem every day for the rest of his life and Mr. Shamir -- like most Israelis -- would still never trust him in a swap of land for peace. Too much has gone between them.
The only thing that might mitigate this Israeli attitude is not an outgrowth of the gulf war, but more fallout from the end of the cold war: Israel is being flooded with Soviet Jews and cannot resettle them without massive American economic help. If Mr. Shamir snubs Washington now, that aid could be imperiled.
Mr. Shamir also needs his grapes. Can he afford to fight the vineyard keeper?

LENGTH: 1082 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
A Longtime Precedent for Disregarding Precedent

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN the Supreme Court overturned five of its own precedents during its last term, all in the area of criminal defendants' rights, liberals on and off the Court complained that the new majority had embarked on a course not only regrettable but illegitimate. Nothing about the cases had changed, Justice Thurgood Marshall declared in an angry dissent from one of the rulings, issued hours before he announced his decision to retire, adding: "Only the personnel of this Court did."
Conservatives, not surprisingly, saw the matter very differently -- it was "payback time," as L. Gordon Crovitz, a Wall Street Journal editorial page editor, wrote in a recent column. "The hypocrisy here is impressive," he wrote, noting that liberal Justices were not shy about overturning precedents when they had the votes. 
 Events of the recent term, as well as the prospect that the Court may soon overrule its 1973 decision establishing a constitutional right to abortion, have placed the question of judicial respect for precedent in an unaccustomed spotlight. What that spotlight reveals is no abstract legal axiom, but rather an earthy mix of law, politics and history in which one of the few consistent elements has been inconsistency.
The command of precedent has deep roots in Anglo-American legal tradition. Lawyers and judges often use the Latin phrase "stare decisis," meaning "to stand by things decided." The doctrine is binding on lower courts, meaning that Federal trial and appeals court judges must apply Supreme Court precedent whether or not they agree with it. Last year, when the Senate Judiciary Committee was examining Clarence Thomas for a seat on the Federal appeals court here, members asked for his views on a variety of Supreme Court precedents. He replied that because he would be obliged to apply those precedents in any event, his own views were irrelevant.
The question is bound to recur now that Judge Thomas is a Supreme Court nominee. The Supreme Court, too, has regarded itself as bound by precedent -- except for the more than 260 times that the Justices have overruled themselves since 1810, when the Court rejected a two-year-old precedent. During the 16 years that Earl Warren was Chief Justice, the Court overruled 63 cases. During Warren E. Burger's 17-year tenure as Chief Justice, the Court overruled precedent 61 times.
The virtues and vices of stare decisis have been debated almost endlessly in judicial opinions, law review articles and other commentaries. The virtues of the doctrine are apparent. It fosters stability in the law and, particularly in a political system that gives enormous power to unelected judges, a sense of legitimacy in judicial institutions. As Justice John Paul Stevens said in a 1981 opinion, citizens should be able to have confidence that the rules they rely on "are rules of law and not merely the opinions of a small group of men who temporarily occupy high office."
But a Court that cannot change its mind is one that cannot acknowledge old mistakes or adjust to new insights -- for example, that separate is not equal after all, as the Court concluded in 1954 when, in Brown v. Board of Education, it unanimously overruled an 1896 decision, Plessy v. Ferguson.
On the current Court, Justice Antonin Scalia is the most aggressive attacker of stare decisis. Dissenting in South Carolina v. Gathers, a 1989 decision that barred prosecutors in death penalty proceedings from introducing evidence about the quality of the murder victim's life and the grief of the survivors, he said that his oath of office bound him to interpret and apply the Constitution as he understood it, not as it might have been erroneously interpreted by Justices in the past.
Few members of the Court have put the argument so bluntly. But even fewer have been unwilling to abandon precedents they disagreed with.
In a 1983 case, City of Akron v. Akron Center for Reproductive Health, a majority opinion by Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. strongly reaffirmed Roe v. Wade, the 1973 abortion precedent, with the admonition that stare decisis "is a doctrine that demands respect in a society governed by the rule of law."
Yet three years later, Justice Powell, who retired in 1987, wrote a majority opinion in Batson v. Kentucky, permitting criminal defendants to challenge the prosecution's exclusion of jurors on the basis of race. That decision overruled a 1965 Supreme Court case, Swain v. Alabama, which had set an evidentiary standard for bringing such challenges that defendants as a practical matter could never meet. In their dissents, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Justice William H. Rehnquist, now the Chief Justice, said it was "truly extraordinary" for the Court to overrule a precedent on the basis of an argument that the parties in the case had not made.
Yet last month, in Payne v. Tennessee, Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote a majority opinion overturning South Carolina v. Gathers and a similar decision restricting victim impact evidence. Neither the death-row inmate in the case, Pervis Payne, nor the state of Tennessee had asked the Court to overrule the precedents.
It is tempting to conclude that stare decisis is just so much sauce for alternating geese and ganders. But another element gives the Court's current approach to precedent added significance, as something more than just a 1991 version of "My Turn" by William Rehnquist. It is the sense that the new majority is not waiting for errors to be brought to its attention but is on a search-and-destroy mission against a generation of jurisprudence that it sees as fundamentally misguided.
Chief Justice Rehnquist's opinion in the Payne case provided a blueprint for the Court's new approach. In cases involving economic doctrine, he said, stare decisis should be at its "acme" because people need stability to plan their business affairs. But in cases involving "procedural and evidentiary rules" -- a description fitting much of criminal law -- "the opposite is true," he said. He appeared to mean that criminals should not be allowed to rely on favorable precedents.
Cases decided by "the narrowest of margins" and over "spirited dissents" are particularly appropriate for overruling, the Chief Justice said. With the Court so closely divided for so long, that description fits many important rulings of the last two decades. The question is not whether but which and how many precedents will be swept away, and what the Court will put in their place.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
A Costly 10 Percent

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
Among the people of 10 industrialized nations, those of the United States were found in 1990 to be the least satisfied with their health care system. Yet, the U.S. allocates to medical care the highest proportion of income -- 12.2 percent of gross national product -- of any nation.
 You don't have to be a brain surgeon to know that there's something wrong here -- spiraling expense not least. The cost of corporate medical benefits rose, in an often cited example, to $3,161 per employee in 1990, 44 percent more than in 1988.
 
 But that figure is misleading, not because it's wrong, but because of that seemingly precise phrase "per employee." The experience of Blue Cross-Blue Shield in the Cleveland area suggests that a major cause of rising health care costs is the expense of caring for a small number of people with very severe medical problems.
 In this area, Blue Cross-Blue Shield insures about 64,000 employees in "small groups" ranging from 2 to 150 employees, with more than half numbering less than 50 members. In 1989, health benefits paid out to group members totaled $123 million, an average -- as such things usually are reckoned -- of $1,923 each.
 In fact, a study for John Burry Jr., chief executive of Ohio's Blue Cross-Blue Shield, found that for 90 percent of all those insured, benefit payments averaged only $794. For the remaining 10 percent, with major health problems, average benefits soared to $10,529. Thus, 10 percent of small-group employees accounted for $79.7 million of the $123 million in total benefits -- about twice the benefits of the other 90 percent.
 The same principle applies to that expensive top 10 percent. Among these very sick individuals, just 1 percent received $29.1 million in benefits, nearly half the total. That 1 percent received about a quarter of all benefits.
 Put another way, 50 people -- victims of major, sometimes chronic problems like muscular dystrophy, cancer and mental disorders -- alone required more in health care benefits than 40,000 of the people in the 90 percent requiring the least care. Three organ transplants, for a graphic example, generated nearly $1 million in benefit payouts. Similarly, a 12 percent increase in "inpatient days per thousand" -- which could drive up a small group's costs -- could be the result of increased hospitalization for only one person.
 No wonder Mr. Burry argues that "the health problems of the top few percentiles of health care utilizers drive the overall health care costs of the entire group." But traditional "per employee" cost-containment efforts rarely are based on or effectively deal with this fact -- which probably would be replicated on a larger scale than the reasonably representative Cleveland study.
 Mr. Burry advocates "key strategies" for employers that would recognize the importance of these relatively few high-cost cases. One would rely on "individual case management" -- for instance, shortening the hospital stay of a hip-replacement patient by paying for a ramp to his or her home.
 Another asks whether every hospital should be capable of every form of exotic treatment -- transplants, open heart surgery and the like. Mr. Burry, instead, would establish "centers of excellence" and negotiate with each a fixed fee for such expensive procedures, to be charged by the hospital; it would then pay surgeons, specialists, staff, etc. He believes this would drive down the current high costs of the kind of treatment usually needed by only a small number of patients.
 More controversially, Mr. Burry points out that the development of new technologies, while helping to keep some people alive, has resulted in spectacularly rising costs. "Is it fair," he asked in a recent speech, "to allocate the astronomical costs of these quasi-experimental (in some cases) procedures and technology to the employer and/or the individual?"
That raises interesting possibilities, as a national election campaign renews interest in an expensive but deficient system in which more than 30 million Americans have no health care insurance at all:
 Can something be done politically both to lower the cost of caring for the expensive 10 percent, and to take that cost off the shoulders of the relatively healthy 90 percent? Might that help pay for extending some form of health care protection to the millions who now have none?

HEADLINE: We Need Informed Discussion of Health Plans

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The long-awaited Democratic leadership bill for a national program of health insurance was introduced on June 5 by Senators George J. Mitchell, Edward M. Kennedy, Donald W. Riegle Jr. and Jay Rockefeller. This answer to the plight of 60 million regularly or intermittently uninsured Americans and the skyrocketing cost of health care for all was briefly reported by the news media and then generally ignored. 
 When the bill, S. 1227, with 345 pages of complex text, became available, the reason was clear. The proposal is simply too complicated for the average person to understand. Private insurance for employees would be mandated for larger employers. An ambiguous supplementary plan called AmeriCare, largely covered by contributions, could be authorized for those not otherwise covered. Special provisions are attempted for small businesses. It would largely subsume Medicaid and be administered by the states.
No direct plan for controlling costs of medical providers is included in the bill, but arrangements for negotiations are authorized. This whole program sounds like a crazy quilt pieced together from existing programs while trying to avoid the sensitive toes of hospitals, physicians and insurance companies.
I have not seen any subsequent commentary or analysis of this bill, nor mention of another bill, H.R. 1200 introduced by Representative Frank Russo and 31 other members of the House. This bill provides a single national program covering all major health needs to be paid for by the United States Government. At a recent hearing of a subcommittee of the House Committee on Government Operations it was indicated that the Canadian experience demonstrated such a plan could save us $67 billion a year in paperwork alone. It seems to me $67 billion is a high price to pay for our love affair with a competitive free-market economy, inappropriate to the health-care situation.
Both bills deserve study and public debate as a preliminary to solving a critical national problem. We spend more on health care and get less for it than any other industrial country in the world.
 
ELIZABETH WICKENDEN
Haverford, Pa., July 2, 1991
 
The writer is a consultant in social policy.

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
American Women on Parade: Pat Answers, Few Revelations

BYLINE: By Vicki Goldberg; Vicki Goldberg's new book, "The Power of Photography: How Photographs Changed Our Lives," will be published in October.

 BODY:
If someone asked you to take a picture that would answer the question "What does the American woman look like?" who would be your choice? Julia Roberts? Sandra Day O'Connor? A 36-year-old computer programmer in Kansas City with 1.2 children? Someone -- Esquire magazine, to be exact -- did ask a number of fashion, editorial, reportage and art photographers to take just such a picture, and the answers can be seen in an exhibition called "How She Looks" at the Staley-Wise Gallery (560 Broadway, through July 31) and in the August issue of Esquire.
Fifty photographers, later edited down to 26, and ranging from Matthew Rolston at the glamour end of the spectrum to Larry Fink at the gallery end, were asked by the magazine's editors to "surprise us." Unfortunately, most did not, so revelations are in short supply, but in the predictability of their answers lies a social lesson, and the maverick pictures in the show make up for the dull ones en route. 
 Two photographs, both 20-by-24-inch Polaroids, stand out for idiosyncrasy. In William Wegman's "Performance Artist Fay Ray, Weimaraner," the face of his well-known dog emerging from an enormous, frothy, black wig tops the body of a young woman who gestures with delicate arms and wears a jumpsuit that might accommodate both herself and Fay. One look at this American female's earnest, soulful face and highly intelligent eyes should convince you of the utter seriousness of her performance, although it is less clear whether the photographer was entirely ironic in portraying the American woman as a bitch.
In "Jessica Tandy, Actress," Joyce Tenneson casts Miss Tandy as a kind of classic muse, dressed in strapless muslin with a transparent shawl and holding a twisted wand apparently made of metal and streaks of light. The actress's flesh is pale, pale pink, her scant hair barely gray, the muslin cream-colored, the background a soft shade of unpolished brass. Mysteriously deliquescent, the photograph celebrates Miss Tandy's beauty and by extension old age itself, and the woman at its center seems to be disappearing before our eyes.
The overwhelming majority of the women in this show (including the Weimaraner) are fairly young -- Keith Carter even contributes a nice portrait of pre-adolescent girls -- or are made to look younger than they are. As half of the women in this country are older than 33.8 and more than 18 million are 65 or over, it is a relief to see several photographers addressing age.
Larry Fink's black-and-white portrait of "Maggie Kuhn and Sylvia Kleinman, Gray Panthers" -- the former is head of the Panthers, the latter the photographer's mother -- is crammed with factual information, from the affectionate pose to the patterns on sweaters and wallpaper to Ms. Kuhn's twisted, arthritic hand. Nicholas Nixon's three images of "The Brown Sisters" come from his simple but penetrating exploration of time, a series of pictures he has taken of his wife and her three sisters every year since 1975, tracing changes wrought by age, fashion, and fortune, and hinting at subtle shifts in personality and family relationships. The magazine had the good grace to print them all.
Take a copy of Esquire with you to the gallery; the comparison amounts to a succinct lesson in originals, reproductions and picture presentation. Certain pictures, especially the large Polaroids, are far more successful on the wall, whereas some of the more journalistic images strike a livelier note on the page. The quality of Esquire's reproduction is fine, but color is always tricky; it can vary from print to print even in the darkroom. And color almost always translates differently on a printing press; what the photographer witnessed is not quite what we see.
The youth and glamour predominant in this show are gently spoofed in Richard Gordon's " '32 Marilyns': Miss Artichoke Festival, San Francisco": 32 models in white halter-neck dresses and blond, curly wigs a la Marilyn in "The Seven Year Itch." These and 15 more like them, not one of whom resembled the original in the least, were hired to pass out pieces of artichoke at the festival to commemorate that great moment in 1947 when Marilyn, still largely unknown, became the first Miss Artichoke in history.
There are good pictures, if not in every case up to their best work, by such photographers as William Coupon, Sally Gall, Greg Gorman, Timothy Greenfield-Sanders, Mary Ellen Mark, Dan Peebles, Neal Slavin. The general impression of this exhibition is that the American woman is young, attractive, lean, healthy, sexy and, more likely than not, white and an actress. Different photographers might have come up with different responses, but the dice were loaded for this particular set. No one asked for a demographic or economic cross section of America, and none was supplied. No poor folks here, though there is a little ethnic variety; a bit more was submitted but edited out on grounds of quality.
The project, brainchild of Alison Morley, Esquire's picture editor, was actually an ambitious and rather daring magazine assignment; most of the participants simply did not live up to it. Not that offering an endless variety of women for men to stare at is exactly a bold notion, but giving photographers free rein in style and subject, then allotting 30 pages to the result is hardly standard magazine practice.
Although the editors' letter to the photographers stressed that they should not do what they thought the magazine would ordinarily want, many did just that. According to Ms. Morley, tough reporters took soft pictures, mostly of the usual young, attractive, etc., and some ordered up cheesecake, fairly tame by today's standards. (Everyone knows that the pneumatic Varga and Petty girls long ago traded in their tiny garments, and an Esquire woman is now supposed to have a profession as well as a bosom.) Photographers with more far-ranging ideas still came up with pat answers: more than one suggested Elizabeth Taylor, Katharine Hepburn, Cher and, on the literary side, Eudora Welty. The editors tried to discourage the general drift toward major monuments and ended up with a certain amount of garden-variety decoration.
Is this indeed how the American woman looks, youthful and pretty and sure of her appeal? Well, yes, that woman is all over the tube and the silver screen, and she owns the ads; she's on the covers of the men's magazines and the women's magazines; she's just about the only woman anyone designs clothes for; and you can even find her in the street -- but she's not the majority, she's not the norm. What she is, evidently, is what almost everyone wants either to be, to look like, or to go home with.
But it may be that what these photographers were confirming was not so much a desire for this creature as the knowledge that she sells and the expectation that magazines and their readers want to see her. The ubiquitous media images that shape our cultural assumptions leave no one untouched; they shape the assumptions of the image makers as well.
The general level of high competence and low daring probably reflects the fact that commercial photographers aren't used to so much liberty. Portrait photographers rarely get to pick their own subjects; advertising photographers often have to imitate an art director's drawing; fashion photographers generally have to listen to the magazine's stylist; editorial photographers are advised by editors about what is important to shoot. This assignment suddenly gave everyone absolute freedom, and as Jean-Jacques Rousseau recognized, "Liberty is a food easy to eat but hard to digest."
The idea deserves a cheer, even if the product is only intermittently imaginative. Photographers should only be lucky enough to have such freedom and so many pages without text more often; it might make them braver. The "How She Looks" portfolio is no more than a straw in the wind, but the wind is blowing in this general direction. Although almost no publication has gone this far, magazines and newspapers (including this newspaper) have begun to print more and bigger photographs than they were printing only a few years ago.
It was television that originally cut into magazine readership and contributed to the death of the big picture magazines, and it is television that accounts for the cautious increase in photographic coverage in the press; the public's expectations of visual information and rewards just keep growing, and the only way to satisfy video addicts may be to offer them the quick fix of a photograph on the page. Where this will leave the printed word, already squeezed between TV and dwindling magazine space, is anybody's guess.
