HEADLINE: Questions Linger as California Spill Sits

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAKEHEAD, Calif., July 19

 BODY:
As a stinking, bubbling glob of spilled pesticide sinks slowly into California's largest reservoir, people who live along the wooded shoreline want to know why so little seems to be understood about it, nearly a week after it spilled from a derailed train.
The unanswered questions are urgent not just in this stunningly scenic woodland, in the shadow of Mount Shasta near the California border, but all over California. 
 Will the chemicals in Shasta Lake disperse or remain condensed? How quickly will they reach Shasta Dam, at the southern end of the lake 11 miles away? In a state already parched by drought, will the chemicals endanger the drinking water that flows from the dam into the state's water supply? And how will they affect the health of an area that depends on its pristine environment for pure water and for the fish, deer and hiking trails that draw tens of thousands of tourists a year?
For now, it is clear that the pesticide has been deadly to everything it has touched. Jim Pedri, supervising engineer for the California Regional Water Quality Control Board's Central Valley office, called it "the worst chemical-environmental disaster inland in California history."
 
Finding Dead Fish

Now that the spill has entered the reservoir, officials said today they were taking more aggressive action, pumping out some areas of heavy concentrations of the pesticide and pumping in air elsewhere to disperse the spill and speed its decomposition.
On Friday, testers in motorboats, wearing gas masks and rubber gloves, scooped some of the tens of thousands of dead fish from the water's surface. But officials said they were still conducting analyses to determine how the chemical would affect wildlife and whether drinking water would be contaminated. They do not know how long the chemicals take to decompose or what their long-term health risks are.
"I think it's kind of tight that they couldn't figure out right at the beginning what was going on," said Sean Harrington, a waiter in one of the resorts around the Shasta Lake reservoir, 175 miles northeast of San Francisco. "It's weird. This is the 20th century, isn't it?"
The spill occurred Sunday, when seven cars of a 97-car freight train of the Southern Pacific Transportation Company slipped off the track in a steep canyon. A tanker car tumbled into the Sacramento River 45 miles north of the lake and ruptured, spilling up to 19,500 gallons of the pesticide metam sodium.
The chemical is marketed under the name Vapam. It is used to rid soil of weeds, nematodes and insects before planting several crops, including fruits, vegetables and cotton.
 
Chemicals in Suspension
 The chemical blob, now about half a mile long and 200 yards wide, entered the northern branch of the reservoir on Wednesday, and is now suspended in 40 feet of water.
In the lake, which supplies drinking water throughout California, the effects of the drought are all too plain. The water level has sunk to 547 billion gallons, about 55 percent of its capacity, leaving a vast, stark strip of naked red earth and rock around its rim. Officials said the lower water level only made the spill's effect worse.
Attorney General Dan Lungren said Friday that he would file a lawsuit over the spill, and his spokesman said the railroad company was likely to be one defendant. A spokesman for the railroad said the cause of the accident had not been determined but said that it might have been less likely if the train had had an extra locomotive at the rear.
A second locomotive can help prevent the slack that can lead to a derailment. This week the company added these extra locomotives to similar trains on the route.
 
Criticism of Federal Officials

Other criticisms have focused on the fact that the pesticide was not listed as a regulated substance by the Federal Department of Transportation and that, therefore, precautions were not taken. Regulated substances are carried in double-hulled tanker cars and information on the handling of the substances is furnished to train crews.
At a news conference in San Francisco on Friday, William K. Reilly, Administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, said the spill should occasion a review of the nation's pesticide regulations, which he called "totally anachronistic."
Some of the residents of the tiny town of Dunsmuir, where the spill occurred, were evacuated, and about 200 people were treated in local hospitals for symptoms that included nausea, headaches, eye irritations, rashes and respiratory complaints.
Then, to the growing agitation of residents, officials watched, tested and issued warnings, but took no action to combat the spill as it swirled downstream, giving off the stink of rotten eggs and killing all aquatic life in its path: dragonflies, mayflies, mosquitoes and fish, including at least 100,000 rare, aggressive rainbow trout.
 
Sight of Dying Fish

As the spill flowed downriver, hundreds of fish could be seen churning the smooth surface ahead of it, leaping into the air, flapping and dying.
Charlie Jakobs, a fire captain with the California Department of Forestry, said it was understandable that residents were frightened and angry when officials were unable to give them quick answers or to take quick action. "The scientists just don't know what this much volume of this chemical in this much water will do," he said.
Peter Bontadelli, director of the State Department of Fish and Game, said: "How could we possibly know how it would react? We thought it would sink, but it's suspended now. It's a land-based chemical, not water-based. That's the problem. With all this knowledge we have, there are still gaps in what we know."
 
Years Until Recovery
 As the week drew to an end, the moss along the banks of the Sacramento River began to turn brown and the Indian rhubarb plants to curl up and wilt. Biologists said the possibility that willows, oaks and alders along the riverbank might also die could greatly extend the current 10-year estimate for the river's return to full vigor.
So far, scientists have found no confirmation that the otters, deer, beaver, raccoons or bears, or the birds including bald eagles, that feed along the river have been affected.
Now that the spill has passed, the river is running clear, clean and empty of life. Residents have returned to their homes and officials have stopped advising travelers to roll up their windows as they pass by on Interstate 5.
But signs are still posted warning: "No swimming. No drinking. Don't touch the water!" And the summer tourists on whom much of the economy depends are staying away.
At Dunsmuir, Jan Garrigus, owner of the Splash of Color clothing store, said, "As far as business goes, there really is none."
But the summer activities of boating, fishing, water skiing and houseboat rentals continued around most of the 365-mile perimeter of Shasta Lake.

An article last Sunday about a pesticide spill at Shasta Lake in northern California misstated the trade name of the chemical involved. It was Alco, manufactured by the Amvac Chemical corporation of Las Angeles - not Vapam, which is manufactured by ICI Americas Inc. of Willington, Del.

HEADLINE: States Seeking Aid on Budgets From Pensions

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
Growing numbers of state and local governments are drawing money from or slashing contributions to their pension funds, raising concerns about the funds' ability to pay retirees decades from now.
To many government officials, reducing pension contributions or finding a way to recapture any pensions surpluses are simply prudent financial steps. The money is needed, they note, to avert the types of steep reductions in services or layoffs that many local governments are ordering. And in some cases the employee unions support the changes rather than accept layoffs.
 
Fast-Growing Technique
 In the past, governments facing financial difficulties have occasionally sought help from their pension funds, as New York City did in the 1970's. In the last several years, cuts in Federal assistance, the faltering economy and the political difficulty of raising taxes have led more states and cities to look at pension money as a means of addressing budget problems. At least 18 states, including New York and California, have delayed or reduced payments to their pension plans in the last two years, or are considering doing so. 
 "It's becoming an all-too-frequent practice, maybe even a common practice, for cities and states to find one means or another, creative or crude, to tap into the pension funds," said James M. Hacking, the executive director of the Minneapolis Employees Retirement Fund.
So far, there has not been any effect on the benefits received by current retirees. But the trend is being watched warily by many of the nation's 14.7 million state and local government employees who are worried about the effect on the long-term safety of their pensions.
They are concerned about steps like these: Legislators in California approved a plan this month to withdraw $1.6 billion from two funds controlled by the state's public-employee pension system, as part of their package to close a $14.3 billion budget shortfall. California's move was a relatively rare instance of a state actually taking money from a fund.
"Instead of tax increases, states have had to look at every other possible source of revenue," said Brian Roherty, the executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers. "In some states there's a lot of money in public employee pension funds, and some states see that money as a way to get through hard times."
More commonly, state and local governments have tried to reduce their annual contributions to pension funds by stretching out payments or changing the accounting methods and assumptions they use to calculate the funds' long-term financial obligations. In Connecticut, for example, government employees recently agreed to allow the state to stretch out required pension contributions into future years, saving the state $190 million this year. In Texas, legislators are considering proposals to slash contributions to pension funds over the next two years.
New York State reduced its pension-fund contributions by $289 million in the last year, changing some of the accounting rules used to determine the funds' financial condition.
Some big cities are employing the same techniques. New York City, whose employee pension funds helped bail the city out of its last fiscal crisis, recently completed a budget-balancing package that calls for delaying pension contributions.
 
Trillion-Dollar Lure
 Public-employee pension funds, which nationwide have nearly $1 trillion in assets, hold an obvious lure for financially strapped governments. Many of the funds' investments did very well in the bull markets of the 1980's. By some accounting standards, many funds have enough money to meet all their payments to retirees for decades to come with plenty to spare, even if the state and local governments reduce their contributions.
But many retirees, government employees and fund officials say the steps amount to a raid on the funds. They claim that in some cases the accounting techniques that permit governments to reduce their contributions could endanger the ability of the pension systems to meet their obligations.
"If you're a baby boomer, this process currently going on suggests there will not be the money to cover the benefits you're being promised for when you retire," said Sarah Teslik, the executive director of the Council of Institutional Investors, a research and lobbying group financed by public pension plans. "It's virtually certain based just on what's happened so far that there will be a shortfall."
Concerned about the future, the Civil Service Employees Association, the largest government-employee union in New York, is suing to reverse the state's decision to change to an accounting method that allows to slash its required level of contributions.
"The Governor and the Legislature raided the pension fund as if it were their own private reserve to handle the problems of the state, which it is not," said Joseph E. McDermott, the union's president.
The accounting changes enacted in New York save money for the state in the short run by decreasing the level of contributions for employees early in their careers, but it may require a higher contribution rate down the road as more employees move closer to retirement. Claudia Hutton, a spokeswoman for the state budget office, said the Cuomo administration believes the changes are financially sound and do not endanger pension benefits.
Yet even experts in the field of pension accounting said it was difficult to assess whether the soundness of pension systems is being endangered. Indeed, the issue of financial prudence comes down to a debate over how best to apply complex and arcane accounting techniques to determine how much money a pension fund needs to meet its obligations in the decades ahead.
Skimping on pension-fund contributions to help balance a budget today, critics say, will simply postpone the day of reckoning. In this scenario, mounting shortfalls in pension-fund assets will eventually have to be made up by the taxpayers, as the population ages and the number of retirees increases. If taxpayers balk at making up the shortfall retirees could face big reductions in their pension payments and other benefits.
In Vermont, the legislature has provided the teachers' retirement fund $18 million less than it requested over the last two years, said Ron Boucher, the state's deputy treasurer. "It means that in the immediate future, starting next year, the contribution has to be higher than it would be," Mr. Boucher said. "And you're creating a funding mismatch that will widen 30 or 40 years down the road."
Altering the accounting assumptions used to determine the annual contributions can yield huge reductions. In Texas the legislature is considering reducing contributions to the teachers' retirement fund to 6 percent of total salaries paid from a previously agreed level of 7.6 percent. Over the next two years, the change would reduce contributions to the fund by $422 million. The teachers' fund is fighting the proposal, saying it needs a contribution rate of 7.31 percent to insure that it remains financially secure.
 
Tinkering With Assumptions
 The most common technique of tinkering with the assumptions is to increase the estimated returns from the fund's investment portfolio. Increased appreciation and income growth in the stocks, bonds and real estate investments held by the funds means the governments can reduce by millions of dollars a year the amount they must pay to keep the pension systems financed.
Government officials say the investment return projections used by many pension systems are far too conservative and do not match the double-digit returns most of them have earned in recent years. But pension officials said that in many cases pension systems are being pressured to meet return rates that may not be realistic in the long run.
New Hampshire, for example, has increased its investment return assumption to 9.75 percent a year from 8 percent. In California, the California Public Employees Retirement System fought off an attempt this month by Gov. Pete Wilson to raise the rate to 9.5 percent from 8.5 percent. But in a compromise, the 8.5 percent figure will be examined by outside accountants.
Raising investment-return assumptions "seems to be the trend of the future," said Will Keating, the executive director of the Nevada Public Employees Retirement System. He said fund managers around the country were worried that governments would impose increases in the assumed rate not for valid financial reasons but simply to save money.
"It's the way to make the biggest impact on the required contribution," said Mr. Keating, who is also chairman of the Public Pension Coordinating Council, a national association of pension funds.
Financially pressed governments are prevailing on their funds for other types of help, as well. In Minnesota, Gov. Arne Carlson proposed recently that the state pension funds invest $200 million in Northwest Airlines as part of a package to persuade the airline to build maintenance bases in the state and create 2,000 jobs there. Some state-employee groups objected on the grounds that Northwest might not be a good investment, and it is unclear whether the deal will be made.
In Philadelphia, the city government was so strapped for cash earlier this year that it borrowed $150 million from its pension funds for several months.

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on July 21 about cities' and states' use of their pension funds to help balance their budgets misstated the amount borrowed by Philadelphia from its fund. It was $37.5 million, not $150 million.

HEADLINE: Technology;
The Robots That Go Where Humans Fear to Tread

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: HILLSBOROUGH, N.J.

 BODY:
These workers do not mind toiling for hours in 130-degree heat and high humidity, or even working under water. They stroll through deserted machine rooms looking for leaks and breakdowns. They do not notice most radioactivity unless they are told to, in which case they do it better than a human.
 They do get tired climbing stairs. 
The workers are robots in nuclear reactors, with names that are supposed to sound human, like Seymour, Cecil, Rosa or Rover, although their human creators have sometimes tortured a few acronyms to make them sound friendly.
 Robots have not found the market once predicted for them in factories and other business settings, but they are gaining ground in nuclear reactors, where they increasingly show an ability to work in places where humans cannot go for long, or cannot go at all when the reactor is running. In some cases, they go places that humans cannot go under any circumstances.
 Public Service Electric and Gas, for example, is crowing over Cecil, which is being used at the New Jersey utility's Salem 1 reactor unit here. The robot is adept at crawling into one of the most vulnerable parts of a nuclear plant, the steam generator, and doing work that cannot be accomplished any other way.
 Cecil is not the most impressive looking robot; it is of a size and shape to suggest it wandered off a model railroad set. But Cecil illustrates how robots in nuclear plants have the potential for reducing human exposure to radiation, shortening the time that reactors must be shut for maintenance and reducing the potential for accidents.
Utilities are already using robots for 192 different applications, according to Harry Roman, the principal engineer for research at Public Service Electric and Gas, who heads the lab here and is also the president of the Utility/Manufacturers Robot Users Group. The number of tasks will grow, said another expert, James F. Lang, acting director of the nuclear engineering and operation department at the Electric Power Research Institute, a consortium in Palo Alto, Calif. "They are very useful to free up humans going places that are hard for humans to get to, or diving into pools where radiation levels are high," said Mr. Lang, who added that the next generation of nuclear plants will be designed in part around robots.
 Cecil, built by Foster-Miller Inc., of Waltham, Mass., with support from the Electric Power Research Institute and the Empire State Electric Energy Research Corporation, has also been purchased by reactor operators in France and Japan, two countries generally regarded as leaders in nuclear reactor technology. It has also been purchased by the United States Navy for use in submarine propulsion plants. The robots cost more than $1 million each. Foster-Miller said that so far it has sold "more than five" and has interest from other utlities. Last year the company had revenues of $30 million.
 Others, like the Westinghouse Corporation's Rosa, and Jethro and Seymour, being developed by other groups, are beginning to make inroads, too. But growth in the use of robots in nuclear plants is limited by a problem that hamstrings much of the industry: the 111 operating plants embody almost 111 different designs, so standardizing robots to do the same task from reactor to reactor is difficult. In addition, many plants were designed with insufficient thought given to maintenance, so reaching or inspecting critical components can be difficult.
 Robot designers hope for a new generation of plants that will be standardized, with tight corners eliminated and ramps installed instead of stairs. Ramps are critical because robots can weigh several hundred pounds and have trouble hauling themselves up stairs or up even a single step. Generally, robots prefer elevators.
 "One of the things you like in power plants is to minimize your manned access," said Richard Slember, a power plant expert and executive vice president of Asea Brown Boveri in Stamford, Conn. "Making a plant robot-friendly will minimize manned access."
 Cecil began life several years ago at the Consolidated Edison Company's Indian Point 2 reactor in Buchanan, N.Y. The reactor works like most of the reactors in this country: Nuclear fission heats water in the reactor vessel, and the water is kept under pressure to prevent boiling. With repeated passes through the reactor, the water becomes radioactive and must be kept inside the plant.
 The hot, pressurized and radioactive water is passed through a steam generator, which has thousands of thin-walled pipes inside. Cold, clean water on the outside of the pipes is boiled into steam by the reactor heat.
 But at Indian Point 2, as elsewhere, the cold water leaves a corrosive sludge. Humans can clean out the sludge in the first seven or eight rows of tubes in the generator, but no further. Cecil, equipped with a video camera, lights and high-pressure water jet, crawled in another 20 rows and discovered that most of the sludge was deep inside the generator -- but could be cleaned out.
 Public Service, which has emerged as a leader in nuclear plant robotics, improved Cecil so that it could carry miniature tools. At Salem 1, near the southern tip of New Jersey, a Cecil robot crawled more than three feet into the steam generator and retrieved a washer, a welding rod nub and a welding rod, all apparently construction debris.
 The task was not a trivial one. At other plants, foreign objects have rattled around in steam generators until they smashed into tubes and broke them, resulting in the loss of thousands of gallons of radioactive water. Tube ruptures always involve some release of radiation to the environment, and engineers worry that the ruptures could set off a bigger accident.
 Such robotics feats may contribute to stricter safety regulations, said Mr. Roman. If inspection by robot is now possible, he said, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission may decide to require it. Federal regulations like that would be a sales boon to robot makers like Foster-Miller.
 Cecil is only one of several robots. In Mr. Roman's laboratory, another robot, thus far lacking an acronym, crawls on magnetic wheels through pipes, sending back color video pictures as it prowls about looking for signs of wall thinning.
 In any plants, pipes that look normal from the outside may actually be growing thin on the inside and about to burst, an accident which has occasionally killed workers. It is hoped the magnetic-wheeled robot might be able to detect the problem.
 The robot, less than five inches high and wide, comes with 100 feet of control tether, and, like Cecil, a computer on the end that controls the robot's movements. Engineers here are working on modifications to let the robot climb steeper grades.
 Another robot, Westinghouse's Rosa, short for Remotely Operated Service Arm, can also work in steam generators, but on the side where the radioactive water flows. It can test tubes through which the water flows and plug defective ones. Rosa and Cecil never meet, however; they are separated by a thick steel plate that holds up the tubes.
 So far, robots are limited in their ability to make decisions, but their designers are studying how to give them rudimentary intelligence. Mr. Roman is developing a robot named Jethro, whose crawler tractor treads can negotiate stairs. Jethro measures radiation and humidity, collects air samples, swipes at surfaces to measure contamination and sends back audio and video signals.
 The next step, said Mr. Roman, is to program its on-board computer to sort through the sounds it hears, identify those that are abnormal and alert the operator.
 Sea-Mor -- Seymour -- can work alone but is more useful as an underwater helper. With video camera, light, claw-like hand and propellers to push it forward, back, up and down, Sea-Mor helped a human diver at the Hope Creek reactor adjacent to Salem 1 here.
 One underwater robot helped end a service shutdown at Salem 1 a day early, according to Mr. Roman, saving $500,000 in electric power. So far, Public Service calculates it has saved $3 million with robots, on expenses of $1.5 million.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Harry T. Roman, an engineer, with an inspection robot. Above: Sea-Mor, an underwater robot. (Photographs by John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dell Aims for the Big Leagues

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Humbled leaders of big personal computer companies like I.B.M., Apple and and Compaq Computer have slashed prices, trimmed payrolls and even linked arms this year in various deals to share technology and revive an industry beset by a lag in new technology, financially ailing dealerships and a recession. But not Michael Dell.
 The 26-year-old Mr. Dell is winning corporate customers, expanding his staff and grabbing market share by playing marketing hardball, stressing service and churning out reliable, innovative and lower-cost desktop models -- all I.B.M. compatible -- that fill market voids. 
Formed here in 1984 as a pesky mail-order company known as PC Limited, the Dell Computer Corporation's winning formula, analysts perdict, could help nearly double its sales, to $1 billion next year from $546 million in 1990, even if demand for personal computers remains sluggish. Its revenues rose by 45 percent, to $175 million, in the first quarter, even though industry sales in the United States were flat.
 But success has spawned competition. Now, with a host of me-too marketers often undercutting its prices and bigger rivals pricing their products more aggressively, Dell is having to rethink its position. To distance itself from these new clone-makers and compete more directly in the big leagues, Dell has been cutting prices more cautiously and plowing more money into research.
 A rash of new products has resulted. Dell introduced a staggering total of 18 new models in the last 12 months, configured specifically to take business away from the Compaq Computer Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation. "That is the essence of our strategy," said Mr. Dell, whose 35 percent stake in Dell is now worth almost $230 million.
 The models include a notebook-size computer with a battery lasting three-and-a-half hours -- 30 minutes longer than the Compaq model. Another is the fastest version of the most powerful I.B.M.-compatible model, using the 50 megaherz chip in Intel's 486 series of microprocessors, which entered the market last month. Dell also mounted a broad attack this year against one of Compaq's best sellers, the Deskpro 386/25e. Four new machines, all built around the i386SX microprocessor but varying in speed and size, range in price from $2,900 to $3,900, compared with the Deskpro's $4,500 list price.
 "The battle in the PC business this year and in '92 will be to replace your product as quickly as you can at every price point," said Daniel C. Benton, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "Dell has filled virtually every single niche in the $2,000 to $4,000 price range. That is the sweet spot in the market."
 Indeed, when the Southern California Edison Company gave department managers the option of buying either Dell or I.B.M. models this year, Dell prevailed by a margin of three to one, receiving orders for about 300 machines. "Especially in times like now, when dollars are scarce," Dell has the edge, said Nick Condap, the utility's manager of personal computer products.
 In most cases, Dell's prices remain 10 percent or more lower than I.B.M's and Compaq's. Its distribution methods have also proved more efficient than the independent dealerships that sell large volumes of I.B.M. and Compaq machines. Corporate managers say dealers like Businessland have lost customers because, as machines have become like commodities, buyers rely less on others to assess different brands.
 Perhaps most critical, service quality can range from good to abysmal even within the same dealer network. That is why Ebasco Services, a consulting and engineering firm in New York, switched mainly to Dell products. "We're a mobile company, operating from project to project and trailer to trailer on short-term jobs," said Hal Manoogian, Ebasco's head of corporate purchasing. "We began to find out that some dealers were not surviving. We can't ship equipment all over the country just to get it fixed."
 Dell long ago broadened its sales effort beyond mail-order advertisements, adding representatives to call directly on big companies, which, along with government and education buyers contributed nearly half of Dell's sales last year. And last fall, for the first time, the company, in an effort to reach out to small business and individual buyers, shipped machines to one of several fast-growing discount computer retailers, the Soft Warehouse, now called CompUSA.
 Dell benefits from its direct links with customers that companies that sell mostly through dealerships do not enjoy. Owners of Dell products can call a toll-free telephone service for problem-solving. Records of thousands of customer calls are analyzed each month, in an effort to spot consumer trends. Mr. Dell maintained that the exercise gives his product designers better and faster information than I.B.M. or Compaq get from their dealers about what features will help new machines sell faster.
 Dell executives acknowledge that frequent callers drive up costs. But they say improvements in handling common questions and complaints have reduced the average call to six minutes, from 12, in the last three years and have kept the cost of the program flat.
"It's a very inexpensive way of providing service," said Eugene G. Glazer, an analyst at Dean Witter, in New York.
 The combination of toll-free customer service and, when necessary, the promise of repairs within 24 hours are big reasons why Dell has often outranked its rivals in customer surveys, including one earlier this year by J.D. Power and Associates. Rivals, stung, point to other surveys. Compaq announced this month that a customer survey by Datamation magazine placed it atop a list of companies selling fast and powerful machines with the i486 chip. And Hewlett-Packard said last week that it outranked Compaq, Dell and I.B.M. in a Datamation survey of corporate buyers of i386 machines.
 In 1990, Dell held 1.2 percent of the country's mammoth I.B.M.-compatiable personal computer market, according to the International Data Corporation, a market research firm in Framingham, Mass. Although its share is still growing, competitors are crowding Dell. Newcomers to the mail-order business include Northgate, of Eden Prairie, Minn., and Gateway 2000, of North Sioux City, S.D., each of which had sales of more than $200 million in 1990. Zeos International, of St. Paul, Minn., had revenues of $100 million last year.
 Another Austin-based clone-maker, the Compuadd Computer Corporation, has been selling similar models at prices 5 percent to 15 percent below Dell's. Compuadd, a privately held company owned by Bill Hayden, a former engineer at Texas Instruments, has a growing network of nearly 100 discount stores and generated $515 million in sales last year, not far behind Dell.
 Noting that Dell finished 1990 with 2,100 employees, compared with 1,500 at Compuadd, Edward D. Thomas, Compuadd's president, suggested that Dell could become vulnerable if its expenses and profit margins get too fat. "Our expenses are lower," he said.
 Some analysts say smaller rivals have already put chinks in Dell's armor. "They are turning out quality products and selling them at much lower prices because they don't have the R.&D. staff that Dell has," said Seymour Merrin, head of Merrin Information Services, a marketing research firm in Menlo Park, Calif.
 Yet the mail-order rivals may fade into oblivion if they continue to spend little money for research on products to follow the mainstream i386SX machines. Mr. Benton of Goldman, Sachs said Dell wisely increased its gross profit margins to 33.3 percent last year, from 29.2 in 1989, by not cutting prices too far below Compaq and I.B.M.
 That gives Dell more money for new products and for a marketing campaign to offset fierce efforts at I.B.M. and Compaq. Compaq turned to the courts last March to try to halt brash advertisements by Dell that it claimed inaccurately compared list prices for some popular models. Dell was forced to make changes in advertisements running in Britain, but so far has not had to alter its American campaign. Compaq took another swipe in April, cutting list prices on some of its models by as much as 34 percent.
 And in June, I.B.M. introduced three lower-priced models based on the Intel Corporation's standard i386 chip. The new models, priced between $2,000 and $2,925, are aimed straight at Dell's territory.
 "These are absolute screamers in terms of price and performance," said Leslie Fiering, a personal computer analyst at the Gartner Group in Stamford, Conn. She said the new models would tempt some former I.B.M. customers who defected to Dell and other lower-priced models "to come back to the I.B.M. fold."
 For his part, Mr. Dell said Compaq's attacks backfired by focusing more attention on Dell's lower prices. "They had the biggest marketing mystique you could imagine," he said. "Now they've thrown that away and convinced customers who bought from them that they paid too much." And I.B.M.'s counterpunch with the i386 machines has not slowed Dell's advance, he said.
 Then there are the new alliances. Compaq, Digital Equipment and more than 20 other computer companies are trying to create standards for powerful work stations that some executives and analysts anticipate will replace I.B.M.-compatible personal computers. Separately, Apple and I.B.M. have agreed to share technology to bolster their positions in the splintering PC market. Apple will share software technology that I.B.M. needs to ease its reliance on the Microsoft Corporation and in turn obtain rights to the RS/6000 microprocessor that I.B.M. has developed for powerful computers.
 Mr. Dell is ignoring the alliances, betting that customers will prefer, and that Dell can design, machines built around advanced versions of the Intel computer chips that have been at the heart of each new generation of I.B.M.-compatible models. Software companies have written thousands of programs that customers use on machines run by Intel 386 and 486 micrprocessors, he said, and that they will want to put more effort into new programs for machines built around the 586 chip Intel is now developing.
 "People have been talking about this clashing of the PC's and work stations for a number of years, but not very much has happened," Mr. Dell said. "If there are standards for the work station business, then we believe we have the capability to develop products around those standards as well as anybody."
 
DELL'S SOURCE: MR. RESEARCH
 The tenure of G. Glenn Henry as head of research at the Dell Computer Corporation got off to a rocky start when he and Michael Dell concluded early last year that they had to scrap a series of innovations.
 Once a star scientist and manager in I.B.M.'s personal computer unit, with the rare status of I.B.M. Fellow, the highest ranking for scientists, Mr. Henry moved to Dell in 1988. He said he had become frustrated with I.B.M.'s strategy, especially its reliance on dealers. "I looked around and found that Dell actually had the formula for success," said Mr. Henry.
 He quickly expanded its research staff and then designed a new product line using a faster method for handling computing tasks, called multiprocessing, and a faster chip using fewer codes. New alliances among industry leaders have developed their own versions of this reduced instruction set computing technology, called RISC, and put it at the heart of their efforts.
 But corporate customers who saw early versions of Mr. Henry's creation were unimpressed, mainly because the technology could not run many existing software programs. The decision not to ship models with the multiprocessing gear after having spent millions of dollars on the development left Dell with few new products and a sagging stock price.
 Mr. Henry's group recovered quickly -- with a flurry of 18 new machines that have been introduced since September. "They've succeeded in spotting important technologies that others like I.B.M. and Compaq have used or are about to use," said Jim Seymour, an industry consultant in Austin. "I don't think of them as great innovators, but as great synthesizers."
 Dell has already exploited some discoveries from Mr. Henry's aborted first venture. New models, for instance, can be converted into faster, more powerful machines as faster chips become available. That's because the new machines are equipped with plug-in cards, now holding either i386SX or i486 chips. The engineering problems were mastered in Mr. Henry's multiprocessor project.

LENGTH: 930 words

HEADLINE: Village Captured in Photos, 60 Years Apart

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: HASTNGS-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
IN the 1920's, a retired chemist who had recently moved to this Hudson River community from Brooklyn explored his new surroundings with camera in tow and a scientist's perspective, diligently photographing village scenes and meticulously documenting the images for future generations.
But Dr. Arthur C. Langmuir, photographing nearly 1,100 local scenes over two decades, also had another mission. The photographer, historians say, was a man ahead of his time, an environmentalist before it was fashionable to be one. 
 Working just before and during the Depression, Dr. Langmuir was dismayed by the condition of some of the sites he was viewing through his camera lens. A newspaper clipping from the period reads: "Clean-Up Championed by Langmuir, Cites Need for Spic-and-Span Village."
 
Open Spaces Are Gone
 Today, more than 60 years after the majority of Dr. Langmuir's photographs were made, the local historical society, which is celebrating its 20th anniversary, has started to rephotograph 500 of the images to see just how much the village has changed.
"Some things are so different you wouldn't recognize the site, while others really haven't changed that much at all," said Mary L. Allison, trustee and photo archivist for the Hastings-on-Hudson Historical Society.
"Where there were big open spaces, it is now developed," Ms. Allison said, citing the most noticeable change in the landscape during the years since Dr. Langmuir photographed. "And in some places, the foliage has grown so that the view has been obscured." In contrast, one community field, she said, looks much the same today, except for the addition of tennis courts and a children's playground.
As for championing a "spic-and-span quality" for Hastings-on-Hudson, Dr. Langmuir's goal had been achieved, Ms. Allison said. The photographer recorded scenes of rusty cars, bedsprings and other castoffs on public roads, not just in the poorer sections of town, but also on the streets of well-to-do neighborhoods.
 
Debris Taken for Granted
 Through his photojournalism, Ms. Allison said, Dr. Langmuir helped residents become aware of the condition of their surroundings and urged them to improve it. He also hired unemployed people to haul away the garbage littering the streets.
"People are more conscious of the environment today," Ms. Allison said. "They wouldn't stand for all that clutter and debris that everyone took for granted then."
Under the Margaret Kennedy Photography Project, named for a historical society trustee who died in 1990, 10 local photographers, amateurs and professionals, have been given copies of some of Dr. Langmuir's images and assigned to rephotograph the sites under similar weather and lighting conditions.
"You almost go through a time warp doing this, since you know he was standing right there," said Mary Fennell, a magazine photojournalist and teacher who has been shooting scenes in the village's small business district and in some residential areas.
Ms. Fennell said it was "like solving a mystery," working with the old photos and trying to find the same scenes, despite the changes. She said, for example, that she looked for angles of an old building that might have undergone renovation or had trees grow up around it, to be sure that it was the same location. Trying to replicate the photos, she said she always worked at the same time of day and under similar light conditions, occasionally going out in a snowstorm to achieve the desired effect.
Robert Nelson, an amateur photographer who owns an advertising and marketing company, said rephotographing residential sites emphasized the transitory quality of life.
"In some cases, the houses had not changed that much," Mr. Nelson said. "Only the occupants had. You know that if someone was in that house 60 years ago raising a family, a new family is there today. It gave me a different kind of perspective on the changes that had taken place."
Many of Dr. Langmuir's negatives were given to the historical society by his daughter, Ruth Van de Water. More negatives were found in the attic of the photographer's home on South Broadway when it was sold to its current occupants.
All the photographs and negatives were accompanied by detailed notes, citing the date and place that the picture was taken, the film used and the f-stop set on Dr. Langmuir's camera.
In 1979, with a $725 Corporate Community Jobs Project grant from the county, the society hired a high school student to begin cataloguing the photographs, which Ms. Allison refers to as "the jewel of our collection." The photographs were divided into categories like "scenic and historical," "neighborhoods," "schools," "clean-up project" and "business district."
The catalogued photos remained in the archives of the historical society, which is in a 19th-century tenant farmer's cottage on Washington Avenue, until last year, when trustees of the 1,200-member organization decided to embark upon the current project.
"We had been thinking of this project for some time," Ms. Allison said. "We decided the time had come to do for future generations what Dr. Langmuir did for us. In that sense, this is more than a then-and-now project. We want to leave a record for those that come after us, the way he did."
The society is paying the photographers a small fee for each negative it uses. In return, all future rights to the pictures are given to the society.
The Margaret Kennedy Photography Project, which is being financed through private donations, will culminate with a public exhibition next year.

Langmuir); Mary Fennell is one of several photographers working on a project to reshoot scenes photographed by Dr. Langmuir. (Elsa Brenner)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 760 words

HEADLINE: Life in Splitsville

BYLINE: By Barbara Ehrenreich; Barbara Ehrenreich is the author of "The Worst Years of Our Lives," a collection of essays of social criticism.

 BODY:

DIVORCE
An American Tradition.
By Glenda Riley.
Illustrated. 262 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $24.95.  
 Moving along from such issues as school prayer and abortion, this country's "pro-family" forces are gearing up to restrict the right to divorce. And why not? Divorce is the veritable plutonium of domestic fission, leaving a trail of heartbreak, confusion and the poverty of single-mother households. But the one thing opponents of divorce will not be able to claim is that it contradicts this country's traditional values. As the subtitle of Glenda Riley's thoroughgoing and thoroughly intelligent study announces, divorce is an American tradition, going back more than 300 years.
The Puritans, for example, who are sometimes imagined to be the direct progenitors of Phyllis Schlafly and Pat Robertson, granted divorces on such grounds as female adultery, male cruelty, bigamy, desertion, failure to provide and even impotence. The first colonial divorce, Ms. Riley writes, was awarded in 1639 to a Mrs. James Luxford, on the ground of bigamy, and resulted in her husband's being fined and "set in the stocks an hour upon the market day."
The Declaration of Independence, which may be the most momentous divorce document in history, gave added legitimacy to what was already a venerable institution. In fact, Ms. Riley tells us that Thomas Jefferson appears to have honed his famous linkage of independence and personal happiness while working as a lawyer on a divorce case in the early 1770's. In the wake of the Revolution, divorce seekers began to frame their arguments in terms of "tyranny," "misrule," "injustice" and the newly claimed right to the "pursuit of happiness."
And divorce they did, in numbers that astonished European visitors, says Ms. Riley, who teaches American history at Ball State University. Women, who over the years have been twice as likely to initiate divorce proceedings, discarded husbands on grounds of drunkenness, desertion, gambling, infidelity and, increasingly, the vague charge of "cruelty."
But men were not always the parties at fault. In the 19th century, errant wives risked the loss of their children, yet they too abandoned marriages in search of freedom or true love. Ms. Ri ley cites several cases of white Southern women who were divorced for producing half-black babies and who "publicly acknowledged" that their lovers were "negro slave[s]." In another case of remarkable female daring cited in "Divorce: An American Tradition," Mrs. May Walker disappeared in the company of 17-year-old Mabel Wade, a "very good looking girl."
If divorce always seems to be a modern evil, it is because the divorce rate has been rising inexorably, decade after decade, century after century. There have been especially steep increases after each war and occasional plateaus, associated chiefly with economic hard times. As Ms. Riley ably shows, restrictive laws have never successfully curbed the American impulse to break free from the bonds of marriage. Historically, disgruntled spouses have simply deserted, run off to less restrictive states or set up more congenial menages outside the law. Nineteenth-century South Carolina, for example, had to compensate for its lack of legal divorce by effectively recognizing adulterous liaisons.
Not surprisingly, the debate over divorce is almost as much of an American tradition as divorce itself. Even women, who have the most at stake in a strictly economic sense, have long been divided. Some 19th-century feminists opposed divorce as an escape hatch for feckless males; others saw it as a kind of Emancipation Proclamation for female "slaves" of all colors. The greatest reform effort, a drive at the beginning of this century to create a uniform national divorce law and thus abolish the notorious "divorce mills" of Western states like Nevada, foundered on American ambivalence. Family stability is a fine old value, but so is individual liberty.
All those tempted to join the new crusade against divorce should be required to read "Divorce: An American Tradition," cover to cover and pencil in hand. They may be forced to conclude, along with many of our ancestors, that divorce is indeed a great evil and source of much suffering. But then so is the institution that generates it -- marriage, especially marriage under conditions of gross inequality between the sexes. Perhaps the surest way to reduce the rate of divorce, as some reformers suggested almost two centuries ago, would be to restrict the grounds for marriage.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 30; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1040 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE;
Prince Charles Pursues a Green and Pleasant Land

BYLINE: By WENDY STEINER; Wendy Steiner, a professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania, has been working in England on current issues in architecture and fiction.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
In a dim attic office in St. James's Palace, plans are afoot for the Prince of Wales's second annual Summer School in Civil Architecture, which will begin on Aug. 3. This program, Prince Charles's most recent attempt to erase what he sees as the blot of modernism on the British cityscape, has provoked a good deal of media attention and something akin to hysteria among architects.
 Supporters hope the school will reintroduce the beauty and civility lost since the introduction of modernist architecture. Opponents, mostly modernist architects, fear that the Prince's intervention has put a hex on their efforts to grab important building contracts in the United Kingdom. In an age of computers, professors of architecture disdain a return to the old-fashioned life drawing and crafts training that form the basis of the summer school curriculum. 
 The opening session of the school on the campus of Oxford University last summer was veiled in the kind of secrecy that other countries reserve for the development of strategic weapons. Lecturers were pledged not to speak to the press as a condition of employment; all but a few reporters were refused access to the site, and the only press release was an application-form blurb by Prince Charles extolling "civil architecture." This year, with a new director, Brian Hanson, who is also the Prince's "secretary in architecture," the tone is calmer. The aim is to consolidate last year's experiments into a program exploring the spiritual dimension of architecture, an idea the Prince's men formulate as "man the builder."
 At stake, as the Prince of Wales sees it, are the livability and traditional look of British cities, the degeneration of which during this second Elizabethan Age has become a cause of national alarm. Over the past six years, the Prince's speeches have delighted the public, and in the process have turned the British design profession on its head. Architecture is now discussed with the passion reserved in the United States for baseball. The problem, in the Prince's view, is that the public has lost faith in the profession. One of his chief architectural advisers, Leon Krier, puts it this way: "People want beauty around them, and everywhere they are denied it."
 The 25 young men and women in last year's session, who came from Britain, America and Europe, set out to instruct themselves in this popular idea of beauty. Two-thirds of them were architects; the rest were civil engineers, artists, craftsmen and builders. They spent five weeks at Magdalen College in Oxford and the British School in Rome, visiting sites and receiving lectures and studio instruction. They practiced the time-honored but by now unfashionable techniques of life drawing, and constructed an architectural order of columns from 19th-century pattern books. They watched as their capitals were cut into stone, and then drew the stone, switching back and forth between two- and three-dimensional conception, the essence of the architectural task.
 Working only from documents, they designed a row house to replace a modernist misfit in an Oxford street, then learned the necessity of modifying their designs after visiting the site and talking to the residents. They invented ornaments and thought hard about small-scale elements like walls and pavements and signs. The assignments were often challenges to bring about a major change by the cheapest and simplest means.
 This training is unlike any other available at the moment in Britain. As things stand, students enter architecture school from high school and take a three-year academic course leading to a degree. Then they spend one year in an office gaining practical experience, two years back in school, and one more year in an office. Their training does not include drawing, carving, bricklaying or other craft or workmanly skills. The Prince is convinced that a return to these techniques will bring about a renaissance in building.
 It may seem puzzling that a small summer program in Oxford and Rome should provoke such heat, but the school is seen as part of the larger British debate between modernism and classicism. Jules Lubbock, last year's principal, says that the school, whose planning the Prince supervised down to the design of the letterhead, is broadly traditional in orientation. It is not solely classicist, as opponents have charged, but exposes students to a variety of styles -- Islamic, Gothic, classical, even modernist. The point, he says, is to teach the best that the history of architecture has to offer.
 Paul Finch, editor of the London trade publication Building Design and an avid Prince watcher, claims that Charles is coming to the conclusion that his quarrel is not with modernism but with bad modernism. The Prince's enthusiasms have gone from community architecture to neo-classicism to, most recently, the kind of reconciliation of technology and nature practiced by Frank Lloyd Wright. He seems no longer to be championing one style over all the rest, but accepting the idea that the quality of thought behind architecture is what counts.
 Ron Heron, an official of the Architectural Association school, which has trained some of London's most diverse and influential architects, is sure the summer school will only institutionalize the worst aspects of the Prince's program.
 "It's not about architecture, but movie-set values, how it looks from the street," he says. "What is needed is invention and wit responding to the context of life as it is now."
 Despite the fears the school provokes in Britain, Brian Hanson reports growing interest among members of the Economic Community and Eastern Europeans in collaborating with it. Many Britishers within the profession have adopted a wait-and-see attitude. Paul Finch wrote in a Building Design editorial last summer: "Whether teaching people the virtues of drawing the orders guarantees something different is far from clear. But there is a strong case for the Prince's school continuing, if only to add to the variety of educational approaches now being adopted. And it will keep us in stories for our next thousand issues." Perhaps. How often does one get to announce a stylistic revolution by royal decree?

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2954 words

HEADLINE: On the Way With L.B.J.

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann, a national correspondent for The Atlantic, is the author of "The Promised Land: The Great Black Migration and How It Changed America."

 BODY:

LONE STAR RISING
Lyndon Johnson and His Times, 1908-1960.
By Robert Dallek.
Illustrated. 721 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $30.  
 During the last decade of Lyndon B. Johnson's long political career, the country changed in ways that took him completely by surprise. To cite just one aspect of the change, from the province of intellectual life: before the 1960's a prominent academic historian who undertook to write the biography of a major political leader would surely have felt himself to be within a secure, central, admired tradition in American culture. Johnson did not keep up with American culture, but if he had, he would have wholeheartedly approved of this state of affairs: the big men of the academy naturally gravitating, as they sought to understand how the country worked, toward the study of the big men of politics.
Today, as the aftereffects of the period when Johnson was President continue to play out across our society, Robert Dallek's rock-solid biography, "Lone Star Rising," has, like its subject, an unmistakable air of embattlement about it. To one side of Mr. Dallek, a professor of history at the University of California, Los Angeles, is mainstream academia, which now considers a project like his to be intellectually uninteresting and beside the point: ideas and economic and social structures, not powerful leaders, determine the course of history. To the other side is Robert A. Caro, representing another aspect of the broad national shift that caught Lyndon Johnson unawares, the rise of the press to a position of power and self-confidence -- so much so that a journalist-author like Mr. Caro can now attempt a magisterial multivolume political biography of Johnson that concedes no ground to professional historians.
In his preface, Mr. Dallek complains that "there exists a hatred of Johnson that passes the bounds of common sense and contributes nothing to historical understanding"; he says we "now need a balanced biography." Obviously this is a slap at Mr. Caro, and it makes Mr. Dallek look as if he might be in danger of crossing the line from balanced into defensive. In a few places in the early going, he seems to be gritting his teeth as he gets through material Mr. Caro used to demonize Johnson -- such as Johnson's dirty campaign to take over student politics at his college, or the nervous breakdown to which he drove his early aide Gene Latimer. Mr. Dallek makes a point of counterbalancing this sort of material with blandly sunny on-the-other-hand statements. For example, in the college section, he writes that Johnson "was an exceptionally warm person who made friends easily and took a genuine interest in them."
On the whole, though, and especially after he gets past the part of Johnson's life that was covered in Mr. Caro's first volume, Mr. Dallek is absolutely not an apologist. It does him an injustice even to discuss his work in terms of whether it is positive, negative or balanced about Johnson (though Mr. Dallek is the one who put those terms into play), because his interest in his subject is so obviously that of a seeker after truth rather than someone out to attack or defend. He doesn't pull any obvious punches: Johnson, in these pages, is crude, egomaniacal and capable of being cruel to the people around him. Mr. Dallek shows him using his position in the Government to enrich himself through the acquisition of broadcasting licenses, and stealing the 1948 election that put him in the United States Senate. He was wiretapping opponents and receiving enormous illegal campaign contributions a quarter-century before Watergate. His racial attitudes were mixed up beyond any possibility of our untangling them cleanly now: Mr. Dallek quotes him defending the Supreme Court appointment of the very well-known Thurgood Marshall, rather than a black judge less identified with the civil rights cause, by saying to a staff member, "Son, when I appoint a nigger to the court, I want everyone to know he's a nigger."
There is a substantial difference in feel between Mr. Dallek's Johnson and Mr. Caro's, but it springs from the way in which the two authors handle their material, not from a great disparity in the basic information they have at their disposal. (One of Johnson's many paradoxes is that although he loved to keep secrets from people, a good deal of the dirt on him is publicly available in the Presidential library that he built as a monument to himself and staffed with loyal former aides; Mr. Dallek even quotes from documents that people sent L.B.J. with the request that he destroy them after reading, which now reside in the marble palace in Austin.) Without pushing the armchair psychologizing too hard, Mr. Dallek presents Johnson as what is known as a borderline personality -- a man who, as a result of childhood traumas (mainly, Mr. Dallek speculates, the conditional nature of his mother's overpowering love for him), had to spend his whole life struggling, without complete success, to keep himself within the bounds of functional society.
Johnson in pursuit of political office, Mr. Dallek points out, was a desperate man, helplessly in the grip of "some sense of unrelenting deprivation" and willing to do nearly anything to win the prize. But once he got it he usually performed magnificently, driving himself and the people around him to get the Government to do more than it ever had for people who needed help. Johnson made an epic achievement even out of that most routine of a politician's tasks, answering constituent mail: Mr. Dallek has him once dictating and signing 258 letters in a day. In Mr. Caro's books, Johnson's rise seemed foreordained, and the empathy of readers was directed toward the people unfortunate enough to get in his way. In "Lone Star Rising," the odds against Johnson feel extremely long, and you find yourself rooting for him.
In part because of the lack of scholarly interest in Johnson, his current historical balance sheet is oversimplified: there is one big item in the assets column, civil rights, and one overwhelming liability, the war in Vietnam. "Lone Star Rising" ends with Johnson's election to the Vice Presidency -- Mr. Dallek plans a second volume on the rest of L.B.J.'s life -- so it does not directly try to correct or explain the main impressions we have of his Presidency. But it does provide interesting hints as to why he could have got one issue so right and the other so wrong.
Johnson spent nearly his whole career feeling vulnerable on his right flank. He won his seat in Congress because, in 1937, central Texas was still deep in the Depression and he was able to demonstrate a connection to Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was a god there. In 1941 he lost (or, more accurately, had stolen from him) his first Senate race, to the reactionary, buffoonish Pappy O'Daniel. In 1948 his opponent was the reactionary, upstanding Coke Stevenson, whose supporters felt comfortable also backing Strom Thurmond's Dixiecrat Presidential campaign that year. When he became a statewide politician, Johnson acquired a much more conservative constituency than he had had as a Congressman, and one that made up for being less intensely segregationist than the rest of the South by being more intensely anti-Communist and antilabor. Only a month after the 1948 election, Johnson told Bobby Baker, the head Senate page, that "the New Deal spirit's gone from Texas."
Throughout his career he flourished as a doer -- in every job, he accomplished more than anyone ever had before -- and as a compromiser. His triumphant period as Senate majority leader, when he engineered the censure of Senator Joseph McCarthy and the passage of the first civil rights law in decades (using persuasive techniques up to and including lobbying the air traffic controllers at Washington's National Airport to land planes in the order he preferred), came at a time when the Democrats had only a one-seat majority. Johnson openly allied himself with the Eisenhower Administration, and made himself the person liberals had to come to if they wanted to get anything done. When he found himself dealing with liberals who were more powerful and farther to the left, as he did after the 1958 and 1964 elections, it threw him off his feed; what was natural for him was placing himself a few notches to the left of the position of the right. On Vietnam, this meant pursuing strong but not annihilatory policies, and his instinctive expectation was that the liberals would thank him for having tamed the conservative beast again.
Perhaps the larger problem was that Johnson's experience did not prepare him well for an executive role. He was used to mediating among competing interests, not deciding what course the nation should follow. As dominating as Johnson was personally, he could be dominated by others intellectually. And he was especially vulnerable to this in the area of foreign policy. As early as 1940, one of Johnson's mentors, the Texas attorney Alvin Wirtz, was writing him, "I will admit you are a whiz on domestic problems but I still think that on international problems you should listen to the elder statesmen."
Johnson's domestic agenda as President was not something he had dreamed up: he was applying his awesome political skills to ideas that he had been hearing all of his adult life. On racial issues, he had been preoccupied for decades with the idea that segregation, besides being immoral, was keeping the South from economic prosperity and Southern politicians from holding national office. But in the case of Vietnam, Johnson himself had to make the decision, based on the advice of experts, of what American policy should be, and all he personally had to go on was a lifetime of promilitary, internationalist, anti-Communist opinions. Mr. Dallek quotes him criticizing Eisenhower's decision not to intervene in the battle of Dien Bien Phu in 1954, which makes the disastrous escalation in 1965 look very much like a foregone conclusion.
It would have been very hard, anyway, for Johnson to have conceived of dovish liberalism as an important political tendency before it emerged as one. In 1958 the columnist Drew Pearson, who habitually nagged at Johnson from the left, published a book called "USA -- Second Class Power." In bringing up this and other details about the climate of the late 1950's, Mr. Dallek reminds us that an interventionist strain in foreign policy dominated the Democratic Party for all of Johnson's years on Capitol Hill. He categorizes Johnson ideologically as "a liberal nationalist who saw a broad consensus for a strong defense against external threats and for domestic programs that eased the problems of an advanced industrial society and particularly served the economic needs of the South."
Like everything Mr. Dallek says, this is completely sound as an overall explanation for the domestic and foreign policy choices Johnson made as President, but it doesn't soar. There will be plenty of room left after Mr. Dallek completes his biography for more theoretically daring historians to explain the meaning of Johnsonism. "Lone Star Rising" whets the appetite not only for Mr. Dallek's second volume, but for their work, and also for Mr. Caro's next volume; Mr. Dallek brings Johnson himself to life, but Mr. Caro will surely make figures like Bobby Baker, the sleazy idiot savant of the Senate, and the aptly named Allan Shivers, the cold-blooded Governor of Texas in the early 1950's, memorable in a way that is beyond Mr. Dallek's literary capabilities. The rustle of index cards is always detectable behind Mr. Dallek's prose -- but he would never let the urge to dramatize the material get such a hold on him that he could present the 1948 Senate race as a struggle between good and evil, as Mr. Caro did. For better and for worse, Mr. Dallek is the rare present-day practitioner of the "three yards and a cloud of dust" school of biography. He lays out the facts and allows the grand themes to emanate from them, relatively untouched by authorial hands.
The main emanation that is given off by the facts of Lyndon Johnson's life and times is that the country he inhabited is different from the one we live in now chiefly because of the role of government. Johnson believed unshakably that government was both the best vehicle for solving people's problems and the place where the most ambitious people would naturally come to seek the gaudy success they wanted. The businessmen Johnson knew well -- lawyer-lobbyists, construction magnates, broadcasting executives -- gravitated to government to obtain money no less than the politicians he knew did to obtain power. Mr. Dallek calls Johnson's friends "self-serving altruists," which is apt. Johnson's world was one in which educated, accomplished people put years of scheming into getting jobs as postmasters.
In part this is a phenomenon common in third world countries, of which Texas was one when Johnson was coming of age; on the other hand nothing happened during Johnson's career as a national politician in the 1950's to change his view that the more the Federal Government could do in every area, the better. In Mr. Dallek's account it is plain that politically, the Government was to some extent a victim of its own success. The New Deal coalition began to erode -- very dramatically in Texas -- as soon as ordinary working people ceased feeling poor. Later, when Johnson was President, his Great Society programs did bring the South into the national mainstream and make the Sun Belt phenomenon possible, but they also Southernized the rest of the country by introducing into national politics the preoccupation with race that had long bedeviled Southern liberalism.
It appears that one of Johnson's clearest intimations of the mortality of American politics as he had always practiced it came when John F. Kennedy won the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1960. Nothing in politics had ever taken Johnson so much by surprise. As Mr. Dallek demonstrates, Johnson truly, almost poignantly, believed that the attention of the electorate was focused on the progress of legislation on Capitol Hill. It was inconceivable to him that a man whose main assets were charm, grace, eloquence, vision and looks, rather than a track record, and who was more wired in to the news media than to the organized political constituencies, would be found preferable to him. Johnson had always assumed that the political fate of liberalism would be a function of how many Government benefits it could deliver; Kennedy demonstrated that in the postwar United States liberals could win on the basis of abstract leadership qualities, and thus instantly reduced the centrality of the Government in society.
Little more than a decade after Johnson left the White House following five years of frenetic Federal activity, another Southwesterner, Ronald Reagan, took the oath of office on the steps of the Capitol, and immediately proclaimed that "government is the problem." Explaining how we got from one extreme to the other over such a short period of time is one of the crucial tasks for those who seek to provide us with a full understanding of late 20th-century America. Surely Johnson's Presidential performance played an important part in the story, and surely some kind of social transformation of the United States did too. It will probably take a small shelf's worth of important books-of-the-future to get us to the point where we know what happened -- and there is every reason to expect that one of them will be Robert Dallek's next volume.
 
 
 
'NO ONE'S GOING TO HAVE THE LAST WORD'


 When Robert Dallek, the author of "Lone Star Rising," was asked for his opinion on the work of Robert A. Caro, his rival Johnson biographer, Mr. Dallek responded with a single word: "Who?"
There followed silence and a laugh.
Although Mr. Caro has written two highly popular and highly critical volumes and plans two more, Mr. Dallek insisted, "I'm not writing against Caro, I'm writing on Lyndon Johnson. It's all to the good that we have competing views of L.B.J. This is what fuels historical understanding and interest." And Mr. Dallek added: "I'm not a believer in definitive history or biography. No one's going to have the last word."
The two actually met once -- at the Johnson Library, appropriately enough, where both men were working on what turned out to be dissimilar interpretations of Johnson's life. According to Mr. Dallek, their meeting was "perfectly cordial and amiable," except, perhaps, for the first words out of Mr. Caro's mouth. When Mr. Dallek introduced himself, Mr. Caro asked, "Who are you?"
"He knew exactly who I was," Mr. Dallek said.
Speaking by telephone from his home in Los Angeles -- where, he says, a stern-visaged campaign poster of L.B.J. dominates his study -- the 57-year-old Mr. Dallek described himself as "an old-fashioned liberal" who started the project "with a pretty critical perspective" on Johnson. "I was surprised by the extent to which I found very positive things to say about the man."
The Lyndon B. Johnson Foundation contributed two $1,200 grants toward Mr. Dallek's project, an irony not lost on the author: in a moment of whimsy, Mr. Dallek noted that Johnson "reaches out even from the grave" to spread a little money around. Of course, with the L.B.J. Library charging 30 to 35 cents per page for copying, he said, the money went fast.
"Lone Star Rising," Mr. Dallek's fifth book, took him seven years; the second volume, covering 1960-73, may take as long. The working title is Thomas Jefferson's description of the Presidency: "Splendid Misery." -- JOSEPH A. CINCOTTI
