HEADLINE: HOWELL TOWNSHIP JOURNAL;
Residents Are Angry Over Reservoir's Cost and Water's Taste

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

DATELINE: HOWELL TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
IT is hard to find anyone who does not admire the beauty of the Manasquan Reservoir. The meandering verdant preserve has a 740-acre lake that sprang up in the middle of what used to be little more than the scrubby northern fringes of the Pine Barrens.
Since the reservoir opened and began operating a year ago, under the New Jersey Water Supply Authority, the lake and several hundred adjoining acres have attracted a plethora of wildlife -- deer, waterfowl and songbirds -- and residents say that the sailing and fishing for bass and trout are excellent. 
 Recreation and esthetics aside, Howell Township and other Monmouth County communities that must now augment their ground-water supplies with the reservoir's more expensive surface water are not pleased with the results. Water bills have doubled or quadrupled in the last year or so and are expected by local and state officials to go even higher.
 
Problem Stems From Court Decision
 Howell Township's problem stands out among the 16 or so municipalities and private water companies in Monmouth County that draw from the new reservoir, residents and officials say, because of a decision this year by the Appellate Division of Superior Court and the controversy that preceded it.
Now awaiting a possible review by the State Supreme Court, the Appellate decision upheld the township's abolishment of the Howell Township Municipal Utilities Authority, which, in the interim, has continued to provide the water service.
Local and state officials say there is no end in sight to the rate increases, which essentially are paying for continuing debt service on the local and state bonds that financed the $85 million reservoir, as well as municipal treatment plants and distribution lines that are being built.
"People are paying a lot of attention to the cost of water here, and there have been sizable rate increases," said Thomas R. Waskozich, the Howell Township administrator.
One of those paying attention to the water rates is Mayor Susanne M. Vietergruber, who said her rates had quadrupled, mostly as the result of the reservoir connection. "I'm paying about $200 a quarter now for just me, my husband and two teen-age daughters -- no swimming pool and no lawn sprinklers," the Mayor said.
Jerry Friedhoff and his wife, Patty, who have two children and a modern three-bedroom home, are paying about the same as the Mayor. "I guess I noticed the increases a little over a year ago and, after the initial shock, have sort of gotten used to them by now," Mr. Friedhoff said.
The reservoir water, he said, is "murky and has more air in it" than the well water. But neither he nor his wife has noticed much of a change in the taste, which many people say is worse now because surface water from the reservoir might be more heavily filtered and chlorinated.
 
'It Tastes Horrible'
 "It tastes horrible, nothing like it was when we got our water from the wells," Virginia Wombough of Wall Township said.
While Howell Township officials and members of the Howell Township Municipal Utilities Authority refused to comment on individual complaints about the new water system or the subject of rates, commercial and residential users have been outspoken.
Ron Barrow, the co-owner of the Howell Self-Service Car Wash, said he had paid the same quarterly bills this year, about $1,800, as before the reservoir came into use, despite new water conservation measures at his carwash, which resulted in the use of 25 percent less water this year.
"What makes it really bad in addition to the fact that we have well water in our own backyard that we could be using," he said, "is that we had to pay $21,000 to hook up to the township water when we opened in 1988."
 
Lawn Sprinker System Required
 Mr. Barrow said he had also been required by the township to install sod and a lawn sprinkler system on his commercial property, which, he said, "is the biggest waste of water there is." Since the reservoir came on line, he said, water pressure has decreased considerably, requiring him to install new lawn sprinkler heads because the original ones needed more pressure to function than the township was able to supply.
Although higher water rates have resulted in higher costs to carwash customers in the past, Mr. Barrow and his partner, Chuck Ranges, said that the present economy and competition from other carwashes made it impossible to pass on the latest water rates to customers.
The Manasquan Reservoir is a modified version of one originally proposed for the area in the 1950's and was eventually listed as a $40 million project on the state's Water Supply Bond Referendum Act of 1981.
But a new design and greater treatment of the Manasquan River's customarily coffee-colored waters resulted in the final $85 million expenditure, said Thomas G. Baxter, the chief engineer for the New Jersey Water Supply Authority.
The need for the reservoir, he said, was justified by a 1978 study by the United States Geological Survey. It showed that the area's aquifers were being depleted. Further studies by the State Department of Environmental Protection in the 80's, Mr. Baxter said, resulted in the environmental agency's issuing orders to municipalities to find new water supplies and to limit the pumping of their existing wells. The reservoir presented the only viable alternative, although a costly one, he said.
But Mayor Vietergruber asserted that Howell's wells were never in any danger of being depleted and that the Municipal Utilities Authority, as was stated in the court papers, had contracted with the State Water Supply Authority for far more water than the township could use.
"The reservoir is a truly lovely addition to our township and provides recreational opportunities that our residents never had," the Mayor said. But she added that "we just do not need half the water that we are now required to purchase from the reservoir."
Santa Triolo, the executive director of the Howell Township Municipal Utilities Authority, said the current contracts with the Water Supply Authority, as well as the $11.4 million municipal treatment plant that had to be built to treat the reservoir water, were based on the township's project growth figures and water supply needs in the late 80's.
Howell's rapid growth in the 80's, he said, "came to a grinding halt" in the final years of the decade, and there have been fewer new water customers since.
Mr. Barrow, for one, objected to a recent proposal by the Utilities Authority to require every residence and business in the township to tie into the new municipal water system, which uses the reservoir, even if their own well-water supplies are deemed to be adequate. "It would be totally unfair," Mr. Barrow said.
Ray Sloccum, a resident of Wall Township, said a municipal bond proposal there, which would raise an additional $470,000 to improve local distribution of the reservoir water to residents, was yet another example of how, in the early 80's, taxpayers were never told how much the new water supply would ultimately cost them.
"Township officials just told us back then that we desperately needed a new source of water and that there was no other choice but to accept the reservoir," Mr. Sloccum said, adding that his water bill will increase about $400 this year. "The officials told us it would cost more but never seemed able to say to what extent," he said.
Mrs. Wombough said she and her husband, Robert, were paying $100 a year for up to 100,000 gallons of water before the reservoir came on line last July. This year, she said, their water bill will be "closer to $500" for less water.
The latest water rate increase in Wall came on top of a tax increase, Mrs. Wombough said, and "these increases are causing people like us, who are close to retirement, to consider moving out of the state."
Mrs. Wombough said, "We're just not sure we'll be able to afford to live here after Bob retires."
 
Fixed Incomes Taken Into Account
 Paul Shives, the Wall Township administrator, said the Township Committee had taken people on fixed incomes into account when setting the new water rates. But, he said, the average residential user will be paying $462 this year for 92,250 gallons of water, and rate increases can be expected for the next two years.
Mr. Shives said Monmouth County had simply run out of alternatives for providing the adequate and inexpensive well water that people had become used to over the years. The reservoir, he said, was a costly but proper solution.
If Wall Township had to rely on its own supplies last August during a mild drought, Mr. Shives said, "we wouldn't have been able to fight a fire for very long and we could not have provided a complete supply to residents."
The reservoir, he said, "came on line just in time for us."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Earnings Drop At Affiliated

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 21

 BODY:
Affiliated Publications Inc., the parent of The Boston Globe, says its net profits dropped 58 percent in the second quarter. The company cited continuing decreases in advertising revenues.
Net income was $3.1 million, or 4 cents a share, for the three- month period that ended on June 30. That compared with earnings of $7.4 million, or 11 cents a share, in the comparable period of last year. Revenues totaled $130.9 million, compared with $132.1 million. 
 The company said on Friday that the recession in New England had caused The Globe's ad volume to shrink. Other newspapers have also been suffering financial strains.
Affiliated said the poor advertising climate had also hurt another subsidiary, BPI Communications Inc., which produces arts and design publications as well as Adweek, a trade magazine that experienced an operating loss.
Advertising revenue during the quarter totaled $91.3 million, a 6 percent drop from the period a year earlier.
The company's shares closed unchanged on Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, at $8.875 a share.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Sell Bills and Notes This Week

 BODY:
The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to the bill and note markets, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. The Treasury will auction two-year notes tomorrow, five-year notes on Wednesday and a one-year bill on Thursday.
Late in the day Friday the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 5.58 percent, a six-month bill at 5.73 percent and a one-year bill at 5.88 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.89 percent, while the five-year note was priced to yield 7.89 percent. 
 In Government agency financings, the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation said it planned to announce on Wednesday the interest rates for a three-part bond offering totaling $2.417 billion.

HEADLINE: The Luster Fades at First American

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Although banking regulators are still puzzled by exactly who owns First American Bankshares Inc. of Washington and what connections it had with the recently closed Bank of Credit and Commerce International of Luxembourg, there is not much mystery about the bank's business.
With banks in Washington and six states and $11 billion in assets, enough to make it about the 50th-largest banking company in the country, First American is much like dozens of other regional banking companies, collecting consumer deposits and making loans to local businesses. 
 The group of Middle Eastern investors who bought the company in 1982 are represented by Clark M. Clifford, the 84-year-old chairman of First American and one of Washington's most illustrious lawyers. He is not involved in the company's day-to-day operations, though he is a link between First American and some Middle Eastern investors whose ownerhip of B.C.C.I. is the target of a series of investigations in the United States and abroad for a host of accusations, including one of fraud. Mr. Clifford's junior law partner, Robert A. Altman, is also a director of the bank.
Mr. Clifford, whose ties to First American began when he represented the investors during their four-year battle to acquire First American's predecessor parent, Financial General Bankshares, keeps his primary office at the law firm of Clifford & Warnke. But there is no doubt, said Jack W. Beddow, First American's chief, that Mr. Clifford "sets the overall policy and direction for the company."
Until last year, when the downturn in the Washington real estate market caused First American a loss of $139.3 million, followed by an additional $20 million loss in the first quarter of this year, First American had a record of steady though unspectacular profits. The backbone of the bank is a network of 185 branches in Maryland, Virginia and Washington, making it the third-largest bank in the District of Columbia, Maryland and Virginia.
As it grew in the 1980's, the company spread into New York, including a Park Avenue office; Georgia, and Florida. And until recently, it had a good record of making profitable loans. But its luster has faded with real estate loan losses in the Washington area, while its banks in the Southeast and New York proved to be only marginally profitable and weak competitors against stronger rivals.
 
Feeling a Malaise
 Worse, First American's biggest banks' knack for making good loans deteriorated. Where they once were in the top third of American banks their size, they sank to the bottom 10 percent of the industry when the Washington economy finally slowed and commercial real estate values faded. Regulators have asked the company to expand its capital base to cushion further losses.
"First American is a generally well-run company, but right now they are feeling the malaise of the local economy," said Arnold G. Danielson, a banking consultant in Rockville, Md.
First American's traditional emphasis on business lending, particularly to real estate developers, served it well during the 80's, when the Washington area grew rapidly, but left it vulnerable to losses when real estate prices plummeted in 1990 and developers began defaulting on loans.
 
'A Real Estate Economy'
 According to documents filed with the Federal Reserve, the bank pursued real estate lending with such relish in the booming real estate market of the 80's, that on March 31 of this year, commercial real estate loans accounted for 27.6 percent of the assets at First American's Virginia bank and 30.1 percent at its Maryland bank. The concentration on commercial real estate was unusually high, even for the Washington area. At the American Security Bank of Washington, for example, such loans accounted for 24 percent, while the more conservative Riggs National Bank held such loans to 11 percent.
"This is a real estate economy," said Paul G. Adams, First American's chief operating officer. "Those were basically the kind of loans the market offered."
Mr. Adams said that "until 1989, we had literally no charge-offs of any significance on real estate loans."But he noted that the riskiness of the company's real estate lending rose in the late 80's as developers who had concentrated on lower-risk residential housing moved into riskier commercial projects.
 
Regulatory Intervention
 The 1990 loss led to an agreement with banking regulators three months ago that calls for First American to try to reduce its reliance on real estate lending. Mr. Adams said the plan calls for consumer loans to grow by roughly 13 percent a year, a sharp reversal from the 1987-90 period, when consumer loans fell to $1.2 billion, from $1.39 billion. He expects modest growth in business loans not related to real estate, and a 50 percent decline in real estate construction loans, to about $500 million by 1994.
In the late 80's, fewer than 1 percent of loans at First American's Washington, Maryland and Virginia banks were troubled, and they ranked in the top third of banks their size. But by the end of March 1991, the total of badly delinquent loans and real estate acquired through foreclosure had increased to nearly 12 percent of all assets at the Washington bank and 8 percent in Virginia.
Last month, First American's shareholders complied with regulators' demands for more capital by supplying $39 million of additional funds. The company also agreed early this year to sell its highly profitable Tennessee bank to First Tennessee National Corporation of Memphis for about $75 million, which would produce an additional $22 million of capital for the remaining banks. First American's Florida bank, which has $48.5 million in assets, will also be sold to local investors, but is too small to produce any significant gain.
Except for the real estate lending losses, the major missteps by First American have been those made at the sugggestion of its Middle Eastern owners, as they pushed the company to expand into New York and Georgia. The move into New York started with a new bank in 1983 and was soon supplemented by the purchase of 33 branches and their deposits in the Albany area from the Bankers Trust Company. Since 1986 the $1.6 billion-asset New York bank has never earned more than $2.6 million in a year. It is a mediocre record that First American's owners could easily have bettered by investing the bank's more than $100 million of capital in Treasury bills.
At the time of the move into Georgia, Mr. Beddow, First American's chief executive, said, "We understood our stockholders were interested in having us buy the bank, and they provided us with the money to do it." The Georgia bank, whose $1.53 billion of assets make it the sixth largest in the state, has never been strongly profitable, and its losses of $26.1 million last year and $8.5 million in the first quarter this year are greater than its profits in 1987 through 1989.
 
Well-Positioned in Washington
 The seller of the Georgia bank was Gaith R. Pharaon, a Saudi Arabian businessman and B.C.C.I. shareholder who bought the bank in 1980 from Bert Lance, former budget director under President Jimmy Carter. Mr. Lance was also an adviser to the Middle Eastern investors who created First American in 1982 after buying Financial General.
While Mr. Adams said there is no active plan to sell the New York or Georgia banks, he acknowledged that "it is now recognized that good value to shareholders from a regional bank comes when the bank has a leading position in its local market."
Because of its strong position in the Washington area, where First American has about 7.5 percent share of deposits, after Sovran Bank with 9.2 percent and MNC Financial with 8.4 percent, Mr. Paul said, the company "has a lot more value than might be recognized right now because of the problems." He does not expect a quick sale of the B.C.C.I. holdings, but said that when the shares are available, "my personal view is that some entrepreneurial group will take a position that will later lead to consolidation with some other company."
Mr. Danielson, the analyst, noted that First American is further along than its competition in organizing itself as one company, at least in the Washington area, despite Federal laws requiring it to operate seperate banks in Maryland, Virginia and Washington.
But the centralization process has also been caught up in the unraveling of the company's grandiose plans. A new computer center in Reston, Va., handles processing and account records for all of First American's banks but has the capacity to do much more. To save $3 million annually, First American earlier this year turned the center over to Pro-Systems, a Ross Perot company that needed more space to expand its own processing businesses.
"The computer center was built when we had a vision of being a much bigger bank," Mr. Adams said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press;
Papers begin to See Hints That Ad Slump Is Ending

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
SIX months into 1991, the prospects that newspaper advertising will show an improvement over 1990 are dim at best. A decline in newspaper advertising spending this year would be the first back-to-back annual drop since World War II.
But like the first balmy whiff of spring in early March, the fleeting and elusive scent of better times has been detected by some newspaper exectives. 
 "Before, there was an ill wind blowing, but now there's a still in the air and a sense that the next wind is going to be a good one," said Jerome S. Tilis, vice president of marketing for Knight-Ridder Inc. and chairman of the executive committee of Newspapers First, which sells advertising collectively for 39 newspapers.
Mr. Tilis, like every other newspaper executive contacted for a spot-check of the advertising climate, added that he did not know just when that fair wind might begin to blow.
The Persian Gulf war paralyzed consumer spending and sent newspaper advertising plummeting well below the depressed levels already caused by the recession.
At midyear, the advertising trough remains widespread, but with quirks.
For instance, newspapers in the Northeast continue to suffer and some of New England's papers are in an economic rout. The pain is also sharp, if not so cumulatively deep, at newspapers in California, which had been spared until late last year.
In some markets, real estate advertising is starting to make a comeback and retail advertising has stopped going down after a long slide.
The brief euphoria after the gulf war slowed the advertising decline in May; alas, the trend slowed or sputtered out in June at many papers.
"We don't see any drastic changes in advertising trends," said David Laventhol, president of Times Mirror Inc., who added, "We hope for a slight upturn in the next couple of months, but that's a hope, not a prediction."
Kenneth T. Berents, a media analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, a Baltimore securities firm, has surveyed 1,500 newspapers three times this year, asking them to predict 1991 advertising levels.
Mr. Berents said his January survey indicated that most papers expected a decline in 1991; in his April survey, the decline predicted was greater. And in his latest survey, the first 200 responses indicate that results are expected to be even worse. Mr. Berents said such results meant that many papers had given up hope of a turnaround this year to compensate for the disastrous first quarter.
Yet despite such pessimism about this year's prospects, several newspaper executives said they sensed that the mood of the industry has subtly shifted from the gloom that pervaded at April convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in April.
They characterize the new mood as an embattled realism, bolstered by renewed confidence that when the economy improves, the newspaper business will get significantly better.
Still, unlike other cyclical downturns in newspaper advertising, this one was accompanied by widespread uncertainty about how much advertising would return to newspapers when the economy improved.
Changes in the marketplace -- including department-store consolidations, shifts to advertising by mail and warehouse stores that do not advertise at all -- have caused huge anxiety in the newspaper industry.
As a result, there has been a grim round of soul-searching throughout the industry, which had become lethargic and spoiled by the boom years of the mid-1980's. The last few months have prompted feverish bursts of creativity aimed at finding ways to overcome these changes.
For instance, Mr. Tilis said The St. Paul Pioneer Press, which is owned by Knight-Ridder, formed an alliance with a television station to co-produce and promote a health magazine. The paper also sent an ad salesman to Las Vegas, Nev., and now passengers on flights from St. Paul to Las Vegas get a copy of the paper wrapped in four pages of Las Vegas advertising.
The Pioneer Press has also begun producing local trade shows, which provide income from display space and tickets, as well as assuring newspaper promotion with advertising.
At The New York Times Company's Regional Newspaper Group, which includes 32 small to medium-sized papers, John R. Harrison, the group's president, said many of the papers were concentrating on small advertisers, which had been overlooked in the boom years.
Business directories, with ads from plumbers, pest-control companies and other small businesses, have become a staple at many small papers.
And smaller papers are also aggressively selling ads to car dealerships and other businesses in neighboring towns. This has become a burgeoning source of new advertising that had previously been avoided for fear of angering local merchants.
But part of the new realism is a recognition that the golden years of the mid-80's are probably gone forever. Mr. Berents said the average operating profit margins for newspapers peaked at 24.1 percent in 1986 and 1987. According to his 1991 surveys, newspapers expect profit margins of about 16.6 percent in 1991.
Those responding to surveys this year said they now considered a "normal" profit margin to be 20 percent, well below the previous peak levels.
"I don't expect business to be as vibrant in the 90's as in the 80's," said W. Dean Singleton, chief executive of Media News Group. "But I don't expect it to be elementally bad either."

HEADLINE: Baker, Now in Israel, Finds Hope That Peace Is Possible

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 21

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived tonight in Israel, a land of skeptics, many of whom would like to be convinced that this round of American shuttle diplomacy holds greater promise than earlier efforts.
The apparent concessions Mr. Baker is bringing from Syria and Saudi Arabia have raised people's hopes, despite the reception given them by the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. But these hopes find only wary expression because Syria and Saudi Arabia, along with Iraq, are regarded by most Israelis, regardless of political affiliation, as implacable enemies. 
 People of varied political views, questioned in random conversations, tempered their hopes with caution.
"It still needs to be seen," said Hanoch Bartov, a well-known novelist and biographer, appraising Syria's apparent readiness to enter into direct talks with Israel. "But what they said is a change."
 
Details Wanted From Baker
 Mr. Bartov, whose views represent the opposition Labor Party's mainstream, spoke emphatically, as did such officials as Yossi Olmert, director of the Government Press Office, on the need for Mr. Baker to fully disclose the substance of his agreement with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.
"We don't know what the deal is, and we have the right to find out," said Mr. Bartov, who is president of the Israeli Center of PEN, the international writers' group.
Peter Milic, a Tel Aviv businessman, was readier than most Israelis questioned over the last three days to accept the results so far of the Baker mission as an opportunity for Israel. "There is a big difference," he said. "It's the first time that Syria has said something positive, and the first time that Saudi Arabia has spoken like that."
Saudi Arabia told Mr. Baker that it was ready to suspend its economic boycott of Israel if the Israelis suspended the building of settlements in the occupied Arab territories.
Mr. Milic cited as particularly positive the fact that Saudi Arabia had not demanded the dismantling of existing settlements. "That sounds reasonable," he said.
 
Shamir's Strength Doubted
 But he also expressed fear that political pressure on Mr. Shamir from the settlers would prevent him from responding positively to the American initiative.
Mr. Milic cited a statement today by Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, proclaiming the right of Israelis to settle on the West Bank for "hundreds of years" to come. Mr. Sharon rejected any link between "the Jewish people's right to its homeland" and the Arab boycott.
"And Labor hasn't come up with its own program," Mr. Milic continued. "They should be helping Shamir on this."
Much as Israelis in general welcomed the reported Saudi concession, they objected to the linkage between ending the boycott and the Jewish settlements.
"I must say that for the first time I'm in line with Shamir," Mr. Bartov said. "This quid pro quo should never have happened. There is no symmetry possible there. This is unbearable."
 
Linkage Resented
 The writer emphasized that he opposed the continuation of the settlement policy, but compared the linkage to what he called the "immorality" of the 1975 United Nations General Assembly resolution denouncing Zionism as a form of racism.
"For the mediator to bring this here as an achievement turns the United States position upside down," Mr. Bartov said. "After all, the United States has always opposed the Arab boycott, which began even before the creation of this state."
"There is simply no comparison," said Aharon Amir, a poet and translator who is an advocate of the concept of a "Greater Israel." "We should pay no price for the end of the boycott."
But Mr. Amir expressed optimism on the American mediation. "There is hardly any doubt that things will get moving in this area," he said. "But we should not be overwhelmed; we should be prudent."
He voiced a suspicion that Israelis across the board seem to share in varying degrees. "It should be suspected that there has been a sort of deal behind Israel's back," he said.
Many Israelis doubt that the Syrian President would have offered to attend a regional conference with Israel without receiving some American assurance that has not been disclosed.
Most of those interviewed thought Mr. Assad had been told that the United States would press Israel to return the Golan Heights, captured in 1967 and, unlike the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, incorporated into Israel by the earlier Likud Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin.
"No Israeli in his right mind would hand it all back to Assad just because he begins to smile," Mr. Bartov said. But he said that a compromise on the territory was possible. He suggested a formula under which, for "a long interim period," Israel would remain in control on the ground while recognizing eventual restoration of Syrian sovereignty over the area.
Even Mr. Olmert, interviewed in his office, said "the Golan is negotiable."
"Syria is wrong if they calculated on an Israeli 'no,' " the press office chief said. "We do not rule out the possibility that a positive change has occurred."
Many Israelis coupled their caution toward dealing with Syria with an appreciation of Mr. Assad's political skill, as evidenced in the timing of his accord with the United States and the consistency of his Government's policies toward Israel.
"They have fulfilled whatever they said," Mr. Milic said.
"He is the wiliest, cleverest and most dastardly guy in this area," Mr. Amir added.

HEADLINE: Arab Trade Ban Hurts Others Besides Israelis

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
An offer by several Arab countries to end more than four decades of economic warfare against Israel would end a struggle that has wounded but not crippled the Israeli economy, many American companies and the Arab world itself.
Saudi Arabia and Jordan have offered to suspend their boycotts on trade with Israel and companies doing business there in exchange for a suspension of Israel's construction of settlements in the occupied territories. The offer was made after Egypt, which signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979 and does not observe the ban, suggested such an arrangement. 
 Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has rejected any link between the building of settlements and the boycott.
The costs of the boycott over the years have been hard to measure. The losses to the world economy lie mostly in trade deals that were never struck, investments never made and technology never transferred. The political cloud over business in the region has discouraged the efficient and enriching specialization of economies that trade and foreign investment provide.
 
Arab League Acted in 1954

Arab countries cut most economic links with Israel when it gained independence in 1948. In 1954, the Arab League, which now has 21 members, passed a resolution that called on members not to trade with Israel.
The Arab League later set up a special office in Damascus to administer the boycott, and in 1972 this office drew up a set of regulations for all league members to apply in international trade and finance. The rules banned economic contacts not only with Israel but also with companies and banks doing business there.
The boycott has been a political issue in the United States, with Congress passing laws barring American companies from helping the boycott, even when this might involve losing contracts, exports and jobs.
"Our companies have, most of them, with certain exceptions, tried to walk this tightrope between violating these boycott laws and yet playing in the big Arab market," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who introduced legislation three months ago to tighten Federal scrutiny of companies that may reject doing business with Israel.
If the boycott is lifted, the most likely immediate effect would be more foreign investment in Israel, economists and trade lawyers said today. There might also be some increase in trade for Israel and the Arab world, they said, both with each other and with small and medium-sized American companies now leery of doing business in the region for legal reasons.
"The heaviest effect of the boycott on Israel has been on investment, and not on goods," said Howard F. Rosen, a research associate at the Institute for International Economics, a Washington center for scholars. While many companies now sell goods in both Israel and Arab countries, they have been wary of investments in factories and other assets that are hard to hide.
And some exports that might have made economic sense were forestalled. "There is a chilling effect," said Cherif Sedky, a partner at Kirkpatrick & Lockhart in Washington and the general counsel of the National U.S. Arab Chamber of Commerce. "Smaller companies may feel, 'Uh oh, this is a trouble area; let's stay out of it.' "
Publication of the Arab League rules in 1977 drew particularly loud protests in the United States, where they were perceived as a extraterritorial threat to the civil rights of American Jews. Despite protests from corporations with large operations in the Arab world, particularly international construction companies, Congress passed legislation in 1979 that barred compliance with the boycott and set strict penalties for violations.
 
U.S. Opposition Strict
 The United States has been much more strict than other countries in carrying out the anti-boycott laws since then, and some business groups have objected that this represents a sanction that hurts American businesses more than Arab countries.
The enforcement of the Arab boycott has varied across countries and across industries. Saudi Arabia, for instance, conducts strict inspections of imports at its borders, and has been known to turn back products because they contain even a few small Israeli-made components, Mr. Sedky said.
But Arab countries have shown considerable willingness to ignore the boycott to obtain American goods, particularly weapons.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
If Those Are Whirling Dervishes, Then This Stop Must Be Istanbul

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 21

 BODY:
It was fitting, of course, that George Bush, described by some as America's most famous whirling dervish, should get a chance to see the real thing.
Playing anything-but-accidental tourists today, President Bush and his wife, Barbara, went to Topkapi Sarayi, the great palace of the Ottoman Sultans, their harems and their judicial councils, and watched five dervishes whirl. 
 "A whirling dervish?" Mr. Bush delightedly asked his host, President Turgut Ozal of Turkey. "Wonderful."
Dervishes are Sufis, members of a Muslim fraternity of mystics who dance in their flowing white costumes in a trance-like state, spinning on the right foot to the accompaniment of musical instruments.
The local band was fine on the Turkish music, but their repertoire of American tunes to play as the Bushes arrived was sparse. There was no "Hail to the Chief" or "Star Spangled Banner" here: At the welcoming ceremony, the band struck up "I'm a Yankee Doodle Dandy" and "The Mexican Hat Dance."
 
 Wish List Fulfilled

The Bushes and President Ozal and his wife, Semra, whirled about Istanbul today, visiting the magnificent Blue Mosque, which featured police snipers in the minarets; taking a boat ride on the Bosphorus, and checking out the weeping column and wishing hole at Hagia Sophia, which was the cathedral of Constantinople for a thousand years of the Byzantine Empire.
"Turgut, want to make a wish?" Mr. Bush asked Mr. Ozal, as he poked his finger into a well-worn hole where tourists make wishes at Hagia Sophia.
Mr. Ozal did not. Indeed, Mr. Bush may already have granted all his wishes, by being effusively praising "my friend, Turgut," by promising lots of F-16's and $625 million in military aid next year, and by omitting any reference to Turkey's human-rights record, although Amnesty International and other groups had asked him to raise the issue.
 
 Footwear of Many Colors

Mrs. Bush won the day's award for oddest fashion statement. When she bounded up the plank of the Sarayburnu, a converted steamship that was to carry the party up the Bosphorus toward the Black Sea, the First Lady was wearing one red and one blue sneaker with her white-and-black polka dot dress.
Asked for an explanation of the First Footwear, Anna Perez, Mrs. Bush's press secretary, said that the President had given the First Lady 20 pairs of Keds for her birthday June 8 "and this way she gets to wear them all."
 
 The Diplomatic Marathon

At the news conference in Ankara on Saturday, the President was asked how he and his staff were holding up under his dizzying tour of four countries.
Mr. Bush made a rare concession, saying he felt a bit tired, and added that he was still taking medication and getting his thyroid checked every day by the doctors traveling with him.
But the 67-year-old President insisted that he would not slow down because "I'm very blessed with, you know, the ability to keep charging."
Mr. Bush also said proudly that he had converted his old friend and former campaign manager, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, to the Bush style of traveling.
Mr. Baker is on a tour of the Middle East for peace talks, after the economic summit meeting in London last weekend and before a scheduled meeting with Southeast Asian leaders in Malaysia on Monday. Both Mr. Baker and Mr. Bush will also go to Moscow in a week.
Sounding like a successful fitness trainer, a prosyletizing Jack LaLanne, the President said: "Jim Baker used to get tired when he drove across town in Washington, D.C. -- literally. He'd call me up and tell me how tired he was, campaigning and all of that. Now he's going all around the world all the time, dedicated to trying to help solve this problem."
 
 Who Looks at the Polls?
 Mr. Bush made two firsts on this trip. He admitted that he sometimes gets tired. And he admitted that he pays attention to polls -- something he had always denied.
Reporters asked President Ozal about a recent poll in Turkey that showed that most Turks feel that the United States, through the coalition against Iraq, has been interfering in Turkey's internal affairs.
Mr. Ozal said he didn't see it. But when Mr. Bush was asked if he reads polls, he finally 'fessed up.
"My wings would drop off if I told an untruth," he said. "So put it this way: from time to time, I look at them."
 
 Burnishing the Image

It's nice to know that even the highest officials of the land engage in a little resume enhancement now and again.
Consider the biography for the White House Chief of Staff, John H. Sununu, printed in the official United States Information Service media guide for the President's visit to Greece.
"Part of the job of the Chief of Staff is to mediate the many competing requests of Cabinet members and others seeking the President's time and attention. At the same time, he must insure that the President's policy is presented effectively to Congress and the public. Mr. Sununu's experience in an elective office ensures his effectiveness in both venues.
"He is considered an able, meticulous and experienced administrator whose political toughness helps shape the Bush Administration's approach to bureaucracy."
Mr. Baker's biography is equally flattering.
It says of Mr. Baker, who says he is more interested in returning to his ranch than running for President: "Many in the political arena see James Baker as having a very bright future in politics and feel, as a political insider has put it, 'that he will be a major force on the political scene for the next 10 or 15 years.' "
By the time the Presidential party got to Turkey, the biographies had been yanked from the official media guide.

HEADLINE: West Virginia Roads: A Bumpy Legacy Lives On

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTS, W.Va.

 BODY:
As the four-wheel-drive lurches across the mountain, splashes through the creek and bounces down a graveled lane, miles from the cushioned comforts of blacktop, a thought occurs: John Denver may have immortalized West Virginia's country roads, but he didn't have to drive on them.
In West Virginia, the struggle to build and maintain roads is a Sisyphean quest that is woven into the state's politics, with significant social and economic consequences. 
 Bad roads can keep children from school, workers from work and the sick from people who can heal them. They bring endless promises from West Virginia's politicians and occasional rulings by the state Supreme Court.
 
A Harder Road to Build
 No other state combines the mountainous terrain, dispersed population and poverty that makes roads so hard to build in West Virginia. Roads are more expensive here than they are in just about any other state, and few states have less money to build them. West Virginia may be the only state where a roadless town has petitioned the Soviet Union for foreign aid.
"West Virginians are constantly preoccupied with their roads," said Ken Sullivan, a historian who edits the state magazine, Goldenseal.
But if bad roads have been part of the state's sorrow, they are also part of its glory. By preserving some of the region's isolation, they help maintain the distinct culture that keeps so many residents from ever wanting to leave.
For the families in Sand Creek Hollow, a few mountainous miles from Harts, the road to school has brought the kind of epic misadventure rarely found outside Road Runner cartoons. Every morning, until a recent court decision, the hollow's 11 children -- Patience, Frank, Amy, Marie, Larry, Jason, April, T. C., Jasper, Eddie and Shawn -- would crowd into Louise Collins's dilapidated red pickup truck.
Down the hollow they would bounce on a dirt road that sometimes crossed the creek and other times was the creek. Assuming no ice or floods, they would emerge at the hollow's mouth, turn left and hug the railroad track for three miles, spitting gravel.
From there, all they had to do was climb out of the truck, crawl under the occasional parked coal train and scoot across a swinging bridge without sides that dangles 60 feet above the Guyandotte River. In good weather, that is.
In bad weather, the truck would bog down and the children would push.
"We'd be late just about every morning," said Patience Collins, now 15 years old, who is Louise Collins's daughter. "Everybody'd be in class looking at you. That's embarrassing, water squishing out your shoes."
Since a 1986 ruling by the State Supreme Court, things are better, though how much so remains in dispute. Holding that the right to attend school includes a right to get there, the court told the state's Division of Highways to fix the road.
These days, the middle section of its four-mile stretch is studded with progress's own jewel: gravel. But, with a good rain, the end that crosses the mountain and opens onto blacktop still turns to gravy, making it too dangerous to travel. And the other end is still blocked by creek and railroad.
 
2 Miles in 2 Hours
 The local school board now sends in a four-wheel-drive vehicle. In good weather, the trip, about two miles as the crow flies, takes about 45 minutes. In bad, it has been known to last two hours.
Conditions there are not unique.
"We're reluctant to print letters to the editor about poor roads, because they just set off an avalanche of letters saying, 'My road's worse than yours,' " said Don Marsh, editor of The Charleston Gazette.
Political brawls over West Virginia roads are older than West Virginia itself, dating back to the time when Virginia was united. Westerners accused easterners of hogging all the development money. That, along with slavery, led to the westernmost counties' separation from Virginia in 1861.
A century later, in 1965, Congress created the Appalachian Regional Commission as a conduit for development money in a 13-state area. Since then, about two-thirds of the money has gone to road building.
 
Emphasis Is Changing
 Those roads, along with the federally financed Interstates, have reduced the region's isolation, providing four-lanes between most major West Virginia cities. And efforts by the commission and others have helped bring health clinics and social services to underserved areas.
But getting out of the hollow can still be a feat.
"We're just now getting around to taking the emphasis off the Interstate and switching it onto those local roads," said Randy Epperly, of the Division of Highways.
In most mountain states west of the Rockies, the population congregates in towns and cities. In West Virginia, by contrast, the population is spread out in the hollows carved by the state's countless streams. This means it takes more roads to reach the people.
 
Higher Road Costs
 And West Virginia is the only state that lies completely within Appalachia. States like North Carolina, Kentucky and Virginia have lowland areas with prosperous cities that can help subsidize road building in the mountains.
In steep, creek-crossed West Virginia road building almost always entails earth-moving and bridge construction, and the high cost s bleeds away money from other services.
"It lowers the overall quality of social services that West Virginians can draw on," said John Alexander Williams, a leading historian of the state.
How much does it cost to build a West Virginia road?
Consider "common excavation," otherwise known as moving dirt. The Federal Department of Transportation's 1990 statistics show the national average at $2.38 a cubic yard. It West Virginia, it cost $7.87.
Of the 33,000 miles of state roads here, only 61 percent are paved. And 13 percent are categorized as "unimproved" or "primitive." In other words, "It'd have grass growing in the middle," said Paul Wilkinson, the head of planning for the highway division.
How much yearning can a West Virginia road produce?
In 1977, the self-proclaimed mayor of a hamlet called Vulcan was so frustrated by a fallen bridge that he wrote the Soviet Embassy in Washington, seeking help.
A Soviet journalist came to investigate, and a local radio station reported bomb threats toward any bridge built with communist help. Embarrassed state officials coughed up $1.3 million to build Vulcan's bridge.
West Virginia is one of the few states where virtually all the roads are maintained by the state, rather than counties and cities. This helps insure that roads remain a focus of state politics.
It is true that Mr. Denver's "Take Me Home, Country Roads" has been adopted as an unofficial state anthem. But few people here take its misty-eyed view of roads very seriously. After all, Mr. Denver's real name is Henry John Deutschendorf Jr., and he grew up in Arizona, Alabama, Ohio, Texas and Japan, not West Virginia.
 
A Song to Remember
 When West Virginians get real about roads, they turn to songs like this one, written by Billy Edd Wheeler for John D. Rockefeller 4th's 1976 campaign for governor:
 
 Well you rattle and you shake
 Speed up and then hit your brakes
 I'm jumping like a toad
 On this West Virginia road
 Bumpity-bump, bumpity-bump.
And if he made more road promises than he kept, Mr. Rockefeller, now a United States Senator, was following in a proud tradition.
Evident amusement comes into the voice of Mr. Marsh, the newspaper editor, when he tells of what happened when Mr. Rockefeller, as Governor, bought a block of television time and invited voters to call in.
"He had all these high ideas about a colloquy between the governing and the governed," Mr. Marsh said. "And all he got was curses: 'My road ain't no good; my holler ain't got no road.' "
In a state that cannot afford many basic services, Mr. Marsh said, it is unrealistic to expect a road to every hollow. Either accept rural life as it is, he said, or move.
But many students of Appalachia have long marveled over its residents' intense love of home. The hills are filled with stories of workers who once moved to booming industrial cities, like Cleveland and Detroit, but made 10-hour drives back, just for the weekend. When the Industrial Belt rusted, they came home for good.
 
It Is Their Home
 Among them was Thomas Church, Patience Collins's grandfather and the patriarch of Sand Creek Hollow. Nine of his 10 children still live there, scattered across the 369 acres his stepfather bought in 1941. Stymied in part by the difficulties of getting there, none finished high school.
Mr. Church's daughter, Louise Collins, began her pickup truck service with the determination to see her children go further. She and her family say the responsibility helped bring on a subsequent nervous breakdown.
Whatever the hardships, Mr. Church and his children have a hard time imagining a place they would rather be than in their current backyard, filled with mountains, streams and bumblebees.
As for the argument that the state cannot afford to fix the road, Mr. Church is skeptical, pointing to an imprisoned former Governor, Arch A. Moore Jr., and what Mr. Church calls another of the state's great political traditions, corruption.
"They sit over there in Charleston and let them steal all that money; they can afford to put in a road," he said.

HEADLINE: TV Dials Set to Rhode Island Bank Crisis

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 21

 BODY:
Six months after the collapse of a private bank insurance fund left 300,000 Rhode Island depositors locked out of their accounts, televised hearings have transfixed the state and focused attention on one question: Why were public officials and financial leaders able to withdraw their own money on the eve of the crisis?
The hearings, the first of several phases of public testimony in coming months, will resume Monday and continue through Thursday. The nine-member investigating panel was created by the Legislature to look into the collapse of the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation, a private company that insured the deposits of 45 credit unions and banks. 
 After the company failed on New Year's Eve, the banks and credit unions it insured were ordered closed by the new Governor, Bruce G. Sundlun. The closings directly affected one out of three Rhode Islanders, creating the state's worst banking crisis since the Depression and shaking the political establishment.
 
$1 Billion in Assets Frozen
 More than $1 billion in assets, representing the accounts of 160,00 depositors, are still frozen in the 13 credit unions and banks that remain closed. The other financial institutions were allowed to reopen after obtaining Federal deposit insurance. Accounts in Federally insured banks and credit unions throughout the state were not affected by the crisis.
Last week, Rhode Island residents watched the televised hearings with fascination as public officials and former officials of financial institutions answered questions about whether they used inside information to make last-minute withdrawals, aggravating the crisis at the expense of ordinary depositors.
While not a root cause of the crisis, the issue has given Rhode Islanders a focus for their frustration. The crisis is widely perceived to be an outgrowth of an inbred political culture that produced a tangle of conflicting interests among public officials and financial institutions.
One witness last week was State Representative Robert V. Bianchini, who until this year was the vice chairman of the House Finance Committee and also headed the trade association of state's credit unions.
Mr. Bianchini, a Democrat, has been criticized for his role in the failure of a 1986 bill that would have required all credit unions to obtain Federal insurance, putting Rhode Island Share and Desposit out of business.
Mr. Bianchini was called to explain a complex series of personal transactions in which he borrowed $85,000 from a credit union just before it closed, then later used his frozen passbook accounts to pay off the loan. Mr. Bianchini vigorously defended the moves, saying they did not represent a withdrawal and were unrelated to the condition of insurance fund.
 
Last-Minute Withdrawals
 Other witnesses have included the Mayor of North Providence, a state senator, several credit union executives, along with the fund's former president, his wife and his mother-in-law. All were asked about last-minute withdrawals. Several have invoked their Fifth Amendment right against compelled self-incrimination.
The commission is made up of legislators and community leaders, but most of the questioning has been done so far by its two special counsels: Alan I. Baron, whose investigation as special counsel to the United States House Judiciary Committee led to the impeachment of two Federal judges in 1989; and John W. Nields Jr., chief counsel for the Iran-contra inquiry in 1987 by the United States House of Representatives.
In the coming months, the commission plans public hearings into areas that cut closer to the roots of the crisis, including roles played by legislators, state banking regulators and the credit unions themselves.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Cable Networks See Dimmer Future

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 21

 BODY:
The central story in the television industry for the last decade has been the erosion of the broadcast networks' audiences. Now, a new story is emerging: the erosion of cable.
Executives from several of the biggest cable networks -- including MTV, Showtime and Turner Network Television -- said last week that they did not expect their channels to continue to build audiences; rather, they are calculating ways to try to hold on to their current audiences. 
 Indeed, several established cable networks -- like ESPN, MTV, TBS and the Family Channel -- have begun to lose viewers.
Up to now, cable networks have generally grown steadily as more and more homes added cable service. Cable currently reaches about 60 percent of American households. But future growth based on future expansion of cable service appears to be limited. Most areas of the country are now wired for cable service, so most homes that want cable are already able to add it.
Moreover, the continuing increases in the cost of cable service has created consumer resistance. The slowdown in the growth of subscribers for the pay channels, like HBO and Showtime, is widely regarded as an indication that the boom in consumer spending on cable is over.
Cable network executives said the competition for viewers and programs was likely to become increasingly intense and even cutthroat as cable systems added more channels, and that the climate would be especially hostile toward the newcomers.
"Cable is going to begin eating itself," said Scott Sassa, president of Turner Entertainment Networks. "Will it eat itself to death? No. But we're looking at our backs right now."
The metaphor of creeping threats from within what used to be known as the "cable family" runs throughout the industry. Nickelodeon's president, Geraldine Leybourne, said, "We're aware of having to watch over our shoulders."
Doug Herzog, senior vice president of MTV, said, "Clearly, we're thinking hard about our cable neighbors."
And Tony Cox, chairman of Showtime Networks, said, "The industry is quickly moving toward a classic battle between the haves and the have-nots."
One executive said established channels were moving aggressively to try to prevent newer channels from gaining a foothold. The chief method: buying up many programs that new channels want.
"We heard that someone was going to try to start up the Cowboy Channel," said the senior executive from a long-established channel, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
"Do you think we're going to sit there with our pants down?" the executive continued. "No. We buy up every cowboy movie we can. And so does everybody else. Same with the Science-Fiction Channel. There's only a finite amount of that stuff available. To an extent, we can prevent them from getting started."
 
'Opening a Pandora's Box'
 As cable systems expand to include more and more channels, audience shares are likely to decline even more steeply. Systems of up to 150 channels are now expected to be widely in place within a decade.
"It's kind of like opening a Pandora's box," Mr. Sassa said. "The networks started to get eaten up first by independent stations. Then the first wave of cable channels came along. Now there's a second wave. The viewing has to come from somewhere. Viewing is a zero-sum game. It's arrogant to believe we have this size of audience and we're always going to have it. You're going to have to fight for it."
Many cable networks are responding to the huge expansion of channel capacity by planning to offer their programming in what they call a "multiplex format." In this format, a cable subscriber gets HBO or MTV on as many as three channels, with different lineups on each.
While this may help protect a cable franchise, it has the prospect of spreading viewing levels out even more. "As hard as it was for the broadcasters to understand what cable was going to mean to their lives, I think it is hard for us to understand what a multiplex environment is going to mean for our lives," Ms. Leybourne of Nickelodeon said.
But that flood of new channels will not signal the official beginning of cable erosion.
"Cable erosion is for real already," said Lee Masters, president of "E," an all-entertainment channel of the second wave. "MTV is still making $85 million a year. But it has only been on the air 10 years and its share is already falling. How long can they keep making profits like that with declining shares? Cable has been a great business. But it's going to be a very different business in the 90's."
Among the differences cited by the executives: higher prices for programming, lower profit margins and possibly even well-established channels going out of business.
"The cable channels have really stepped up and paid out large rights fees in recent years for sports and movies," said Matthew C. Blank, president of Showtime. "Those involve ongoing payments of a lot of dollars. If you crank their business down just a hair, some of those guys could go under."
The addition of more sports events could increase viewing on some cable channels. But better attractions, like championship boxing matches, are likely to be siphoned off to pay-per-view channels. And Congressional opposition is likely to prevent cable from gaining the biggest sports events, like the World Series and the Super Bowl, because legislators object to people without cable being frozen out of such events.
What some channels fear the most is that more cable operators will react to consumer resistance to higher cable bills by separating channels into numerous "tiers," with sharply different prices.
At the moment, all the main advertiser-supported channels share space on most systems in what is known as "basic cable" -- that is, customers receive all these channels for the same monthly price. They pay extra if they want a "premium channel," like HBO or Showtime.
As Mr. Cox sees it, any move toward tiering channels jeopardizes those that are not intrinsically linked to a program theme (like ESPN and sports) or a specialized audience (like MTV and teen-agers).
"The Lifetimes and the Arts & Entertainments of the cable world have been extraordinarily lucky because they have basically hidden in the weeds," Mr. Cox said.
If these channels were ever placed in a price tier above the more popular basic channels, Mr. Cox said, they could be vulnerable.
But all the channels are vulnerable to an explosion in the cost of programming. Part of the reason for that explosion: what Mr. Masters called a "feeding frenzy" among the cable channels for programs. "You have everybody vying for old network sitcoms," he said. "That drives up the price for everybody."
In order to try to protect their franchises from looking too much like others, channels increasingly want to produce original programs. But these are even more expensive and further drive down profit margins.
 
'That Hits the Bottom Line'
 Then, Mr. Masters said, there is the need for channels on a heavily crowded dial to spend much more in marketing to try to make an impression on viewers, or to maintain the ones they have. "Again, that hits the bottom line," he said.
Clearly, that is another problem that will be far worse for newcomers. "I feel very fortunate that our company was in the first wave," Mr. Sassa of Turner Entertainment said. "In a 50- to 60- to 150-channel environment, how do you tell people you exist? How does 'E' tell people it exists?"
Most cable executives, who have depended on change to provide an opportunity to take viewers from the broadcast networks, realize with some chagrin that change now has the potential to undermine them.
But, Mr. Sassa said: "We have to accept that television is an evolving medium. We've seen it change in our lifetimes from sociology, from technology. It's up to us as programmers to continue to find our own edge."

HEADLINE: A Sea of Doubt Swells Around Bush's Education Plan

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, July 19

 BODY:
Three months after President Bush staked his claim to be the "education President" by unveiling an ambitious plan to transform American schools, his strategy is coming under increasing fire.
Within the last two weeks, the presidents of the country's two major teachers' unions have sharply attacked his plan after earlier praising it. A committee of business leaders assembled to raise money to build innovative model schools is reportedly facing tough going in the recession. 
 And both here at a major education conference and elsewhere around the country, many educators are beginning to question whether the President's strategy will actually produce widespread, fundamental changes. Past reforms, they note, have not had trouble creating model programs to serve as points of light. The open question is whether most of the country's 110,000 schools will be ablaze, or whether only a few candles will flicker in the dark.
Many temper their criticism with praise for the President's commitment to keep education in the spotlight. Congress is moving quickly toward action on some of his proposals. And President Bush's highly regarded new education team is fanning out across the country to sell his plan to the important constituency outside Washington and education circles.
 
Arousing the Populace
 The "America 2000" strategy that the President announced April 18 relies primarily on such populist outsider forces to turn around America's ailing schools. He asked each community to realize that the problem lies with its own schools and its own children. To set high standards and measure progress, he proposed a system of national tests to show for the first time how students and schools ranked across the country.
He charged business leaders to raise about $150 million to help create "new American schools" to serve as models of excellence. To prod reluctant schools to change, he proposed vouchers, allowing Federal money to follow children to whatever school they choose, whether public, parochial or private.
Although most educators and union leaders heaped praise on the initial announcement, the tone has turned decidedly combative in recent weeks. Several educators here in Denver made acid comments about the plan at the annual meeting of the Education Commission of the States, a policy body primarily serving governors and state legislators. Both Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, and Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, blasted the plan in recent speeches.
The President's endorsement of open school selection and private school vouchers is political dynamite, stirring both ardent supporters and detractors. It was their belief that the choice option was the heart of the President's agenda, the union leaders said, that changed their minds about his plan.
 
Picking a Fight
 "If they want to pick a fight, they've picked one," Mr. Shanker said of the choice issue. "This is a terrible tactical error. If they don't find a way to get off this, it will destroy the program."
While the choice proposal has drawn the most strident comments, education and business leaders are also expressing reservations about other parts of the plan. The most fundamental problem, they say, is that the President has not shown how his plan will lead to broad-based, systemic change.
Here in Denver and in a collection of articles by 30 prominent education experts just published by the William T. Grant Foundation and the Washington-based Institute for Educational Leadership, educators outlined what they saw as glaring omissions. The plan offers no new money or strategy to combat poverty, they said, despite its widely recognized link to school failure. It does not directly reach out to the very people who will implement change, teachers and principals, and few details have emerged on several crucial points, like national testing.
Lamar Alexander, the new Secretary of Education, is unperturbed by the storm. "It doesn't bother me one bit -- the debate is engaged," he said.
It is far too early to tell whether the growing furor will scuttle the plan or just widen the debate. The President's supporters remain confident, but they are wary about union opposition.
"There was a kind of honeymoon period that's clearly over, but I don't think the marriage is on the rocks," said Chester E. Finn Jr., a leading architect of the plan. "The education community, on the whole, is behaving about the way I expected it to: 'Things are O.K. the way they are; send money.' But if this educator resistance extends in a big way to blocking state and local change, then it's much more damaging if it cannot be overcome."
Unions do wield considerable power, particularly at the state and local levels, which pay more than 90 percent of educational costs and where reforms are won or lost, Mr. Finn said.
But Mr. Alexander is still able to draw on a considerable reservoir of good will, and many educators continue to praise Mr. Bush, who they say is the first President to make education a truly national issue. Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, says his colleagues are eager to work with Mr. Alexander and to address issues of concern. Congress, too, is moving quickly on the President's proposal. A bill based on the plan is likely to move to the Senate floor soon after the summer recess, with many of the President's ideas intact except for the provisions on private school vouchers, a Senate Democratic aide said.
 
Alexander as Crusader
 The real test of the strategy, Mr. Alexander and Mr. Finn said, will be how it sells outside Washington. "On the surface, it may look reasonably quiet this summer, but I've only been here four months," Mr. Alexander said. "What we will be spending our time doing is trying to create this framework for a crusade, for a populist movement."
So far, Mr. Alexander and his deputy, David T. Kearns, the former chairman of Xerox, have traveled to a few states that have pledged to become "America 2000" communities by encouraging all citizens to work for better education. It is unclear whether this is a stirring public-relations exercise or the preface to real change, but Mr. Alexander, a canny politician and coalition builder, reports good ratings from the hustings.
Back in Washington, however, he faces a more skeptical audience. Letting Federal money follow each child to the school of choice remains the sticking point, not only among union leaders but also among some business groups. Both the Business Roundtable and the National Alliance of Business expressed tepid support at best of the idea in recent position statements.
"There are those who believe that choice is the only thing we need to do, an ideological panacea," said William A. Kolberg, president of the National Alliance of Business. "We do not believe that. Our attitude at this stage is that choice needs to have a lot more experimentation done."
 
Avoiding Testing's Pitfalls
 While the proposal for national testing is the sketchiest at this point, it is already stirring as many passions as the proposal on choice. A National Council on Standards and Testing has begun to debate concerns raised by many critics -- how to draw up what will be in effect a national curriculum for the first time in America's history, how to make sure tests are used to enforce high standards without dooming the futures of those who fail them, and how to avoid charges that tests are biased against minority students.
Mr. Bush's proposal for "new American schools," and his decision to ask business leaders to raise money for their design, is also drawing criticism. Several educators here mentioned similar projects in the 1960's that created isolated model schools but did not change most schools.
Many educators wondered why it was necessary to pay for design teams when many other models for creating schools that excel are already up and running -- for example, James Comer's work in New Haven or Theodore R. Sizer's Coalition of Essential Schools. Many members of Congress, a Senate Democratic aide said, worry that the design teams will overlook the needs of inner-city schools.
Several educators in Denver who attended the National Alliance of Business's recent meeting reported concern among business leaders about raising $150 million in a recession. Moreover, some fear that businesses will simply switch financing from ongoing projects.
 
The Big Enemy: Poverty
 "It's not going to be a new pool of money," said Michael D. Usdan, president of the Institute for Educational Leadership. "Is it going to dry up other local and state initiatives?"
Mr. Alexander dismisses such concerns, saying the fund-raising group has already raised $30 million. The schools will work, he says, because they will engage whole communities for the first time in thinking about how children should be educated.
In the end, many educators believe, the strategy's ambitious agenda will fail unless it includes steps to fight poverty. At the very least, several educators said, President Bush could have moved more quickly to make preschool programs like Headstart available to every eligible child.

HEADLINE: JORDANIANS AGREE TO JOIN IN TALKS ON MIDEAST PEACE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 21

 BODY:
Jordan joined Syria, Lebanon, Egypt and Saudi Arabia today in agreeing to attend a regional peace conference proposed by the United States. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, however, told the visiting American Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, that he wanted more time to consider the matter.
King Hussein said, "We are ready to attend a peace conference, and we are very happy indeed it is going to be a comprehensive one." The Jordanian ruler spoke at a news conference with Mr. Baker after their talks in Amman, Jordan's capital.
Until now, Jordan has wavered on accepting the American proposal, waiting to see if Syria would.
 
5 Acceptances in His Pocket
 Mr. Baker, armed with commitments from the five Arab countries to take part in a conference that would open the way for direct negotiations with Israel, flew here from Amman to try to persuade Mr. Shamir to drop his opposition to the proposed peace talks.
The Israeli Government, though, seemed shocked -- confronted by Mr. Baker after he obtained, over three days, commitments from the Arabs to take part in the conference and in subsequent direct talks.
Jordan also joined Saudi Arabia and Egypt in offering to suspend the Arab economic boycott of Israel if it will suspend the building of settlements in the occupied lands. And President Bush, on a visit to Turkey, again suggested that Israel halt settlement building on the West Bank.
The Israeli public appears skeptical about the latest round of American diplomacy, tempering hope with caution. [Page A6.]
 
Deadline or No Deadline
 Mr. Baker denied that he had set a deadline for an Israeli response on peace talks, but American officials say it is possible that when President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Moscow on July 30 and 31, they will issue invitations to the conference -- as its joint sponsors -- whether the Israelis have responded positively or not. Such a move would put Israel under even greater pressure to attend.
"We have always indicated that that would be something we might pursue," said Mr. Baker, when asked whether invitations would soon be sent. "Of course, it would be much better, if there is going to be a conference, if everybody could sign on before invitations are issued."
Senior Israeli officials said they had no idea what Mr. Shamir was going to do, and the Israeli Prime Minister was saying nothing.
Mr. Shamir's dilemma, though, is clear. If he says yes to Mr. Baker, his fragile coalition Government is likely to collapse and he will be challenged by members of his own rightist Likud bloc. If he says no, he risks alienating Israel from the United States, and from much of the rest of the world.
Mr. Baker met with Mr. Shamir alone for 90 minutes. The meeting was taken up almost entirely with a review of the essence of the letter that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria sent to Mr. Bush a week ago. In that letter, the Syrian leader is said to have committed his Government to take part in the peace conference and subsequent direct talks.
The Israelis have been deeply suspicious that Washington and Damascus struck some sort of deal. American officials said that Mr. Baker, without actually showing Mr. Shamir the Assad letter, had briefed him both on its contents and on the side assurances that the United States had provided the Syrians.
 
What U.S. Would Do for Syria
 Those side assurances mostly involve restatements of American policy: that the United States does not recognize the Israeli annexation of the Golan Heights; that it believes that United Nations Security Council Resolution 242, calling on Israel to exchange land for peace, applies to the Golan Heights as well as to the West Bank, and that the United States is committed to pushing any peace negotiations actively, so as not to allow delays.
Mr. Shamir asked Mr. Baker for more time to consider the matter, and the two men will be meeting again on Monday. "We are not under any pressure to give an answer soon," the Prime Minister's spokesman, Avi Pazner, said. "The problem is content, not deadlines."
Before Mr. Baker met with Mr. Shamir, he held talks with three West Bank Palestinian leaders, led by Faisal al-Husseini, and made it clear to them that they, too, had to make some hard decisions. American officials said it was a tough, and at times emotional, encounter in which the Palestinians were essentially told that as the weakest party in the equation, they would have to accept previously unpalatable political realities.
One of those is that the Palestine Liberation Organization, led by Yasir Arafat, can have no direct involvement with their delegation to the peace conference, since that would prompt the Israelis to walk out immediately.
The other is that no Palestinians from East Jerusalem can take part in the first stage of the negotiations. The Israelis have ruled this out, arguing that such a role would imply that East Jerusalem, which Israel has annexed, was negotiable.
But it is possible that the second restriction might be finessed if there is a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation and Palestinians born in Jerusalem take part with Jordanian passports.
Despite those restrictions, the Palestinian leaders were told that they would soon have to come up with a list of acceptable representatives, American officials said.
An intriguing thing about the endorsements that Mr. Baker has won from the Arab countries is that the Arab leaders all say in public that they are ready to accept Mr. Bush's proposal to attend "a peace conference" to reach a "comprehensive solution" based on Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. But none of them ever mentions that this conference is intended as a ceremonial opening event for direct Arab-Israeli talks.
American officials insist that the Arab leaders have privately assured them that they understand this, but do not now want to say it publicly for fear of alienating their own hard-liners. Each one, instead, allows Mr. Baker to say it for him.
Thus, when reporters asked King Hussein today if he would say in public that he was committed to direct talks with Israel, he was not pleased.
Looking a bit flummoxed, the King replied, "This is about the most ridiculous question I have ever heard."
If it is so simple, the reporters persisted, why not give just a simple answer?
"What do you attend a conference to do?" the King retorted. "To mime? To make faces at each other, or to discuss and try to resolve the problem? I have been calling for this for years and years. I assure you that this is really the intention, and it is very, very clear."
As the journalists continued to press the King to say the words "direct bilateral talks with Israel," he declared the news conference over and walked out with Mr. Baker.

BUSH REITERATES VIEW
 ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 21 (Special to The New York Times) -- President Bush, on a visit to Turkey, suggested once again today that Israel should be flexible for the sake of peace in the Middle East and halt settlement building on the West Bank.
"The question of settlements has been important," Mr. Bush said, in response to a reporter's question at a meeting here today with Turkish opposition leaders. "I haven't encountered anybody in this part of the world that thinks increasing settlements is a helpful thing. And the United States policy has been opposed to it for years."
The President also said he did not want to use a "volatile" word like pressure in talking about his stance with the Israelis. He preferred to call it "reasoning and taking this -- what I keep calling a new credibility for the United States in the Middle East -- and using that to encourage what is a very reasonable and important step to peace."
