HEADLINE: American and T.W.A. Plan a Competing Bid for Pan Am

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Trans World Airlines and American Airlines plan to make an offer today for much of Pan American World Airways, challenging Pan Am's agreement to sell most of its assets to Delta.
People involved in planning the offer said yesterday that T.W.A. and American wanted to divide up much of the bankrupt carrier. 
 Under the expected offer, the two airlines would pay Pan Am $310 million, with American would putting up $250 million and receiving the East Coast shuttle and Pan Am's routes between the United States and Italy, Spain and Portugal. T.W.A would pay $60 million for Pan Am's large Frankfurt operation and routes between London and Miami and Detroit.
Earlier this month, Pan Am accepted an offer from Delta Air Lines, agreeing to sell its African, Asian and European routes, the Boston-New York-Washington shuttle and 45 planes for $260 million.
Because Pan Am is in bankruptcy, that deal is subject to the approval of the Federal bankruptcy court. If competing offers or a bidding war emerge, the court has the power to choose among the various proposals.
"We are really beginning to see some competitive bidding, which will help establish the realistic levels at which these properties should be sold," said Paul Turk of Avmark Inc., an airline consulting company in Arlington, Va., that is advising Pan Am's unsecured creditors about the value of the company's assets. "I don't know what those levels are, but we haven't seen them yet."
 
A Blow to Delta's Ambitions

Delta sought its deal to gain a leg up in its competition with American and United Airlines, the nation's two largest carriers. In making this offer with T.W.A., American is clearly trying to deal a knockout blow to Delta's ambitions.
T.W.A. also plans to invest an additional $140 million in Pan Am's remaining operations, which are largely in Latin America.
But T.W.A. has had substantial financial problems of its own, and its chairman, Carl C. Icahn, has said the airline might be forced to file for bankruptcy protection. T.W.A.'s debt is estimated to be $1.37 billion, and it has defaulted on about $200 million in principal and interest and withheld payment on equipment leases.
Asked about the expected offer, John Hotard, a spokesman for American Airlines, said last night, "Our corporate policy is not to comment on any possible mergers or acquisitions."
At Delta, Neil A. Monroe, the director of public relations, said he could not say whether Delta would increase its offer for Pan Am's routes. But he said the T.W.A.-American offer did not come as a surprise.
"We have an excellent package in place that we feel is very fair," he said.
Pan Am has repeatedly said that a primary objective in coming out of bankruptcy is protecting its employees. The people involved in planning the T.W.A.-American offer, who insisted on anonymity, said their proposal would save the jobs of about 10,000 Pan Am employees, 4,000 more than the Delta bid. Mr. Monroe of Delta questioned whether that expectation was reasonable.
On Friday Northwest Airline bid for one route included in the Delta package, and Pan Am responded that it considered the route sold to Delta.
 
A Return to London
 John V. Pincavage, a partner in the the Transportation Group Ltd., a New York-based investment company, observed, "The offer gives American the things they want, it gives T.W.A. the things they want, and it lets Pan Am exist and get reorganized and save a lot of jobs."
T.W.A. and American have forged a number of links in recent months. American recently bought T.W.A.'s lucrative routes between London and the United States, and the two airlines agreed to mesh their frequent-flier programs.
The proposed deal with Pan Am would put T.W.A. back into business in London, and Pan Am would feed passengers into the London routes that would be acquired by T.W.A.
T.W.A. would also take over Pan Am's hub in Frankfurt, which would allow it to regain a strong European and international presence. In addition, T.W.A. would take over Pan Am's Eastern European routes, which are likely to gain value with the region's switch to free markets, as well as additional landing slots at La Guardia Airport and Kennedy International Airport in New York, and at Washington National Airport. It would also get some Pan Am aircraft, engines and ground equipment.
Mr. Pincavage said heavy government regulation has prevented American from opening routes to Italy, which it has wanted to do for some time. "The only way to get into the market is to buy your way in on somebody else's routes," he said.
 
A Focus on Miami

If American and T.W.A. could acquire the Pan Am assets they seek, Pan Am would be left with its routes to Central and South America out of its Miami hub, its only profitable operations.
T.W.A., and possibly some outside investors who were not identified, are expected to invest $140 million in equity to reorganize Pan Am and would also provide a line of credit to finance Pan Am's operations. Equity in the reorganized company would be owned by Pan Am's creditors, T.W.A. and any outside investors.
Pan Am and T.W.A. would coordinate their business operations, a strategy that has been sought by both carriers in the past.
Delta has made a similar offer to invest in Pan Am that would enable Pan Am to continue its Latin American operations, and a Delta spokesman said that offer was contingent on the completion of the purchase agreement.
In an offer that analysts estimated at $200 million to $300 million, United sought to buy the Latin American routes, which had operating revenues of $736 million in 1990, a 14 percent increase from 1989. But it was rebuffed by Pan Am's creditors, who said the offer was too low.
Delta Air Lines, based in Atlanta, is the nation's third-largest carrier, behind American and United. Through its deal with Pan Am, it hopes to join the handful of carriers with vast international route networks that are expected to dominate the industry in the next decade.
 
Behind the Shuttle Deal

Its acquisition of the shuttle, which Pan Am acquired from New York Air in 1986 for $76 million, would make Delta a much greater threat to the smaller carriers that now operate in the Northeast market. These include Northwest Airlines, which is in the process of buying the competing Trump Shuttle, and Continental Airlines.
Delta said it would offer jobs to about 6,000 of Pan Am's 22,000 workers, most of whom are expected to be workers overseas, at the other end of the international routes.
Analysts had called the $260 million price a great bargain for Delta and had speculated that other bidders might emerge. Northwest's bid on Friday was $20 million for Pan Am's Detroit-London route, or $35 million for that route and another between Los Angeles and Mexico City.
Mr. Turk, representing the Pan Am creditors, and other industry watchers said T.W.A. and American might be making a nuisance bid to drive up the cost of acquiring Pan Am. While American has wanted routes in Italy for some time, it also has an interest in preventing Delta from gaining strength.
"While they aren't worried about T.W.A. and Pan Am, they don't want United or Delta to get these assets without paying a high price for them," Mr. Turk said.
Analysts said that in agreeing to the deal with Delta, Thomas G. Plaskett, the chairman of the Pan Am Corporation, was trying to carry out an orderly liquidation of the airline to avoid a hasty fire sale after the carrier ran out of cash later this year.
 
Hurt by Deregulation

Unable to compete after the industry was deregulated in 1978, Pan Am was forced to sell assets including its headquarters building above Park Avenue in midtown Manhattan, its Pacific routes and its London routes to raise case to keep flying.
Pan Am's bankruptcy is being overseen in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York by Judge Cornelius Blackshear.
Any deal also requires the approval of Pan Am's creditors and the boards of the purchasing airlines. And it would be subject to approval by the Transportation Department and various European governments.
The Europeans are expected to be tough in the negotiations since they will demand new rights for their carriers serving the United States in return for allowing powerful carriers like Delta or American into their countries.
Founded in 1927, Pan Am grew and thrived when the industry was highly regulated; it dominated the market for international travel and seemed to some people to be the quasi-official United States carrier. It inaugurated service across the Pacific, ordered the first Boeing 747 and was widely known for its Clipper service. But it faltered under the pressures of deregulation. And in the last year it has been devastated by the decline in international traffic caused by the Persian Gulf war and the recession. Its operating costs soared as fuel prices doubled.

HEADLINE: C'mon Connecticut, Try It

 BODY:
Three weeks into the new fiscal year, Connecticut still has no budget. The General Assembly can't muster the courage to enact one with an income tax, or the votes to override Gov. Lowell Weicker's veto of the alternative, which would maintain the state's high sales tax.
Enough already. It's time to experiment. 
 An experiment is just what the Governor proposed last week. On television in prime time -- pre-empting "Jeopardy" and other taxpayer favorites -- he said he would accept an income tax that expired automatically at the end of 1993. It would be a test to see if the new tax flies. To make the tax permanent, the Assembly would have to vote again, and approval would require a 60 percent majority.
The offer was brave, smart and fair. It would give people a chance to feel the effect of a modest tax on their wages, salaries and other income, offset by sharp cuts in the 8 percent sales tax as well as in the current taxes on dividends, interest and capital gains. If they didn't like it, little would have been lost. The unwanted tax on wages and salaries would self-destruct on Jan. 1, 1994, and people could go back to paying the extra 8 percent on nearly everything they buy -- the highest of any state sales tax -- and the even higher taxes on unearned income.
So why not give it a try?
Granted, while the Weicker plan reduces the burden on lower-income taxpayers, it would tax upper-income families more heavily. Granted also, the very thought of becoming an income-tax state, after years as a no-income-tax haven, is unnerving.
The politicians blocking the change are saying, in effect, it's better to run the state badly. Reliance on a sales tax is careless and cruel; it yields erratic revenue, depending on economic conditions, and at all times it penalizes the poor, socking them for the same 8 percent as the rich.
The obstructing politicians are most of the Republicans in both houses, and the Senate Democratic leadership, all of whom would like to see Mr. Weicker in retirement. But they may well find themselves in retirement if Connecticut's voters tire of their dawdling.

HEADLINE: Bush Lifted South Africa Sanctions Too Soon

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Bush's decision to lift South African sanctions (front page, July 11) ignores compelling evidence that the South African Government is pursuing a double agenda -- freeing Nelson Mandela, unbanning the anti-apartheid opposition and dismantling much of apartheid's legal structure, but at the same time orchestrating violence against its chief rival, the African National Congress. While Americans want to believe that the South African Government is unequivocally ending apartheid, the following evidence of government-sponsored violence should not have been ignored. 
 Africa Watch, the American human-rights organization, finds that during last year's township conflicts in Natal between the A.N.C. and Inkatha, South African security forces repeatedly joined with Inkatha against the A.N.C., and transported Inkatha vigilantes in police vehicles, standing by while Inkatha attacked, and intervening only to stop A.N.C. supporters from defending themselves. Almost without exception, independent journalists report similar security force support for anti-A.N.C. violence this year in the Transvaal.
Lawyers for Human Rights, a respected South African human-rights group, has documented that former South African military officers are using black surrogates to attack the A.N.C. from the Ciskei homeland in the Eastern Cape. The anti-apartheid newspaper New Nation reports similar activities in the Gazankulu homeland in the far northern Transvaal.
A former South African intelligence officer, Maj. Nico Basson, has described a secret government operation to supply AK-47 submachine guns to Inkatha and to organize attacks on the A.N.C. According to Mr. Basson, South African security forces use black surrogates, such as Inkatha and other vigilante groups, to create the false impression that attacks on the A.N.C. are so-called "black on black violence," rather than planned and coordinated by security forces.
Undercover police have assassinated dozens of anti-apartheid activists, according to a former South African police captain, Dirk Coetzee. The Afrikaans language newspaper Vrye Weekblad printed Mr. Coetzee's allegations that a senior police official, Gen. Lothar Neethling, prepared poisons for government opponents. After General Neethling sued the newspaper for libel, a South African judge pronounced him a liar for denying the allegations and pronounced Mr. Coetzee a truthful witness.
A few months later, a sophisticated letter bomb addressed to Mr. Coetzee exploded and killed a South African human-rights lawyer. Africa Watch has concluded that the evidence fully warrants "findings that death squads have been supported by both the South African police and the South African Defense Force."
President F. W. de Klerk resists an independent investigation of the security forces, preferring that inquiries be supervised by National Party loyalists. Defense Minister Magnus Malan and International Security Minister Adrian Vlok deny that security forces have acted improperly. While rogue units in the South African security establishment could be responsible for anti-A.N.C. violence, it is difficult to believe this occurs without the knowledge of Mr. de Klerk, Mr. Malan or Mr. Vlok.
Among conditions imposed for lifting sanctions by the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act are that the South African Government permit free exercise of political activity and negotiate in good faith for a new constitution. The inaction and defensiveness of South Africa's three most powerful government officials on security force violence raises a serious question about compliance. Can a government that condones security force violence, including death squads, against its chief political opposition be said to permit free exercise of political activity or to negotiate in good faith.
 
STEPHEN B. COHEN
Washington, July 11, 1991
 
The writer, a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for human rights, is a professor at Georgetown University Law Center.

HEADLINE: Bush Lifted South Africa Sanctions Too Soon;
Time to Move On

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"South African Sanctions: Go Slow" (editorial, July 5) asserts that sanctions were a factor, among many others, in stimulating change in South Africa, though not in my view the most important. I believe the efforts of the black people of South Africa and the recent initiatives of President F. W. de Klerk are the foremost reasons for change in South Africa. 
 As a Liberal opposition member of the South African Parliament, who has always opposed apartheid, I have been privileged to be involved in the dramatic changes that have taken place in my country. There can be no doubt that the Government is committed to implementing a democratic system, leaving behind the immoral, outdated, even evil apartheid empire.
Likewise, there can be no doubt that all but one of the five conditions in the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986 for lifting sanctions, have been met. The single outstanding condition (release of all political prisoners) may well be met by the time this letter is published.
This cannot and should not mean that people who have been incarcerated as a result of common law crimes such as murder, rape or robbery should be released.
While I can appreciate your desire to be even-handed and to resolve reasonable doubts about the conditions, I am disappointed that you have suggested a go-slow.
The South African economy is in a perilous state brought on in part by the Congressional sanctions. Unemployment among South Africa's economically active stands at more than 40 percent. Economic growth is at zero, while the population is growing at 2.8 percent. Inflation is more than 15 percent. There is a massive housing shortage and education crisis.
Sanctions have outlived their useful purpose as the change is irreversible, and America should focus attention on assisting South Africa to achieve a growing economy to help particularly those people who were disadvantaged as the result of apartheid.
It may be added that independent opinion polls have indicated that the majority of black people in South Africa are opposed to the continuation of sanctions.
 
LESTER FUCHS
Washington, July 5, 1991

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Balk on I.M.F. Funds

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
A request by the Administration to give $12 billion to the International Monetary Fund has run into trouble in Congress.
What initially appeared to be a routine request for an increase in the money that the I.M.F. has available to lend to countries facing trade problems has become an increasingly partisan issue. Democrats are objecting to the Administration's handling of the request, and they are also unhappy at the I.M.F.'s resistance to making its loans conditional on environmental preservation programs and efforts to alleviate poverty. 
 The House has sent the Senate an appropriations bill that includes no money for the I.M.F. The chairman of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee for Foreign Operations, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said he was reluctant to add the money in the Senate version of the bill because the fund had not done enough to acknowledge a 1989 law requiring the Treasury Secretary to press the I.M.F. to pay more attention to the environment.
"The I.M.F. kind of treats it with an Olympian disregard, that mere mortals at the United States Senate couldn't possibly understand all the decisions they have to make," Mr. Leahy said in an interview. "We mere mortals, however, can't understand why they need all that money."
 
Avoiding the Politics
 The fund itself has stayed out of the political dispute in the United States. An official of the fund who insisted on anonymity pointed out that some previous capital requests by the agency had been addressed through separate legislation rather than in appropriations bills. But other fund officials express concern that the capital increase may not be approved at all.
The Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, and David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, have lobbied Congress on behalf of the bill. "We think it's absolutely critical," particularly because of the I.M.F.'s current program to help Eastern Europe, said a Treasury official who insisted on anonymity.
Political games of chicken also occured the last two times Congress considered increases in the I.M.F.'s capital base, in 1981 and 1983. Democrats ended up supporting the Administration both times, first to help third world countries struggling with high oil prices and then as a response to the third world debt crisis.
 
Concerns Hard to Address
 The Democrats' stated concerns this year are hard for the agency to address.
The I.M.F.'s sister institution, the World Bank, has traditionally lent money for specific projects, particularly for the alleviation of poverty, while the I.M.F. has largely confined itself to dealing with broad national economic policies.
The conditions the fund attaches to aid are designed to promote financial stability and long-term economic growth and typically call for currency devaluations, increased exports, the elimination of subsidies and other cutbacks in government spending. But the conditions can temporarily put many people out of work, wipe out government-run environmental programs and increase the pressure for harvests of timber and other natural resources to export.
The currently proposed increase would raise the agency's base to $180 billion, from $120 billion, with the United States providing a fifth of the increase, a share based largely on the size of the American economy as a fraction of the world's economy.
 
Not Part of Deficit
 The $12 billion United States contribution is not counted directly as part of the Federal budget deficit because it goes into a special Government account from which the I.M.F. may only withdraw money as needed. The I.M.F. also pays interest on any money withdrawn.
But the I.M.F.'s use of this account has resulted in an annual loss in recent years for the United States because of exchange-rate fluctuations. This loss, forecast at $800 million in the coming year, is included in the budget deficit.
Some Democratic lawmakers have been leery of supporting the I.M.F. since 1982, when a Republican group encouraged candidates to accuse Democratic supporters of the I.M.F. of supporting an institution that lends money to Communist countries. The Democratic lawmakers had voted for the money at the request of President Reagan, and insisted on a public letter from the President before backing the next increase in 1983.
Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, Export Financing and Related Programs, asked for a similar letter this year from President Bush but has not received it.
Mr. Obey said that the possibility of the I.M.F.'s request not being granted this year, "doesn't give me an ounce of sweat."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 29, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day last Monday about a proposed United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund referred incorrectly to the effect of exchange-rate fluctuations on past contributions and also to a forecast of the effect this year. Since 1986, the fluctuations have on average produced a surplus, not a loss. The Government has not determined the effect of the fluctuations in 1991.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Weak Quarter Seen at Oil Giants

BYLINE: By Thomas C. Hayes

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
AS big oil companies release earnings reports in the next two weeks, most will post lower profits for the second quarter. Analysts say that despite higher oil prices, compared with the spring quarter of 1990, too many other parts in the long chain of the energy business fared poorly.
 "Most of the major oils will have down quarters," said Bryan Jacoboski, oil analyst at Paine Webber Inc. in New York. "The comparisons are going to be ugly." 
But many analysts see various factors giving oil stocks a lift, relative to the broad market, in the months ahead. The oil industry has underperformed the broader market this year, but many analysts believe that as the recession eases, oil stocks will recover and actually outpace the market as a whole.
 The recession produced a weak quarter for the refining and chemical business. Natural gas prices in the United States, still reeling from an unusually warm winter and huge supplies, plunged by the end of June to the lowest level in more than 15 years: to $1.07 per 1,000 cubic feet in the Gulf of Mexico, the bellwether area.
 And a price war among gasoline marketers in the West, normally the region with the fattest profit margins for gasoline sales, erased most profits in that part of the industry for the main competitors: ARCO, Chevron and Unocal. Analysts said overall operating profits for those companies fell an estimated 50 percent or more in the quarter, excluding special charges from write-offs or gains from asset sales.
 Most analysts agree that only the Exxon Corporation, the largest of the major oil companies, had a higher operating profit for the quarter, compared with a year earlier. Exxon, which reported the highest quarterly profit in its history in the first quarter, has more of its refining and oil business outside the United States, where profit margins were wider in the second quarter.
Oil production generally was the only bright spot for the diversified oil giants in the spring quarter. Prices were a few dollars a barrel higher than in the spring of 1990, averaging more than $20 a barrel. Analysts had expected a global oil glut to develop after the war in the Persian Gulf, and some had predicted that prices would slide to less than $15 a barrel.
 They were wrong, for several reasons. Production in the Soviet Union continued to fall. Iraq's output was limited to 350,000 barrels a day. And Kuwaiti production is not expected to reach its daily quota of 1.5 million barrels before early 1993.
 In the United States, a glut developed in refined petroleum products. Kenneth Miller, senior principal at Purvin & Gertz, refinery consultants in Houston, said demand for gasoline, fuel oil, jet fuel and other refined products fell 2.7 percent in the second quarter, compared with the quarter in 1990, following a 3.5 percent drop in the first quarter.
 Michael L. Mayer, of Wertheim Schroder in San Francisco, estimated that Mobil's earnings slipped to 95 cents a share, from $1.01 in the period a year earlier; that Amoco fell to 70 cents, from 76 cents; that Texaco declined to 95 cents, from $1.26; that ARCO plummeted to $1.35, from $2.33, and that Chevron dropped to 85 cents, from $1.67.
 Analysts expect profits for both the third and fourth quarters to be lower than in 1990 for most of the large oil companies. In 1990, oil prices soared to a peak of $40 a barrel in the futures market in October, and for many companies the price averaged nearly $30. Prices in the last half of 1991 will range between $22 and $24 a barrel, analysts said.
 The outlook for lower oil revenues helped put the brakes on oil stocks through the spring and early summer. Industry stock values lagged gains in the broad market this year, and companies with operations mainly in the United States suffered most.
 The Standard & Poor's index of 400 industrial companies was up 18 percent through Friday, while stocks of the 15 largest energy companies based in the United States rose 5 percent.
 Shares of Exxon and the Mobil Corporation, two big international companies, rose 15 and 17 percent for the year, respectively. The stock of a rejuvenated Texaco Inc. climbed 8 percent. A broader sampling of companies with assets mainly in the United States showed 2 percent gains for the Chevron Corporation and the Phillips Petroleum Company, and gains of 1 percent for Amoco and ARCO.
 As a group, oil stocks showed some life last week, as investors reacted to renewed threats of military action against Iraq by the Bush Administration and some allies. Oil prices rose to the highest level since the gulf war, more than $22 a barrel.
 Some analysts see further gains ahead, saying the fundamentals of excessive supplies, weak prices and lower demand that worked against refining, marketing and chemical units in the first half will improve as the economy improves.
 Frank Knuettel of Prudential Securities in New York noted gasoline demand had picked up, prices in the slumping chemical sector had steadied and natural gas prices were certain to climb as seasonal demand rises after Labor Day.
 Shares of ARCO and Phillips Petroleum will be oil favorites as the recovery takes shape, said George F. Friesen, oil analyst at Deutsche Bank Capital in New York. He expects Phillips to benefit from improved natural gas prices and ARCO from higher gasoline profit margins. His buy recommendations also included Chevron, Mobil, Texaco and Royal Dutch Petroleum.
